subject: [this email was unsent by sender]
body:
This is awkward. Not too long ago, I set out on this journey of sending an email every day for 100 days.

 Aaaand I haven't sent an email in 6 days.

 If I had a good excuse, I'd insert it [here].

 But I don't.

 Let's pretend like that didn't happen and carry on with day 10, okay?

 Okay.

 If you ever want to lose faith in humanity, get an apartment overlooking a busy road. I've witnessed 3 near accidents while pondering where I will take this email.

 My brain is fried from scrolling through tik tok all day. And writing for all of these different offers has confused me.

 I'm so adept at putting myself in a client's shoes and writing to their audience that I've lost touch with my voice.

 I've joked about this before, but I might be starting to develop schizophrenia.

 There are so many things I want to write abou‚Äì YOU NEED TO MAKE MONEY ONLINE, OR YOUR FAMILY HATES YOU, AND YOU'RE A WORTHLESS PIECE OF SCUM.

 Sorry, that was an alternate personality coming out. I didn't mean it.

 I wish no one actually read this thing. Because then I could share what I want without putting on a front.

 But I can't see who's on the other side of the screen. What if it's a potential client? Or someone who looks up to me? An acquaintance? A friend? A family member? (It's not a family member; I manually unsubscribed all of them).

 What if my reality doesn't live up to your inflated perception of me?

 Or maybe it's not inflated? Maybe you think I'm just some idiot kid, sporadically typing illegible sentences to you through the world wide web‚Ä¶

 This was supposed to be a safe space. One where I earn your trust by sharing the good, the bad, and the ugly.

 I want to write like nobody's reading‚Ä¶ maybe I'll keep this one in the archive forever.

 I'll write another email about how I generated a few hundred grand for my clients this week.

 That'll keep the readers happy. How cool, right? I'll tell them about the webinar and how amazing the Black Friday sale went‚Ä¶

 That's the email I'll share‚Ä¶ definitely not this one. 

 So now that it's just you and me, I'm glad we can talk.

 Because on the outside, you may see this 22-year-old kid who's got it figured out. He lives in Miami, has dope friends, makes money, travels, and builds cool shit (and he's insanely fucking handsome).

 But sometimes, on the inside, he feels like everything is crumbling‚Ä¶like he's faking it all‚Ä¶He thinks others are passing him, he'll never figure it out, and he bit off more than he can chew.

 Maybe that's why he hasn't sent an email in 6 days ‚Äì Because he doesn't want them to know what he wants to say.

 Whenever he opens his laptop, he stares at a blinking cursor on a blank screen. He knows what he wants to write when he puts his fingers on the keyboard. But those thoughts vanish to protect this illusion he portrays.

 Now, this is all hypothetical, of course. I don't want you to think I'M saying any of these things. 

 My life is actually perfect. And this journal entry will never actually see the light of day anyway.

 So I guess I'll start to wrap this up. Because I've got to write the email that I'm actually going to send today.

 I'm glad we had this chat, though - just the two of us.

 Just keep doing what you're doing, bro. You're on the right path‚Ä¶ And you know no one really knows what they're doing? They're all just faking it too.

 Think about how far you've come. In another world, you're about to start looking for a $70k-a-year job out of college.

 Be grateful for where you are.

 Good talk.

subject: How to advertise effectively even if you can't spend thousands
body:
Do you try running facebook or instagram ads just to feel like you're lighting your money on fire?

 Well {{ subscriber.first_name }}, you're not alone my friend.

 I have talked to 437 basketball trainers over the past 8 months (yes, I counted). The vast majorities' experience with advertising goes something like this: 

 They try running ads by boosting post or sending traffic directly to their website. 

 They don't set up the pixel and if they do, they don't configure events properly (this allows facebook to track everything).

 They let the campaign run for a few days judging based on link clicks and total impressions to see how the ads performed.

 They are unsure whether or not it helped bring them new business and conclude facebook ads don't work.

 Sound familiar?

 I get it... dealing with the entire set up process, constantly testing new ads, offers, angles and funnels is time consuming and frustrating.

 But with great struggle comes great opportunity. 

 Ya see {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 99% of basketball trainers are not using paid advertising to its' fullest capability.

 And what this does is it creates a huge gap between the 1% that advertise effectively and everyone else, allowing those who do to have MASSIVE success.

 I'm sure you have a handful of competitors in your area and I'm gonna assume you offer a better training service than all of them (you wouldn't be receiving this email if you didn't).

 If you've given up on paid ads, all you're doing is allowing another trainer the opportunity to swoop in and steal clients from you.

 Give your training program the justice it deserves and join the top 1% of trainers who take the time to learn how to advertise effectively.

 Whats that you say? You want to give paid ads another shot?

 Guess what {{ subscriber.first_name }}, it must be your lucky day because I'm opening up a few spots on my calendar for the next week. 

 If you want me to directly walk you through a bulletproof, battle tested, surefire way to run ROI driven Facebook/ Instagram ads, book a call with me here . 

 First come, first serve.

 Chat soon killer,

 Ben

 P.S. - What are you still doing here? Book a call before another trainer beats you to it. ‚Äã

subject: (story time) chasing a crackhead in mexico
body:
Hi {{ subscriber.first_name }}‚Ä¶ remember me?

 You miss me?

 No? Ok well I miss you.

 It‚Äôs month 2 down here in Mexico and right now I‚Äôm sitting outside on the balcony of my 4 story building, overlooking the beautiful city of Playa Del Carmen.

 I accidentally winked at the crackhead across the street and she is now foaming at the mouth while touching herself in places dirtier than the cartel members‚Äô drug money.

 And no, I‚Äôm not fluent in Spanish yet however a nice looking Colombian woman seduced me into taking clases de Espanol.

 I‚Äôve pretty much been in monk mode for the past month or so. 

 If you don‚Äôt know what monk mode is, it‚Äôs when one rids themselves of all dopamine for an extended period of time. 

 So for the last month, I haven‚Äôt been speaking, eating, going outside, smiling, using the bathroom, or sleeping. 

 I take 6 cold showers every day and start each morning with an hour-long prayer to a poster of David Goggins on my wall. 

 I then run 18.3 miles chasing crackheads through the Mexican jungle while listening to ‚ÄúVivir mi Vida‚Äù on repeat.

 Ok sorry, I got kind of carried away there.

 Those past few statements might not be entirely true.

 But I recently restructured the way we do things over here at Hoopr Media and it has been a lot of work.

 I wanted to talk about a topic that‚Äôs been on my mind a lot lately...

 Do you ever feel like the outcome you received did not correlate with the work you put in?

 A few times throughout this past month I felt that exact way.

 It‚Äôs frustrating.

 There‚Äôs a quote in Napoleon Hills‚Äô Think And Grow Rich that helps keep me going in times like this. 

 ‚ÄúEvery failure brings with it the seed of an equivalent success.‚Äù 

 As of late those seeds finally started to sprout for me and I‚Äôm glad I had the patience to see it through.

 I‚Äôve been less emotionally attached to the output of my actions and solely focused on the input.

 You can control what you do every day to move the needle forward.

 In most cases, you cannot directly control how, when, why, and in what order things unfold the way you intend them to.

 It‚Äôs in times of uncertainty that your faith and confidence in yourself are truly tested.

 Will you pass that test?

 Anyway, I have lesson number 2 with my Spanish tutor today. That‚Äôs a test I will pass :)

 Hasta Luego,

 ‚Äã

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: What you can learn from the dentist
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 I'm back.

 Today I've got a great one for you my friend...

 Over the past few weeks I have started working with some academy owners that are absolutely killing it.

 Their gyms are consistently full, their clients pay them handsomely, and they know exactly how much money they have coming in each month, never worrying about chasing down invoices.

 Sounds great doesn't it?

 Well {{ subscriber.first_name }} I'm gonna tell you what separates them from everyone else... and it might now be what you think.

 Odds are they aren't exponentially better than you when it comes to the on court side of the business.

 And honestly I wouldn't be surprised if you went pound for pound with them when it comes to basketball training expertise.

 You might be shaking your head in agreement right now...

 But that's the problem.

 You're only seeing 1 part of the equation.

 Being a good trainer is a pre-requisite for building a successful program.

 Here some all of the other factors that go into it: 

 Equipment/ Facility Organization Communication Professionalism Staff Advertising Systems Company culture Tracking All of the big academy owners are absolutely dialed when it comes to this part of the business.

 Make sense?

 Let me ask you a question...

 Let's say you're choosing between 2 dentists.

 Dentist #1 has an outdated website and takes days to get back to you. Once you finally get ahold of him you schedule a consultation and head to the office. 

 You walk in seeing old rusty equipment, and listen to the surgeon continuously tell stories about how he "would've been the Michael Jordan of cleaning teeth if it weren't for his knee injury in college."

 Dentist #2 has a clean, functional website that allows you to schedule online. You receive a series of text and email reminders leading up to your appointment.

 Once you arrive you're greeted with a smile and brought a cup coffee as you sit down in the waiting room.

 You enter to brand new equipment and images of happy clients on the walls.

 The dentist is completely professional and your consultation goes in a smooth, orderly fashion.

 Which one are you choosing?

 Point made.

 See you in the next one,

 ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }} please join my cult
body:
Hola {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 Long time no talk.

 I write to you from the quiet city of Merida, Mexico.

 I am now fluent in Spanish and have spread my seed among 12 baby mamas‚Äô across the Yucatan Peninsula.

 Adios, America.

 Jokes aside, this is my second to last day in Mexico and I have some big news for you (name).

 I know that says (name) idiot. Let's get into it, {{ subscriber.first_name }}!

 When I first got into online biz, I had this idealistic belief that my time would be spent traveling and meeting cool new friends.

 I quickly learned a lot of nights (especially in the beginning) are spent alone.

 But now I have a network of absolute G‚Äôs that make this whole entrepreneurship thing 10x better.

 I‚Äôve built these relationships through various communities online, Twitter being the main platform.

 The people I used to watch from a far are now some of my closest friends.

 And if you don‚Äôt know, mi amigo Harry and I started a podcast a few months ago called Internet Kids.

 The sole purpose was to have interesting conversations and connect with more people in the online biz world.

 We did just that and people loved it, so we pondered the idea of making clothing and turning it into a brand.

 But unless you‚Äôve been living under a rock or are blind and deaf, you‚Äôve heard about everything that‚Äôs going on with Web 3.

 Getting deeper into this space allowed us the creativity to build something that encompasses all that the Internet Kids brand really stands for.

 We want to create an environment that will allow people to connect with others and build this idealistic lifestyle that many of us have when they get into online business.

 The Internet Kids NFTs will give you access to exclusive clothing, private events (first one in Miami Q1 2022), interactive games that allow you to win SOL, and white girls with parental issues.

 This community will be truly special and I‚Äôd love to see your handsome (or pretty) face inside.

 ‚Äã Join my cult here. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã Now! ‚Äã

 ‚Äã NOWWW!!!!! ‚Äã

 See you in Miami ;)

 - Ben

subject: YOUR EXTENDED WARRANTY
body:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 I was just thinking about you.

 Well, not specifically you (unless you're @cardinalmason) because this is an email list but anyway:

 It's a rainy Saturday down here in South Florida and I'm writing this email as a way to procrastinate going to the gym.

 I just spelled the word "procrastinate" wrong 3 times.

 I've been doing this thing where I sound out words instead of looking them up and it's really started to expand my vocabeloalarry.

 Business is good.

 Contrary to popular belief I'm not running drugs across the Mexican border (though that would be cool). 

 Recently I've been working on detaching my happiness to the amount of money I'm making.

 I was listening to a podcast of my Twitter friend Brodie Kern and something he said really stuck with me.

 "How would you operate differently if you knew the end was secure?"

 I thought about it.

 At 21 years old, I know I'll never have to work a regular job.

 I'll make more money than my former college professors this year.

 And if everything went to shit, I could build a new business and get it to $10k a month in just a few months.

 I don't mean to be cocky but it's really that simple.

 Sometimes I get caught up looking around at my other friends on twitter cruising around my Miami in *supercars,* making 6 figures a month, etc. **Disclaimer: A C8 is not a supercar (Tate Chronicles: 9:9) 

 Don't get me wrong. It's good to keep striving to one up the person you were the day before.

 But don't sacrifice, your happiness, your sanity, nor your peace for after you reach a milestone.

 Because odds are you'll end up getting neither.

 *mic drop*

 I know you missed these sarcastic 349.4 word emails, that always somehow coherently drove home a decent point at the end.

 The truth is I just want your validation so if you liked this email, hit reply and let me know.

 I'll send one lucky winner a half eaten klondike bar and a pack of mango juul pods.

 Alright, time for me to go to the gym.

 Talk soon {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 Ben

 Sent from my Iced Watermelon Puff Bar

subject: Take off your mask {{ subscriber.first_name }}
body:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Are you still listening to them?

 They tell you that you need "this" to be happy.

 That you need "that" to be successful.

 But they don't know YOU {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 You make your own rules.

 You define your own success.

 Stop abiding by their arbitrary metrics of life.

 It is truly your own life.

 No one shares the same lens of the world as you do.

 You are an amalgamation of all of the unique experiences and perspectives you hold.

 Stop robbing the world of your uniqueness.

 What are you hiding?
‚Äã
What part of yourself are you running from?

 Question your beliefs. Question your limitations. Remove the metaphorical box you place on yourself.

 You are whoever you want to be at any given moment.

 {{ subscriber.first_name }} has no boundaries.

 {{ subscriber.first_name }} is limitless.

 Don't let the jaded ideas of others shape your own perspective of YOU.

 Aim to grow.

 Aim to be better than the person you were the day before.

 Carry yourself with confidence and stop second guessing your true desires.

 Do the things you do for yourself and yourself only.

 Make the younger version of yourself proud of the current version you have become.

 And never stop growing...

 ... whatever that means to you {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Thanks for reading my self improvement ramble. I listened to a guided meditation and was feeling inspired.

 I'll go back to spewing nonsensical bullshit into your inbox another day.

 Keep being you,

 -Ben

subject: spinning pizza will make you rich
body:
‚ÄúAny task completed repeatedly for an extended period becomes effortless.‚Äù

 Someone smart said that before.

 It was probably more articulate than I just stated, but the same point nonetheless.

 It‚Äôs simple.

 Do something for a long time, and you‚Äôll get good at it.

 I remember my 11-year-old self watching with pure amusement as the man behind the counter perfectly spun the pizza on his finger. I thought to myself, ‚Äúdamn, I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd ever be able to do that.‚Äù

 Now at age 22, I still can‚Äôt spin a pizza on my finger like my long-lost friend Mario.

 But I guarantee you that if I spent these last 11 years honing my pizza-spinning skills, I‚Äôd be whipping dough around my fingers like nobody‚Äôs business.

 I don‚Äôt actually remember his name but Mario just sounds right.

 Anyway, back to the point.

 I‚Äôm talking about this Kaizen principal because today marks day one of a long journey.

 One hundred days in a row of long-form writing.

 Why?

 Good question. I‚Äôm not sure what I‚Äôm gonna do with this or where I‚Äôll share it. But if you‚Äôre reading this, I guess I figured it out.

 So I guess a hello is appropriate.

 I‚Äôm Ben.

 Right now, I‚Äôm sitting in my overpriced-but-somehow-worth-every-penny Herman Miller Aeron chair.

 It‚Äôs a quiet Thursday night here in my Miami skybox.

 My across-the-sky neighbor is on the couch in his living room playing call of duty again. It‚Äôs become a nightly ritual for us.

 I‚Äôll watch him turn on COD around 8:33 pm and consequently wonder if anyone is watching me and writing about it on the internet.

 He just got a kill.

 I‚Äôm also toggling back and forth between this page and the Thursday night football game.

 I bet on the Falcons, and their deficit seems to increase every time I check. Down 13-0 at the moment.

 I just remembered what I wanted to talk to you about today. This idea came to me in the shower a few hours ago while I was thinking about one of the happiest periods of my life.

 It was around February to May 2021. I‚Äôd finally started making money online. Those first $3k, $5k, and $10k months were unforgettable.

 I was on top of the world. After all this time, I finally proved I could do it.

 But when I think back to those times, most of the highlights aren‚Äôt sexy.

 They‚Äôre the little moments of gratitude. Or the normally mundane mornings that I‚Äôve colored with a nostalgic hue.

 I remember walking on the stair stepper at my college gym, wearing a ripped blue t-shirt, smiling like an idiot while typing away Tweets on the keyboard.

 It was my first $6k month, and I was rich. Not literally, but I would‚Äôve been if wealth were measured in gratitude.

 There‚Äôs a collection of other minuscule moments I won‚Äôt bore you with a story behind, but this idea in and of itself is interesting.

 You probably have this grand vision for where you‚Äôd like to be in 6 months, a year, five years‚Ä¶ but the scenes you imagine now probably won‚Äôt be what you appreciate when you get there.

 You‚Äôll have fond memories of the beautiful blonde in the passenger seat of your Porsche 911, but the one that stands out isn‚Äôt picture-perfect.

 It‚Äôs the late-night fast food run where she spills her frosty on the seat, and you rip the t-shirt off your back to wipe it off before it seeps into the leather.

 It‚Äôs when you drop your potatoes and run out of the grocery store to your desk because you just had an idea that must be acted upon immediately.

 I don‚Äôt know if any of this made sense, but if you‚Äôre still reading this far along we‚Äôre probably on the same page (figuratively).

 It looks like my Call Of Duty-loving neighbor just called it a night and that‚Äôs my sign to do the same.

 Day 1 is down; 99 more to go.

 We‚Äôll chat tomorrow if I don‚Äôt forget.

 - Ben

‚ÄúAny task completed repeatedly for an extended period becomes effortless.‚Äù

 Someone smart said that before.

 It was probably more articulate than I just stated, but the same point nonetheless.

 It‚Äô

subject: Re: Re: Re: couldn't think of subject line
body:
It's day 2 of the next 99.

 I've learned the hardest day when starting any new habit is not day 1.

 It's usually day 2.

 The excitement and naivety fade as you realize you're in it for the long haul.

 I feel like I'm a prisoner writing to my long-lost son, Guilherme. I guess these are my Boron letters.

 Unless you write copy for a living, you probably don't get that reference, but it's okay. You don't need to.

 Today is 11/11/22. Apparently, it's a lucky day.

 After putting my net worth on black at the online roulette table, I beg to differ.

 Kidding.

 Speaking of great ways to waste money, I dropped out of college in January 2021. 

 Twenty-two months later, my life looks a lot different.

 I've made a few hundred grand and generated a lot more for my clients by clicking buttons on the internet.

 Now I'm living in Miami with a circle of brothers that make me feel poor.

 One principle I can think of has been pivotal in my success.

 I'm trying not to sound like one of those dorks from Twitter who tells you to drink water and stop jerking your chicken.

 Hear me out.

 Delusional self-belief is the best trait you can adopt.

 You truly are the person you believe you are. Nearly everything can be trained and improved.

 If you don't like the person you see when you look at yourself in the mirror, you have all the power to do something about it.

 Having an unwavering sense of self will give you the confidence to take more risks. To burn the boats. And to be resilient.

 If there's one thing you do from reading this email, let it be this:

 Take out a piece of paper and describe in detail the person you want to be.

 What does he or she look like? What are their habits? How would their friends describe them?

 List out their character traits, the type of clothes they wear, and so on. This can be the "you" six months or six years from now. There's no right or wrong way to do this as long as you're detailed.

 Once that person is established, it's time to take the baton.

 Carry yourself the way that ideal version carries themself. Talk the way they talk. Think the way they think.

 Understand that nothing happens in the future. If you want to change, that change must happen NOW; this is how you do it.

 This is how you change your life.

 Aren't you glad you subscribed to this instead of some random girls only fans?

 Listen.

 This is how you reinvent yourself.

 It sounds corny, and it kind of is.

 But I went from basketball player to frat star, to idiot business owner, to less idiot business owner. And it's all because I chose the person I wanted to be and assumed that identity.

 Your reality is a conscious decision.

 You decide to put yourself in a box.

 You decide to let circumstances affect you.

 And you decide the lifestyle you live.

 Unsubscribe from the beliefs that no longer serve you.

 And unsubscribe from your exes only fans.

 ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

subject: thoughts on fat people
body:
I‚Äôve been staring at this blank screen for about 6 minutes and 24 seconds now.

 It‚Äôs 8:04 pm in Brickell, and I‚Äôm watching fireworks from my balcony. All of the buildings are lit up. My across-the-sky neighbor is enjoying the show with his girl.

 It‚Äôs not the COD-playing neighbor I wrote about in 001. I don‚Äôt think he has many friends. The dude on the floor above him is my homie, Clarence.

 We‚Äôve never spoken, but he looks like his name is Clarence.

 We wave to each other while drinking morning coffee on our parallel balconies.

 I think he‚Äôs in ecom because he works on his laptop and I saw him taking product pics one time.

 Anyway, I wish you guys could see the view right now.

 I‚Äôd take a picture for you, but ‚Äúsome moments are best kept as memories.‚Äù

 A girl told me that while we were drinking wine on the beach looking up at the stars.

 I‚Äôm not sure if it was profound or if I just wanted to smash. She had pretty eyes.

 It‚Äôs a Saturday night and I‚Äôm leaning toward staying in.

 Many of my favorite nights are spent at my laptop with a ninety-dollar Diptyque candle on my desk. I‚Äôm either planning a road to $100 mil or gambling away my life savings at the roulette table. Never an in-between.

 Life‚Äôs too short to half-ass anything. But most people half-ass the entire thing.

 It‚Äôs easy to do when you were raised like me. Good family and never had to stress about food on the table, or bills being paid.

 Sounds like a pretty good upbringing, no?

 It is, but often times it leads to a mediocre life.

 Everything is too convenient. It‚Äôs easy to get a decent job and climb the corporate ladder.

 Why push for more?

 Just play it safe and you‚Äôll never have to struggle.

 Easy times create weak men and weak men cut off their balls and dye their hair pink‚Ä¶ or however the saying goes.

 To me, the most miserable existence of all is one where you never push all your chips to the middle.

 You never get to find out what you‚Äôre capable of when your back is against the wall.

 I‚Äôd rather lose everything than never try.

 You test yourself as a man. And like a sword, you come through the fire sharper than you were before.

 Run towards the things that scare you. The more resistance you feel, the more it means you need to do it.

 Unless you‚Äôre scared of fat bitches because I am too and I‚Äôm RUNNING away like the wind.

 I got stuck walking behind one today for 22.4 seconds. The longest 22.4 seconds of my life.

 This email just took a turn and if I keep going down this route I might end up in handcuffs.

 I‚Äôll leave you with a quote from a movie that changed my life, Fight Club. eye-roll 

 ‚ÄúI see in fight club the strongest and smartest men who‚Äôve ever lived. I see all this potential, and I see squandering. God damn it, an entire generation pumping gas, waiting tables; slaves with white collars. Advertising has us chasing cars and clothes, working jobs we hate so we can buy s**t we don‚Äôt need. We‚Äôre the middle children of history, man. No purpose or place. We have no Great War. No Great Depression. Our Great War‚Äôs a spiritual war‚Ä¶ our Great Depression is our lives. We‚Äôve all been raised on television to believe that one day we‚Äôd all be millionaires, and movie gods, and rock stars. But we won‚Äôt. And we‚Äôre slowly learning that fact. And we‚Äôre very, very pissed off.‚Äù

 Thanks for reading today‚Äôs scatterbrained rant.

 Chat tomorrow fellow space monkey,

 Ben

subject: How to build the next Facebook
body:
Do you remember when Sundays felt like Sundays?

 I'd dread going to sleep because I knew at 6:55 am the generic apple sound, "Chimes," would start blaring. That sound gives me PTSD to this day.

 Roll out of bed. Brush my teeth. Eat a soggy Jimmy Dean sandwich. And get in the car for school.

 "Fuck. I have a science test second period." I'd frantically remember.

 It was one of those classes where I couldn't even tell you what the test was about. 

 I was just hoping that the Asian girl to my right would write big enough so I could copy her again. She got me an 84 on the last one. I think her name is Sarah, but I'm not sure.

 That's how it went for all four years of high school.

 The week was spent looking forward to the weekend, and the weekend was spent dreading the following week.

 That's where I grew such a strong aversion to living on someone else's clock and taking orders.

 "Can I go to the bathroom? Turns into "Can I get a week off?"

 No. Thank. You.

 I prefer to be in control of my own urination cycle and time.

 Switching gears, I just did my laundry, and it gave me an idea.

 "Partimegirlfriend.com"

 How cool would that be?

 You log in to an online portal, pick the one you want and click confirm.

 Seven seconds later, Jenny spawns from thin air, eager to do the dishes and fold your clothes.

 You can take her out to dinner, go on put-put dates, or even introduce her to your Grandma.

 But when you want to be alone, you just click a button, and she vanishes.

 It's basically Closify but for companionship.

 You get all the benefits of having a girlfriend without the responsibility; A true win-win.

 And no, it's not the same as ordering a hooker. She does it out of love, and you take care of her.

 I wonder if this is how Zuckerberg felt when he got the idea for Facebook.

 Anyway, I sat in the sun for a while today, and it made me sleepy.

 Half of my body was in the shade, and now I look like the dude from Batman when he gets his face burned off.

 I'm gonna go to bed and hope that when I wake up tomorrow, it somehow evens out.

 Have a great week,

 Ben

 P.S. If you read this whole thing, could you reply real quick and let me know? Trying to see something.

subject: this guru scammed my friend
body:
I read the book "Relentless" by Tim Grover during my freshman year of high school.

 He was the trainer of Michael Jordan and a handful of other superstar athletes.

 Quick side note - I raced MJ off a red light in Jupiter, FL. I was in a Honda Civic. He was in a yellow Ferrari Pista. Safe to say I didn't win.

 Ok, back to the story.

 A lot of the book is just motivation porn, but for a 13-year-old with big dreams, it was my bible.

 In retrospect, one of the book's last lines made a lasting impact on me.

 "Every dream you imagine, everything you see and hear and feel in your sleep, that's not a fantasy, that's your deep instinct telling you it can be all real. Follow those visions and dreams and desires and believe what you know. Only you can turn those dreams into reality. Never stop until you do."

 Gives me the chills to this day.

 When you ask a 9-year-old kid what they want to be when they grow up, they don't say investment banker. They don't say accountant. They don't say waiter. They don't say only fans model.

 But 12 years later, whatever goals they had have been beaten out of them.

 Makes me sad just talking about it, so I'm changing the topic.

 Today I learned that one of my (formerly) favorite gurus is kind of a scammer.

 Not a full scammer‚Ä¶ he didn't hire an army of college kids to hand out fake parking tickets, set up a "website" where people go to pay, steal their card info and sell it on the black market.

 I had that idea after I got a parking ticket once. It's genius.

 Anyway, I watched this guy's Youtube videos in college and took a full 2-3 pages worth of notes on each video.

 I planned on going to his live events and maybe investing in his coaching one day.

 And today, I found out he sucks at his job.

 Want me to tell you who?

 You're probably on the edge of your seat right now.

 Let me tell you how I learned this. 

 I was talking to a guy today who has over 450k followers on tik tok. He's in the dating niche, his content is good, and anyone in that position should be able to make AT LEAST $20k a month.

 Like bare minimum. Seriously.

 He's working with [redacted], who told him to make an 8-week coaching program and sell it entirely through the DM's. No sales calls.

 The course is only $300 and this poor guy is lucky when he gets more than 2 sales a month.

 Here's the worst part‚Ä¶

 [redacted] is charging him $2,500 a month for CONSULTING.

 The anonymous brain-dead monkey accounts on Twitter could help this guy more than [redacted] is.

 U N R E A L

 If you're still reading, reply with a guess of who you think the guru is, and I'll tell you if you're right or wrong.

 My eyes are getting tired and you're probably tired of reading the word [redacted] so I think we should end this.

 I have to sneeze.

 Much love,

 Ben

subject: 10pm in Brickell
body:
It‚Äôs 9:55 pm here in Brickell, and it‚Äôs one of those days where it‚Äôs a struggle to even get a sentence out on here.

 I legit had to rewrite that first line 8 times.

 This would be much easier in person because of days like this. I could just ask you a question and nod my head as if I‚Äôm listening.

 In college, I got pretty good at appearing interested in what people are saying without actually listening.

 After all, it‚Äôd make anyone go crazy listening to 26 variations of the same blonde girl explaining crystals and star signs.

 ‚ÄúYes Jessica, I get it. When Sagittarius rises, the sun goes into retrosynthesis.‚Äù

 Imagine getting that same lecture every day.

 I had to tune it out for my own sanity.

 Over the past few days, I‚Äôve started to notice how everything in my life is connected.

 When I‚Äôm consistent in the gym, I get more work done. When I write to you people, sad voice goes away.

 Action = Happy Ben.

 I‚Äôm envious of people that are able to have a horrible routine and still be incredibly productive.

 One of my friends embodies this to its core. I don‚Äôt want to name names, so we‚Äôll call him ‚ÄúEagle Jason.‚Äù

 Jason wakes up whenever he wants and scrolls on tik tok for an hour while puffing on his 4 pink puff-berry vapes.

 He rolls out of bed to go downstairs and get the venti skinny vanilla latte he just ordered on uber eats.

 Then he gets out his laptop and refreshes stripe. He‚Äôs already made more money today than most people will all month.

 Cardin‚Äì I mean, Eagle Jason is your anti-guru. The kid can do everything ‚Äúwrong‚Äù and still operate at a level that most people can‚Äôt reach without a copious amount of stimulants.

 I learned 2 new things today.

 The word ‚Äúvapious.‚Äù The geographical layout of America. I realized I had very little understanding of which state was which, so I started taking this online quiz.

 It gives you the name of a state, and you click the according location on the map.

 This little ‚Äúding‚Äù would sound when you got the answer correct, and that sound quickly became addicting.

 2 hours later, I got 50/50 and started timing myself on how quickly I could complete it.

 I knew my friend Mason (crazy how close his name is to Jason, lol) would appreciate this tedious little game.

 So, I sent him the link, and about an hour later, we were racing each other to see who could complete the map quicker.

 This consumed my entire afternoon.

 My high score was 1 minute 24 seconds, and Mason‚Äôs was 1 minute 11 seconds. Kids got fucking speed.

 ‚Äã Here‚Äôs the link if you‚Äôre also an autistic monkey that‚Äôs entertained by the simplest things.

 Listen to the song ‚ÄúFortunate Son‚Äù by CCR for added effect.

 God bless America,

 Ben

subject: Weird way to make money (fire & hammers)
body:
It‚Äôs day 7 of 100.

 I‚Äôm gonna be honest - I do not wanna be writing this right now, so if it‚Äôs a little grim, bear with me.

 I had to look up the correct usage of ‚Äúbear‚Äù or ‚Äúbare‚Äù for the sentence above. Apparently, the latter means ‚Äúto reveal‚Äù

 It‚Äôs 10:36 pm, and I spent the last 22 minutes watching a Corvette C8 review on Youtube.

 My dopamine receptors get really fucked up every Wednesday because I watch my friend/client make an absurd amount of money in about an hour and a half on our weekly webinar.

 After the high of seeing the money come in so quickly, there‚Äôs this looming sense of emptiness afterward.

 Money is interesting.

 It‚Äôs not going to solve all of your problems.

 But it‚Äôs a problem that needs to be solved.

 And as you solve the money problem, your other problems will be solved.

 I know it sounds like I‚Äôm a homeless man babbling riddles to his imaginary best friend, so let me explain.

 In most cases, you have to become a very capable person to make a lot of money.

 A person that‚Äôs capable of critical thinking, showing poise under pressure, leading a team, etc.

 The type of person with the qualities I mentioned above is disciplined and rational, but valiant.

 See where this is going yet?

 Many qualities people lack before making money are earned in the process of making money.

 I don‚Äôt know if this is high-level insight or if I‚Äôm just really tired, so it sounds good, but I‚Äôm going to keep running with it.

 This is why the crypto dorks or lottery winners will end up doing some dumb shit and lose their money.

 I might‚Äôve made this analogy a few emails ago, but it applies here, too, so forgive me:

 When you heat a sword in fire, it becomes malleable. Then you beat it with a hammer over and over, and eventually, its impurities are gone‚Ä¶ Creating a much sharper than it was before.

 The moral of the story - burn lottery winners and crypto dorks and beat them with hammers.

 I‚Äôm tired.

 Goodnight.

 ( I know it‚Äôs not nighttime when you receive this email, so good morning or good afternoon too)

 Ben

subject: srry
body:
Welp.

 Maybe you noticed, maybe you didn‚Äôt.

 But yesterday, a kid somewhere woke up and ran downstairs ecstatic to open his presents, only to find nothing sitting under the Christmas tree.

 Only this newsletter is the present, and you‚Äôre the kid looking under the tree.

 If you didn‚Äôt notice, I didn‚Äôt email you yesterday.

 I have a good excuse so hear me out, okay?

 Yesterday was a busy one. I had to write 4 emails, an entire sales page, and send a cold DM.

 After all that, I was left with only 3 or 4 hours to spare.

 You might be thinking, ‚Äúisn‚Äôt that enough time to write a 400-word email?‚Äù

 Great question. And yes, it is.

 BUT here‚Äôs what happened. I decided to put a small $300 live bet on the Miami Heat to beat the Washington Wizards.

 After that didn‚Äôt hit, I went to the virtual roulette table to recoup my ‚Äúinvestment,‚Äù where I found myself in a $1,500 hole.

 Now, if there‚Äôs one thing you know about me, it‚Äôs that I‚Äôm not a quitter. 

 I dug myself all the way out of that hole and only ended down $400 on the day.

 As a celebration, I smoked a joint for the first time in a few months, and there was zero chance I was sitting down to write a coherent sentence after that.

 We‚Äôre back today, so thanks for your patience.

 It‚Äôs interesting how everyone has a story that they tell the world and another story that‚Äôs the real truth.

 I decided to commit to 100 days of writing long-form emails because I wanted to become a better writer‚Ä¶

 Kinda. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôll tell you if you ask.

 But truly, I‚Äôm doing this for a few reasons.

 The first is discipline. If I can‚Äôt commit to sitting at my desk for 30 minutes a day and hitting random letters on my keyboard, I have bigger problems.

 The final reason (and the actual one behind the two cover-ups I just gave you) is to use this as an outlet to vent.

 If I go a while without pausing to check in with myself, I start to go crazy.

 My goal here is to break down the wall between who I present myself as to the world and what really goes on inside my head.

 But even now, I‚Äôm debating saying what I know is true vs what I want you to think.

 This is quite vague and scattered, and I assume I‚Äôve lost most of you, so if you‚Äôre still with me I hope this made some sense.

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 Only th

subject: lesson from old guy
body:
One of the greatest writers of all time, Mark Twain, once said, ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt have anything nice to say, don‚Äôt say anything at all‚Ä¶

 ‚Ä¶ but if you don‚Äôt have anything nice to write, keep writing until you do.‚Äù

 Right now, I have nothing to write.

 Also, Mark Twain never actually said that.

 I‚Äôve noticed that a lot of my best work starts out this way.

 I don‚Äôt really know where I‚Äôm going with an idea, but if I just put my fingers to the keyboard long enough, something will work.

 This can serve as a metaphor for life.

 Whenever you start something new, you don‚Äôt really know what‚Äôs gonna come of it.

 You might have a vague idea in your head of the route that you want to take, but that route is usually altered.

 ‚ÄúThe best-laid plans of Mice and Man often go awry.‚Äù That‚Äôs a real quote from one of the few books I read in high school.

 It basically means that no matter how detailed, meticulous, orderly, (or whatever other fancy adjective you want to put in there), you cannot possibly predict the outcome.

 Accidents will happen. 

 Shit will go South.

 ‚ÄúProblems‚Äù will turn into solutions and vice versa.Some of the biggest mistakes you‚Äôll make will force you to learn something that ends up serving you in the future.

 Thinking back on the path I‚Äôve taken to get to where I‚Äôm at now, the plans have changed A LOT.

 At first, I wanted to be a videographer, then do ecom, then high ticket sales‚Ä¶ all of which I thought were going to be my long-term play.

 Then after finding success working with basketball trainers, I was positive that‚Äôd be an industry I‚Äôd dominate for years.

 And now I‚Äôm doing something completely different.

 The irony here is the fact that you need a plan if you want any shot at achieving a goal.

 Making true progress in any endeavor requires a plan. Otherwise, the pursuit of the goal cannot be measured.

 Ok, I‚Äôm tired of sitting at my desk.

 Talk tomorrow friend,

 Ben

subject: I'm back with the milk hahahaha
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 It‚Äôs been a super productive morning. I‚Äôve gotten almost everything on my to-do list done already, and it‚Äôs only 10:15 am.

 Who knew how much you could accomplish when you just sit down and work?

 I‚Äôd been meditating naked while praying to my David Goggins poster for the last 2 years, thinking THAT would make me a millionaire.

 Oh well, better later than never.

 Wait, why are you looking at me like I impregnated your Grandma?

 Do I have something on my fa‚Äì OHHH, you‚Äôre mad that I haven‚Äôt emailed you in months after telling you that I was gonna email you for 100 days straight.

 Aaaand to make it worse, I‚Äôm carrying on like nothing ever happened. Talk about an elephant in the room.

 This is probably how girlfriends feel when you do something they don‚Äôt like, but they don‚Äôt wanna tell you what it was.

 You know somethings wrong, and you keep asking her, ‚Äúbb, what‚Äôs wrong‚Äù and she says, ‚Äúnothinngggg‚Äù but the tone gets angrier every time you ask.

 And then, FINALLY she cracks and tells you what‚Äôs pissing her off.

 Turns out she‚Äôs mad that you got her whole milk instead of oat milk in her iced latte‚Ä¶ Yup, been there too man.

 Ok, sorry I'm deflecting.

 You see, what really happened is I‚Äôve accidentally been sending to the wrong segment. So we‚Äôre actually on day 74 of the 100-day email challenge, and you just haven‚Äôt been getting the emails! Haha!

 Ok, you‚Äôre right that‚Äôs BS. Stop looking at me like that‚Ä¶ FINE! I committed to writing an email every day for 100 days, and I quit on day 9. I said it. Happy now?

 A lot has changed since we last spoke.

 First and most importantly, I got a Nespresso machine. I‚Äôm actually sitting on my balcony with a burnt tongue, still managing to sip down this latte.

 Second, I bought a toy.

 It‚Äôs black and german (pause).

 Yes, I‚Äôm talking about an Audi RS5. And don‚Äôt forget the R or the S. Because that means racing sport. And it signifies that I‚Äôm better than all the other wagie cucks that drive around in A5s or S5s.

 I didn‚Äôt really post it on Twitter (like everyone else when they get their first nice car) because I wanted to feel like I was better than everyone.

 It sounds cooler to buy it and keep it private, right? Like, oh, not a big deal at all that I spent more money on a hunk of metal than what I would‚Äôve made annually with a job out of college.

 Not that that‚Äôs super impressive‚Ä¶ I imagine most Communications majors from the College of Charleston end up dying their hair pink and making frappuccinos' for a living.

 I‚Äôm buying another toy today too, actually. It‚Äôs a lot smaller and about 1/5th the price.

 I‚Äôll show you tomorrow on the rare chance that I actually send another email this quarter.

 Anyone wanna take a side bet? Live odds for me sending an email tomorrow are about +800.

 But hey, if you read all the way to here, hit reply and let me know. I thrive off validation from strangers behind a screen, and if enough of you [redacted] reply, maybe I‚Äôll keep this train going.

 GREAT catching up with you {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Talk tomorrow for +800 :)

 Ben

subject: I'm dropping a course to scam ppl
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 It‚Äôs 11:51 pm, and my eyes are getting heavy.

 I‚Äôve been sitting here for the last 24 minutes scrolling through Twitter and Instagram to avoid writing this.

 It‚Äôs been a looooong day.

 You know that feeling when your mind is occupied all day‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre in and out of calls, moving from one task to another, scrolling through thirst traps on tik tok, etc.

 And then, finally, after you‚Äôre done with everything, you can turn off the noise and exhale.

 Finally, some quality time alone. 

 Quick side note - I started using Grammarly to increase my writing speed, and it‚Äôs just slowed me down.

 Every time I see that goddamn red line I have to fix it, and then I lose my train of thought.

 It also just randomly tells me to add commas, in parts, of sentences, that, don‚Äôt need, a comma.

 That was probably hard to read.

 I hope you guys didn‚Äôt get suckered into those 800-1 odds I gave you on me writing an email the other day lmao.

 That's a bet I know I would‚Äôve taken.

 After working with so many info-product and coaching gurus I‚Äôve decided that I‚Äôm gonna start selling something to you guys eventually.

 Not because I want to impact the world or share knowledge and help people succeed. But because I want your money.

 All of these people that you see online are making a FUCK TON of money, and I‚Äôm only getting % of it.

 I want the whole pie.

 So I decided that I‚Äôm gonna start taking this newsletter more seriously and sell you some bullshit Dan Koe/ Dickie Bush style writing course.

 Not to hate on either of them because they‚Äôre both great. And they‚Äôre really good at organizing notions.

 Anyway, I worked with a guy recently who had a really hot assistant. It was clear she was only on the team because she was hot, but boy was that a great idea.

 When you‚Äôre in the presence of an attractive female, everyone brings their A-Game. And it‚Äôs completely sub-conscious.

 And just imagine being a client trying to fire me, and some bimbo barbie gets on the call and says, ‚Äúnoooo don‚Äôt go, John. I know we spent $104,000 last month and we only made you $2,400 back, but think about all the fun we‚Äôve had. We‚Äôre meant to be.‚Äù

 The original ‚Äúclient retention hack.‚Äù Not that any of your favorite Twitter dorks keep clients for longer than a few months anyway.

 Oh yeah, back to my writing course.

 I think the first module will be able how to write concisely, and never get sidetracked. Because CLEARLY, I‚Äôm very good at that.

 Also Mason, if you‚Äôre reading this, don‚Äôt worry. It‚Äôs not gonna compete with Copy MBA (it‚Äôs gonna be way better).

 But you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}, should go click that link and buy it because I get a %.

 Didn‚Äôt think this email would turn into a promo for one of my friends' courses, but here we are.

 On that note, time for me to ask chat GPT to tuck me in and read me a bedtime story because I‚Äôm calling it a night.

 Live odds I email you tomorrow are +1100. Reply to put in your bet.

 Night,

 Ben

subject: i got you breakfast {{ subscriber.first_name }}
body:
It‚Äôs 10:11 am, and I just sat down inside my favorite coffee spot in Miami.

 The sweet lady who takes my order every day seemed kind of sad, so I bought her an iced latte.

 I wasn‚Äôt planning on writing an email to you right now, but it‚Äôs a good excuse to postpone my long list of to-dos for the day.

 There‚Äôs a couple to my left, and this woman literally spent 4 minutes taking pictures of her acai bowl before she started eating it.

 I know it was 4 minutes because I‚Äôve been staring at my screen for the same amount of time, trying to decide where to take this email.

 Yesterday I posted an Instagram pic, and someone commented, ‚Äúneed to obtain this lifestyle.‚Äù

 It‚Äôs interesting how that works. Remember when you were chasing what you have right now?

 But now it just feels so normal‚Ä¶ there was no mystical point of arrival.

 Before I turn this into some corny ‚Äúbe grateful‚Äù type email, the couple next to me got like 4 different entrees, and shorty just got up to order more.

 Breakfast is a scam. Anyone that claims to be hungry before noon literally just has no self-control. They‚Äôre just bored and would rather get up and waddle to the local woofery rather than do anything productive with their lives.

 If you‚Äôre reading this while taking a bite of your warm little pancake breakfast at 11 am, spit it out. And unsubscribe. You‚Äôre not welcome here.

 You can have coffee before noon. That‚Äôs it.

 Seriously fasting will help your focus so much. We‚Äôve all been psyop‚Äôd by big breakfast into believing that breakfast is the most important meal of the day, and it‚Äôs simply not true.

 I think fat people should have to pay extra taxes too.

 Oh my god, this bitch to my left is taking more pictures of their FIFTH entree.

 Sorry, I‚Äôm gonna kill someone.

 Imagine one day I‚Äôm running some really big public company, and someone just screenshots the last few lines of this email.

 [CEO says, ‚Äúfat people should pay extra taxes.‚Äù] What a headline.

 Ok, I‚Äôve gotta get to work. I know this was schizo as fuck, so hopefully, I at least made you giggle on this beautiful Monday morning.

 Have a great day (unless you ate breakfast),

 Ben

subject: the most important questions of your life
body:
Good morning {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 Have you ever wondered why there‚Äôs a space between good and morning but no space in goodnight?

 Me too.

 Just another piece of mind-controlling government propaganda we‚Äôve all been sold (lol).

 If I see one more person using ‚Äúthe matrix is attacking‚Äù angle to sell some bullshit course, I think I‚Äôm gonna implode.

 ‚ÄúThe economy is collapsing! Your job doesn‚Äôt care about you! The government is trying to kill you‚Ä¶

 Aaaand if you want to protect yourself from these things, you need to build a social circle! Pick up my program, How to stop being a bubble-blowing clown-loving burger-flipping idiot loser, today.‚Äù

 Moving on‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôve been thinking about how all stages of our lives eventually become mostly-happy memories.

 Even the darker stages.

 When I look back on times when I was super stressed out or down bad, it‚Äôs with nothing but gratitude.

 The word gratitude has become so corny, but I can‚Äôt think of a synonym, so you‚Äôre gonna have to bear with me.

 The things that once brought me turbulence all seem so minuscule now.

 I encourage you to audit your life as well.

 Most people just sleepwalk through this whole thing.

 Pause to analyze the things that you‚Äôre stressing about and understand that all things are temporary. Good or bad.

 You‚Äôll probably look back at this period in your life with amusement for the person you once were and appreciation for who you‚Äôve become.

 I‚Äôm doing this right now.

 A few moments ago, I had to google whether it was ‚Äúbare with me‚Äù or ‚Äúbear with me.‚Äù

 Apparently, it was the latter.

 Now I know‚Ä¶ silly old me.

 Speaking of silliness‚Ä¶

 A handful of my friends around my same age have gotten married, and some even popped out a kid or two.

 In no way am I hating on them, but this is just an absolute mindfuck to me.

 Like how are you possibly mature enough to know you want to spend the rest of your life with a 20ish-year-old girl?

 What if she gets a wrinkle? Or clogs your toilet? Or even worse‚Ä¶ you discover she likes pineapple on her pizza???

 Maybe I‚Äôm missing something, but these are all dealbreakers for me.

 And I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm anywhere close enough to figuring out this life thing the way I‚Äôd want to in order to feel ready to share a bed with someone for the rest of time.

 I could be immature. Idk man.

 If you‚Äôre still here, hit reply and lmk what you think. How does one decide they‚Äôre ready to get married and have kids?

 And if girls don‚Äôt poop, why do they spend so much time in the bathroom?

 The world may never know.

 See ya,

 Ben

subject: get high with Jordan Peterson
body:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 Happy Monday.

 Yesterday I figured out how to add an auto-plug tweet that drops my newsletter link and got a bunch of new subscribers.

 So if you‚Äôre new here, welcome {{ subscriber.first_name }}. Pleasure to have you.

 I‚Äôll fill you in real quick.

 On November 10th, 2022, I set out to write a daily email to my subscribers for 100 days straight.

 Today marks day 116 in a row.

 Crazy right?

 I‚Äôve written an email every day for the last 116 days, which is even more than I originally set out to do. You should feel horrible about yourself.

 Only the thing is, today is day 14.

 I took a long hiatus after day 9 and have been writing a few emails a week for the last week or so. Consider me your fun uncle. Sometimes I disappear for while but when I'm around it's a great time.

 Now that you‚Äôre all caught up let‚Äôs get down to business‚Ä¶

 In college, I used to take chops a few nights a week.

 If you don‚Äôt know what a chop is, it‚Äôs when you put weed and tobacco in a bong and clear it in one hit.

 It‚Äôs the craziest head rush a few dollars worth of weed and a fifth of a light blue American Spirit can buy.

 The thing about chops is they‚Äôre not entirely pleasant.

 You usually start spinning and feel like you‚Äôre gonna throw up. Or you end up drooling all over yourself.

 But if you can get over that phase, the buzz is completely and utterly unmatched.

 Imagine all of the lights in your brain just shutting off for a fleeting moment. It‚Äôs like you transport into the mind of a 20-year-old blonde sorority girl.

 I‚Äôm telling you this because chops offer a perfect analogy for life.

 The lows allow you to appreciate the highs (literally).

 Look at child celebrities and kids that made it big in crypto.

 Most of them go insane because they were handed everything too quickly. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs fun at the beginning, where you‚Äôre just able to fuck off for a bit.

 But what happens when that kind of stuff gets old?

 Surely nothing can give you the same kind of dopamine high that you get when you turn $1,000 into $10m on some meme coin of a dog.

 Right?

 Maybe I‚Äôm just jealous.

 Anyway, I gotta go scam little kids on the internet.

 Hit reply if you‚Äôre new here, and tell me your favorite color or something.

 Talk soon,

 Ben

subject: don't open
body:
It‚Äôs 12:21am in Brickell and I feel like a fool.

 Business is good. Deals are happening like crazy, should be another record month, have a clear path to $100k per month.

 But that‚Äôs not why we‚Äôre here. All that stuff is silly in the end.

 Life is meant to be lived. It‚Äôs the most beautiful gift any of us will ever get. But most of us miss all of it.

 Including the entrepreneurs and the people that ‚Äúescape the rat race.‚Äù

 We make our own rat race.

 We‚Äôre constantly chasing the next arbitrary number that doesn‚Äôt mean anything in the end.

 I was in the shower thinking about what I‚Äôd do if someone gave me $100m today.

 The thought of that scares me.

 It‚Äôll scare you too if you pause and think about it. Right now you occupy your time with stuff that you pretend matters so you live a life that doesn‚Äôt feel pointless.

 But,

 What you stress about is meaningless.

 And so is anything you accomplish.

 Here's why:

 Let‚Äôs say you solve the money problem.

 You wake up tomorrow, refresh your banking app, and 100 million dollars are in your savings account.

 You now have the biggest problem you‚Äôve ever had in your entire life.

 You have to figure out what you really want.

 I‚Äôm writing to you because my 3 year old dog, Tucker got diagnosed with a kidney disease today and he has around a year to live.

 This all made me think about how everyones clock is ticking. One day, everyone I love and everyone you love will be gone.

 As bad as it sounds, imagine if that‚Äôs one of your (human) family members.

 Everything you‚Äôre working on or stressing about, all becomes white noise.

 And now you feel like an idiot for neglecting some relationships in order to get the next dopamine hit.

 If we spend all our time chasing these numbers on a screen‚Ä¶

 We‚Äôll miss the entire time that the people (and dogs) we loved were here.

 Which is the point of it all.

 When my loved ones die, I don't want to feel like I left anything on the table...

 If you‚Äôre still reading I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôve joined me for todays spiritual enlightenment. I swear I‚Äôm usually not this doom and gloom.

 Normally I'll just write some funny schizophrenic email and then forget I have an email list for a few weeks. 

 This was actually just gonna be a journal to myself, never to be published on the world-wide web.

 But for some reason I half-way want to share it so I'm scheduling it to send at 1:04am so no one reads it.

 Including you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Goodnight‚Ä¶ love you no homo,

 Ben

subject: i'm still alive
body:
I missed you {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 A lot has changed since we last spoke.

 For starters I rearranged my desk, got a new rug, started drinking black coffee, and had a baby.

 One of the things in the sentence may not be true and I'll leave it to you to discern which one.

 I‚Äôve been trying to be more in tune with the voice in the back of my head that never shuts up and it‚Äôs been telling me to make more content.

 So that‚Äôs why we‚Äôre here.

 One thing I miss about being in a college town and not knowing as many people in the online marketing space is that it was easier to make my own decisions.

 You have far fewer inputs from various people,

 It‚Äôs just you and your gut instinct.

 A couple years ago, my gut instinct told me to build a marketing agency working with basketball trainers.

 In hindsight it was a dumb decision.

 Most of them didn‚Äôt have much money and it was hard to get results for them.

 But that ‚Äúfuck up‚Äù equipped me with the tools to build my next business to over $50k a month.

 When you listen to others and are always trying to make the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù decision it robs you of the lessons you may have learned by following your intuition and having to take a longer route.

 It‚Äôs almost as if you know deep down the route that you‚Äôre supposed to be on in order to become the type of person that you‚Äôre destined to be.

 And the thing is, that route is not the smooth one.

 It‚Äôs bumpy, there‚Äôs ups, there‚Äôs downs, and every now and then you hit a tree and run over a fat person.

 Figuratively 

 I originally got into this space because I wanted to be a content creator.

 There were a dozen people I looked up to on social media and their lives looked incredible so naturally I wanted that for myself.

 But I needed something to talk about.

 And I thought that building a business would give me the life experience I needed to become someone worth listening to.

 So I built my first biz and told myself I‚Äôll start making content when I was making $10k a month‚Ä¶ then $20k a month‚Ä¶ then $30k and so on.

 But at each milestone I‚Äôd come up with some new arbitrary destination for when I had enough ‚Äúauthority‚Äù to share a message with the world.

 You may be doing something like this too.

 You think to yourself ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be happy when this happens, I‚Äôll be less anxious when I just accomplish XYZ.‚Äù

 But you‚Äôre gonna reach that goal NAME.{{ subscriber.first_name }}

 And when you do, you‚Äôll be the same damn person you were before you got there.

 Your inner dialogue will be the same.

 Your self image won‚Äôt change much.

 And you‚Äôll be stuck, looking at the (wo)man you are in the mirror wondering why you don‚Äôt feel the way you anticipated you would when you set out on this journey.

 Only then will you realize that you‚Äôll only ever have yourself; a self that never changes.

 A connection to something that‚Äôs greater than you‚Ä¶ and it simply wants peace.

 It doesn‚Äôt care about what you accomplish, how much money is in your bank account, how many girls you have in your DM‚Äôs.

 It‚Äôs not playing the status game.

 Because somewhere in there, buried underneath all of the armor you‚Äôve built above it‚Ä¶

 ‚Ä¶ it won‚Äôt change.

 Listen to that voice.

 And find peace with the person you are today. If you‚Äôre still here reading and any of this made sense to you, hit ‚Äòreply‚Äô and let me know because I thrive off of your validation.

 Anyway, I ate an edible 39 minutes ago and it seems as though it‚Äôs starting to hit me.

 In order to maintain the legibility and keep the schizophrenia levels to a minimum on this email, I‚Äôm gonna end it here.

 Goodnight {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 Ben

I missed you {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 A lot has changed since we last spoke.

 For starters I rearranged my desk, got a new rug, started drinking black coffee, and had a baby.

 One of the thing

subject: how to opt-out of taxes
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}, how was your day?

 Mine was good too.

 When I was in the shower earlier I realized that the thousand dollar Herman Miller chair I‚Äôm sitting in right now was kind of a scam.

 Sure it‚Äôs kinda comfy.

 It looks okay.

 But the only reason people rave about these chairs is because they‚Äôre expensive and other people like them.

 So I got placeboo‚Äôd into liking it too because I didn‚Äôt want to be the odd one out.

 Oops.

 Anyway, any chance you‚Äôre an accountant {{ subscriber.first_name }}?

 I‚Äôve been needing to submit a bunch of income statements and other docs to one of the 2 accountants I‚Äôve been leading on during this tax season.

 But I really don‚Äôt feel like doing it, so it‚Äôs sat on my daily to-do list every day for the last 3 months.

 Maybe I can just opt out???

 Guess we‚Äôll find out.

 Switching gears again - you know you‚Äôre growing when you‚Äôre able to look back at yourself 3-6 months ago and you kind of cringe.

 You think about how naive you were, how you were less confident, and the silly things you might‚Äôve been stressing about.

 Over the weekend I was back in the city I went to college in.

 When I‚Äôd ask people what‚Äôs new in their life, nearly all of their responses would go as follows:

 ‚ÄúNot too much man‚Ä¶ same old. Kind of tired of doing the same thing everyday and I‚Äôm ready to get out of here.‚Äù

 Many of my friends are about to graduate.

 They think the new experience of getting a job and moving to a different city will paint their life with excitement.

 And it might for a little bit.

 But in a couple years that new routine and new city will once again become mundane and they‚Äôll tell themself the same old lie that they just need to change their environment.

 They refuse to ever consider the possibility that the circumstances are not the problem.

 They are the problem. 

 You‚Äôre probably the problem in your own life too.

 I know I am.

 I was addicted to basketball from the age of 9 to 17.

 I was sneaking into the gym to workout, always watching film, I even bought a mental performance course from a guy named Taylor Alan.

 But all that work I put in never really showed in games.

 I was a decent player, I started my junior and senior seasons in high school, but I never dominated the way I knew I could‚Äôve.

 And there was always an excuse.

 My coach wouldn‚Äôt let me play the way I wanted, my teammates didn‚Äôt work together, my shoes felt weird, I was hungry, the defender kept grabbing me, etc‚Ä¶

 There‚Äôs one constant variable here and it was me.

 I was the problem.

 I couldn‚Äôt get out of my own head and just play.

 Most of what you want lies on the other side of getting out of your own way.

 Stop blaming anything and everything that you‚Äôre not where you want to be.

 And don‚Äôt buy a Herman Miller chair just because your favorite guru has one.

 Love you,

 Ben

subject: you have more to say than you think you do
body:
Your story is unique. That‚Äôs what makes it interesting.

 You think people don‚Äôt care, and to an extent - most don‚Äôt.

 But there‚Äôs always gonna be a pocket of people that resonate with your message.

 Not because it‚Äôs so much better than any of the other people they can listen to online.

 But because it‚Äôs you saying it.

 Through your own lens you‚Äôve experienced the world in a way that is different from everyone else.

 I used to neglect my journey because I‚Äôve never been through anything incredibly difficult, relative to others.

 I was never in poverty.

 I didn‚Äôt watch my parents struggle.

 And I‚Äôve always had a safety net.

 If I wanted to, I could've followed the traditional route and lived a decent life.

 But that‚Äôs not what the 10 year old version of myself wanted‚Ä¶ that younger version had the intuition to know that together, we were capable of more.

 And while most are able to quiet that undying ball of light inside them, I never could.

 Believe me I tried.

 So much so that I hacked the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù rich kid life.

 College was paid for so I chose a school with a 70% female population, joined a frat, and convinced myself that it was all okay.

 I was gonna coast through my 4 years of fun - although it might‚Äôve taken an extra year or two at the rate I was at.

 Then collect my degree and go off and live a comfortable life.

 But the best laid plans of mice and men often go awry. 

 And thankfully, an olive branch was offered to me so I took it.

 In 2020, right before the pandemic I went through a breakup.

 I could write a page on the series of events that lead up to that breakup, but to refrain from boring you all I can point to is divine intervention.

 Everything worked out too horribly; and too perfectly not to be planned.

 One thing led to another and next thing you know I was alone; trying to figure out how to make money again.

 When I was younger I‚Äôd toyed around in various online business models only to find little success.

 But once I was in college enjoying the frat life, all of that stopped.

 About 3 years later I‚Äôm sitting in my Miami high rise on a Wednesday night, writing to you.

 My business is coming off back to back record months, each of which I‚Äôve made more money than I probably would‚Äôve made in an entire year with a job out of college.

 But I‚Äôm not writing this to brag about my accomplishments or paint myself in the light of someone who‚Äôs ‚Äúmade it.‚Äù

 I don‚Äôt know if anyone ever truly makes it.

 I do know that I‚Äôm incredibly lucky to be in the situation I‚Äôm in and I‚Äôd feel as though I‚Äôm doing an injustice to the world by not sharing tidbits of the lessons I‚Äôve learned along the way.

 Furthermore it‚Äôd be an injustice to myself.

 We all want to feel heard.

 We want to feel understood.

 And we want to feel important.

 But this isn‚Äôt validation that you can find outside of yourself.

 You‚Äôll look for it and come up empty handed.

 Truthfully, no one really cares about you.

 They care about themselves.

 So one of the best things you can do for someone - and what they truly want is for you to teach them lessons that you wish you would‚Äôve known when you were in their position.

 And before you know it you‚Äôll impact thousands of people in ways that you couldn't have imagined.

 Maybe that‚Äôs where you‚Äôll find the fulfillment you‚Äôre looking for.

 Ben
snippet:
Your story is unique. That‚Äôs what makes it interesting.

 You think people don‚Äôt care, and to an extent - most don‚Äôt.

 But there‚Äôs always gonna be a pocket of people that resonate with your message.

subject: i'm not who you think i am
body:
I‚Äôm not who you think I am.

 And you‚Äôre probably not who I think you are either.

 I‚Äôve been back on the Zyns if you couldn‚Äôt tell.

 Some bad habits just seem to only have positive effects.

 At least in the short term that is.

 Lana Del Ray is humming in the background as I sit here looking at a blank page, buzzing like a bee from the nicotine pouch cutting into my mouth ever so slightly.

 Is this heaven?

 There‚Äôs a story about a girl who went through severe brain trauma and upon waking up couldn‚Äôt remember anything.

 Not her name.

 Not her personality.

 And none of her family members or friends.

 For the sake of the story let‚Äôs call her Sarah.

 When her mom came into the hospital room, Sarah asked her to describe her personality.

 Sarah's mom described her as sweet, a little shy, genuine and wouldn‚Äôt hurt a fly.

 Not too long after, her boyfriend came in. She asked him the same question.

 He told her how exuberant she is. How she lights up a room. And how she‚Äôs never afraid to speak her mind.

 She prodded a little more by asking him what things that he doesn‚Äôt like about her.

 He told her that she has questionable decision making when it comes to her friends‚Ä¶ and that the reason she was in the hospital is because a few of her friends got in a fight, she ended up in the middle of it and hit her head on the concrete.

 The next day another one of her friends walks in. She describes Sarah as loud and crazy. She says that Sarah is hilarious but sometimes doesn‚Äôt know when to stop and that‚Äôs why the fight started. She goes on to tell Sarah that she instigated the fight and describes the sequence of events leading up to it.

 How can this be?

 All 3 descriptions that she‚Äôs received sound like they could be 3 completely different people.

 She wonders who is lying to her and why. But What Sarah doesn‚Äôt realize is that each persons‚Äô reality is colored by their perception, made up of their own unique previous experiences.

 Hence the disconnect.

 In their minds they weren‚Äôt lying.

 Think the same concept holds true in your life?

 Does your mom know the same version of you that your friends do?

 Maybe. Maybe not.

 Truthfully when I read this, I didn‚Äôt really know what to make of it.

 My best attempt at describing the message of this story would be something along the lines of‚Ä¶

 Stop caring so much about what other people think about you. Their opinion is more so a reflection of them than it is an all-encompassing description of you.

 You know who you are when you‚Äôre alone. Bring out that true authentic version of yourself no matter who you‚Äôre around ‚Äì within reason.

 The best person you can be is you. Because that‚Äôs what separates you from everyone else.

 Something to think about.

 Chat tomorrow {{ subscriber.first_name }}‚Ä¶ if that‚Äôs even your real name.

 Ben
snippet:
I‚Äôm not who you think I am.

 And you‚Äôre probably not who I think you are either.

 I‚Äôve been back on the Zyns if you couldn‚Äôt tell.

 Some bad habits just seem to only have positive effects.

 At lea

subject: is everything we believe a lie?
body:
There comes a point in your life where you realize your parents are human.

 For many of us, when you‚Äôre growing up it‚Äôs easy to think your parents can do no wrong.

 Their word is like the word of God himself.

 This is the frame in which you see the world for most of your childhood.

 It probably never ends for some.

 But the inevitable truth that you may come to realize is ‚Äì they‚Äôre human.

 They fuck up.

 They have flaws that are likely passed down to you.

 And they don‚Äôt always know what‚Äôs best for you the way you do.

 It's not their fault.

 The same thing happened to them and every generation of your family before them.

 It‚Äôs a freeing yet terrifying conclusion to draw.

 It may shatter your world view and make you begin to question everything.

 Who can you really trust?

 Who‚Äôs fundamentally flawed beliefs have you almost unconsciously been subscribed to?

 Some recent events in my life have brought me to this very position and I feel somewhat lost because of it.

 I‚Äôve never been one to blindly follow the paradigm of others and have lived by my own rules for a while.

 But still I can‚Äôt seem to shake this feeling that some of the people I‚Äôve looked up to in my life might not be who I thought they were.

 This leads me back to what seems to be an ongoing theme in this newsletter‚Ä¶

 We all perceive the world through a lens that is 100% unique to us.

 If we don‚Äôt build our own values and our own belief system, one will be placed upon us.

 And this is one that we don‚Äôt have any control over.

 It‚Äôs a jaded perception of reality that was adopted by someone else who‚Äôs had a completely different set of experiences than we‚Äôve had.

 The embodiment of a reality that is truly up to us is freeing and scary.

 But if you don‚Äôt eventually come to this conclusion on your own and live by it; it‚Äôll happen on its own.

 And this is a level of freedom that you might not be prepared for if you haven‚Äôt started to realize it on your own.

 Maybe I‚Äôm right, maybe I‚Äôm wrong.

 But thanks for reading my thoughts.

 Let me know if this resonated.

 Ben

subject: what makes someone interesting?
body:
I‚Äôve got a quicker one for you today so if you‚Äôve been opening my emails and skipping till the end ‚Äì try giving this one a read.

 There are periods in your life where it makes sense to optimize for more experiences rather than more money.

 Yes, you need money.

 And it will likely be a top priority for the majority of your life.

 But the most interesting people are not the richest people in the world.

 I don‚Äôt want to be the next Bill Gates or Jeff Bezos.

 No one looks up to the guys that have perfectly optimized their sleep schedule and flex their Oura ring number like it‚Äôs a trophy.

 We look up to the people that have seemingly lived a thousand lives.

 They‚Äôve experienced the highs, lows, and everything in between in a plethora of various realms.

 Even the wealthiest people are not interesting just because they made a ton of money.

 People like Matthew McConaughey or Richard Branson could entertain a room without ever talking about business.

 Their experiences outside of the accumulation of wealth make them interesting.

 When I first moved to Miami in September of 2022, my first priority was to make more money.

 I‚Äôm now in a position where I‚Äôm making the money I wanted, but I‚Äôm not doing the things I imagined I would at this point.

 If I continued on this current trajectory eventually I‚Äôd become a robot.

 I‚Äôll hit $100k a month and be jealous of the guy making $10k a month who has his community on lock.

 He can‚Äôt go anywhere without running into a handful of people he knows.

 He doesn‚Äôt wait in lines.

 He has all of the girls and status that would make you think he‚Äôs the one that‚Äôs balling financially.

 And isn‚Äôt that everything that you think of when you imagine the future version of yourself that‚Äôs making the money you want to make?

 You don‚Äôt fantasize about refreshing your banking app and seeing a number the equivalent length of a phone number.

 You fantasize about everything that supposedly comes with that.

 Don‚Äôt forget that when you reach the point that you‚Äôre aiming for financially right now.

 Thanks for skimming through this one {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 Ben

subject: if schizophrenia was an email
body:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Apologies for the radio silence the past few days.

 I was babysitting a lost puppy that I found on the internet and then went to a mastermind where my mentor yelled at me for being poor.

 Did you know there is a girl that's made like $8m selling gnomes on the internet?

 And 2 other chicks that are probably making more money than all of us combined selling bath water and jars of farts with a rose in them?

 AND the "catch me outside" girl has made nearly $50 MILLION in the last 2 years on only fans?!

 Now ya know.

 These are some things I learned at my mastermind.

 Anyway {{ subscriber.first_name }} I've been reading the book "Atomic Habits" by James Clear.

 Biggest takeaways through 10 chapters:

 We are the amalgamation of a bunch of small habits added up over time.

 The best way to add a new habit is to make it enjoyable and easy to execute on.

 Create triggers that remind you to perform the new habit and it becomes easy.

 Most things that aren‚Äôt scheduled on a clear day with a clear time do not end up happening. All of my goals are lagging indicators of my small daily habits.

 Also, I get through books way quicker when I listen to the audio along with it. I think I'm semi-retarded.

 I've been boxing a lot recently. Do you think if someone hits me hard enough it'll balance out the schizophrenia?

 Learning a combat sport will "put some hair on your chest" as every 50 something year old white dad likes to say.

 You know that list of a few things you have in the back of your head that you're scared of but you know you're gonna have to do at some point in order to stop feeling like a little bitch?

 Boxing was one of those for me and it feels great to be finally doing it.

 There's a good book on this called either "the war of art" or "the art of war". One of those is about actual war and the other is about internal resistance - I'm referring to the latter but can't remember which title is which.

 Did you miss the more manic, somewhat illegible style of emails? I know I did.

 "But Ben, aren't you a marketer?? meaning you like, write copy for a living? isn't a part of good copy making your writing clear and concise? didn't you literally tweet that today?????"

 Yes.

 Thank you for letting me word dump on your chest {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Gn,

 Ben

subject: good is better than great
body:
Something is better than nothing. 

 Not everything you do will be a masterpiece. 

 You'll have business ideas flop, 

 your content will be cringe, 

 you'll have shitty workouts, 

 you'll 360 no-scope the girl of your dreams. 

 And that's okay . 

 Because consistently being good enough is better than occasionally being great. 

 When you put in more reps, your baseline raises and your average becomes most peoples best . 

 I really didn't want to write this email. 

 My friends are all hanging out and I'm getting FOMO. 

 But I told myself I'd write this today so I'm showing up for myself. 

 Even if it's not the best email I've ever written... 

 It's good enough for today. 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben
