subject: how i'd start all over
body:
I became a man recently (I started listening to country music) and feel like a brain-dead monkey for knocking it for the past 22 years. 

 That has nothing to do with this email, but I thought I‚Äôd let you know anyway. 

 I‚Äôve been going to this Latin Cafe to get a large cafe con leche every morning. 

 On my way there today, I ran into a younger guy I‚Äôd spoken to previously in the sauna (no homo). 

 He was heading in the same direction, so we walked together, and he started asking about what I do and how this online marketing stuff works. 

 It got me thinking about what I‚Äôd do if I had to start over. 

 Let‚Äôs say I never dropped out of college, and I‚Äôm getting my worthless communications degree from Snowflake School in a month. 

 The looming fear of being a wagie cuck for the rest of my life is growing, so I decide to give a stab at this online business thing. 

 But I have no skills‚Ä¶ 

 No connections‚Ä¶ 

 And no personal brand‚Ä¶ 

 I‚Äôm effectively a female, but I can‚Äôt cook or sell my body for money. 

 Here‚Äôs how I‚Äôd start all over: 

 Step 1: Identify what I‚Äôm naturally good at and figure out how I can make money with it. 

 I‚Äôve always been a solid writer, so that‚Äôs where I‚Äôd start. 

 This copywriting thing can‚Äôt be too hard, can it? 

 Step 2: Get obsessed 

 The next few weeks would be spent learning everything I could about copywriting. I‚Äôd watch Youtube videos, read books, buy a course or two, etc. 

 Then I‚Äôd write a bunch of sample copy for brands or people that I find interesting and make that my ‚Äúportfolio.‚Äù 

 Step 3: Ask strangers if you can work for them. 

 This one‚Äôs pretty straightforward. I‚Äôd find people that are selling things on the internet and I‚Äôd try to start a conversation with them. 

 In the beginning I wouldn‚Äôt mind working for cheap or even free to get some experience under my belt. 

 It‚Äôs really that simple folks. 

 If you‚Äôre in a position where you want to make money online and you‚Äôre a decent writer, my friend Mason is hosting a free copywriting class tonight. 

 He‚Äôll teach you how to make a lot of money as a copywriter (even if you look like a 12 year old boy and you need a step stool to get into your truck). 

 ‚Äã Register for the class here and tell him I sent you. ‚Äã 

 Click that link you fucktard ^ 

 Ben

subject: How to use your flaws to your advantage
body:
I really have to sneeze, 

 but I can‚Äôt. 

 So I just have this uncomfortable tingling feeling in my nose right now. 

 As I start this email, it‚Äôs Monday at 11:11 am, and I‚Äôm sitting on my balcony with my coffee mug beside me. 

 It‚Äôs a nice day in Miami. Not a cloud in the sky. 

 If you don‚Äôt have a pair of Birkenstocks, you should buy some just for days like this. 

 I need to cut my toenails, though. 

 Isn‚Äôt it wild that it‚Äôs May 1st already? 

 I swear it was just January, and now we‚Äôre nearly halfway through the year. 

 The other day I took an IQ test once and got an embarrassingly low score, so I was seriously considering the possibility that I am retarded. 

 I‚Äôve never retained information very well (unless I get obsessed with a topic). 

 And one time in college, I got lost on the way to the gym that I'd driven to every day for a year. 

 In all seriousness, I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm super intelligent intellectually. 

 But I‚Äôve always been able to connect with people. 

 I pick up on things that most people don‚Äôt. 

 I‚Äôm either empathetic or good at faking it. 

 And people seem to trust me easily. 

 You‚Äôre probably like, ‚Äúokay, Ben I don‚Äôt really care about you,‚Äù how does this relate to ME? 

 Give me one more minute, and I‚Äôll explain‚Ä¶ 

 Everything I‚Äôm doing in business right now correlates with the skillset I described above. 

 I can relate to people well, so this helps me write copy. 

 I don‚Äôt want to crunch numbers all day and am not super analytical, so I focus on angles, marketing, and offers more than data. 

 I‚Äôm simply playing to my strengths. 

 And once you identify your strengths, business gets easier. 

 If you‚Äôre organized, good with numbers, and like stimulants‚Ä¶ 

 ‚Ä¶become an accountant for a drug cartel. 

 If you love talking to people... 

 ‚Ä¶work at a call center and scam boomers out of their retirement savings. 

 If you‚Äôre a hot 20-year-old girl with nothing but air between your ears‚Ä¶ 

 ‚Ä¶stop reading this email and go sign up for only fans. 

 Life gets easier when you bend reality to your advantages. 

 Alright, I gotta go answer one of my clients' retarded questions. 

 He‚Äôs a good dude, and I love working with this guy, but I swear, every day he‚Äôll ask me one question that makes me want to reply, ‚ÄúGoogle it, you fucking smooth-brained monkey buffoon.‚Äù 

 But I don‚Äôt say that. 

 I say, ‚ÄúYeah, brother, great question! Let me fix that right away üëçüèº‚Äù 

 What a display of emotional intelligence. 

 Wait, last thing if you‚Äôre still here - reply to this email and let me know what kind of content you want from me. 

 Do you like somewhat schizo rants like this? 

 More in-depth marketing/ copywriting stuff? 

 Porno‚Äôs? 

 Life-lessons where I use big words and pretend to have this whole life thing figured out? 

 LMK bb <3 

 Ben

subject: how i went from full idiot to less idiot
body:
I was in a state of constant unease . I was going in the wrong direction but didn‚Äôt know where else to turn‚Ä¶ I was completely lost. 

 I‚Äôm sitting in my childhood bedroom as I pull out my computer and start typing.

 For the last 6 months, I‚Äôve been pretending to be someone I‚Äôm not.

 I‚Äôve gotten so good at acting like I‚Äôm happy to the point that I‚Äôm starting to forget what it actually feels like.

 My fingers hit the keyboard as I write,

 ‚ÄúNever in my life have I felt this lost. I have always had something that I‚Äôm working toward, with an end goal in sight. This made it easy to get up every day and spend most of my time doing things that I thought would bring me closer to that goal. But what happens now?‚Äù

 I wrote this in January 2020 while on winter break, after finishing my first semester of college with a 1.1 GPA.

 About a year later, I got my first paying client for my lead gen ‚Äúagency‚Äù - a basketball trainer in Long Island.

 Over the next 12 months, I built my brand as a marketer in the basketball training space when a trainer with a big personal brand asked me if I could help him sell his online products.

 I‚Äôd only run Facebook ads for local basketball training businesses at the time, a completely different (& easier) game than marketing for info-products.

 So naturally I said, ‚ÄúSure, of course I can help. I‚Äôm an expert!‚Äù 

 I started running his Facebook ads, writing emails, and building funnels for him.

 And although I had little idea what I was doing‚Ä¶

 It worked. 

 I‚Äôd made him a few hundred grand over the next 6 months, which was a big win considering he had almost zero prior success with online training.

 This led me to start working with 3 of the other big personal brands in the space, and it‚Äôs how I learned the ins and outs of paid ads, copywriting, and all things info-product related.

 After a while, I started taking on clients outside of the bball niche.

 My first big wins for clients came through webinars and offer launches.

 Because I‚Äôve built a versatile skillset, the scope of work changes from client to client, but in most cases, I built out a new funnel for a client, script their VSL or webinar, and then help them launch the offer to their email list & on socials.

 Depending on the offer and size of their personal brand, we may start running paid ads if it seems like a good fit after the initial launch.

 Most of my deals consist of an upfront investment anywhere from $5k - $15k and then around 10% of the revenue we generate.

 A year ago, my biggest client paid me $2,000 per month.

 Today, I‚Äôve had singular clients pay me over $20,000 in a month.

 All because:

 I stopped working with broke people. I pick clients that have a lot of leverage I can help them capitalize on. Let me know if you liked this style of email and are more interested in learning more about how my business works.

 I kinda like spewing autistic nonsense better, but if enough of you reply with questions, I can make an appeasement.

 Happy sixo de mayo,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: how i actually make money (18 + üòâ)
body:
Writing is a great way to close all of the tabs that are open in the back of your head. 

 When you articulate these almost subconscious thoughts, it clears up a lot of mental space and alleviates anxiety. 

 It‚Äôs 4:08 pm on this beautiful Monday, and sitting on my balcony once again. 

 An anonymous Twitter account called Deju Ru said to fast today, so I haven‚Äôt eaten and felt great. 

 I finished everything I needed to do for the day about an hour ago and took a long walk in the sun after buying some Zyns. 

 Maybe I should listen to anonymous cartoon characters on Twitter more often. 

 I was thinking about how my business breaks a lot of the rules of a traditional marketing agency. 

 Most people would tell you to pick one skill to master and become the go-to guy for that one thing. 

 It‚Äôs sound advice. 

 I‚Äôve become more of a jack of all trades in my business. 

 We scale info-products and education businesses (fancy way of saying course shillers) by doing‚Ä¶ well, whatever it takes. 

 I script & run ads for clients. 

 I write & send their emails. 

 I built their funnels. 

 I script their VSLs and webinars. 

 I connect their software through Zapier. 

 And I‚Äôve helped build & organize their CRMs. 

 Now I‚Äôm not doing each of these things for every client. 

 I do what‚Äôs necessary for them in their unique situation. 

 I wouldn‚Äôt really consider my business and agency. 

 Simply put, I‚Äôm a freelance marketer ‚Ä¶ or course-slinging, boomer scamming, idiot monkey retard. 

 One of the two. 

 I don‚Äôt know if this is the best way to build a business, but it‚Äôs worked for me so far. 

 I stacked a bunch of different skills, and I utilize each of them as I see fit. 

 But if I had to boil my value down to one or two things ‚Äì it‚Äôd be understanding copywriting and direct response marketing. 

 Getting leads to take a desired action through words has made me invaluable to clients. 

 I use it when writing scripts, ads, emails, webinars, landing pages, etc. 

 THIS is what‚Äôs made my clients millions ‚Äì and because I‚Äôve coupled it with supplementary skills like media buying, building landing pages, setting up backend systems, etc‚Ä¶ 

 I‚Äôm irreplaceable. 

 Well‚Ä¶ I take that back. 

 They could replace me, but they‚Äôd need 4 different agencies to do so. 

 This is I‚Äôm able to charge some of them $10k - $20k per month. 

 Fuck I wish I had my own course to plug here. 

 I‚Äôd love to start selling you idiots something so I can buy a Rolex Presidential and a Porsche 911, but I got nothing for you at the moment. 

 ‚Äã Instead, click here and sign up for my friend Mason‚Äôs free copywriting class on Thursday. ‚Äã 

 I usually make a short guest appearance, and Mason‚Äôs quite entertaining on his own. 

 Did you like this email? LMK bb :) 

 Love you NAME, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: why i'm buying a bucket of rocks
body:
Reliance on routine makes you fragile. 

 I was watching the Lakers/ Warriors playoff game last night. 

 It‚Äôs the 4th quarter, and the Warriors looked like they were about to take control of the game. 

 And then a guy that you‚Äôve probably never heard of came off the Lakers bench and nearly outscored the Warriors in the quarter by himself while winning them the game. 

 His name? 

 Lebron James. 

 No. 

 Lonnie Fucking Walker (yes, that‚Äôs his legal middle name). 

 This dude scored 15 points in the 4th quarter after not playing for the majority of the playoffs. 

 Do you think that‚Äôs the optimal way to get into a rhythm? 

 You‚Äôve barely played for the last few weeks, and then you‚Äôre just inserted into crunch time in your career. 

 Probably not an easy situation to be in. 

 This concept of being able to perform under changing circumstances is something I consider a lot. 

 Sure, I have a routine, and I like sticking to it. 

 But I never want to be the dork that can‚Äôt function because his whoop told him he had a low sleep score. 

 Those who win are the ones who are durable. 

 They don‚Äôt need perfect conditions. 

 They show up and perform, no matter the circumstances. 

 I could continue elaborating on this point, but I think you get it. 

 Instead, I‚Äôm gonna transition to my disdain for grown men riding scooters around Brickell. 

 Today, I was on a pleasant walk when some Apple-Watch-wearing wagie cuck comes flying down the sidewalk. 

 There is a special place in hell reserved for these people. 

 Do your legs not work? 

 Can you not budget enough of your 401k from your $120k/year salary to buy an S-Class? 

 You look like a child. 

 These are the people that proudly tell you they make ‚Äú6 figures ‚Äù while riding around on a scooter like a fucking 12-year-old girl. 

 And why the fuck are you on the sidewalk? 

 At least go dodge traffic like a real man. 

 Ugh. 

 I‚Äôm gonna start leaving rocks on the sidewalks so they wipe out and tear a hole through their J-Crew pants. 

 Anyway, don‚Äôt be a fragile optimizer that can only perform when you‚Äôre at 100%. 

 Most of the time, you won‚Äôt feel great. 

 Cultivate your energy so that you can do what you need to do 100% of the time, even when you‚Äôre running on fumes. 

 Gonna go find some rocks. 

 Ben

 It‚Äôs the 4th quarter, and the Warriors looked like they were about to take control of the game

subject: are you dumb enough to trust yourself?
body:
As my email list has started to grow, I‚Äôve found myself putting on a filter that wasn‚Äôt previously there. 

 This is an attempt to break through that filter. 

 Your self-image dictates your actions. 

 Everything you do,everything you think about, and everything you stress over, all point back to the person you believe you are when you look in the mirror. 

 I‚Äôve noticed I‚Äôve been second-guessing myself lately. 

 Living in Miami, there‚Äôs no getting away from the noise. 

 I have friends that are crushing it and mentors I can turn to. 

 My personal brand (although not huge) has given me this warped idea of the way people perceive me, so I‚Äôve felt a need to stick within the lines of that perception. 

 But when I started my agency in 2021, I was a stupid little idiot ‚Äì alone. 

 I didn‚Äôt have people in my ear telling me what to do. 

 And I wasn‚Äôt competing with friends or others on social media. 

 It was just me, my pea-sized brain, and an urge to build a better life. 

 Objectively, I‚Äôm way smarter, more experienced, and have more leverage than the 20-year-old beginner version of myself. 

 But that kid had something I‚Äôve lost to an extent ‚Äì he was dumb enough to trust himself. 

 This leads me to the question, 

 Where does certainty come from? 

 There are two types of certainty. 

 Type 1 is evidence-based. 

 When you‚Äôve done something a million times, previous data leads you to a conclusion. 

 Simple right? 

 But the second type of certainty is the one that‚Äôs needed to maintain a healthy balance. 

 Type 2 is delusional confidence. 

 It‚Äôs guided by intuition. 

 And it knows it could very well be making a poor decision, but it‚Äôs okay with any outcome that comes its way. 

 The thing about this type of certainty is if you don‚Äôt use it, you start to lose it. 

 The ideas you used to have and your naive intuition start to get quieter. 

 You become a robot confiding within the lines of whoever you believe yourself to be. 

 And if that identity isn‚Äôt malleable, you find yourself in a box. 

 Within that box, you create your own limitations, and you lose the confidence in yourself to trust outside of them‚Ä¶ 

 Maybe? 

 Idk. I‚Äôve been blindly typing away on my computer for the last few minutes, so I‚Äôm gonna reread this email to see if it makes any sense. 

 Ok, I‚Äôm back. 

 My intuition told me to stop being a bitch and send this email, so I‚Äôm just gonna click the button and go watch a movie. 

 Gn (or gm if you‚Äôre reading this in the morning, which is honestly kind of offensive because I expect you to drop everything you‚Äôre doing and read my email no matter where you are at any time of day). 

 Efkbnehjwkfbnjlknfi, 

 Ben
snippet:
As my email list has started to grow, I‚Äôve found myself putting on a filter that wasn‚Äôt previously there. 

 This is an attempt to break through that filter. 

 Your self-image dictates your actions.

subject: i drove a car through the white picket fence
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 It‚Äôs been about a week since we chatted, and I‚Äôm starting to miss you. 

 I wrote half of an email the other day and didn‚Äôt send it. 

 It was about ‚Äústriking while the iron is hot.‚Äù 

 In short, the initial excitement you get about a new project will carry you through the grunt work. 

 But if you wait to take action for too long - that excitement fades, and you usually never start. 

 About halfway through, I got distracted and stopped writing. 

 Ironic right? 

 Anyway, I would've graduated this past week if I didn‚Äôt drop out of college to scam boomers and little kids on the internet. 

 It‚Äôs interesting seeing people I went to school with ‚Äúfall in love‚Äù and get married. 

 Are they really in love? 

 Or are they just settling because they think they won‚Äôt be able to do any better? 

 I don‚Äôt know. 

 It just seems so early. 

 What I can tell you is that if they are settling, it won‚Äôt last. 

 Over the next few years, the white picket fence will begin to decay. 

 Those little cracks will get bigger. 

 And eventually, someone will probably cheat with the maid or pool boy. 

 I don‚Äôt mean to be so doom and gloom. 

 But life gets dull when you‚Äôre not working on something new. 

 You start to wonder what else is out there. 

 Most cope with this by obsessing over things that don‚Äôt matter, starting drama, and worshiping celebrities. 

 It‚Äôs an attempt to make their lives feel like they aren‚Äôt pointless. 

 But what makes life worth living? 

 Am I doing it the right way? 

 I‚Äôm building businesses, cultivating lasting relationships with amazing people, and working towards going through a pack of zyns daily. 

 I‚Äôve found a different outlet to occupy my time on this spinning rock. 

 It feels right, but what‚Äôs the end game? 

 It‚Äôs only when I‚Äôm able to take a step back and zoom out that I feel like I truly appreciate it. 

 18-year-old me would‚Äôve given away his last pack of mango Juul pods to be where I am now. 

 Still, most days still feel relatively monotonous . 

 That feeling is what I wanted to escape by taking this route. 

 Sure, it‚Äôs better than sitting in a cubicle with a bunch of they/thems, taking orders from some schmuck who thinks they‚Äôre the shit because they make $186,000 per year. 

 My average client will make more than your annual salary this month, jackass . 

 But I don‚Äôt know if the feeling of monotony ever goes away. 

 Not matter how exciting things are, 

 No matter who you know, 

 No matter who you are, 

 You still have to get up every day, put your pants on the same way you‚Äôve done since you were 4, and get shit done. 

 Great things take time, and the work isn‚Äôt always fun‚Ä¶ 

 But when you learn to enjoy the work, that‚Äôs when life begins to matter. 

 Take the Lakers - 3.5 tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. In order to reach my peak schizophrenic state that I love so much, I'm fasting until 7pm tomorrow. You should join. Reply if you're in <3

subject: your $902923834 payout is on the way!
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}, how was your day? 

 Mine was good. 

 The Jews that are controlling the weather must be happy because it was a beautiful day in Miami. 

 Ok, I have a confession. 

 Yesterday I told you that I was gonna fast until 7 pm today. 

 I might've had a slice of banana bread at 4 pm. 

 Sorry. 

 A lot of you replied to yesterday's email, so it gave me enough of an ego boost to write again today. 

 But I don‚Äôt really know what to talk about. 

 Sometimes these emails come to me easily. 

 I start typing, my fingers seem to get taken over by my monkey brain, and a few minutes later, I have a semi-coherent email. 

 Other times, I‚Äôll write a sentence, think about how it‚Äôll make you perceive me, and talk myself out of it. 

 Am I oversharing? 

 Will this make me look weak? 

 Do I sound too homophobic or fatphobic? (I am genuinely scared of fats). 

 But then I remember that you, too, are just some grown little kid trying to figure things out. 

 Even if you‚Äôre making $300k a month. 

 It‚Äôs starting to become embarrassing that I‚Äôm not netting $100k a month yet. 

 I almost deleted that sentence. 

 Ok, I‚Äôm out of thoughts ‚Äì let's try something new. 

 Reply to this email with a question, and I‚Äôll base my next email around the best questions I get. 

 I don‚Äôt know why you would want any advice from some 22-year-old child, but hey, let‚Äôs see what happens. 

 Everyone tries so hard to appear authoritative online. 

 I‚Äôm guilty of it. 

 But at the end of the day, I‚Äôm just a retard that figured out how to make my clients millions by typing words on my laptop. 

 No one has it all figured out. 

 Ask me a question, and let‚Äôs figure it out together. 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben

subject: Re: answering your stupid questions
body:
Yo. 

 This newsletter is growing a little bit, and it‚Äôs starting to piss me off. 

 Is a day coming when I‚Äôm gonna have to filter my deranged thoughts in order to protect myself from getting canceled? 

 I hope not. 

 Don‚Äôt share my newsletter anymore because I like it better when it‚Äôs just me and you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 I should really build some stupid coaching offer to sell you. 

 Anyway , the other day I sent an email asking you to reply with a question, and a bunch of you actually replied. 

 Now I feel obligated to answer them. Here we go: 

 (if you asked me something and I‚Äôm not answering it, it‚Äôs because it was a stupid question. You should scroll down to the bottom of this email and click ‚Äòunsubscribe‚Äô) 

 1. What‚Äôs the Ben Bader story? 

 I figured I‚Äôd start here to help anyone that‚Äôs new get caught up. 

 Long story that I don‚Äôt have the mental capacity to recite. I‚Äôm 22 (and still waiting for my brain to fully develop). Here are some recent highlights: 

 - Dropped out of College of Charleston after 2 years. 

 - Made my first $100k with a marketing agency for basketball trainers. 

 - Transitioned to info-products, and now I help big personal brands and ‚Äúinfluencers‚Äù make more money with their courses and coaching. 

 - Now living in Miami high rise with a bunch of other idiot monkeys that make a lot of money. 

 - I also am severely addicted to Zyns. 

 2. How do you find clients to work for? 

 I talk shit on Twitter and have built a bit of a brand there. I share results, and people come to me inbound. 

 I also get a lot of referrals and work with my close friends. 

 3. Since you can work from anywhere, why Miami? Long-term to stay there or move somewhere else, or even buy a second home/apartment somewhere? 

 All of my friends are here. Good weather. Parents have a condo an hour and a half north. Great place to meet other young entrepreneurs. 

 I'll likely be in South Florida for a while‚Ä¶ not sure how long it‚Äôll be Miami. 

 Don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd get a second place any time soon unless it were necessary for biz, or I fall in love with some random girl that lives in bumble fuck Idaho or something lol. 

 4. If you were 19 years old and trying to get to $10-15k a month as quickly as possible, what would you do? 

 If female: OnlyFans. 

 If male: Learn a high-value skill, pitch a fuck ton of people, get a client, repeat. 

 It‚Äôs really that simple. 

 Send enough cold messages, connect with enough people, and hack your way into different groups‚Ä¶ you‚Äôll find clients. You just gotta look hard enough. 

 5. When you think about yourself 10 years in the past or 50 years in the future, does that feel like ‚ÄúBen at a different time‚Äù or ‚ÄúThis is a totally different person‚Äù? 

 Ben at a different time. 

 I thought differently. 

 I operated differently. 

 I had a different self-identity. 

 But at the end of the day, the current me was in there all along. 

 Okay, enough writing. 

 There actually were a few other decent questions, but this email is already getting too long. So if I didn‚Äôt answer you, don‚Äôt take it to heart. 

 Blame your fellow subscribers, actually. They have the attention span of a gnat, so I know I‚Äôll lose them if I keep rambling. 

 If you guys liked this lmk, I‚Äôll make this Q&A a weekly thing. 

 Love you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I wrote a somewhat legible Twitter thread today. Read it here. ‚Äã

subject: i'm currently locked in a hotel room
body:
I‚Äôm sitting in a hotel room, leaning back in this dark leather chair. 

 The carpet and paintings in here are a bit outdated, but It‚Äôs a nice room with a spacious bathroom. 

 But I have a problem. 

 The balcony door won‚Äôt open. 

 I can‚Äôt decipher if I‚Äôm too dumb to figure out how to unlock it‚Ä¶ 

 ‚Ä¶Or if it‚Äôs truly broken. 

 So now I‚Äôm sitting here at the desk by the ‚Äúsliding ‚Äù glass door. 

 And I‚Äôm stuck, staring outside at the chairs on the balcony‚Ä¶ awaiting me. 

 Is this what it feels like to get cucked? 

 I swear I tried everything . 

 I turned the lock all the way to the left, right, up, down, halfway‚Ä¶ nothing. 

 I looking in all the cabinets and all the drawers, scouring the room for a key... 

 ...but found nothing. 

 Now I‚Äôm inside, miserable , looking at how perfect my life could be outside. 

 I‚Äôm not appreciating the nice cool temperature in here. 

 Or the comfortable chair. 

 Or the fast wifi‚Ä¶ 

 I‚Äôm ruining my time inside because I want to go outside. 

 But what I don‚Äôt know yet, is that the outside has its own list of problems. 

 Maybe the chairs are uncomfortable, or the wifi doesn‚Äôt reach that far. 

 Maybe a bird will poop on my computer and ruin this email. 

 Or maybe there will be a gust of wind, and I‚Äôll get blown away like a plastic bag. 

 But for now, ignorance is bliss. 

 I‚Äôm gonna keep dreaming about getting outside in the sun where all my problems will go away. 

 And I‚Äôm gonna put myself in a perpetual state of misery until I get there. 

 Because where I am now is not enough. 

 I‚Äôm not gonna accept it. 

 I'll get so caught up in the pursuit of getting to a place that I'm not, that I'll forget to be present where I am. 

 So I'll fail to realize that the key to getting outside was on the counter to my right all along. 

 Maybe if I weren‚Äôt so busy staring out the window, I would‚Äôve noticed that I already had what I needed. 

 I lean back in my brown leather chair, exhale, look at the key to my right and type‚Ä¶ if not now, when? 

 Ben 

 P.S. I didn‚Äôt actually find the key, and it‚Äôs still pissing me off that I can‚Äôt go outside. Also, I wrote this with zero caffeine or nicotine in my system, so if you hated it that‚Äôs why. God Bless.

subject: Confidence
body:
One day during my sophomore year of high school, I was talking about confidence with a teammate on my basketball team. 

 His name is Colin, and he‚Äôs probably reading this email along with you. 

 In that conversation, he said something that stuck with me to this day - hence the email. 

 I‚Äôd asked him how he seemed so unbothered when he missed shots. 

 He replied, ‚ÄúMy confidence isn‚Äôt a rollercoaster.‚Äù 

 Colin went on to become the all-time leading scorer at our school. 

 I was on a walk today thinking about this idea of unwavering confidence. 

 As I write this email, I‚Äôm wrestling with where it comes from. 

 We can all agree that a large part of confidence is derived from preparation ‚Äì but it‚Äôs not that black and white. 

 I was obsessed with basketball throughout high school. 

 I put in as many hours as anyone. 

 But when I‚Äôd miss a few shots, I‚Äôd start to hesitate. 

 When I turned the ball over, I didn‚Äôt want it the next play. 

 My confidence didn‚Äôt run parallel to my preparation. 

 It fluctuated. And when I‚Äôd get into a rut, it‚Äôd be a downward spiral. 

 But Colin was almost always emotionless . 

 Good game, bad game, didn‚Äôt matter. 

 He could miss every shot and still want the ball in his hands with the game on the line. 

 Maybe the recipe for unwavering confidence goes as follows: 

 Preparation - emotion = confidence‚Ä¶ 

 Eh. I still think there‚Äôs something missing. 

 There‚Äôs an element of confidence that doesn‚Äôt rely on preparation. 

 It‚Äôs built on trust. 

 Ok, wait, that makes sense. 

 You just watched me hash this out in real-time, so thanks for your patience. 

 People that have unwavering confidence aren‚Äôt prepared for every situation ‚Äì but they have enough trust in themselves to figure it out. 

 I could go down the rabbit hole of where that trust comes from, but that would take a lot more critical thinking on my end, and you‚Äôre not really helping here. 

 This newsletter was never supposed to offer profound advice or life lessons anyway. 

 There‚Äôs enough advice out there. I‚Äôd rather offer you my perspective and let you agree or disagree. 

 Last thing I‚Äôve internalized recently: 

 Your reality acts as a mirror of your self-beliefs. 

 It‚Äôs a common saying in sales that ‚Äúwhoever has the most certainty wins.‚Äù 

 This couldn‚Äôt be more true, and it doesn‚Äôt just apply to sales. 

 If your beliefs about yourself aren‚Äôt strong, other people's beliefs about you will start to manifest. 

 If you don‚Äôt feel respected by those around you, it's because you don‚Äôt respect yourself. 

 Choose who you are, or let others choose for you. 

 Sounds simple, but something to consider in your own life. 

 That‚Äôs all for today. 

 Talk next quarter, 

 Ben

subject: reply for a chance to win a bag of dorritos
body:
Ok. 

 I‚Äôve been staring at this blank page for 3 minutes now, so I just put a zyn in my upper right lip in hopes that I‚Äôll have a nicotine-induced burst of creativity. 

 Um. 

 Ummmm. 

 Still nothing. 

 Why do I even write these? 

 I have nothing to sell you, and I get no benefit from this other than a slight ego boost when someone replies, ‚ÄúWow, this almost sounded like it wasn‚Äôt written by an autistic toddler. Keep it up, Ben!‚Äù 

 The liberal-wagie-cuck army on tik tok is starting to get to me. 

 I‚Äôve had a couple of videos go semi *viral* recently, and half of my comments are people calling me a trust fund baby. 

 The other half are girls commenting on my eyelashes. 

 Fuck off woman, no I don‚Äôt have a ‚Äúlash tech,‚Äù and if I did, I wouldn‚Äôt refer you to them. 

 And to be fair, I did grow up in a great neighborhood, but every dollar I‚Äôve made has been on my own. 

 I actively tell my parents and grandparents that I don‚Äôt want their money. 

 Business is going swimmingly right now. 

 Clients are crushing, and I‚Äôm getting close to being out of poverty (I can taste $100k a month). 

 But in all honesty, it feels a bit dull. 

 An extra $20k per month or so wouldn‚Äôt change much about my life right now. 

 Recently I‚Äôve realized that money loses its value if you don‚Äôt utilize it. 

 My life now looks cool, but I was going out more and having more ‚Äúfun‚Äù when I was making around $10k per month, living like a rockstar in a college town. 

 My favorite thing I‚Äôve been able to do recently is impact people around me. 

 Roughly 6 months ago, this 18-year-old kid found me on social media and asked me to mentor him by sending me a dollar on Venmo. 

 I had some money sitting in my Venmo account, and I sent him $1k back. 

 Phillip used that money to buy a course from a friend of mine and is now making $10k a month in sales. 

 He‚Äôs moving out of his parent's house next month. 

 Another dude who I call Scooby, has been replying to my emails updating me on his life. 

 He was in a tough situation, so my friend Mason and I bought him a laptop to help him start making money online (love you scooby). 

 One of my best friends from college, Stevie, was born to be in sales. 

 This guy could make a brick wall laugh. 

 I helped him get into a great opportunity, and he closed his first deal (and made $500 in commission) today. 

 These 3 situations are some of the highest ROI things I‚Äôve been able to experience recently, and they have nothing to do with me personally making more money. 

 Funny how that works. 

 Being a catalyst to help other people grow is really fucking cool. 

 Sorry for the jumpiness in this email, I guess the zyn worked. 

 Love you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Ben

subject: the SIMPLE 5 step system i used to build my business
body:
This email‚Äôs about business. 

 So if you‚Äôre only here for manic rants where I say things that would jeopardize my chances if I were to run for president, go away. 

 Let‚Äôs get into it. 

 A little under a year ago, I started working exclusively in the info-product & coaching space. 

 I had some experience, but pivoting from working with local basketball trainers to course sellers was a whole new game. 

 Since then, I‚Äôve been able to put myself in a position where I‚Äôm the go-to guy for many of the bigger names in the industry. 

 I‚Äôm making way more money than I ever did working with bball trainers. 

 I‚Äôm working with guys I used to watch on social media. 

 And I‚Äôm building cool shit with cool people and making a lot of money doing it. 

 It‚Äôs made business fun. 

 People commonly ask me why I don‚Äôt offer any coaching right now. 

 In short, there‚Äôd be so much to teach. 

 The way that I work with clients is fluid and flexible. 

 Almost no 2 clients need the exact same prescription. 

 I‚Äôve learned a multitude of skills and accumulated knowledge that would take months or years to pass along to others. 

 And I also don‚Äôt really have systems. 

 My onboarding process is a bit messy, and I talk to clients through facetime and iMessage. 

 Clients come to me through my Twitter (where I mostly talk shit) and referrals from a network that‚Äôs taking me years to build. 

 But most of this wasn‚Äôt necessarily intentional. 

 I started tweeting for fun. It helped me connect with people who became friends and eventually clients. 

 The skills I‚Äôve picked up have been a byproduct of me telling people I knew how to do things that I didn‚Äôt actually know how to do until I figured it out on the fly. 

 I get to rely on warm inbound leads, my website sucks, I don‚Äôt use a CRM, and my offer isn‚Äôt easily replicable for each client. 

 I‚Äôm doing everything wrong, but business feels easy. 

 And I think it‚Äôs because I‚Äôve done the hard things right. 

 It‚Äôs taken me multiple years to build my Twitter presence and become a marketing ‚Äúexpert.‚Äù 

 And now everything is coming to a perfect storm. 

 My network is bigger, and I have the skills/ experience to meet the opportunity. 

 If I tried to teach someone how to do it the exact way I‚Äôve done it, it‚Äôd take a while. 

 If they wanted quick success, I‚Äôd tell them to do a bunch of things that I don‚Äôt currently have to do. 

 But if you want to eventually stumble into a high-leverage position the way I have, do the following: 

 Post more content & don‚Äôt be a dork about it Connect with cool people and be genuine Say yes to any project that comes your way & learn as much as you can Do everything in your power to get amazing results for clients Post more content about those results There‚Äôs your simple 5-step system. 

 Reply if you have questions, and I‚Äôll get back to you within 337 business days. 

 Sweet dreams, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I‚Äôm taking on 5 students for coachi‚Äì lmao imagine if I just plugged a coaching offer after basically telling you how you‚Äôre too retarded to do what I do like an absolute asshole.

subject: I hope this went to spam
body:
Do you ever consider the possibility that we‚Äôre already living in the metaverse? 

 I installed an app on my phone that makes me wait 5 seconds and click a few extra buttons every time I want to use social media. 

 But I look at my screen time and see a number so large that I‚Äôm ashamed to share it with you here publicly. 

 I guess I‚Äôm not perfect. 

 Every now and then, I‚Äôll go to war in the sauna. 

 It‚Äôs the kind of war where if you were to spectate this situation, you‚Äôd think I‚Äôm schizophrenic and belong locked away in an asylum. 

 My inner dialogue becomes audible, and it turns into a screaming match between the person I am and the person I tell myself I want to be. 

 Right now, I‚Äôm battling comfort. 

 There are some things I want to change about my life ‚Äì and myself. 

 I‚Äôm stuck in the middle between desire and acceptance. 

 The desire hasn't been strong enough to elicit action. 

 But it IS strong enough to deter acceptance. 

 Does that make sense? 

 In any situation, you decide if you want to accept it or change it. 

 If the cost of change outweighs the desire, you do nothing ‚Äì but it‚Äôs easy to fall into a trap where the desire is everpresent. 

 I don‚Äôt think it has to be this way, though. 

 There‚Äôs got to be a way where you can accept your current circumstances and your current self while continuing to morph into a new and improved version. 

 It‚Äôs a code I haven‚Äôt cracked. 

 And it‚Äôs dangerous. 

 If you only take action when your back is against the wall, your life will become a seesaw. 

 You‚Äôll only see progress after you reach a new low. 

 You go up and then right back down. 

 Or if you‚Äôre really unlucky, you‚Äôll just stay floating in the middle for eternity. 

 I don‚Äôt like being this vulnerable with you. 

 But I know if it‚Äôs something I‚Äôm struggling with, some of you may be able to relate. 

 Acceptance. 

 I know the answer is acceptance. 

 But I‚Äôve been operating on this seesaw for my entire life, and it‚Äôs gotten me here. 

 I guess I‚Äôm not perfect. 

 Ben

subject: haaaaaaaapppppppiiinnneeeeeesssssss
body:
I like being alone. 

 It‚Äôs a superpower and a downfall. 

 If I wanted to, I could go months without talking to anyone but myself and the 9 other personalities in my head. 

 Maybe some of you can relate to this - 

 If I spend a few days constantly surrounded by other people and I don‚Äôt take an opportunity to reset, I lose my mind. 

 I start to forget who I am, and I become an extension of the people I‚Äôm with. 

 So sometimes it‚Äôs nice just to turn the world off and be with me, myself, and I. 

 I can hear myself best in solitude. 

 But I do understand this is a dangerous game. 

 Some Harvard dorks did an 85-year study on happiness. 

 Basically, they took about 800 people from around the world and monitored their happiness levels every 2 years. 

 The strongest correlation to happiness wasn‚Äôt financial success. 

 Or career achievement‚Ä¶ 

 Or even health. 

 The happiest people were those with the best relationships. 

 Looks like I‚Äôm doomed because I hate you fucks. 

 Hahahaha. 

 Maybe schizophrenic people are actually the happiest because they always have someone to talk to. 

 You can only grow so much in isolation. 

 The depth at which you know yourself is limited by your experience with the outside world. 

 Your relationships with others reveal your true relationship with yourself. 

 And to have a truly happy relationship with yourself, you need to have strong relationships with others. 

 I‚Äôm kinda figuring this out on the fly here, but I think that makes sense, right? 

 No matter how great of a human you are or how much you THINK you‚Äôve grown ‚Äì interacting with other real humans is the litmus test. 

 And if you really are a good person, you‚Äôd be doing a disservice to the universe by not sharing your gifts with the world. 

 So if you‚Äôre like me and you‚Äôre content being a hermit ‚Äì be careful. 

 (I say that as I sit on my balcony in the middle of Brickell, where I am literally surrounded by people all the fucking time) 

 Gonna go get a Cuban coffee from the nice lady at the cafe. 

 Let‚Äôs talk more, I enjoyed this. 

 Ben 

 P.S. I plug each of these emails into chatgpt and ask it to analyze them. The response it generates actually blows my fucking mind - try it with some of your writing.

subject: a bunch of random thots
body:
Any time I open a blank doc like this, my brain starts to fire. 

 I‚Äôll come up with an idea and map it out to see if I can turn a thought into a coherent email. 

 Usually, I‚Äôll churn through a handful of these half-baked thoughts before I arrive at what I follow through with. 

 Here are some of the ideas I‚Äôve had over the last 63 seconds: 

 1 - How you show up in one area of your life is reflected in other areas. 

 If you‚Äôre hiding parts of who you are in one relationship, it subconsciously manifests in other relationships. 

 It dictates your level of authenticity and the way that you interact with the world as a whole. 

 I‚Äôd keep going, but I don‚Äôt want to get too personal. You‚Äôre a stranger reading my inner dialogue, and I don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre thinking on the other side of the screen. 

 Next. 

 2 - Everything is a mental game. 

 I cold-plunged yesterday for the first time ever. 

 The first 5 minutes were torture. 

 I kept telling myself to get out. 

 But eventually, that voice got quieter. My body went numb, and 15 minutes later, I felt like a new man. 

 This mental fortitude shined through for the rest of the day in my mental state and the way that I spoke to people. 

 I guess this relates to my first point. 

 3 - With enough input, your desired result will unfold. 

 Some of the pieces of content I‚Äôve put out recently kinda flopped. 

 Each of which I posted thinking, ‚ÄúThis is a banger.‚Äù 

 Apparently, they weren‚Äôt. 

 But that‚Äôs okay. 

 Some of my favorite artists put out hundreds of songs before they had one pop. 

 If your results dictate your consistency, you will fail before you give yourself the chance to succeed. 

 Hmm. 

 Maybe all of these half-baked thoughts are intertwined. 

 Maybe this email was somewhat coherent. 

 I think there‚Äôs a deeper lesson in there, but I‚Äôll leave it up to you to connect the dots. 

 I‚Äôd continue on with this stream of consciousness, but it took me 3 tries to sound out the spelling of consciousness. 

 I think that means it‚Äôs time to turn off my brain. 

 Have a good week {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Ben

subject: my first scam at 14 yrs old (fun! easy! simple!)
body:
Ding ding ding 

 The bell rings. 

 I grab my backpack and hustle out of the classroom so I can be the first one out the door. 

 The teacher tells me to slow down on my way out. 

 I pretend not to hear her. 

 I get to bus #5 and walk down to row 16 on the left side by the window, per usual. 

 Then I pull out my light blue iPhone 5 and start reading. 

 This was my routine every day for the past few years. 

 I subscribed to a newsletter from a guy named Taylor Allan. 

 His emails were absolutely incredible. 

 The vivid imagery he used made me feel like I was participating in any situation he described. 

 He articulated my thoughts and my exact situation in a way that connected the dots in my head. 

 I no longer felt alone. 

 This random stranger that sent me emails every day somehow understood me and my problems better than my parents did 

 Maybe even better than I did. 

 He was selling an online basketball training product in the early 2010s. 

 I don‚Äôt remember how expensive it was, but one day I found a link to get it for free. 

 So I put in my contact info and immediately got access. 

 Then I felt guilty. 

 I told my Mom what I did, and said that she could see me selling an online basketball course one day. 

 She let me use her credit card to go back and pay for the course so I could alleviate my guilt. 

 And now, I spam your email inbox and help people sell courses. 

 Such beautiful foreshadowing. 

 Anyway, 

 I‚Äôve been getting a lot of replies to my emails recently, and I just wanted to let you know I appreciate you <3 

 My goal is to write such bangers that you experience the same excitement that I used to when reading Taylor‚Äôs emails. 

 Reply and let me know what kind of content you‚Äôd like from me going forward. 

 Honestly, I‚Äôll probably discard your suggestion ‚Äì not because it‚Äôs a bad suggestion but because I like to pretend that I come up with all my ideas on my own. 

 You probably do that too. 

 Thanks for reading, {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 -Ben 

 P.S. Copywriting is the one skill I‚Äôve used in every business I‚Äôve ever tried ‚Äì it‚Äôs made me rich for a 22-year old 

 My friend Mason is one of the only people that I sometimes get jealous of when reading his writing. 

 He‚Äôs fucking good, and he made a killing as a freelance copywriter. 

 ‚Äã If you‚Äôre interested in getting paid to click letters on your keyboard like a retarded monkey, check out this free class. ‚Äã

subject: quick story
body:
I was heading to my usual lunch spot today when someone who looked familiar walked in ahead of me. 

 I stood behind him and 3 of his friends in line. 

 The person in front of him whipped out his phone and started taking a video. 

 After about 30 seconds, I realized that two of the people he was there with didn't speak English. 

 "He's buying lunch for random strangers he found on the street?" I thought to myself. 

 This person is known to be extremely generous and commonly does things like this. 

 Both registers were open, and I ended up next to him as I was ordering. 

 I said "hola" to my friend behind the register and asked for some tacos. 

 To my right, they rang up his order. 

 Before he could pull out his card, I put my Amex down on the chip reader. 

 Honestly, I don't know why. 

 I wasn't trying to get something out of this and didn't expect anything in return. 

 I figured he does a lot of nice things for people, and it's probably been a while since someone did something nice for him 

 He gave me a sincere thank you, and we chatted for a bit. 

 He said that he'd actually flown out the people he was with from Japan and that they were staying with him for a few days. 

 I sat down and enjoyed my meal. 

 That concludes my story on buying lunch for SteveWillDoit. 

 Sometimes you get random inclinations to do nice things for people. 

 If you follow them, they usually open doors for you or, at the very least, offer you some good karma. 

 Ben

subject: Kobe Bryant wasn't confident
body:
I planned this email out in my head earlier today. 

 But right now, I‚Äôm hesitating to write it. 

 I was gonna tell you about how the need for confidence becomes a crutch. 

 I had a story prepared that demonstrated this example perfectly. 

 I was gonna tell you how I was sitting at lunch today when I saw a pretty wooman walking by. 

 Instinctually I thought, ‚ÄúI should go up to her,‚Äù but I didn‚Äôt. 

 My brain came up with a thousand reasons as to why that‚Äôd be an outrageous thing for me to do, and I talked myself out of it. 

 I told myself I didn‚Äôt have the confidence to do that right now. 

 I wasn‚Äôt wearing a watch. 

 I was dressed like a toddler. 

 It was a bad hair day. 

 Maybe I‚Äôll do it another day when I‚Äôve done the inner work to build up my confidence, and I look a little more presentable. 

 So I let the opportunity pass me by, and now I‚Äôll never be able to impregnate this pretty stranger. She could‚Äôve been my wife. 

 The thing is, it wasn't confidence that I was lacking. 

 It was courage. 

 And having the courage to act in the face of uncertainty is how you build confidence. 

 It lets you use real-life examples to change the story you tell yourself about who you are. 

 You give your brain data that says, "{{ subscriber.first_name }} you are this type of person. Remember when you did XYZ even though you were nervous?‚Äù 

 When you stop relying on confidence, you‚Äôll no longer need it. 

 Because no amount of inner work ‚Äì no amount of money ‚Äì no fancy watch will magically turn you into someone that you‚Äôre not right now. 

 Only actions can do that. 

 Last point to drive this home: 

 Every star basketball player has bad games. 

 There were times when Kobe would go 3/14 throughout a game. 

 He literally holds the NBA record for the worst single-game shooting percentage when taking 5+ shots. 

 Yet he still wants the ball in his hands with one minute to go‚Ä¶ no matter how the previous 47 minutes have gone. 

 Not because he‚Äôs feeling extra confident to step up to the plate that day. 

 But because in his world, confidence doesn‚Äôt exist. 

 It doesn‚Äôt matter. 

 And he doesn‚Äôt need it because he replaced it with courage. 

 Rip Kobe. Makes me sad just thinking about it. 

 Anyway, I‚Äôm not gonna send this email. 

 Instead, I‚Äôll write a less personal email that makes me look like a perfect, confident person. 

 If you received this, no, you didn‚Äôt. 

 Miss her man, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Good article that Kobe wrote about obsession ‚Äã 

 P.S.S. Chat GPT graded my email a 7/10 because I spelled woman with two O‚Äôs, and ‚Äúimpregnate this pretty stranger‚Äù wasn‚Äôt professional. Fukk you, Chat GPT

subject: Why you should give up on your dreams
body:
You‚Äôre in a hallway. 

 It‚Äôs a narrow hallway with white walls and fluorescent lights. 

 There‚Äôs a row of wooden doors on both sides. 

 You‚Äôre looking for a golden key. 

 You try one of the doors on your left, but it‚Äôs locked. 

 In a moment of panic, you turn and start running down the hall, past the other doors. 

 Eventually, you see a door with golden light shining from under it at the end of the hallway. 

 You make your way down and open the door. 

 There‚Äôs an empty room with an arrow on the wall pointing toward a new door on the right. 

 You walk to the new door and open it. 

 Another arrow and another door. 

 In the next room, you see the same thing. 

 You continue to follow the according arrows and open new doors. 

 Finally, you reach a room with glowing walls. 

 And on the floor in the center of the room, you find the key you were searching for. 

 You grab the key and get out of the hallway. 

 On your way out, you look back at the hallway. 

 And you see all the locked doors that you‚Äôd run past on your way to the first door were now open. 

 What I‚Äôm describing isn‚Äôt a psych ward or a never-ending maze. 

 It‚Äôs the law of surrender. 

 Many of the paths you take in life will lead you to the next path ‚Äì a better-suited path‚Ä¶ 

 IF and when you‚Äôre ready. 

 But you can‚Äôt unlock the next path until you‚Äôre ready. 

 And if you spend too much time banging your head against the wall in one path, the next one will never illuminate. 

 Let‚Äôs bring this back to earth a bit. 

 When I was a junior in high school, I gave up my lifelong dream of playing college basketball. 

 I saw the signs that it wasn‚Äôt for me, and I listened. 

 I let that dream die. 

 A similar thing happened that led me to drop out of college and dissolve my first business. 

 The thing is, I never got a direct tap on the shoulder telling me it was time to move on. 

 The universe whispers, I had to be quiet enough to hear it and surrender my control to trust it. 

 Looking back, I can see that those decisions led me right to where I needed to be. 

 But this wasn‚Äôt evident until I got there. 

 I gave you this analogy to show you this: 

 There is power in knowing when to surrender your control and follow your intuition. 

 When things aren‚Äôt working, no matter how hard you try to force it, it could be a sign that you‚Äôre missing a key. 

 And to find that key, you‚Äôll need to open a different door. 

 Allow life to surprise you. It always knows. 

 - Ben 

 P.S. If you‚Äôve noticed I‚Äôve been more consistent with these emails, you‚Äôre right. This is a bit Hubermanesque, but I‚Äôve built a ritual for myself when I want to enter creative mode. Dim lights, music in the background, lit candle & a zyn. 

 Try building a ritual for yourself when building a new habit. 

 P.P.S. Check out this podcast episode - trust me. ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: life lesson from instagram models
body:
I recently made a video talking about how we all have seasons in our lives. 

 Sometimes we‚Äôre in grind mode. 

 Sometimes we‚Äôre more relaxed. 

 I‚Äôve come to realize that it‚Äôs a bit more nuanced. 

 There are a multitude of seasons that you need to experience in order to keep things interesting. 

 For me, life has been very peaceful recently. 

 I‚Äôm working a lot, but mostly on things I enjoy doing. 

 For now, I like it this way. 

 But eventually, this stage will no longer serve me. 

 I‚Äôll need more stress. 

 More chaos. 

 More unpredictability. 

 ‚ÄúEverything is temporary‚Äù 

 This is a quote that one in every five girls will put in their Instagram bio. 

 Scroll down, and you‚Äôll see rows of bikinis pics. 

 That part's unrelated. 

 When we fight these seasons, things start to feel misaligned. 

 We start swimming upstream. 

 Our minds have an interesting way of telling us what we need. 

 When you‚Äôre anxious, maybe it‚Äôs because you‚Äôre stagnating. 

 You need to add more to your plate. 

 You need to move to a different city. 

 You need to make a change. 

 The key is to observe the way you‚Äôre feeling and accept whatever stage you‚Äôre in. 

 Maybe this is why women have menstrual cycles. 

 That was a joke - but actually, considering women seem to be more intuitive than men, maybe there‚Äôs some truth there. 

 Either way, listen to the way you feel. 

 When things just seem to be ‚Äúoff,‚Äù it‚Äôs time to make a change. 

 Or you‚Äôre pregnant. 

 Ok, that‚Äôs enough. 

 I ate an edible for the first time in a bit, and it‚Äôs starting to hit me. 

 Should I still be telling you this now that my email list has doubled in subscribers? 

 Maybe. 

 Everything is temporary, I guess. 

 (that makes no sense, but it just sounded right in my head). 

 Have a good night, {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you made it this far, reply and let me know if this email made any sense to you because I can no longer tell if my realizations are intelligent or if I'm just stoned.

subject: i'm in a rush
body:
I‚Äôm leaving to pick up my friend Mason at the airport in 6 minutes. 

 It‚Äôs highly unlikely that I‚Äôll be able to give you anything worth of value in our short amount of time here. 

 But I can‚Äôt miss this email today. 

 It‚Äôd be the 2nd day in a row. 

 And that would start a negative streak - which would make it harder to write an email tomorrow. 

 So this email probably won‚Äôt change your life. 

 But if you learn anything, I guess it‚Äôs exactly that. 

 If you skip any habit you‚Äôre trying to build for 2 or more days, it‚Äôs harder to start again. 

 I sound like I read the book Atomic Habits and made it my entire personality. 

 But anyway I gotta go. 

 Jkwfnefljwbeidbewnjifdnw, 

 Ben

subject: Do you feel like you know yourself?
body:
I‚Äôve been avoiding this all day. 

 I‚Äôm sitting here watching this cursor blink over and over. 

 It‚Äôs been 2 minutes now. 

 Why is my mind still blank? 

 Are my new subscribers gonna think I‚Äôm an idiot? 

 I just grabbed my mouse to click away to another tab. 

 But I stopped myself. 

 Not today, Satan. 

 I‚Äôm gonna sit here and write this fucking email no matter what. 

 Should I talk about the shitty coffee I had this morning? (I cheated on my main spot). 

 Or should I talk about how failures make us who we are because they‚Äì 

 Never mind, you‚Äôve heard enough of that lately. 

 Ok. 

 The depth in which we know ourselves determines the depth in which we interact with the world. 

 Let me say that in English: 

 When you‚Äôre aware of your motives, why you want what you want, why you do what you do ‚Äì you see with more clarity. 

 It lets you trust yourself more. 

 And that trust shines through in your relationships. 

 On a related note, my least favorite people are those who lack self-awareness. 

 You may be reading this right now and thinking it‚Äôs ironic that I‚Äôm saying that ‚Äì but at least I‚Äôm aware enough to acknowledge that possibility. 

 Those who lack self-awareness view themselves as someone they‚Äôre not, and that creates misalignment in the way reality is viewed. 

 They‚Äôre the kind of people that you never see eye to eye with - no matter how well you explain your perspective on a situation. 

 And this is created by a lack of introspection. 

 So if there‚Äôs anything of value that you take away from this ‚Äì find a way to ‚Äútalk to yourself‚Äù more. 

 Could be journaling, walking, driving, or whatever else lets you feel like you‚Äôre spending quality time with yourself. 

 Alriiiighty... 

 For whatever reason, this one‚Äôs been a struggle for me to write, so if you‚Äôre still here, thanks for sticking with me. 

 Hopefully, my thoughts will be more coherent tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Watch this video if you want to feel like a stupid, incompetent, pre-pubescent child ‚Äã 

 P.P.S. Reply and let me know what you thought of this email if you made it down here.

subject: 398 words that will help you
body:
Writing is the best skill you can learn. 

 I know some great salespeople that suck at writing, but I don‚Äôt know any amazing copywriters that suck at sales. 

 Case closed. 

 Here are 3 somewhat unique ways I‚Äôve improved my writing over the years: 

 (I‚Äôm always cautious when giving tips about writing because it creates added pressure to be perfect). 

 1 - Daily journaling 

 I don‚Äôt journal as much as I used to ‚Äì though I should. 

 But when I was really honing my writing skills, this is how I did it. 

 I‚Äôd write to my future self, updating them on my life and sharing lessons I‚Äôve learned ‚Äì very similar to the flow of these emails. 

 Writing a sales email is really not that different from *some* of my rant emails/journals. 

 Because there‚Äôs one characteristic your writing needs to have, no matter the purpose of it‚Ä¶ 

 It needs to be ENGAGING. 

 If it‚Äôs not engaging, no one will get through it. And if no one gets through it, no one will buy. 

 This leads me to my second point‚Ä¶ 

 2 - Reading good copy 

 You‚Äôre already subscribed to the best newsletter in the world (mine). 

 Why not add a few more? 

 Seeing different writing styles and the way various arguments are made will help you be more creative in your own writing. 

 Any time you see a good ad, sales page, email, etc. ‚Äì save it. 

 I have a folder with 200+ funnels on my bookmarks tab. 

 I suggest you start to build one of your own. 

 Last and final point‚Ä¶ 

 3 - Thinking & doing other shit 

 Many of my best realizations and ideas have come while doing something that isn‚Äôt writing. 

 One time I basically wrote an entire sales page in my head while I was at the gym. 

 I got home, and I just transcribed my brain onto a doc. 

 You need to give your mind quiet time to think. 

 The more you understand yourself and the way you operate ‚Äì the more you‚Äôll understand the world. 

 And a vast array of experience will give you a wider perspective which translates to you being a better writer. 

 Alrighty, this was a lot easier today. 

 If you actually implement anything I told you to in this email - you‚Äôll become a better writer. 

 Thanks for reading, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Here‚Äôs a 3-minute info-product marketing masterclass for you ‚Äã

subject: never send an email at 12:50am
body:
Every Sunday, I go for a ~2-mile run around this riverwalk close to my apartment. 

 To be clear ‚Äì I‚Äôm not an apple-watch-wearing cardio dork. 

 But I enjoy getting out in the sun, and running provides a great opportunity to fight the voice in my head that wants to be lazy. 

 So today, I threw on my running shoes and went over to the path. 

 It‚Äôs almost always crowded, so I‚Äôve made it a competition in my head when I see other runners in front of me. 

 My pace fluctuates a bit when I‚Äôm more motivated or going downhill versus uphill. 

 But there are two scenarios where I drastically increase my speed. 

 When I see someone in front of me, I turn on the jets. 

 I try to run by them as fast as I can, so they feel bad about themselves they decide to stop running altogether (this is my attempt to make the riverwalk less crowded). 

 On my way home today, I was coming up on this big intersection. 

 Usually, it takes about 25 seconds to walk across. 

 By the time I got up there, the countdown signal to cross the street was down to 4 seconds. 

 I had two options‚Ä¶ 

 One - Stop and wait 2 minutes for the lights to turn red again. 

 Or two - Hit the gas. 

 I put my head down and ran faster than I had all day. 

 If I didn‚Äôt, maybe I would've ended up on someone's windshield based on how aggressive drivers can be in Miami. 

 My point ‚Äì I ran the fastest when I absolutely had to. 

 Faster than when I‚Äôm tracking down another runner. 

 And faster than when I feel more motivated. 

 Because nothing can induce speed the way necessity will. 

 If you emptied your bank account and had to make a certain amount of money, or you‚Äôd be homeless in 30 days ‚Äì you‚Äôd figure out a way to get it done. 

 At that point, motivation doesn‚Äôt matter, it‚Äôs just a buzzword. 

 It‚Äôs easy to take action when you have no other option, but it gets harder once you‚Äôve had some success. 

 Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôre making decent money with X business model. 

 You want to pursue Y business model, but right now, X is paying for your lifestyle. 

 What I‚Äôve done, and perhaps the practically ‚Äúsound‚Äù decision, is to start Y on the side while maintaining X. 

 Once you‚Äôre making good money with Y, you transition into doing it full-time. 

 Logically it makes sense ‚Äì but here‚Äôs where it gets dangerous. 

 If there's an idea that‚Äôs been on your mind for a while and you haven‚Äôt acted on it yet, it could be because your current situation offers you too much comfort. 

 And if that idea lingers for long enough without the according action, it‚Äôll drive you crazy. 

 Maybe that‚Äôs when you consider burning the boats. 

 ‚Äã You‚Äôll figure out how to swim when you‚Äôre in the water. ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 P.S. I‚Äôve made my clients millions of dollars online, and I don‚Äôt know the difference between a metaphor and an analogy. I thought this running story was an analogy, but Chat GPT told me it was a metaphor. Maybe AI will replace us.

 P.P.S reply if you liked this email <3

‚Äã

subject: can you help me think of a subject line?
body:
Following your passion is bullshit. 

 Kinda. 

 There is a route where your passion intersects with your leverage and knowledge. 

 It‚Äôs your job to find that intersection. 

 To think you can make a lot of money ‚Äúdoing what you love‚Äù without complementary skills is a naive approach. 

 There are times when you won‚Äôt be passionate about the vehicle you‚Äôre in. 

 But those times give you an opportunity to find a key that you‚Äôll need later on. 

 I‚Äôve always enjoyed writing. 

 If I could make millions of dollars sitting at my desk writing these emails, I‚Äôd do it. 

 But I wouldn‚Äôt have anything worthwhile to write about if it‚Äôs all I did. 

 I need life experience as a reference point. 

 And progressing in business allows me to share insights and bring value. 

 If writing was my sole focus, maybe I‚Äôd use bigger words or know the difference between an analogy and a metaphor. 

 But it wouldn‚Äôt matter because no one would read it. 

 It‚Äôs like trying to build a puzzle by finding the last piece you‚Äôll need. 

 No bueno. 

 Being passionate about what you get paid for is a privilege that must be earned. 

 And the way to earn it is through experience. 

 Which in my opinion is one of the most valuable things you can optimize your life for when you‚Äôre young. 

 You simply need to taste everything to know what you like. 

 Work in different industries. 

 Live in a big city then move somewhere quiet. 

 Be a degenerate and then go into monk mode. 

 The best reference points and learnings are found on various ends of the spectrum. 

 And with enough experience, the connection between your knowledge and your passion will be obvious. 

 But only when you have the necessary toolkit. 

 When your work starts to feel more like play, it means you‚Äôre on the right path. 

 At least I think so. 

 But as always, I could be way off about everything in this entire email. 

 May Chat GPT be the judge. 

 Goodnight, 

 Ben 

 P.S. About to watch this Tai Lopez rant if you wanna watch it with me (no homo) 

 P.P.S Banger analogy from Chat GPT: 

 It's like setting off on a cross-country road trip without a map or GPS. You have an idea of your destination ‚Äì it's a city you've always dreamed of visiting. But without understanding the terrain, the distances, and the possible roadblocks, you'll likely end up lost or going in circles. Along the way, you need to gather information, learn how to navigate, and understand the characteristics of your vehicle. Similarly, following your passion without developing relevant skills and acquiring necessary knowledge can lead to frustration or even failure. Experience and understanding of the real-world terrain of your passion is crucial to reach your desired destination.

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }} i literally wrote this in my sleep
body:
I had a dream last night where I was playing basketball. 

 I can‚Äôt recall the exact situation or where I was, but I know this ‚Äì my team was up 7 points with a few minutes left in the game. 

 We started playing keep-away. 

 Instead of trying to score, we passed the ball around the perimeter to keep it out of the other teams' hands. 

 Then I started dribbling around, weaving through the defenders. 

 Eventually, I lost the ball, and that‚Äôs when I woke up (I never lose the ball, so my brain was like yup, this is a stupid dream). 

 In my delirious half-awakened state, I had an idea. 

 Most people are playing keep-away with their lives, and it‚Äôs fucking everything up. 

 They just try to get to a baseline level of comfort so they have just enough breathing room to not blow the lead. 

 And then they stop trying to score. 

 They‚Äôre no longer playing to win, they‚Äôre playing not to lose. 

 If you know anything about sports, this is how big leads get blown. 

 In life, it‚Äôs no different. 

 Avoid this at all costs. 

 I literally woke up at 4:44 am and said, ‚ÄúHey Siri, text Ben Bader ‚ÄúRun out the clock‚Äù so I‚Äôd remember this idea. 

 ‚Äã You need to constantly be on offense. 

 When you start to feel happy with what you got, and you go into ‚Äúpreserve mode,‚Äù that‚Äôs when you‚Äôre gonna find yourself in trouble. 

 This is especially true as you start to make more money. 

 It gets easy to think you have a big enough ‚Äúlead‚Äù (safety net or nest egg) to where you can coast. 

 I don‚Äôt know about you, but I just can‚Äôt see that working out well. 

 Stay on offense. 

 Keep attacking. 

 And run up the scoreboard. 

 Happy 4th, 

 Ben

subject: Why you need to be a drug addict
body:
When you were young, you wanted to be extraordinary. 

 Maybe you wanted to be an athlete, singer, painter, gamer, astronaut, etc‚Ä¶ 

 Maybe you became obsessed with this idea. 

 You convinced yourself it‚Äôs what you were born to do. 

 Most of your days were spent practicing, envisioning, and thinking about this one goal. 

 But after a while, that dream was beaten out of you. 

 Something you‚Äôd been obsessed with for so long was now gone. 

 And like energy -- obsession cannot be created or destroyed. Only converted from one form to another. 

 This is where it gets problematic. 

 We‚Äôre naturally hardwired to stalk our prey, attack, and kill. 

 But the sad truth for most people is that they become their own prey. 

 Instead of finding a new outlet for that obsession, they try to stuff it down. 

 The world tells them who they should be, obsession is bad, and that they need to find balance. 

 So they listen. 

 Next thing you know, these are the people that are addicted to drugs, alcohol, gambling, porn, etc. 

 And perhaps just as miserable are the ones who bury their obsession to the point where it doesn‚Äôt have one of the above outlets. 

 They are the ones who eat themselves from the inside out. 

 They become obsessed with attacking themselves, overthinking, and fantasizing about what life could be like if they were dealt a different hand. 

 Because no matter what, you can‚Äôt outrun obsession. 

 It‚Äôll eat you alive. 

 In 1854, Henry David Thoreau wrote, ‚ÄúThe mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation and go to the grave with the song still in them.‚Äù 

 You can‚Äôt outrun obsession. 

 Find an outlet for it -- And do it every day. 

 Unless that outlet is black tar heroin. 

 Thx for reading -- Reply and LMK your thoughts on this topic, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Read Kobe Bryants' article on obsession if you haven‚Äôt already ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: Only open if you brush your teeth
body:
I haven‚Äôt been super consistent with these emails the past few days.

 Once upon a time, not too long ago ‚Äì I set out to write an email to my list for 100 days in a row.

 I made it about 9 days before I disappeared for a few months, and my subscribers probably thought I died.

 If you remember that, you‚Äôre an OG.

 Consistency is something we all struggle with at times.

 But why?

 You brush your teeth every day (hopefully) without any issues.

 You scroll through social media every day.

 You text your ex every day.

 But sometimes, when you try to build a new habit, or you sit down at your desk to work, or you‚Äôre trying to make progress in the gym‚Ä¶

 It just doesn‚Äôt happen.

 And it‚Äôs because you‚Äôre trying too hard to be perfect.

 When you brush your teeth, you don‚Äôt think about the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù stroke. *pause*

 You‚Äôre a robot.

 You probably have the same brushing pattern every time, whether you‚Äôre conscious of it or not.

 Sometimes you‚Äôre still drunk from the night before, and you‚Äôre a bit less thorough.

 Other times your breath smells, so you‚Äôre more intentional.

 But it happens no matter what (with some exceptions, of course).

 As I felt the looming pressure of going another day without writing an email, I started racking my brain to get an idea.

 I came up with a few things, but they all felt forced and repetitive ‚Äì and now generating an idea for something that I usually enjoy doing started to feel like work.

 Then I stopped and said to myself:

 ‚ÄúJust do something.‚Äù 

 Use those 3 magic little words the next time you feel like you‚Äôre in a rut.

 That something doesn‚Äôt have to be great.

 It doesn‚Äôt even have to be good.

 But it‚Äôll protect you against the atrophy that would occur if you didn‚Äôt use your muscles that day.

 Just. Do. Something.

 Done,

 Ben

 P.S. In most of my recent emails, I keep coming back to the same few principles. One that seems to be ever-present is this idea of having trust in yourself ‚Äì even in uncertainty. Trust that you‚Äôre on the right path and trust that if you just start, you‚Äôll figure it out. The painting can only be completed after the last stroke.

 P.P.S Just do something ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: i'm freezing.
body:
Today marks day one of making the cold plunge my entire personality. 

 So here‚Äôs a lesson I‚Äôve learned from submerging myself in cold water: 

 It only hurts when you resist the pain. 

 When I first get in, all my brain says is, ‚ÄúThis is freezing. Why are you doing this? Get me out of here. Joe Rogan is a liar. Ok seriously get out.‚Äù 

 But then I take a deep breath and relax. 

 I loosen the muscles in my body that are tensing up and tell myself it‚Äôs really not that bad. 

 And after a minute or so, the pain goes away. 

 Or maybe it doesn‚Äôt dissolve ‚Äì but I learn to tolerate it. 

 Either way, it‚Äôs an interesting dynamic. 

 There are a few analogies we can pull from this. 

 The most obvious one is ‚Äúrun towards fear. Pleasure is on the other side of pain, blah blah blah.‚Äù 

 It‚Äôs a valid point, but I‚Äôm not gonna bore you with David Goggins-themed motivation. 

 I think there‚Äôs a deeper lesson here that may or may not resonate with you‚Ä¶ 

 We feel pain when we resist our true selves. 

 It creates an internal conflict where the image that we‚Äôre presenting to the world isn‚Äôt congruent with our core belief system. 

 Because saying what you want to say and showing others who you really are, sounds intimidating. 

 It makes you vulnerable. 

 So you‚Äôd rather hide. 

 It‚Äôs more comfortable to just paint on a fake smile, fake personality, and fake belief system. 

 But after a while, you‚Äôll realize that you‚Äôre pretending ‚Äì and it‚Äôll start to eat you alive. 

 And then you‚Äôre left with a choice. 

 Do you continue to cover up your authenticity with a bigger shield so that people can‚Äôt see in? 

 Or do you remove the layers that you‚Äôre hiding under and stop resisting who you really are? 

 Because maybe there‚Äôs a chance that it was all just a figment of your imagination. 

 Maybe raw authenticity won‚Äôt actually make you vulnerable. 

 Maybe you‚Äôll unlock the desires that you were chasing and couldn‚Äôt catch. 

 And maybe you‚Äôll finally find peace with that same voice in your head that tells you that the water is too cold. 

 Or maybe, I‚Äôm just kind of sleepy, and this made no sense. 

 Reply and let me know what you think :) 

 Talk soon, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Come to my friend Mason's free copywriting class this Sunday if you want to learn how to get paid to click letters on a keyboard like a monkey with an 80 + IQ ‚Äã

subject: don't let your friend drive your trackhawk
body:
I‚Äôm staring at a page of semi-coherent thoughts. 

 For the past 20 minutes, I‚Äôve been attempting to write to you about reliance on others. 

 What I‚Äôm trying to say to you is making sense in my brain, but I‚Äôm having difficulties translating it into legible English. 

 In short, here‚Äôs my point: 

 Odds are there are many things that you situationally rely on other people for - even though you could do them yourself if you tried. 

 Some of these things are as simple as being the one who drives, leading the conversation with the waiter, or planning the trip for everyone. 

 Other examples could be relying on a partner to operate a part of the business or lead the conversation on a sales call. 

 If you‚Äôre constantly taking the backseat, these little things add up over time and make you less capable. 

 Is this making any sense yet? 

 Feed your brain information that says, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not the one who takes the initiative in this situation,‚Äù and you‚Äôll start to think you‚Äôre incapable. 

 Let‚Äôs try to reel this in some more. 

 This became apparent to me recently when I noticed I take a different role socially depending on who I‚Äôm around. 

 When I go out with one group of friends, I‚Äôm the one who calls the shots. 

 I decide where we go, I walk up first, I order the drinks, and I go talk to the group of pretty blonde girls. 

 When I‚Äôm with a different group, I do none of the above. 

 This might sound elementary, but it‚Äôs important to take note of where this concept bleeds through in other areas of your life. 

 Reliance on other people allows you to limit yourself. 

 Notice the verbiage there. Other people don‚Äôt limit you ‚Äì they allow YOU to limit you. 

 Let‚Äôs say your Mom ‚Äúmakes‚Äù your pop tart every morning by putting it in the toaster and clicking a button. 

 You were never cognizant of how she did it, and now you think you don‚Äôt know how to heat up a pop tart. 

 Extrapolate this to every part of your life, and I think this jumbled-up email will make a bit more sense. 

 What you‚Äôre aware of you‚Äôre in control of. What you‚Äôre unaware of controls you. 

 Reply if you liked this one {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 It‚Äôs been a while since I used the first name field. 

 I kinda like saying your name {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 Ok bye {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Here's me in the cold plunge today 

 ‚Äã

subject: i bought a richard mille for lunch
body:
Here‚Äôs a POV as I open my laptop to write this email. 

 ‚Äã I‚Äôm at my favorite lunch spot that I go to every day in Brickell. 

 I spend $40-$50 here every day (sometimes more if I get a sweet treat). 

 And honestly, I‚Äôd pay double for the hospitality, speed at which the food comes out, and ambiance in this place. 

 It‚Äôs the Richard Mille of lunch. 

 When I first started my business, I was closely attached to the money. 

 I wasn‚Äôt necessarily cheap, but I felt every dollar I spent ‚Äì and when I was having a slow week or slow month, it was reflected in my confidence. 

 But recently, I‚Äôve never worried less about money. 

 $400 dinners with the boys, 100 bucks to skip the line at the club, first-class flights, 100% tips on the bill, a few grand on new clothes‚Ä¶ 

 I don‚Äôt feel any of it. 

 And I know some of you may be reading this thinking I‚Äôm a bombastic asshole, but that‚Äôs not my intention here. 

 The best part of making money is not thinking about money. 

 But we all pedestalize it to an extent. 

 ‚ÄúMaking $10k per month will fix all of my problems and make up for the fact that I‚Äôm insecure because my left nipple is slightly smaller than my right one.‚Äù 

 No, it won‚Äôt ‚Äì but I get it. 

 It‚Äôs a lesson that can only be internalized if you experience it firsthand, over and over. 

 You hit the arbitrary money goal in your head and immediately want more. 

 Go through a few cycles of this and then realize it‚Äôs turning you into a crazy person. 

 And eventually, you come to the realization that money is just a tool. 

 Solve the money problem, so you have the financial peace of mind to develop other areas of your life. 

 The biggest irony is when people say things like, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care about money!‚Äù 

 This attitude causes every decision you make to be limited by a lack of financial resources. 

 Those who TRULY don‚Äôt care about money ‚Äì focus on it & make it ‚Äì So they never have to think about it again. 

 Ok, enough writing for today. 

 I‚Äôve been at this restaurant all day and have had a revolving door of friends walking in and out of here, so this email has been a highly distracted excursion, but I hope you liked it <3 

 Talk later bb, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Help me out real quick ‚Äã

 ‚Äã
