subject: i'm going through a quarter life crisis bc of my TV
body:
I woke up viscerally angry today that I don‚Äôt have more followers on Twitter. 

 ‚Äã So plz go here and follow me real quick if you don‚Äôt already (it‚Äôs where I actually share more in-depth business advice). 

 Thx. 

 Moving on ‚Äì this morning, I went through a brief quarter-life crisis on my walk. 

 You see, a few months ago, my TV randomly broke. 

 I tried everything to fix it ‚Äì I turned it off and turned it back on (twice, actually). 

 But it didn‚Äôt work. 

 Most of the time, I don‚Äôt think about the fact that I lack a functioning TV until I sit down on the couch, grab the remote, click the on button, and see a black screen. 

 In theory, I could order a new TV or go to best buy, but it just sounds like too much of a hassle ‚Äì so instead, I opt to grab my laptop and just watch whatever I want to watch on there. 

 It‚Äôs a tricky spot to be in. 

 I kinda want a new TV, but that desire isn‚Äôt strong enough to spur me into action. 

 So let's break this down‚Ä¶ 

 Most of the time, we operate within a range of 2 levels of desire. 

 Things that we kinda want. 

 And things that we can‚Äôt not get. 

 The latter of the two usually eventually unfold - I felt like I had to drop out of college, start a business, build a personal brand, etc. 

 There was no other option, so the action became obvious. 

 You probably have some things like this in your life ‚Äì those things that you can‚Äôt not get ‚Äì you‚Äôre obsessed. You‚Äôre constantly thinking about them, and they're going to happen no matter what. 

 But you also have a laundry list of the things that you kinda want. 

 Maybe you kinda want to get jacked, take surfing lessons, learn guitar, go on more dates, start a YT channel, etc. 

 These unclosed loops become death by 1,000 papercuts. 

 They linger in the back of your head like a gnat that only bothers you occasionally. 

 Most of the time, you‚Äôre not thinking about it, but when it‚Äôs buzzing in your ear, you want nothing more than to kill it. 

 And in life, you‚Äôll get occasional reminders about your ‚Äúkinda wants‚Äù to the point where you‚Äôll eventually need to start tackling them. 

 They could be completely unrelated to your main thing (the things you can‚Äôt not do) and feel like a pointless side quest. 

 But if they continue to linger, it means there‚Äôs something there. 

 It‚Äôs an urge you have to quench. 

 All this said, I likely won‚Äôt be getting a new TV until September 10th (first day of the Bengals football season). 

 Don‚Äôt be like me. 

 Start attacking one thing that you kinda want today. 

 ‚Äã And follow me on Twitter plz, ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 P.S. Chat GPT graded this an 8/10, which is lower than usual. I care more about your opinion bc you‚Äôre a real person. Let me know if this one resonated <3

subject: I'm getting a 9-5 (clickbait)
body:
I walk past the 9-5ers in Brickell on a sunny Thursday afternoon. 

 Most of them are dressed as men's warehouse mannequins. Shirts tucked in, pants the perfect length, and Apple watches on their wrists. 

 It‚Äôs 90 degrees outside, and they‚Äôve gotta be burning up. 

 I can‚Äôt help but feel a sliver of guilt as I pass by shirtless ‚Äì wearing nothing but kill crew shorts and running shoes. 

 At the age of 22, I have the freedom and am making the money that they‚Äôre trading 40+ years of their lives for. 

 I‚Äôm not saying this to sound like a pretentious asshole but rather to point out the inequity of our inputs. 

 Those of us who are in a similar position to me (where life effectively feels like a video game) are not inherently smarter than those trapped at a desk. 

 I‚Äôd be willing to bet some of those people would smoke us as entrepreneurs. 

 But the difference is in the way we view the world. 

 For whatever reason, we were lucky enough to be delusional. 

 So delusional to the extent that we brainwashed ourselves into believing a different reality was possible. 

 And this reality rewarded us for our delusion. 

 No matter where you‚Äôre at in life, you‚Äôre going to reach a multitude of intersections where you have to make a decision. 

 Do I continue living in my current reality by telling myself the same thoughts, ideas, and stories? 

 Or do I change the narrative I tell myself and thus adopt different beliefs that will let me see a new reality? 

 This might sound a bit ‚Äúwoo woo,‚Äù so to put it simply: 

 The guy hating everyone in tik tok comments lives in a different reality than the guy who‚Äôs making $10k/month. 

 The guy making $50k/month lives in a different reality than the guy making $10k/mo. 

 And the guy making $1m/month lives in a different reality than any of the above. 

 To reiterate ‚Äì these realities are simply made up of the stories we tell ourselves. To change your situation in life, you must change your belief system. 

 Observe the ever-present thoughts running through your head. 

 Do they make sense? 

 Do they serve you? 

 Do they align with your goals? 

 OR have you just been identifying with them out of habit? They‚Äôve been engrained so deep into your psyche that you don‚Äôt even question them. 

 Continue to audit your beliefs, continue to discard those which don‚Äôt serve you, and continue to watch your dreams unfold. 

 I must add -- all of this means nothing without taking the according actions and developing skills. 

 Love you, 

 Ben 

 P.S. My friend Grant helped me connect the dots and understand this concept - follow him on Twitter if you‚Äôre not weird ‚Äã 

 P.P.S. I ordered a new TV this morning. I know ‚Äì very courageous of me. If you‚Äôre new here and don‚Äôt understand why me ordering a TV is a big deal, check out this email from the other day. ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: {insert subject line here}
body:
The right answer can only become obvious once a decision has been made. 

 I could end the email here and leave that sentence open to your interpretation. 

 But there's almost nothing I love more in this world than to spew my thoughts across a computer screen, so here we are. 

 Your current situation in life is made up of a series of decisions and actions that you‚Äôve chosen (consciously or unconsciously). 

 Whenever you're faced with a tough decision, the answer isn‚Äôt always obvious on the surface ‚Äì but it‚Äôs only once you make a decision the right answer will reveal itself. 

 I‚Äôm kinda talking in circles right now, so let‚Äôs get more practical‚Ä¶ 

 As I look back at the last few years of my life, every big decision I made eventually became the ‚Äúright‚Äù decision ‚Äì but in the moment, there were always doubts. 

 From when I decided not to play college basketball to when I dropped out of college, those felt like big moves at the time. 

 As I think about them now, it couldn‚Äôt be more glaringly obvious that those decisions served me. 

 But a lot of people get stuck trying to make a perfect decision, so they never do anything. 

 Even the wrong move will illuminate the right move ‚Äì as long as you‚Äôre MOVING. 

 The first real business I started was a marketing agency for local basketball trainers. 

 I couldn‚Äôt have picked a worse niche, but in hindsight, it‚Äôs what led me to the info-product world, where I‚Äôve been able to find success. 

 Someone I know reached an impasse in their career a little bit ago. 

 They had just shut down their previous business and were ready to start something new ‚Äì but trying to figure out what that new thing was gonna be. 

 We were on the phone one night, tossing around an idea for what they could do next. 

 After some back and forth, they said, ‚Äúwhat the hell I‚Äôll try it." 

 They‚Äôre now in a position to make multiple seven, if not eight figures with that business and impact thousands of people. 

 But none of this would‚Äôve happened if they didn‚Äôt simply decide and act. 

 So if you‚Äôre wondering why I‚Äôm telling you this and how it applies to you ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know. 

 I can‚Äôt answer that question for you. 

 Maybe you‚Äôre contemplating a big life move right now, and you‚Äôve been weighing your options for a bit. 

 Maybe the weight of the decision is making you anxious and unhappy. 

 Maybe it‚Äôs time to make the decision so you can finally figure out if it was the right or the wrong move. 

 And eventually, you‚Äôll see that all you needed to do was decide because you‚Äôll end up right where you need to be. 

 As always, reply and let me know if this one resonated. 

 ‚Äã And check out this podcast I did recently with my friend Alex. ‚Äã

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: don't read this
body:
Start 7/24/23 10:08am 

 I‚Äôm sitting outside Starbucks, sipping on a cold brew. 

 I just watched this mid-20‚Äôs aged mom struggle to open the door with her stroller. 

 While I considered getting up to help her, I figured it would take too long to get up and walk to the door. 

 Now I feel like an asshole. 

 There‚Äôs a man standing about 20 feet in front of me. 

 I can‚Äôt determine if he‚Äôs homeless or not. 

 He‚Äôs wearing a grey wife-beater, champion shorts, and Birkenstocks while holding his(?) phone and dancing like a maniac to the music coming out of his wired headphones. 

 You might be thinking, ‚ÄúOk Ben, well if he has a phone and headphones, that means he‚Äôs not homeless.‚Äù 

 And to that I say, most homeless people in Brickell actually make around $10k a month and have base model Rolex‚Äôs. 

 Stop 7/24/23 10:14am 

 Start 7/26/23 7:43pm 

 I wrote that two days ago and then got distracted. 

 Unfortunately, I wasn‚Äôt able to figure out if the guy was homeless or not ‚Äì but he started aggressively yelling and laughing shortly after. 

 That‚Äôs when I left. 

 It‚Äôs now been 4 days since you last heard from me. 

 At the moment I have no idea what I‚Äôm gonna share with you, but I figured if I miss another day it could spiral into a long hiatus. 

 This is usually the point where I‚Äôd transition into how just showing up every day is better than trying to be perfect blah blah. 

 But you‚Äôve heard enough of that. 

 In fact, you‚Äôve probably heard enough of everything. 

 Once upon a time, I was addicted to consuming content. 

 I‚Äôd go down a dropshipping rabbit hole, then SMMA, then Amazon, etc. 

 For weeks I‚Äôd mindlessly watch Youtube videos and take notes so it felt like I was being productive and doing something that would help my life. 

 But I never implemented any of the stuff I learned. 

 Finally, I realized that I was effectively fantasizing about success and giving myself a false dopamine hit by watching this content, so I turned it off and stopped listening to all the gurus. 

 Then I made money. 

 Simple right? 

 The lesson here is that there‚Äôs no lesson here. 

 If you‚Äôre not where you want to be stop endlessly consuming content without taking action on any of it. 

 You‚Äôre basically getting off to other people's words. 

 And that‚Äôs weird. 

 Go do something <3 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: i lost $28k today
body:
I‚Äôm back at the Starbucks I wrote to you about yesterday. 

 6 cops on motorcycles just drove by with their lights on. 

 The man I told you about in yesterday's email is here again, and I‚Äôve concluded that he‚Äôs definitely homeless. 

 He‚Äôs wearing the same clothing except for a different pair of sandals (which actually look really comfy) and is carrying 6 worn down plastic Target bags ‚Äì which I imagine hold the entirety of his belongings. 

 He‚Äôs still schizophrenic too. 

 The girl sitting behind me just asked me to watch her bag while she goes inside to get a drink, and now I feel morally obligated to defend it with my life. 

 I just fought off 12 large men. 

 The world is so interesting when you stop to observe it. 

 I could write about the Mehgan Fox-looking girl who just walked by or the man that just sat down in front of me, and I think is staring at me because every time I look up, we make eye contact‚Ä¶ 

 Do you ever think about how maybe we‚Äôre the NPCs and the schizophrenic homeless guy that‚Äôs screaming in laughter is actually the awakened one? 

 This guy‚Äôs still staring at me. 

 He just nodded, and I pretended not to see it. 

 I‚Äôm not mean he just has a crazy look in his eye. 

 I fucked up. 

 He‚Äôs walking over here. 

 Ok, he‚Äôs gone now. 

 He definitely had a screw loose, but he seemed harmless. 

 He sat down across from me, shook my hand, and told me his name was Cornelius (I promise I‚Äôm not making this up). 

 He went on to tell me how his phone is broken and then started asking me if I live around here and if I have a working phone. 

 I said no to both and then pretended to be intensely working on my computer, so he said goodbye and walked away. 

 What an interesting morning. 

 Honestly, if I read this email, I‚Äôd think I‚Äôm either a pathological liar or that schizophrenia is contagious and that I should stay away from the homeless guy. 

 Anyway, I spent $18k this morning and then gave away another $10k. 

 Long story short, I realized I wasn‚Äôt getting billed for a mastermind that I‚Äôm in, so I let them know, and they offered me a $6k discount to just pay in full for the year. 

 I couldn‚Äôt say no. 

 And the $10k was a ‚Äúmisunderstanding‚Äù with a now ex-client where they claimed we agreed to a performance fee of bottom-line revenue (profit), but we actually agreed to topline (total rev). 

 Although I have a document (that they signed) that clearly states I‚Äôm entitled to roughly $10k more than they paid, I honestly don‚Äôt care enough to go through the headache of pursuing it. 

 Oh well. 

 Feeling like aggressively inflating my lifestyle, so I‚Äôm forced to make more money. 

 Stop taking life so seriously, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Good movie about a dog that I watched the other night ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: How to stop fumbling the bag
body:
Finally. 

 I‚Äôm so back. 

 This is the first ounce of creativity I‚Äôve had in a week. 

 For a bit, I thought I was completely out of ideas, and I‚Äôd said every word of value that I could. 

 But I was wrong. 

 I have plenty to tell you about, and I just wasn‚Äôt giving my thoughts enough of a vessel to transfer into reality (whatever the fuck that means). 

 As I was sitting outside Starbucks this morning, it hit me. 

 The only reason people don‚Äôt find success in life & business is because they fail to recognize opportunities that are presented to them. 

 They wander through life, perpetually messing up every chance they have at making a lot of money. 

 All it takes is one good connection or one win to completely change your life. 

 They get a well-respected client who could send them hundreds of referrals‚Ä¶ 

 Buuut they can‚Äôt get results, so it falls apart. 

 Or they meet someone who can open various doors for them‚Ä¶ 

 And they don‚Äôt go above and beyond to add value to that person's life. 

 It‚Äôs like they‚Äôre either blind to the opportunity or so nervous to mess it up that they just crumble. 

 One of my first big personal brand clients was a guy named DJ Sakcmann. 

 He‚Äôs got about half a million followers on IG and is one of the main authorities in the online basketball training space. 

 I connected with him through a cold DM on Instagram. 

 We got on a call, and he said needed a new funnel. 

 I said, ‚Äúsay no more, fam‚Äù and spent the next 4 hours writing some of the best copy I‚Äôd ever written. 

 I built the entire landing page, and by the next morning, he had a new funnel. 

 At the time, I was making around 10k per month, so I obviously could charge for my work ‚Äì but I didn‚Äôt ask him for a dime. 

 The funnel I built literally converted 5x better than the one he had previously, and it generated hundreds of thousands of dollars. 

 For the next 4 months, I basically worked with him as an unpaid intern, and it was one of the best decisions I ever made. 

 Not only did I eventually get paid a lot of money from DJ, but it opened so many doors for me. 

 He sent me a handful of referrals It gave me confidence that I could get results in the info-product space And DJ is now a good friend of mine and one of my most notable case studies But it would‚Äôve been so easy to fumble this opportunity. 

 I could‚Äôve let my ego get in the way and asked for a lump sum of money upfront. 

 I could‚Äôve stopped following up with him when he didn‚Äôt reply. 

 I could‚Äôve half-assed the funnel and taken much longer to get it done. 

 But I recognized the potential upside in this partnership, so I seized it. 

 This is just one of many examples of the art of craftiness ‚Äì the most overlooked skill in business. 

 I‚Äôm working with a kid right now named Kevin, who edited a recent podcast I did (without asking for money). 

 Not only am I gonna pay him, but I‚Äôll send him intro‚Äôs to potential clients and give him advice on scaling his business‚Ä¶ 

 Just because he has enough foresight to go out of his way to provide value for me and not be greedy by asking for a bunch of money. 

 Odds are you‚Äôve had chances in your life to help someone who can open doors for you. 

 It‚Äôs up to you to recognize when those opportunities present themselves and go above and beyond to pounce on them. 

 Hope you enjoyed this email, I‚Äôm glad to be back. 

 ‚Äã Check out the podcast I did with Cardinal Mason and Grant Lannin here. ‚Äã

 Ben 

 P.S. Reply if you liked this one :) 

 ‚Äã
snippet:

 I‚Äôm so back. 

 This is the first ounce of creativity I‚Äôve had in a week. 

 For a bit, I thought I was completely out of ideas, and I‚Äôd said every word of value that I could. 

 But I was

subject: I'm selling you something
body:
I‚Äôm once again sitting outside this Starbucks without any idea what I‚Äôm going to write about today. 

 I just chugged a cold brew and coconut water, so my bladder feels like it‚Äôs going to explode. 

 But I refuse to use the bathroom here because it‚Äôs one of those where you have to ask them for the code to unlock the bathroom door. 

 And that‚Äôs just not something I‚Äôm willing to do. 

 ‚ÄúHey sir can you give me the code for the bathroom??‚Äù Nope. Couldn‚Äôt be me. I dropped out of school for a reason. 

 Okay, I‚Äôm stalling now. 

 What should I write to you about? 

 Uhhh. 

 I‚Äôve been thinking about putting together a course or coaching offer for a while now. 

 I keep going back and forth on what I‚Äôd offer, how hands-on it‚Äôd be, and what people want to learn from me. 

 If I built an agency coaching offer, here‚Äôs how I‚Äôd position it: 

 I‚Äôd start by demonizing the traditional SMMA model. 

 You may have heard the saying, ‚ÄúAn enemy of my enemy is a friend of mine.‚Äù 

 This common enemy tactic is one of the most powerful tools you can use as a marketer. 

 You‚Äôre breaking the beliefs of your audience while simultaneously building a bridge to your solution. 

 This is how I‚Äôd sell you on the ‚Äúfull-stack marketer‚Äù business model. 

 I‚Äôd show you how it‚Äôs easier to get a few clients to pay you $5k-$10k+ per month rather than try to stack a bunch of clients on cheap retainers and constantly have to do outreach. 

 I‚Äôd tell you how I worked with 50+ clients that paid me $1k per month and how much of a headache that was. 

 And I‚Äôd show you how I now get paid $10k- $30k per month (per client) without needing a huge team. 

 With enough social proof and personal stories, I‚Äôd sell you on the business model, and I‚Äôd sell you on me. 

 Now it‚Äôs time to sell you on you. 

 This offer would be for people that have a client or two as a freelancer, so I‚Äôd speak directly to that archetype. 

 ‚ÄúSince you already have some results, this is the easiest way to scale. You‚Äôll simply be selling more services to someone that already trusts you.‚Äù 

 This is where I‚Äôd use language that shows you how I was once in their shoes and transfer my certainty into their soul (if I can do it, you can do it). 

 This is how successful offers are created. 

 Sell an audience on a mechanism (business model), sell them on yourself as the authority, and sell them on themselves so they can actually visualize their own success. 

 Hope this gave you a better understanding of how to extract money from strangers on the internet. 

 Reply if you liked it :) 

 Ben 

 P.S. It's a miracle I finished this email without peeing my pants. You're welcome. 

 ‚Äã

subject: Getting canceled on a podcast
body:
I‚Äôm sitting at the crowded coffee shop in my hotel lobby. 

 It‚Äôs kind of cold in here, so I ordered a hot latte with vanilla. 

 Fun fact ‚Äì I went through a 3-day phase where I was drinking black coffee and felt like I was better than everyone else. 

 Then I missed flavor and switched back to sugary, milky coffee. 

 My airpods are dead, but I have them in my ears to try to drown out the noise from all of the other people in here. 

 There‚Äôs a guy sitting over to my right that I swear I‚Äôve seen many times throughout my life. 

 Does that happen to you too, where you see people that you think have been following you from city to city since you were old enough to remember? 

 Because same. 

 I like asking you questions even though I know you can‚Äôt actually answer me because you‚Äôre a stranger on the other side of the screen, probably reading this on the toilet (unless you‚Äôre a female bc girls don‚Äôt do that). 

 Ok, I‚Äôm 173 words in now, and I‚Äôve written nothing of value. 

 This is the part where I try to find some important life lesson to share with you that makes you go, ‚ÄúWow, that‚Äôs super interesting,‚Äù and then you forget about it 2 minutes and 6 seconds later. 

 I‚Äôm going on a podcast in a few hours, and I‚Äôm a bit nervous. 

 I have no logical reason to be nervous, but I am. 

 The nerves are coming from feeling like I need to uphold or project an image of myself to the world. 

 I know when you‚Äôre 100% comfortable with yourself, the nerves go away... 

 But I woke up this morning to a (well-meaning) comment on my Tik Tok that said, ‚ÄúHaving a conversation with you must be so insightful. Your friends are so lucky to be in your circle.‚Äù 

 And now, I feel the need for every word I say to be insightful. 

 What if I want to talk about Joe Burrow and Cincinnati Bengals? 

 Or my fear of fat people? 

 Or how I‚Äôm currently seated next to the line to order a coffee, and some dickhead is standing too close to me? 

 If you couldn‚Äôt tell by now, my newsletter is more for me than it is for you. 

 You‚Äôre just an innocent bystander getting hit in the crossfire of the combative thoughts in my head. 

 Thanks for reading, and as always lmk if you liked this one {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 Have a great Saturday (if the day of the week means anything to you), 

 Ben 

 P.S. I wrote to you yesterday about how I‚Äôm considering offering coaching for agency owners that want to make more money with fewer clients and fewer headaches. 

 If you fall into that bucket, can you do me a quick favor? 

 Simply reply and let me know what type of agency you run and what your biggest challenge is with your business right now. 

 You can write 6 words or a full novel, thanks in advance :) 

 ‚Äã

subject: it's getting late and i miss you
body:
I‚Äôm 34,000 feet in the air as I type this on my phone. 

 If there‚Äôs one reason to make multi-8 or 9- figures, it‚Äôs to avoid airports and only fly private. 

 Smelly fat people. 

 Idiots standing still in the middle of the aisle. 

 And NPCs standing up right when the plane lands as if their stomach rolls are gonna magically propel the plane to the gate. 

 This is the first time I‚Äôve flown in a bit actually, and I‚Äôve decided that I‚Äôm only sitting in first class from here on out. 

 Although I still had to deal with the airport people, the power trip of walking past the line at the gate, and sitting down in 1D is 100% worth the extra money. 

 I‚Äôll stop being a judgmental asshole for a sec and share something that‚Äôs been on my mind recently. 

 Your eyes are a gateway into your soul. 

 You know when you meet someone that you can just tell us actually ALIVE? 

 They‚Äôre not just going through the motions of life or suppressing their true self. 

 They‚Äôre attacking every day with ferocity. 

 I‚Äôve started to take note of this whenever I‚Äôm in public. 

 Walking around the airport is mostly an energy drain. 

 Most people look like life‚Äôs beaten every ounce of creativity and passion out of them. 

 I swear you can see it just by looking people in the eyes. 

 Here‚Äôs my hypothesis: 

 Every time you suppress a desire, it sacrifices a piece of your soul. 

 Working a job, you hate, staying in unhealthy relationships, not approaching the pretty brunette that you saw at lunch 2 months ago( miss her man). 

 These things eat at you. 

 At the end of last week's podcast, I was asked the following question‚Ä¶ 

 ‚ÄúIf you had to leave the world with one message, what would it be?‚Äù 

 Immediately I said, ‚Äúfollow your curiosity.‚Äù 

 I was never super religious growing up, but I‚Äôve always noticed these signals where I‚Äôm simply called to follow an inclination. 

 You‚Äôre drawn to ideas, people, and places for a reason. 

 And you have the choice‚Ä¶ 

 Do you ignore those desires and sacrifice your soul? 

 Or do you follow your curiosity no matter how intimidating it may be? 

 Just touched down in LA. 

 Hope you‚Äôre having a good hump day {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Stealing my rich neighbors Porsche in Beverly Hills
body:
I just got a sugary iced latte from the most liberal coffee shop I could find in Beverly Hills as I start this email from the balcony at my Air BnB. 

 I‚Äôm in a nice residential neighborhood, and my across-the-street neighbor just pulled out in a black Porsche boxter with red rims. 

 His driveway looks like a luxury car shop. 

 Along with the boxter, he has a white 911 turbo, a new range rover, and a vintage beige Mercedes. 

 He drove the 911 yesterday morning. 

 I‚Äôve become so accustomed to the sweltering heat in Miami that I‚Äôm wearing a hoodie on this cloudy 72-degree morning. 

 The energy here is quite different from Brickell. 

 It‚Äôs more laid back, and there seems to be a constant blue undertone in the sky. 

 As I think about ways to transition this email to a life lesson, my mind is drawing a blank. 

 I‚Äôve been stuck for the last few minutes staring at this blinking cursor. 

 Whenever I feel like my well of original thoughts has run dry, there‚Äôs one thing that revitalizes my creativity. 

 Movement. 

 I‚Äôll go on a walk, work out, or simply do anything to get myself away from my computer and back in touch with the thoughts in my head. 

 When I sit at my desk and try to force creativity, it usually eludes me. 

 The harder you try, the harder it gets. 

 I‚Äôve realized that much of the progress I‚Äôve made in business has been in times when I don‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôm trying that hard. 

 I‚Äôll get obsessed with something for a period of time, and the work starts to feel like play. 

 I don‚Äôt have to force myself to sit at my desk ‚Äì I simply do it because it‚Äôs the obvious thing that I want to do at that moment. 

 This trait seems to be a blessing and a curse. 

 It‚Äôs made it very difficult for me to do things that I don‚Äôt want to do. 

 In school, I absolutely hated homework. 

 I‚Äôd do anything and everything that I could to avoid it. 

 And in business, when there are tasks that I don‚Äôt feel like tackling, I‚Äôll procrastinate until the final deadline. 

 Even if it‚Äôs something that literally takes me 3 minutes to knock out, it feels like a herculean feat. 

 Obviously, you can‚Äôt always neglect the things you're not excited about. 

 But there‚Äôs definitely a balance between doing work that allows you to enter a flow state and swimming upstream for too long and going in the wrong direction. 

 Not sure if that makes sense, but I have a handful of things that I‚Äôve been putting off this morning that I need to go do. 

 They‚Äôll take me about 3 minutes each. 

 I decided to write this email first because it‚Äôs something I actually felt motivated to do. 

 Weird how that works. 

 Talk soon, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Check out my recent podcast with Grant Lanin and Cardinal Mason if you haven‚Äôt already ‚Äã 

 P.P.S. Reply if you liked this one (if you feel motivated enough to do so)

subject: skipping my flight to write this
body:
The doorman told me I should leave now for my 11:59am (PST) flight. 

 He said it‚Äôs one of the year's busiest travel days, and LAX will be a madhouse. 

 I don‚Äôt buy it. 

 I‚Äôll leave in an hour or three. 

 (if I miss this flight to write this email, it‚Äôs 100% your fault). 

 I have too many things to write about today. 

 Instead of writing about one singular idea like a normal person, I‚Äôm gonna go rapid-fire. 

 You ready? 

 - I met a kind, early 30‚Äôs woman at the bar at Catch. 

 I told her I liked her bag, and we started chatting for a few. She‚Äôs a famous model/actress (isn‚Äôt everyone), and I‚Äôm thinking about asking her to fund my lifestyle. 

 - Have you ever had New Zealand licorice? 

 Go to Trader Joe's right now and get some if you haven‚Äôt. 

 - I kind of want to get a place in LA. 

 Only for a few months out of the year, so I don‚Äôt end up dying my hair purple and cutting off my [redacted]. 

 Do I actually want to spend more time here, or am I idealizing it because it‚Äôs new to me? 

 - Business is easy once you‚Äôre good at making other people money. I‚Äôm gonna repeat that for the people in the back. 

 Business is easy once you‚Äôre good at making other people money. 

 Everyone tries to play the client acquisition game, but nobody plays the get results game (for lack of a better term). 

 I have inbound leads coming to me, following up with me till I finally reply (because I hate getting on calls), and then they transfer 5 figures to my bank account after a 20-minute phone call‚Ä¶ Because they know I will make them wayyy more than that. 

 Keep your client acquisition systems dorks. 

 - I was originally going to leave yesterday, but I moved my flight, and first class was full. 

 I‚Äôm in 12C like a peasant. 

 - You guys kept harassing me, so I‚Äôm finally building a course about funnels. 

 It‚Äôs literally gonna be the bible for understanding types of funnels and when to use them. 

 And I‚Äôm gonna charge you an arm and a leg for it (lmk if there are some specific things you want to learn). 

 Okay, I think I actually have to go now. 

 The doorman is gonna be mad at me when I walk out of here an hour after he said I should leave. 

 I still have to pack up my stuff and go get a coffee. 

 Let‚Äôs see if I make it to Miami. 

 Deuces, 

 - Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: waste 3 min of your day with me
body:
I wrote one-fifth of an email to you yesterday. 

 It was about how I‚Äôd been spending too much time on my phone and how to get out of the ‚Äúsocial media vortex.‚Äù 

 Then I got distracted by my phone and stopped writing. 

 The most honest people are hypocrites. 

 I‚Äôve realized it‚Äôd be a really good idea to start taking more of my own advice that I write to you about in these emails. 

 The other day I told you how I‚Äôm creating a course about building funnels. 

 It‚Äôd be wise for me to spend the next couple of weeks talking more about business and priming you for when I drop the offer. 

 But I don‚Äôt want to. 

 Instead, I‚Äôll write about how I finally took 47 seconds out of my day to hire a maid to clean my apartment. 

 It was something I‚Äôd been contemplating for weeks, and it‚Äôs one of the best decisions I‚Äôve ever made. 

 She even got the stains out of my windows from months ago when I decided to launch blueberries at the glass (story for another day). 

 Remember the doorman I told you about at my hotel in LA? ( context if you‚Äôre new here ) 

 He told me I was gonna miss my flight if I didn‚Äôt leave right away. 

 I waited another hour and then left. 

 Turns out he was a paranoid liar. 

 I got through security in 3 minutes and had to stand there for an hour before my flight boarded. 

 And to make it worse, I had to sit next to a very large woman on the plane who wouldn‚Äôt stop trying to teach me bad words in sign language. 

 I was nice to her at first, and that was a mistake because then she attempted to give me her life story throughout the flight. 

 It got to the point where I was basically pretending to be deaf (hence the sign language). 

 I wouldn‚Äôt wish that experience on my worst enemy. 

 It‚Äôs a cloudy day here in Miami, and my energy is low because of it. 

 This has been a super jumpy email, and if you‚Äôre still reading, I applaud you. 

 Maybe you‚Äôre waiting for a life lesson or something to take away from this. 

 You‚Äôre gonna be waiting for a while because I‚Äôve got nothing for you. 

 Sometimes I just want to brain-dump, and this was one of those times. 

 Maybe I‚Äôll teach you how to solve world hunger and make a gazillion dollars tomorrow. 

 Thanks for wasting your time with me today, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Outside bleeding in the rain waiting for you
body:
The back of my left sock is bloody again. 

 It‚Äôs a gloomy morning. 

 The sky is dark grey, and constant gusts of wind indicate it‚Äôs about to start raining. 

 I lace up my shoes and look out the window. 

 ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gonna pour. You should just stay inside and work out here instead,‚Äù I think to myself. 

 I go back and forth for a few minutes before deciding not to cancel this run. 

 If I get caught in the rain, I‚Äôll be okay. 

 Four minutes later, I‚Äôm outside running, and the wind is picking up. 

 The people around me are hustling to their cars. 

 It‚Äôs not directly raining yet, but somehow, it feels like I‚Äôm getting hit with raindrops from the side. 

 Considering I‚Äôm running by a river, I guess it‚Äôs safe to assume the water is being blown from there. 

 My left shoe is starting to rub against the back of my ankle. 

 I already have a blister there from the same thing happening the other day. 

 As I continue along, it starts drizzling. 

 At this point, I‚Äôm honestly excited about the torrential downpour. 

 But as I get closer to the end of my route, it still hasn‚Äôt started. 

 I think my blister ripped open, but I can‚Äôt feel the pain because I‚Äôm hunting down the man in a blue shirt about 150 feet ahead of me. 

 I fly past him, and not too long after, I‚Äôm back at my apartment. 

 That‚Äôs actually when I tried to start this email, but I got distracted by a call from a friend. 

 I then tried to continue it at the coffee shop, but it was far too crowded for me to be able to hear my own thoughts. 

 You might be thinking, ‚ÄúBen, is there a reason you just described your morning in vivid detail to me, or are you wasting my time again?‚Äù 

 Oh yeah, I had a metaphor for you. 

 Long story short, the ‚Äúrain‚Äù is a future obstacle that‚Äôs keeping you from attacking a goal. 

 You don‚Äôt start a business because you‚Äôre worried about paying taxes (lol). 

 You don‚Äôt ask her out because you‚Äôre worried that you‚Äôll look like an idiot. 

 You don't step in the ring because you're worried you'll get hit in the mouth. 

 It‚Äôs a tale as old as time. 

 But once you start running toward the things that scare you, you realize that the rain isn‚Äôt as bad as you thought it‚Äôd be. 

 Maybe you end up with a bloody ankle, but you don‚Äôt care because you‚Äôre finally in the game. 

 It's a feeling of aliveness that money can‚Äôt buy. 

 Don‚Äôt rob yourself of this gift ‚Äì if you get caught in the rain, you‚Äôll be okay. 

 Thx for reading. 

 As always, reply if you made it down here <3 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Advice for {{ subscriber.first_name }}
body:
I need to clean this computer screen. 

 I‚Äôm outside on my balcony, and the combination of the sun and dust on my laptop is making it difficult to see. 

 Maybe I‚Äôll just buy a new computer instead. 

 I have a friend that doesn‚Äôt do laundry. He just cycles through a dozen new shirts every few weeks. 

 About a year and a half ago, I read Jordan Peterson‚Äôs book ‚Äú12 Rules For Life‚Äù ‚Äì and by ‚Äúread,‚Äù I mean I skimmed about 70% of it. 

 One of his first rules was ‚Äútreat yourself like someone you‚Äôre responsible for helping.‚Äù 

 At the time of reading that, I didn‚Äôt think much of it. 

 But for whatever reason, it‚Äôs on my mind as I sit here writing to you. 

 You have all the answers, you‚Äôre just letting your emotions get in the way. 

 You know how to make more money. 

 You know how to stop overthinking. 

 You know how to get over your fears. 

 And if someone in your exact situation came to you and asked for advice, you‚Äôd tell them exactly what they need to hear ‚Äì even if they don‚Äôt want to hear it. 

 But when it comes to ourselves, it‚Äôs like we have blinders on. 

 We pretend not to know the answers to our problems because this state of ‚Äúuncertainty‚Äù becomes comfortable‚Ä¶ 

 Well, at least more comfortable than the real uncertainty that would occur if we changed what actually needs to be changed. 

 That make sense? 

 A lack of clarity isn‚Äôt the issue ‚Äì it's emotion disguised as a lack of clarity. 

 I just reread that, and I think my breakdown made this concept more confusing than it really is. 

 Long story short, take the advice you‚Äôd give to a friend in your situation. 

 It‚Äôs easy to come up with a solution when it isn‚Äôt clouded with fear or doubt ‚Äì just pure logic. 

 This was pretty jumbled, but at the end of the day, it‚Äôs really just advice to myself. 

 Maybe I should take it. 

 Good luck, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

body:
Hi {{ subscriber.first_name }}, sorry I haven‚Äôt been emailing you much recently. 

 I have a good excuse. 

 Do you notice how traveling, trying a new hobby, or going somewhere new unlocks thoughts you didn‚Äôt previously have access to? 

 If you get stuck in the same routine and virtually live the same day every day, your ideas will usually remain constant. 

 It‚Äôs not a bad thing ‚Äì but for the sake of creativity, I think it‚Äôs good to switch things up every now and then. 

 That leads me to the lack of emails as of late. 

 I‚Äôve been on a mini-bender. 

 Up until now, my well of creativity had run dry. 

 I‚Äôd sit down to write and type ‚Äúgood morning‚Äù or ‚Äúhey‚Äù and then immediately get stuck. 

 I literally have 4 emails in the drafts from this week where I didn‚Äôt make it past the first line. 

 Usually, when I feel a creative lull, I go for a walk, and it fixes me. 

 But not this time. 

 I concluded that more drastic measures were necessary. 

 Aside from the bender, I started taking boxing lessons, playing tennis, I‚Äôm 5 days off the zyns, and I‚Äôm moving to a 2-bed apartment because I want an office. 

 I think it worked. 

 The lesson here? 

 When you get bored, simply change everything. 

 Don‚Äôt take that too seriously. 

 That advice probably isn‚Äôt the most practically sound, but understand that your environment will dictate your thoughts 

 When things feel off, and you don‚Äôt know why, maybe you need to shake the snowglobe. 

 Ok, I have a lot of work to do today, so this‚Äôll end here. 

 I‚Äôm rusty, and my computer's light is hurting my brain. 

 Hopefully I‚Äôll write to you tomorrow, but I can‚Äôt make any promises. 

 Have a good Sunday friend, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Here‚Äôs a clip of me spewing nonsense to a 6‚Äô8 woman ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: moon blue coffee black
body:
I‚Äôm starting this from my phone outside of Starbucks. 

 A cold brew sits in front of me, but something looks different. 

 Instead of the usual sugary vanilla cream that creates a smooth, lightly brown colored milkshake‚Ä¶. it‚Äôs‚Ä¶. black. 

 ‚Ä¶ 

 I started a 48-hour fast last night. 

 Why? 

 Something to do with a full blue supermoon. 

 And so that I could tell you I‚Äôm doing it. 

 I‚Äôve got some thoughts today. 

 Holy fuck it‚Äôs windy I‚Äôm gonna walk home - be right back. 

 Ok, I made it. 

 Anyway, I was about to tell you about procrastination . 

 You familiar with that word? 

 Me too. 

 I‚Äôve been procrastinating building the course I told you I was gonna build 2 weeks ago. 

 I was procrastinating taking boxing lessons for a year. 

 I procrastinated finding a couch for my new apartment that I‚Äôm moving into on Friday, but luckily, I caught a hail mary and found what I was looking for yesterday on Instagram. 

 I‚Äôm even procrastinating doing other work by writing this right now. 

 All of the reasons you tell yourself why you have to put something off until later are usually a facade. 

 They‚Äôre a pastiche. A simulacrum. A Potemkin village. They‚Äôre not the real McCoy. 

 The best example I can think of to illustrate what I‚Äôm trying to tell you is cold approach. 

 You see a girl. You want to go talk to her (if you‚Äôre a woman reading this, replace the girl with me, and you‚Äôre nervous to come say hi because I‚Äôm so famous). 

 Your brain starts feeding you objections. 

 ‚ÄúI need to learn how to approach girls first.‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to say.‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúI actually like men.‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúMy shoe is untied.‚Äù 

 Aaaand she walks past you. 

 The singular action you needed to take to succeed was to walk up and say hello. 

 But you found all these scapegoats for why that couldn‚Äôt happen. 

 Odds are this exact situation is happening in multiple areas of your life. 

 A big one for me was content. 

 I told myself for a while that I‚Äôd start making more content once I was making $10k per month. 

 But I didn‚Äôt really put effort into growing on TikTok until I started making over $50k/mo. 

 And I‚Äôm still not making YouTube videos like I wanted to. 

 The thing is, I‚Äôm getting a dopamine hit by telling you this right now. 

 It gives me an illusionary feeling that I‚Äôm moving closer to making YT vids. 

 The same thing happens when you tell your friends you‚Äôre starting 75 hard soon or you‚Äôre gonna start training for a marathon. 

 You get brownie points in your brain but don‚Äôt get closer to the goal. 

 Tricky territory to be in. 

 The solution is actually to do the singular action. 

 The unsexy action that you‚Äôve known all along that you needed to do. 

 Like set up a camera and start talking. 

 Or walk up to her and say, ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm {{ subscriber.first_name }}.‚Äù 

 That‚Äôs when you stop fantasizing success (like a cuck). 

 Love you, and happy blue full superhuman moon or whatever, 

 Ben 

 P.S. reply if you read all 510 words <3 

 ‚Äã

subject: i didn't eat for 2 days
body:
Start: 11:32am 

 I‚Äôm 40 hours into this fast and concluded that food is a scam. 

 This is so easy that I watched a cooking show on netflix last night to try to make it harder. 

 I have a call in 30 minutes, so I have to be quick. 

 I‚Äôm sitting outside of Starbucks, casually sipping another black cold brew. 

 The dude I see here every day who drives an R8 with ‚Äúforexxx‚Äù on the license plate is sitting across from me, getting a tarot card reading from a pretty girl. 

 Astrology chicks > 

 You guys seemed to like yesterday‚Äôs email, which gave me a lot of dopamine. 

 I‚Äôm moving tomorrow, and I still haven‚Äôt called a mover. Ugh. 

 There‚Äôs a new grey Ford Bronco parked to my left. 

 The new models seem to get hate, but I really like them. 

 If I get a place in LA, maybe I‚Äôll get a 911 and a Bronco‚Ä¶ 

 Stop: 11:47am 

 Start again: 10:52pm 

 A lot has changed since I left off here. 

 I broke my fast a few hours ago, found a mover, and even started thinking about packing up my belongings. 

 Oh, and I bought a rose gold olive dial Rolex Presidential today. 

 I didn‚Äôt mean to, but I finished my work early for the day and had nothing else to do other than drive 40 minutes to my boy Jamie and buy a new watch. 

 I don‚Äôt want you to think I‚Äôm flexing (even though I am). 

 I‚Äôm sharing this with you because I noticed this purchase felt different. 

 You know all the things that you envision coming with your ‚Äúdream‚Äù life? The car, the girl, the house, the status, etc‚Ä¶ 

 I remember thinking to myself at one point, ‚ÄúWow, I‚Äôll be so cool once I have Rolex ‚Äì or Audi ‚Äì or move to Miami.‚Äù 

 And every time I got one of those things, they lost their lust quickly. 

 I‚Äôd buy them expecting some grand feeling of accomplishment, only to be let down once the lust wore off. 

 But today, I didn‚Äôt feel that. 

 I bought the watch because I wanted it ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt expect it to make me feel any better about myself or change my perception of who I am. 

 Dropping those illusionary expectations allowed me to find a different level of appreciation. 

 Everything that you own, you‚Äôve earned in one way or another. 

 You have a right to be proud of that. 

 But understand that the things are not you. They are not a place to source for your own self-worth. And they are not much more than a subtle e xternal trophy for winning internal battles. 

 Fuck I gotta start packing for tomorrow. 

 Goodnight, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I went on the Stick Talk podcast recently if you wanna check it out ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: I fought off a pack of wolves for wifi (story)
body:
I‚Äôm sitting at the counter at my lunch spot in Brickell. 

 Yes, I now call it ‚Äúmy‚Äù spot because it basically is. 

 Some chubby dork in a red tank top is standing right over my shoulder waiting for his food, and I‚Äôm seconds away from backhanding him. 

 I hope he‚Äôs reading this because he‚Äôs close enough to see it. 

 I will hit you buddy. 

 If you‚Äôre not brand new here and you actually read my emails, you‚Äôd know I moved a few floors up to a 2-bed apt the other day. 

 Moving sucks. 

 I swear it‚Äôs a less strenuous process for me to make $50k+ on an hour-long webinar with a client than it is to lug around boxes and disassemble/reassemble furniture. 

 Mr. Red Tank Top just left. 

 I‚Äôm sitting at this counter because I don‚Äôt have wifi in my new spot until 2pm. 

 And I had to fight tooth and nail even to get it that soon. 

 AT&T is the only provider you can use in my building. 

 I thought setting up new wifi would be as simple as carrying up the box from my old apartment to the new one, but that wasn‚Äôt the case. 

 Oscar (support agent) told me over the phone that they had to transfer and activate the signal to the new unit and then have a ‚Äútechnician‚Äù come out to verify it. 

 But before that could even happen, they needed the lady who lived in the unit before me to cancel her account to be able to transfer the signal. 

 I thought that was bullshit, but Oscar implored me that it was the quickest solution and that he‚Äôd reach out to the previous tenant and let me know when she answers. 

 So I did what any rational human would do and built an army of Phillipino (I‚Äôm guessing) AT&T agents. 

 Right when I got off the phone with Oscar, I called again, got placed with a different agent, explained the situation, and asked them to reach out to the lady. 

 I did this a handful of times until I had 5 or 6 agents literally harassing this woman. 

 For the next 16 hours‚Ä¶ nothing. 

 I called again and told them the lady was dead so there was no way of contacting her, but still they insisted that it was the only solution. 

 About 30 minutes later, John (definitely not his real name), whom I‚Äôd just told that the lady died, called me back. 

 ‚ÄúGood news Ben, I got a hold of her and canceled her account. We‚Äôll have a technician come out on Thursday, and you‚Äôll be all setup.‚Äù 

 First, I told him I loved him for tracking down the lady and laughed at how she miraculously must‚Äôve been revived from the dead. 

 And then I said, ‚ÄúThursday isn‚Äôt gonna happen; what can you do here.‚Äù 

 Those nine words saved me 4 days of no wifi. 

 John (who is now my next of kin in my will) put me on hold for 30 seconds, pulled some Vudu magic, and said, ‚ÄúOk, your signal will be back tomorrow at 2pm. You‚Äôll just need to plug the router into the wall.‚Äù 

 I‚Äôm telling you this whole story for a reason. 

 There is always a way to get what you want. 

 Whether you‚Äôre building a business, trying to get into an exclusive venue, or want to connect with someone important‚Ä¶ 

 If you‚Äôre persistent enough, you will find a way. 

 Even if it means employing half a dozen Phillipino VAs. 

 Or harassing staff to get an omelet at 3am (inside joke - if you know, you know). 

 Go harass an old lady today, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Check out my recent podcast if you haven't already (It‚Äôs a banger ‚Äì I think. But I could also be spewing nonsense ‚Äì what‚Äôs the difference?) 

 ‚Äã

subject: The eyes chico
body:
I was walking around my house like an idiot 3 minutes ago, trying to find my computer to write this email. 

 It was hidden in plain sight, but I didn‚Äôt know where to look because it wasn‚Äôt in any of the usual spots. 

 Lesson in there. 

 On my walk back from soybucks this morning, I was trying to make a TikTok about how money means everything and nothing at the same time. 

 The video sucked because it‚Äôs easier for me to work out concepts like this in writing first, so let‚Äôs do it together, shall we? 

 Money gives you the autonomy to be who you really are. 

 My friend Mason has said something like this before. 

 The peace of mind in knowing you‚Äôre good financially allows you time to ‚Äúside quest.‚Äù 

 And in these side quests, you‚Äôre gonna learn more about yourself and the world than you would if your only pursuit is money. 

 I neglected this for a while, but it‚Äôs how you start to live in a way that genuinely aligns with your soul. 

 And when you do that, you become magnetic. 

 This sounds woo-woo, but it‚Äôs true-true. Ok pretend I didn‚Äôt say that. 

 You can see this in people's eyes ‚Äì It‚Äôs a glimpse into their soul. 

 The eyes chico, they never lie. 

 It‚Äôs why you get a weird feeling about someone when you meet them, but you can‚Äôt explain it, so you just say something's ‚Äúoff‚Äù about them. 

 It‚Äôs why you know she‚Äôs a good girl at heart even though she‚Äôs at the club every night (miss her). 

 And it‚Äôs why you naturally gravitate towards some people more than others. 

 They‚Äôre either truly themselves, and it makes you want to be around them more, or they‚Äôre pretending, and you can feel it on a subconscious level. 

 Here‚Äôs a litmus test for you: How many things do you do just because you want to? 

 There‚Äôs no real angle or motive; it just feels like something you were called towards. 

 That‚Äôs why I make content. That‚Äôs why I write these emails. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm boxing. 

 These are just mini-side quests that I feel obligated to tackle. 

 At some point maybe I‚Äôll make money from the content/emails (if I ever get around to building a course), but as of right now, I‚Äôm doing it for free. 

 And I‚Äôll keep doing it even if I never make a dollar from it. 

 Find the things in your life that you would do every day even if the only benefit is quenching an urge that‚Äôs floating in the back of your mind. 

 Because honestly, doing that will make you feel better than money ever could. 

 But you need money to allow yourself the luxury. 

 Thanks for working this out with me. 

 Have a good Tuesday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Here's me shamelessly plugging a recent podcast I went on for the 36th email in a row ‚Äã 

 P.P.S. Reply if you liked this one <3 

 ‚Äã

subject: Sorry i forgot about you {{ subscriber.first_name }}
body:
There‚Äôs a new (potentially) homeless guy next to me this time. 

 He‚Äôs somehow acquired a phone, Lululemon bag, and a watermelon ice puff bar. 

 I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever seen a more accurate representation of the word ‚Äúdisheveled‚Äù until seeing this guy. 

 He‚Äôs not in horrible shape, and honestly I hope my hair looks as good as his when I‚Äôm his age (probably in his 40‚Äôs or 50‚Äôs) 

 But he just looks‚Ä¶ disheveled. 

 Other than that, he‚Äôs been arguing with someone on the phone for the last 7 minutes. 

 Except his phone is sitting face down across the table, and he definitely doesn‚Äôt have air pods or headphones. 

 So I guess the ‚Äúsomeone‚Äù on the phone is actually another person(?) in his head‚Ä¶ 

 The schizophrenics fascinate me. 

 Do they have access to a different dimension? 

 Are they enlightened?? 

 Am I the crazy one??? 

 I‚Äôve missed you, by the way. 

 It‚Äôs been a week since we last spoke, and I‚Äôm starting to feel guilty. 

 Gonna walk home real quick because I don‚Äôt know where I want to take this email yet. 

 Ok, I‚Äôm at my desk in my new office, and my mind is still blank. 

 Well, blank isn‚Äôt the right word ‚Äì I have infinite half-baked ideas I want to write about. 

 Do you ever think about how you would live your life if you were completely detached from the outcome of your actions? 

 Not in a mid-evil barbaric way where you have no consequences, so you run around like it‚Äôs GTA and kill people when they cut you off in traffic. 

 But in a way where you do the things you want to do without giving any value to the voice in your head that tells you it‚Äôs scared. 

 You simply take more shots. 

 I saw this Theo Von video where he was giving advice to his 20-year-old self, and he said, ‚ÄúAsk her out.‚Äù 

 Whatever ‚Äúshe‚Äù is ‚Äì a business, a new city, a random inclination, or a real human. 

 I think that‚Äôs where you find fulfillment. 

 You just live in complete alignment with your soul. 

 Your doubts, fears, and worries likely don‚Äôt go away, but you don‚Äôt give any power to them. You run your life‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre not on autopilot. 

 Do this enough, and maybe you‚Äôll be so enlightened that you end up disheveled, sitting outside of Starbucks, talking to the voice in your head‚Ä¶ 

 Or maybe you end up becoming exactly who you were meant to be. 

 Missed you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 And if you‚Äôre new here, welcome. I know you‚Äôre probably wondering what you subscribed to, and maybe your finger is hovering over the unsubscribe button. 

 I was gonna offer an explanation, but honestly this email is long enough. So if you want to leave, it was nice knowing you. 

 Yep, schizophrenia is definitely contagious. 

 Have a good Tuesday and reply if you liked this email <3 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: How to cure everything
body:
I‚Äôm convinced everyone has anxiety and/or depression. 

 It‚Äôs just a matter of what degree they listen to it. 

 Keep telling yourself bad things, and you will literally program yourself to always think that way. 

 Those constant negative thoughts end up shaping your entire identity and perception of yourself. 

 Once a belief is accepted as an unchangeable fact, our malleability gets diminished. 

 ‚ÄúI am an anxious person‚Äù or ‚ÄúI am a depressed person‚Äù gets repeated until it‚Äôs deeply embedded into someone's psyche. 

 And on a long enough time horizon, that person forgets that there was ever another option. 

 An option where they didn't have to give power to their negative thoughts. 

 Or where they understood they could decide who they are. 

 And as long as they don‚Äôt suppress their true desires, that evil voice gets a little bit quieter. 

 I don‚Äôt think it ever goes away ‚Äì it just takes a backseat. 

 Even when you‚Äôre living your ‚Äúdream life,‚Äù sometimes you‚Äôll wake up on the wrong side of the bed. 

 You‚Äôll never be completely immune to occasional highs and lows. 

 Every now and then, you‚Äôll question everything about your life just hours after thinking you‚Äôre invincible. 

 That fluctuation is inevitable. It‚Äôs natural. 

 And accepting it is part of the solution. 

 It can be as simple as shifting from ‚ÄúI feel like shit right now, and I hate this‚Äù to ‚ÄúI feel like shit right now, and that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù 

 Of course, there are times when a negative situation shouldn‚Äôt be accepted and instead used as fuel for change. 

 But I‚Äôm talking about the other times where you just seem to hit a wall for no rhyme or reason. 

 That happens to me all the time. The same goes for almost all of my friends, so I imagine it happens to you. 

 The secret is discerning when a feeling needs to be accepted and when it needs to inspire change. 

 Before dropping out of college a few years ago, sometimes I‚Äôd quietly get anxious. 

 Although my life looked fun on the surface, I could simply feel that path wasn‚Äôt right for me (emphasis on feel, not think). 

 There was objectively no fulfillment. 

 I went out all the time and ‚Äúcelebrated‚Äù although I had nothing to celebrate ‚Äì it was an escape from a life with a lack of purpose, ambition, or improvement. 

 If I didn‚Äôt change, it would‚Äôve eaten me alive. 

 On the contrary, I‚Äôm now in a position that I was enamored by for years. 

 But that doesn‚Äôt stop me from occasionally questioning if I‚Äôm an absolute idiot and if I should move across the country to live on a farm with Amish people and cows. 

 Odds are that‚Äôs just a natural low ‚Äì in fact, I know it is because it feels different. 

 So when those types of thoughts come up, I try not to give them power. I accept them as they are ‚Äì the devil who will always be there on my shoulder. 

 And that‚Äôs okay. 

 Hope this all made sense. Let me know if you made it down here. 

 Have a good day, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: I'm going broke
body:
I turn 23 tomorrow. 

 I‚Äôm expecting to receive a bouquet of flowers from each of you. 

 That‚Äôs 8,395 days I‚Äôve been alive, and I still botched the spelling of the word ‚Äúbouquet‚Äù so hard that even autocorrect didn‚Äôt know what I was trying to say. 

 I had to type it into Google and play with the spelling until I got close enough. 

 Recently I‚Äôve been spending 3-4x my normal expenses. 

 Between my upgraded apartment, buying clothes, watches, shoes, going out, and the very expensive short Jewish chiropractor that I put on a retainer to come to my place once a week‚Ä¶ 

 Life hasn‚Äôt been cheap. 

 It‚Äôs been a bit nerve-wracking but also freeing. 

 I‚Äôm becoming detached from money yet realizing that I need more and more of it. 

 It‚Äôs shown me how easy it would be to spend $50k/mo+ on lifestyle consistently, which has given me a renewed sense of excitement for working. 

 For the last few months, there weren‚Äôt many things business-wise that I actually wanted to do. 

 Even when I hit new financial milestones, they felt meaningless because it was just a bigger number on a screen. 

 But now I can see the true utility of more money. 

 I know what I‚Äôd do if I tripled my income and now have a real incentive to get there. 

 I‚Äôm not telling you to go spend all your money but rather to pay attention to the way that you feel. 

 When life gets dull, it usually means it‚Äôs time to shake things up. 

 And dull doesn‚Äôt just mean boring; it can actually be the opposite. 

 After partying all the time for 2 years in college, that lifestyle eventually lost its luster. 

 That‚Äôs when I dropped out, moved to Mexico, and basically was in ‚Äúmonk mode‚Äù for 3 months. 

 Anyway, as I sit here on my balcony, I can‚Äôt help but think about how much can change in one year. 

 Put real effort into anything for 365 days, and you will come out on the other side with a completely new perspective. 

 A year ago I‚Äôd just moved to Miami ‚Äì nervous about upgrading my expenses and in a very different spot mentally. 

 Above all ‚Äì the biggest thing I‚Äôve been able to reignite in myself this past year is trust. 

 I follow my gut. 

 I don‚Äôt do things I don‚Äôt want to. 

 And I say what‚Äôs actually on my mind. 

 This alone has made me feel like I know myself way better, and feels good to live in alignment with your soul. 

 I encourage you to start paying attention when you suppress what you really want to do or say. 

 Start with small things, take baby steps, and it‚Äôll create a ripple effect. 

 Do that for a year, and who knows where you‚Äôll be. 

 Thx for the bouquet in advance, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Here‚Äôs a video of me talking about living in alignment with your soul ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: Your wake up call
body:
I‚Äôm sitting in the hotel lobby, drinking a coffee that the liberal barista just made for me. 

 She‚Äôs actually sweet and made a hell of a latte, so I‚Äôm gonna refrain from saying anything hurtful. 

 I just got an email from the water company telling me I need to call and update my address. I‚Äôve been putting off making this 4-minute phone call for 3 weeks now. 

 I‚Äôll probably continue to procrastinate until I wake up one day and can‚Äôt turn on the faucet to brush my teeth. 

 Today is my first full day being 23 years old. 

 Birthdays are interesting because they are meaningless unless you give them meaning. 

 It‚Äôs not like you instantly reach a new level of wisdom or get your first grey hair the day after you hit a new number. 

 The only difference is the perception. 

 If a 29-year-old degenerate wakes up on his 30th birthday and decides that he‚Äôs now too old to smoke weed all day and throw together 19 leg parlays in hopes that $6 will turn into $800, and he changes his actions accordingly; then the arbitrary number now has meaning. 

 I‚Äôm feeling this right now, too. 

 The perceived gap between 22 and 23 is rather large in my head. 

 At 22, the bar‚Äôs pretty low ‚Äì simply having my own apartment, a nice car, and smelling nice seemed to be impressive. 

 At 23, I feel more pressure. 

 $500k-$1m annually is cute. Enough to feel rich without being anywhere close to it. 

 My audience should be bigger. I should be employing more people. 

 It‚Äôs honestly embarrassing that I don‚Äôt have a supercar. 

 Why don‚Äôt I have $10m liquid? 

 I‚Äôm kind of kidding right now, but I‚Äôm really not. 

 I feel like I‚Äôm only tapping into 1/100th of my potential, and having to say a new arbitrary number when someone asks my age is a reminder of this. 

 Maybe you‚Äôre in the same boat, and you know that deep down. 

 But you‚Äôre waiting until it gets bad enough. 

 You wake up at 30 and realize your bucket list is full of unchecked boxes‚Ä¶ 

 Your bank account hits zero‚Ä¶ 

 You put on so much weight that you can‚Äôt see your toes when you look down‚Ä¶ 

 Maybe you‚Äôll change then, maybe you won‚Äôt. 

 Why do we operate this way? 

 Is an embarrassingly new low the only thing that can inspire change? 

 It can‚Äôt be. 

 Maybe the answer is to give ourselves a manufactured wake-up call instead of waiting for the arbitrary one. 

 If you're waiting for a slap in the face, here‚Äôs your sign to stop half-assing life while pretending to give maximum effort so you don‚Äôt have to accept the fact that you‚Äôre neglecting your true potential. 

 I‚Äôm gonna call the water company and update my address. 

 Happy Saturday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. First - thx for the bday wishes yesterday <3. Second - reply if you liked this one 

 ‚Äã

subject: There's a hornets nest in my bedroom
body:
There's a pink a pink box outside of my apartment door. 

 I can read the text on the side of the box facing me as I get closer, which reads "cupcakes." 

 Do I have a secret admirer? 

 Was one of my wives feeling generous today? 

 Is it a bomb? 

 These thoughts run through my head as I pick it up. 

 Unfortunately, none of the above is true. 

 I pick up the box and see a girls name on the delivery address. 

 The mailman must've mistaken the number 7 for a 2 and accidentally put the package at my door. 

 I take the stairs up a few floors and drop it off at her door. 

 What's a good deed if you don't tell people about it on the internet? 

 The error that the mailman made is the same error that stops people from ever being successful in business -- or anything for that matter. 

 It's the thing that causes unnecessary headaches at the worst possible time. 

 And it's the reason a football team can lose to a much less talented team on any given Sunday. 

 Attention to detail. 

 Today has been hectic. 

 It's felt like a thousand little problems have popped up, and it's making my head spin. 

 These issues would've been avoided with the necessary planning and organization. 

 But those two things have never been my strong suit. 

 So now I'm left with all these mini-fires that need to be extinguished. 

 And the pink cupcake box outside of my door was a perfect representation of what happens when you take your eye off the ball for a moment. 

 Don't be like me. 

 Kill the hornets before they build a nest. 

 I'm back. 

 Sorry I forgot about you {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 And if you're new here, welcome. 

 I usually write a few of these types of emails weekly, sharing little lessons I learn like this one. 

 Happy to have you onboard, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Reply if you missed me <3 

 ‚Äã

subject: It's okay to want more
body:
I often make fun of the dudes who constantly preach gratitude. 

 It can sound ingenuine as if they‚Äôre talking about how grateful or how ‚Äúat peace‚Äù they are as a way to make themselves feel better than others, which couldn‚Äôt be more hypocritical. 

 It‚Äôs similar to those who use their belief and connection to God as a way to prop up their ego. 

 But there comes a time when gratitude stares you back in the face as the only answer. 

 You‚Äôll go and get everything you previously dreamt of, and it won‚Äôt feel the way you anticipated. 

 How many times can you go through this process until you realize that you‚Äôre chasing your own tail? 

 Considering this is a topic I‚Äôve written about frequently, the answer to the question above is obvious. 

 The truth is, you will always want more. 

 There‚Äôs always gonna be another mountain to climb, hoops to jump through, and levels to ascend to. 

 And that‚Äôs okay ‚Äì as long as you accept it. 

 Acceptance is another thing that‚Äôs been on my mind recently. 

 Everything you do is a choice that you make. 

 Where you are right now, your habits, and your beliefs about yourself are all decisions that can be traced back to no one but you. 

 Unease comes from the lies that you tell yourself about your desires. 

 You say you want to change, but your actions do not correlate with change. 

 When your actions fail to follow suit with the things you claim to want, it creates a disconnect between your actual reality and your desired reality. 

 And that‚Äôs where unhappiness stems from. 

 Pause for a second and audit your current situation in life. 

 Consider your goals, routine, and beliefs. 

 Would the previous version of you from a year, 2 years, or 5 years ago be ecstatic? 

 Good. You have a lot to be grateful for. 

 But it‚Äôs also likely that you‚Äôre currently holding some desires that are causing you anxiety because your actions do not align with them. 

 It‚Äôs okay that you want more ‚Äì just ensure that you‚Äôre taking the necessary action to fulfill those desires. 

 Enough rambling for today. 

 Hope this was semi-coherent, 

 Ben

subject: Why you feel uninspired
body:
I‚Äôve spent the last 45 minutes contemplating the best route to more money and more freedom. 

 The past couple of weeks have been busy, and I haven‚Äôt had a chance to spend much quality time alone. 

 I define quality time alone as the uninterrupted moments between you and the 37 voices in your head. 

 These are the opportunities that allow you to think critically and perform a mini audit on your life. 

 I could write a whole email on the importance of prioritizing this and how most people are too sTuCk iN tHe MaTriX to ever figure out what they actually want. 

 But I‚Äôll spare you today. 

 I went on a long walk this morning and let my mind wander. 

 After my walk, I sat down outside Starbucks with a cold brew, and now I‚Äôm here writing to you. 

 Sometimes, just the act of thinking about your ‚Äúproblems‚Äù will drastically improve your mental state because you realize how silly they are. 

 There are people dying, and I‚Äôm over here stressing about how I need multi 8 figures by age 30. 

 99.9% of the world would trade everything for my ‚Äúproblems.‚Äù 

 I could go on about this, but there are already enough people who talk about gratitude on the internet. 

 While I was walking, I was thinking about a friend of mine who recently ended up in a sticky situation. 

 His 7 figure business fell apart nearly overnight, and a series of unfortunate events drastically depleted his bank account. 

 Scary right? 

 There‚Äôs a level of freedom you reach when everything goes to shit like this ‚Äî and it gives rewards the equal (or even greater) opportunity if you can get through it. 

 My friend started a new business and has been on an absolute tear for the last handful of months. 

 He‚Äôs working nonstop but just seems to be electric about the work and thinks that this new business could make him 8 figures over the next few years. 

 I‚Äôve been envious of the excitement he has for this new project and asked him if he ever has days where he doesn‚Äôt want to work. 

 I‚Äôm paraphrasing, but basically he said, ‚ÄúSure, there are, but I don‚Äôt give much power to it. The work just feels like something that has to be done.‚Äù 

 His answer makes perfect sense to me. 

 He‚Äôs not passionate about the day-to-day tasks. He‚Äôs not immune to the monotony that comes with building a business. 

 But the end goal and the vision are big enough that they carry him through the tediousness (plus the situation with his previous business adds some urgency). 

 My main takeaway here is this: 

 If the work always feels like a herculean task, you‚Äôre playing too small. 

 When you truly believe that what you‚Äôre building has the potential to be special, that passion puts you on autopilot and carries you through the boring stuff. 

 Take a walk today and think about where you want to be in 5 years. 

 Clearly envision it ‚Äì money, lifestyle, relationships, impact. 

 Do your current daily actions align with that goal? 

 If not, now you know where to start. 

 Hope you enjoyed this one. 

 Much love, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Start paying more attention to the things that come naturally to you. 

 Write down a list of the things you enjoy doing the most, and do not neglect them. 

 P.P.S. I am not a self-improvement guru or life coach. My goal is simply to share my perspective through the lens in which I view the world. Nearly nothing I tell you is a universal truth. 

 Let me know if my perspective resonates :) 

 ‚Äã

 The past couple of weeks have been busy, and I haven‚Äôt had a chance to spend much quality time alone.

subject: Step in the ring
body:
I‚Äôm gonna keep this one relatively short: 

 Listen to yourself. 

 Listen to what you feel called to do. 

 Pay attention to the things that you are resisting the most. 

 Run towards them. 

 You‚Äôll make it out on the other side and laugh about how you were ever scared or uncertain. The fear was an illusion. 

 It was a devil on your shoulder ‚Äì or in your own mind ‚Äì that desperately tried to preserve the previous version of yourself. 

 That version of you is comfortable the way they are. 

 They like their limiting beliefs. 

 They like their fears. 

 They like their perception of self. 

 That version needs to die. 

 I know this sounds like an intro to a corny self-help manifestation book, but bear with me. 

 A few months ago, I made a list of things that I wanted to do but was putting off. 

 I started checking them off the list, and every single time, I‚Äôm left with the same feeling that sounds something like: 

 ‚ÄúWhy was I ever nervous to do that?‚Äù 

 I stepped in the ring, got hit, and it didn‚Äôt feel as bad as I thought it would. 

 I‚Äôve actually grown to like it. 

 And Improvement has come much quicker than I anticipated. 

 This is both an analogy for everything that I‚Äôve tackled over the last few months and my actual experience from boxing. 

 I‚Äôm telling you that checking these things off your ‚Äúone-day‚Äù list is what will make you feel alive. 

 It‚Äôs how you end up living the life that you envision in your head. 

 It‚Äôll make you look like you have fire in your eyes, and your aura will become magnetic. 

 And it‚Äôs how you become authentically you. 

 Reply if this one resonates :) 

 Let‚Äôs have a good week, 

 Ben

subject: Do more
body:
I use the background of the lock screen on my phone as a reminder to myself. 

 Up until the other day, it was a white background with the words ‚Äúdo more.‚Äù 

 I set it as that about a year ago, during a time when I felt like I was becoming too one-dimensional. 

 I‚Äôd just moved to Miami and honestly was a bit nervous to be here. 

 At the time, I was making $15k to $20k per month, which will quickly make you feel small in a city like Miami. 

 The social scene here was also intimidating to me. I‚Äôm not usually one to be anxious socially ‚Äì It was just a lot of ‚Äúnew‚Äù at the same time. 

 New city. 

 New friends. 

 New routine. 

 Etc. 

 I immediately had a solid group of friends who I‚Äôd met through social media, but none of us were really ‚Äúplugged in‚Äù here. 

 And because all of the newness was intimidating to me, I kind of just latched on to the friend group. 

 I never took the lead or planned anything ‚Äì I would just go with the flow. 

 Then, after a few month period where I was almost never going out, I realized that I wasn‚Äôt living the fun ‚ÄúMiami lifestyle‚Äù I envisioned. 

 I also started to really despise working. 

 A $50k month vs a $100k month virtually had no difference to me, so I lost almost all motivation to keep pushing for new numbers. 

 So I took back control and started doing my own thing. 

 I hired a boxing coach, went out to new clubs and restaurants, and started meeting new people. 

 I learned to lean more into my uniqueness and have become more of myself. 

 And now, I‚Äôve created the exact lifestyle that would play as a movie scene in my head when I pictured moving to Miami a year and a half ago. 

 I‚Äôm sharing all this with you to encourage you to do more. 

 -- You can grow your business while living the social life you want, trying new hobbies, and keeping up with all of your 16 wives. 

 -- You feel most alive when you get rid of the scapegoats you may blame for why you‚Äôre not as happy as you want to be. Take control of your habits, routines, and decisions. 

 -- It‚Äôs okay to do things for the ‚Äúsake of it.‚Äù You have an inclination to do those things for a reason. 

 -- Do not settle when it comes to your true desires. Most get a tenth of the way there and justify settling for ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù along the way. Fuck that. We want Lambos and Pateks. Not a Model 3‚Äôs and Apple Watches. 

 Alrighty. 

 Originally, this email was gonna be about my new lock screen on my phone, but I got caught in the zone and felt like this deserved the spotlight. 

 Maybe I‚Äôll write to you about the new one tomorrow. 

 Hope you liked it ‚Äì let me know if you made it all the way down here <3 

 Do more, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Do your best
body:
Oh no. 

 This is the first time in over a month that I‚Äôve sat down to write an email two days in a row. 

 Are we‚Ä¶ back?? 

 I‚Äôm running on 5 hours of sleep, and I haven‚Äôt had any caffeine yet. 

 I imagine this is what the baseball players who weren‚Äôt taking PEDs in the Barry Bonds era felt like. 

 I‚Äôm at a disadvantage, but at least I‚Äôm honest. 

 In yesterday's email , I told you about my phone background that formerly read, ‚ÄúDo more.‚Äù 

 A few days ago, I changed it to ‚Äúdo your best.‚Äù 

 It‚Äôs corny, it‚Äôs cliche, but actually doing your best is often the answer to every challenge you face. 

 When the goal is simply to do your best, you become outcome-independent. 

 It shifts your attention back to where it should be ‚Äì right here, right now. 

 There will be days when the work feels like a pain, and you don‚Äôt want to do it. But if you can simply bring yourself to do your best in that given moment, you‚Äôll keep moving forward. 

 Doing your best also applies to your interactions with others. 

 Instead of worrying about what to say to impress someone or the perfect lines to make a girl fall in love with you ‚Äì approach interactions with the goal of simply spreading good energy (corny again, but true). 

 This approach takes all of the pressure away, and It gives you control of any situation. 

 Switching gears - sometimes, I‚Äôll run into moments like this when I‚Äôm writing, and I feel like I‚Äôve completed the entire argument for the point I‚Äôm trying to make. 

 How many more times can I tell you to do your best? 

 I actually got this ‚Äúdo your best‚Äù concept from the book The Four Agreements , and it stuck with me for a few days, so that‚Äôs when I decided to make it my phone background. 

 I‚Äôm not gonna keep hammering this into your head ‚Äì But just start to take note of your goals in different situations. 

 ‚ÄúAm I anxious when talking to this person because I‚Äôm trying to get something out of them or impress them?‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúAm I tired of doing the same monotonous work, so I procrastinate until the last second and then half-ass it, which makes me anxious because I know I could‚Äôve done better?‚Äù 

 In those situations, changing the goal is the solution. 

 If you go into the interaction aiming to do your best to say what you want to say, or if you approach your work with the goal of doing what you need to in the most effective manner possible‚Ä¶ 

 The anxiety goes away. 

 You feel your best when you do your best. 

 Anyway, thanks for reading <3 

 If you reply and tell me you love me, maybe I‚Äôll even write another email tomorrow. 

 Much love, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
