subject: How to get out of prison
body:
The only rules you have to abide by are the ones you‚Äôve created in your own mind. 

 A lot of anxiety comes from feeling obligated to do things that you don‚Äôt want to do. 

 You feel obligated to go get a drink with an old friend because they kept asking you, and finally, you gave in. 

 You feel obligated to get a safe job so you have something to talk about at Thanksgiving dinner. 

 You feel obligated to stay in a relationship that doesn‚Äôt serve you anymore because you‚Äôre comfortable, and deep down, you feel like you couldn‚Äôt do better. 

 You feel obligated to live where you live, eat what you eat, think what you think, and go where you go. 

 But the thing is, all of these obligations are imaginary ‚Äì They‚Äôre pacts that you‚Äôve made in your own mind that you never stopped to question. 

 You are simply imprisoning yourself. 

 Do you know how much freedom you truly have? 

 I was thinking about this after my Sunday morning run‚Ä¶ 

 Right now, if I wanted to, I could pack up and fly across the country. 

 I could drop all my clients and start a completely new business. 

 I could stop running businesses altogether. 

 I could start making a different style of content, start posting on a different platform, or stop making content. 

 I could shave my head, start talking with a Russian accent, and tell people my name is Igor. 

 Am I going to do all of these things? No. 

 But recognizing the freedom and the options that we have will help us understand this: 

 Everything that is going on in your life right now is a result of decisions you have made. 

 You choose the stress you allow into your life; you choose the people, the goals, and the perception of reality that you make. 

 You choose whether or not you want to have difficult conversations with a friend, and you choose whether or not you tell yourself that you‚Äôre too hungover to go on your Sunday morning run. 

 You choose how much of yourself you express when you‚Äôre around different types of people, and you choose the way you react when things don‚Äôt go as planned. 

 You choose to hold yourself to a certain standard and to do or not do things that you commit to. 

 Now, I say all this to show you that if you are unhappy, if you are anxious, or if you feel like you‚Äôre not living in alignment with the life you‚Äôre meant to live ‚Äì it‚Äôs on you. 

 You‚Äôre actively deciding to live the exact life that you‚Äôre living right now, and any conflict comes from failing to accept that decision as your own. 

 You have more freedom than you‚Äôre telling yourself, but you‚Äôre making shitty rules that keep you stuck. 

 Obviously, without any rules, chaos would ensue ‚Äì just make sure the ones you abide by are actually serving you. 

 Happy Sunday and go Bengals, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: 3 lessons 1 email
body:
Happy Monday {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 It‚Äôs easy to forget that you are in control of your state. 

 Yes, you will have bad days, you‚Äôll go through ruts, and there are some circumstances outside of your control. 

 But half the battle is in just showing up for yourself and doing what you know needs to be done. 

 Yet sometimes, even though you know this to be true, you still manage to neglect the things that will make you feel fulfilled. 

 For me, I know that when I do the following, I feel better than when I don‚Äôt: 

 Long-form writing (this can be tweeting, journaling, these emails, or all of the 3) Knocking out my to-do list and staying on top of everything in my business Making video content Walking outside & spending time in the sun Going to the gym I‚Äôm sure there are others that I‚Äôm missing, but these are the core 5 that come to mind. 

 It‚Äôs irresponsible to underestimate the power that little habits like this can have in our lives (speaking from experience, as you‚Äôve seen some inconsistency in these emails lol). 

 My friend Miles is one of the most dialed people I know when it comes to his routine. 

 And it just so happens that he never seems to be down. 

 He knows the handful of things that have to be done every day for him to keep moving the needle forward, and he doesn‚Äôt miss a day. 

 Make a list of your non-negotiables and do them every day. 

 I kind of sound like the corny self-improvement personal brand guy that I make fun of. 

 Maybe they have a point? 

 Moving on ‚Äì success is inevitable when you pull the one big lever. 

 I turn away most of the prospects that come to us because they simply don‚Äôt have enough traffic. 

 They‚Äôre trying to optimize all the backend systems and their offer ‚Äì but even if those two things are the best in the world, it won‚Äôt matter because no one is seeing it. 

 If you have a ton of traffic, you can do everything wrong and still make money ‚Äì that‚Äôs when you know you‚Äôve found something. 

 Similarly, in dating, when a girl truly likes you, you can break all the red-pill rules of ‚Äúgame,‚Äù and it‚Äôll probably make her like you more. 

 You can be goofy, and you don‚Äôt have to try hard to have ‚Äúframe control‚Äù because you are the frame ‚Äì You‚Äôve developed into someone worthy of respect and admiration, so simply leaning more into your nature and showing your personality will make that person like you more. 

 Last thing that‚Äôs been on my mind that I‚Äôll attempt to articulate: 

 Playing in the different arenas of life will expose you to the fact that you need a true mission. 

 You need to conquer your inclinations to side quest and quench those thirsts. 

 These can be new hobbies, traveling, dating, etc. 

 Only once you pursue them will you know that you cannot find fulfillment in them ‚Äì and that‚Äôs a good thing. 

 You‚Äôll be able to enjoy these pleasures as they are and return to your main goal with more firepower. 

 Not sure if this last point is making sense for you, but it‚Äôs one of the biggest things I‚Äôve learned recently ‚Äì let me know if it resonates at all. 

 I know this one was long and scattered, but hopefully, you enjoyed this somewhat rapid-fire style today. 

 Let‚Äôs have a great week, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: about to fall asleep
body:
Whatever your expectations are as you open this email, lower them. 

 I‚Äôm half asleep, but I can‚Äôt miss today as I was just starting to rebuild momentum with these. 

 A few things I‚Äôve been thinking about recently: 

 1: Do girls drink water? 

 I swear any time I‚Äôm with a girl, they will not drink unless I basically force them to. It makes me wonder how they operate on their own and if they just go throughout their day without water. 

 2: We are hard-wired to be obsessed. 

 If you‚Äôre smart, you get obsessed with something that brings you fulfillment and makes you money. 

 Your purpose is to find the things that are worth obsessing over for you and carry them out to their fullest potential. 

 This is where you find the flow state. 

 3: I‚Äôm (probably) not smarter than you. 

 Sometimes, I see people comment on my videos or reply to my emails saying things like, ‚ÄúHow are you so wise for being this young?‚Äù 

 The answer is that I trust myself. I‚Äôve developed enough conviction in my own perception of the human experience that seems to resonate with others. You, too, have the same wisdom if you care enough to listen to it. 

 4: Being intentional and setting goals put your subconscious to work. 

 Almost every time I put ‚Äúmake 2 tik toks‚Äù or ‚Äúwrite 3 tweets‚Äù on my to-do list for the day, my brain starts feeding me ideas. 

 This applies to any goal or desire in life. 

 5: When you utilize money to its maximum ability, you reach a new level of autonomy. 

 I buy $300 massages a few times per month (no happy ending). I didn‚Äôt realize this was ‚Äúexpensive‚Äù for a massage until the way a friend of mine reacted when I told them. 

 It made me think about other little things like this that make me appreciate money ‚Äì fancy dinners, clothes, sporting events, paid parking, and subscriptions, are all effectively free. 

 6: I‚Äôm going to bed. 

 I‚Äôm not gonna proofread this, so if it was illegible or I spoke about my disdain for fat people - I‚Äôm sorry. 

 Hope this was half-decent. If ya liked it, let me know! 

 Gn, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: "Just wait till you're my age"
body:
I‚Äôm sitting outside people watching. 

 One of my biggest fears is becoming one of those people who love to tell you about how it all goes downhill after 40. 

 This fear was brought to my attention as I just watched this woman mock her husband's hand gesture when they crossed the street with their elderly parents/in-laws. 

 It was a small interaction that I‚Äôm sure the two of them forgot about in the following 30 seconds. 

 But is that just what happens when you spend years with someone? 

 The way they breathe, the way they sit, the way they chew, and the mannerisms they use while doing certain activities just become annoying. 

 Maybe this is why I like speed dating. 

 I had a series of brief relationships throughout college that felt like eternities. 

 Over the course of two weeks, we‚Äôd spend nearly every day together, share phone locations, and I introduced one of them to my parents on our 3rd date. 

 Then I‚Äôd usually get tired of the girl and all the little things she‚Äôd do would start to bother me. 

 The way her ponytail bounces when she walks, the brief moment where both of us would open our eyes at the same time when we kiss, the way she sleeps, etc. 

 I‚Äôd be silent about these things though and then completely blindside her when I pull away. 

 I‚Äôve changed I promise. 

 And it‚Äôs not that I‚Äôve never been in long-term relationships or haven‚Äôt met girls that make it past the 2-week honeymoon. 

 It‚Äôs just that it has to stay really fast-paced and exciting for me to be able to overlook the inevitable icks. 

 The finance bros just walked out of Starbucks and are heading back to the office. 

 That scares me too. 

 Fake smiles, the same 5 shirts they rotate through each week, taco Tuesdays with the wife, beer night and football on Thursdays with the boys, and a 401k that leaves you with just enough money for low-budget vacations twice a year. 

 To me, it just sounds like a slow, silently painful death that starts the day where you can semi-accurately predict what the rest of your life will look like. 

 I guess that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm scared of. 

 Too much predictability. Complacency. Living the same day for 50 years. Losing the spark with a girl and staying in the relationship only because finding someone else would be too hard. Or when the most exciting part of the day is hitting the green light at the busy intersection on the way home from work. 

 Does the spark inevitably fail after a while or is that a lie that‚Äôs been perpetuated by these doom and gloom water cooler conversation and ‚Äúwait till you‚Äôre 40‚Äù types? 

 Or are they actually the enlightened ones because they‚Äôre able to seem outwardly content with the ‚Äúsimple life‚Äù and I just don‚Äôt have enough appreciation for the little things? 

 Maybe. These are questions I don‚Äôt have the answers to. 

 For now, I‚Äôm gonna go get the same tacos I eat every day for lunch, hop on the usual 3 pm meeting, hit the gym, and call it a day. 

 Ooh, it‚Äôs chest day. If it‚Äôs not too crowded and I can get a bench that‚Äôll be the highlight of my day! 

 Some good basketball on tonight too. 

 Will circle back tomorrow! 

 Ben 

 P.S. Watch my most recent podcast if you haven't already ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: $1,000 on black
body:
I see about a dozen ‚ÄúUntitled Documents‚Äù as I open my email folder to write to you. 

 It‚Äôs the early afternoon here in Vegas, but I haven‚Äôt fully adjusted to Pacific time yet, so it feels like it‚Äôs later. 

 The untitled docs are emails that I started and never completed. 

 Some had a few sentences, some were too incoherent to send, and some were completely blank. 

 I was gonna write about how the untitled docs in our lives are the dreams that we started and never finished. 

 We tried to be too perfect, we got nervous, or we half-assed it. 

 But as I often do when contemplating an idea for an email, I discard it because it sounds too elementary or basic. 

 The last thing I want is to become a corny platitude, vanilla advice type of dude. 

 At the same time, I understand that there are very few things that I can tell you that would be completely new or unique. 

 You‚Äôve heard every piece of advice there is, and you intuitively know what‚Äôs right for you. 

 The only time we go in the wrong direction is when we refuse to listen to our intuition. 

 We‚Äôre conditioned to silence it over and over until we can‚Äôt hear it at all anymore. 

 Anyway, Vegas is interesting. 

 It‚Äôs my first time here, and I didn‚Äôt really know what to expect. 

 I think it‚Äôd be extremely easy for me to get addicted to gambling, so I‚Äôve been staying away from the Casino even though it‚Äôs just an elevator ride down from my suite. 

 Fuck I wanna go play roulette now. 

 Ok, last time changing the topic and then I gotta run: 

 No matter your current situation, you truly are 2-3 years away from your dream life. 

 I know that might sound like a long time right now, but I‚Äôm not talking about the ‚Äúrealistic‚Äù dream life where you get half of what you want and settle. 

 I‚Äôm talking about the life you envision that sounds a little far-fetched, and you don‚Äôt even know how to make it happen. 

 Between my (and a friend's) first-class flight here, my suite on the strip, dinners, shopping, and other activities, this trip will probably cost at least $15k. 

 It honestly could be way more, and I wouldn‚Äôt even know because my Amex is set to auto-pay. 

 I‚Äôm here with an amazing group of friends, business is hitting an all-time high this month, and I can‚Äôt even tell you the details of what I see when I look up from my computer while writing this. 

 All it took was a consistent effort for an extended period of time, and boom - nearly exactly what I used to picture in my head has come true. 

 And the best part is; money is a complete afterthought. 

 I don‚Äôt have to think about it, I don‚Äôt have to stress about it‚Ä¶ I just pull out this magical card and put it on the reader. 

 I‚Äôll leave you with this: 

 You owe it to yourself to make your dream life come to fruition. You will never experience the depth of life if you don‚Äôt attack the things you want and shape your reality to your imagination. 

 Just don‚Äôt forget to stop and enjoy the moment once you get there. 

 I guess this did turn into a motivational guru email, but I hope you liked it.
Let me know if you did ‚Äì and finish your Untitled Documents. 

 $1,000 on black, 

 Ben

subject: Don't forget to water the grass
body:
I‚Äôm walking on the sidewalk in Beverly Hills, looking up at the beauty of the trees and surrounding scenery. 

 It‚Äôs 75 degrees and sunny, with no wind and not a cloud in the sky. 

 I like the way California license plates look. I like the ever-present blue tint in the air. 

 ‚ÄúIt would be impossible to be unhappy living here.‚Äù I think. 

 And that‚Äôs when I stop and catch myself. 

 I already live in paradise. 

 Minus the aesthetic of the hills and homelessness, Miami is basically the same thing. 

 And I‚Äôm not unhappy in Miami at all ‚Äì I‚Äôve absolutely loved it recently. 

 But that thought of ‚Äúbetter‚Äù still crept in. 

 That singular thought has the potential to be cancerous. 

 Imagine you‚Äôre dating your dream girl (or dream man if you're a girl). 

 She‚Äôs gorgeous in that unique, innocent way that you just don‚Äôt see every day. 

 You guys get along perfectly. She‚Äôs clever, she can banter with you, and most of the time, you know what she‚Äôs thinking before a word comes out of her mouth. 

 It‚Äôs that kind of chemistry that makes other couples fight after seeing you out because it makes them question the depth of their relationship. 

 But one day, you start to develop eyes for a different girl. 

 She‚Äôs equally beautiful, and you‚Äôre intrigued. So you start fantasizing about girl number 2. 

 ‚ÄúWhat would life be like with her? I bet she wouldn‚Äôt get mad at me for leaving the toilet seat up the same way my girl does.‚Äù 

 And here comes the poison. 

 You start observing your girl in a different light. 

 The things you loved about her begin losing their luster. 

 You think more and more about what she does wrong and what you don‚Äôt like about her. 

 Over time, your relationship is silently in shambles. Neither of you have acknowledged it yet, but you‚Äôve been fighting way more about little things. 

 You‚Äôre no longer the person she fell in love with, and you‚Äôve warped your perception of her to the point where you think she‚Äôs the problem. 

 Eventually, it all goes up in flames, and you find your way to girl number 2. 

 Except she‚Äôs not just number 2. 

 You‚Äôve ben doing this countless times with nearly everything in your life. 

 You get what you want, and stop watering your own grass. 

 You slowly poison it, evade to the next one, and start all over. 

 This is a vicious cycle ‚Äì Water your own grass and be careful of these thoughts that there is always something better. 

 They will sprout quickly, and soon enough, you‚Äôll live in a forest full of poison. 

 Avoid looking for problems where there are none ‚Äì because you will find what you seek. 

 The grass is always (and never) greener when you fail to water your own, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I had fun with this one. My creativity is way better here than it is in Miami. I think I‚Äôd like it here better, for sure. After all, the constant reggaeton in Miami gets annoying. And everythings so congested! Hmmm. 

 P.P.S. ^ that is sarcasm to illustrate my point if you‚Äôre slow and didn‚Äôt catch it. 

 ‚Äã

subject: Passion is a scam
body:
You cannot ‚Äúfind‚Äù your passion. Get to work, and your passion will find you. 

 When I first started playing basketball as a kid, I had no idea that it would consume the following decade of my life. 

 I figured, ‚ÄúWhat the hell?‚Äù I‚Äôll try this thing out and see if I like it. 

 A few years later, I was still lukewarm ‚Äì I enjoyed the sport and was decent for my age, but it wasn‚Äôt too serious. 

 Then I started working with a trainer who played in college. 

 I still remember walking into the gym in my first session with him and seeing orange cones sprawled across the hardwood. 

 And the following workout changed the course of my entire life. 

 It was the most challenging 1.5-hour session I‚Äôd ever done ‚Äì and in those moments, I fell in love with the pursuit of mastery. 

 For the next 7+ years, this pursuit of mastery became my life. 

 I cherished the times when I‚Äôd walk into an empty gym. 

 The sound of the ball hitting the court was like music to me. 

 I felt completely present, and that‚Äôs when I knew I was alive. 

 The thing about this feeling is it can never leave you. 

 It‚Äôs almost like you can‚Äôt unsee it once you see it. 

 If you‚Äôve ever been obsessed with something and have spent every waking hour at your disposal consumed by said thing, you can never go back. 

 If and when that thing ends, that fire is still in you, and it must be transmuted into something else, or it will burn you alive. 

 But let‚Äôs rewind real quick. 

 I got so distracted by the power of obsession that I forgot why I started this email. 

 It‚Äôs no secret that life without purpose is a bland life. 

 Everyone wants to ‚Äúfind their passion,‚Äù but few seem to do so. 

 The problem is people assume that this intensity towards a calling is just gonna slap them in the face one day. 

 They‚Äôll just be frolicking through the dairy aisle and get hit with a carton of milk that says, ‚ÄúDedicate your life to XYZ.‚Äù 

 Not how it works. 

 You have to go out there and hunt. And after hunting for a while, maybe you‚Äôll find your prey. 

 But if you don‚Äôt, that doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre broken. It simply means you aren‚Äôt opening enough doors. 

 You‚Äôre not giving luck enough of a chance. 

 So you keep hunting and building until you realize that you‚Äôve found exactly what you‚Äôre looking for. 

 And when you stop and pause, you‚Äôll see that passion actually did slap you in the face. It was already inside of you, and you just had to let it out. 

 Happy Monday {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
snippet:
You cannot ‚Äúfind‚Äù your passion. Get to work, and your passion will find you. 

 When I first started playing basketball as a kid, I had no idea that it would consume the following decade of my life.

subject: Now what?
body:
Perhaps the best thing about buying expensive material items is that it quenches the thirst of a desire. 

 Yes, you‚Äôll enjoy the watch, car, shoes, etc. But the hidden value is the fact that the desire is no longer taking up mental bandwidth. 

 Have you ever been out to dinner with someone that just can‚Äôt decide what they want? 

 They go back and forth between menu items and keep changing their mind. 

 Maybe they want the more expensive dish but are hesitating to spend the extra money. 

 It‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve been around such a person, but this indecision has always disgusted me. 

 The way they‚Äôd stress over such a meaningless decision would, in turn, stress me out. 

 And finally, once they decide, it‚Äôs like a weight is lifted off of everyone‚Äôs shoulders. 

 My first big purchase was my Audi RS5. 

 I‚Äôd moved to Miami a couple of months prior, and although I didn‚Äôt buy it with this intent - the car ended up being a symbol of a new chapter in my life. 

 The same thing can be said for the Rolex‚Äôs I‚Äôve purchased. 

 Buying each of these things has helped give me clarity and steer me back to what‚Äôs really important. 

 It‚Äôs like when the cat finally catches the mouse. It‚Äôs a surreal feeling. But life goes on. 

 And all you‚Äôre left with is the question: 

 Now what? 

 However, there‚Äôs been one common theme that hasn‚Äôt sat right with me among my bigger purchases. 

 I‚Äôve always waited for some arbitrary permission. 

 I bought my Audi days after a friend bought a new car and the same goes for my first couple Rolex‚Äôs. 

 I‚Äôve told myself I need to get to a certain revenue milestone before making other purchases. 

 That‚Äôs one trait I‚Äôd like to discard. 

 An ungovernable man does not need to justify his desires with made-up rules. 

 He simply listens to his own voice and follows his intuition at his own speed. 

 The other day I woke up with a visceral urge to buy a Porsche 911. 

 It‚Äôs always been my dream car, and I‚Äôve found myself talking about it a lot recently. 

 Here‚Äôs a pic of my new turbo. 

 Hope you‚Äôre having a good Tuesday :) 

 Ben 

 P.S. The game never ends, and you never win. 

 You simply collect a combination of trophies and battle scars along the way. 

 The collection of these memories is the actual "win" because it means you're living a full life full of a variety of perspectives and experiences. 

 Go get everything you want. 

 But just know that they're trophies to add to your shelf -- not the end goal. 

 ‚Äã

subject: this email lacks coherence
body:
People-watching is so fun sometimes 

 There‚Äôs this one dorky, curly-haired kid sitting to my right 

 I always see him outside of Starbucks, and he makes me grateful for the type of business I run. 

 I overheard him on a sales call one day, and it was apparent he runs the same kind of lead gen agency I used to run in the basketball space, but he‚Äôs in a boring financial niche. 

 A tall man in work clothes just walked by while holding a book up to his face and reading. 

 Could you do that? I certainly couldn‚Äôt. 

 And then this Asian girl walked out of Starbucks really quickly and really‚Ä¶ hard. 

 I‚Äôm not sure how else to explain her strut. 

 It was like she was exerting all of her force into each step and swaying aggressively from side to side. 

 Similar to the way you‚Äôd see the nerdy, overly excited, yet timid girls walk in school. 

 I didn‚Äôt even mention the homeless man to my left, who‚Äôs been murmuring random sentences for the last few minutes, but let‚Äôs move on. 

 Often times when I don‚Äôt have an immediate idea to write about, I‚Äôll start the email the way I did above. 

 Just a bunch of random little observations of my surroundings. 

 Maybe that‚Äôs a lesson. 

 I feel much more present now than I did a few minutes ago. 

 I also think it helps put me in a different state where I no longer approach this blank page with the thought of ‚ÄúI need to think of something to write about.‚Äù 

 But rather, I just start writing, and whatever comes to mind goes on the page. 

 Let‚Äôs extrapolate these two things to life: 

 You know how all guided meditations start with presence? 

 ‚ÄúFocus on your breathing, feel the seat beneath you, place your attention on your chest, etc.‚Äù 

 It serves as a reminder that you are here ‚Äî where unless you‚Äôre in some immediate danger or physical pain, nothing is wrong. 

 And when you‚Äôre fully present this way, that‚Äôs when you‚Äôre at your best. 

 Ok, quick detour, the homeless guy to my left is starting to get into an aggressive argument with someone in his head and growing increasingly loud. 

 If he mistakes me for the person in his head, I‚Äôm ready to throw hands with this guy. 

 He just got up and scurried away. 

 It‚Äôs interesting because I‚Äôve seen this guy in particular a lot and sometimes he‚Äôs been semi-normal. 

 I heard him having a conversation about the Ohio State and Michigan football rivalry, and it sounded perfectly sane. 

 I guess that‚Äôs schizophrenia for ya. 

 I‚Äôm sidetracked now and forget what I was gonna say before that detour. Ironic for an email about presence. 

 Anyway, the last thing I‚Äôll share with ya... 

 My agency has consistently been over $100k a month for a few months now while working with just 6-9 clients at a time. 

 A few notes: 

 Rev shares are how you make real money with an agency Getting clients through inbound and referrals is far superior to cold outreach. Do not be afraid to sacrifice some margin and delegate ‚Äî this has been a big one for me as I started to feel burnt out with client work. Learning direct response copy is the first fundamental skill you need. Over time you can add complementary skills that make you more valuable to businesses. Alrighty, that‚Äôs all for today. 

 If you have any specific questions - whether it‚Äôs about business or anything else I ramble about here, reply and lmk <3 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: How I make 6 figures per month
body:
Let‚Äôs talk about business. 

 If you have zero clue what I do and how it works, here‚Äôs a brief TLDR: 

 I run a marketing agency where I work with many of the big personal brands that you see online with hundreds of thousands of followers. 

 Over the last few months, we‚Äôve consistently been over $100k per month with minimal expenses. 

 I have a team of 3 people, and we work with around 7-10 clients at a time. 

 The majority of clients we work with are making anywhere from $100k- $600k per month selling info-products and coaching programs. 

 Most of the revenue we bring in as an agency comes from our 10-20% performance fees on the revenue we generate. 

 Our bread and butter as an agency are webinars and new product launches. 

 We provide full-stack services to our clients, meaning we build their funnels, script VSLs, script and build slides for webinars, run email marketing, and provide a few other services, including general consulting. 

 All of our clients come to us through referrals and my Twitter account. 

 Make sense so far? 

 Here‚Äôs how I ended up here: 

 A few years ago, I started a different agency working with basketball trainers. 

 I was able to work with many of the trainers you may see on social media that had big audiences, and in that process, I got really good at one thing: 

 Getting people to take action through the written word, otherwise known as copywriting. 

 I also accumulated a handful of other skills that I use with the clients we work with, including funnel building, backend system setup, and a deep understanding of info-product businesses as a whole. 

 I don‚Äôt know how this all may relate to you, but perhaps you‚Äôre an agency owner or freelancer who wants to make more money with fewer clients. 

 Here are some of the biggest things I‚Äôve learned in going from $25k/mo - $100k/mo+ over the past year: 

 The real money is in revenue shares. To be able to get rev shares where clients pay you $20k+ without batting an eye, you must become irreplaceable in their business. This is where the multitude of services we offer (and do better than 99% of other agencies) comes in handy. You need a team, but hiring doesn‚Äôt have to be difficult. I‚Äôm a horrible operator, and I didn‚Äôt want to have to babysit new team members I brought on. So, my team consists of 2 of my closest who were already very skilled in the work we do. And although I sacrifice some margin, it saves me so much time and headache that I would have if I tried to do everything on my own. Client results & personal brand is the best form of outreach. Two months ago, I closed a new client who found me through Twitter and knew some of the people we work with. He‚Äôs paid us over $50k, mostly from our performance fees. I have opportunities like this come up frequently because of the two assets I mentioned above (client results & personal brand). Do not be afraid to cut ties with clients when things are not going the way you need them to. I am selective with who I bring on, and I‚Äôve learned that short-term cash is never worth the headache when I see red flags. I turn away most of the prospects that book calls with me if they don‚Äôt fit the criteria that I know we need to succeed. If you‚Äôre working in a similar type of business, I hope this helps. Feel free to reply and fire away with any questions. 

 Let get richer, 

 Ben

subject: Re: your question
body:
I got many questions from our chat about business the other day. 

 ‚Äã Read it here if you missed it. ‚Äã

 I‚Äôm sorry if I didn‚Äôt get back to you, but I promise it‚Äôs for good reason: 

 I‚Äôm lazy. 

 And actually, the questions I received helped me come to an important realization that you might benefit from. 

 Most of you already know exactly what you need to do. 

 And if you don‚Äôt, it‚Äôs probably because you haven‚Äôt taken the time to think critically and objectively about the situation at hand. 

 I remember being in this exact position. 

 I‚Äôd hit a plateau in business and invest in a coaching program or mentor. 

 Just by taking the time to explain my situation to them, what I needed to do became obvious in my own head. 

 By the end of my spiel, I‚Äôd usually answer my own question, and if I didn‚Äôt, the advice I‚Äôd get would be incredibly simple. 

 And that‚Äôs exactly what I needed. 

 The answer to most of the problems you face right now is the following: 

 Think about it and do what you think is best. 

 You aren‚Äôt lost; you just want to be told what to do. 

 This reminds me of these two younger dudes who I recently started consulting with because they kept harassing me and offering me money. 

 They come to our calls with a world of ideas, fancy diagrams that track their data, and a bunch of new buzzwords and KPIs. 

 Most of the calls are filled with one of them rambling about any of the things I mentioned above and me saying something along the lines of ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs cool, so why don‚Äôt you just do more of this one simple thing that‚Äôs already working for you to make more money.‚Äù 

 Sometimes, I feel bad because they‚Äôve paid me, and I‚Äôm not necessarily bringing any revolutionary ideas to the table for them. 

 But honestly, that‚Äôs the secret ‚Äì the revolutionary ideas don‚Äôt exist. 

 And by simply providing a vote of confidence that they‚Äôre on the right track, I‚Äôm able to help solidify the things they already know to be true. 

 Sure, there will always be some nuances and information that you unlock with more time in the game, but most of the time, the right answer is the obvious answer. 

 Avoid pretending not to know what to do in order to procrastinate doing the thing you know you need to do. 

 I don‚Äôt know why, but that‚Äôs a common trap that I‚Äôve fallen victim to frequently. 

 Trust yourself my friend. 

 Happy money Monday, 

 Ben

subject: The safest thing you can do is floor it
body:
It‚Äôs 1:37am and I‚Äôm on my way home. 

 I‚Äôm driving with the top down as I merge onto the highway. 

 The car in the left lane (autistically) creeps into my lane, and there‚Äôs a car on my right, so I can‚Äôt move over. 

 I hit the gas and narrowly weave between the 2 cars. 

 Sorry it‚Äôs been almost a week since I last emailed you. 

 I went out Monday through Friday. 

 I know everyone talks about how this whole entrepreneur thing is a grind, you have to sacrifice fun, blah blah blah ‚Äì but I‚Äôve legitimately spent more time in the club over the last 5 days than I have at my desk. 

 ‚ÄúLife‚Äôs about balance, and the balance is in her (the bottle girl) account now‚Äù - Socrates. 

 Anyway‚Ä¶ 

 The purpose of the driving tidbit I shared above was to illustrate the cliche lesson of going on the offensive. 

 If I hadn‚Äôt hit the gas when I did or if I tapped the brake, I might‚Äôve gotten hit. 

 So, in hindsight, the safest thing I could‚Äôve done was to floor it. 

 This reminds me of my thought process when I decided to drop out of college. 

 I remember weighing the two options and coming to a realization that it actually wasn‚Äôt as risky as everyone made it out to be. 

 Spending 4 years of my life to get a sheet of paper that barely proves a baseline level of competence in hopes of getting a $60k/year job out of college sounded riskier. 

 I was gonna go on and on about this topic, but I‚Äôm extremely sleep-deprived, and I keep nodding off. 

 Lesson in there. 

 I‚Äôll write something longer and more valuable tomorrow, but for now goodnight {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 Ben

subject: Might as well
body:
When I stepped foot on a college campus 4 years ago, I had no intentions of joining a fraternity. 

 Rush week started, and I began going to parties and events with my roommates 

 If you don‚Äôt know how the whole Greek life thing works; basically rush week is when all the frats throw these parties and events to recruit new members. 

 After that week, I figured this whole pledging thing couldn‚Äôt be that bad. 

 Next thing you know, I got a bid and became a pledge in a fraternity. 

 This is not the fun part. 

 For the next 3 months, my 11 pledge brothers and I were constantly running errands for the members of the frat, setting up events, and of course, having our fair share of‚Ä¶ ‚Äúwelcome to the frat‚Äù moments. 

 If you know me, you know I love my time. 

 There are few things I dislike more than feeling like I‚Äôm not in control of where I go and what I do. 

 Pledging a fraternity completely ate up all my time. 

 There was a moment early on when I was thinking about dropping (quitting). 

 It was maybe 2 weeks in, and I started to come to the discouraging realization that this wasn‚Äôt going to end any time soon. 

 I was going back and forth thinking about it and honestly was ready to get out of it. 

 But by that time, I‚Äôd made a couple of close friends, and I didn‚Äôt want to bail on them. 

 I also felt an obligation to myself to finish what I unknowingly started. 

 So I did. 

 I would‚Äôve never pledged had I really known what I signed up for, but once I was in it, I couldn‚Äôt bring myself to back out. 

 The words that come to mind when I think about this situation are the following: 

 ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre already this far in; you might as well finish the job.‚Äù 

 And if we extrapolate this to life or business, it‚Äôs a valuable lesson to pull from. 

 The hardest part of doing anything new is the beginning. 

 You suck at the thing. It sucks. And change is hard. 

 But once you start, inertia starts to build. 

 Even when you keep getting caught with a right hook‚Ä¶ 

 Or a prospect cusses you out and hangs up on your cold call‚Ä¶ 

 Or you look like an idiot in front of your date because you stumble over your words and accidentally tell the waiter, ‚Äúyou too,‚Äù when they say, ‚Äúhave a good meal.‚Äù 

 Momentum carries you through the shitty parts like this. Once you‚Äôre in, there‚Äôs no going back because it‚Äôs like you can almost taste what the other side will be like. 

 Yesterday, I was reminded of this very concept. 

 I sat down to record a YouTube video, and 36 tries later, when I was about to quit, I told myself that this was my last try and I was following through with it no matter what. 

 I imagined how I‚Äôd feel after finally making and uploading the video. 

 And I told myself, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre already this far in; you might as well finish the job.‚Äù 

 ‚Äã You can watch that video here. ‚Äã

 Hope you‚Äôre having a good week, and show some love on the YT vid if you like it :) 

 Ben

 If you don‚Äôt know h

subject: Just get an easy bucket
body:
I used to watch basketball religiously. 

 Whenever I studied the greatest shooters in the NBA, I noticed a commonality: each of them had their go-to shots that they would try to get to towards the beginning of the game. 

 Guys like Steph Curry and Damian Lillard would do this to get into a rhythm. 

 And whenever they got a solid look and knocked down an easy bucket early on, you could just tell they were locked in, and it was gonna be a long night for the defense. 

 Similarly, for nearly any task you want to complete consistently, you need to find ways to get yourself in the right mental state. 

 My creativity has been at a high the last few days. 

 It‚Äôs like my brain is feeding me tweet after tweet and video idea after video idea. 

 And I think it‚Äôs because of the exact same reason that Steph is ready to go off after he gets that first bucket to drop‚Ä¶ 

 I‚Äôve been forcing myself to write a singular tweet early in the day. 

 Even if it‚Äôs not my best work or if it takes 10 minutes to get over the initial resistance, I simply get it done. 

 It‚Äôs my version of an ‚Äúeasy bucket,‚Äù and after that, it‚Äôs like the pressure is gone. 

 That very act builds enough goodwill in my brain that it rewards me by continuing to keep creativity flowing in spurts throughout the day. 

 And this concept applies to a lot more than creativity or basketball. 

 Have you ever been on a date where your conversations are kind of dry? 

 You keep asking each other questions, but you‚Äôre unable to make the vibe more lively and drop the filter that both of you are upholding. 

 Then, one of you says something that makes both of you feel more comfortable, and the mood instantly switches. 

 You can feel the weight being lifted off your shoulders as you conversate, and you‚Äôre finally in that carefree state in which you operate best. 

 That‚Äôs the zone. 

 And if you understand how you operate, you can put a protocol in place to give yourself the best chance of accessing it in different scenarios. 

 For example, sometimes when I have work to do that I‚Äôm dreading, I‚Äôll start by completing a few easier tasks to build some momentum and get the ball rolling. 

 Does it work 100% of the time? 

 No. 

 But can it occasionally help me do that thing that I didn‚Äôt want to do with more efficiency and focus? 

 Yes. 

 Get an easy shot, get your first rep out of the way, go home with a four (or don‚Äôt), write one tweet, etc. 

 And boom, you now have access to one of the most valuable assets that can propel you to success: Momentum. 

 Good chat today. 

 I‚Äôm selling you something soonish btw. 

 Hope you‚Äôre ready, 

 Ben

subject: You were sold a lie
body:
You scroll through the internet and see dozens of people sharing various opinions. 

 Perhaps you adopt some of them and begin to abide by them. 

 ‚ÄúA capable man needs to get rich, fight, shoot guns, and get jacked.‚Äù 

 You do as you‚Äôre told, and not long after, you‚Äôve acquired many of the traits and skills that others proclaim as necessities. 

 You‚Äôve accepted the values, opinions, and rules of others. 

 On paper, you‚Äôre exactly what you ‚Äúshould‚Äù be. 

 And these things were supposed to make you happy, to set you free, to build you into someone worthy of respect. 

 But there‚Äôs an emptiness that comes with these traits as you‚Äôve ‚Äútransformed‚Äù into the person they told you that you need to be. 

 Under all these arbitrary obligations, you‚Äôve buried the most important one. 

 Who are you? 

 ‚ÄúYou‚Äù are no longer there. 

 You‚Äôre a hodgepodge ‚Äì a mosaic ‚Äì an amalgamation of a variety of opinions and features that you didn‚Äôt come to on your own regard. 

 Self-improvement or self-actualization is not the act of blindly accepting the ideals of others. 

 It is piercing through their opinions and standards to formulate those of your own. 

 Don‚Äôt forget who you were before they told you who you should be. 

 Value your instincts, your inclinations, your personal experiences, and your unique perception of truth above all else. 

 This is freedom. 

 This is what a ‚Äúman‚Äù does. 

 This is access to the autonomy that likely seduced you into this game in the first place. 

 As you become free financially, you must also become free mentally and spiritually. 

 Don‚Äôt neglect the last two. 

 Happy Saturday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Check out my recent YouTube video if you haven't already <3 ‚Äã

subject: When to "jump-ship" VS stick it out
body:
I‚Äôve been going to a different coffee shop recently. 

 This one‚Äôs a bit more liberal, and I think they pump estrogen into the air. All the employees are wearing reindeer ears and the male barista attempts to hold eye contact with me for a few milliseconds too long. 

 I evade and tell him to make me an $8 iced latte with vanilla. 

 Before I got here, I was scouring my apartment. I tore up my office, dug under the couch, swept through the kitchen, and even looked in my bathroom although I knew there was little chance I‚Äôd find what I was looking for in there. 

 It‚Äôs not that I even wanted to find the item that bad, it‚Äôs that I knew it was there somewhere which was driving me crazy. 

 But for now, I‚Äôm listening to Christmas music at this cafe because I had no luck finding my airpods. 

 I rarely wear headphones. But when I do, it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm in a noisy area and I want to write. Listening to my own music helps me feel like I‚Äôm in my own world where I can ignore the dorky-looking man at the counter to my right wearing a fanny pack around his shoulder. 

 I literally remember putting them on my counter yesterday. 

 Maybe someone broke into my apartment, ignored the expensive watches, my car keys, and any other more valuable items they could‚Äôve taken, and decided to run away with my disgustingly earwax-stained airpods. Hahaha. 

 I had something I wanted to write to you about, but I‚Äôve gotten so sidetracked that I completely forget it now. I guess it‚Äôs just that kind of morning. 

 Something that‚Äôs been on my mind however is career paths. 

 I don‚Äôt understand how people can stay in one role in the same field for more than a few years. 

 Especially as entrepreneurs. Maybe I‚Äôm just immature, but thinking about doing the same exact thing I‚Äôm doing now for the next 3 years makes me want to chew glass. 

 Sure you can always make the argument that ‚Äúfeelings don‚Äôt matter. Do it anyway‚Äù blah blah. 

 And I know there will always be some things I don‚Äôt want to do in any business I run. But to me it just makes sense to upgrade or switch business models every few years (if that‚Äôs what feels right). 

 I get bored doing the same thing every day after a while. 

 Again, you can make a sound argument that it doesn‚Äôt matter how you feel and that you should power through the things you don‚Äôt want to do. 

 But you can also make the counterargument that if you can find excitement in your work, you‚Äôll be much more effective than when you‚Äôre dreading it. Even if that means your business model has to change or evolve every so often. 

 Last point on this and then I gotta run: I‚Äôm not saying you should constantly be jumping from one completely different business to another. 

 You likely have innate skills that can be applied in a variety of different ways, and sometimes being open to the application of your skill set in a similar or parallel field may make sense. 

 You with me here? 

 I could be completely wrong, but thanks for reading anyway. Let me know if you liked this one. 

 Happy Christmas and Merry Hanukkah. 

 Ben 

 P.S. Watch my recent YouTube video Or... Watch my recent Podcast ‚Äã

subject: How to dissipate any chance of regret
body:
I found the airpods that I told you I lost in yesterday‚Äôs email. ‚Äã

 Any guess where they were? 

 If you said ‚Äúthe washing machine‚Äù you‚Äôd be correct. 

 I guess that‚Äôs one way to get earwax off. 

 Last night I was thinking about the last organized basketball game I ever played. 

 We were losing by double digits, and I fouled out with a couple of minutes left. 

 As I ran off the court, I didn‚Äôt realize that it would be the last time until I saw the look on my coach's face. 

 It was a mix of sorrow and regret. 

 I had a fine high school basketball career, but it never felt like I truly played at the level I was capable of - and like I‚Äôd left something out there on the court. 

 By the look in my coach's eye, we were silently in agreement on the statement above, and I think he felt some guilt (although I don‚Äôt offer him any of the blame). 

 Knowing that you could‚Äôve done better and that you squandered an opportunity to display your gifts to the world is one of the worst feelings there is. 

 It can be as simple as an awkward interaction with someone you respect or as big as dedicating years of your life to a project and never seeing it come to fruition. 

 But as I think more about this situation now, I genuinely think that it‚Äôs the best thing that could happen to you. 

 That feeling will light a fire inside of you. 

 If you carry that flame into your next project, your relationships, and your general approach to life, you begin to become a light. 

 Your underlying goal is now to express your true, genuine self. 

 When you do your best to represent that version of yourself, you‚Äôre no longer robbing the world of your unique gifts. 

 Getting kind of spiritual here but I hope you‚Äôre still with me and can resonate with this a bit. 

 Don‚Äôt run off the court feeling like you could‚Äôve done more. 

 Don‚Äôt walk away from a relationship feeling like you didn‚Äôt adequately represent yourself. 

 And don‚Äôt take your last breath wondering what could‚Äôve been if you had just approached your life with a true effort to do your best. 

 Thanks for sticking with me here and as always, let me know if this one hit. 

 Ben 

 P.S. Watch my recent podcast here ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 If you said ‚Äúthe washing machine‚Äù you‚Äôd be correct.

subject: Holidays are for women children and wagies
body:
Merry belated Christmas. 

 Not gonna lie I‚Äôm kind of excited for the Holiday season to be over and to get back into the natural swing of things. 

 To me, it‚Äôs always felt like Holidays are just for people who hate their normal lives and want to soak up their annual two-week break from reality. 

 Maybe I‚Äôm just a grumpy asshole, but I like my normal reality. 

 I went to the dentist for the first time in a while today, and he was asking about my business. 

 There‚Äôs an art to being able to describe what you do to people who are not in your world. 

 I explained how I run marketing for people who sell coaching and information online. 

 To help him understand, I told him that if he were to get on social media and make educational videos about how he started his practice, he would naturally garner an audience of people who would pay to learn more from him. 

 He then understood. And I had no cavities, so that was pretty cool. 

 The online education industry still blows my mind sometimes. 

 Nearly anyone who has acquired any niche skill has the capability to share their story on social media and find people who are willing to spend hundreds or thousands of dollars to learn from them. 

 With the boom of short-form content, it‚Äôs never been easier to start making minute-long videos from your iPhone, and *boom* now you have a potential seven-figure business. 

 This is the situation for every single one of my clients. 

 We‚Äôve been working with a client who buys small local businesses. 

 It‚Äôs a much more complicated process than I‚Äôll make it sound here, but basically, he has a system that allows anyone with a stable income and some money to invest to acquire a ‚Äúboomer‚Äù business that cashflows around 6-figs per year right off the bat. 

 The process of finding a type of business that‚Äôs a good buy is the most complicated part, but once an acquisition is complete, he can operate the business remotely and only spend about an hour per week on each business, making sure nothing catches on fire. 

 He started making content on social media, and just months later, we‚Äôre doing multi-six-figure months, and he‚Äôs got dozens of successful students. 

 There‚Äôs no real lesson here today, but I just wanted to make it clear how simple it can be to launch and scale an online education company. 

 I‚Äôve got something coming for you soon if you‚Äôre someone who is building this type of business or something similar, so be on the lookout for my emails over the next few weeks. 

 Let‚Äôs hit the gas and build a life in 2024 where you don‚Äôt have to ‚Äúlook forward to the Holidays‚Äù because your whole life feels like a Holiday :) 

 Thanks for reading my words today. Let me know if you liked this one. 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: 4 traits that *might* correlate with success
body:
I‚Äôve been in the online marketing space for about three years now. 

 Throughout this time, I‚Äôve met a lot of people who were trying to ‚Äúmake it‚Äù as entrepreneurs. Some completely failed, some stagnated, and others have been on par with the same level of success I‚Äôve seen or have found financial success quicker than me. 

 Obviously, there are unicorns, but for the most part, intelligence doesn‚Äôt seem to play a huge role as long a baseline level of competence is established. 

 It‚Äôs similar to being a professional athlete ‚Äì at the highest levels, everyone is a ‚Äúfreak‚Äù athlete. It‚Äôs the minimum standard, and generally, the intangibles are what separates the good from the great. 

 Here are a few of the less tangible traits I see in my more successful friends (which those who stagnate or fail seem to lack): 

 1. Ingenuity & craftiness: In the world of entrepreneurship, rules are meant to be broken, loopholes are meant to be found, and the lines between what works and what doesn‚Äôt are blurred. 

 There‚Äôs a proclaimed ‚Äúright way‚Äù to find success, and then there's the way that actually works for you. 

 Creativity and persistence will (sometimes) take you much further than blindly following a ‚Äúproven system‚Äù that other people tell you to. 

 2. Discipline & the ability to create order in chaos: Freedom causes most people to lose their minds. When you‚Äôre accustomed to being told what to do, what to think, and where to be, having to tell yourself those things is a big adjustment. 

 Build a system for yourself that works for you. Again, it doesn‚Äôt have to be what other people are doing as long as it puts you in an environment and mental space that allows you to do what you need to do. 

 3. Comfortable with the unknown: Eventually, you come to the realization that no matter how much you plan, no matter how hard you try, and no matter how badly you want something to happen, you are not in complete control of the outcome. 

 Certainty makes us feel safe. And if you‚Äôre too attached to that feeling of safety, go get a desk job and a 401k. Or prepare to always have a voice in the back of your head that thinks everything is gonna crumble at any given moment. 

 Bonus trait 4 - The gut feeling paradox: There‚Äôs a balance between listening to signs from the universe that tell you that you need to make a change versus jumping from one shiny object to the next. 

 Sometimes, when things don‚Äôt feel right, it‚Äôs a sign that you need to make a change. 

 Other times, when things don‚Äôt feel right, it‚Äôs a sign that you‚Äôre on the cusp of something great if you can power through that feeling. 

 This is a constant game. I don‚Äôt have any advice on how to navigate it because truthfully, I don‚Äôt know if anyone does. 

 I guess that brings us back to trait #3, huh? 

 Alrighty, hope you liked this one. Keep pushing these next few days and build momentum going into 2024. 

 Happy hump day, let me know if you read this whole thing <3 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you still haven‚Äôt watched my recent YouTube video, go here plz. ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: How to fail in 2024
body:
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs how to make your goals come true in 2024!!!‚Äù 

 I hate the sentence above because everyone is using this angle to sell their stuff right now. 

 So, this email will be about why you won‚Äôt accomplish your 2024 goals. 

 Most people will probably tell you to write out your goals and reverse engineer the steps you need to take to get there. 

 If you want to make $100k/month, figure out how many clients you need, and then figure out how many outbound messages you need to send daily to book calls with potential clients, given your close rate. 

 And now boom, you have the goal to ‚Äúsend 30 messages per day.‚Äù 

 It‚Äôs a sound system and something I‚Äôve used over the years. 

 But as I think about times when I felt stuck or fell short of my goals, it wasn‚Äôt because I couldn‚Äôt devise a simple plan like the one above. 

 It was because the execution of those actions was harder than it looked on paper. 

 I‚Äôd wake up on January 1st and think, ‚ÄúAh shit, I told myself I was gonna start this thing today‚Ä¶ ok, let me scroll through TikTok first.‚Äù 

 By the time I‚Äôd get around to attempting to complete whatever task was at hand, my focus was horrible, and I couldn‚Äôt muster up the discipline to actually sit there and do it. 

 I objectively was in a situation that I didn‚Äôt want to be in. 

 I knew the steps I needed to take to change. 

 But actually doing them felt like I was attempting to lift up a Ram TRX with my pinky finger. 

 Why is this? 

 Inaction can be caused by a plethora of factors, but here‚Äôs one I used to face: 

 I was scared to raise my standards because I knew the further I got from the bottom, the harder it would be to go back. 

 There‚Äôs a lot of comfort in stagnation. 

 Even though I was telling myself I wanted to change, I could see that the road to my destination was filled with potholes and dead ends. 

 I was gonna have to become somebody that I wasn‚Äôt presently ‚Äì and that‚Äôs a painful experience. 

 And you know what‚Äôs less painful? 

 Turning on the TV and watching another episode of South Park because after all, being a normie doesn‚Äôt sound THAT bad. 

 This mental battle was a constant dilemma I faced every time I tried to start something new. 

 If this sounds familiar to you, here‚Äôs my advice: 

 Drop everything that you tell yourself you want, and accept the fact that you weren‚Äôt born to do anything special. 

 Deal? 

 No‚Ä¶? 

 Fine - If that advice doesn‚Äôt sound like something you want to do, then stick with me. 

 All you have to do is dive in. 

 When the cold water hits your body, you‚Äôre gonna want to get out. 

 You‚Äôre gonna think of a thousand different reasons as to why you should get out, why Ben‚Äôs advice is stupid, and why it‚Äôs not the right time. 

 Don‚Äôt listen to the voices for long enough, and you‚Äôll get over the flinch. 

 On the other side of the flinch, you‚Äôll find that the things you were scaring you are actually not that scary. 

 The monsters under your bed look more like teddy bears and less like Dracula. 

 And maybe you‚Äôll learn to love the cold, uncomfortable, unchartered water. 

 Just don‚Äôt bitch out. Simple. 

 Hope you enjoyed my anti-self-improvement turned self-improvement email. 

 Love ya, 

 Ben

subject: finally back 2 work!
body:
I'm stoked for the new year. 

 Mainly because all of the tourists will leave Miami today and my morning coffee walk will be far less crowded. 

 Back to the natural swing of things we go. 

 I crawled out of bed at noon today and saw a text asking me if I wanted to speak at a Mastermind later this month. 

 Truthfully I don‚Äôt like public speaking. Shit makes me nervous. 

 I immediately started thinking of excuses I could come up with to get out of it. 

 Maybe I‚Äôll plan a trip that weekend so that I have a legitimate reason to say no. 

 Or perhaps I‚Äôll say my dog ate my computer and I can‚Äôt make the PowerPoint presentation. Or maybe I‚Äôll start licking door handles and kissing homeless people so I can be sick that day. 

 Ugh. 

 As my conscious thoughts run through a variety of excuses, I have a feeling in my stomach that tells me that I have to say yes. 

 This is a common occurrence among the things we don't want to do. 

 It can be as simple as when someone invites you to dinner, and you initially try to say no, but somehow you get roped into going. 

 Then you end up having a good time, and you're glad you went. 

 But our ego wants to protect us. It wants to talk us out of putting ourselves in any position where there‚Äôs an opportunity to look like a fool or be challenged in any way. 

 I could get up there, start my presentation, and forget how to pronounce my own name and lose my ability to speak english. 

 Imagine I do the whole thing in Spanish and no one understands it. 

 But in reality ‚Äî detached from the fragile, overbearing ego that‚Äôs inside of all of us, I know that it‚Äôs an experience that‚Äôll be good for character development in the movie that I star in inside my own head. 

 And the last email I wrote to you was literally about how getting over ‚Äúthe flinch‚Äù is all you need to be successful. 

 So that‚Äôd be extremely hypocritical of me to bitch out because I‚Äôm nervous. 

 If there‚Äôs one thing I want you to take away from my rant today, it‚Äôs this: 

 You have conscious thoughts that your ego feeds you as a protection mechanism. 

 And then you have your gut feeling. 

 Learn to decipher the difference between the two when you‚Äôre making a decision, and it might lead you to experiences that are necessary for your development. 

 Or you‚Äôll embarrass yourself and never listen to me again. 

 Happy New Year, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: How to make $100k per month by doing everything wrong
body:
My agency website is quite horrible. 

 ‚Äã You can look at it here. ‚Äã

 It‚Äôs almost been a year since I last revised it, and we have loads of client results that I‚Äôve been too lazy to compile. 

 I can‚Äôt remember the last outbound DM I sent to a prospect, and just spent 4 minutes looking for one before giving up. 

 It‚Äôs been months since I last tweeted about what we do, and I‚Äôve never done one of those corny auto-dm tweets in order to get new prospects. 

 We communicate with most of our clients through iMessage, I don‚Äôt really have any SOPs (standard operating procedures), and if it weren‚Äôt for the basic Notion doc I use to plan my days, I‚Äôd completely forget what needs to be done each week. 

 I am the epitome of most things that people tell you what not to do in order to scale an agency. 

 Yet we‚Äôve been consistently doing over $100k per month, whereas most ‚Äòagency experts touch $20k per month one time and jump into coaching. 

 This is a result of a few fundamentals that we seem to have gotten right: 

 - Client results 

 Results create happy clients, and happy clients create referrals. This one‚Äôs simple, so I won‚Äôt spend too much time here. 

 - Clear idea client avatar 

 We‚Äôve become quite strict on the type of business for which we can provide the best work. 

 If a prospect comes to us wanting a funnel, webinar, VSL, or email list management, yet they have little traffic and a minimal email list, we do not pitch them. 

 We usually refer them to a friend who can help them with their organic content or simply give them pointers on how to build their audience. 

 They sometimes end up coming back months later after they‚Äôve taken the steps we gave them on the call. 

 - Personal brand & network 

 If you go to my Twitter or TikTok, there is proof that I am a real human doing real things. It‚Äôs also clear that I‚Äôm not another self-proclaimed ‚Äúexpert agency owner‚Äù who regurgitates the same three talking points. 

 This makes it so people develop a bit of a relationship with me and my idealogy before we ever get on the phone. 

 I‚Äôm telling you all this in order to show you that many things you may think you need to find success are often a facade. 

 Whether you run an agency or a completely different type of business, your success often boils down to a few key factors. 

 Once you understand what those factors are, double down on them rather than wasting time trying to find the next magic pill that will carry you to the promised land. 

 Repeat successful actions, and success becomes inevitable. 

 Let me know if you liked this one, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I‚Äôm making another YouTube video this week. Reply and let me know if there‚Äôs anything you‚Äôd like me to talk about in my next video, and click here to watch my most recent video. ‚Äã

subject: No Half Measures
body:
Have you ever thought about what your life would be like if you gave it your all? 

 I‚Äôm not referring to the lies that you tell yourself about how hard you‚Äôre working, how you just need some more guidance, how things are good enough as they are, or how one day you‚Äôre gonna do it. 

 But truly. 

 What type of person would you become? 

 How high would your standards be for yourself? 

 What would your life look like? 

 If you can read the questions above and picture the exact life you‚Äôre living right now, congrats. You‚Äôre doing it right. 

 But if you‚Äôre like me ‚Äì and like most people, you know in your core that you‚Äôre not even scratching the surface of your potential. 

 Even if things are good. 

 Hell, that‚Äôs honestly more dangerous. You get some money, a fun lifestyle, a girl or 10‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs easy to throw in the towel and feel like you‚Äôve won. 

 And maybe you have won by most people‚Äôs standards. 

 But you know that it‚Äôs not complete. It‚Äôs not even close. 

 That doesn‚Äôt sit right with you. So even though you‚Äôre ‚Äúliving the dream,‚Äù that voice in your head doesn‚Äôt go away. 

 It‚Äôs the same voice you heard when you felt compelled to start a business or make any life-altering change. 

 It eats you up silently.
You suppress it and tell yourself false narratives and stories in an attempt to remove its power. 

 Perhaps it works temporarily. 

 But on a long enough time horizon, you just can‚Äôt seem to shake it. 

 Eventually, you‚Äôll be left at a crossroads where you have to decide whether or not you‚Äôre going to quench those urges and step into the reality that you know is possible for you. 

 Or continuously attempt to fool yourself and risk sabotaging your life in the process. 

 After all, the only way to ensure that you‚Äôre rarely disappointed is to do your best. 

 As long as you do that, there will never be ‚Äúwhat ifs.‚Äù 

 Sure, things won‚Äôt always go your way. But you‚Äôll sleep knowing you did everything in your power with the resources you had on hand. 

 You‚Äôll find peace in the fact that you actually fucking tried. 

 You get one shot at this. Don‚Äôt half-ass it. 

 Alright even motivation, can we stop saying ‚ÄúHappy New Year‚Äù now? 

 It‚Äôs the 4th. Nobody was saying Merry Christmas on NYE. 

 I hope this made you feel some fire in your soul if you made it all the way down here, and if it did, you‚Äôll probably like this too. ‚Äã 

 Happy 4th day of the new year, 

 Ben

subject: Keep it simple, stupid
body:
After waiting 8 minutes and 27 seconds for the elevator, I threw in the towel and took the stairs 30-something floors down from my apartment. 

 I‚Äôm refraining from telling you the exact floor in case someone has infiltrated my email list to gather information and rob me. 

 If that's you, you‚Äôre gonna need backup. 

 I have nothing to write to you about today and was hoping that sitting down at this cafe would give me a surge of creativity. 

 I‚Äôve grown to hate the word ‚Äúvalue.‚Äù 

 It makes me think of minute-long Instagram reels with yellow captions and tweets that contain the words ‚Äúhere‚Äôs how‚Äù and a ball of yarn emoji. 

 Everyone is talking about the same shit over and over. 

 ‚Äú9-5 is evil, college is a trap, you have to escape before it‚Äôs too late‚Ä¶ Become an appointment setter!!!‚Äù 

 It‚Äôs no secret that you can go to YouTube or spend some money on courses to learn just about any way to make money online. 

 The abundance of information has made it incredibly easy to build a business while simultaneously making it more difficult. 

 There are simply too many options. 

 If you don‚Äôt have the discipline to stay locked in on one thing, you‚Äôll jump from one business to the next for eternity. 

 Everything is so simple when you just focus on the basics: 

 1. Learn how to provide a service or build a product that solves a problem for other people. 

 2. Find a mechanism to get clients or customers. 

 That‚Äôs it. 

 Repeat that process a bunch of times, and then you no longer have to look at price tags. 

 I‚Äôve grown to believe that you cannot develop into the highest version of yourself until you‚Äôre in complete abundance financially. 

 When you have to worry about menial expenses and constantly chase cash, it distorts your lens of reality. 

 Your broke ‚Äúlife coach‚Äù has two motives. First, they need to keep you as a client. Second, they want to help you just enough but not too much so that you‚Äôre ‚Äúfixed‚Äù and can leave. 

 Sorry, I‚Äôm rambling here. 

 Last thing I‚Äôll share today: 

 I‚Äôm opening up a small consulting group exclusively for people on this email list. 

 It‚Äôll be fairly expensive and isn‚Äôt for complete beginners. 

 But it should be pretty dope and ‚ÄúVaLuAble‚Äù for people who are in the online coaching space, run agencies, or simply want to chat with me on a more intimate basis (no homo). 

 If you‚Äôre interested, just reply to this email and let me know so that I can have Russian hackers send you a phishing link and steal your credit card info. 

 I know this one was a bit all over the place, so thanks for sticking with me {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 Happy Monday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I‚Äôve condensed my best tweets into my ‚Äúhighlights‚Äù section if wanna check them out here. ‚Äã 

 There‚Äôs some gold in there. But also a lot of nonsense and stuff that I‚Äôll probably cringe at in 3 months. Such is life! 

 Okay, bye love u. 

 ‚Äã

subject: How we accidentally made $3.5M in 9 months
body:
I just knocked out most of the client work I had for the day as I sit here in a crowded coffee shop in the middle of Brickell. 

 I‚Äôm drowning out the noise in here with a random Spotify playlist blasting in my headphones. 

 The song ‚ÄúSweater Weather‚Äù came on a few minutes ago. Absolute banger. 

 Anyway, I've got a good one for you today (I think). 

 I‚Äôve never publicly shared a ton about the ins and outs of how we‚Äôre scaling our clients' info-product businesses because it‚Äôs always felt a bit boring. 

 Honestly, scaling a coaching program or course business to $500k/mo+ is shockingly simple. 

 I know that may sound like a crazy amount of money, but here are some of the main things I‚Äôve learned about how we got there *by accident.* 

 - Traffic solves all. You can have the best offer in the world, pay me $20k to build out your funnels, and hire Jordan Belfort as your closer. But none of it will matter if you don‚Äôt have eyeballs. 

 - If you can‚Äôt crack organic content, you should probably get a 9-5. Seriously. If you have something to sell and you‚Äôre unable to get attention on the internet in 2024, you should be an accountant instead. The entire multi-7-figure business I‚Äôm writing about was built off of short-form content. 

 - Do not forget to build your plane while you‚Äôre flying it. Because these businesses scale so fast, there‚Äôs a lot of added complexity to the product and fulfillment side. If you neglect the customer experience, you will crash and burn on a long enough time horizon. 

 - Systems only matter at scale. We neglected a lot of the optimizations and organizational aspects of the business until we were already making multi-6-figs per month. Until then, we only focused on more traffic, more webinar registrants, and more booked calls. 

 - There is no secret sauce. I can‚Äôt emphasize this enough: Build offer, get attention. Build offer, get attention. Build offer, get attention. Fix everything else later. The degree to which you can scale is dependent on your ability to consistently bring more people into your funnel who know, like, and trust you. 

 Enough writing for today. 

 I hope this helped you in some way, and if it didn‚Äôt, thanks for wasting some time with me. 

 By the way, there were a lot more people than I anticipated who replied to my email yesterday about the consulting group that I‚Äôm opening up. 

 I‚Äôm still mapping out the details in my head, but I‚Äôll have more info for you soon. 

 Thanks for chatting with me today. 

 Talk soon, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Time freedom is a trap
body:
Sometimes I get lazy. 

 I procrastinate. 

 Tasks that should take 3 minutes to complete end up taking weeks because I put them off for so long. 

 On the contrary, I‚Äôve had periods where I‚Äôm super locked in and productive. 

 After I dropped out of college, I spent the following 3 months in Mexico. 

 I‚Äôd wake up early every morning, hit the gym, bike home, take sales calls, spam more prospects, check in with my clients, write copy, and make content. 

 There was no room to be lazy. 

 If I skipped one thing, everything else would fall apart. 

 The whole ‚Äútime freedom‚Äù fantasy is a bit of a trap. 

 Not having any obligations sounds great in theory, but if you don‚Äôt have the discipline to fill your time with productive activities that help you generate momentum, you‚Äôll fail. 

 Think about these three instances: 

 Guy quits his job. 

 Kid drops out of school. 

 Girl breaks up with guy. 

 Each of these usually acts as a catalyst for a big life change ‚Äì either positive or negative. 

 All the time and energy that was spent working, studying, or reminding your girlfriend to drink water is now freed up. 

 Some people replace those things with a structured routine, and others don‚Äôt. 

 Most cannot handle freedom. 

 But obviously, this is all paradoxical because too much structure makes you a dork, and too much freedom makes you lazy. 

 Here‚Äôs what reminded me of this concept: 

 Last night, I ordered a cheesesteak on Uber Eats. 

 This isn‚Äôt just any cheesesteak. 

 Imagine God himself transmutes into a hard-working (likely Mexican or Cuban) man who sets up a ghost kitchen on Uber Eats called ‚ÄúChef Pepper.‚Äù 

 As I waited for Liana to weave through traffic on her motorbike to deliver my order, I remembered that the last thing on my long to-do list for the day was to make a YouTube video. 

 I‚Äôd already had a busy and productive day, so why not see if I could knock out a video in the 10 minutes that I‚Äôm waiting here? 

 I set up my iPhone camera and started yapping. 

 7 minutes and 19 seconds later, I had a semi-coherent ramble that I had enough confidence in to upload on the World Wide Web. 

 ‚Äã (you can watch it here btw) ‚Äã 

 Funny how that works, huh? 

 I‚Äôd procrastinated for 27 days since making my last video, but once I entered a race against a cheesesteak, I was able to knock it out in less than 10 minutes. 

 Pressure spurs you into action. If you‚Äôre not competing, you‚Äôre likely stalling. 

 Even if it means you have to find creative ways to jumpstart your productivity. 

 Happy hump day, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Don‚Äôt forget about my YT video ‚Äã 

 P.P.S. I‚Äôll be opening consulting spots in one of my next few emails. Keep an eye out if you don‚Äôt want to miss it (thanks for your patience). 

 ‚Äã

subject: Stop avoiding punches
body:
I‚Äôve been boxing for the last few months and sparred with a guy yesterday who was way better than me. 

 It felt like every time I‚Äôd throw a combo at him, he‚Äôd counter with some shit I was completely unprepared for. 

 Even my jabs would rarely make contact. 

 By our 4th round, I was mostly just trying not to get hit. 

 Instead of continuing to attack, I became reactive. 

 I tried to guess what he would throw next rather than being focused on my own game. 

 As I ran around like a chicken with its head cut off, I looked up at the clock and saw that there were only 32 seconds left in the round. 

 ‚ÄúThank God,‚Äù I thought to myself. 

 But those next 32 seconds were the longest of my life. 

 It felt like 32 minutes. 

 That‚Äôs a feeling I haven‚Äôt experienced in a while. 

 Remember in school when you‚Äôd tap your pencil on the desk, waiting for the clock to hit 3pm? 

 Those last 30 minutes before the bell rang felt like an eternity. 

 Yesterday‚Äôs sparring session made me think about the dangers of trying to play against the clock. 

 You‚Äôre not trying to win. 

 You‚Äôre not improving. 

 And you‚Äôre not present. 

 You‚Äôre simply trying to hang on for dear life until it‚Äôs over. 

 That‚Äôs not a winning recipe in the ring, and definitely not a way to live your life. 

 You want to anticipate, play offense, and create opportunities for success to find you. 

 Instead, most people are constantly in a reactive state: 

 They hate their job, are obsessed with other people, and just trying not to mess up too badly or piss anyone off while they‚Äôre here. 

 It‚Äôs the same thing when you‚Äôre in a destructive relationship, and you‚Äôre just waiting for your partner to do something bad enough so you can justify leaving. 

 Or as an entrepreneur, you don‚Äôt give your full effort and push off problems that need to be dealt with. 

 Eventually, that comes back to bite you, and you have to react to a tsunami of issues that you created. 

 Don‚Äôt spend your life scrambling for answers and trying to wait out the clock. 

 Make shit happen. Play offense. 

 If you‚Äôre gonna be here, you might as well make the most of it. 

 TGIF (every day is Friday), 

 Ben 

 P.S. Watch my recent YouTube video and leave a comment if you‚Äôre not fake. ‚Äã 

 P.P.S. The Bader Group is opening soon. 

 If you‚Äôre in the info-product space, you‚Äôre a freelancer, agency owner, bad bitch, or simply someone who likes my content and wants to make a 4 figure donation to me monthly, this might be for you. 

 We‚Äôll have fun. And you might learn a thing or two. 

 Details soon. <3 

 ‚Äã

subject: What would you do if you lost everything?
body:
Before I get into today's message, quick update on the consulting group I‚Äôm putting together: 

 To be quite honest, I‚Äôve been going back and forth on the idea, debating whether or not it‚Äôs the right time. 

 But if you‚Äôve been reading my emails for a while, you‚Äôve probably heard me say the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù time never comes. 

 I decided to take my own advice. 

 This week, I‚Äôll be launching ‚ÄúThe Bader Group.‚Äù 

 Once launched, the application window will be open for a few days, and then I‚Äôll close the doors for a bit. 

 More details on the way in future emails. 

 That being said, let's get into it‚Ä¶ 

 I often think about what I‚Äôd do if I lost everything. 

 Bank account gets wiped clean, housekeeper steals my watches, and all my clients drop me. 

 This thought honestly excites me more than it scares me. 

 I could throw in the towel, sell the rest of my possessions, and move back home with my parents. 

 Or figure out a way to make money fast so I can uphold the lifestyle I‚Äôm living right now. 

 Let‚Äôs pick the latter. 

 If I still had my personal brand, network, and skillset, I‚Äôd be absolutely fine. 

 It‚Äôd probably light a fire under my ass to go 10x harder than I am right now. 

 The three assets I mentioned above are the ultimate safety net. 

 Once acquired, it‚Äôs nearly impossible to go broke. 

 But one thing I realize as I think about this hypothetical situation is that my next move becomes rather obvious. 

 If I needed money fast, I‚Äôd start pitching people on Instagram and Twitter. I‚Äôd sell anything I could to my audience. I‚Äôd find ways to help my friends in their businesses. 

 And because I‚Äôd be on a real-life clock against time, I know I‚Äôd be absolutely relentless. 

 Take a second now to think about what you‚Äôd do in this situation. 

 Who can you go to for help? 

 What‚Äôs the easiest way you can make an extra $10k? 

 What value can you provide to other people? 

 When you picture yourself in this predicament, you may realize that the solutions you come up with could be implemented right now. 

 If you feel like you‚Äôre stuck or you‚Äôve stalled out at a certain income threshold, odds are you‚Äôre just not being resourceful enough. 

 Maybe you‚Äôre a bit too comfortable, and although you tell yourself you want to progress, your desire doesn‚Äôt outweigh the pain of change. 

 This leaves you with a few options: 

 1. Do nothing and stay in this constant state of unease where your actions don‚Äôt meet your desired reality. 

 2. Do nothing and accept that you are comfortable where you are, even if you‚Äôre selling yourself short. 

 3. Act like you just donated your livelihood to a stripper and get back to work with a newfound ferocity. 

 The choice is yours ‚Äì Just some food for thought. 

 Talk to you tomorrow {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Ben. 

 P.S. Watch my recent YouTube video here. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã
