subject: do not join
body:
My least favorite part of my day is the time spent twiddling my thumbs, waiting for the elevator. 

 If that‚Äôs the worst part of my day, I‚Äôm pretty lucky, huh? 

 I‚Äôm on my 5th coffee shop since moving to Miami 15 months ago. 

 This means I‚Äôll frequent one place every day for roughly 3 months, randomly get sick of it one day, and start going somewhere else. 

 I‚Äôve noticed this desire for periodic change as a trend in many other areas of my life, including those that bring more consequences than a slightly different-tasting latte. 

 Over time, things just seem to get dull if you‚Äôre not iterating ‚Äì business, relationships, habits, lifestyle, environment, etc. 

 Oh wait real quick before I continue‚Ä¶ 

 If you subscribed to this list yesterday to apply for my consulting group, you can go here to do so. ‚Äã

 If you applied and I haven‚Äôt gotten back to you yet, I will shortly. 

 Anyway, back to what I was saying: 

 I think this habit of switching things up once you get bored can be both good and bad. 

 You see people like Hormozi talk about doing one thing over and over for a very long time. 

 I know he has like $100m‚Äôs or whatever but that sounds boring. 

 Gym, work, missionary with Leila, gym, work, missionary with Leila, gym, work, missionary with Leila. 

 Actually, do you think she‚Äì never mind, I‚Äôm being rude. 

 Variety gives life flavor. 

 It broadens your perspective. 

 You learn what you like and what you don‚Äôt like. 

 You try out different lifestyles and business models and voyage on different side quests. 

 A man goes and gets what he wants. And then sometimes realizes that he didn‚Äôt actually want it once he has it. But at least he knows now. 

 To me, it‚Äôs at the point where you‚Äôve tried everything and quenched the majority of the desires that you actually have the perspective to say ‚Äì 

 ‚ÄúOkay, here‚Äôs the way I want to live the rest of my life.‚Äù 

 Adults vaping has to be one of the most cringe things I‚Äôve ever observed. 

 Sorry to get sidetracked here, but I just saw a woman who looks like her name is Susan tilt her head back and blow a fat cloud into the air as if she‚Äôs smoking hookah at a club. 

 I guess I‚Äôm an adult too, and I do occasionally vape, but I don‚Äôt act like I‚Äôm Rick Ross in a sea of large women while sitting at the coffee shop. 

 And I‚Äôm not a 30-something-year-old woman. 

 I know today's email has been all over the place, but I‚Äôm doing this to ensure you that my list will not become an ‚Äúescape the matrix, gain remote freedom‚Äù sausage fest now that I‚Äôve opened consulting. 

 I frankly do not care if you join, but it‚Äôs here if you want it :) ‚Äã

 Gonna go smack this vape out of Susan's hand. 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you‚Äôre newer here and were hoping for super in-depth information about how I run my agency and how we scale our clients' offers to half a million per month, this might not be for you. 

 Every now and then, I‚Äôll give specific business advice, but most of these emails are little rants and observations I find interesting. 

 Too many people become carbon copies of big gurus when they take the ‚Äúgive value‚Äù approach, and I never want to be one of them. 

 Stick around if you‚Äôd like, and maybe you‚Äôll enjoy it <3 

 ‚Äã

subject: Is selling an info product immoral?
body:
Question for you: 

 Would you kill 1,000 terminally ill people to save 50 healthy children? 

 What about 10,000 to save 100? 

 What if you knew one of the children would go on to cure cancer? 

 This is a tough one for me. Sure, the terminally ill people are likely gonna die soon anyway, but that‚Äôs a lot of blood on your hands. 

 This is the way I see the majority of the info products on the market. 

 Most people will fail. 

 As an education business scales, a few things happen that start the degradation of their client success rate. 

 First, they start selling to beginners and idiots. 

 Oftentimes, if you want to get to $300k/month+, this is the only way to do it (although there are anomalies). 

 And naturally, when the quality of your customer decreases, so does the effectiveness of your product. 

 They buy courses and never open them. They ask for a refund or chargeback after doing 1% of the work. 

 These are the terminally ill. They were never gonna make it anyway. And you‚Äôre better at spending their money than they are, right? 

 The second reason success rates decline is because it‚Äôs fucking difficult to manage hundreds (or thousands) of customers. 

 Many won‚Äôt get the support they need unless they proactively seek it out. 

 Plus in some situations, teaching a large batch of people the same methods to start a business can make those methods less successful. 

 Does this make selling info products immoral or evil? 

 Here‚Äôs the flip side: 

 Let‚Äôs say 100 people buy a course that teaches them how to start a marketing agency. 

 95 people give up after a few months and lose the few hundred or few thousand dollars they‚Äôd spent on the course. 

 But 5 people actually commit to building this business. 

 6 months to a year later, they‚Äôve completely changed their lives. They‚Äôve quit their 9-5s, dropped out of college, and paid off their parents' medical bills. 

 Fast forward a few years, and one of them has amassed millions of dollars. 

 That person now employs a dozen people, supports their family, and inspires thousands of others online. 

 So, was that worth it? 

 Sure, a little blood was spilled, but think about all the good that came out of it. 

 And after all, who are we to be judges of morality? 

 If you read this far, hit reply and let me know what you think. 

 Two last things for you: 

 1. Enrollment for my 1-on-1 & small group consulting is closing in a few days. 

 ‚Äã Go here to apply before the deadline on Sunday. ‚Äã

 2. Internet Kids clothing is back. 

 ‚Äã Check it out here. ‚Äã 

 Good chat today my friend, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: I paid $20k for this advice
body:
I‚Äôm in a coaching program by a guy named Jeremy Haynes. I pay about $20k per year to be in the group. 

 He hosts a quarterly mastermind at his house in Miami, where he‚Äôll have a handful of speakers talk about a variety of topics and give a presentation of his own. 

 If you were reading my emails earlier this month, you may remember me saying that he invited me to speak. 

 I gave my presentation this morning. 

 Here are some things that I found interesting from giving my own talk and some of the other speakers today: 

 - Most of the time, you‚Äôll be glad you said ‚Äúyes‚Äù to doing things you initially felt resistance towards. 

 Whether it‚Äôs a business opportunity, speaking at an event, or saying yes to the voice in your head that tells you to go up to the pretty girl. 

 The more you can overcome that resistance, the more it loses its power, and you‚Äôll laugh that you were ever nervous. 

 - You do not need to be back against the wall to find motivation. You need to manufacture internal dialogue that tells you to make more money. 

 It‚Äôs easy to be inspired when you have no other options. But as you find success, you need to move out of ‚Äúsurvival mode,‚Äù and your vision needs to get bigger. 

 Set goals and envision a lifestyle that gives you a reason to make more money ‚Äì especially if you have enough money to live comfortably for the next 3 years sitting in your checking account. 

 - Your current reality is a lagging indicator of your previous actions and habits. 

 The future version of you 6 months ‚Äì 1 year ‚Äì and 10 years down the line is the result of what you do today. 

 Figure out what you want that future to look like and reverse engineer the daily actions you need to take to make it inevitable. 

 The three lessons above may sound basic or elementary to you, but most of the time, we don‚Äôt need revolutionary new advice. 

 We need to be reminded of the fundamental elements that lead to success and we need to actually practice them. 

 These masterminds always remind me how small I‚Äôm playing and how much further I have to go. 

 If you feel an equal need to get substantially richer, the application for my 1-on-1 and small group consulting is closing tomorrow. 

 No pressure and no fake scarcity, but this is one of your last chances to apply before our calls start on Monday. 

 ‚Äã Go here now to learn about The Bader Group. ‚Äã 

 I‚Äôm exhausted so apologies for the lack of personality in this one, but hope you liked it. 

 Need moor monies, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Four lokos and the secrets of the universe
body:
I met a homeless man while restocking on zyns a few minutes ago. 

 He wasn‚Äôt all the way there mentally, but enough to tell me his name was David and make some small talk that didn‚Äôt necessarily confide within the usual ‚Äúweather and sportsball‚Äù chit-chat. 

 He first told me that God had answered his prayers and that he was going to see his family in 13 days. 

 We walked towards the back of the rundown 7/11 together to get him a ‚Äúbrew.‚Äù 

 He said he was from New York, and that word was a part of their slang. 

 In this case, ‚Äúbrew‚Äù meant a large gold four loko (which is utterly insane to be drinking casually). 

 As we made our way back to the counter, he told me that he‚Äôd spent 15 years in prison for trafficking cocaine, and it‚Äôd been tough ever since. 

 ‚ÄúI thought I was God, and it was a big mistake,‚Äù he exclaimed. 

 I told him I‚Äôd been there (not prison but rather feeling immortal). 

 It was a refreshing interaction. 

 Although the cards may not have fallen in his favor, he was in good spirits and seemed excited to enjoy the brew and pack of Newports I‚Äôd just bought him. 

 On my way home, I walked by Myron (fresh and fit guy) and Sneako filming a video. 

 They‚Äôd set up a table and chairs on the street corner with a sign that read ‚ÄúWhy women deserve less.‚Äù 

 As I walked by, a bus full of large, screaming women drove past slowly. 

 It‚Äôs one of those 2 story party buses that blasts music through the street. 

 My friend Mason has coined them the ‚Äúbrokie buses.‚Äù 

 I think we all appreciated the perfect irony as they panned the camera from the ‚ÄúWhy women deserve less‚Äù sign to the brokie bus full of hippos. 

 I‚Äôm sure that made for good content. 

 Anyway, I‚Äôm excited for the coming week. 

 Life has a way of reminding you of what you need to hear at the perfect time ‚Äì if you‚Äôre open to receiving it. 

 It‚Äôll guide you in the right direction when you‚Äôre looking for answers and shoot you down when you‚Äôre flying too close to the sun. 

 The more I‚Äôve relied on intuition and divine guidance, the more I see how everything is connected. 

 Your relationships, work, habits, and even quick interactions with homeless people. 

 It‚Äôs all intertwined and likely relaying an important message if you‚Äôre cognizant enough to receive it. 

 Have a killer week, and don‚Äôt participate in drug trafficking, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Let me know if you read this one :) 

 ‚Äã

subject: Have you been in Vogue?
body:
I forgot my headphones today. 

 This is one of the many minor inconveniences that come with living in a box 30-something floors up in the middle of a city. 

 I realized I‚Äôd forgotten my headphones the second I got off the elevator. 

 But at that point, I‚Äôd already taken the trek down. 

 Am I really gonna click the button to go back up, stand there like a wagie, and bobble my head to the non-existent elevator music back up to my room? 

 No. I‚Äôm a man. 

 However, the crying baby in the coffee shop is making me reconsider this decision. 

 I think when I have kids, I‚Äôll be out of their lives until they turn 4 or 5. 

 At that point, I think they‚Äôre supposed to be potty trained, and I can start breeding them to go to the NBA. 

 This is why I like tall girls. We‚Äôll make a bunch of future all-stars and live vicariously through them as I grow old and start taking TRTs so I can keep up with my much younger model wife. 

 Hahaha. 

 Speaking of girls, I‚Äôve been reflecting on some things I‚Äôve learned about dating recently. 

 First, women are amazing. 

 Nearly every girl I meet is pleasant to be around and has their own unique vibe (if they‚Äôre comfortable enough to show that side of themself to you). 

 Don‚Äôt listen to the losers who tell you Western women are ruined. 

 Sure, not every girl you meet is gonna be a potential wife, and that‚Äôs okay. 

 Understanding this allows you to appreciate them for who they are and simply have fun. 

 It also gives you a more complete perspective on what qualities you look for in someone you would take more seriously and potentially date. 

 Next, take it slowwwwwww. 

 If you scroll through TikTok, you‚Äôll see ‚Äúdating coaches‚Äù say that you need to commit to someone within 1-3 months. 

 This is absolutely crazy in my opinion. Normalize 6-12 month talking stages. Sometimes longer. 

 Seriously. 

 It takes time to get to know someone. There are many things you‚Äôll learn about them that will only come out over time. 

 Rushing into a relationship is a surefire way that it‚Äôll go up in flames. 

 And no, this isn‚Äôt just a way to keep your freedom and avoid exclusivity. 

 It ensures that you guys actually know each other before you put a label on it. Because that label will only complicate things. 

 Little fights turn into UFC matches (not physically, I hope) and if the foundation of the relationship isn‚Äôt rock solid, it‚Äôll collapse. 

 Last thing and most important one. 

 If you‚Äôre a girl reading this, you should stop here. I‚Äôm sorry it has to be this way, but it does. 

 The solution to 99% of your ‚Äúgirl problems‚Äù is solved by having‚Ä¶ 

 options. 

 Lots of them. 3 Barbies, 2 Cinderellas, a Tinekerbell, and maybe a Harley Quinn or 3. 

 This sounds bad when I say it out loud like this, but I‚Äôm doing so for a reason: 

 Detachment. 

 Neediness has to be the #1 turn-off for women. And when she‚Äôs your only option, she can feel it. 

 Women are intuitive little creatures. They‚Äôre actually harder to deceive than men. 

 When you‚Äôre someone who truly has options, you care less about losing one of them, and it changes your entire demeanor. 

 You‚Äôre not a dancing monkey trying to impress her. You‚Äôre you. 

 They‚Äôll never admit it, but they like a man with options. 

 Crucify me. But I‚Äôm right. 

 Ok, enough for today. Lmk if you liked my takes on this topic and want to hear more. 

 Take a pretty model on a date tonight, 

 Ben 

 P.S. One of my subscribers suggested I take my old emails and basically turn them into a little blog. Any suggestions or ideas on how to do this (platforms, organization, etc.)? 

 ‚Äã

subject: Tend your own garden
body:
It was my 6 month anniversary with my wife yesterday. 

 We‚Äôre not dating, and we break up every three days. 

 But I was appalled by the absence of ‚ÄúHappy Anniversary‚Äù messages I got from my loyal subscribers. 

 Extremely rude of you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, but I guess we can move past it. 

 I want to make a documentary called ‚ÄúNormies In The Wild.‚Äù 

 It‚Äôd be a compilation of people freaking out while trying to navigate basic human tasks. 

 Have you ever observed the mid-IQ wagies in airports? Or coffee shops? Merging onto a highway? 

 It‚Äôs like their systems get overloaded, and they revert to monkey brains, where they just start making sounds and looking for bananas. 

 Anyway, let‚Äôs talk about more important things. 

 Imagine you‚Äôre building yourself a car. 

 You get all the parts you need and spend countless hours configuring your vehicle. 

 Finally, you‚Äôre ready to hit the road. 

 You hop in and start driving. 

 At first, it‚Äôs great. You‚Äôre excited to finally enjoy the fruits of your labor. 

 But after a few hundred miles, the engine starts making a strange noise. 

 You pull over and pop the hood. 

 It‚Äôs a minor problem, and you know exactly what you need to do to fix it. 

 You close the hood and tell yourself you‚Äôll fix it later. 

 As you continue driving, you see another car and are immediately enamored. 

 ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the kind of car I want,‚Äù you think to yourself. 

 When you get home, you order parts and set out to build it. 

 Over the next few months, you start neglecting car #1, and the minor problem with the engine has turned into a much bigger issue. 

 Instead of fixing it, you spend all your time building a new car. 

 And finally, once your ‚Äúperfect‚Äù car is ready, you hit the road. And the cycle continues. You see a new car you like better, neglect your own, and start all over. 

 See where I‚Äôm going with this? 

 This is how many of us treat our businesses, relationships, and a variety of other endeavors. 

 We spend so much time laying the foundation for what could be something special. 

 But once the novelty wears off and we realize the constant maintenance that‚Äôs necessary for continuous progression, we start looking for the "new thing." 

 Instead of putting our feet on the gas and maximizing what‚Äôs in front of us, we let what we‚Äôve built deteriorate so that we can have an excuse to start all over. 

 It‚Äôs a familiar comfort. It allows for the illusion of productivity. But it keeps you stuck. 

 And don‚Äôt you want to find out how far you can go if you can resist the urge to turn your head every time you see a new girl in a red dress? 

 Water your own plants. Today, tomorrow, and especially in 6 months when it‚Äôs no longer as exciting. 

 Thx for reading, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Don't be dumb, get rich
body:
Fuck it‚Äôs only 9:49 am. 

 I haven‚Äôt even been here for 2 hours yet, and I‚Äôm already counting down the time until I can leave‚Ä¶ Gonna be a long week. 

 This is how I remember Mondays sitting in class. 

 Odds are you can relate, and maybe those thoughts are going on in your head as you read this if you‚Äôre in school or at a job you don‚Äôt like. 

 Side note: There‚Äôs about $600,000 worth of Patek Phillipes on the wrists of the two men sitting across from me at the coffee shop right now. 

 Let‚Äôs talk about money. 

 Odds are, it‚Äôs at the forefront of your mind. 

 It‚Äôs the reason why you‚Äôre living the life that you are right now. 

 Whether that reality aligns with what you want or not is completely on you. 

 Before I had money, I hated Mondays. 

 Today, I woke up at 7:31 am, got dressed, and walked over to the coffee shop to knock out some work and write this email. 

 I enjoy this routine. 

 My life has gotten exceptionally better as I've made more money, and I‚Äôm still relatively poor. 

 The lesson I have for you today is this: 

 You owe it to yourself to make money. 

 You owe it to yourself not to have to think about money. 

 You owe it to yourself to be able to live wherever you want, with whoever you want, and actualize the lifestyle you dreamt of while you were naive enough to think you could do anything. 

 And you will never be able to experience the full spectrum of what life has to offer if you‚Äôre trapped worrying about expenses. 

 But I have good news: 

 Making money is easy. 

 All you have to do is crack the ‚Äúmoney code‚Äù once. 

 Develop a skill set that people are willing to pay you for‚Ä¶ 

 Or learn how to build and sell products‚Ä¶ 

 Or solve some other niche problem for people. 

 Boom, now you have some kind of value to add to the financial ecosystem that you can sell repeatedly. 

 Do that until rich. 

 You don‚Äôt have to be exceptionally smart, creative, or ingenious. 

 You just have to be stupid enough to not be stupid. 

 Action. Action. Action. 

 That‚Äôs it. Don‚Äôt be stupid. 

 This email is especially simple to prove to you that I am no smarter than you. 

 All of my friends are relatively rich. 

 And all of my friends are likey no smarter than you either. 

 Do not be dumb. Get rich. It‚Äôs easy. 

 Enough motivation for today. 

 Gonna go do things that will make me money! 

 I recommend you do the same :) 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: You are that guy (or girl i guess)
body:
Gm. 

 When was the last time you thought about how lucky you were to be alive? 

 I‚Äôve found that I‚Äôm usually more grateful in times of stress or when I feel like things aren‚Äôt going my way. 

 It‚Äôs these times that force you to zoom out. 

 You‚Äôll be beating yourself up, feeling like the walls are caving in, and then boom - you have a glimpse of consciousness that puts it all in perspective. 

 And you realize that your problems are amazing problems to have. 

 Maybe you don‚Äôt want to hear this right now. 

 Maybe you think I‚Äôm turning into a life coach who lives in Bali and makes $3k/mo selling breathwork classes. 

 But let's just take a second to appreciate what we have. 

 ‚Ä¶ 

 On to today‚Äôs lesson. 

 Developing magnetism in yourself will change your life. 

 It‚Äôs not something you‚Äôre necessarily conscious of but rather a byproduct of living your life a certain way. 

 You know people who seem just to have this special aura about them? 

 It makes you respect them and want to be around them. They lift your energy and make you feel better about yourself. 

 Recently, I‚Äôve noticed that people generally perceive me quite positively. 

 I‚Äôll get random invites to things, girls will pursue me to an extent, service workers love me, and I have absolutely amazing friends in my life. 

 I‚Äôm not saying this to gloat here. 

 I‚Äôve had times in my life where it feels like I‚Äôve been perceived as the exact opposite of what I just described above. 

 If I had to boil down what‚Äôs changed for me into one word, it‚Äôd be this: 

 Expression. 

 People like it when they can be themselves. They like it when they know they‚Äôre not gonna be judged or used for some ulterior motive. 

 And the easiest way to get people into this state is to be in it yourself. 

 When you‚Äôre truly you ‚Äì you say what you want, you‚Äôre honest, you‚Äôre observant‚Ä¶ it creates this genuine look in your eyes and your smile. 

 People can just sense it. 

 But this is only developed when you cultivate enough respect for yourself to stop suppressing who you really are. 

 So let me remind you: 

 You are uniquely you. 

 You‚Äôve overcome every hurdle you‚Äôve encountered. 

 You‚Äôve relied on yourself in times of hardship and uncertainty. 

 And you got yourself through it. 

 There's a voice inside you that knows the way. 

 That trusts you fully.
That accepts you for who you are. 

 You owe it to that voice to bring it to life. 

 And when you do ‚Äì you deserve the world. 

 Be you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 Love ya, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Life is working
body:
Sorry for the week-long hiatus, but I‚Äôm back. 

 It‚Äôs been frigid the last few days in Miami, like mid 50‚Äôs- low 60‚Äôs cold. 

 I‚Äôm going to New York tomorrow, and I don‚Äôt imagine it‚Äôll be any warmer there. 

 Such a tough life! 

 I can‚Äôt remember if I‚Äôve told you about one of my friends who works in my building. 

 He‚Äôs a Hispanic dude in his early 40‚Äôs but looks much younger. 

 We see each other nearly daily, and he talks to me in Spanish as I nod and smile in confusion. 

 I don‚Äôt know his name so I call him Papi. I genuinely think he‚Äôs the happiest person I know. 

 Papi always has a smile on his face and just radiates energy that lets you know he‚Äôs grateful to be alive. 

 Yesterday in the elevator I told him I just went to the gym (fui al gimnasio) and was about to get work done (voy a trabajo). 

 In English he said, ‚ÄúLife is working.‚Äù 

 Papi probably knows a total of 100 words in the English dictionary, but those three together can be quite powerful. 

 I recently realized that I‚Äôd developed a bad habit. 

 No matter how great things are, I‚Äôm constantly pondering every detail of my life ‚Äì even the things I already understand and have no reason to be stressing about. 

 ‚ÄúHow am I gonna make more money?‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúHow is this relationship gonna work out?‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt I feel the way I anticipated when I envisioned the lifestyle I‚Äôm living now?‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúWhat do I need to change?‚Äù 

 All I‚Äôm doing as I think about these things is reinforcing the idea that there is some future Utopia that I don‚Äôt have access to right now. 

 No bueno. 

 Most of us need to think less and do more. 

 You can analyze and reflect once you reach the top of the mountain. 

 But until then, 

 Feet on gas. 

 Head down. 

 Quiet mind. 

 Life is working. 

 Thanks for reading - glad to be back. 

 Talk soon, 

 Ben

subject: 3 steps to life-maxxing
body:
I saw my ex today. 

 She‚Äôs not really my ex because I never asked her to be my girlfriend, but nonetheless, we shared a lot of time together and many amazing memories. 

 Seeing her from across the restaurant that we used to go to together was strange. 

 We waved and briefly said hello as she walked by on her way out. 

 I got back from a 4-day bender in New York yesterday. 

 We didn‚Äôt do much other than go to dinner and the club with the 20 girls (literally) that we brought, but it was fun for obvious reasons. 

 My sincere apologies for neglecting you over the last two weeks. 

 Over the last 6 months, my lifestyle has taken a complete 180. 

 I barely went out during the first 10 months I lived in Miami. 

 While I had a circle of a few close friends, I was never the one to initiate the plans or make an effort to find exciting things to do. 

 After a while, it started feeling like I wasn‚Äôt my own person. 

 I became an extension of my friend group, who lacked his own interests, hobbies, and network. 

 And most of my nights were spent sitting at my desk with a lit candle and some music in the background, clicking buttons on my computer. 

 Now, nights like this are rare, and I have an added appreciation for them. 

 While the work I did during the time when I lacked a social life laid the groundwork for us getting to 6 figure months with my agency, life feels a lot fuller now. 

 I‚Äôm sure there will be a time when I go back to being a bit more of a hobbit, but this work-hard, play-hard lifestyle is much more enjoyable for my current stage. 

 Here are some of the things I did that allowed me to build a fun social life while continuing to grow my business: 

 1. Delegation 

 I sent a $30,000 wire to a team member/friend today. 

 Bringing him on was one of the best decisions I‚Äôve made. 

 It‚Äôs made it much easier for me, freed up my time, and the quality of work we‚Äôre able to deliver has improved. 

 After all, money is just a number on a screen until you put it to use. 

 If you‚Äôre unwilling to sacrifice some margin, have fun being trapped at your desk all day. 

 2. Branching out 

 I went out of my way to make new friends and build a bigger network in Miami. 

 Once I met one or two well-connected people, it created a snowball effect in my social life. 

 Outside of just my network, I started to ‚Äúbranch out‚Äù by taking up new hobbies, like boxing and tennis. 

 Finding new interests and hobbies like this helped me reinvent my perception of myself. 

 This helped reshape my identity and made me feel like I had more exciting things going on in my life. 

 3. Social media 

 If you go look at my Instagram toward the end of July, you can see a shift occur. 

 Even my facial expression and demeanor appear more confident in more recent photos. 

 I know it may sound superficial, but putting effort into making a better-looking Instagram and posting consistently on TikTok has opened so many doors and brought me a world of connections. 

 These three things helped me enter a version of myself that I couldn‚Äôt access previously. 

 My lifestyle is exactly the way I envisioned it when I pictured living in Miami. 

 Although this is just a ‚Äúside quest‚Äù to the main mission (getting disgustingly rich), it‚Äôs brought me a lot of clarity and taught me lessons that I couldn‚Äôt have learned at my desk. 

 Cheers to life-maxxing. 

 Call your ex today, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Reply if you read this whole thing and happy early Valentines Day baby <3

subject: You create your problems on purpose
body:
The ‚Äúmake money online‚Äù info-product space is starting to give me a headache. 

 Everyone is teaching things that they‚Äôve never done to naive beginners who have a better shot at getting struck by lightning than they do to succeed with whatever business model they‚Äôre being sold on. 

 Am I bitter that some of the people selling these courses are making more money than me? 

 Yes. 

 But as you frequently see people do online, I‚Äôll take the moral high ground in order to opt out of feeling envy. 

 I just want to print cash by writing words in a cafe for a few hours daily. 

 No fulfillment, no calls, no community. 

 Just cold hard course content. 

 Recently, I‚Äôve had 692 things on my mind at any given moment. 

 I‚Äôve found creative ways to stress about things that don‚Äôt need to be stressed about. 

 You know how sometimes you‚Äôll have days when you‚Äôre constantly anxious and feel like the world is ending? 

 It‚Äôs interesting to observe yourself on these days. 

 You‚Äôll realize that you‚Äôre repeating the same negative thought pattern repeatedly. 

 Whatever you‚Äôre thinking about likely only requires a few minutes of consideration, but you let it consume your mind all day. 

 Next thing you know, you‚Äôre super stressed out for no reason. 

 And it‚Äôs almost like you enjoy this stress. 

 I guess feeling something is better than feeling nothing. 

 This brings me back to a topic I frequently revisit: Acceptance. 

 When will you learn to accept what is? 

 You‚Äôre creating problems out of boredom. 

 It‚Äôs like you‚Äôre taking out a magnifying lens and analyzing a painting to see if you can find any tiny flaws. 

 Once you find them, you obsess over them, even though they only account for less than 1% of the entire portrait. 

 Now you‚Äôre distracted. 

 You can‚Äôt focus on what really matters. 

 You start neglecting the things that you know are good for you. 

 And now that your attention is scattered, you can‚Äôt show up as the full, present version of yourself because a large portion of who you are is trapped inside your own head. 

 The solution? 

 Idk. Maybe write an email about it. 

 Tends to help me. 

 I hop this one made sense. I have to get on a call and don‚Äôt have time to proofread or revise it. 

 I WILL send you an email tomorrow (maybe), 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Dumb = Rich
body:
I‚Äôve been grinding all morning and am now trying to switch my brain back to creative mode to write this email. 

 This would be a lot easier with a zyn, but I quit (again) 3 days ago. 

 One thing I‚Äôve realized recently is that everyone is dumb. 

 Even smart people. 

 Actually, especially smart people. 

 All of the rich young dudes that you see on social media are likely no more intelligent than you. 

 They‚Äôre unorganized, naive, and negligent. 

 The key to their success is simplicity. 

 They have a few personality traits and skills that allow them to thrive ‚Äì and they‚Äôre dumb enough to double down on those two things. 

 Yesterday, I was telling a friend how the majority of advice I give to people who are trying to scale their agency or coaching program goes as follows: 

 Me: ‚ÄúWhat have you done that‚Äôs worked so far?‚Äù 

 Agency guy: ‚ÄúI got 3 clients by sending cold DMs.‚Äù 

 Coaching guy: ‚ÄúI sold 5 people who found me on TikTok.‚Äù 

 Me: ‚ÄúOkay, do more of that.‚Äù 

 Do you see how stupidly simple this is? 

 But it‚Äôs literally the secret. 

 Find something that works ‚Äì do it a lot. 

 The same thing goes for your day-to-day life. 

 Highs and lows are natural. 

 I‚Äôll have part of my day where I feel like the world is ending and other parts where everything seems perfect. 

 I know that I am in a better mental state when I occupy my mind with productive tasks. 

 The more progress I make, the less stressed I become and the better I feel. 

 I think the key here is identifying your non-negotiable daily habits that keep you sane. 

 For me, some of these are writing, making content, journaling, walking, and boxing or lifting. 

 No matter what, you won‚Äôt be in a peak mental state every day ‚Äì that‚Äôs just not realistic. 

 But if you identify a few things that keep you at least around a 6 or 7 out of 10 each day, and you‚Äôre consistent with them, you can decrease the power of the tide in your emotional state. 

 This email is kind of a culmination of half-baked ideas, but I gotta go meet a friend for lunch, so we‚Äôre gonna end this here for today. 

 Talk tomorrow, thx for reading, 

 Ben

subject: Who are you competing with?
body:
Yesterday, I saw a clip of Johnny Manziel talking about how depressed he was during his first couple of years playing in the NFL. 

 He said Lebron, who was his childhood hero, would call him a few times a week to hang out, and he‚Äôd decline because he didn‚Äôt want to leave the house. 

 Looking at this from the outside in, here‚Äôs what I gather: 

 Once you begin to get the things you want, you gradually internalize that they won‚Äôt change anything. 

 By ‚Äúthings you want,‚Äù I don't just mean material items or lifestyle, but also your outward perception. 

 You can get all the praise, respect, and validation. 

 You can be the guy other dudes envy and girls want to be with. 

 This comes with a lot of pressure, which can break you if your self-image isn‚Äôt rock solid. 

 The expectations of others start to weigh on you, and your standards rise to a level that takes a lot to maintain. 

 If you feel undeserving, you manifest that idea into reality. 

 Your motivation dwindles, you lack discipline, and you start to let your problems add up. 

 ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt outperform your self-image.‚Äù 

 The weight of the contrast between how others perceive you versus how you perceive yourself causes you to crumble. 

 That make sense? 

 Anyway, a guy in front of me at this coffee shop is reading the book ‚Äú7 Habits Of Highly Effective People.‚Äù 

 He‚Äôs mouthing the words as he reads, which I find interesting. 

 When I walked in to order my coffee, the barista told me she liked my hoodie and replied, ‚ÄúBen 10‚Äù when I told her my name was Ben. 

 I found that endearing, so I gave her the Van Cleef bracelet off my wrist. 

 One time, I sat next to Johnny Manziel at dinner (I think I told you about that in an email months ago). 

 Not long after, he DM‚Äôd the girl I was with that night. 

 Shooters shoot, I guess. 

 Last thing ‚Äì Yesterday, I was journaling and asked myself, ‚ÄúWhat would make your life better than it is right now?‚Äù 

 It was easy to come up with an answer to that question, and I found it interesting that my answer had little to do with more money or anything flashy. 

 I encourage you to ask yourself the same thing when you have 20 min today. 

 Thanks for reading, and hope you enjoyed, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Self improvement doesn't work
body:
Spotify and I haven‚Äôt been getting along recently. 

 Sometimes, I‚Äôll hit shuffle and it‚Äôll give me one banger after another. 

 Other times, it force-feeds me the same 6 songs until my mind goes numb from the repetition. 

 For the last few weeks, it‚Äôs been the latter. 

 Per usual I‚Äôm sitting at an ultra-liberal, hipster coffee shop, hoping that I‚Äôll get a good idea to write about before I bore you. 

 There‚Äôs a bulletin board of post-it notes in front of me with a bunch of Pinterest-esque quotes. 

 ‚ÄúBe happy! Enjoy 2024‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúYou are loved!‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúSmile! Today‚Äôs a great day‚Äù 

 Outside the quotes, a combination of people likely identify as ‚Äúcreatives‚Äù are promoting their work. 

 ‚ÄúNeed graphics? DM me on Instagram! @arthoe6969‚Äù 

 There are over 100 sticky notes and ‚Äúbusiness‚Äù cards on here. 

 Plus a lost cat flyer in the top right corner. 

 In the middle, nearly covered up by the self-love propaganda, there‚Äôs a note that says, ‚ÄúBe here now.‚Äù 

 Probably a lesson in there. 

 Being present is something that‚Äôs a constant battle for me. 

 Two summers ago, I was on a beach in Greece, watching the sunset with a bunch of friends. 

 Instead of admiring the view, I was stuck in my head, stressing over whatever was happening in my business then. 

 I remember looking around at my friends and wondering if they were thinking about something else too, or if I was just broken. 

 Last night, a client of ours ran a webinar (where we made over $100k) and was asked the question: 

 ‚ÄúHow do you deal with stress as an entrepreneur?‚Äù 

 He said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚Ä¶ Nothing that I do is stressful,‚Äù and moved on to the next question. 

 As simple as this answer was, I found it interesting. 

 What you give your attention to grows. 

 The people who wrote these stupid little quotes on the board in front of me are probably unhappy. 

 They‚Äôre so obsessed with positive affirmations ‚Äì and fearful of anxiety, that they bring their fears to fruition. 

 The ‚Äúself-love‚Äù reminders attempt to convince themselves that they don‚Äôt hate themselves. 

 A happy person doesn‚Äôt need a reminder to be happy. They just are. 

 It‚Äôs almost like when you‚Äôre overly conscious about improving your mental health, it has an inverse effect. 

 Dictating how you feel can be as simple as making a decision. 

 Simply decide not to stress over something, stop giving it power, and it goes away. 

 When my client on the webinar was asked that question, it was like the idea of stress didn‚Äôt even exist in his world‚Ä¶ he was almost confused. 

 And, after all, worrying and over-analyzing do nothing but exacerbate the problem. 

 Maybe the answer is to bE hEre noW! 

 Corny but true. 

 I‚Äôm gonna start meditating. 

 Hope you and your Spotify shuffle get along today, 

 Ben

subject: it is what it should be
body:
I got multiple messages today asking when I‚Äôd write my next newsletter. 

 It made me feel bad for neglecting you, so here we are. 

 My sleep schedule is out of whack after a few late nights in Puerto Rico. 

 Here‚Äôs a thought that‚Äôs been rattling around in my brain: 

 We make decisions based on how we feel in the moment. 

 If you ask a girl to marry you after a long night of fighting because you told her that her sister is hot, she‚Äôll probably say no. 

 On the flip side, your chances are much higher if you propose during a romantic dinner on the Amalfi Coast while listening to old Frank Sinatra music. 

 Similarly, your potential customers must be put into a buying state when you ask them to purchase your product. 

 That‚Äôs why webinars have worked so well for our clients. 

 Every slide in the presentation is strategically placed to steer them into an emotional high. 

 They need to feel understood, they need to understand, and they need to believe. 

 Meaning you‚Äôve demonstrated that you empathize with their pain points and their exact dilemma. 

 You‚Äôve broken down how your method works, and they‚Äôre confident in it being the vehicle that will take them from pain to pleasure. 

 Lastly, you‚Äôve put them into a state where they‚Äôre hopeful they can overcome their previously held limiting beliefs. 

 And just like that, they‚Äôre ready to pull out their wallet when presented with the right offer. 

 When you want someone to do something, it‚Äôs your job to understand how they feel in the current moment. 

 Even the words on this page are reflective of the current state I‚Äôm in. 

 Switching gears a bit, life is beautiful. 

 Do not miss it. 

 Do not take it for granted. 

 Do not tell yourself something is missing, as you will always find something to look for. 

 The thing you are looking for is you. 

 You have the power to bend reality to your will. 

 A few years ago, I was at a frat party, looking around at everyone happily drinking, and I remember this moment when the lights turned on in my brain. 

 I had no purpose and was going down a route that would lead me to a lifetime of emptiness. 

 In that instant, I decided I‚Äôd change my path. 

 Fast forward to now; these past few days have felt like a movie. 

 I celebrated my friend's birthday with amazing people, took a jet to and from PR, and hopped in my dream car to drive to dinner at Carbone. 

 It‚Äôs all possible, my friend. 

 And when you get here, don‚Äôt forget to enjoy it. 

 Goodnight, 

 Ben

subject: The opposite of locked in
body:
Happy Friday {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 I wrote this one yesterday and forgot to send it once I got to my hotel, so I am sending it now. 

 Enjoy <3 

 ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

 I‚Äôm on a flight to LA right now. 

 I land in about 30 minutes and have spent the last 4 hours finding clever ways to procrastinate writing this email. 

 It started with the usual scroll through social media, but that can only last so long. 

 So I got creative. I took a personality quiz, changed my return flight, got ahead on some work, and did enough research on LA restaurants that I could write one of those gay ‚ÄúTop 10 MUST TRY spots in LA‚Äù blog posts. 

 Just so you know, I‚Äôm in seat 1A. There‚Äôs no reason for me to tell you this, but I figured I‚Äôd tell you anyway. 

 Let‚Äôs talk about money and identity. 

 When I first started making some money a few years ago, my mental well-being became entirely reliant on my monthly income. 

 When I‚Äôd hit a new all-time high, I‚Äôd be over the moon. 

 I was more confident, I spoke with conviction, and I generally felt and acted much more positively. 

 Conversely, when my monthly income stagnated or regressed, I lost all confidence and was in a constant state of panic. 

 When I‚Äôd talk to people, I wasn‚Äôt really there. I was physically there, but my mind would drift, drowning out the person who was talking with my own thoughts. 

 These times were interesting. 

 This fight-or-flight mode wasn‚Äôt pleasant, but I think it helped me progress quicker. 

 All I thought about was business. 

 Recently, it‚Äôs been the opposite. I honestly don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs been a good or bad month for the agency numbers-wise. 

 We did help a client make $400k in 4 days recently which was pretty cool. 

 He paid us our commission in crypto, so I threw all that money into a meme coin. 

 Back to the main point - I‚Äôve been the opposite of ‚Äúlocked in‚Äù recently. 

 Locked out? 

 Opened in? 

 Not sure of the correct term. 

 Everyone loves to act like they‚Äôre always working so hard. 

 This may cause you to feel like you constantly need to be at war, as it did for me. 

 It also meant my self-image was tied to my income. 

 While I think that can be a good thing to an extent, it‚Äôs a hamster wheel that no amount of money can get you off of. 

 Sure, if you‚Äôre not growing, you‚Äôre dying ‚Äî but growth can come in many forms. 

 It doesn‚Äôt always mean you‚Äôre doubling your monthly income or spending 12 hours a day at your desk. 

 Maybe it means you‚Äôre traveling more, building deeper relationships, beating your friend Jimmy in 2K, etc. 

 Simply side questing. 

 And know there will be a time when you need to lock back in. 

 You can‚Äôt just coast forever ‚Äî but sometimes, momentary coasting can help you return to work with an added excitement. 

 Or at least that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm telling myself. 

 I'm about to land and gotta wrap this up, but there is one last thing I want to add‚Ä¶ 

 *Everything I just said does not apply to you if you don‚Äôt have enough money to fulfill the immediate image that pops into your head when you think about having money. 

 For me, that image is the exact life I‚Äôm living now. 

 I imagine for me to find the motivation to push beyond where I‚Äôm at now, that vision must evolve. 

 Ok, I just landed. Gotta go. Missed you, let me know if this one made sense to you. 

 Bye from 1A, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Why you need to get punched in the face
body:
I just got home from sparring with my boxing coach. 

 We were going pretty light, though he caught me in the head a few times. 

 Maybe I‚Äôm a weirdo, but it feels really good to get hit in the face. 

 We‚Äôll be trading punches, somewhat messing around until boom‚Ä¶ 

 I‚Äôll move the wrong way and position my face perfectly into his jab. 

 There‚Äôs this feeling of aliveness that comes after that moment. 

 It‚Äôs like a signal goes through my brain that says, ‚ÄúOkay, time to lock in,‚Äù while I simultaneously realize that I‚Äôm not going to die. 

 Immediately after, I enter a new state where I‚Äôm much more free-flowing, and my energy is revitalized. 

 I‚Äôm ready to attack because once that first punch connects with my nose, I‚Äôm no longer scared of it. 

 I know I‚Äôm gonna be okay no matter what. 

 There‚Äôs an equally powerful lesson in there that we can extrapolate to life. 

 Sometimes, you have to let yourself get rocked. 

 When you‚Äôre comfortable at a certain income level or have enough money in the bank to where you wouldn't have to work for the next couple of years‚Ä¶ 

 You have to punch yourself. 

 You‚Äôre trying to live comfortably and ignore the possibility that reality could rock you with a right hook if you‚Äôre too slow. 

 Over the last few months, I completed the vision that I‚Äôd been aiming at for a while. 

 My business reached six-figure months, I bought my dream car, my social life was thriving, and I was living in the exact movie that I used to dream of. 

 After a few months of fun, my anxiety started to increase. 

 I‚Äôm not growing. I‚Äôm not evolving or working towards anything. 

 And admittedly, I started to take my foot off the gas. 

 This life I aspired to attain began to feel empty, and I was left with the feeling of‚Ä¶ 

 ‚ÄúWhat now?‚Äù 

 Stagnation served as a punch. 

 Stay in the same place for too long, and you become predictable. 

 Become predictable, and you get hit. 

 But the solution is simple. 

 You gotta keep moving. 

 Reach a milestone, great. What's the next level you can get to? 

 Picture it. 

 Maybe it‚Äôs a house in the hills, more supercars, and the ability to fly private whenever you want. 

 Or you don‚Äôt want to feel an ounce of anxiety on any purchase under 6 figures. 

 You want a penthouse, your girl wants a Birkin, and you want to put a family member on payroll to do nothing. 

 Sure many of these are materialistic, but it‚Äôs your reality ‚Äì you can design it however you‚Äôd like. 

 You‚Äôve just begun to taste freedom. You‚Äôre not even scratching the surface of how you could live, and you‚Äôre getting comfortable. 

 Don‚Äôt rob yourself. 

 True freedom has no bounds, and the only limits come through your imagination. 

 Let your imagination run free, and you‚Äôll create a new movie in your head that you aspire to live in. 

 That's your new goal. 

 Start building towards it now unless you want to wait until you get knocked on your ass. 

 And by then, it‚Äôll be a hell of a lot harder to get up. 

 Thanks for reading, and I promise I‚Äôm really back for good this time. 

 Lmk if you liked this one, 

 Ben

subject: How to manifest without being weird
body:
There are some elements of spirituality that I find rather stupid. 

 Once upon a time, I hired a ‚Äúlife coach.‚Äù 

 After our first call together, I decided I didn‚Äôt need him and would instead take life advice from myself. 

 He was one of those meditate in Bali, peace and self-love types. 

 This is loosely related to the topic of this email, but it popped into my head when I started thinking about spirituality. 

 If manifestation and the law of attraction sound a bit out there to you, I‚Äôm gonna try to break down what I believe these concepts to be as simply as I can. 

 Your subconscious is constantly working either for or against you. 

 When you set goals and intentions, you give your subconscious a direction to follow. 

 When you fail to do so, your brain finds another way to occupy itself that likely isn‚Äôt conducive to the reality you want to build. 

 The most simple example of this that I see is in my habits and daily routine. 

 Making content every day has been a priority of mine for a while. 

 I‚Äôve noticed I‚Äôm the most consistent, and content ideas come to me easily when I‚Äôm intentional. 

 If I write ‚Äútweet 3 times‚Äù or ‚Äúmake 2 videos‚Äù on my to-do list for the day, my subconscious starts to help me out. 

 I‚Äôll be walking to the coffee shop to get an iced vanilla latte from a blue-haired barista with an Adams apple who calls him(her?)self Megan, and boom ‚Äì I‚Äôll get a random idea for a video. 

 Could it be a coincidence? 

 Sure. But nearly every time I set intentions like this, completing the action becomes easier. 

 Although this is just one basic example, I hope it‚Äôs starting to illustrate the point. 

 What you focus on and put your attention toward grows, even if you‚Äôre not conscious of it. 

 If you‚Äôre obsessed with reaching a new income level, your brain is constantly working on that problem in the background. 

 You‚Äôll get an idea while you‚Äôre driving or doing some other mindless activity, and it‚Äôll be the key to reaching that next milestone you‚Äôre aiming for. 

 You might feel like the idea came out of nowhere, but it‚Äôs likely because you‚Äôve given your subconscious something to occupy itself with. 

 And eventually, it finds the solution. 

 The same thing goes for anything that you want in life. 

 If you can create a clear image of the lifestyle, people you‚Äôre surrounded by, what you‚Äôre doing for work, how your routine looks, and the general way of life you want to build‚Ä¶ 

 And you work towards those things‚Ä¶ 

 The combination of the work and setting intentions will eventually reach a perfect storm and you‚Äôll feel like everything somehow ended up exactly how you wanted it. 

 The way that your goals unfold likely won‚Äôt be how you imagined, but that‚Äôs a topic for another email. 

 Hope you enjoyed this one and it made sense to you. 

 Happy Friday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I finally compiled my old emails and aded them to this site ‚Äì you don‚Äôt have to opt in over there, just scroll down to view previous newsletters. 

 ‚Äã

subject: Angry normies & how dating is like an iceberg
body:
A large corner of the internet is very angry at me right now because of this tweet. ‚Äã

 They‚Äôre calling me a scammer posting rage bait to sell my course. 

 If you‚Äôve been around for a while, you know I don‚Äôt have one ‚Äì although I probably should. 

 This reaction has been surprising to me as I didn‚Äôt think much of the post when I sent it. 

 The thought was formed while I was in a crowded elevator going up to my apartment. 

 There was a guy who looked a few years older than me with airpods in and a bag of Chipotle in hand. 

 He was visibly disgruntled, carrying a black work bag. 

 When we stopped to let others off on the way up, he spammed the ‚Äúclose door‚Äù button, almost shutting it on a few people who were too slow for his liking. 

 Considering it was a Friday around 5 pm, I imagined he‚Äôd just gotten off work after a long, boring week and was eager to get home and devour his burrito on the couch. 

 I could be completely wrong in my assessment, but I then started thinking about what my life would‚Äôve looked like had I continued on the college, 9-5 route. 

 And that tweet is what I came up with. 

 I didn‚Äôt mean to attack this life path but rather paint a vivid picture of what I wanted to avoid ‚Äì who knows if it would‚Äôve actually been my reality. 

 My Twitter is unusable right now, as every time I refresh, I have dozens of new notifications from wagies who felt attacked by my words. 

 If anything, they‚Äôre proving my point to be true; if they didn‚Äôt partially identify with the person I described, they wouldn‚Äôt be offended, right? 

 To me, it looks like they‚Äôre trying to defend the lie they‚Äôve sold themselves that they‚Äôre happy with an average existence. 

 I guess every hive needs worker bees. 

 Anyway, I‚Äôll stop being mean and move on to a completely unrelated topic. 

 Something that‚Äôs been on my mind recently is the difference between short ‚Äúflings‚Äù and hookups compared to longer-term relationships. 

 Any guy who‚Äôs casually dated many girls knows at some point, the game gets a bit too easy. 

 Although it‚Äôs fun, it‚Äôs kind of like an iceberg. 

 You show someone just enough of your personality for them to start to romanticize you. 

 By nature, you end up saying similar lines, sharing the same stories, and cultivating a particular image of yourself. 

 You can do this endlessly ‚Äì revealing a glimpse of your character to new people over and over. 

 Once you reach the stage where the entire tip of the iceberg has been revealed (pause, no homo), you bounce to the next situationship to do it all over again. 

 You never give anyone the chance to get to know you past the image you aim to portray. 

 And there‚Äôs nothing wrong with that. Maybe it‚Äôs just a phase of life that you‚Äôre in, or you‚Äôre especially selective about who you spend an extended period of time with. 

 But if and when you move past the casual fling stage, you realize there‚Äôs no longer a place to hide. 

 Your flaws and insecurities are reflected back to you when you let someone get to know the real you, and that process reveals your self-image. 

 Fake confidence only lasts for so long, and if there are areas in your identity that you‚Äôre not comfortable with, you‚Äôll be forced to make amends with them. 

 I hope this makes sense to you. I‚Äôd go a bit more in-depth, but I just realized that I have hundreds of new subscribers here. 

 Some of whom are probably ops that were angry at my tweet and will do anything they can to take what I say in this email out of context. 

 So I‚Äôll let them weed themselves out, and then we‚Äôll continue our regularly scheduled programming. 

 Anyway, It‚Äôs date night with sweet pea tonight! 

 Can‚Äôt wait to try the restaurant and watch our favorite show on the couch!!!! 

 Hah. 

 Happy early Easter, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you‚Äôre new here, watch this to learn more about me and how I built a 7-figure copywriting business. ‚Äã

 P.P.S. Check out my previous emails here. ‚Äã

subject: The antidote to resistance
body:
I‚Äôve grown to love the peaceful Sunday night at home. 

 When I was in school, this day was always dreadful. 

 Monday morning was around the corner and the looming stockpile of work I‚Äôd been procrastinating was staring me in the face. 

 I was just debating whether or not I‚Äôd write an email to you today. 

 There are a million excuses my brain could come up with as to why I shouldn‚Äôt. 

 But then I thought about the feeling I get after completing one of these. 

 It‚Äôs like when the endorphins kick in after a tough workout. 

 Maybe you didn‚Äôt want to do it, but you always feel better once it‚Äôs done. 

 There are many things that we resist even though we know they‚Äôre good for us. 

 If you‚Äôre building a business you can likely think of a few off the top of your head. 

 The boring 30 minutes of outreach. 

 The long meeting with your sales team. 

 Or the time spent planning your week to stay on track with your next income goal. 

 Usually, with tasks like this, the only immediate reward you get is internal. 

 Going to the gym once won‚Äôt add 15 pounds of muscle. 

 You won‚Äôt close a client right after sending 20 DM‚Äôs. 

 And writing this email does nothing for me financially at the moment. 

 But these things give us that type of dopamine that can only be earned when we know we‚Äôre doing something positive for our future selves. 

 When a goal is accomplished, it‚Äôs a lagging indicator that shows you consistently completed those sometimes monotonous actions that yield you next to nothing in the short term. 

 As I contemplated writing this, I considered how I felt yesterday after I clicked send. 

 I knew replicating that same feeling would be worth it (plus, I actually enjoy writing these). 

 So I guess that‚Äôs my first piece of advice: 

 Any time you resist something good for you, think back to how you felt after the last time you did it. 

 And if it‚Äôs something that you‚Äôve never done before, replace that image with anything else you once felt a sense of accomplishment after completing. 

 If you can‚Äôt think of anything, you‚Äôre cooked. 

 But if you can, use it as fuel to complete the task in front of you. 

 This is how you rewire your brain to crave long-lasting, deserved dopamine rather than cheap, social media-infused dopamine. 

 It‚Äôs like how you view a relationship with someone who is easy to get versus someone you have to work for. 

 You‚Äôre always gonna place more value on the person who‚Äôs a challenge because you had to earn it, which shows they value themself. 

 When you bring a girl home after buying her two drinks and making fun of her shoes, that usually means she isn‚Äôt wifey material because if you could do it that easily, so could someone else. 

 Compared to the more elusive girl, who, although she likes you, wants to make sure you‚Äôre really the person you appear to be before she fully trusts you. 

 And that‚Äôs the difference between cheap dopamine and deserved dopamine. 

 The more you can teach your brain to run toward the hill that‚Äôs harder to climb, the better. 

 Anyway, hope you‚Äôre avoiding the Sunday scaries and ready to crush the week. 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã Read my previous emails here ‚Äã

subject: indirectly following your passion
body:
Ok, I know it‚Äôs probably past your bedtime, but I wanted to talk {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 If you‚Äôre reading this in the morning, gm. 

 I have an important topic for you: 

 Money. 

 The way you‚Äôre gonna get rich is to find the intersection between what you‚Äôre naturally good at/passionate about and what you can make money with. 

 Sure, you can figure out how to make money with a ‚Äúpassion project‚Äù or collect some shekels doing something you hate. 

 But these two elements are most powerful together. 

 When I think about the people I know who are crushing financially, their business fits their personality type. 

 My friend Mason built a multi-seven-figure business by yapping on TikTok and being relatable. 

 My friend Rob (who is worth many millions) is absolutely obsessed with building brands and actually uses the products he sells. 

 My Dad has always been a car enthusiast and makes his money flipping cars at auctions. 

 I was obsessed with basketball growing up and built my first business running ads for basketball trainers. 

 In school, I always enjoyed writing and built my second business using the skill of copywriting. 

 In all these examples, we ended up in vehicles that allowed us to make money using our predisposed interests. 

 Had we directly followed our passion, we‚Äôd be in very different spots. 

 I‚Äôm a few decisions away from being a journalist making $50k per year or teaching people how to dribble balls for a living. 

 If you need some direction, odds are you'll find it in discovering how to use your innate abilities to add value to other people's lives. 

 To get a bit more practical, if you‚Äôre a people person, use your networking skills to connect wealthy people and take a cut of the business they do together. 

 If you‚Äôre organized and good at managing multiple tasks, you can use that skill to be an operator in a company. 

 If you‚Äôre a hot girl, use that to swindle old men into giving you money. 

 I‚Äôd dive deeper into this idea, but I‚Äôm getting sleepy, and Glenda (my cleaner) is coming tomorrow morning, so I have to get up early. 

 Let‚Äôs talk more tomorrow, and hope you enjoyed this somewhat inconclusive ramble. 

 Goodnight, 

 Ben

subject: Decide, commit, act
body:
I‚Äôm 37 minutes into an hour-long Tai Lopez rant on YouTube and just clicked pause to write this. 

 Yesterday, I wrote a tweet about shifting your identity and wanted to expand on it. 

 It‚Äôs long, so it‚Äôll take up the majority of this email, but I genuinely think this is one of the keys to making continuous progress in any realm of life. 

 Here it is: 

 The speed at which you progress is dependent on your ability and willingness to shift into a new identity when you complete the vision you were formerly working toward. 

 When you actualize financial/lifestyle goals, it‚Äôs like you‚Äôre beating a level in a video game. the next level is an entirely different game, and you‚Äôre starting at zero with new obstacles that you‚Äôre unfamiliar with. 

 Sometimes, you may fail or refuse to move to the next level because you‚Äôre comfortable with the current level you‚Äôre operating at and the problems associated with it. 

 This is where you get trapped. 

 Stay in one identity for too long, and your lack of progression starts to eat away at you. 

 So, you begin to sabotage your current reality because you want to feel like you‚Äôre moving forward. 

 The only way to do that while avoiding a complete shift in your identity is to first move backward and then go back up the ladder you already climbed. 

 So you‚Äôre now spending your time beating the same level of a video game only to click the reset button and start over. 

 This is the trap of stagnation, where you give yourself the illusion of progress.‚Äù 

 I‚Äôve found that whenever I feel stuck, it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm simply refusing to step into a new identity. 

 Perhaps you‚Äôve heard the saying, ‚ÄúThe vehicle that gets you to point A isn‚Äôt the vehicle that gets you to point B.‚Äù 

 Similarly, the person you are right now has a ceiling. 

 You can reach a certain level financially, emotionally, and spiritually. 

 Once you reach the peak of that level, you have the choice to continue progressing or stay where you are. 

 And change is hard. 

 This is especially true when that change requires you to discard your previous beliefs about yourself and replace them with beliefs that will suit you in the new arena you are stepping into. 

 You can spend eons avoiding this and fool yourself into believing you‚Äôre making progress when you‚Äôre actually sputtering. 

 But this will only create an internal hell. 

 You know you‚Äôre capable of more, and you‚Äôre resisting. 

 The solution here can be summed up into three words: 

 Decide, commit, act. 

 Devise a plan to reach your next level, paint a vivid picture of how this new version of you operates, and execute that plan. 

 It‚Äôs the work you‚Äôre avoiding, the habits you‚Äôre refusing to develop, and the beliefs that hurt to change. 

 It‚Äôll be painful, but so will the feeling of staying the same. 

 And this is the only way through. 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã Read my previous emails here. ‚Äã

subject: Your standards determine your reality
body:
We procrastinate on the things we know we need to do most because we are afraid of becoming the person who is capable of doing them consistently. 

 For the last two weeks, the words ‚Äúmake a YouTube video‚Äù have been at the top of my to-do list. 

 Every day, I wake up and look at that task only to put it off to the next day. 

 Today, I finally got around to it, and it was a struggle. 

 Over a dozen takes later, I gave up. 

 I told myself, ‚ÄúAt least you tried,‚Äù and turned off the camera to go buy zyns. 

 As I stood in the hallway waiting for the elevator that was taking obnoxiously long to arrive, I thought about how I still wouldn‚Äôt be able to cross that off my to-do list. 

 Then, I considered how I‚Äôd feel if I‚Äôd accomplished it. 

 That‚Äôs when I turned around, walked back into my apartment, and made this video. ‚Äã

 And the weight of the unfinished task was finally lifted off my shoulders. 

 Recently, I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about standards. 

 It‚Äôs your standards that hold the invisible bar for what you believe you are capable of. 

 Whenever you want to transform into someone new, that bar has to be raised. 

 We know this, and it‚Äôs the reason that we sabotage ourselves. 

 You‚Äôre likely comfortable in the reality that you‚Äôre currently operating in. 

 Sure, you want to improve, but committing to the actions required to do so is a whole lot different than fantasizing about progress and telling yourself you‚Äôll get around to it one day. 

 So you place a ceiling on yourself and resist anything that forces you to step out of that box because you‚Äôd then show yourself that the ceiling is imaginary. 

 You‚Äôre capable of more, and you know it, but you‚Äôre refusing to give yourself data to solidify that. 

 Because then you can no longer be naive, and you have to exit the box of limitations you‚Äôre comfortably situated in. 

 And you‚Äôre forced to step into a new identity. 

 With that new identity comes a reality you‚Äôre unfamiliar with. 

 Challenges you haven‚Äôt faced and standards you‚Äôre not accustomed to. 

 It might be easier to stay where you are for now, but that voice telling you to do more won‚Äôt go away. 

 It‚Äôll torture you until you either quench it or suppress it enough to where you‚Äôre comfortably numb. 

 And the light that shines with hope behind your eyes will be gone. 

 That‚Äôs probably not a recipe for a happy and fulfilled life. 

 Don‚Äôt let that light go dim. 

 ‚Äã Watch my new YouTube video here :) ‚Äã

 Thanks for reading, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Read my previous emails here ‚Äã

subject: Clarity is earned
body:
I‚Äôm sitting on my balcony, watching boats go by. 

 The buildings are lit up, and the city is buzzing. 

 I have a 10:45pm dinner reservation at Carbone. 

 My friend Mason convinced me to go to the club after (against my will). 

 Opportunities are a lot like puzzles. 

 If you try to build a puzzle by mapping out where all the pieces will be placed, you‚Äôll never start. 

 You can sit there for hours, thinking about each piece individually and where it will end up. 

 But if you don‚Äôt combine any of them, you‚Äôll never get closer to a finished product. 

 Similarly, if you try to predict every step you will take to achieve a goal instead of taking step one, you‚Äôll never move closer to the goal. 

 Simple right? 

 Although this is an easy concept to grasp, it‚Äôs much more difficult to put into practice. 

 When you feel stuck, the problem is likely because there are too many different directions you could go in. 

 Obviously, you want to pick the best one, so you sit there thinking about how everything will work out. 

 This puts you in a state of inaction. 

 You tell yourself you‚Äôll start moving toward your goals once you have clarity on where to go. 

 But as you wait for some divine sign telling you what to do, the clarity you‚Äôre looking for continues to elude you. 

 So, you go back to the drawing board and start thinking more. 

 You can do this for eternity if you let yourself. 

 But the truth is opportunities are created through action. 

 You open one door, and the next opens up. 

 You take the wrong turn, and it reroutes you to the right one. 

 You must earn clarity. 

 When you‚Äôre lost, it‚Äôs because you‚Äôre refusing to step on the gas despite the fact that you don‚Äôt know where the road you‚Äôre going down will lead you. 

 Do the things that feel right, even if they offer no immediate reward. 

 Eventually, you‚Äôll end up in a situation where everything aligns, and you find the last piece of the puzzle. 

 That‚Äôs when the road becomes clear, and you can finally floor it. 

 It starts with step one. 

 See you at dinner, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Watch my new YouTube video here ‚Äã

subject: 5 steps to make more than an investment banker
body:
Happy Monday. 

 I genuinely think 90% of the people I meet sell info (courses and coaching). 

 Literally. 

 I met a 96-year-old woman named Dorthy on my coffee run this morning. 

 We started talking because she complimented my eyes and told me she hoped her granddaughter would find a guy like me one day. 

 She then started telling me how she sells a course teaching elderly women how to keep their husbands happy by learning how to bake her special apple pie with a secret ingredient. 

 The ingredient reinvigorates their marriage and helps them find that spark they felt years ago. 

 It‚Äôs called Viagra. 

 Dorthy grabbed my arm and asked if I wanted to try it. 

 That‚Äôs when I stole her cane and ran away. 

 Now, I‚Äôm writing this fictitious story to you with Dorthy's imaginary cane leaning up against my desk. 

 Jokes and fictional stories aside, EVERYONE SELLS INFO. 

 If you‚Äôre a copywriter, I don‚Äôt think finding opportunities working with coaches has ever been easier. 

 All you have to do is: 

 Become a competent writer and gain a fundamental understanding of how coaching businesses work. Send loom video pitches on Instagram until you get someone on the phone. Talk to the potential client and see what they need. Maybe it‚Äôs email copy, ad copy, video scripts, VSL scripts, funnel copy, etc. You are a copywriter. That means your skillset is versatile, and you should be able to fill whatever gap they have in their business to get your foot in the door. Once you close the client, go above and beyond. The bar for service providers is so low that if you simply put in more effort than what is asked, you will be rewarded. They‚Äôll send you referrals, give you a case study, or trust you to operate other parts of their business (meaning you can now charge more + rev share). Now, you turn a $3k/month client into a $10k/month client. Complete the process above a few times, and you‚Äôll be making more than the average investment banker at Goldman Sachs. 

 Plus, you didn‚Äôt have to snort Adderal and cheat off your smart Asian friend named Kevin for four years while getting your bachelor's degree. 

 That‚Äôs what I‚Äôd do if I had to start all over. 

 Even if you‚Äôre not a copywriter, the process I outlined is basically all you need to do to accelerate your success in any service-based business. 

 Your skillset gets you in the door, and you decide what happens now that you‚Äôre in the room. 

 If you earn the trust of the right person, one connection could change your life. 

 Just be competent and over-deliver. 

 Now you‚Äôre rich. 

 ‚Äã Thank me by watching this video and leaving a like and comment :) ‚Äã

 Peace, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you‚Äôre trying to build a copywriting or ‚Äúgrowth operating‚Äù business, hit reply and let me know what your biggest roadblock is right now. Building something cool for you.

subject: i was wrong
body:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }}, big news‚Ä¶ 

 I ordered a whiteboard. 

 It comes with a stand, markers, and erasers. 

 Cool right? 

 A problem I sometimes encounter when I sit down to write is that I start questioning whether the immediate idea that comes to mind is important enough to warrant an entire email. 

 As I sit here thinking about where to take this, I‚Äôve probably discarded five ideas. 

 All of which could have made for a banger email. 

 But because I don‚Äôt feel they‚Äôre worthy, I sit here telling myself my mind is blank. 

 I recently wrote about how your standards determine your reality and that if you want to improve anything, you have to raise the internal bar for what you perceive as acceptable. 

 I‚Äôm now realizing the opposite is also true. 

 I believe nerds call this a paradox. 

 (side note real quick ‚Äì Grammarly fucking sucks. It‚Äôs a tool that gives you suggestions on your writing, and everything it tells me to do sounds like it‚Äôs attempting to be an off-brand Shakespeare). 

 Anyway, back to the standards paradox. 

 Sometimes, if you don‚Äôt lower your standards, you won‚Äôt do anything. 

 You want to write the perfect message, make the best video possible, say the right line to the girl, or impress someone you look up to. 

 The desire for perfection has an inverse effect. 

 You don‚Äôt start, or you filter your thoughts, and you find any excuse not to approach the girl. 

 This is because the measuring stick is in the wrong place. 

 Instead of setting an incredibly high bar for the quality of the output, the bar needs to be set for the quantity of the input. 

 ‚ÄúI need a big idea for this email‚Äù becomes ‚ÄúI need to write an email today, no matter what.‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúI need to say the right line to the girl‚Äù becomes ‚ÄúI need to walk up and say anything.‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúI need to impress this person‚Äù becomes ‚ÄúI need to express myself and say what I‚Äôm thinking.‚Äù 

 You‚Äôre optimizing for reps instead of trying to protect your ego by being perfect. 

 Sure, I want to ‚Äúwow‚Äù you with every email I write. 

 But if I wait until I have a groundbreaking idea every time, I‚Äôd be writing once a quarter. 

 If I make sure to get this done even when I don‚Äôt feel heavily inspired, the quality of the output increases in correlation to the input. 

 That means do more of the thing, and you will get better at it way quicker than you would if you tried to do it perfectly. 

 There's a Harvard study about this. 

 Long story short, students in a ceramics class were separated into two groups. One group was told to make the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù clay pot, and the other was told to make as many as possible. 

 All of the best-looking pots came from the quantity group rather than the quality group. 

 You should get the point by now. 

 Be wary not to conflate having ‚Äúhigh standards‚Äù with a defense mechanism to protect your ego. 

 Odds are that when you fail to take action, you‚Äôre trying to save yourself the embarrassment of realizing that you have some improvement to make. 

 So does everyone else ‚Äì and those who improve the fastest are the ones who get the most reps. 

 Grammarly keeps giving me more dumb suggestions, so I‚Äôll wrap this up here, but go watch my recent YT video if you haven‚Äôt already. ‚Äã 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Reply if you liked this one :) ‚Äã

subject: My thoughts on "growth operating"
body:
I was having an amazing morning until now‚Ä¶ 

 It‚Äôs a beautiful 78-degree day in Miami. 

 Birds chirping, sun shining, and people genuinely seem happier here. 

 I walked to Soybucks to grab my iced shaken espresso. They greeted me with love and told me to have a great day. 

 I smiled and tossed the barista the keys to my G Wagon. 

 Then, everything changed. 

 I opened my phone and went to Instagram. 

 Boom, I see another pitch from some little ass kid telling me he could be my ‚Äúgrowth operator.‚Äù 

 He said, ‚ÄúBen, did you know you could monetize 1% of your audience??? I can make you $30k per month!‚Äù 

 If you don‚Äôt know what ‚Äúgrowth operating‚Äù is, let me fill you in. 

 You partner with someone who has a big audience, help them set up a Skool community, and take 50% of the profits. 

 It‚Äôs basically a simplified version of what we do at my info-product agency. 

 Obviously, I think it‚Äôs a solid business model to run, and it‚Äôs made me 7 figures. 

 But I think there‚Äôs a bit of a misconception about how it‚Äôs been positioned online. 

 From firsthand experience, I can promise you that helping someone scale an info-product is complex. 

 There are many moving pieces in these types of businesses, and you need to have a broad skill set along with a general understanding of the info-product space to succeed as a service provider. 

 You write email copy, build funnels, script video sales letters, build systems, and orchestrate the sales process. 

 If you‚Äôre a complete beginner, it‚Äôs damn near impossible to learn all these skills at once. 

 Instead, it makes much more sense to start by learning one thing and one thing only ‚Äì copywriting. 

 It‚Äôs the foundation of my business and the reason I‚Äôve scaled to 6 figures per month with my info agency. 

 We‚Äôve scaled offers from zero to $600k/month and orchestrated over a dozen multi-six-figure launches. 

 We helped a client go from $30k/mo to $350k/mo in a month and a half, and our smallest clients are making a minimum of $1m/year. 

 But I didn‚Äôt end up in this position by saying I wanted to be a ‚Äúgrowth operator.‚Äù That term didn‚Äôt even exist. 

 I worked as a freelance copywriter/marketer and eventually accumulated the skills required to run a full-stack agency for info products. 

 If I were starting all over again, I‚Äôd start by becoming the best copywriter I could be. I‚Äôd study all types of copy ‚Äì emails, ads, sales pages, VSLs, direct mail, billboards. 

 Then I‚Äôd start doing outreach to get clients while continuing to learn supplementary skills like funnel building, the different types of funnels, when to use which, how to navigate zapier, sales process management, etc. 

 Once I had a better understanding of these things, I‚Äôd pitch my copywriting clients on more services. 

 Get one really good case study, and boom ‚Äì now you have a real business. 

 Let me clarify, though: I‚Äôm not saying the growth operator business model is bad. The guys who teach it are legit. 

 But it‚Äôs not a beginner business model, and you won‚Äôt get anywhere close to 50% profits from any creator who knows what they‚Äôre doing. 

 If you‚Äôre starting from scratch, learn copy, and the next door will open for you. 

 Hope you enjoyed this one, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã Read my previous emails here. ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã
