subject: why your beliefs will change
body:
Goood morning {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Before I start rambling and forget to tell you, I made a new video explaining how I‚Äôve made $124,255 in a month as a copywriter. You can watch it here after you read this. ‚Äã 

 I‚Äôm sitting on my balcony as I write to you, and the dude who parades around the streets in Brickell while dancing on his bike is blasting the song ‚ÄúDance Monkey.‚Äù 

 If you‚Äôve ever been here, you probably know who I‚Äôm talking about. 

 He usually annoys me, but I‚Äôm in a good mood today, so I‚Äôm refraining from sniping him. 

 Anyway, whenever I see someone online pushing a narrative really hard, it makes me think they‚Äôre trying to convince themselves that it‚Äôs true. 

 I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôve all been guilty of this at some point. 

 But I keep seeing Alex Becker pop up on my Twitter timeline, talking about how ‚Äúfulfilled‚Äù he is by getting up at 3 am and sitting at his desk all day. 

 He‚Äôs a pioneer in the online money space, so no shade directly at him ‚Äì I just think that someone who is truly happy doesn‚Äôt have to tell you how happy they are. 

 In the same way, someone who‚Äôs found the right path for themselves doesn‚Äôt tell you how your path is wrong. 

 And a person who has a true relationship with God doesn‚Äôt judge you for not following the same rules they follow. 

 This problem seems to arise when you deeply subscribe to a belief and discard anything that may contradict that belief. You don‚Äôt understand that most things are temporary and there are few universal truths. 

 But because you‚Äôve fully convinced yourself that your way is the right way, when you encounter a situation where that belief is challenged, you take it as a threat. 

 It‚Äôs why someone who follows the college, 9-5 route gets angry when they see a 16-year-old with their annual salary on their wrist. 

 And on the contrary, it‚Äôs why a struggling entrepreneur feels the need to criticize 9-5ers so they can solidify that they made the right choice in their own mind. 

 There‚Äôs a sliver of doubt that they‚Äôre attempting to cover up by denying that any alternative could be true. 

 But that‚Äôs the thing ‚Äì the alternative can almost always be true. 

 One thing I know with 100% certainty is that my outlook on life will change over time. It‚Äôs supposed to. 

 Different seasons in life bring additional perspectives. 

 I‚Äôm not saying you should lack conviction in your current beliefs if you‚Äôve thoughtfully crafted them. 

 Just understand that they may change over time. 

 Don‚Äôt marry your beliefs, or you‚Äôll end up bitter when you see someone succeeding in a different lane than you. 

 There are a million ways to win. Choose yours. 

 Alright, I gotta go to boxing, and you gotta watch this video. ‚Äã 

 Happy Friday, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Two habits that will change your life for the better
body:
Hello and happy Sunday, {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 If you‚Äôre in a cold or grey climate right now, I feel bad for you because Miami is absolutely beautiful. 

 I‚Äôm wearing Birkenstocks without socks, which could be considered a crime against humanity but is also indicative of the sunny 80-degree day we have here. 

 First, I want to say thank you for the love of my recent YT videos. Your validation is giving me the motivation to upload consistently, so please keep it up. 

 Recently, I‚Äôve been thinking about how copywriting has impacted my life. 

 Not only has it helped me build my business, but it‚Äôs served as an outlet for me to develop more concrete ideas. 

 For the last couple of years, I‚Äôve been journaling, tweeting, or writing an email nearly daily. 

 It feels like a form of art. 

 In simple terms, I‚Äôm taking ideas that are jumbling around in my head and assembling them into a series of words that form a complete thought. 

 This has made me a more articulate speaker as well. 

 Whether talking to friends, on a date, or making content, I feel the ripple effect that comes from writing consistently. 

 Being able to use your words and share your perspective with someone in a way that may persuade them to agree with your beliefs feels like a superpower. 

 Whether or not you want to build a business that involves copywriting, I genuinely think getting into the habit of writing consistently is one of the highest ROI activities you can do. 

 Once you hone this skill, a world of opportunities opens up. 

 It can lead to a successful business, deeper relationships with others, and/or a loyal audience of people on the internet that resonate with your beliefs. 

 And as I think about the most successful entrepreneurs I know, this is almost always their unfair advantage. 

 Switching gears a bit, another thing that‚Äôs been on my mind is the value that comes with continuous learning. 

 School tricked us into thinking that education is a boring chore. 

 This causes most people to put little time into gaining new information once they graduate. 

 But learning new things should be fun. 

 I‚Äôm sure there are dozens of topics that you are naturally curious about and would enjoy exploring further. 

 And who knows ‚Äì maybe it could lead to more money, a better social life, or at least give you an interesting topic to discuss at the dinner table. 

 When you‚Äôre constantly learning new things, you become more unique and interesting. And being a wealth of knowledge is cool. 

 I encourage you to take some time each day to learn about something new. It doesn't have to be about money or anything that even offers you any tangible benefit. 

 Simply allow your curiosity to lead you and someway, somehow, you‚Äôll be glad you did. 

 This is a part of how you develop into a well-rounded version of yourself, which I talk more about here. ‚Äã

 Anyway, I gotta record some course content (which you‚Äôll have access to soon), and Grammarly is pissing me off again because it keeps suggesting retarded edits to my writing. 

 Go watch my latest YT video if you haven‚Äôt already :) 

 Love you, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã P.S. Read my previous emails here. ‚Äã

subject: the only way to get better at anything
body:
I was working out with my boxing coach the other day, practicing a new combination. 

 While we train, he frequently pauses to give me an analogy or anecdote to help cement new concepts in my head. 

 In this particular session, he said something that gave me no other choice but to reply with the word ‚Äúbars‚Äù because it applies to any area of life that you are aiming to improve. 

 He said, ‚ÄúConfidence comes through competence, which comes through repetition.‚Äù 

 In other words, the more reps you get, the better you become, and the better you become, the more confidence you build. 

 I‚Äôm noticing this already on YouTube. 

 The first time I sat down to make a video, it took me too many tries to count. 

 I‚Äôd start talking and stumble over my words, lose my train of thought, or find an issue with the lighting or how the camera was positioned. 

 Because of this, making a video felt like I was climbing this big mountain. 

 Although I still run into occasional issues, it‚Äôs become much easier to sit down and knock out a video. 

 While the quality is subjective, I also feel that my ability to articulate the concept I‚Äôm discussing in each video has improved. 

 The words flow more smoothly, I‚Äôm more comfortable being expressive, and I‚Äôm getting closer to losing the filter that naturally comes with making videos for the internet. 

 It‚Äôs a perfect example of the quote from my boxing coach. 

 I don‚Äôt want to harp on this one point for too long because it‚Äôs so simple yet so difficult to actually practice. 

 The last thing I‚Äôll say here is that I promise you with full certainty that when you stop putting off things you want to do, it‚Äôll be worth it. 

 You have to get over the immediate flinch that comes with starting anything new and sometimes have to say, ‚Äúfuck it if it sucks, it sucks,‚Äù and do it anyway. 

 Over time and repetition, you will get better. 

 Anyway, I gotta hop on a coaching call, so I‚Äôll keep this one short. 

 Thanks for reading ‚Äì and go here to check out the video I uploaded today about why ‚Äúmonk mode‚Äù makes you less productive. ‚Äã 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: HOW TO NOT BE A BOT
body:
I sneezed on my walk to get coffee and a stranger said, ‚ÄúBless you.‚Äù 

 I found that endearing. 

 Then I saw a grown man wearing a bulky helmet and work clothes zipping through traffic on a scooter. 

 Those are for children. Grow up. 

 A couple things on my mind today: 

 1. Craftiness is the most underrated skill in business. 

 It‚Äôs the reason some people seem to get lucky. 

 I know a newer copywriter who‚Äôs gotten to multi-five figures a month way faster than most people. 

 He‚Äôs a smart kid but considering he‚Äôs brand new to copywriting, it‚Äôs safe to assume there are many better writers than him. 

 But it‚Äôs the intangibles that have allowed him to scale to quickly. 

 I‚Äôve watched him relentlessly follow up with prospects in a nonaggressive way that doesn‚Äôt piss them off. 

 He‚Äôll confidently say ‚Äúyes‚Äù when someone asks for something he has little idea how to do and figure it out on the fly. 

 He‚Äôs simply the boy. 

 I was talking to my friend Mason about this the other day. 

 When I describe someone as ‚Äúthe boy‚Äù it‚Äôs one of the biggest compliments I can give. 

 It means that they just get it. They‚Äôre a good vibe, people like them, they‚Äôre socially calibrated. 

 It‚Äôs the highest rank in the Bader-dialogue hierarchy. A step up from ‚Äúthe homie‚Äù even. 

 When someone has the traits above, they "make it" ‚Äî even if they‚Äôre not the most skilled. 

 My mentor when I was building my basketball trainer SMMA used to always say that if we can get someone laughing on a sales call, they will close. 

 It's a high ROI tip ‚Äî in a world of cookie-cutter, boring, lifeless robots, be expressive. Crack the borderline offensive joke. Tell your prospect they need to hire you so they can afford better wifi when their connection cuts out on the Zoom call. 

 Smile. And be handsome. 

 I got carried away writing this first point and now I forget the other things that were on my mind. 

 Hmmm. 

 I‚Äôm sitting outside at Starbucks and another corporate drone just rode by on a scooter. 

 Oh, next thing that that I was thinking about: 

 2. If getting clients is a struggle, you‚Äôre being a bot. 

 This relates to my first point but THINK OUTSIDE THE BOX. 

 ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt get any clients, I‚Äôve been sending the same retarded pitch to everyone for 3 months and no one replies.‚Äù 

 CHANGE YOUR PITCH. 

 Test shit. That‚Äôs life. You test until something works for you, even if it goes against the ‚Äúproven system‚Äù that cornballs on the internet give you. 

 One of the copywriters I consulted with got his first couple of clients by digging through Youtubers channels, finding their email addresses, and pitching them via email. 

 No one taught him that. But that‚Äôs ingenuity. 

 The first time I heard the word ‚Äúingenious,‚Äù I had just broken into my high school gym to play basketball. 

 There was a hidden key in the storage closet to turn the lights on and lower the hoops. I‚Äôd found it months before, but one day, I walked in there, and it was gone. 

 ‚ÄúGoddamnit, Terry,‚Äù I thought to myself. She was the athletic trainer who would always kick me out because it was a liability for a minor to be in the gym without supervision. 

 I bent the metal part of an old lanyard I found in my backpack and made a new key. It worked. 

 A few days later, Terry walked in right after I used my makeshift key to get the baskets down. 

 She asked how I did it, and I told her I had made a new key. That‚Äôs when she said, ‚ÄúWell, that was ingenious of you.‚Äù 

 In my head, I was like ‚Äúfuck yeah it was Terry.‚Äù 

 Anyway, I‚Äôm rambling, but if you‚Äôre stuck right now, BE CRAFTY. BE INGENIOUS. DONT BE A LUKE BELMAR IMAN GHADZI ANDREW TATE CLONE. STEAL YOUR GRANDMAS COMPUTER. SELL YOUR KIDNEY ON THE BLACK MARKET. SEND THE MAFIA TO A PROSPECTS HOUSE. 

 Ok, thanks for reading all this, now go here to uncover the secrets of the Universe. ‚Äã

 Talk tm, sorry for yelling. 

 Bye, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: how to overcome the voice in your head
body:
The hardest part of starting anything is the beginning. 

 When I open this document to a blank page, and a blinking cursor, a voice in my head tries to convince me that today isn‚Äôt the day. 

 ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre out of ideas for now. You‚Äôre uninspired. Just wait until it comes to you,‚Äù it says. 

 This is a familiar voice. 

 I hear it whenever I turn on the camera to make a video. 

 It screams at me when the cold water touches my body in an ice bath and tells me to get out. 

 Maybe you‚Äôve heard it too. 

 When you listen to it, you‚Äôll be convinced not to go to the gym, avoid approaching the girl, and wait until the ‚Äúperfect time‚Äù to start the business. 

 A few years ago, I listened to an audiobook about this topic during a plane ride. 

 It‚Äôs called The War Of Art by Steven Pressfield. 

 He refers to this voice as ‚Äúresistance‚Äù and describes it as ‚ÄúA universal force that has one mission: to keep things as they are.‚Äù 

 You‚Äôre likely aware of the things you resist ‚Äì consciously or unconsciously. 

 You also probably don‚Äôt want to stay the same forever. 

 And you know that the only way to change is to overcome your initial desire to flinch when taking the first half step. 

 You can ask yourself three questions to identify what you‚Äôre resisting right now and make a convincing argument for moving toward it. 

 Answer these with me real quick: 

 1. What‚Äôs one thing I want that I‚Äôm not getting right now? 

 2. What‚Äôs stopping me from getting this thing? 

 3. What would happen if I could do this thing? 

 Got it? 

 Okay. 

 By answering question one, you thought of something you want to do that you‚Äôre avoiding. 

 In question two, you selected the first excuse that came to mind for why you couldn‚Äôt do it. 

 And in question three, hopefully, you realized how stupid that excuse is because of the benefits, the person you become, and the new life you unlock by overcoming your resistance. 

 It‚Äôs literally impossible to make a logical argument for why you should avoid the things you‚Äôre avoiding. 

 Your excuses are bullshit. 

 That‚Äôs your ego trying to defend against change. 

 Because with change comes the possibility that things don‚Äôt go as planned. 

 Maybe your video gets three likes, and they come from your grandma, mom, and little brother. 

 Even your cousin gave it a thumbs down. 

 Or maybe you get rocked in the face the first time you step in the ring. 

 If those are big enough reasons to stay where you are, be my guest. 

 But by making that decision, you‚Äôre also closing the door to the possibility that it will eventually work out. 

 Sure, maybe it will start slowly. 

 Maybe things won‚Äôt go as planned even after you beat resistance. 

 But one day, your efforts will compound. 

 You‚Äôll hang in there long enough and have the results to show for it. 

 That‚Äôs when you‚Äôll laugh at the fact that you ever were scared to pursue the things you want. 

 You in? 

 Cool. 

 ‚Äã Now, go here and let me tell you about the one trait you need to make as much money as you possibly want. ‚Äã 

 Love you, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: stop feeling sorry for yourself
body:
Today was a tough one for my speaking ability. 

 I probably have over 100 clips on my camera that will all be deleted. 

 Earlier today I was trying to make a VSL for a new offer I‚Äôm putting together where you can work with me directly. 

 After dozens of takes, I finally had a video that I thought was sufficient. 

 I exported it and was about to call it a day. 

 Then I watched it a couple more times and decided that I didn‚Äôt like it. 

 I took a walk to clear my head and was inspired to make a Youtube video once I got back. 

 20 takes later, I still didn‚Äôt have a complete video. The sun went down and the lighting in my apartment makes the video look grainy once it gets dark. 

 I turned off the camera and am now sitting here writing to you. 

 It‚Äôs funny because yesterday I wrote an email to you about overcoming the initial resistance you feel when starting something new. 

 And today, I couldn‚Äôt beat it. 

 I started to feel bad for myself after the initial VSL failure. 

 And then during my walk earlier, I opened an email reply from someone on this list. 

 They said ‚ÄúThank you Ben for rekindling this flame inside me with these emails.‚Äù 

 That‚Äôs when I realized that the decision to pity myself after things didn‚Äôt go as planned is incredibly selfish. 

 I‚Äôm making videos and sharing content on the because it feels like something I have to do. 

 As a byproduct, I get to inspire other people and impact lives for the better. 

 Obviously, I‚Äôm not on the front lines here risking my life for the benefit of humanity, but making 

 content like this is probably one of the most influential things I can do with my time at the moment. 

 When I think about, the possibility that I even impact a few people for the better vastly makes up for days like today, where I struggle. 

 I get messages and comments every day from people telling me that I‚Äôve helped them in some way. 

 And to say ‚Äúwoe is me‚Äù while sitting and pouting about a couple of unsuccessful videos is childish, bitch-like behavior. I have a responsibility here, and it‚Äôs my obligation to uphold it. I‚Äôm too blessed to feel sorry for myself. The mission doesn‚Äôt allow for pity. 

 This is the pep talk I heard in my head. Perhaps it applies to you as well. 

 In general, I think the worst thing you can do in any situation is to feel sorry for yourself. It makes you powerless. It‚Äôs a slap in the face to anyone who supports you or roots for you, as you‚Äôre not even giving the same level of respect to yourself. 

 No more pity parties. You have responsibilities to tend to and a divine calling to follow. 

 Don‚Äôt be a bitch. 

 Ok bye thx for reading Happy Friday. 

 Ben 

 P.S. Did you watch my recent YT video yet? ‚Äã 

 P.P.S Lmk if you liked this one <3 

 ‚Äã

subject: How to build a copywriting business from scratch
body:
I started writing this in my head during my morning run. 

 The trail was abnormally crowded today. 

 I had to weave through an abundance of slow walkers, oblivious dog owners, strollers, and preoccupied middle-aged Hispanic men. 

 It was windy, to the point that the water from the Miami River to my left was blowing up onto the walkway. 

 The trees were rattling, but I pierced through the wind in my white Nikes, which I‚Äôve been wearing for the past year. 

 It‚Äôs definitely time to buy a new pair, but completing minuscule tasks like going to the shoe store feels equivalent to climbing Mt. Everest to me. So I‚Äôll probably wait until the sole starts to fall off or my toes bust through the mesh. 

 I was walking back home after my run when I ran into my friend Bo. Bo is a copywriter that Mason and I have been coaching for the last six months or so. 

 She quickly reached $10k per month inside Mason's program, the Copy MBA Inner Circle, and then started asking me for help scaling further. 

 With my help she‚Äôs scaled past $50k per month by turning her copywriting business into a full stack info agency. 

 A few weeks ago, I was thinking about how we could create more success stories like hers. 

 She started by learning the skill of copywriting and then added many of the other services that I offer to clients. 

 Things like funnel building, VSLs, webinars, and building all the systems on the backend. 

 It seems like this is the common path for those who get the best results when first starting out as a beginner. 

 They get good at copy and then expand their skill set to become more valuable to their clients. 

 This gave me the idea to partner up with Mason inside of Copy MBA. 

 Over the last few weeks, I‚Äôve been building out course content to add to the program, and I‚Äôm nearly ready to launch it. 

 If you‚Äôre just starting out, this is gonna be a cheat code for you. 

 Not only will you get access to Mason and his team, along with all of the existing content inside of there‚Ä¶ 

 But you‚Äôll also begin to learn the skills that you‚Äôll need to know to eventually be able to charge clients up to $40k in a single month the way I have. 

 I‚Äôm putting the final touches on everything, and because you‚Äôre on this list, you‚Äôll get first access to it once it goes live. 

 I can promise you with full certainty that if you‚Äôre a complete beginner who‚Äôs looking to build a copywriting business, this is gonna be the most valuable resource you have at your disposal. 

 I‚Äôll be giving you more info in the coming emails. 

 For now, go here and check out this video that‚Äôll help you develop a magnetic aura and make other people love you. ‚Äã 

 Happy Sunday, and thanks for reading, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you‚Äôre interested in the program I outlined above, hit ‚Äòreply‚Äô real quick and let me know. 

 ‚Äã

subject: The anti-robot approach to getting clients
body:
The other day, I sent you an email titled ‚ÄúHOW TO NOT BE A BOT.‚Äù

 It‚Äôs the most important life hack you can understand.

 It‚Äôll get you clients, friends, perceived status, etc. Simply put, not being a bot makes you a winner.

 Today, I want to dive into the psychology behind this.

 In college, there was a kid in my pledge class who we called a robot.

 For the sake of the story, I‚Äôll call him Robo-Joe.

 Robo-Joe had one goal in life:

 Get with sorority girls.

 He was decent-looking and our school was literally 70% female, so the odds were stacked in his favor.

 But there was a problem‚Ä¶

 He had the charisma of a rock.

 Joe was the type of person that likely doesn‚Äôt have inner dialogue, but if he did I imagine it would sound as follows:

 ‚ÄúI want gorls. I go to school that 70% gorl. I join frat to seem normal so I get mor gorl. I go gym to get big and strwong so gorl like me.‚Äù

 Because he was a robot, he took a very direct approach to the above goal.

 He thought that all of the things above would make him desirable.

 And while he did have some ‚Äòsuccess,‚Äô Joes intentions became clear to anyone with half a brain.

 He didn‚Äôt pledge a fraternity because he wanted to make genuine friends; he did so to make it look like he had friends.

 He was obsessed with the gym because, in his mind, it would make him desirable to women.

 Robo-Joe tried to cover up his intentions by becoming your typical jacked frat bro.

 And he wasn‚Äôt the sharpest tool in the shed, so it didn‚Äôt really work.

 Fun fact: our wardens actually made him play brain games for 20 minutes a day and report back with his progress because he was quite slow.

 Anyway, I‚Äôm telling you all about Robo-Joe because this is the approach most people take when they want something.

 Let‚Äôs say you want to get your first client and decide that you‚Äôre just gonna spam DM a bunch of people without doing any research on who they are or what you should offer them.

 You do that for 3 months, and it doesn‚Äôt work because you‚Äôre retarded so you quit.

 That‚Äôs the direct Robo-Joe approach.

 Let‚Äôs talk about the better way to get what you want‚Ä¶

 The first five info-product clients I got were all online basketball trainers.

 I went 4/4 on outreach, and one of them (who had half a million followers) reached out to me first.

 So, to make it clear, I sent four messages and got five clients, which is statistically impossible if you‚Äôre not named Ben Bader.

 The reason this worked wasn‚Äôt because of my script or even any crazy case study.

 It was because of two things:

 I existed on the internet. I was posting content about basketball trainer marketing and running ads. I used my brain to reach out at the right time. If they posted a new offer or something that I thought I could help with on their story, that‚Äôs when I‚Äôd send a DM. Actually, I guess I lied ‚Äî the third element was that I was half decent at writing copy and providing the other services I was offering, so I was confident in the way I spoke to them.

 That‚Äôs the anti-robot approach. It might sound like it‚Äôll take longer, but it diminishes your need to get lucky by spam DM‚Äôing a bunch of people.

 I don‚Äôt know if there was any saving Robo-Joe, but if he had put the time into becoming someone who was desirable to women instead of trying shallow fixes to fake it, maybe he would‚Äôve had a shot.

 ‚Äã Anyway, I figured out the key to happiness and share it with you in this video. ‚Äã

 See you over there,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: Opportunity for you {{ subscriber.first_name }}
body:
As I walk past the joyful construction workers on my way back from the coffee shop, I can‚Äôt help but feel a sense of guilt. 

 It‚Äôs only 9am but the dirt covering their hands and clothes indicates they‚Äôve been up working for hours. 

 They‚Äôre blasting an upbeat Hispanic song while smiling and laughing, probably making fun of stupid gringos clutching their coffee cups tight to their chests as they walk by. 

 I‚Äôm sure they have a long day ahead of them, but the spirit in their eyes shows that they‚Äôre okay with that. 

 ‚ÄúThese are the people I envy,‚Äù I think to myself as I sit here clicking buttons in my air-conditioned box in the sky. 

 I‚Äôve spent much of the morning in my head. 

 Thinking about how I need $100m yesterday, my dead hoop dreams, and the mountain of things on my to-do list for the day. 

 But when I walked by the jovial construction workers, it brought me back to the present. 

 They were sitting there on the edge of their truck, completely here. 

 No moping, no whining, just utter appreciation for life itself. 

 The lesson that resonated with me the most in The Four Agreements was ‚ÄúDo your best.‚Äù 

 Those three words make up the background on my phone, and although it‚Äôs a simple message, it truly diminishes the possibility of disappointment. 

 It gives you a sense of pride as it ensures that you always show up as the best version of yourself. 

 When you do your best, you make the most of every opportunity. It makes time fly by, even when you‚Äôre completing a rather trivial task. 

 The construction workers show up every day and do their best. That's what makes it fun. 

 Sure, they have other goals, aspirations, and worries. 

 But for now, they are where they are. 

 And you are where you are. 

 Accepting that fact doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre forgoing your hopes and dreams, as you don‚Äôt need to constantly create an internal Hell to continue progressing. 

 You perform best when you find a way to enjoy what you‚Äôre doing. 

 Be here, do your best, and life goes from black and white to color. 

 Anyway, this was supposed to be a launch email where I tell you about my new partnership and offer for you. 

 As you can tell, I deviated from that plan, so I‚Äôll just plug it here quickly. 

 If you‚Äôre trying to build a copywriting business, become a ‚Äògrowth operator,‚Äô or build an agency, and you want my help‚Ä¶ 

 ‚Äã Go here and I‚Äôll give you all the details. ‚Äã

 Have a good day and don‚Äôt forget to be where you are, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: how i accidentally became a copywriter
body:
I was just writing a separate email to you, but I got stuck halfway through. 

 Now I‚Äôve opened up a new blank page, and hopefully this time, I‚Äôll be able to fill it with enough words to create a coherent email. 

 My fingers keep trying to drift to one of the other 30 tabs I have open on my computer to distract me from writing this. 

 I guess while we‚Äôre here, I‚Äôll tell you about my new partnership with Copy MBA. ‚Äã

 You may know of my friend Cardinal Mason. 

 He has a coaching program teaching people how to build a copywriting business. 

 A few years ago, we did a podcast together while I was living in Tulum, Mexico. 

 He was making around $40k per month as a copywriter, and I was spinning my wheels trying to scale my basketball trainer marketing agency. 

 I remember thinking to myself that I could do what he was doing and make more money than I was then. 

 I didn‚Äôt realize it then, but the next month, I got my first copywriting client. 

 It was an online basketball trainer named Ganon Baker. 

 He had tens of thousands of social media followers, and I came in to write ad scripts, run his email marketing, and write a new VSL script. 

 He was paying me $2,500 per month for all of this, which I was stoked about because I‚Äôd previously been working with clients who paid me just $1k per month. 

 Next thing you know, I was working with 3 of the other big online basketball trainers. 

 One of them was a guy named Jordan Lawley, who has over half a million followers on Instagram. 

 I remember him telling me on our first call that he wanted to work with me because he liked the copy in one of the ads I wrote. 

 This was the foundation of the business I run now which has allowed me to hit $100k months. 

 I used my copywriting ability to land clients and then started offering other services to them. 

 Things like I mentioned above, like ads, email automations, and video scripts. 

 Plus, building funnels, backend systems, and helping manage their sales teams. 

 It was the addition of these skills that allowed me to get clients on rev share deals and charge up to $45k/month. 

 But it all started with copy. 

 And that‚Äôs why I think it‚Äôs the most valuable skill anyone can learn as a beginner. 

 The Copy MBA Inner Circle is the best place to start. 

 Mason will give you everything you need to know to become a proficient copywriter, and you‚Äôll also get access to my course, which will teach you the additional skills I‚Äôve used to scale my business. 

 I made a video talking about this new partnership, which you can watch here. ‚Äã

 See you over there, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Here‚Äôs my recent YT video on how I got my first client ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: how to stop drifting through life
body:
I was sitting at lunch today with a couple of friends, and we talked about what people do after college. 

 All three of us could think of a handful of people we knew in school who are now just drifting. 

 They either moved back in with their parents or they‚Äôre working some dead end job ‚Äúfiguring things out.‚Äù 

 This is absolutely asinine to me. 

 Wasn‚Äôt the point of college to find some direction and career path? 

 Many of my friends who graduated about a year ago have reached out to me, expressing unhappiness about the situation it‚Äôs left them in. 

 They‚Äôd spent the last four years (and hundreds of thousands of dollars) pretending like this day would never come. 

 Now, it‚Äôs not like they‚Äôre doomed for life, but it‚Äôs definitely a hell of a lot harder. 

 I‚Äôm not writing this to shame them but rather to warn you about what could happen if you try to ignore the inevitable destination that it will lead you to. 

 How long will you lie to yourself and say you‚Äôll make a change ‚Äúone day?‚Äù 

 That day will never come if you don‚Äôt create it. 

 It starts by making the conscious decision to design your life in a way that will steer you in a new direction. 

 Your habits, thoughts, and beliefs must begin to change. 

 This is how you step into a new identity. 

 The worst place in life is in the middle, drifting between what you want and what you have. 

 If your actions aren‚Äôt in alignment with the life you want to create, you‚Äôre in danger. 

 You can continue ignoring that feeling that tells you that you want more, or you can decide to actually commit to building this new reality. 

 I know this sounds simple, but if you objectively audit what you‚Äôre doing right now, and it isn‚Äôt propelling you to where you want to be, you have a problem. 

 If you choose to ignore the problem, it will grow like a parasite in the back of your mind. 

 Eventually, you‚Äôll be the unhappy 50-year-old with a life full of ‚Äúwhat ifs.‚Äù 

 Stop drifting, my friend. 

 Life is beautiful when you create it. I‚Äôm telling you firsthand that the hardship that comes with change is worth the experiences and freedom it grants you access to. 

 Take control of your life before it‚Äôs too late, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you want to build a copywriting business, I have an opportunity for you. 

 You may have seen that I recently partnered with my friend Cardinal Mason inside of Copy MBA. 

 It‚Äôs his birthday tomorrow, and we‚Äôre running a $1,000 discount for the next few days. 

 ‚Äã To get access to it, go here and apply now. ‚Äã

 This is limited and won‚Äôt be available for long. 

 P.P.S. I made a new video that‚Äôll show you how to get through the days when you don‚Äôt feel like being productive. 

 ‚Äã You can check it out here. ‚Äã

subject: Preparation is the enemy of success
body:
When I moved to Miami almost two years ago, I was a very different person. 

 I was making around $15k-$20k per month, I had less confidence, and the move here was intimidating to me. 

 The last ~20 months have been transformational. 

 My income has increased by more than 5x, and my social circle has expanded while I‚Äôve developed tighter bonds with the few people I‚Äôd consider brothers. 

 The entire way I view myself has changed. 

 I started doing many of the things that were on my ‚Äúone-day‚Äù list. 

 My personal brand has grown, I‚Äôve picked up new hobbies, and my lifestyle is exactly the way I used to dream of. 

 I‚Äôve taken a series of actions that have created a ripple effect. 

 When you do one thing that you‚Äôre a bit nervous to do, your brain realizes that the fears you have around that thing are self-imagined. 

 The ceiling that you‚Äôve placed on yourself starts to get removed. 

 This makes it easier to tackle the next thing you‚Äôre putting off, and so on. 

 But knocking down that first domino is always the hardest. 

 Right now, you have beliefs that align with the person that you are in the present. 

 To do something new, those beliefs have to change ‚Äì but they won‚Äôt change by standing in the mirror and telling yourself affirmations, watching self-help YouTube videos, or meditating in front of a Tony Robbins poster. 

 You must go out into the world and give yourself real data that an alternate identity is possible. 

 Obviously, I can sit here and tell you this over and over, but it won‚Äôt mean shit to you until you actually put it into practice. 

 Throughout my days as a basketball player, this was something I struggled with. 

 I was always in the gym, watching film, writing down goals, and doing everything I could to make my hoop dreams come true. 

 But I was never fully able to step into that new reality and play to what I knew my true ability was in real games. 

 It‚Äôs almost like I was rewarding myself for all the preparation I was doing rather than actually applying it where it mattered. 

 This is similar to rehearsing the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù lines to say to a girl at the bar, but when you get there, you stand in the corner refreshing the weather app. 

 Or you could do all the research possible about copywriting, read all the books, and buy courses, but never send a DM and try to get a client. 

 Practice means nothing without action. 

 Sometimes, it‚Äôs better to be less prepared and dive in head first rather than sharpening your sword to never pull it out. 

 Do the things that are difficult for you and watch your limitations evaporate. 

 I promise it‚Äôll be worth it. 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Our $1,000 discount on the Copy MBA Inner Circle is live ‚Äì go here to start building your copywriting business. ‚Äã

subject: brain dump for {{ subscriber.first_name }}
body:
Happy Friday! TGIF!!! Any fun weekend plans??? 

 Hahaha. 

 Grow up. 

 It‚Äôs such a beautiful day here that I feel bad for anyone who isn‚Äôt in the state of Florida. 

 Besides those who are in Orlando. Or even worse‚Ä¶ Tampa. Ew. 

 Imagine the highlight of your city being a predatory theme park or a place called ‚ÄúMeat Market.‚Äù 

 At least Tampa has ‚ÄúThe Edition‚Äù - a 3.5-star hotel in any major city, but seems to be the main attraction since there‚Äôs nothing else to do there. They also only employ members of the LGBTDJKD community. 

 I‚Äôm not trying to be homophobic, but members of this community don‚Äôt seem to have the best work ethic, so things tend to take longer at this hotel. However, they are very good at making lattes. 

 Anyway I‚Äôm sitting outside Starbucks, sipping on a cold brew with vanilla cream and sugar, and thinking about how much of a hypocrite I am. 

 I just got jealous of a homeless man because he looked happy and had really good posture. 

 I can‚Äôt help but judge the man a couple tables away from me wearing a suit on his lunch break. 

 I started off this email by making fun of those who look forward to Fridays and weekends, but I‚Äôd be lying if I said my mood isn‚Äôt slightly better on days like this. 

 And if I actually followed the majority of the advice I give on the internet, I‚Äôd be a billionaire by now. 

 A wise man once said, ‚ÄúThe most honest people are hypocrites.‚Äù 

 The wise man who said that is the same one who‚Äôs writing this email. 

 And if you‚Äôre still reading by now you‚Äôre probably wondering where the lesson is or what I‚Äôm gonna ‚Äúteach‚Äù you here. 

 My goal is not to teach but rather entertain. 

 The richest people are the entertainers. Think about Tate. His message wasn‚Äôt something that others hadn‚Äôt said prior. 

 But he blew up because the guy is just outrageous. The way he speaks, the stories he tells, and the unapologetic expression of his thoughts. 

 It was refreshing to see someone who genuinely seemed not to care if people didn‚Äôt agree with him while simultaneously saying what everyone else was thinking. 

 On another note, most of the successful people I know are really lazy when they‚Äôre uninterested. 

 Myself included ‚Äî I‚Äôve always had a really hard time doing things I don‚Äôt want to do. 

 I‚Äôll wait until the final deadline, half-ass the project, cheat off the Asian kid, and do everything I can to get by while putting in minimal effort. 

 But when I‚Äôm bought in and find something that I‚Äôm interested in, I turn into an autistic computer engineer. 

 I can spend hours at my desk without losing focus. It occupies my mind constantly. 

 Maybe you‚Äôre the same. 

 One thing I‚Äôve started to understand about this is that obsession is created, not found. 

 You don‚Äôt ‚Äústumble‚Äù upon something you‚Äôre passionate about. 

 But rather, you create that passion by diving into a project and learning to love the mundane tasks that come with it. 

 Ok, I gotta hop on a call, but before I go, I‚Äôm feeling generous today, so I‚Äôm giving $100 to a random subscriber who watches and comments on my recent YT video. 

 ‚Äã Go here and watch this video (leave a comment with your favorite thing I said in the video). 

 Considering my audience is still relatively small, you have like a 1/10 chance of winning probably. 

 Bye love you, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you want me to help you build a copywriting or ‚Äúgrowth operator‚Äù business, check this out. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: secret to enjoying your life
body:
Happy Mother‚Äôs Day. 

 I‚Äôm mildly hungover and going to lunch in 10 min, so this will be a quicker one. 

 I saw a tweet from my friend Grant this morning that goes as follows: 

 ‚ÄúIf your work doesn‚Äôt get finished, you can‚Äôt enjoy anything 

 So if your habit is avoiding work, it is also a habit of living without enjoyment‚Äù 

 Couldn‚Äôt be more true. 

 Odds are, you know that exact feeling. 

 You could be out with friends, walking on the beach, or in bed with the love of your life. 

 But when there‚Äôs something that you‚Äôre avoiding, you still hear that voice in the back of your head. 

 It mocks you while you try to forget about it by doing literally anything but confront it. 

 It doesn‚Äôt let you find peace. It doesn‚Äôt let you enjoy the moment. It‚Äôs a constant chatter that won‚Äôt be shut up by ignoring it. 

 Whether it‚Äôs work you‚Äôre avoiding, a decision, or the direction of your life entirely ‚Äî your soul knows when your actions aren‚Äôt in alignment with your desires. 

 You‚Äôll be in a constant state of anxiety when you‚Äôre avoidant. 

 You can lie to others, but you can‚Äôt lie to yourself. 

 But honestly if this sounds familiar, you‚Äôre one of the lucky ones. 

 You now know that there‚Äôs some fire in your soul. 

 And you know that there‚Äôs a direction it‚Äôs pulling you in. 

 It‚Äôs up to you to follow it :) 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Come with me to get a pup cup (like and comment your favorite quote from the video, and I‚Äôll send a random subscriber $100) 

 P.P.S If you commented on my previous video I just replied to the winner of the last giveaway so check your notifs. 

 ‚Äã

subject: The money you want is right in front of you
body:
The money you want is right in front of you; you‚Äôre just looking in the wrong places. 

 This is something I think about often. 

 Every now and then, I‚Äôll hop on calls with people who are clearly sitting on a goldmine. 

 Maybe they have an in-demand skill, a large audience that isn‚Äôt properly monetized, or some other form of leverage they are not accessing. 

 From the outside looking in, the right move is so clear to me. 

 But it‚Äôs almost like they‚Äôre wearing tinted glasses that are blocking them from making the obvious decision that could drastically increase their income. 

 It‚Äôs like when you have a friend who gets into a relationship with someone who clearly isn‚Äôt good for them. 

 They‚Äôre ‚Äúdrunk in love‚Äù and can‚Äôt see the red flags or problems associated with the relationship. 

 Once the glasses are removed, their vision becomes clear, and the problem vanishes. 

 This works the same way in business. 

 People continuously look for the next shiny object, the next move, or the alternative direction they could take. 

 But they refuse to look at what‚Äôs right in front of them. 

 Let‚Äôs say you get a copywriting client who pays you $3k per month to run their email marketing. 

 You think to yourself, ‚ÄúOkay, this is great. Now I just need to get a few more clients, and I‚Äôll be at $10k per month.‚Äù 

 You then spend the majority of your time trying to get more clients. 

 It doesn‚Äôt go as planned, and the client you had dropped you after a few months because they weren‚Äôt getting the desired result from email. 

 Now you‚Äôre back at square one. 

 The problem? 

 You were looking in the wrong place. 

 Had you objectively assessed their business, you would‚Äôve noticed that their funnel needs work, their VSL is shit, and their sales team isn‚Äôt following up with leads. 

 Because of this, your emails didn‚Äôt increase revenue because there were other holes that needed to be patched. 

 But you weren‚Äôt focused on that. 

 You were spamming strangers on the internet, trying to get another client. 

 What if you had fixed the other gaps in your clients' business? 

 Let's say you rewrite their VSL, build them a new funnel, and help the sales team manage their leads. 

 Between these changes and your email marketing efforts, the revenue increases by 2 or 3x. 

 And because you were the person who helped them make more money, they‚Äôre happily giving you a percentage of the revenue. 

 Boom - you just turned your $3k/month client into a $10k/month client because you maximized the opportunity in front of you. 

 Here‚Äôs the part where I shamelessly plug the Copy MBA Inner Circle and show you how Vagner is doing exactly what I described above. 

 ‚Äã He‚Äôs already made an extra $2k because of it. 

 To get access to the same information he has, a community of other copywriters, and direct coaching from me and the Copy MBA team, go here now to learn more. ‚Äã

 See you over there, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Winners And Losers
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 I don‚Äôt know why, but I have this deep disdain and partial jealousy for people who ‚Äúsell out‚Äù for the info bag. 

 By ‚Äúsell out‚Äù I mean normify their offer. 

 All their videos turn into hyper-edited VSLs. 

 They talk about extremely basic and broad concepts. 

 And their sole goal is to convince the masses that the business model they‚Äôre selling is the ‚Äúeasiest way to hit $10k/month.‚Äù 

 This works. You dumb down all of your content and sell the dream to naive beginners. 

 You know 90% or more of your customers will fail, but this is usually how to make the most money in coaching. 

 Is it unethical? 

 Not necessarily ‚Äî if your program is good and some people still get results, you can make the argument that you did your best. 

 But it‚Äôs just not my style. 

 Even though I‚Äôm now partnered with Copy MBA and am financially incentivized to tell you how ‚Äúeasy‚Äù copywriting is, I can‚Äôt. 

 No business model is easy. 

 I think it‚Äôs a better option than dropshipping, trading, wholesale RE, and many other business models. 

 But is it any better for a beginner than doing sales or TikTok shop affiliate? 

 No. 

 And will most people who buy any course or coaching program fail, no matter the business model? 

 Yes. 

 I don‚Äôt mean to be pessimistic here. I just firmly believe that the intangibles make or break you. 

 There are winners and losers. 

 ‚Äã The best copywriting program in the world can help you, but at the end of the day, you will never outperform your self-image. 

 And if you‚Äôre unable to transform yourself into a person deserving of financial success, it will always elude you. 

 No matter if you‚Äôre a copywriter, dropshipper, TikTok shop affiliate, or onlyfans thot. 

 Actually, OF might be the one exception. 

 Anyway, I‚Äôll always keep it real with you. Even if that costs me money. 

 You will succeed at any business if you‚Äôre a winner. If you‚Äôre a loser, good luck. 

 Enough rambling for today ‚Äî I made a vlog yesterday and will give a random commenter $100. 

 ‚Äã Watch me live a normal day in Miami here. (and comment your fav part of the video to enter the giveaway). 

 Love you, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Just so you know I'm not capping about the $100 giveaways, here's a screenshot of me sending money to the last two winners: 

 ‚Äã

subject: 3 important reminders
body:
It‚Äôs gotten to the point in Miami where the second you step outside, you start sweating. 

 I just got back from a 30 min walk, and I‚Äôm very wet (pause no homo). 

 As you may have seen, I recently started uploading on Youtube. 

 It‚Äôs been my obsession for the last month, and I‚Äôve been reminded of many lessons, three of which I‚Äôll share with you now: 

 1. You allow for the possibility of greatness when you stop trying to be perfect. 

 The other day, I woke up scrambling for an idea. 

 I wanted to start my next Youtube video with narration and b-roll. 

 As I walked to Starbucks to get some shots and try to think of an idea, I realized it was right in front of me (watch the video for context) ‚Äã

 The lesson: 

 Your best work and most fruitful business ventures usually happen by accident. 

 Just get the ball rolling, and things will work out. 

 As long as you‚Äôre aware and conscious of the opportunities that appear in front of you, you‚Äôll stumble into greatness. 

 2. Don‚Äôt let your fear of heightened standards stop you from starting. 

 This is something I talk about often, as I‚Äôm frequently reminded of it. 

 As you progress in any endeavor, you add more pressure by revealing to yourself what you are capable of. 

 You‚Äôre probably subconsciously aware of this now, and it could be the reason that you‚Äôre putting off a goal. 

 I‚Äôm reminded of this with each video I post. There's this voice in the back of my head that says, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs next? How are you gonna top that?‚Äù 

 It‚Äôs a constant pressure that comes with a certain standard. But I can promise it‚Äôs far better than the anxiety that comes with suppressing your desires. 

 3. The best lessons are pulled from the trenches. 

 Any time I take on a new endeavor, I‚Äôm able to see many similarities between each pursuit. 

 I‚Äôve learned more from things like boxing, lifestyle maxxing, and making content than I have from any coaching program or course. 

 Side quests are often life's best teachers. 

 And who knows, maybe you‚Äôll learn a lesson or open a door that‚Äôll help you financially as well. 

 Anyway ‚Äì here‚Äôs the link to my new Youtube video. ‚Äã

 As always I‚Äôll give $100 to a random subscriber who comments their favorite part from the vid. 

 Love you, and lmk if you liked this one :) 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: ATTENTION
body:
‚ÄúAttention is the new currency.‚Äù 

 You‚Äôve likely heard this before. 

 Make content, build an audience, and sell them something. 

 It‚Äôs one of the quickest ways people are getting rich. 

 Over the last few years, it seems like the floodgates have been opened. 

 Everyone and their Grandma are content creators. 

 I can‚Äôt go to lunch without seeing people with hundreds of thousands of followers. 

 It literally seems like it‚Äôs one in every three people. 

 This is what has allowed me to build my agency. 

 As you may know, I work with people who have a big audience and sell information. 

 We write their copy, build their funnels, script their videos, and basically manage the entire backend for them, so all they have to do is make more videos and get more attention. 

 The more eyeballs they get, the more money they make, which makes our services more valuable and they end up paying us more. 

 This is the simplest way I can explain my business's role in the ‚Äúattention economy.‚Äù 

 We‚Äôre leveraging a vast skillset, time, and expertise to capitalize on creators' existing audiences and help them make way more money than they would without us. 

 For most of our clients, our work is relatively the same ‚Äì we build the similar landing pages, write similar emails, and even the VSL and webinar scripts are relatively templated. 

 On our end, there‚Äôs minimal difference in the workload between a client who pays us $5k/month versus one who pays us $30k/month. 

 The singular variable is attention. 

 We recently started working with a guy who has a really solid audience. 

 He has multiple six-figure followers, good engagement, and his content is fire. 

 From one post on Instagram and Tik Tok, he‚Äôs gotten the number of leads that we should be able to generate around a quarter million dollars from over the next week. 

 From one post. 

 Let me reiterate ‚Äì the one difference between him and someone who makes little money from info is the audience. 

 Someone else could have the same story, results, success, expertise, etc. 

 But if they don‚Äôt have a loyal audience of people who know, like, and trust them on the internet, it means nothing. 

 Attention is everything. 

 Whether you‚Äôre trying to build your own coaching business or you‚Äôre doing something similar to me. 

 Your marketing efforts, systems, and positioning do not matter if no one is seeing it. 

 So if you‚Äôre a copywriter or ‚ÄúgRoWtH oPeraToR‚Äù keep this in mind when trying to get clients. 

 To get a killer case study, you need a killer client ‚Äì a pig with lipstick on is still a pig. lol. 

 Anyway, I‚Äôve been having a ton of fun working with the students inside the Copy MBA Inner Circle, and it‚Äôs dope to see them getting results from it. 

 ‚Äã If you wanna make money as a copywriter or growth operator you should go here and apply so I can make you rich ok? Ok. ‚Äã

 Talk later, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: The "easy bucket method"
body:
I was crossing the street this morning and there was a red Tesla quickly approaching me. 

 Considering it‚Äôs an electric vehicle, I figured if it hit me I would do more damage to the car than it would to me. 

 Luckily, it stopped, and we didn‚Äôt have to find out if that hypothesis would hold up. 

 I have a quick tip for you tn‚Ä¶ 

 I‚Äôm on the couch scrolling through Youtube and watching Kyrie Irving dominate against the Timberwolves. 

 As I begin writing this, he has 26 points. Early in the first quarter, he hit two open shots in a row, and from that point on, he‚Äôs been lighting it up. 

 This is something you‚Äôll commonly see amongst the best scorers in basketball. 

 If they get an easy shot early on, this will help them get into a rhythm, and it‚Äôs going to be a long night for the defense. 

 This ‚Äúeasy bucket method‚Äù is something I use almost every day (off the basketball court). 

 When I sit down to work, most of my tasks each day fall into one of two categories: 

 1. Easy to complete, low time commitment 

 Or‚Ä¶ 

 2. Difficult to complete, higher time commitment 

 I almost always start with one of the easier, lower-friction actions, and once I knock a few of those out, I build momentum ‚Äì Which makes it much easier to move on to the more time-intensive stuff. 

 This is one of my best ‚Äúproductivity hacks,‚Äù and I use it whenever I am trying to achieve a bigger goal. 

 Very simple concept, but try it out next time you find yourself procrastinating. 

 Anyway, check out my recent video if you haven‚Äôt already üëá 

 ‚Äã I have $100 for a random subscriber who leaves a comment about their favorite part of the vid :) 

 Night {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Ben

subject: The best things in life are earned
body:
All of the best things in life are earned. 

 This is especially true for men and is something that you‚Äôll constantly be reminded of as you ‚Äúlevel up.‚Äù 

 There are no shortcuts. 

 True genuine friendships, the girl who loves and admires you, and the impact on other people are all things that you cannot access by finding a loophole. 

 You have to become ‚Äúhim.‚Äù 

 Money alone won‚Äôt do this for you. 

 There is one thing that usually has the biggest impact on the quality of experience you get to access. 

 And it‚Äôs your relationships. 

 First with yourself and then with others. 

 Let‚Äôs say you get ‚Äúlucky‚Äù financially. 

 You hit a big crypto rug pull, you run scam eCom brands, or you start selling Viagra to old men and pimp out your grandmother on OF. 

 It works, and you get ‚Äúaccess‚Äù to all the money you could need, which, in theory, will buy you the best experiences that life has to offer. 

 But there‚Äôs this deep-seated belief in your head that feels like you‚Äôre unworthy. 

 While you earned the money you wanted you didn‚Äôt improve your relationship with yourself along the way. 

 Maybe your back was never against the wall and you didn‚Äôt develop the grit that comes with digging yourself out of a hole. Or maybe you don‚Äôt fully respect yourself because you‚Äôve found success through nefarious means. 

 Because of these factors, you aren‚Äôt the type of person that other amazing, genuine people want to be around. 

 You end up attracting shallow people into your life ‚Äì guys who would slander your name if it‚Äôs in their best interest and a girl who would leave your table at the club to go to Futures table (rip). 

 You see a lot of these types in Miami and they‚Äôre usually dripped out in Chrome Hearts. 

 These are people who ‚Äúbeat the system.‚Äù 

 They found the financial success that others dream of, perhaps without having to go through the usual hardship or personal development process. 

 But they don‚Äôt get to fully enjoy the money because they haven‚Äôt become the person who is worthy of incredible relationships, as you attract what you are. 

 And even if you ‚Äúearn‚Äù all the money in the world, you still have to earn your relationships. 

 Laying on the beach in Barbados means nothing if you aren‚Äôt with people you love. 

 Driving your dream car through the Hollywood hills doesn‚Äôt hit the same if the girl in your passenger seat only likes you for your money. 

 Opening your banking app to a number that would allow you to retire at any moment feels empty when you don‚Äôt like the person whose face you see in the reflection of your screen. 

 Your relationships are everything and there are no shortcuts that will earn you respect. 

 So if you‚Äôre in the trenches right now and you feel like you‚Äôre not reaping the rewards of your efforts‚Ä¶ 

 Congratulations. You‚Äôre in the process of developing into the person who is worthy of the reality that you want. 

 Sorry for the hiatus. Good to be back, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Go here if you want my help in building a copywriting or "growth operating" business. ‚Äã

 P.P.S. I‚Äôm thinking about putting together a program for coaches, consultants, and course sellers who are under $100k per month. In there, I will give you the systems that we use to scale clients up to $600k/month. If this is something you might be interested in, hit reply and let me know.

subject: One habit that improves every area of life
body:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Four years ago, I started one habit that's been the single biggest driving factor of my growth and success. 

 Not only has it made me seven figures and helped me build an audience online‚Ä¶ 

 But this one habit has acted as my therapist, improved my mental clarity, and has made me a more articulate and effective communicator. 

 And the fact that you‚Äôre reading this right now is proof of all of this. 

 Let's rewind to 2020. 

 I‚Äôm a 19 year old sophomore in college and I‚Äôve started to dip my toes in the water of entrepreneurship. 

 There‚Äôs a lot on my mind on this particular summer day in Charleston so I decide to open a Google doc and start writing. 

 I write about what I‚Äôm trying to do in my business and what‚Äôs been stressing me out. 

 After a few paragraphs, I close my laptop and realize I feel a lot better than I did before I opened it. 

 I didn‚Äôt realize it at the time, but my life had just changed. 

 This became a habit I‚Äôd do almost daily for the following years. 

 Over time, I started to notice the benefits. 

 I became a better writer, my brain felt less cluttered, and holding myself accountable became easier because I was reporting back to myself on progress I‚Äôd made each day. 

 I began writing on Twitter, I put together this newsletter and picked up a few copywriting clients. 

 Writing became a part of me. 

 My outlet, my income, and my vessel to share my thoughts with others on the internet. 

 It led to the lifestyle I‚Äôm living now. 

 It bought me my dream car. 

 It connected me with my best friends. 

 And this is why I think it‚Äôs one the most valuable skills you can learn and habits you can develop. 

 Whether you want to build a copywriting business, grow an audience online, or have an outlet to close the tabs in your head at the end of each day‚Ä¶ 

 Start writing. 

 You won‚Äôt regret it. 

 Have a good weekend, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you want my direct help in building your copywriting or growth operating business, I'll show you exactly what we do for our clients with millions of followers (plus how we're able to charge singular clients up to $40k/month) -- check this out. ‚Äã

subject: Why you should tell more lies
body:
Last night my girl and I tried to make Carbones spicy rigatoni at home from scratch. 

 We left the sauce on the heat for a bit too long so it got kind of soupy but other than that it was good. 

 The only problem is my apartment still kind of smells like onions. 

 This information is completely irrelevant to you but I thought I‚Äôd share it anyway. 

 Moving on ‚Äì the other day I watched a video my friend Rob made titled ‚Äútell a lie 1,000 times and it becomes the truth.‚Äù 

 Many successful people are examples of this. 

 It‚Äôs like they ‚Äúcrown themselves‚Äù prematurely and after enough time, they become what they were pretending to be. 

 Let‚Äôs use your average agency owner turned course guru as an example. 

 They get to ~$30k/month with their agency and build an audience online in the process. 

 Eventually they start to feel ‚Äúburnt out‚Äù from their agency and realize they‚Äôre sitting on a different goldmine. 

 They have this big audience of people who knows, likes, and trusts them as an authority in the agency space. 

 Now, are they the most ‚Äúqualified‚Äù agency owner in the world? 

 Definitely not. 

 There are plenty of agency owners making 5x, 10x, and even 100x their revenue. 

 But are there hundreds of people ready to pay to learn from them? 

 100%. 

 And now they reach a crossroads‚Ä¶ 

 Do they keep trying to scale the agency as the main focus, or do they launch a coaching program? 

 That‚Äôs when they ‚Äúcrown themself.‚Äù 

 They become the agency guru, make a bunch of money coaching and then stop running an agency. 

 And because info is typically an easier business model to scale, now they‚Äôre making $200k/month. 

 They simply decided that they were qualified to consult other people for a price. 

 Because they gave themself this permission, they became "qualified" and were heavily rewarded for it. 

 This is how most coaching programs and info products are born. 

 The only issue that eventually arises here is when the coach stops doing what they are teaching. 

 After a few months or a year, their knowledge becomes obsolete. 

 This is why it can actually be good to learn from people who teach you the exact marketing system they used to get you to buy their product. 

 Long story short ‚Äì give yourself permission to become the person you want to be or start the business you want to start, and that reality will come to fruition for you. 

 Make sense? 

 Cool. 

 Happy Monday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Get my help in building your copywriting or growth operating business to $10k/month+ here. ‚Äã

 P.P.S. Watch my new video where I share 10 rules to change your life in the next 90 days. ‚Äã

subject: no ones thinking about you
body:
I'm sitting at my favorite coffee shop watching an asian man in a yankees hat have an episode. 

 He's sitting about 10 feet to my right in a white tank top with black shorts and his legs crossed. 

 There are three empty bottles of corona in front of him and he just knocked one over. 

 He's now struggling to open his black leather backpack. 

 Part of me hopes he‚Äôs reaching for a weapon because this would be the perfect time for me to become a hero. I'm seated slightly behind him so he wouldn‚Äôt see me coming. 

 Plus he can‚Äôt be more than 140 pounds and one right hook to the temple should knock him out. 

 Damnit. no weapon, just airpods. 

 From the moment I sat down he‚Äôs been talking abnormally loud. 

 Most of which has been mumble nonsense but at one point he asked the man in the floral shirt at the table in front of him if he could come sit with him. 

 The man politely declined. 

 He just took a final sip out of each of his three bottles and is now flailing his arms above his head. 

 Smoke break. He put a cigarette in his mouth and walked outside. 

 This is fun. It's usually only homeless people that you get to see have outbursts like this. 

 Other than a few staff members, no one else in the restaurant has even noticed him. 

 Everyone is just in their own little bubble, dealing with their own ambitions, obstacles, and problems. 

 I guess if there‚Äôs a lesson here it‚Äôs that letting the opinions of others stop you from doing something you want is so silly. 

 First of all, you‚Äôre gonna die one day. 

 Second of all, who cares what they think. 

 And third, they‚Äôre probably not even gonna notice you. 

 Our friend is back from his smoke break. 

 He asked for another beer and the waiter reluctantly told him that they aren‚Äôt legally allowed to serve more than three alcoholic beverages. 

 I wonder if that‚Äôs true or if he was just worried that this guy was gonna start dancing on the table. 

 Instead the waiter went and got him some water. The manic man got up and gave him a hug. 

 He drunkenly said, ‚ÄúThank you. I‚Äôve had such a rough day,‚Äù grabbed his things and walked out with hope in his stride. 

 Aw. What a nice happy ending. 

 I guess everyone‚Äôs dealing with their own shit and it's not good for us to judge. 

 Anyway ‚Äì This video is one of my favorites and it‚Äôs something that helped me go from being a normal college kid to building my dream life over the last 4 years. ‚Äã

 See you over there, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Lesson from $100m man
body:
Before I get into today‚Äôs email, I have a new opportunity that may be a good fit for you. 

 If you‚Äôre a coach, consultant, or course seller and you want to scale to 6 figure months, check out the video on this page. ‚Äã 

 Alrighty, pitch out of the way - let‚Äôs get into it. 

 On my walk today I passed by former NBA player Amar'e Stoudamire. 

 He was sitting on a bench with his dog‚Äôs leash tied around the leg of it, while reading a torah with a cigar in his mouth. 

 According to Google, he made $165,683,566 over the course of his career. 

 But there he was, enjoying his day while doing something that costs zero dollars. 

 I saw a quote the other day that said: 

 ‚ÄúA rich man works all is his life to live like a poor man in a village by the sea‚Äù 

 That‚Äôs a bar. 

 Another wise man once tweeted ‚ÄúThe best things in life are free but you can only appreciate them once you buy everything else.‚Äù 

 That wise man was me. 

 And this is the truth. The best thing money does for you is it offers peace of mind and freedom. 

 You earn yourself the freedom to take a long walks or enjoy a cigar on a bench on a random Thursday afternoon. 

 Without having to worry about bills, drama at a job you hate, or any of the other things that normies have to worry about. 

 You can say what you want. You can think how you want. You can side quest. You can try new things and embark on ‚Äúmeaningless‚Äù pursuits. 

 Money is freedom. 

 And it 100% makes your life 100x better because it lets you live like you don‚Äôt have it, while giving you the peace of mind of someone who does have it. 

 Getting rich is the most selfless thing you can do. 

 Because then you have the clarity to go figure out what you're supposed to do here. 

 Make sense? 

 Let me know if you liked this one, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Go here if you want my help in building your copywriting or growth operating business ‚Äã

subject: How to buy a bugatti asap
body:
Happy Sunday. 

 I just posted a banger video about how I‚Äôd make $100k asap if I had to start all over. 

 Go watch that after you read this, or be poor and sad forever. 

 A man named Luis is currently on his way to my apartment on a motorbike, carrying the cheesesteak I just ordered. 

 The NBA finals are playing on the TV behind my computer screen. 

 What a life. 

 They just showed a stat about Luca Doncic, who is averaging 34 points per game in the playoffs, which is the most since MJ in the 90‚Äôs. 

 The interesting thing about Luca is he simply does the basics. 

 He‚Äôs not incredibly fast or athletic and he isn‚Äôt super fancy with the ball. 

 But he‚Äôs incredible at the basics and makes everything look simple. 

 Every movement is precise, from his footwork to the way he uses his body (no homo). 

 He makes the right read coming off of screens and just plays at his own speed. 

 Because he is so exceptional at the simple ‚Äúbig levers‚Äù he‚Äôs better than 99% of players in the league. 

 Business works the same way. 

 Many of the richest people I know aren‚Äôt the most‚Ä¶ meticulous. 

 They stay away from complex systems and focus on the one to handful of actions that produce the most results. 

 If you‚Äôve seen this jacked dude named Wes Watson on social media, he‚Äôs the perfect example of this. 

 Go watch his content right now and he‚Äôs regurgitating some Bruce Lee quote with motivational music and a workout compilation over it. 

 He‚Äôs yelling at the camera with veins popping out of his eyelids. 

 Clearly he isn‚Äôt the most intelligent or articulate person in the world. 

 But he‚Äôs posting multiple times per day and if you opt-in to his funnel, you‚Äôll get a text and a dial from his sales team within minutes. 

 And based on his social media and the fact that I constantly see him on Brickell avenue in an orange Bugatti, the guy is fucking rich. 

 He has one job ‚Äì get attention. 

 The more eyeballs he gets, the more the sales team can harass new leads and quite literally sell them air. 

 That part is unimportant. 

 He does the basics better than everyone else. 

 He knows what the big levers are in his business. 

 He yells. A lot. 

 And it bought him a Bugatti. 

 Fuck. I want a Bugatti. 

 Let‚Äôs do more of the basics and have a great week, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Go here if you sell info and you want to scale to $100k/month. ‚Äã

 P.P.S. Go here if you want my help in building your copywriting business. ‚Äã

subject: Got a haircut and figured out how be rich forever
body:
Very important update for you {{ subscriber.first_name }}‚Ä¶ 

 Guess what? 

 I got a haircut. 

 It‚Äôs my first one in three months because I had PTSD from the last one, but my boy Roger actually hooked it up this time. 

 You can hold the applause for now, thank you though. 

 Today, I‚Äôm thinking about an idea that can help you. 

 Recently I came to the realization that I‚Äôll likely be making money through my personal brand for a long time. 

 Whether it‚Äôs by getting agency clients, coaching clients, or even something else that I‚Äôm not currently doing. 

 Unless something changes, my personal brand will likely be the vehicle that buys me a rose gold Patek and a different supercar for each day of the week. 

 But I don‚Äôt know exactly how the micro will look. 

 I don‚Äôt know what offer will be the one that I scale long term. 

 I don‚Äôt know what platform will bring me the most clients. 

 And I don‚Äôt know all of the little details that‚Äôll have an impact on my success. 

 That‚Äôs a lot of don‚Äôt knows. 

 But I do know one thing: 

 More attention can only help. 

 The more people that find me on the internet, resonate with my content and offensive jokes, the better. 

 That will only make me money. 

 Plus it‚Äôs really fucking cool reading comments from people who tell me I inspired them because just four years ago I was that person on the other side of the screen. 

 So right now, I‚Äôm focusing on the macro. 

 Content the big, obvious lever I can pull and I‚Äôd be an idiot not to do everything I can to maximize it, even though I don‚Äôt know exactly what doors it‚Äôll open. 

 I‚Äôll figure out the details as I go. 

 I sound like Gary Vee talking about content and ‚Äúmacro‚Äù but let me ask you ‚Äì 

 What‚Äôs the one thing you can do consistently that‚Äôll ensure you‚Äôre successful over a longer time horizon? 

 Maybe it‚Äôs content, maybe it‚Äôs honing your craft, maybe it‚Äôs outreach, maybe it‚Äôs something entirely unrelated. 

 But figure that one thing out. 

 And do it consistently. 

 Congrats, now you can never go broke. 

 Hope you enjoyed this one, let me know if you made it down here :) 

 Ben 

 P.S. Yesterdays video is a banger and it‚Äôll help you escape poverty ‚Äã

subject: NGMI or FITFO
body:
There are two types of people in this world. 

 The first type of person is the one who hesitates to start a business because they‚Äôre worried about how they‚Äôd pay taxes if they were to make money. 

 They sit there and think about every possible problem that they could possibly run into. 

 ‚ÄúWhat happens if I get a client and then they ask me to do something that I don‚Äôt know how to do?‚Äù 

 These are the types that want a ‚Äúfull step-by-step playbook‚Äù to start a business. 

 It‚Äôs like they‚Äôre taking the 9-5er approach to business and need to be told what to do every step of the way. 

 There‚Äôs an acronym that accurately describes this type: 

 NGMI (not gonna make it). 

 They‚Äôre effectively toddlers. 

 The second type of person is the one who adopts a different mindset. 

 Sure, they still have hesitations, fears and doubts. 

 And they don‚Äôt know what every step of the staircase will look like. 

 But they take action despite these factors. 

 There‚Äôs a different acronym that they follow: 

 FITFO (figure it the fuck out). 

 Yesterday I found a perfect example of these two people in the comment section of one of my Youtube videos. 

 One person commented ‚ÄúThis video is ABSOLUTELY POSITIVELY POINTLESS‚Äù and right underneath him was a comment that read: 

 ‚ÄúExactly what I‚Äôm going through rn. Your YouTube was really put in my life for a reason. The timing of this video is impeccable‚Äù 

 Can you guess who‚Äôs who in this example? 

 Sure I‚Äôm biased because it‚Äôs my own video but this was interesting to me. 

 How can two people watch the same exact video and have completely opposite reactions? 

 Perception. 

 Your reality is colored by the lens in which you view the world. 

 If you think someone is coming to save you, or you think there‚Äôs a step by step system that everyone who ‚Äúmakes it‚Äù follows, you will find information that lacks training wheels useless. 

 Instead you‚Äôll watch hyper edited videos that follow a script and have gay animations over them. 

 You‚Äôll get a dopamine rush and think you‚Äôre doing something useful. 

 But you‚Äôll never actually find success because you‚Äôre type one. 

 You need everything to be predictable ‚Äì which is the opposite of entrepreneurship. 

 On the contrary, if you understand that anything worth having takes time and that your reality lies on your shoulders alone, you will eventually achieve your desired result. 

 And when you consume information that reminds you of this, instead of getting angry that you weren‚Äôt handed an ‚ÄúA-Z blueprint‚Äù you‚Äôll feel inspired that others see the world the same way you do. 

 Every day you have the power to choose which of these two people you want to be. 

 One will serve you and push you towards your goals. 

 And the other will keep you stuck in the same mindset that has gotten you nowhere. 

 Choose wisely. 

 Ben 

 P.S. Join Copy MBA if you're a FITFO person. ‚Äã

subject: How to easily be a better writer
body:
Happy Saturday {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 It‚Äôs been rainy and gloomy here in Miami for the past few days. 

 The sky is white right now but there‚Äôs no rain coming down so I‚Äôm sitting on my balcony as I write this to you. 

 Over the last few days I‚Äôve really noticed how the weather impacts my mood. 

 I‚Äôm a firm believer that 99% of problems can be fixed with a long walk in the sun. 

 When it was constantly raining and I was unable to do so, I started to go crazy. 

 Anyway it‚Äôs unusually quiet for a Saturday in the middle of Brickell. 

 Usually there's this dude who bikes around carrying a beat box. 

 He‚Äôll stop on random street corners and start break dancing. 

 Imagine you‚Äôre hungover at 8am on a Saturday and you‚Äôre woken up by a Bad Bunny song. 

 You get up, walk out onto your balcony and see some guy with pink hair and the shape of a heart on the back of his head. 

 He's blasting music and dancing like a freak. 

 You‚Äôd probably try to snipe him right? 

 I tried once but hit an old lady by accident. 

 Maybe someone finally got him because it‚Äôs quiet today. 

 Anyway, the other day I hosted a group call inside of Copy MBA. 

 Someone asked a question about ‚Äúwriters block‚Äù when first starting out. 

 Whether you want to build a copywriting business and you‚Äôre trying to practice, or you just want to start writing in general, this is inevitable. 

 This student was trying to write a sample email for this supplement brand, but whenever he opens a google doc, he stares at a blinking cursor and eventually closes his laptop. 

 Happens. 

 I asked him what sport he played growing up. 

 He told me he does mixed martial arts so I recommended that he find someone who is selling MMA courses or pick a clothing brand in that space and write for that instead. 

 The reason this is effective is because it‚Äôs much easier to write about things you‚Äôd be in the market for. 

 Especially when you‚Äôre first starting out. 

 When I started, I was writing copy for basketball trainers. 

 In every email, every ad, and every funnel I built ‚Äì I was writing to my previous self. 

 I understood the pain points and desires of the market because I was the market. 

 And this made practicing 100x easier. 

 Between this and building the habit of writing every day, I got better quickly. 

 If you want to get better at copy, you need to write for fun. 

 Start journaling. 

 Start tweeting. 

 Write a love letter to your ex. 

 Go sit down in a coffee shop and write about the barista that held eye contact for too long when taking your order. 

 Write about the idiot who‚Äôs standing in the middle of the doorway. 

 Write about the poor bastard who passes by on a scooter in work clothes with a backpack on. 

 Describe what you see in detail. 

 Make it entertaining and don‚Äôt hold back 

 Just write. 

 It will make your life better. And eventually, you‚Äôll be half decent at it. 

 Alrighty I‚Äôm going to the gym. 

 Let me know if you liked this one, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I posted a free 30 minute live call on Youtube where I map out the launch of a coaching program. 

 ‚Äã Check it out here. ‚Äã
