subject: Please stop pitching me
body:
Every day I wake up to two things: 

 1. The ear-itating (Dad joke ‚Äì happy belated fathers day) sound of construction workers drilling. 

 And‚Ä¶ 

 2. Pitches in every digital inbox I own. 

 Instagram, Twitter, TikTok, Gmail, even Venmo‚Ä¶ 

 People on the internet are constantly trying to get me to buy their services through cold outreach. 

 And my audience isn‚Äôt even that big. 

 99% of the outbound messages I read are absolute trash. 

 With every word they are showing more incompetence and only proving to be someone who I don‚Äôt want to work with. 

 They barely do any research on me or what I could potentially need, their messages are too long, they sound retarded, etc. 

 But honestly, it‚Äôs not their fault. 

 Outreach USED to be a numbers game. 

 If you blindly send enough cold DM‚Äôs, eventually you‚Äôll get a client. 

 It doesn‚Äôt work like that anymore (especially if you want to get GOOD clients that will pay you a decent retainer). 

 Your success is now correlated to the quality of your message and the way you are perceived online. 

 Yes, volume still matters. 

 But failing to put yourself in a more credible position before doing outreach is like DMing Instagram models when you have 29 followers and one picture of yourself holding a fish. 

 Not gonna work. 

 There are three things you can do that will improve your online perception, thus increasing the likelihood you get replies to your cold pitches. 

 1. Post content 

 2. Lead with material that proves competence 

 3. Network 

 The first point (content) is self explanatory. 

 If you‚Äôre a beginner I understand that it may be difficult to know where to start in that regard. 

 But I‚Äôm not just talking about video content or even posting information related to what you‚Äôre pitching. 

 If you look like a normal, cool person on Instagram, you will get more responses. 

 Simple. 

 This second element (material that proves competence) is absolutely crucial as well. 

 I get pitches with shitty sample emails and clips from my videos. 

 The time put into these assets is meaningless if they suck. 

 If they don‚Äôt suck, they get a reply. 

 Last element ‚Äì network (without being a dork). 

 Everyone is more likely to respond to someone they have mutuals with. 

 Strangers don‚Äôt get replies. They stay poor for eternity. 

 Friends do business together. 

 Got it? 

 Stop spraying and praying. 

 Use the three principles of online credibility above, and your chances of landing clients will greatly increase (and now it becomes a numbers game). 

 Hope this helps ‚Äì go show some love on this new video if it did :) ‚Äã 

 Please stop pitching me, 

 Ben

subject: One question you need to ask yourself
body:
I think I just called a they/them ‚Äúbro‚Äù 

 It was an accident. 

 I walked into the coffee shop to get my latte and it (they?) greeted me. 

 At a glance it was 100% a man. 

 But as I got closer I realized it had feminine features and no Adam‚Äôs apple. 

 Oops. 

 Anyway I heard someone say a really interesting quote the other day. 

 ‚ÄúThe only stupid questions are those that we fail to ask ourselves first.‚Äù 

 In other words, use your own brain and critical thinking ability before asking for help from others. 

 When you build the habit of constantly seeking advice, you start to lose trust in your own word. 

 You reach an impasse or situation you haven‚Äôt encountered prior, and feel helpless. 

 So you turn to others and want to be told what to do. 

 This basically turns you into a female uber driver: 

 Absolutely useless. 

 (Sorry I couldn‚Äôt resist ‚Äî I know there are some women who are not horrible drivers). 

 I actually had a female uber driver for a 30 minute ride this past weekend and I‚Äôm still alive so W‚Äôs in chat for her. 

 Back to the point - you have the answer to probably 90% of your problems. 

 When someone gives you advice, generally they‚Äôre just flexing the same critical thinking muscle that you have. 

 And your guess is as good as theirs. 

 Over time, the more you rely on others your self-reliance muscle will atrophy. 

 You‚Äôll lose all the trust that you had in your own judgement and seek approval, validation, and direction constantly. 

 This is even true when you have solid mentors and people that are giving you ‚Äúgood‚Äù advice. 

 Someone may tell you the right move to make on paper but that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs actually right for you. 

 It‚Äôs often the inclinations, or the trails that you recklessly and delusionally follow that end up leading to the biggest opportunities. 

 Now I'm not saying that gathering perspective from those who know more than you is always a bad thing. 

 Obviously there are times where direction from others can really help. 

 Just remember to listen to your own voice from time to time. 

 And before you go looking for help, 

 Ask yourself first. 

 Bye bro, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I‚Äôm launching something cool next week. You‚Äôll get one on one access to me, a private network, and content I don‚Äôt share elsewhere. 

 Since you‚Äôre on this list you‚Äôll have the opportunity to get in before I launch it publicly. 

 Hit reply and say ‚ÄúYes‚Äù if you‚Äôre interested and I‚Äôll add you to the waitlist. 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: True freedom can't be bought
body:
The other day I talked to two different business owners. 

 One of them was making $1m a month. 

 The other was making about a 20th of that. 

 After the two calls, I noticed something interesting. 

 I had much more respect for the guy who was making less money. 

 On that call, we talked a bit about business but the conversation quickly turned more philosophical. 

 He shared some of his goals with me and explained why he's doing what he's doing. 

 I could tell he was really thoughtful and intentional. 

 He put effort into considering what he actually wanted -- Not what would appear "cool" to strangers on the internet. 

 The other guy was far less interesting to talk to. 

 Sure, he'd reached a higher number in his business, but he was a dork. 

 He had an Amazon automation offer (which are typically a scam). 

 And was stressed because a few things had gone wrong in his business recently causing revenue to decline. 

 I wrote a tweet yesterday expanding on this which I'll share with you now: 

 "After a few years in business I‚Äôve stopped ‚Äúlooking up‚Äù to people simply because they‚Äôre making a lot of money. 

 Most guys end up losing the traits that make them interesting. 

 They get so bought in to adopting a worldview that others tell them to have. 

 With that, goes their autonomy. 

 They‚Äôre no longer thinking for themselves and what they want but rather for what other men will perceive as higher status. 

 I have more respect for the broke guy who figures out a way to live a dope life. 

 Or the entrepreneur who follows a more creative path, even if it costs him money. 

 Freedom of the mind can‚Äôt be bought. 

 And $1m a month is meaningless if you never stopped to figure out why you‚Äôre doing it. 

 Money can be an outlet to live how YOU want. It‚Äôs not an identity." 

 I'll never be someone who tells you not to make as much money as possible. 

 But just remember to continuously audit the path you're on and ensure it aligns with what you want. 

 And whatever path you choose -- follow it with conviction. ‚Äã

 Talk later, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Do this to guarantee you never go broke
body:
It‚Äôs 11:02am on a Monday morning as I start writing to you shirtless from my balcony. 

 I‚Äôm thinking about what I would do if everything got wiped to zero tomorrow. 

 Bank accounts drained, car stolen, watches donated to the homeless, all of my clients fire me, etc. 

 And I realize that I‚Äôd be fine. 

 There are three things I‚Äôve done over the past few years that have made me ‚Äúrecession proof.‚Äù 

 Meaning if some event occurred where I had to basically start all over, I have full conviction that I‚Äôd get back to where I am quickly. 

 And that‚Äôs good news for you, because the three things that give me that confidence are resources that anyone can access. 

 If you want to ensure that you can never go broke, do this: 

 1. Learn high income skills 

 2. Use social media to build a network 

 3. Build a personal brand 

 Those three assets turn you into a weapon. 

 The first step (learning skills) is simple. 

 Simply learn copywriting and sales and you‚Äôre in better shape than 99% of people. 

 Watch Youtube videos, pitch strangers on the internet, learn more on the fly. 

 Step two (building a network by being a normal cool person) opens doors and gives you a safety net. 

 If you can just start to connect with more people who are on a similar path as you (or ahead of you) opportunities flow your way. 

 The best way I‚Äôve found to do this has been through Twitter and by joining mastermind and coaching programs. 

 And lastly, step three (personal brand) is perhaps the most valuable resource you can build in 2024. 

 Now, not everyone is meant to have tens or hundreds of thousands of followers. 

 But that doesn‚Äôt mean that you can‚Äôt share some insights on social media and utilize the platform. 

 This goes hand and hand with networking in step two. 

 Even if you don‚Äôt end up building a huge personal brand, posting content online can only help you. 

 All three of these things will give you security and the best safety net possible if things ever go south. 

 It‚Äôs the peace of mind that a college degree is supposed to give you. 

 Let me know if you liked this one :) 

 Btw I have something really cool for you launching this week and I‚Äôm excited to share it with you. 

 Talk soon, 

 Ben

subject: How to go from good to great
body:
I cracked the code. 

 It‚Äôs summer 2015. 

 An hour in to a grueling basketball workout, my trainer makes a new rule. 

 ‚ÄúIf the ball hits the rim it counts as a miss and you have to run sprints. Swishes only.‚Äù 

 I think to myself ‚Äúthis mf crazy, I need a new trainer.‚Äù 

 But I keep shooting, now aiming only for nylon. 

 The ball hits the back of the rim and goes in. Doesn‚Äôt count. 

 Front rim. Side rim. Rattles in off the glass. 

 Doesn‚Äôt matter, I‚Äôm running. 

 ‚ÄúThis is ridiculous. I‚Äôm literally making these shots and still being forced to run,‚Äù I complain to myself. 

 But then something cool happens. 

 I find the sweet spot and the ball stops hitting the rim. 

 The way I‚Äôm shooting feels different now. 

 I‚Äôm no longer just aiming for the basket. 

 I‚Äôm aiming for a very specific part of the back of the net. 

 I‚Äôm conscious of exactly how the ball has to leave my fingertips. 

 Everything is incredibly precise. 

 I‚Äôve reached a level of attention to detail and focus that I wasn‚Äôt accessing previously. 

 This is the difference between good and great. 

 It‚Äôs what keeps some business owners stuck at $10k, $50k, or $100k per month. 

 It‚Äôs what causes tens of thousands of dollars worth of leads to fall through the cracks in a sales process. 

 And it‚Äôs what created the opportunity for me to make 7 figures as a marketer for info-product businesses. 

 I get paid to fill in the gaps. 

 To improve the copy, or the sales process, or the video script. 

 I bring a new level of attention to minor details and make an extra 6 figures a month for my clients. 

 They pay me a percentage of it. 

 This is how you win as a service provider for coaching business. 

 Find the broken piece(s) of their business. 

 Identify a solution using your critical thinking ability. 

 Get paid. 

 For example if an usually low amount of leads end up on sales calls, my job is to find the crack in the system. 

 Maybe the email sequence sucks or there‚Äôs none at all. 

 Maybe the leads aren‚Äôt getting dialed. 

 Maybe the video sales letter is horrible. 

 Maybe there‚Äôs a lack of congruence between the content and the messaging on the funnel. 

 Whatever the problem is, the way to make money is to identify and fix it. 

 Boom, now you‚Äôre a valuable piece to any coaching business. 

 You‚Äôre turning good, into great. 

 ‚Äã Congrats, that‚Äôs how the money is made. ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 P.S. I'm in the process of building a course and community called The Artisan Lab. 

 Because you're on this list, you'll have access to it before I promote it publicly (and at the lowest price). 

 It's made up of the 3 pillars: 

 Self, skillset, and social. 

 Anyone who wants to increase their income and build their dream lifestyle needs to master those 3 things. 

 If you're building a similar business to mine or if you want to direct access to me and my network, this will be a game changer for you. 

 Excited to share it with you in the coming days. 

 ‚Äã

subject: Why successful people are lazy
body:
July 1st. 

 Before I was doing anything with my life, it was usually around this time of year where I‚Äôd start to panic. 

 In the beginning of the year, I‚Äôd set a bunch of lofty goals. 

 I‚Äôd promise myself that this year is gonna be different. 

 But my New Year‚Äôs resolutions would remain as unchecked boxes on my computer screen. 

 By March, I‚Äôd start feeling the pressure. 

 ‚ÄúOk, you gotta lock in bro.‚Äù 

 I‚Äôd change my routine for a few days or maybe a week. 

 Then something would throw me off and I‚Äôd revert back to old habits. 

 I‚Äôd continue on autopilot for the next few months and then this time of year would hit. 

 That‚Äôs when I‚Äôd reach panic mode. 

 We‚Äôd be more than halfway through the year and I hadn‚Äôt made nearly any progress on my goals. 

 If this sounds familiar and you woke up in a frenzy this morning, good. 

 You‚Äôre just a few actions and a few months away from a very different life. 

 I‚Äôm writing to you from the lobby of one of the nicest hotels in LA where they filmed the movie Pretty Woman. 

 In a couple hours, I‚Äôll order a $200 uber black lux to take me to the airport even though I could get a normal one for $50. 

 On my flight back to Miami I‚Äôm in seat 1A and my girl is in 1B (as long as they don‚Äôt rug pull me again). 

 My life looks a lot different than it did when I‚Äôd procrastinate taking action on my goals for the better half of a year. 

 But I‚Äôm that same lazy kid. 

 I hate doing things I don‚Äôt wanna do. 

 I hate not knowing exactly how things are gonna work out. 

 I hate change. 

 But more than all of these, I hate the idea of living a life that I don‚Äôt want to live. 

 And that fear was powerful enough to help me overcome my lazy nature and habit of procrastinating. 

 So if you want to spur yourself into action, picture in vivid detail what your life will look like if you keep stalling. 

 And if that doesn‚Äôt do the trick you‚Äôre probably cooked. Sorry. 

 Talk to you when I‚Äôm back in Miami, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I uploaded a new narration style video yesterday ‚Äî let me now your thoughts ‚¨áÔ∏è 

 ‚Äã ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: my subconscious wrote this email
body:
Quick one for you today. 

 You need to make your subconscious your friend. 

 Once you activate your RAS (reticular activation system) to work in your favor, opportunities and ideas fall into your lap. 

 It‚Äôs like when you start thinking about a certain car and begin seeing more of it on the street. 

 Similarly, when you become intentional and get a general idea for the direction you want to head in‚Ä¶ 

 Your subconscious starts to conspire in your favor. 

 You get a random idea that turns into a breakthrough. 

 You get a weird inclination to start a new habit, or connect with a certain person. 

 That inclination create an opportunity. 

 This starts by doing the following: 

 When yo u want something, write it down. Think about it. Start taking actions that will move you towards said thing. 

 I‚Äôm frequently reminded of this when I make content. 

 Since I‚Äôve developed the Tuesday, Thursday, Sunday, Youtube video schedule, I start getting ideas on these days. 

 It begins when I consciously decide, ‚ÄúOkay, I need to make a video today.‚Äù 

 As I continue thinking about what I want to talk about, sometimes my subconscious will throw me a random thought. 

 I‚Äôll be on a walk or in the shower and boom. 

 I figure out what I want to talk about. 

 I could keep going on about this but I have to leave for dinner so maybe we can revisit another day. 

 ‚Äã Here was today‚Äôs thought by the way. ‚Äã

 Okay love you bye, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: $10 and spaghetti can create your dream life
body:
‚ÄúI would much rather fail gloriously than not try. I‚Äôm not interested in telling stories with competence. I‚Äôm looking to tell them with some style, originality, and creativity.‚Äù - Anthony Bourdain 

 Happy Saturday {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 The other day I was on a 90-foot yacht for the 4th of July, having a brief conversation with a friend about YouTube. 

 A few years ago, he had 27k subscribers but wasn‚Äôt making any money from his channel. 

 Then he got a piece of advice that changed his life forever. 

 In passing, one of the biggest YouTubers in the world told him to change the thumbnail on a video he‚Äôd posted 6 months prior. 

 So, he paid someone $10 to take a new thumbnail photo and uploaded it. 

 Over the following 24 hours he went from 27k subs to over 100k and quit his job at Subway. 

 He eventually reached over 1m subscribers before his channel was banned by the platform (you might know who I‚Äôm talking about here lol). 

 What‚Äôs crazy to me is that all happened because of one small adjustment. 

 Here‚Äôs how this pertains to you: 

 A single decision can completely change your life. 

 It could be a seemingly miniscule decision that you don‚Äôt give much thought to. 

 It could be a risk or hail mary attempt that leads to a big break. 

 Or it could be the decision to power through a tough time and change a behavior. 

 Genuinely, sit there and think about this for a second. 

 You are one decision away from everything you could ever dream of. 

 Right now, you don‚Äôt know what that decision is. 

 Odds are, you won‚Äôt know the ripple effect that it‚Äôll create even when you make it. 

 But if you keep throwing spaghetti at the wall hoping that it sticks, eventually it will. 

 Maybe you‚Äôll have to get creative and change from spaghetti to penne, or marinara to alfredo. 

 Maybe Anthony Bourdain will descend from heaven and casually tell you to add a single ingredient that makes it stick. 

 Or maybe you just have to keep throwing it over and over, past the point that you would usually quit. 

 One day, it will stick. 

 The culmination of all of your formerly unrewarded effort will be paid back 10 fold in an instant. 

 To others, you‚Äôll appear to be an overnight success. 

 But you‚Äôll know that‚Äôs not the case. 

 It was a result of tens, hundreds, or thousands of decisions and repetitions‚Ä¶ 

 Plus a disdain for the run of the mill, competent effort. 

 Eventually, it works. 

 Keep firing, and test the occasional aberrant idea. 

 Ben 

 P.S. Let me know if you liked this one. 

 Someone recently left a comment on a video of mine saying ‚ÄúAnthony Bourdain energy.‚Äù 

 I was somehow unfamiliar with Anthony until then and just watched this video where I got that quote in the beginning of the email. 

 ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: The superpower you don‚Äôt know you have
body:
I have a superpower. 

 It's a singular strength I‚Äôve really developed over the last few years. 

 It‚Äôs helped me in my personal life, business, and social media. 

 It seems to have made me more likable and has played a role in client acquisition and results. 

 Meaning it‚Äôs the reason people buy things. 

 And it‚Äôs probably the same reason you like my content (unless you hate it and you‚Äôre just here to talk shit in my replies). 

 The cool thing about this superpower, is it‚Äôs something you have too. 

 Maybe you‚Äôre accessing it right now, maybe you‚Äôre not. 

 But I think it‚Äôs one of the key factors in finding success in all the above domains. 

 ‚ÄúOk Ben, I get it, this thing is important. Now would you tell me what it is???‚Äù 

 No. 

 Don‚Äôt you understand? 

 Right now, you‚Äôre either using your superpower or you‚Äôre not. 

 You‚Äôre either hearing me, or you‚Äôre not. 

 And that‚Äôs the secret. 

 My superpower is I listen. 

 I listen to others when they talk. Not just what they say, but what they mean. 

 When my girl says ‚Äúit‚Äôs fine‚Äù I know that‚Äôs code for ‚Äúyou fucked up but I‚Äôm not telling you what you did, so you have to figure it out.‚Äù 

 When a prospect tells me about their business, I put myself in their shoes. 

 I think about their motives, desires and roadblocks. 

 And I assess their situation as objectively as I can. 

 This is obviously a huge part of copywriting and sales. It‚Äôs having the empathy to prescribe the right solution to a certain problem. 

 And if you don‚Äôt listen, you won‚Äôt be in tune with the problem. 

 Furthermore I listen to myself. 

 What do I actually want? 

 Why am I doing or not doing a certain thing? 

 Are my actions in alignment with what I say I want? And if not, am I willing to change? 

 I honestly think my habit to intellectualize my life is a blessing and curse. 

 It keeps me quite in touch with the underlying narratives going through my head. 

 Which helps me create content that feels really personal. 

 If it‚Äôs ever felt like I‚Äôm articulating an exact problem you have, and the way you think about it, this is why. 

 But sometimes it also stops me from taking action as quickly as I should. 

 Two sides to every coin I guess. 

 Anyway - listen more. 

 Stop jumping to conclusions. 

 Get off your high horse. 

 And do your best to be empathetic. Both with others and with yourself. 

 Remember - you‚Äôre one decision away from turning everything around. ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. My community, the Artisan Lab is in the works and launching soon. 

 If you want to learn from me in any capacity this is gonna be for you. 

 Plus it should be a really dope ‚Äúnetworking‚Äù opportunity if you want to meet more people in the online money space who aren‚Äôt dorks. 

 Excited to let you in :) 

 ‚Äã

subject: Don't forget about data
body:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Let‚Äôs talk about data. 

 Personally, I hate numbers. 

 I cheated in every math class I ever took. 

 But sometimes only data can reveal a clear answer when things are stagnant or you‚Äôre not getting a result you want. 

 This can be quite obvious when looking at quantifiable data. 

 If you‚Äôre spending $10k on ads and only making $5k back, clearly there's an issue. 

 Any reasonable person who doesn‚Äôt want to lose money would then try to figure out the problem. 

 To do this, they‚Äôd look at the more granular data. 

 The click through rate, cost per click, cost per impressions, conversion rate, etc. 

 Using this data, they‚Äôd attempt to identify the problem and test a solution. 

 Rinse and repeat. 

 This is a pragmatic, data-driven approach that will result in objective truths. 

 And if you‚Äôre not progressing in a certain area of your life the way you want to, this is what you need to apply. 

 Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôve been trying to put on muscle for 6 months. 

 Your approach hasn‚Äôt been very meticulous and you stepped on the scale today and saw that you‚Äôve only gained 2 pounds. 

 As a sensible person, capable of critical thought, what would you do in this scenario? 

 Answer in your head real quick. 

 If you said something along the lines of ‚ÄúI‚Äôd audit what I‚Äôm eating and how I‚Äôm working out, and see what needs to be changed,‚Äù you‚Äôve come up with a solid answer. 

 Now for whatever reason, this ability to analyze data gets forgotten when the data is less quantifiable. 

 Meaning if you‚Äôve been in a situation you don‚Äôt like for an extended period of time. 

 Whether it‚Äôs: 

 Trying to start a business and not making much progress 

 Stagnating in your business 

 Lack of growth on social media 

 Or even in your personal life: 

 Maybe you‚Äôve been wanting to improve a relationship, you‚Äôve had a list of hobbies that you wanted to try but haven‚Äôt, or you want to build better habits‚Ä¶ 

 Whatever that thing is, you eventually need to take an objective look under the hood. 

 ‚ÄúWhy am I not solving this problem I have? What are the variables that go into the problem? If I were to solve this problem, what would need to change?‚Äù 

 And just like that, you‚Äôve given yourself action steps to execute on. 

 Don‚Äôt forget to look at the data in your life and perform mini-audits. 

 Be pragmatic, and find the objective truth. 

 Ben 

 P.S. I finished recording the last few modules of the Artisan Lab today. 

 It has basically become a digital version of my brain. 

 Here‚Äôs some of the info inside: 

 How I‚Äôve built my agency to 6 figures/month How we‚Äôve scaled info businesses to $500k/month+ My full copywriting guide I‚Äôve used to generate millions The daily habits & routine that took me from being an average college kid to successful entrepreneur Plus a lot more. 

 Thinking about launching it in the next couple days. Do you want more info? 

 ‚Äã

subject: The three pillars of success
body:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Tomorrow I'm launching my new mastermind, The Artisan Lab. 

 It will be centered around the 3 pillars that play the biggest role in your success in online business. 

 Whether you're just starting out, or you're a copywriter, growth operator, course seller, or you're building a different business entirely... 

 These three pillars dictate your success: 

 1: Self 

 Simply put, change starts in the mind. 

 To do something you haven't done before, you need to step into a new identity. 

 This requires you to build new habits and discard old beliefs that don't serve you. 

 2: Skillset 

 Skills give you the security that a college degree was supposed to. 

 This is what makes you valuable -- if you can write copy and you can sell, it's nearly impossible for you to lose. 

 3: Social 

 Connections are everything and social media has made it easier than ever to build a network. 

 Use the internet to connect with likeminded people and opportunities will fall into your lap. 

 If you neglect any of the three pillars above, it's gonna take you a lot longer to reach goals and increase your income. 

 That's why the Artisan Lab will focus on all three of these. 

 Obviously, you'll learn all about how I've scaled my agency to $100k/month... 

 You'll see inside our service delivery process and what we do to scale info products to $500k/month+. 

 You'll get my processes for creating content and growing your personal brand on social media. 

 And yes, you'll get my full systems for building webinars, writing copy, VSLs, etc. 

 But none of that will matter if your mindset is flawed or you can't build relationships with the right people.

subject: Hack to an easier life and effortless success
body:
I‚Äôm on my balcony watching a boat go by in the river in front of me. 

 It‚Äôs early in the morning so there's a really cool blue/white-ish/yellowish tone in the sky. 

 I‚Äôd take a picture and show you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, but my phone's inside and I don‚Äôt feel like getting up to go get it. 

 Anyway, I have an important topic for you today. 

 If you understand this one thing, you gain complete control of your life. 

 It creates a reality where everything becomes a choice. 

 From making more money, to improving your relationships, to feeling good about your daily routine. 

 You simply decide to make something happen and reality follows suit. 

 And luckily, the key to all of this is incredibly straightforward. 

 Ownership. 

 Taking ownership is how you make things happen with the push of a button. 

 I‚Äôm not referring to the ‚Äúeverything is your fault‚Äù type of narrative that you might hear online. 

 But rather understand that everything is your choice. 

 When you make a concerted effort to accomplish something, the outcome is largely dependent on you. 

 Sure, there are variables that you don‚Äôt control and you need to accept that. 

 But obsessing over, or placing blame on those variables will make you powerless. 

 So when you hear yourself start to blame external factors for why things aren‚Äôt working out in your favor, simply cut that narrative. 

 Even if it‚Äôs partially true, it doesn‚Äôt serve you. 

 It‚Äôs like if you‚Äôre playing a sport and you have a bad head coach who doesn‚Äôt let you play the way you want to. 

 You can complain about it, underperform and be miserable. 

 Or you can keep doing your best regardless of the situation. 

 Taking this approach to life makes you unfuckwithable. 

 If there‚Äôs a situation in your business that isn‚Äôt going according to plan, you fix it. 

 Even if that means a client is slacking on their responsibilities. 

 Or a team member isn‚Äôt performing the way you need them to. 

 Or there was a change in the algorithm and your old system isn‚Äôt working the same. 

 You take the problem into your own hands. 

 And you don‚Äôt do so with bitterness for other people in the equation, for they aren‚Äôt on my email list and didn‚Äôt get equipped with this superpower. 

 You are the master of your reality and no one and no thing can throw you off your shit. 

 That‚Äôs the mindset that serves you best and makes success effortless. 

 Take ownership of your shit and you‚Äôll be a hell of a lot happier. 

 ‚Äã And join the Artisan Lab if you want to accelerate your growth. ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã Ben 

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: Benjamin is a loser
body:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 I'm sitting here with my friend Mason, who you probably know as the baby faced assassin copywriter. 

 We're about to go to dinner with our friend Tyler (TJR Trades) who you may also know as the day-trader who looks like a rapper. 

 There's a guy on Tik Tok named Benjamin Graham. 

 He must not have been loved as a child or he hasn't seen naked woman since the day he came out of his mothers womb. 

 This guy has taken it upon himself to become "the internets white-knight." 

 Basically he's the fat chick in a group of girls who tells you the pretty one isn't interested. 

 In every video he "calls out" someone new. 

 He'll cherry pick information and find a way to make the guy out to be a scammer. 

 His audience loves him. 

 Everyone in his comments will be like "Yeah! you exposed that guy! rEnteD LamBo course seller ScaMmEr!!!" 

 And then they probably continue putting the groceries in the bag during their shift at Publix. 

 THIS is the exact mindset that will keep you poor and miserable forever. 

 You'll be the guy who complains that the "bad guy" gets the girl. 

 You'll be the skeptic who hopes for crypto to crash, or the historically great sports team to lose. 

 You'll be the divorced single Mother who yells at the T.V. while watching Leonardo DiCaprio talk about his new 20-year-old super model girlfriend. 

 You'll be the unhappy, pessimistic, smug 50 year old who tells hopeful kids to "wait till you're my age because it all goes downhill." 

 But one time you'll be right. 

 You'll hang your hat on the fact that once upon a time, your skepticism was accurate. 

 Even though you get pissed off watching young guys on social media drive what was once your dream car. 

 While living where you once dreamt of and dating the girls you salivate over on social media... 

 You'll justify it all because every now and then, you do find a scammer. 

 So you elect to believe that it's all a scam and nothing more was ever possible. 

 Does that result in a fruitful, beautiful life? 

 No. 

 If you're reading this right now, it's in your best interest to believe that it's all possible. 

 You can be the guy in the supercar. 

 The business CAN work if you put the work in. 

 And making money online is possible for you because you're watching other people who are just like you do it. 

 Don't be a depressed, miserable dork. 

 Adopt the mindset that it can all be real, put in the according action, and eventually it will all unfold. 

 ‚Äã And join The Artisan Lab if you want my help :) ‚Äã

 Ben 

 ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: How I land the best clients in the info space
body:
Gm. 

 I forgot to write to you yesterday. 

 Not because I don‚Äôt love you (I do). 

 But because I was quite busy. 

 I had a few one-on-ones with new members of my mastermind, I boxed with my trainer, and I brought in a special guest to do a group call with my community. 

 Then I was scrolling through Tik Tok and saw a creator with a huge audience and a really ugly funnel. 

 He probably had some 18 year old kid who calls himself a ‚Äúgrowth operator‚Äù set it up for him. 

 It was a $27/month Skool community. 

 Now listen, I haven't sent an outbound dm since you were in diapers. 

 You‚Äôre probably around the same age as me, so that was a really long time ago. 

 But this guy was sitting on such an opportunity and I was so disgusted to see it being squandered. 

 So, I ran into my office and made him a loom video pitch. 

 It took me 2 seconds to find his email, I wrote a few lines of copy and sent the loom. 

 Using my little spy tool, I saw he opened it instantly. 

 Then I got a notification that ‚Äúsomeone‚Äù watched my video. 

 He didn‚Äôt reply yet, but he went over to my instagram and followed me. 

 We‚Äôll see. I honestly don‚Äôt care if he closes or not. 

 But it‚Äôd be really cool if I could flex on all of you who‚Äôve been doing outreach for a while. 

 Imagine you‚Äôre working your ass off sending 30 pitches a day. 

 And then you see me, scrolling through tik tok in my pajamas when I find your ideal client. 

 I open my laptop, click the loom button and start rambling about how we‚Äôve made a lot of clients a lot of moneys. 

 Next thing you know I‚Äôm on a call with your ideal client and he loves me. 

 We talk about the weather and he tells me about his favorite spots in Miami when he was my age. 

 I show him the keys to my Porsche 911 turbo and then tell him I can help him make the equivalent of 3 of them in a month. 

 He‚Äôs wowed. 

 I pitch a price 100x the average growth operator or copywriters net worth. 

 He says ‚ÄúYES!!!‚Äù and asks if he can add a tip. 

 I receive the wire on the call, my team builds him a new funnel, and we make him $1m next month. 

 Hahahaha. 

 That would be cool. 

 I shared this whole outbound process (including the loom and email I sent) inside the Artisan Lab btw. ‚Äã

 I didn‚Äôt expect to write a rather arrogant email to you today, but here we are. 

 It would also be funny if this whole thing blew up in my face. 

 I‚Äôll keep you updated. 

 This inspired me to start doing outbound again. It‚Äôs kind of fun. 

 Anyway, you can apply to join my mastermind here if you want to get a behind the scenes look at it all. ‚Äã

 Talk to you tomorrow, 

 Ben
‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: want to talk 1-on-1?
body:
In yesterdays email I told you how I sent my first outbound pitch since the Vietnam war. 

 A lot of people replied, so I figured I'd give you a quick update. 

 I had an hour long sales call yesterday afternoon with the prospect and his assistant. 

 He had actually replied to my email 30 minutes after I sent it but it went to my requests on instagram so I didn't see it immediately. 

 Regardless, we ended up on a zoom. 

 I was sitting at the desk you see me at in my Youtube videos and he noticed the keyboard behind me. 

 So I played a verse of Beethovens' Fur Elise . 

 Not joking. 

 Then we chatted for a while and I broke down how I'd help him make a lot more money. 

 The guy has grown to over a quarter million followers on both TikTok and Instagram from scratch after starting in April. 

 Which is absolutely crazy growth and a perfect opportunity for someone like me to come into. 

 We hopped off the call, I sent a proposal over and we'll touch base Monday. 

 This cold outreach thing is kind of fun(?) 

 Idk why I've been hating on it for the last two years lol. 

 Anyway I've been documenting this whole process inside my mastermind. 

 From what I said in the loom video pitch, to the email I sent which got almost an instant reply. 

 I even shared the 4 page proposal that I wrote with everything I'd do to help him get to multi-six figures per month. 

 The Artisan Lab members have been able to see the whole process. 

 That should give you FOMO. 

 Actually, I have an idea. 

 I'm chilling here on the couch on this beautiful Friday evening and don't have much to do. 

 If you're interested in joining the Artisan Lab and have some money to invest in coaching... 

 DM me the word "Artisan" on Instagram here and I'll personally reply and answer any questions you have about the mastermind. 

 I promise it'll be me and not an appointment setter or anything. 

 Here's an unsolicited POV of me right now for proof: 

 ‚Äã ‚Äã DM me "Info" on IG and let's chat. ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Moooooooooove
body:
A lot has changed since the last email I sent to you. 

 First, I moved. 

 Here‚Äôs my new POV as I begin writing to you: 

 ‚Äã I‚Äôm now 80 something floors up with the water view you see above. 

 It‚Äôs much more peaceful than being in the middle of the city (and better than being on a poverty floor under the clouds). 

 I was reminded of a very valuable lesson during this move. 

 You see, I‚Äôm the type of guy that does everything last minute. 

 ESPECIALLY if it‚Äôs something trivial or a task I don‚Äôt want to do. 

 So I waited until 6pm on the day before I was supposed to move to start clicking around on the internet to find a moving company. 

 I filled out a few forms to get quotes and assumed they‚Äôd reach out within a day or two. 

 Next thing you know, I get a call from a local number. 

 Keep in mind, it‚Äôs Sunday at 7:24pm EST, less than an hour after I filled out the form. 

 Some kind woman is on the other end with the moving company and she tells me she can send movers as early as tomorrow. 

 I‚Äôm sold. 

 I don‚Äôt care about the price. 

 I don‚Äôt care to get quotes from other companies. 

 I had a problem and this woman Kathy (not her real name but she sounded like a Kathy) extinguished that problem quickly. 

 That‚Äôs the lesson. 

 If you‚Äôre selling agency services or coaching, or literally anything‚Ä¶ 

 MOVE FASTER. 

 I‚Äôve personally lost deals because I was too slow or wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúavailable‚Äù until a few days later. 

 By then the urgency is gone. 

 And the pain that comes with a fresh problem is diminished, meaning getting the sale is gonna be harder. 

 This is why it‚Äôs a good rule of thumb to have a sales team that dials every lead immediately (if you run a coaching business and you‚Äôre not doing this, that means you enjoy poverty). 

 One of the first lessons I was taught when I started running ads for local basketball trainers 4 years ago, was ‚Äúspeed = lead.‚Äù 

 I was in this coaching program and my coach told me to drill this message into the heads of my clients. 

 My job was to get them leads, but if they don‚Äôt contact those leads ASAP, then they‚Äôre throwing money down a furnace. 

 As you know, business is just a game of solving problems. 

 The bigger problems you solve and the faster you can do so, the more money you make. 

 The first moving company that called me late on a Sunday got my business and charged me $1,200 to move me 5 minutes down the street. 

 Maybe there was a cheaper option. 

 But the problem was resolved and I‚Äôm happy to pay a premium for the efficiency. 

 ‚Äã Don‚Äôt be slow or you‚Äôll get left behind. ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: Spend more money
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 I have a quick money lesson for you today. 

 Once upon a time I was extremely attached to money. 

 When it was a good month in my business, I was happy. 

 When it wasn't a good month, I wanted to go play in traffic. 

 This obviously made my internal state a bit of a rollercoaster. 

 I'd get hung up on a number in my bank account and if it wasn't growing -- or even worse, if it was declining, it'd make me anxious. 

 In my opinion, frugality and neuroticism are not traits that result in fruitful life. 

 So one day, I started spending money a lot more freely. 

 I stopped thinking about paying for food, hotels, flights, or any investment that would help my business. 

 Over time, the number that felt like a lot of money to me drastically increased. 

 This is what broke my attachment to the number in my bank account. 

 I've watched that number go up by $50k-$100k in a day. 

 But I've also cringed while tipping the bottle girl the equivalent of a decent email marketing retainer on a $15k night out. 

 My current lifestyle is expensive. 

 And it's part of what helped me expand my mindset around money. 

 The less I've hesitated to send a $20k wire to grow my business, buy first class seats, doordash every meal, etc... 

 The more money I have made. 

 If you view a number as small and achievable, it becomes exactly that. 

 If you're scared to spend money on yourself, then why would anyone spend money on you? 

 Lesson in there. 

 Anyway I gotta get on a call for Artisan Lab -- which you should totally join here if you want to spend money on yourself :) ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: One thing you should've started yesterday
body:
Inside my new mastermind, The Artisan Lab , I bring in a new guest speaker each week. 

 This keeps it fresh and it‚Äôs interesting to hear various perspectives from people who have found success in their domain. 

 Last night my friend Miles was kind enough to host a call. 

 He‚Äôs one of the most reputable personal brands in the Amazon seller space (@flips4miles on all platforms). 

 Miles has been creating content since the day I met him 3 or 4 years ago. 

 He documented his entire journey from zero to selling 7 figures worth of products on Amazon. 

 The guy is autistically consistent ‚Äì and I mean that in the best way possible. 

 If you want to see, go look at his socials right now. 

 He‚Äôs constantly posting. 

 In fact, he‚Äôs written a Twitter thread every day for nearly 2 years now. 

 As a result, he‚Äôs grown multiple successful businesses off the back of his personal brand. 

 2 software companies and a coaching business that you will only see positive reviews from. 

 But on last night's call, he said that he made basically no money from his first 3 years of posting online. 

 He actually wasn‚Äôt even trying to monetize his brand, he was posting content as a way to build good will and connect with other people in the Amazon space. 

 I‚Äôm telling you all of this because I want you to understand one thing: 

 If you plan on being in the online business world for a while and you‚Äôre not posting any content, you likely have a room temperature IQ. 

 There are a few exceptions to this but let‚Äôs disregard that for now. 

 More people knowing and trusting you can only make you more money. 

 Period. 

 Even if you‚Äôre towards the beginning of your journey, get the ball rolling and then start documenting the process. 

 You don‚Äôt have to build a Hormozi type brand. 

 You don‚Äôt even have to grow a large audience. 

 But simply existing as a normal human on the internet will only open doors for you (as long as you don‚Äôt say anything that will get you canceled). 

 Even if you never want to sell coaching, you can make money without your personal brand, and you think your teeth are too crooked to show your face on camera‚Ä¶ 

 It will only serve you, I promise. 

 It‚Äôs how I met all of my best friends you see me hanging out with. 

 And it‚Äôs the only reason you‚Äôre reading this right now. 

 Now before you say ‚ÄúI dOn‚ÄôT kNoW whAt tO poSt AbOut.‚Äù 

 It doesn‚Äôt matter. 

 Just start. Talk about what you find interesting. Talk about why you‚Äôre poor. Talk about your dog, or your girl, or your obsession with sports betting. 

 Just don‚Äôt say the N word or call fat people disgusting hippos. 

 You‚Äôll be glad you started. 

 ‚Äã Get access to the next guest speaker call by going here. ‚Äã

 Bye, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: Some discouraging words of encouragement
body:
I‚Äôm sorry for the week-long hiatus. 

 But now, I‚Äôm what one may define as ‚Äò so fucking back.‚Äô 

 I‚Äôve been busy closing deals. 

 If you were on this list a week and a half ago, you might remember me talking about an outbound pitch I sent. 

 I just wanted to let you know that it closed. 

 Yes, that‚Äôs correct: 

 I sent one outbound DM for the first time in years. 

 And it resulted in a 5 figure set up fee in my pocket 10 days later. 

 Plus a rev share that will likely be very fruitful, as this is a ‚Äòdream client‚Äô by most standards. 

 Imagine you‚Äôre grinding outreach, sending dozens of messages per day, and I waltz in and steal your best prospect because I got bored. 

 I‚Äôd be pissed. 

 I know I‚Äôm bragging here but I‚Äôm on a caffeine/endorphin high so you‚Äôll have to forgive me. 

 The point I am getting at is this ‚Äì 

 You‚Äôre one (quality) pitch away. 

 It probably won‚Äôt be your first pitch because you‚Äôre not Ben Bader. 

 But it might be your 10th pitch. 

 Or your hundredth. 

 Or your thousandth. 

 Eventually it will work. 

 Whether you‚Äôre trying to get a client, making content hoping something goes viral, or cold approaching models on the street‚Ä¶ 

 All it takes is one yes. 

 I'll leave you with a quote from one of the greatest philosophers of our generation, Future: 

 ‚ÄúI just want to see my dogs ball, seven figures.‚Äù 

 Go make some money today, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I documented this whole process inside my mastermind. 

 From what I said in the pitch, to the sales call, to the proposal, follow ups, and the contract that got the deal done. 

 I‚Äôll also be showing exactly what we do to scale this client to multi six figures a month inside the Artisan Lab. 

 If you want to see that, plus get direct access to me, learn from new guest speakers weekly, and be in a community of winners‚Ä¶ 

 ‚Äã Join me here. ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: how to practice your writing ability
body:
Hey. 

 I‚Äôm starting this email completely blind. 

 Meaning I have zero idea what‚Äôs gonna come out onto this page. 

 Hopefully it‚Äôs kind of coherent. 

 I went for a walk this morning. 

 My new apartment is right by the water so it‚Äôs nice being able to go outside, cross the street, and start moving. 

 It seems like everyone else who walks during this early morning shift is one of two things: 

 1.Old 

 2.Dog 

 I‚Äôm neither of the two. 

 Although I did find a gray hair on my head the other day and I accidentally barked when I saw a pretty girl in the elevator. 

 Hmm. 

 Ok, this leads me to a lesson for you. 

 If you want to become a better writer, you need to enjoy it. 

 So far in this email, I‚Äôve said nothing of value. 

 But I‚Äôm having fun. And you‚Äôre still here, so that means maybe you‚Äôre having fun with me. 

 I‚Äôve never deliberately ‚Äúpracticed‚Äù my copywriting ability, I just wrote. 

 I started sending emails to this list in September 2021. 

 There were probably 6 people who‚Äôd subscribed, including my 4 burner emails, my mother, and grandma. 

 On top of that, I was effectively an autistic Chinese child who didn‚Äôt speak a word of English (if that offended you, grow up). 

 I had no idea what I was talking about, nothing to sell, and very few people who cared to listen to what I was saying. 

 But I started anyway. 

 I developed my own style, my writing became more clear, and I began articulating the ideas that were rattling around in my head. 

 Along with the newsletter, I was consistently tweeting and journaling. 

 This was the ‚Äútraining camp‚Äù that prepared me to work with clients. 

 I‚Äôd read a few copywriting books, I practiced every day (even though it didn‚Äôt feel like practice), and I became half-decent at this writing thing. 

 It‚Äôd be impossible not to. 

 One of my favorite copywriting books is The Boron Letters by Gary Halbert. 

 The reason I like it is because it feels personal (he wrote it to his son while he was in jail). 

 Instead of writing in a super authoritative tone, it reads as if it‚Äôs a journal with insights and tips sprinkled throughout. 

 You can tell he clearly enjoys writing and isn‚Äôt putting any pressure on himself to be grammatically correct or follow any rules. 

 This is how you have to practice. 

 Write about your day. 

 Write about something you enjoy. 

 Write about how you overcame a difficult time in your life. 

 Write about the weird crush you have on your cleaning lady (creep). 

 It doesn‚Äôt matter what you write about, as long as you find a way to enjoy it, and it doesn‚Äôt feel like work. 

 Ok? 

 Ok. 

 Enough for today. 

 ‚Äã Join me in the Artisan Lab if you want to get rich. ‚Äã

 If you don‚Äôt want to join me in there, that‚Äôs fine. But at least reply and tell me you made it all the way down here to make me feel good. 

 Thanks, 

 Ben

subject: nice try diddy
body:
I‚Äôve been a bit stressed out lately that my content hasn‚Äôt been doing super well. 

 YouTube views are down, Tik Tok only pushes my videos when I say something controversial, and half the retards in the comments tell me to ‚Äúput the fries in the bag.‚Äù 

 This is the new normie army insult and it‚Äôs pretty funny. 

 They‚Äôve also started leaving ‚ÄúNice try Diddy‚Äù in the comments on ads. 

 If only they put that energy into something that would actually improve their lives. 

 Anyway, whenever I‚Äôm stressed, I do one of three things. 

 The first thing is bad. 

 If I do this, I lose. 

 It temporarily numbs the stress but doesn‚Äôt revolve anything. 

 And it‚Äôs scrolling through social media. 

 Now the other two mechanisms I use to combat stress seem to work like magic for me. 

 The first is doing what I‚Äôm doing right now, writing. 

 I wrote a whole email to you yesterday and made a Youtube video about how writing will change your life, so no need to repeat myself. 

 Just trust me. Start today if you haven't. 

 The second thing is walking. 

 What better way to clear your head? 

 It‚Äôs literally impossible to be sad when the sun is shining and birds are chirping. 

 I could watch my best friend get eaten by a lizard but if it‚Äôs a nice day I‚Äôll get over it. 

 Ok maybe that‚Äôs an exaggeration. 

 Back to the point. 

 On my walk in the sun this morning, I thought about my life. 

 I realized that success comes in waves. 

 There will be times where I can pull out my phone, make a minute long video and get a million views. 

 And there will be times where I feel like I‚Äôm spewing gold into the camera only for a couple thousand people to even see it. 

 Every wave eventually crashes. 

 But the ocean never stops moving. 

 Your time will come. 

 And if you‚Äôre riding a wave right now, get as much as you can out of it. 

 Last thing: 

 I also realized how ungrateful I was being by complaining about metrics. 

 People leave comments and reply to my emails telling me how much I‚Äôve impacted their lives, but I‚Äôm unhappy because the views are down? 

 What a bitch. 

 Do not take for granted what you have, just because you want more. 

 Greed will make you lose it all. 

 I appreciate you {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 Thank you for reading my emails and engaging with my content. 

 I‚Äôll stop taking you for granted. 

 Have a great day, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Join Artisan Lab here ‚Äã

 P.P.S Reply if you liked this one <3 

 ‚Äã

subject: how to stop the Chinese from infiltrating your mind
body:
Cdhsuifhinfkfbedbfqbef! 

 Hey. 

 Ignore the gibberish in the first line. I‚Äôm just excited to talk to you. 

 Hope you‚Äôre having an amazing Thursday morning. 

 What do you want to talk about today? 

 Oh, I got something. 

 Decisions. 

 Isn‚Äôt it crazy how our entire reality is shaped by countless micro decisions we‚Äôre making on a daily basis? 

 Like you could just wake up one day and start speaking with a British accent. 

 Or you could simply decide to stop being poor and take the actions necessary to make money. 

 Orrr you could decide to stop pulling out and build an NFL team of babies. 

 Everyday you choose to either take actions that will further align you with the person you want to be, or do the opposite. 

 When you open your laptop and the voice in your head tells you that you need to scroll through TikTok for a minute before starting work ‚Äì can you shut it out or do you give in? 

 Because you know ‚Äòone minute‚Äô usually turns into three hours. 

 You simply cannot compete with the Chinese artificial intelligence algorithm. 

 They figured out, ‚ÄúOh, all we have to do is show men titties and show women travel videos and Hermes bags and they just keep scrolling forever. Stupid little lizards.‚Äù 

 Can you resist the double D‚Äôs and birkins? 

 Or will you give in to the Chinese? 

 Hahahah. 

 Sorry I got carried away on that one. 

 Recently I had to make a big decision. 

 It was not easy but I knew that it would be better for me in the long run. 

 My brain tried to do everything in its power to stop me. 

 Because with this decision, much change would come. 

 And that‚Äôs painful. 

 Even days after I‚Äôd made up my mind, I‚Äôd still find myself trying to revert back to old habits. 

 I quite literally had to view the voice in my head like a toddler. 

 ‚ÄúNo, you don‚Äôt actually want that. It‚Äôs just a narrative you‚Äôre telling yourself because it‚Äôs easier than the alternative.‚Äù 

 I used logic to constantly remind myself that I was making the right call. 

 And there was this underlying feeling in my gut that knew that was true. 

 I‚Äôm telling you all this because I want you to make the right choices. 

 You know what you need to do. 

 You know what needs to change. 

 And you know that further contemplation is just a way to occupy your brain so that you feel like you‚Äôre being productive. 

 Don‚Äôt let the Chinese control you. 

 Resist! 

 ‚Äã Lmao, ‚Äã 

 Ben
‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: everything is bad and that's really good
body:
Three days ago I sent you an email about how my content hadn‚Äôt been getting many views. 

 Yesterday, I had three videos go semi-viral on Tik Tok. 

 Whenever this happens, it fries my dopamine receptors for a few days. 

 Every time I refresh the app, I have more comments, follows, and dm‚Äôs. 

 And since I‚Äôm addicted to dopamine, I end up spending the whole day staring at my phone. 

 It‚Äôs funny how this works. 

 In my email the other day, I talked about how success comes in waves. 

 It felt like I‚Äôd been paddling, trying to catch a wave for a while and I was getting restless. 

 But I knew I just had to keep trying. 

 Two days later, I caught three waves in a row. 

 The obvious lesson there is that you never know when your time will come but if you keep shooting, you can‚Äôt go wrong. 

 The less obvious lesson is that ‚Äúgood and ‚Äúbad‚Äù do not exist in reality, they are constructs of the mind. 

 I know it might sound like I‚Äôm reaching in an attempt to sound insightful right now and you‚Äôre like, ‚ÄúOk buddy whatever the fuck that means.‚Äù 

 Allow me to explain. 

 When I was frustrated about my content not performing, it was a lot easier to sit and work on real business tasks. 

 It was the source of the lesson in my email the other day. 

 And it forced me to not let my desire for external validation control and discourage me. 

 You could make the argument that my content flopping was actually a ‚Äúgood‚Äù thing. 

 On the contrary, because I‚Äôve had these few videos go viral, it‚Äôs been really difficult to do anything else. 

 Sitting at my desk to do real work feels like a herculean feat. 

 I‚Äôm constantly checking my phone and I now feel an added pressure to make my videos continually perform. 

 Again, we could make a solid argument here for why virality is a ‚Äúbad‚Äù thing. 

 But in reality, neither of those conclusions would be completely true. 

 It simply is as it is. 

 There are countless pro‚Äôs when a situation isn‚Äôt going as you‚Äôd hoped. 

 There are countless con‚Äôs when a situation is going exactly how you wanted it. 

 It‚Äôs your perception that makes it good or bad. 

 Don‚Äôt get caught up in that perception. 

 And remember, every hurdle is part of a bigger plan. 

 Alright I gotta get back to scrolling. 

 But before I do, quick plug ‚Äì I went on this podcast recently and discussed some things I haven‚Äôt talked much about publicly. ‚Äã 

 Go watch that and happy Saturday, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: I'm getting old
body:
Ok I have a few things I need to tell you about so we're going old school, boomer style newsletter today. 

 First thing -- this just dropped. ‚Äã

 Second thing -- Artisan Lab members are printing. 

 ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã If you'd also like to acquire wealth via the internet while conquering new territories and getting better looking every day... 

 ‚Äã Join them here. ‚Äã 

 You get direct access to me, course content on how we've scaled offers to $500k/month+, my new outreach system to get clients, and a whole lot more -- including a live call with a new guest speaker every week, which has been sick. 

 If you're not inside yet, you either hate money or you're a homeless man who's somehow acquired a phone to read this email but you have no interest in turning your life around. 

 In that case continue on. 

 But in all other cases, go here now. ‚Äã 

 O k, last thing for today. 

 On my walk this morning it started raining. 

 It wasn't pouring, but it was enough to where others scrambled for cover. 

 At first, I was going to join them. 

 But then I figured what the hell, a few raindrops never killed anyone. 

 I continued on as if nothing was happening. 

 A few minutes later the rain stopped. 

 And not long after that, I was completely dry again. 

 Because I kept moving, the rain didn't effect me. 

 It would've been worse had I stopped. 

 In life, you have to choice to do the same thing. 

 When it's "raining," and bad things are happening to you, or your mind is pulling you in a million different directions... 

 You can just carry on as if nothing is happening. 

 And most of the time the "problem" dissolves. 

 After the rain, comes the rainbow. Lol. 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }}, we're going to Vietnam
body:
Good morning {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 I went for a run and then tried to meditate but it didn‚Äôt really work. 

 Now I‚Äôm here, typing to you. 

 I‚Äôm actually sitting at the desk in my ‚Äúoffice,‚Äù which is really just a den. 

 Since I moved about three weeks ago, this has been the last area of my new apartment that still needs work. 

 The lighting in here is kind of depressing and I have a bunch of random belongings on the floor. 

 Because of this, I‚Äôve avoided this room. 

 My phone is in the kitchen because I‚Äôve been really addicted to it recently. 

 It‚Äôs cool that you can get rich and all from your fingertips but wow can that device be destructive. 

 On my run earlier, I thought about what it must‚Äôve been like to be a young man who was shipped off to fight in the Vietnam war. 

 Imagine you‚Äôre a 19 year old kid, fresh out of high school. 

 You‚Äôre awakened in the middle of the night by Forrest Gump. 

 He grabs you by the ear and takes you with him. 

 Next thing you know you have an AK-47 in your hands and you‚Äôre shooting at anyone who has squinty eyes. 

 What a turn of events, huh? 

 All of the problems you had prior to being drafted have now vanished. 

 You‚Äôre no longer worried about what career you‚Äôre gonna go into. 

 You stopped thinking about what to say to the girl you have a crush on. 

 And you couldn‚Äôt give a singular shit about the decor in home or clothes on your back. 

 You now have one goal; 

 Survive. 

 If you‚Äôre reading this, I assume that the Vietnamese are not currently trying to blow your head off. 

 What a lucky guy (or girl) you are. 

 I‚Äôm in the same boat. 

 And although this is obviously a privilege, it comes with consequences. 

 Naturally, you want a war. 

 You want a mountain to climb, and a communist to shoot at. 

 But because life is relatively easy, you have to avoid the trap of getting caught up in bullshit problems so that you feel like you‚Äôre progressing. 

 In other words, don‚Äôt stress about inconsequential things because you don‚Äôt have a life or death thing. 

 You need to find your Vietnam war. 

 Actually, let me rephrase that. 

 You need to make your life the Vietnam war. 

 Build businesses, go hard in the gym, nurture beautiful relationships, get famous, fight a homeless man (lol), travel the globe‚Ä¶ 

 Just do something. 

 Preferably something that‚Äôs actually productive instead of worrying about things that have little impact on your life. 

 That‚Äôs how you avoid becoming a Karen who gets mad at kids for skateboarding on the sidewalk. 

 Or becoming a fat incel whose only joy is yelling racial slurs at the TV. 

 Or even a manic 46 year old housewife who yells at the gardener because he missed a blade of grass. 

 You need real(er) problems. 

 Stuff that‚Äôs actually worth stressing about. 

 And you‚Äôre likely not gonna get sent to Vietnam any time soon so you have to bring Nam‚Äô to you. 

 You‚Äôre lucky. Don‚Äôt waste your luck. 

 Ben 

 P.S. Join me in the Artisan lab here. ‚Äã 

 P.P.S. Lmk if you made it all the way down here, soldier. 

 ‚Äã

subject: this is the opportunity of the decade
body:
Happy Monday. 

 On my walk this morning I overheard a guy talking about the hospitality industry. 

 It sounds like times are tough right now. 

 A friend of mine who works in nightlife told me the same thing recently. 

 Allegedly, a lot of the bigger clubs and restaurants are losing money. 

 Like, lots of money. 

 I began thinking about how complex it must be to run a hospitality group. 

 Between staffing, opening new locations, logistics, operations and a myriad of other factors I‚Äôm probably overlooking. 

 And then finally on top of all that, the most important piece; marketing. 

 You have to deal with all of these annoying logistical issues and even once you solve all of them, you will still fail if you don‚Äôt get people in the doors. 

 That does not sound like a fun time. 

 Let‚Äôs compare this to an online service based business or coaching business. 

 There are two main objectives in each of these. 

 1. Create an attractive, in-demand offer. 

 2. Generate demand. 

 It‚Äôs actually the same process of building a club or restaurant, without the world of complexity attached to it. 

 With an internet business, all you have to do is learn some skills and build the offer. 

 That can take a week. 

 And basically costs nothing. 

 Once the offer is built, you can dedicate the majority of your focus to acquisition. 

 If your content gets attention, or you build a lucrative outbound system, or you can profitably put a dollar into Facebook and get $2 back, scaling becomes easy. 

 You double down on the acquisition system and you make sure nothing breaks on the backend. 

 Next thing you know, you have a $5m/year business that was built off a couple TikTok videos, loom pitches, or cringy ads. 

 Obviously I‚Äôm oversimplifying this a bit, but it really is this simple. 

 You lose when you try to make it more complicated. 

 If you‚Äôre struggling to grow as a service provider or a coach, one of two things are happening. 

 1. You‚Äôre focusing on the wrong things and distracting yourself from the actual needle movers. 

 2. You‚Äôre just really dumb. No offense, but you are cooked. I think McDonalds is hiring though. 

 You might not realize it, but opportunity in the info-product space right now is similar to the way paid ads were 10-15 years ago. 

 I was in diapers back then, but a friend of mine told me he was getting 1 cent cost per click on his ads. 

 1 cent. 

 Meaning, holy fuck, you‚Äôre gonna get rich. 

 But over time, that opportunity diminishes and it gets more expensive. 

 Right now, in 2024 you can whip out your phone and make a 48 second selfie video that millions of people could see. 

 If the content in the video is somewhat useful and you have an offer that correlates with it, you now have a seven figure business. 

 I‚Äôm not exaggerating. 

 Idiots are getting rich. 

 ‚Äã Do you want to join them? ‚Äã 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: Does success come down to luck?
body:
Gooooood morning! 

 I‚Äôm sitting on my balcony and the sun is beaming in my eyes so I‚Äôm squinting at the screen. 

 My neighbors just let out their dogs to take their morning piss on this mat of grass that they‚Äôve been trained to urinate on. 

 They have these two little beige pugs named Ricco and Rocco. 

 Those aren‚Äôt actually their real names but it‚Äôs what I would have named them. 

 I‚Äôm going to steal them one day. 

 Anyway, let‚Äôs talk about how to get lucky. 

 Some people say luck doesn‚Äôt exist. 

 Others believe everyone who‚Äôs successful gets lucky. 

 In my opinion, both of the above statements are true, even though they‚Äôre contradictory. 

 This is called a paradox, in case you slept through that part of English class. 

 I watched a movie last night that had Miles Teller in it and began thinking about how you end up as a world famous actor. 

 Sure, he‚Äôs great at what he does. 

 But so are the tens of thousands of broke actors. 

 There are plenty of people with the same look, talent, and work ethic. 

 Why is he one of few who makes it? 

 Is it luck? 

 No. 

 Well, yes. 

 Well, kind of. 

 If you run a quick Google search on Miles Teller, you‚Äôll see that he made his first feature film in 2010. 

 Three years later, he starred in ‚ÄúThe Spectacular Now‚Äù which put him on the map. 

 And then the film, ‚ÄúWhiplash‚Äù a year later was his big breakthrough. 

 Now he‚Äôs one of the more popular actors and was recently in Top Gun with Tom Cruise. 

 But you don‚Äôt hear about all the projects that flopped. 

 From 2004-2010 he was in a bunch of movies neither of us have ever heard of. 

 Then he had a few ‚Äúbig breaks‚Äù and his life changed forever. 

 This is how success works. 

 The majority of the time that you put in, especially in the beginning, will feel like it‚Äôs all for nothing. 

 You‚Äôll think to yourself, ‚Äúwhy am I even working this hard? Nobody‚Äôs gonna notice me anyway.‚Äù 

 It‚Äôs an uphill battle and you have no idea where the top of the hill is. 

 You just keep climbing and hope that eventually you find it, which isn‚Äôt guaranteed. 

 You could climb for decades and still end up as one of the unknown actors who never found a good role. 

 It‚Äôs a gamble. 

 Maybe you‚Äôll get lucky, maybe you won‚Äôt. 

 However, there are ways that you can increase your chances. 

 Consistency plus iteration creates luck. 

 I think that's the smartest thing I‚Äôve said all year. 

 If you don‚Äôt quit and you continually strive to get better at the craft, you have a chance. 

 Worst case scenario, it‚Äôs likely that your effort will result in an opportunity, even if it‚Äôs not the one you were anticipating. 

 And best case scenario‚Ä¶ 

 ‚Äã Well, the sky's the limit. ‚Äã

 Happy hunting, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Reply if you made it all the way down here :) 

 ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: pain
body:
Up until my junior year of high school, I was dead set on playing college basketball. 

 Being a ‚Äúhooper‚Äù was my entire identity. 

 But over the previous year, some doubt had started to creep in. 

 ‚ÄúMaybe this isn‚Äôt right for me anymore,‚Äù a voice in my head would tell me. 

 I tried to ignore it, but it wouldn‚Äôt go away. 

 When I‚Äôd consider what life would be like if I decided not to play collegiately, it was daunting. 

 All of my friends and family knew me as this basketball guy. 

 It‚Äôs how I viewed myself. 

 How embarrassing would it be to change that? 

 I‚Äôd look like a crazy person. 

 And I had no idea what‚Äôs on the other side. 

 But I couldn‚Äôt shake that feeling in my gut that knew it was time for a different route. 

 In a single moment, I made the decision. 

 I was no longer going to play in college. 

 It was time to let that story go and when I did, I became free. 

 ‚ÄúWalking away from anything you love because it‚Äôs not working for you is the only character building exercise there is. People can't comprehend how much you have to screw yourself over to get self respect.‚Äù - Brute 

 It‚Äôs no secret that change is difficult. 

 Changing your habits is painful. 

 Changing your career path is painful. 

 Changing your negative thought patterns is painful. 

 Because of this, most people elect to endure situations that aren‚Äôt right for them in order to avoid the pain that comes with change. 

 Sure, working a job you hate sucks, but quitting that job to bet on yourself would be temporarily more painful than staying in it. 

 Your willingness to exchange this low level, long term pain for high level, short term pain is what makes you grow. 

 You choose to dig the hole a little deeper. 

 You choose to put yourself in a tough situation. 

 You choose to sacrifice your (illusionary) peace for struggle. 

 And then you‚Äôre free. 

 It‚Äôll be difficult and even after making the decision your ego will try to pull you back into comfort. 

 But if you can withstand that tide, you‚Äôll make it to the other side as a new person. 

 Comfort kills you slowly. Pain kills you instantly. 

 And maybe that‚Äôs what you need. 

 Happy Monday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Join me inside my mastermind if you‚Äôre ready to grow. ‚Äã 

 P.P.S. Watch my new video with 8 figure info-product seller, Tim Luong ‚Äã

subject: when it rains, it pours
body:
Around this time last year, I hit my first $100k month as a growth partner. 

 If you‚Äôre completely new here, here‚Äôs how my business works in a nutshell: 

 I partner with ‚Äúinfluencers" who sell courses (think trading influencer or eCom guru). 

 I help them build a program from scratch or improve their current offer 

 My team and I run all of their operations. 

 From their sales funnels, to email marketing, automations, scripting videos, sales team, etc. 

 My client's job is to make content. 

 My job is to help them get the people who watch their content to buy their course. 

 Make sense? 

 I hope so, because I just explained that to you as if you‚Äôre an autistic monkey. 

 Anyway, about 2 years ago, I was stuck between $10-20k per month. 

 It was frustrating seeing people who I deemed incompetent make way more money than me. 

 I was working really hard but just couldn‚Äôt get through that ceiling. 

 And then, something changed. 

 I hit $25k. 

 Then $30k the next month. 

 Then $35k. 

 $50k. 

 I hovered around $60k-80k for a bit. 

 And then, I finally hit $100k. 

 It was all because of one thing: 

 Positioning. 

 When I was stuck under $20k/month, I had no leverage. 

 I would take any opportunity I could get. 

 I was writing a ton of copy, building funnels, managing CRMs, and it all felt discombobulated. 

 Every client I got basically felt like I had a boss telling me what to do. 

 But then, I got one really good win. 

 I helped a client go from $30k/month to $350k per month in 2 months. 

 A couple months later we were past $500k/month. 

 Not only did that result in a multiple 5 figure rev share for me, but it put me on the map. 

 It changed the way I was perceived by others because I could flex that case study. 

 And it changed the way I perceived myself because I saw my actions result in such a drastic impact. 

 That singular win is all it took to give me endless opportunities, and the conviction I needed to be able to handle them. 

 If you‚Äôre trying to build a copywriting or growth partner business right now, keep this in mind. 

 Just get one fat W, and the floodgates will open my friend. 

 Extrapolate this to any life pursuit you‚Äôre stagnating in. 

 When it rains, it pours. 

 ‚Äã Come check out Artisan Lab if you want to learn from me directly. ‚Äã 

 Later, 

 Ben

subject: famous and broke
body:
I officially know what it would feel like to be a broke influencer. 

 You may have seen some of the skits I‚Äôve been posting on Tik Tok as they‚Äôve gotten over 15m views in the last 30 days. 

 It‚Äôs wild. 

 As cool as it is, it offers me almost no monetary benefit (at least for now). 

 I always wondered how ‚Äòmicro-influencers‚Äô made their money and I now understand that most don‚Äôt. 

 Sure I‚Äôve gained some followers, gotten a bunch of DM‚Äôs and have been recognized in public a bit more. 

 But I‚Äôve made $0.00 from it. 

 Obviously, it‚Äôs a different story once you reach real fame and can make solid money from brand deals. 

 However, if you want to monetize your personal brand, you‚Äôre better off making niche educational content and building an audience of a few thousand people. 

 Then you can sell coaching and happily make millions without having to rely on brand deals. 

 On a similar topic, I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about the intersection between comedy and philosophy. 

 The funniest people are often the most observant. 

 They can turn a niche observation into a joke. 

 They can articulate the thing everyone is thinking, but can‚Äôt express. 

 They can use analogies to connect two seemingly unconnected ideas. 

 Similarly, the most profound insights are often gained from uniquely personal experiences. 

 The lesson is articulated in a way that is so personal, that it becomes universal. 

 Again, it‚Äôs the thing that everyone thinks but no one says. 

 Ironically, I don‚Äôt really have a lesson for this email. 

 These are just some insights I‚Äôve gained as of late and figured I‚Äôd share because what else is there to do other than attempt to entertain and educate strangers on the internet? 

 Anyway, let‚Äôs have a good week. 

 Focus on the needle movers and stop stressing over nothing, okay? 

 Progress is simple, you just have to get out of your own way sometimes. 

 Happy Monday, join me in my mastermind if you want to get rich selling info. ‚Äã 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben

subject: No business model will make you rich
body:
Let‚Äôs talk about money. 

 When you‚Äôre a beginner, you typically think you need to find the right business model. 

 In reality, it‚Äôs not the label that‚Äôs important. 

 Whether you‚Äôre a copywriter, IPGA, IPO, growth operator, growth partner, etc. 

 All of these terms are different ways to say the same thing. 

 You offer ‚Äòdone for you‚Äô services to online businesses. 

 This is important to understand because a business model doesn‚Äôt make you money, your skillset does. 

 People like me, Pierre Khoury, and others who‚Äôve had success in this space have been able to do so because we can offer a multitude of services and truly increase revenue. 

 It‚Äôs definitely NOT because of a fancy label we placed on our services. 

 This brings me to my second point, which is that the market decides your niche. 

 In my business, our biggest wins have come through webinars. 

 It‚Äôs the main reason I‚Äôve gotten to 6 figure months. 

 But that happened on accident. 

 We tested a webinar for a client and it worked. 

 We figured we‚Äôd try it out for other clients and it kept working. 

 That doesn‚Äôt mean that your business has to work the same way as mine. 

 Your big wins could come through VSLs. 

 Or you could figure out that you‚Äôre really good at scripting YT videos or short form content. 

 Or maybe you end up specializing in email automations. 

 My point here is that you‚Äôre a marketer, not a robot. 

 If you label yourself as a growth operator and you‚Äôll only work with creators who have an audience but don‚Äôt have an offer yet, your TAM (total addressable market) is limited. 

 But if you drop the label and think of yourself as a marketer, you can fit into different roles. 

 That‚Äôs how you get your foot in the door with a client (solve one niche problem they‚Äôre facing) and then you start to take over other pieces of their business. 

 Get one big win, and you have a solidified offer. 

 This doesn‚Äôt happen overnight, but it‚Äôs the best way to do it if you wanna work with coaches and course creators. 

 Learn some skills, pitch a bunch of shit, see what works, double down. 

 Now you‚Äôre rich. You‚Äôre welcome. 

 ‚Äã Go here if you want my help in growing your info-product agency or coaching business. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: An email about nothing
body:
Good morning. 

 I‚Äôm sitting on my balcony with an iced latte and a dream. 

 I don‚Äôt know what the dream is, but I thought that sounded cool. 

 It‚Äôs September 5, 2024 which means I turn 24 in 17 days. 

 Does that mean I‚Äôm‚Ä¶ old? Do I need to start taking viagra? Am I developing cataracts? 

 Oh no. 

 I‚Äôm going to New York with my friends Jimmy and Mason today. 

 We have quite the weekend planned, but if I told you about it, I‚Äôd have to kill you. 

 I don‚Äôt think I could ever live in NY. 

 I have one major flaw and it‚Äôs that I‚Äôm geographically challenged. 

 I don‚Äôt know what body of water I‚Äôm looking at off my balcony right now. 

 I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm facing east, west, north, south, or upside down. 

 I don‚Äôt know how to get nearly anywhere without a GPS. 

 Miami is relatively small and I have a hard enough time navigating it. 

 I can‚Äôt imagine how lost I‚Äôd be in New York. 

 Plus I‚Äôd have a bunch of angry neurotic people yelling at me. 

 Speaking of, the other day I watched a clip of Jerry Seinfeld and Larry David. 

 They were talking about Seinfeld, and how it was ‚Äúa show about nothing.‚Äù 

 This is an email about nothing. 

 Well actually, I guess I do have something to tell you: 

 Sorry. 

 I‚Äôve been slacking on Youtube. 

 I was growing really quickly at first, then I hit a plateau, and got too caught up in the numbers. 

 My focus went from ‚Äúhow can I make content that I enjoy?‚Äù 

 To ‚Äúhow can I hook these stupid little lizard brained monkeys into watching more of my video so the algorithm pushes it?‚Äù 

 And that took the fun out of it. 

 I‚Äôm gonna get back on there and stop worrying about the metrics, I promise. 

 But it might be a few days because there‚Äôs a solid chance I get lost in New York. 

 Anyway, here‚Äôs my last thought for you today: 

 You can always find a reason to stress when you tie your sense of self to your accomplishments. 

 In that sense, you‚Äôll never be complete. 

 Sure, this can be a way to motivate yourself but it also stains every experience with jaded glasses. 

 You‚Äôll be in the club in New York with a dozen models around you and your favorite song playing as you dance with your best friends. 

 But you won‚Äôt be all the way there. 

 There will be a part of you that‚Äôs anxious, worrying about how you don‚Äôt have $100m yet. 

 Instead, learn to accept what is. 

 You‚Äôre on your journey and that‚Äôs that. 

 Stressing doesn‚Äôt fix anything, so you might as well be where you are. 

 Congrats. You‚Äôve completed this email about nothing. 

 Let me know if you made it all the way down here. 

 See you in NY, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Join my mastermind here. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã
