subject: How to write an email
body:
I‚Äôm on the run. 

 I just let housekeeping into my hotel room and am now homeless for the next 30 minutes. 

 Should I join the crackheads that roam the streets of NYC? 

 Actually, I have a better idea. 

 The other day, someone asked me about my process for writing copy. 

 So this is an email about how to write an email. 

 If you‚Äôve been on this list for a while, you know that my style is a bit more casual than your average newsletter. 

 Sometimes I ramble about random thoughts, other times I hash out an idea or concept, and every now and then I‚Äôll send you a harder pitch for Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 No matter what, I have one goal in every line of copy I write. 

 And it‚Äôs to get you to read the next line. 

 Typically I start this by bringing you into my world. 

 This is where I set the scene. 

 I‚Äôll tell you where I am, what kind of state I‚Äôm in, and try to make you feel like you‚Äôre right here with me. 

 It‚Äôs personal and casual style. 

 My best emails seem to be when I describe an idea in a way that‚Äôs so detailed to where you feel like I‚Äôm articulating your own thoughts. 

 It creates this feeling where we‚Äôre solving a problem together. 

 Me and you against the world, baby. 

 This is where I think I have a bit of an edge on your average copywriter. 

 Most end up talking down to their audience. 

 They put themselves on this authoritative pedestal, and are so obsessed with ‚Äúgiving value‚Äù that it eradicates the value. 

 Because people hate being told what to do for no reason. 

 If you tell someone why they should live a certain way or think a certain way, without giving them context as to how you arrived at that conclusion, you‚Äôre just preaching. 

 It‚Äôs the personal aspect and storytelling that makes the lessons hit. 

 If I tell you a story about how I overcame a fear and then connect the dots for you as to how you can do the same in your own life, that‚Äôs when it resonates. 

 Versus if I were to impose my own beliefs on you without providing any personal anecdotes, you‚Äôd have stopped reading by now. 

 You read my emails because I talk directly to you. 

 I don‚Äôt think about ‚Äúproviding value‚Äù because I know that if my email is personal enough, it becomes valuable. 

 Is this making sense? 

 I hope so. 

 I‚Äôm dying for a bacon egg and cheese here so I have to run, but the last thing I‚Äôll leave you with is this: 

 You just have to trust yourself. 

 I often start these emails without any idea of what I‚Äôm going to say. 

 But I know that if I just begin writing, my subconscious brain starts to work for me. 

 It feeds me an analogy or story that I can use to articulate my point. 

 And by the time I get to the end, it ends up being pretty coherent (most of the time). 

 Ok I‚Äôm starving. 

 Hope you enjoyed my email about emails, join me in the Artisan Lab if you wanna learn more from me. ‚Äã

 Love you, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: F*** the audience
body:
Gooooood morning, {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 I got back from New York last night, ready to lock back in and make some money. 

 Hope you‚Äôre doing the same. 

 As I sit here pondering what to write to you about, I found myself thinking, ‚Äúwhat will my audience get value from?‚Äù 

 This is a really stupid question. 

 I could sit here and try to guess what you would find valuable. 

 I could think of an angle or analogy to drive my point home. 

 And then I could pitch you my mastermind and a handful of you would apply. 

 It works, but it lacks some personality. 

 You want to know the lessons that seem to hit the hardest? 

 They‚Äôre the ones where I don‚Äôt give a fuck about you. 

 I don‚Äôt try to think of what you need to hear. 

 I don‚Äôt tailor my message to hook you in or get you to click a link. 

 And the word ‚Äúvalue‚Äù doesn‚Äôt cross my mind. 

 Instead, I write about what I want to write about. 

 Typically it‚Äôll be a problem I‚Äôm overcoming, a recent observation, or something else that‚Äôs very personal to me. 

 I can articulate the idea with so much detail, because I don‚Äôt have to imagine what it would be like. 

 I‚Äôm in my own shoes. 

 Couple that with the fact that I‚Äôm not trying to appease the audience (you), and that‚Äôs what makes you feel like I understand you. 

 It‚Äôs like when you‚Äôre trying to win over a girl. 

 When you‚Äôre an idiot, you think ‚Äúoh, if I just agree with everything she says and try to say all the right things back to her, she‚Äôll like me.‚Äù 

 Then you learn that‚Äôs not a recipe for success. 

 You‚Äôre not expressing yourself freely. 

 You‚Äôre uncomfortable. 

 You‚Äôre trying to gain something from her, and you both subconsciously know that. 

 Plus it's exhausting. 

 But what happens when you let go? 

 When you stop caring about winning someone‚Äôs approval, you take back the wheel. 

 You make the jokes you want to make. 

 You say the thing that everyone else is thinking but too nervous to say. 

 You‚Äôre comfortably, freely, you. 

 And that‚Äôs the most attractive state you can be in. 

 Pure indifference because you are who you are. 

 Whether you‚Äôre speaking to an audience or courting your future ex baby mama. 

 Think less about what they want and more about what you want. 

 It sounds counterintuitive, but it‚Äôs actually a much more selfless act than the alternative. 

 Hope you enjoyed this one. 

 ‚Äã Hop in here if you wanna get rich selling info. ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Become a Swiss army knife marketer
body:
Once upon a time, you could get away with being a one trick pony. 

 You could go to a business, pitch them a singular service, and close them. 

 When I started out, that‚Äôs what I did. 

 I‚Äôd pitch course sellers on building them a new funnel. 

 This worked to get my first few clients. 

 But I quickly learned that when you solve one problem, it exposes three more. 

 I could build the best funnel in the world but if traffic was low or if their emails sucked, it wouldn‚Äôt make a difference. 

 So, I started to take over more pieces of my clients' businesses. 

 Because I understood copywriting, it was easy. 

 I began writing their emails, scripting their VSLs, scripting ads, etc. 

 And then on the operations side, I built automations, managed their systems, and set up CRMs. 

 I know this sounds like a lot, but it‚Äôs actually quite simple. 

 Once you learn the fundamentals of direct response marketing, you can add new skills to your toolbox in a couple hours. 

 It‚Äôs exactly what I did and next thing you know, I had clients paying me anywhere from $10k-$40k per month each. 

 The reason this model works is because it turns you into a Swiss army knife. 

 You can work with just about anyone, because you have a multitude of skills. 

 If they already have an email copywriter, you can build them a new funnel. 

 If they already have a funnel builder, you can write them a new VSL or script short form content. 

 If they‚Äôre just starting out, you can help them build from scratch. 

 This is actually how one of my biggest wins happened. 

 I helped an offer go from zero to $600k per month and that was all the social proof I ever needed. 

 The opportunities in the info-product space are endless. 

 You just have to know where to look and be equipped to handle it. 

 And that's what you'll learn inside of my small group coaching program, The Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 Check out some recent wins: 

 ‚Äã ‚Äã Odds are these guys are no different from you. 

 They've just taken the time to becoming a Swiss army knife and are reaping the rewards 

 ‚Äã Go here to join the winning team. ‚Äã

 Or be poor and sad. 

 Talk tm, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: 3 steps to hit $30k months
body:
Gm {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 The other day I figured out that 15 minute walks in the morning are the perfect distance. 

 If the walk is too long, it makes me feel like I‚Äôm wasting time. 

 If it‚Äôs too short, I‚Äôm too restless to sit at my desk. 

 Anyway, today I want to tell you how to get rich. 

 About two years ago, I hit my first $30k month. 

 I had no team members so it was pure profit. 

 For the following six months, my income fluctuated between $30-50k per month. 

 This was one of my favorite times in running my info-product agency. 

 The work was pretty simple because I was mostly just building funnels and managing email marketing. 

 And on my perfect 15 minute walk this morning, I realized this is the perfect way for anyone to start. 

 So if you‚Äôre towards the beginning of your journey, here‚Äôs my braindead simple process for you to get to $10k-30k/month ASAP: 

 1. Learn copywriting 

 Read books, watch Youtube videos, and start writing sample copy. 

 You can improve quickly, you just have to get reps. 

 Writing on Twitter or pretending you have your own email list can also be helpful. 

 Study good copy and your subconscious will recognize patterns. 

 But DO NOT overthink this. 

 You don‚Äôt have to be the best writer in the world, you just have to be competent. 

 2. Start outreach 

 Start before you feel 100% ready, as most learning is done on the fly. 

 Go through social media, find people that are selling coaching and pitch them. 

 Just don‚Äôt be an idiot and copy what everyone else tells you to do. 

 This part is a grind but the bar is low because everyone else is dumb. 

 If you send a good pitch, you have a chance. 

 I‚Äôve literally sent one outbound pitch this entire year and it landed me a 5 figure deal. 

 3. Just say yes 

 If you understand copywriting, learning other skills is easy. 

 I could teach you how to write a VSL in 10 minutes. 

 Same with managing CRMs, automations, and literally any other relevant skill. 

 Just because you haven‚Äôt done something before doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre not one Google search away. 

 If you get an opportunity, take it. 

 That‚Äôs literally how I learned everything. 

 A client would come to me with a need, I‚Äôd say ‚Äúyes I can do that‚Äù and boom, I figured it out. 

 It‚Äôs really that simple. 

 Just don‚Äôt get distracted along the way. 

 ‚Äã If you want my personal coaching in your own journey to wealth, go here. ‚Äã

 Deuces, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: why fake urgency is ethical
body:
I have a much needed haircut in 20 minutes so I have to type fast. 

 Which is a perfect segue for today's lesson: 

 Urgency. 

 If you want people to buy your stuff, you need to provide a reason why now is the right time.
You see marketing ploys that do this regularly. 

 Discounts, bonuses, limited time offers, scarcity, and when all else fails‚Ä¶ 

 Tell your audience that the opportunity is fleeting and if they hesitate they‚Äôll be a matrix slave forever. 

 The truth is, most urgency is a facade. 

 A copywriter came up with an angle and made it sound good. 

 If it‚Äôs effective, it gets the people who were on the fence to take action. 

 Now I‚Äôm not saying that all angles or tactics are lies. 

 But rather, in reality, there is no reason to do anything urgently. 

 You could wait till tomorrow, three weeks from now, 6 months from now, or even 10 years. 

 There is always a reason why now is not the right time. 

 And that‚Äôs why urgency in marketing is important. 

 You‚Äôre fighting the imaginary demons in your audience's head. 

 Let‚Äôs say you want to change your life and start a business. 

 You go back and forth between business models. 

 You convince yourself you need to learn more and you hesitate to take any action. 

 You tell yourself that once XYZ happens, you‚Äôll be in a better position to attack it with full force. 

 I‚Äôve been there. 

 When I was in college, I got a tattoo on my left forearm that says ‚Äúif not now, when?‚Äù 

 Because I understood that nothing happens until I make it happen and the perfect opportunity I was waiting for doesn‚Äôt exist. 

 It will never exist. 

 And until you beat this into your head, you will wait. 

 You will find a new reason why you can‚Äôt do what you want, live how you want, and be who you want. 

 Now will never be the ‚Äúright‚Äù time, but it will always be the only time. 

 Sure new opportunities may be around forever. 

 The ‚Äòlimited spots‚Äô angle might be a gimmick. 

 The discount will probably reactivate in a month or two. 

 And the special bonuses might be something everyone gets anyway. 

 But you and I both know there‚Äôs no perfect time to start anything. 

 In fact, most of the decisions I‚Äôve made that resulted in the most growth were completely impulsive and somewhat manic. 

 I got tired of waiting and followed an inkling in my gut. 

 ‚Äã Maybe it‚Äôs time for you to do the same. ‚Äã 

 Boom. 

 That‚Äôs how urgency is created. 

 Love you, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: How to close $10k/month clients
body:
I just sat in front of the camera for 30 minutes trying to make a Youtube video. 

 Typically once I get the camera out and start talking, coherent sentences start to come out. 

 But today, that didn‚Äôt happen. 

 I stumbled over my words. 

 I‚Äôd start talking for a minute and then lose my train of thought. 

 And eventually I was ready to throw my camera off the balcony. 

 So, I quit. 

 Very inspirational, I know. 

 Instead, I‚Äôll write to you about what I was attempting to say in the video. 

 Let‚Äôs talk about how to get good clients that will pay you lots of money on rev shares. 

 This is a code that once you crack, getting past $50k or even $100k per month becomes easy. 

 But before you get to this stage, you have to go through the trenches. 

 At first, you‚Äôre limited to the bottom of the barrel. 

 Those clients who want to negotiate on price or refuse to pay any money up front. 

 I had my fair share of these, but I made the most of them. 

 I still went above and beyond, using it as an opportunity to sharpen my skills and build case studies. 

 That was crucial. 

 It put me in a position where I had some results to show for, which gave me leverage to get rev shares. 

 The first lucrative deal I got was with a client who I had on a $3k retainer just for email. 

 I proposed a webinar funnel to him and asked for 10% of the rev we generate from that funnel. 

 He agreed. 

 The next month he paid me $10k and my biggest month with him was $18k. 

 That was a lightbulb moment. 

 I figured if I could do that, I could get even bigger and better clients on rev shares. 

 I did, and now I‚Äôve been paid up to $50k in a month from single clients. 

 If you want to scale an info-product agency, this is how it‚Äôs done. 

 Grind outreach until you get some shitty clients. 

 Do everything in your power to get results for them (even if you‚Äôre underpaid). 

 Use that as leverage to get rev share deals with good clients. 

 Next thing you know, you‚Äôll make an average annual salary from one client. 

 Boom. 

 ‚Äã Go here if you want me to show you exactly how it‚Äôs done. ‚Äã 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Stop trying to get rev shares
body:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}, let‚Äôs talk business. 

 I have a secret to tell you. 

 It‚Äôs a secret that may alter your current view of the info-product space. 

 And it especially applies to you if you‚Äôre trying to get clients. 

 Here it is: 

 It is extremely unlikely that you close a good client on a rev share. 

 This notion that the best way to work with creators is to get them on a 30-50% rev share and run their entire backend is a pipedream. 

 Almost no good potential client would agree to that. 

 Plus most of the good ones are already working with someone like me, Pierre, Bo, one of my students, or they have an in-house team. 

 But that doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre cooked. 

 It means you have to work your way up to rev shares. 

 The way to do this is to find small gaps in info-product businesses instead of going for the whole pie. 

 Think of yourself as a marketer, not a growth operator. 

 Your goal is to solve one problem, earn trust, and then solve other problems. 

 That‚Äôs how you eventually end up on a rev share where you can make $10k+ from a single client. 

 But that doesn‚Äôt happen overnight, it happens when you ‚Äúearn your stripes.‚Äù 

 If I started all over, there are three services I‚Äôd mainly be pitching right now: 

 1. Email copywriting 

 2. VSL scripting and funnel build 

 3. Short form scripts 

 Those are all easy to learn and they get your foot in the door. 

 You can get an upfront fee or a retainer to start. 

 Once that goes well, you then start to offer other services and take over more elements to your clients business. 

 Two years ago, I hit my first $25k month doing exactly this. 

 I didn‚Äôt have any big ‚Äúwhale" clients. 

 It consisted of a few email retainers, and I closed a couple clients that needed new VSL funnels. 

 I went above and beyond for my clients, and that‚Äôs how I eventually got rev shares. 

 The point I‚Äôm trying to make here is this: 

 Do not put yourself in a box. 

 Pitch email retainers, VSLs, scripts, funnels, etc. 

 Once you get some experience, you'll have more leverage. 

 That's when you can get rev shares. 

 By then you'll have results to show for, and actually become a skilled marketer. 

 Skills last forever, ‚Äúbusiness models‚Äù do not. 

 ‚Äã Join me over here if you‚Äôre ready to build your Info-product agency. ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: you asked, i answered
body:
I did a Q&A yesterday on new business Instagram (follow here). 

 There were too many questions to get through all of them on IG, so I‚Äôll be answering more here. 

 Let‚Äôs get it: 

 What‚Äôs something about you that hasn‚Äôt changed after being financially free? 

 Nothing. 

 Money doesn‚Äôt change you, it serves as a tool that allows you to be more of who you already were. 

 I‚Äôve become more comfortable expressing my true self as I‚Äôve had financial success. 

 It was always there, I just didn‚Äôt have the confidence to show it until I proved to myself that I could design my life however I wanted. 

 Did your college friends get what you were doing at the time you dropped out? 

 Sort of. 

 They didn‚Äôt know all the details, but they knew I was running some form of marketing business. 

 Not to throw shade at all, but I was actually surprised how few of them were curious enough to ask. 

 Once they graduated and started normal jobs, more have reached out asking for info. 

 Do you do low and high ticket offers with your clients that make over $100k/month? 

 Almost all high ticket offers. 

 In 95% of cases, having a low ticket offer is quite dumb. 

 Only caveats are when its purpose is to liquidate ad spend, the personal brand has a huge audience, or the offer doesn‚Äôt have a direct ROI (teaching a hobby). 

 How do you lock in and work when you don‚Äôt feel like it? 

 I‚Äôve always been horrible at doing things I don‚Äôt want to do. 

 But my biggest leaps in business have been made when I can get over that initial resistance. 

 Starting anything from scratch is difficult. 

 That‚Äôs natural. If you expect it to be easy, you‚Äôll quit. 

 But on the other side of resistance, you start moving with the tide. 

 The work starts to feel like peace and you develop this love for progress. 

 It‚Äôs one of the most beautiful emotional states that you can access in life. 

 But you have to earn it by getting over that resistance in the beginning. 

 So either do the work, or be a pussy forever lol. 

 Ok last one - there were a bunch of questions about doing outreach. 

 And this is the problem. 

 You‚Äôre looking for an ‚Äúoutreach system.‚Äù 

 This is why every pitch I see absolutely sucks. 

 You‚Äôre trying to rush the process as if you‚Äôre attempting to get a girl to go home with you 3 minutes into a date. 

 It‚Äôs creepy and you didn‚Äôt demonstrate any value or status. 

 Why would someone trust you? 

 The only outreach tip you‚Äôll ever need is to use your brain. 

 If you‚Äôre competent, you‚Äôll figure out a way to get in touch with people. 

 If you‚Äôre not, well someones gotta flip the burgers. 

 I know that‚Äôs a bit harsh but it‚Äôs the truth. 

 Thanks again for all the questions, sorry if I didn‚Äôt get to yours. 

 ‚Äã Anyway, check out this new interview I did with Sean, one of my mastermind members. ‚Äã 

 He‚Äôs making $30k/mo working with some big names like Charlie Morgan and Joel Kaplan. 

 See you over there, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: How to live by your own rules
body:
I turned 24 yesterday and now people are calling me ‚ÄúUnc.‚Äù 

 Please stop. 

 Unc status doesn‚Äôt happen until 27 at the earliest. 

 Thank you to everyone who wished me a happy birthday. 

 However, I do have a problem with some of you. 

 You know how you‚Äôll have a cousin or old friend that you only text on birthdays? 

 The text chain will be like: 

 ‚ÄúHappy birthday {{ subscriber.first_name }}!‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúThank you!‚Äù 

 *year passes* 

 ‚ÄúHBD! Hope you‚Äôre doing well!‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúYou too, {{ subscriber.first_name }}!‚Äù 

 Yeah, that shit needs to stop. 

 If you go two years where your texts with someone only consist of birthday wishes, lets just all agree to end it there. 

 Ok? 

 Good. 

 This sounds like a Seinfeld bit. 

 Anyway, I‚Äôve now written 120 words without saying anything of value. 

 The biggest lesson I internalized in my 23rd year of life is that there is no rulebook. 

 You can truly live however you want. 

 Which is freeing, yet terrifying. 

 I don‚Äôt think most people want to accept that truth. 

 Because then, you become the author. 

 You have to take everything into your own hands, and make your own rules. 

 It‚Äôs easier to follow the standard of those around you. 

 I ‚Äòside quested‚Äô a lot over the past 12 months. 

 I started hobbies and pursuits that didn‚Äôt impact the number in my bank account, but felt right. 

 In these quests, I learned a lot about myself and became more comfortable showing who I am. 

 Although this didn‚Äôt push me ahead in this imaginary game we‚Äôre all playing, it made me feel like I‚Äôm winning. 

 It‚Äôs my own game, with my own rules and scoreboard. 

 I learned that I could decide what I wanted and go get it. 

 There‚Äôve been challenges, twists, turns, and everything in between. 

 It‚Äôs been a fun year, but not an easy one ‚Äì although it may look that way on social media. 

 But maybe that‚Äôs the goal? 

 Life will always come with roadblocks and hurdles, but as long as they are conducive to a mission that is your own, that‚Äôs okay. 

 You don‚Äôt want to lose yourself fighting someone else‚Äôs battle. 

 As Dostoevsky said, ‚ÄúYour worst sin is that you have destroyed and betrayed yourself for nothing.‚Äù 

 You have to continuously and intentionally grab life by the balls. 

 Design the reality you want. 

 And the hardships that come with it are building you into the character who is capable of accepting it. 

 ‚Äã Just keep moving, ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: The 2 elements of success
body:
Good morning, {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 You know, success is really simple. 

 There are only two things you actually need. 

 Everything else is just noise. 

 The first thing is you have to be smart‚Ä¶ enough. 

 Being smart enough doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre wicked smart. 

 It means you can walk and talk at the same time. 

 It means you can figure out how to use Google when you don‚Äôt have an answer. 

 It means you can consume simple information and understand it. 

 90% of people I meet are smart enough. 

 The problem is most people doubt themselves. 

 They feel unprepared to start. 

 They over contemplate every potential action. 

 They think success is supposed to be difficult, so they avoid taking the obvious actions that will push them towards their goals. 

 So sure, you have to be smart enough ‚Äì but you also have to be dumb enough to trust yourself. 

 The second element of success is this: 

 You have to consistently work. 

 Notice how I didn‚Äôt say work hard. 

 But literally just work consistently. 

 Genuinely, making your first $10k online isn‚Äôt difficult. 

 Even making $100k in a month isn‚Äôt difficult once you‚Äôre in the right position. 

 It‚Äôs just a battle of distractions. 

 Can you consistently take one or two actions daily over an extended period of time? 

 Or will you get distracted, discouraged, or lose ‚Äòmotivation‚Äô and tell yourself you need to find something you‚Äôre more passionate about? 

 If you can resist the latter, eventually you win. 

 And this doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre going ‚Äúballs the wall‚Äù working 16 hour days. 

 But rather that you‚Äôve identified your highest ROI tasks and committed to them. 

 For example, say you want to build an info-product agency. 

 Once you learn enough about copywriting and marketing (which can take a week or two), there‚Äôs one main thing you should do every day‚Ä¶ 

 Outreach. 

 That‚Äôs it. 

 If you send pitches daily and make a concerted effort to improve your pitches, you will get a client. 

 You don‚Äôt know when, but it will happen. 

 You just have to work consistently. 

 And if you‚Äôre smart enough to understand this email, you‚Äôre good. 

 Now, you just have to be dumb enough to get out of your own way when you want to perfect every little detail instead of taking action. 

 ‚Äã You ready to get rich now? ‚Äã

 Godspeed, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you‚Äôre a complete newbie to online business, I have something exciting coming for you. 

 If you hit ‚Äòreply‚Äô and say the word ‚Äúinfo‚Äù there‚Äôs a good chance I‚Äôll tell you about it tomorrow. 

 Hint ‚Äì Pierre Khoury and I have been working on‚Ä¶ a powerpoint presentation ;) 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: Success is an accident
body:
‚ÄúYour success is largely dependent on your ability to shut out the voice that tries to talk you out of action. There will always be reasons to go back to the drawing board. But it‚Äôs impossible to intellectualize your way to a goal. Sometimes you just have to jump.‚Äù - Ben Bader 

 Yes, I just quoted myself. 

 Because there‚Äôs one thing I want to drill into your head on this beautiful Friday: 

 YOU WILL NEVER BE READY. 

 You‚Äôll never be ready to start a business. 

 You‚Äôll never be ready to take up a new hobby. 

 You‚Äôll never be ready to get into a relationship. 

 Please discard the idea that one day all of the stars will align and you‚Äôll end up with the perfect opportunity to start something new. 

 Progress doesn‚Äôt work like that. 

 Almost all of my best opportunities have felt like accidents. 

 When I first started making some money, I was doing freelance videography. 

 That led me into the agency world. 

 I then started a lead gen agency for basketball trainers. 

 That led me into the info-product space. 

 By then, I‚Äôd started posting on Twitter and built connections. 

 Those connections ended up getting me clients. 

 I didn‚Äôt plan any of this. It‚Äôd be impossible to do so. 

 But throughout that time, I accumulated assets. 

 I became a skilled marketer. 

 My network grew. 

 My personal brand became more prevalent. 

 Action created the perfect storm. 

 I didn‚Äôt wait for it. 

 But before that, I wasted so much time trying to plan the perfect route. 

 It‚Äôs a fool's game. 

 If you resonate with what I‚Äôm saying and you find yourself looking for the perfect business model or waiting for some magical moment to start, I empathize with you. 

 I wanted to know exactly how it‚Äôd all work out before I started. 

 I‚Äôd sit at my desk mapping out the exact steps I‚Äôd take to hit $10k months. 

 I‚Äôd bounce from one project to the next telling myself that I just needed the right vehicle. 

 But eventually I realized that intellectualization is NOT a substitute for action. 

 It‚Äôs a way to make yourself feel productive without being productive. 

 And it won‚Äôt get you any closer to where you want to be. 

 Just jump and trust that you‚Äôll grow your wings on the way down. 

 Are we clear? 

 I hope so. 

 ‚Äã If you want to take that first step towards action, this can help you. ‚Äã 

 Have a good weekend, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: How to avoid a miserable life
body:
It‚Äôs Monday. 

 Because of this, I feel an added pressure to be productive. 

 But before I start rambling, I need something from you. 

 If you‚Äôre not signed up for my free class this Thursday, you either don‚Äôt like money or your thumbs don‚Äôt work properly. 

 ‚Äã Use your thumb to click this and go save your spot now. ‚Äã

 It‚Äôll be a full masterclass on copywriting, launching offers, getting clients, etc. 

 Be there, or be poor. 

 Anyway, let's talk about ‚Äúthe flinch.‚Äù 

 This is something you need to avoid at all costs. 

 It will keep you on the sidelines forever. 

 Your exuberant spirit will be suppressed and depleted. 

 And no matter what you do, you‚Äôll always have this lingering anxiety in the back of your head. 

 It‚Äôll take you out of the present moment and taint everything you experience. 

 Unless‚Ä¶ 

 You get over it. 

 Here‚Äôs how: 

 When you start something new or make a big change, you‚Äôll reach a point where you want to hit the brakes. 

 This is where your mind starts to reason with you. 

 You‚Äôll begin talking yourself out of taking action and use ‚Äú intuition‚Äù as the scapegoat. 

 ‚ÄúHey I know I said I was gonna commit to this new endeavor but now that we‚Äôre here, it doesn‚Äôt feel right.‚Äù 

 Bullshit. 

 That‚Äôs not your intuition telling you there's a better route for you. 

 It‚Äôs your ego trying to protect itself. 

 Change is scary and there‚Äôs a part of you that will do everything in its power to resist change. 

 This is where most people flinch. 

 They go back to the drawing board. 

 They look for a different solution. 

 They blame their lack of progress on external factors. 

 But what happens if you get over the flinch? 

 You stand there calmly, as the pocket collapses around you, resisting the urge to cower. 

 You see a receiver downfield and let go of the ball. 

 For the first time in your life, you let it fly. 

 Maybe it gets caught for a touchdown. 

 Or maybe it gets intercepted. 

 But guess what? 

 You‚Äôve now accessed one of the most beautiful games life has to offer‚Ä¶ 

 You got off the sidelines and you‚Äôre in the arena. 

 And you‚Äôre finally taking shots that can lead you to success. 

 Now as long as you stay there, one of them will eventually hit. 

 Your receiver will catch the ball and you‚Äôll hit you‚Äôll dance together in the endzone. 

 It‚Äôll happen eventually, IF you start firing. 

 ‚Äã It all starts by getting over the flinch. ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: 3 ways to be a better communicator
body:
If there‚Äôs one skill that leads to success in nearly domain, it‚Äôs this: 

 The ability to communicate. 

 It impacts your dating life, friendships, content, sales, and just about any other human interaction you have. 

 Over the past two years, I‚Äôve become a much more effective communicator. 

 I used to be timid. 

 You could hear a lack of confidence in my voice. 

 I‚Äôd overthink nearly every word that came out of my mouth in an attempt to present myself as someone I wasn‚Äôt. 

 This is how most people end up living their entire lives. 

 It‚Äôs rare to meet someone who is articulate and thoughtful. 

 Like anything, you won‚Äôt get better at communicating with others unless you get a lot of reps. 

 And that doesn‚Äôt include the pre-programmed responses that are embedded into your head when people ask about your day. 

 In my experience, there are three ways to improve your communication skills. 

 1. Writing 

 2. Making video content 

 3. ‚ÄúHigh pressure‚Äù interactions like a sales call or date 

 Take a second and ask yourself when was the last time you did any of the three things above. 

 And if it was recent, are you getting reps daily? 

 If not, that needs to change. 

 Consider that last interaction you had with someone who you‚Äôd deem a good communicator. 

 How was their energy? 

 Did they seem content in the life they‚Äôre living? 

 Did you feel good around them? 

 Odds are, that conversation was a breath of fresh air. 

 And this is the reason I‚Äôm telling you all of this. 

 To get anything you want in life, you need to demonstrate your value. 

 If you can‚Äôt do that, it doesn't matter how smart or kind you are. 

 It‚Äôs like being a basketball player who‚Äôs incredibly skilled but doesn‚Äôt perform well in real games. 

 All of the work is eradicated by the fact that it isn‚Äôt presented when it matters. 

 Don‚Äôt let that be you‚Ä¶ 

 ‚Äã He who communicates most effectively, wins. ‚Äã

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: How to justify your spending problem
body:
Hey, 

 This is my first email since last Thursday's free class. 

 If you were there, I hope you enjoyed it and learned a lot. 

 If you weren‚Äôt, sorry for your loss. 

 Before I get into todays email, quick heads up: 

 The price of Artisan Lab is increasing in a few days. 

 We‚Äôve got some absolute studs in there who are crushing. 

 Kidous closed a $6k retainer plus 10% rev share. 

 ‚Äã Otavio hit his first $50k month. 

 ‚Äã Dean closed his first info-product client less than 48 hours after joining. 

 ‚Äã ‚Äã Check out more wins and apply before the price increase by going here. ‚Äã

 Moving on‚Ä¶ 

 There‚Äôs a hurricane coming. 

 It‚Äôll likely miss Miami, but the weather will consist of gray skies and clouds all week. 

 So yesterday, I decided to flee. 

 I texted my friend Mason and asked if he wanted to join me. 

 And then opened my phone and started looking at flights to LA. 

 But as we looked, we ran into a problem. 

 There weren‚Äôt any nonstop first class flights until Wednesday. 

 We hopped on a facetime call and the conversation went as follows: 

 Me: ‚ÄúThis is fucked.‚Äù 

 Mason: ‚ÄúWell, we do have alternative options‚Ä¶‚Äù 

 Me: ‚ÄúHow much would a jet be to LA?‚Äù 

 Mason: ‚ÄúLet me text my guy right now.‚Äù 

 Jet‚Äôs now booked and we‚Äôre flying out at 5pm. 

 I‚Äôm mostly telling you this to flex, but also to show you how cool it is to increase the amount of money that feels expendable to you. 

 I‚Äôve spent a lot of money over the last year. 

 I‚Äôve wasted a lot of money on dumb shit. 

 But this has shown me how replaceable it can be. 

 It isn‚Äôt a scarce resource that I need to cling onto. 

 When I spend freely, it comes back to me. 

 Now, I‚Äôm not encouraging you to spend more than you have. 

 However, if you occasionally splurge on experiences it can help you conceptualize larger amounts of money, thus helping you make more. 

 Or maybe I‚Äôm writing all of this to justify my spending problem. 

 Who knows, I gotta pack for LA. 

 ‚Äã Go here to check out Artisan Lab before the price raises. ‚Äã

 Talk soon, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: The rational man takes "risks"
body:
Hello from a coffee shop in LA. 

 I‚Äôm sitting outside with a large iced vanilla latte that has a bit too much milk in it. 

 Let‚Äôs talk about risk. 

 Recently, one of my newest students in Artisan Lab got a client within 48 hours of joining. 

 He closed someone on a VSL script and funnel. 

 As of right now, he has no idea how to do this. 

 But he figured he‚Äôd close the deal anyway and use the resources inside my mastermind to learn what he needs on the fly. 

 How irresponsible and misleading, right? 

 Let‚Äôs weigh the potential outcomes here: 

 Best case scenario, he builds a solid VSL funnel (which should be easy because he has me as a resource) and the client is happy. 

 They continue working together and it makes him 5-6 figures over the next year. 

 Worst case scenario, he builds the worst funnel in the world, the client hates it and fires him. 

 And then‚Ä¶ 

 He goes back to the way his life was before. 

 Now with a rep under his belt, knowing what he needs to improve. 

 That's it. 

 Meaning the worst case scenario is still a win. 

 This is how most ‚Äúrisks‚Äù actually work. 

 They‚Äôre win-win situations, and the only way you lose is by not taking them. 

 When you think critically about it, this is the rational way to operate. 

 A few years ago when I dropped out of college, here‚Äôs how I saw it: 

 I could stay in school, get my degree and hope I find a job that makes me over $40k per year when I graduate. 

 I‚Äôd be absolutely miserable but at least no one would look at me like I was crazy. 

 That would be the ‚Äúsafe‚Äù route. 

 Or I could drop out of college and take the ‚Äúrisky‚Äù route. 

 I‚Äôd try to make this online business thing work and if it does, my life would be changed forever. 

 Over the next few years I‚Äôd end up making multi-7 figures, move to Miami with my best friends, inspire thousands of people online, buy a porsche 911 turbo, and book a private jet across the country because it was raining. 

 Obviously that‚Äôs how it ended up ;) 

 But even when I looked at the potential downside, it‚Äôs not bad. 

 Let‚Äôs say I didn‚Äôt get online business to work. 

 I accept the fact that I have the IQ of an ape and go move back in with my parents. 

 Maybe I‚Äôd use the skills I learned while trying to start a business to get a decent job. 

 Maybe I‚Äôd do doordash and spend my free time in the sun. 

 Maybe I‚Äôd go back to school and get my degree. 

 And now, at least I can close my eyes at night knowing I wasn‚Äôt supposed to build a business because I actually tried and it didn‚Äôt work out. 

 Getting that clarity is a win. 

 When you break it down like this, NOTHING is risky. 

 It‚Äôs all an illusion! 

 They don‚Äôt want you to be rich, famous and handsome. 

 But you‚Äôre here and you‚Äôre still reading this. 

 ‚Äã And that means you‚Äôre meant for more. ‚Äã

 Love you, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: how to enjoy life even though there's work to do
body:
‚ÄúIt was the best of times. If only someone had told me.‚Äù - Hank Moody in Californication 

 What makes you happy? 

 Well, let me rephrase that: 

 If you were watching the sunset on the beach with your best friends, what would you need to have completed to fully enjoy that moment? 

 Let‚Äôs break this down. 

 Would you be thinking about the work you haven‚Äôt finished, answered emails, or the thing you told yourself you‚Äôd do but haven‚Äôt gotten around to? 

 Would you let that thought take you out of the present moment and cloud what could‚Äôve been a beautiful, unique experience? 

 This is a position I often find myself in. 

 My life is the exact way I formerly dreamt of. 

 The freedom, relationships, lifestyle, and impact are the things I wanted years ago. 

 Yet I still find myself ‚Äòmissing it‚Äô sometimes. 

 And by that, I mean not appreciating the good times because I‚Äôm in my head contemplating a decision or feeling guilty because I didn‚Äôt accomplish a task. 

 It‚Äôs a cloud that can feel everpresent. 

 But when I think about this, the solution is quite simple: 

 Do the things that make me feel productive and fulfill my creative desire. 

 That‚Äôs it. 

 If I do those things, I can enjoy my life. 

 If I don‚Äôt, I can‚Äôt. 

 It doesn't matter where I am, who I‚Äôm with, or what I‚Äôm doing. 

 My unfinished business will sit in the back of my mind like a parasite. 

 I could be across the table from the most beautiful girl I‚Äôve ever seen while she yaps about her hair, makeup, or whatever women talk about. 

 Instead of listening, I‚Äôd be thinking about the text I got three weeks ago that I didn‚Äôt reply to. 

 Or the fact that I didn‚Äôt write an email that day. 

 Or the random side quest that I promised myself I would start and haven‚Äôt. 

 This sound familiar? 

 It‚Äôs impossible to be happy if you fail to do the things that make you feel accomplished. 

 Many of which may have nothing to do with financial gain. 

 But that desire sits in your soul for a reason. 

 It‚Äôs a thirst you must quench to be able to live freely. 

 The alternative is a life where you‚Äôve entrapped yourself in your own mind. 

 You‚Äôre on the sidelines, watching yourself pretend to be happy. 

 But if you can just identify the few things you need to do to turn each day into a ‚Äòwin,‚Äô that cloud will go away. 

 You won‚Äôt let unfinished business ruin your peace‚Ä¶ 

 ‚Äã And you‚Äôll fully experience the fruits of your labor. ‚Äã 

 Let‚Äôs have a good week, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: How to make progress as fast as possible
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 I‚Äôm sitting on my balcony writing to you on a beautiful day here in Miami. 

 There‚Äôs a common dilemma that everyone faces when trying to build a business. 

 It‚Äôs the thing that drastically slows down or halts progress entirely. 

 And it‚Äôs this idea that business has to be complicated. 

 We often look for complex solutions to simple problems in order to avoid action. 

 Odds are, you know what step you need to take right now. 

 If you‚Äôre trying to get clients in the info-product space, it‚Äôs pretty simple: 

 1. Learn about copywriting and marketing 

 2. Start doing as much quality outreach as possible 

 3. Close a client, get good results and repeat 

 But maybe you‚Äôre telling yourself you‚Äôre not ready. 

 You need to learn more or find some outreach system that you‚Äôre currently unaware of. 

 That‚Äôs your mind playing tricks on you. 

 In reality, you‚Äôre scared to start because you don‚Äôt know what you don‚Äôt know. 

 And committing to this process will require you to step into a new version of yourself. 

 It‚Äôs the version of you who doesn‚Äôt hesitate and knows you can figure things out on the fly. 

 With this, comes additional pressure. 

 ‚ÄúWhat if I get a client and run into a problem?‚Äù 

 ‚ÄúWhat if my outreach is horrible?‚Äù 

 It‚Äôs easier to stay where you are (and who you are) now while fooling yourself into thinking that you‚Äôre not ready. 

 There‚Äôs a harsh truth of the universe that you need to understand: 

 You will never be entirely prepared for anything. 

 The stars will never align perfectly until you take the imperfect action. 

 You can wait forever. 

 And you‚Äôll sit there, watching others who are no different from you get the results that you could‚Äôve gotten, if you had the balls to start. 

 This is something I‚Äôve learned while coaching the members inside of Artisan Lab. ‚Äã 

 The biggest value I‚Äôm able to provide people with is conviction. 

 Because they‚Äôve paid me for coaching, they value the messenger more than the message. 

 Meaning if I just confirm to someone that the logical action is right (even if they already knew that) my conviction and assurance is enough to get them to actually do it. 

 The secret is understanding that there is no secret, and you‚Äôre as prepared now as you‚Äôll ever need to be. 

 It‚Äôs a cliche, but an accurate one. 

 Progress is simple. 

 Just actually do the thing that you know you need to do. 

 Anyway, I dropped this video yesterday that people seem to really enjoy. ‚Äã 

 See you over there, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Here‚Äôs your last chance to get into Artisan Lab before the price goes up ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: Read this to sell anything to anyone
body:
There are three ‚Äòmicro-sales‚Äô that need to occur if you want someone to buy coaching. 

 In this email, I‚Äôll reveal them while simultaneously utilizing them to sell you. 

 Should be fun, let‚Äôs dive in: 

 1. The mechanism sale 

 This is where you sell someone on the vehicle. 

 The goal is to show them why your method to get the desired outcome is effective. 

 Example ‚Äì you want to make money online. 

 There are countless business models you could choose from. 

 All of them can work, but that doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre all created equally. 

 Many require capital, years of experience, or rely on finding gimmicks or hacks in the market and don‚Äôt teach you valuable skills. 

 That‚Äôs why the Info-Product Agency is a solid option. 

 It‚Äôs not a ‚Äúbusiness model,‚Äù it‚Äôs a skillset that makes you a valuable asset to any business. 

 And because the online education industry is rapidly growing, it makes logical sense to work with people who sell info. 

 There‚Äôs an abundance of potential clients you can work with and your ‚Äòcompetition‚Äô is horrible. 

 Believe me, the pitches I get in my inbox are barely legible. 

 So this means all you have to do is learn how to apply the skill of marketing to info-product businesses. 

 And then go find them ‚Äì which is easy because they want to be found (that‚Äôs how their business works). 

 Oh, and it‚Äôs basically free to start. 

 See what I did there? 

 I made a logical argument as to why my mechanism works. 

 That‚Äôs micro-sale #1. 

 2. The authority sale 

 If you‚Äôre gonna buy from someone, you have to trust them (obviously). 

 To do this, you need to: 

 A. Show that you know what you‚Äôre talking about 

 B. Show that you have no special advantages or ability that the audience doesn‚Äôt 

 Let‚Äôs see this in action. 

 Your typical guru hits a $20k month one time, then they turn around and start selling courses. 

 90% of their income is from their info-product, not the business they claim to be an expert in. 

 I hit consistent $100k months for nearly a year before I ever sold my own info. 

 This business has given me my dream lifestyle. 

 And I know it can do the same for you, because I was once in your shoes. 

 I bounced from one thing to the next, and felt like making money online was impossible for me. 

 I‚Äôd make some money here and there, but nothing was sustainable or scalable. 

 That was until I found the Info-Product Agency. 

 After years of trying to make money online, I hit my first $15k month just four months after pivoting to the info-product space. 

 And it‚Äôs why I‚Äôm so confident that this can work for you. 

 Boom, there goes micro-sale #2, now you trust me. 

 3. The personal sale 

 At the end of the day, people's biggest hesitations come from their own mind. 

 They don‚Äôt believe in themselves. 

 And it's your job as a marketer to change that narrative and give them hope. 

 This is where you use social proof to show them that there are people who are just like them getting results. 

 Here‚Äôs what that looks like: 

 ‚Äã My student Briar joined Artisan lab 3 months ago, making just $3k/mo from his 9-5 (none on his own). 

 With my help, he just hit his first $10k month with his info agency. 

 ‚Äã Just two months after joining, Kabrin hit $20k/month after starting from scratch. 

 ‚Äã And lastly, Kidous (who runs a software company and is just doing this for fun) closed his first info client for $6k/mo + 10% rev share. client. 

 Everyone you see here is no different from you. 

 They've simply implemented the systems I've given them and they're reaping the benefits. 

 ‚Äã Go here now to join them. ‚Äã

 Aaaand that concludes micro-sale #3. 

 See how this works now? 

 Good. 

 ‚Äã Now hop in Artisan Lab and you'll become and money making machine. ‚Äã

 Later, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: DCA - {{ subscriber.first_name }}
body:
The answer only becomes clear once a decision has been made. 

 You can float in the abyss forever. 

 You can contemplate, analyze, and hypothesize. 

 You can tell yourself you need a sign. 

 You need a jolt. 

 You need the grim reaper to come remind you that the clock is ticking. 

 But you don‚Äôt know, until you go. 

 This is the common dilemma of the critical thinker. 

 It‚Äôs a blessing and a curse. 

 It‚Äôll help you see through the whole 9-5 rat race trap. 

 It‚Äôll lead you to many answers you have about the world and yourself. 

 But as you know very well, it comes with downsides. 

 It‚Äôll lead you to continue ruminating even after you‚Äôve come to a reasonable conclusion. 

 It‚Äôll convince you that you‚Äôre not ready ‚Äì and you‚Äôll never be ready. 

 It‚Äôll fool you into thinking that thought alone creates progress when in reality, it‚Äôs the very thing holding you back. 

 You‚Äôre the voice of reason and your biggest enemy all in one. 

 Will you learn when to shut out that voice who avoids change? 

 Will you let internal conviction take control and start before you‚Äôre ready? 

 Will you understand that nothing changes until something changes, which is impossible without‚Ä¶ 

 A decision. 

 Left or right. 

 Shoot or pass. 

 Hit the gap or slam on the breaks. 

 If you keep floating in no man‚Äôs land, you‚Äôre gonna get hurt. 

 ‚Äã Decide, commit, act. ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Lifestyle curation
body:
‚ÄúThe only real test of intelligence is if you get what you want out of life.‚Äù - Naval 

 {{ subscriber.first_name }}, sorry I ghosted you for a week ‚Äì I‚Äôm back. 

 Let‚Äôs talk about living life by design. 

 Everyone wants to create their dream lifestyle. 

 It‚Äôs what initially attracts many of us to entrepreneurship. 

 You begin to imagine a future version of you with more freedom and confidence. 

 You think about how incredible your life will be once you just crack the money code. 

 But even when you make the money you want, that doesn‚Äôt mean the rest of your life will improve. 

 Sure, money solves money problems, which is great. 

 It gives you more freedom and the pursuit of it can create internal fulfillment. 

 But if you really want to enjoy your life, there‚Äôs one main thing most people fail to do: 

 You must consciously and continually consider if the life you are creating aligns with what you actually want. 

 It‚Äôs simple, but easy to overlook. 

 Just because you have financial access to your dream lifestyle, that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôll happen by default. 

 I first internalized this around a year and half ago. 

 Although I was making more money than I ever had, my lifestyle hadn‚Äôt changed. 

 It felt like it was time for an upgrade. 

 I made a conscious decision to start doing things that I wasn‚Äôt doing. 

 I went out of my way to meet more people, both in person and through social media. 

 One thing led to the next, each connection opened another door, and my life started improving. 

 It was magic. 

 A decision was made, actions were taken, and the goal was accomplished. 

 Fast forward to now and I really don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôd be possible to drastically improve my lifestyle. 

 I have everything I want. 

 From my friend group, to the access I have in Miami, and the clout from social media (which can be vapid, but it‚Äôs cool). 

 I‚Äôve proven to myself that I can create what I want from scratch. 

 And that‚Äôs the biggest benefit of all. 

 Every endeavor forces you to become a completely new version of yourself. 

 This doesn‚Äôt always come with immediate financial gain but it‚Äôll help you live a much fuller life. 

 Progress is not black and white. 

 Money is just a tool that allows you to curate your life ‚Äì don‚Äôt forget to do so. ‚Äã 

 Good to be back, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: Everyone will love you if...
body:
It‚Äôs a 78 degree, sunny morning in Miami. 

 I‚Äôm sitting on a park bench, looking at an advertisement for Jimmy Butlers netflix show go by on the water. 

 Imagine a billboard placed on top of a 20ish foot boat. 

 On my way here, I held the door for a lady with a stroller. 

 She was further than the typical distance that I‚Äôd hold a door for someone, but because her hands were full, I waited. 

 After patting myself on the back, I realized this is the perfect topic for today‚Äôs email: 

 Awareness. 

 Those who win, are typically the most aware. 

 They know not to stand in the middle of crowded hallway. 

 They know how to make their date feel comfortable. 

 They know how to make the shy person feel included in the conversation. 

 They know how to adjust their pitch to their prospect on a sales call. 

 They know to hit the breaks when a driver looks like they‚Äôre gonna pull out in front of them without looking. 

 All of these seemingly minuscule examples indicate a level of consciousness that‚Äôs higher than the average person. 

 Socially this means you‚Äôre calculated, but not too calculated. 

 You‚Äôre considerate of those around but you don‚Äôt entirely discard your own beliefs and standards to fit in. 

 You can walk into a party, make connections and leave others feeling energized. 

 In a business setting, you‚Äôre able to see opportunities for what they are. 

 Because you‚Äôre aware, other people like you. They want to connect with you. They want to help you. 

 Nearly every business is built off of relationships. 

 And awareness is the foundation of the way you interact with the world. 

 Without it, you‚Äôll struggle. 

 Nearly anyone I‚Äôve ever cut out of my life it‚Äôs been because of this reason. 

 There‚Äôs just something that they‚Äôre missing from a social calibration standpoint. 

 I don‚Äôt trust people like that, and neither does anyone else. 

 If you‚Äôre still here reading this and you‚Äôre thinking ‚Äúhow do I become more aware?‚Äù That's up to you. 

 There‚Äôs no tutorial here ‚Äî 

 But if you‚Äôre a conscious observer of your inner dialogue, you pay attention to the micro-expressions of others, and you have the confidence to act accordingly without exchanging your authenticity‚Ä¶ 

 ‚Äã You‚Äôll be further ahead than most. ‚Äã

 Bye, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Trust me bro
body:
It‚Äôs another sunny day. 

 I‚Äôm starting this from a park bench as a pale shirtless man walks past me pushing a stroller. 

 As I sit here pondering what to write about, I keep returning to one idea: 

 Trust. 

 Your ability to trust yourself is the ultimate test. 

 Pursue anything and there‚Äôs a million problems that you don‚Äôt know how to solve. 

 You can let that stop you. 

 Or you can trust that even the things you can‚Äôt control will work out the way they‚Äôre supposed to. 

 Because you‚Äôre you. 

 And YOU will keep moving forward and figure it out. 

 When you do this, you open the door to endless possibilities you didn‚Äôt have previously. 

 Every endeavor I've started or change I‚Äôve made in recent memory has worked out positively. 

 From moving to Miami before I felt entirely ready. 

 To posting on Youtube and building Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 To starting my comedy/skit arc on Tik Tok and Instagram‚Ä¶ 

 Even though these aren‚Äôt huge changes that immediately impact my direction in life, there‚Äôs a level of micro-anxiety when starting anything new. 

 You don‚Äôt know what you don‚Äôt know, and that‚Äôs nerve-wrecking. 

 In my case, I‚Äôd proven to myself that I can thrive when I take on new challenges. 

 This has allowed me to get over that resistance. 

 And even now, I don‚Äôt know how everything‚Äôs gonna work out. 

 I don‚Äôt have a 1, 5, or 10 year plan. 

 But what I do know is that Im planting seeds that will continue to sprout. 

 From my comedy side quests, to business content, to my info-agency‚Ä¶ 

 As long as I just keep moving forward, I have enough trust in myself that I will get everything I want. 

 That‚Äôs how it‚Äôs worked for me so far. 

 So {{ subscriber.first_name }}, I encourage you to approach life through this the same lens. 

 You are a perpetual problem solver. 

 You can adapt to varying circumstances and environments. 

 The right opportunities will find you as long as you start progressing. 

 You have everything you need 

 You are everything you need. 

 And any time you‚Äôre stressed and feel the walls caving in‚Ä¶ 

 That's just another opportunity to show yourself that you can climb out of any deficit. 

 ‚Äã Trust yourself. ‚Äã

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: Instant transformation is the only way to change
body:
Transformations are a result of micro-adjustments. 

 Change is perceived as difficult because we get caught up in old habits, routines, and thoughts. 

 But taking the action to enable change is rarely difficult. 

 Right now in this instant, you can start a full life transformation. 

 If you want money, it can be as simple as picking up the phone and pitching someone. 

 If you want a better social life, you can start a conversation in line at the coffee shop. 

 You can send a DM on Instagram or make a 30 second video that leads to a friendship, customer, or client. 

 You can decide to stop asking other people for advice and follow your own instincts. 

 Over time, that single decision will equip you with the internal conviction necessary to take on more personal responsibility. 

 And with that, you‚Äôll finally be in the drivers seat of your own life. 

 Micro-adjustments, macro-results. 

 You‚Äôre just a series of small changes away. 

 You know this, but you overcomplicate it. 

 These small changes feel like you‚Äôre carrying a whale on your shoulders while walking up a downward moving escalator. 

 And this is because you‚Äôre comfortable with your current struggle and level of responsibility. 

 You don‚Äôt actually want to solve your problem because it‚Äôll force you to evolve. 

 Your current conflict will be replaced with a new one. And this conflict, you‚Äôre not accustomed to. 

 If you solve your money problem, you have to figure out what you want to do with your life. 

 It‚Äôs temporarily easier to just keep grappling with the same issues. 

 And that‚Äôs why the micro-adjustments you know you need to make in order to change are stopping you. 

 You‚Äôre letting small roadblocks turn into sinkholes. 

 But if you just start with one small decision. And one small action, you‚Äôll realize it‚Äôs not that scary. 

 Along the way, you‚Äôll be equipped with everything you need to handle a new level of responsibility. 

 The upgraded, confident version of you is not that far away. 

 He (or she) just started right now. 

 ‚Äã And 6 months later, you‚Äôre unrecognizable. ‚Äã 

 Get moving, 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: You are meant to build
body:
Your energy alone will take you to where you‚Äôre supposed to be. 

 This isn‚Äôt some mystical spiritual concept, but rather an observation I‚Äôve made throughout my journey. 

 I‚Äôve always felt like I was special. 

 Perhaps it‚Äôs a feeling everyone has, but most suppress. 

 People tell you that everyone is equal. 

 They tell you that your ego is a bad thing. 

 And that your selfish inclination to believe that you‚Äôre ordained for greatness is narcissistic. 

 Perhaps they‚Äôre right. 

 Is this belief likely based on delusion and ego? 

 Yes. 

 But will it serve you in ways that I don‚Äôt have enough time to articulate on this page? 

 Also yes. 

 You are who you believe you are. 

 If you walk through life with an exuberant confidence in your eye, others will perceive you as someone who‚Äôs got it figured out. 

 If you believe you are that guy and that you weren‚Äôt meant to be another dull, lifeless NPC going through the motions in someone else‚Äôs movie, that energy will carry you. 

 I‚Äôm not telling you to be an asshole and entirely lose sight of reality. 

 Yes, you have to put in work. 

 You have to prove your competence. 

 And you have to earn the respect of others. 

 But that‚Äôll be impossible to do without a level of internal conviction that most would deem delusional. 

 That feeling in your gut is there for a reason. 

 It‚Äôs a version of you that‚Äôs possible to attain. 

 And it‚Äôs up to you to bring it to reality. 

 Most won‚Äôt. 

 But they aren‚Äôt reading this email. 

 ‚Äã So take this as your head start. ‚Äã 

 Ben 

 ‚Äã

subject: How to make $100k/month
body:
Hello and happy Monday. 

 One of my students inside Artisan Lab hit his first $100k month in October. 

 Here‚Äôs proof real quick: 

 ‚Äã As much as I‚Äôd love to take credit for his success, I can‚Äôt. 

 He‚Äôs gotten to where he is because he hasn‚Äôt needed hand holding or babysitting. 

 The guy just implements what he's told ‚Äîand that‚Äôs the secret. 

 About 4 months ago, he was at $25k per month. 

 We hopped on a 1-1 call, he explained his situation to me and I really didn‚Äôt have much advice for him. 

 I told him to keep doing as much outreach as possible and I gave him confirmation he was in the right path. 

 He doubled down on what was working for him. 

 Next thing you know, he‚Äôs at $100k per month. 

 He rarely asked questions after that initial call, which leads me to the lesson here: 

 Don‚Äôt keep looking for an answer you already have. 

 Once you get clarity on the direction you‚Äôre going in, put your head down and foot on the gas. 

 Any time you hear that voice in the back of your head say ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre ready‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat if we try this instead!‚Äù 

 Tell it to shut up. 

 You know what to do, you just have to execute. 

 And just like that, you‚Äôll be my next best case study inside of Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 Have a great week, 

 Ben

subject: Momentum > Discipline
body:
Trump winning the election has me thinking about how I need a second term with you. 

 Copy that line and send it to your ex. 

 You‚Äôre welcome. 

 Anyway, I‚Äôm sitting out on my balcony on a cloudy day here in Miami. 

 I‚Äôve been in a bit of a rut. 

 As you may have noticed, I haven‚Äôt been very consistent with these emails recently. 

 Every time I think about writing, it‚Äôs like my brain shuts off. 

 Typically I can come up with an idea, open my laptop and 20 minutes later I‚Äôll have a legible email. 

 But as of late, that‚Äôs been a struggle. 

 The advice I‚Äôd give to someone in my position when you just can‚Äôt get yourself to do something that you know you need to do is simple: 

 Make it easy. 

 If something feels like a herculean task, you won‚Äôt do it. 

 But what if you take the pressure off? 

 Instead of trying to write the perfect email, make the best content, or craft an amazing outreach message, you just do what you can. 

 It might not be your best work ever, but it builds momentum. 

 When you‚Äôre in a rut, that‚Äôs what you need. 

 And the next time you sit down to complete whatever task you‚Äôre avoiding, it gets a bit easier. 

 So that‚Äôs what this email is about. 

 I have a friend who recently started making content on Tik Tok. 

 He‚Äôs only made a few videos and keeps asking me for critiques. 

 I told him to stop asking for help until he posts consistently for a month. 

 Because right now, the quality doesn‚Äôt matter. 

 He needs reps and data, and over time he‚Äôll naturally work out the kinks. 

 So {{ subscriber.first_name }}, for any new habit you‚Äôre trying to build, I‚Äôll offer you the same advice. 

 Start small, enjoy the process, and don‚Äôt chase perfection. 

 If you show up for yourself consistently, it will work out. 

 The tasks that once felt difficult will get easier. 

 You‚Äôll get into a rhythm and start swimming with the tide. 

 ‚Äã Just start building. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: The money game is too easy
body:
Sometimes I feel like it‚Äôs all been too easy. 

 I reminisce on the times where I was hopeful and naive. 

 There was a spark in my eye that was ignited by blind ambition. 

 The process of making money and building the life I now have felt like a mythical endeavor. 

 Everything was so new and I was exuberant to be in the arena, playing the game. 

 I was a typical college dropout with big dreams and little idea how I‚Äôd pull it off. 

 Every time I moved a step closer to my goals, it was electric. 

 With each new client I signed, it meant I was that much further away from ever having to work a 9-5. 

 My first full year in business I made around $80k. 

 ‚ÄúHoly shit! That‚Äôs way more than I would‚Äôve made in my first year out of college,‚Äù I thought to myself. 

 That feeling of hopefulness remained as a buzz in the back of my mind for a while. 

 It‚Äôs like I was the chubby, socially off kid on the basketball team who finally gets to play during senior night. 

 I was just happy to be here. 

 But at some point, that wore off. 

 Unfortunately, it all worked and I got most of the things I wanted‚Ä¶ Maybe a little too easily. 

 Perhaps my vision for what I‚Äôd want after accomplishing my current status didn‚Äôt evolve fast enough. 

 I guess that‚Äôs an easy thing to overlook when you begin to embark on any journey ‚Äì What do I do if it works? 

 In the past, my goals would naturally evolve. 

 There was a point where I just wanted to make $5k per month. 

 Once I got there, I wanted $10k per month and so on, all the way up to six figures a month. 

 It was easy to keep going. That was until money stopped impacting my lifestyle. 

 I already don‚Äôt have to think about expenses, I go on trips when I want, and I have my dream car. 

 I could triple my income and it would have a minimal impact on my day to day life. 

 But that‚Äôs where the goals have to evolve. 

 More money now means more security. 

 It means I can invest more and set up my future self and my perfect 10 wife, so we can have beautiful babies that go to the league. 

 It means I can take care of and employ more people. 

 That was never in the vision. 

 I just wanted the flashy shit and fun lifestyle. 

 But that part was surprisingly easy. 

 This might read like I‚Äôm spoiled and ungrateful, but I‚Äôm sharing this because you will likely reach a point in your journey where you complete your vision. 

 You‚Äôll get everything that you believed was possible for you and find yourself in a position where life feels a bit dull, even though it might look exciting externally. 

 That‚Äôs when you have to move the goal post back again. 

 Find a new north star and begin working towards it. 

 See you at the top, 

 Ben 

 PS - Go here to get 1 on 1 help from me and scale your info-product agency ‚Äã 

 PPS - Lmk if you made it all the way down here and liked this one :)
‚Äã

subject: How to befriend millionaires
body:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 You may have heard the following cliche: 

 "You are the sum of the 5 people you spend the most time around." 

 When it comes to financial success, this typically holds true. 

 My immediate circle consists of millionaires and multi-millionaires. 

 Everyone I'm around is crushing it. 

 This has helped me make more money because it's forced me to raise my own standards. 

 I don't want to be the brokie in the friend group that can't hold their own weight. 

 Plus it's a constant reminder of what I am capable of. 

 My friends are dope, but they're no smarter than me. 

 And I know if they can do it, so can I. 

 This is one of the hidden benefits of joining online communities.

 Getting rich.

 ‚Äã When you constantly see people who are just like you getting the results above, it's impossible to not get inspired. 

 The FOMO that comes with knowing you're leaving money on the table forces you to take massive action. 

 And when that happens, you make money. 

 They're no different from you, aside from the fact that they have one special advantage: 

 They're in a community of winners. ‚Äã

 Inside of Artisan Lab they have 1-1 access to me, they get to learn from a new guest speaker each week, and they're able to build with and learn from each other. 

 It's a cheat code that fast-tracks their success. 

 If you want to force yourself to make progress as fast as possible, you need to surround yourself with people who are after the same goal. 

 You can watch everyone else succeed from the sidelines...

 Up to you, my friend.

subject: Stop thinking, you idiot
body:
I woke up on the 28th floor of a hotel in Soho.

 I threw on some sweats and a hoodie, and now I‚Äôm sitting at a red metal table in a crowded coffee shop.

 The woman(?) who took my order was wearing a covid mask and there‚Äôs a girl behind me with a slight lisp talking loudly on the phone about her problems at work.

 I‚Äôm contemplating throwing my sugary iced latte at her.

 You now have a clear picture of my exact situation as I sit here typing to you on my phone.

 Now onto the more important stuff:

 Think less.

 When you‚Äôre making a business decision.

 When you‚Äôre sending a text.

 When you‚Äôre talking to the perfect model 10.

 When you‚Äôre deciding between rigatoni or penne.

 Just please stop thinking so much.

 Your initial instinctive response is the best one 99 times out of 100.

 And you‚Äôre fucking up the natural, authentic flow of life by hyper-analyzing every aspect of it.

 YOU DON‚ÄôT GET ANY EXTRA POINTS FOR CONSTANT CONTEMPLATION.

 All you‚Äôre doing is stressing yourself out and diminishing that natural carefree spirit in your soul.

 ‚ÄúWhat should I say to pretty gorl to get her to like me??? Oh no, should I send this emoji or is that too aggressive? I shouldn‚Äôt have put that period at the end of my sentence, now I sound too serious.‚Äù

 YOU‚ÄôRE COOKED.

 Seriously, this is ruining your life.

 The intention is pure but it has an inverse effect.

 You have instincts for a reason. STOP DOUBTING THEM.

 But I get it ‚Äî This habit of analysis is a double edged sword. 

 Being someone who is aware and thinks critically can help you.

 Without this, you‚Äôll just blindly follow other people.

 But you have to toe the line between overthinking and ignorance.

 Too much thought makes you a spiritually cucked pussy.

 Too little thought makes you a sheep who stands in the middle of crowded doorways.

 Don‚Äôt be either.

 Learn when to shut off that part of your brain who revises every decision before you make it.

 And learn when to question whether or not a belief or operating system aligns with what you want.

 But when in doubt ‚Äî stop thinking and let it fly. ‚Äã

 That‚Äôs life in the flow state.

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: Life is fair
body:
Happy Monday {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 The other day I wrote a tweet I want to expand on.

 I said:

 ‚ÄúLife is actually incredibly fair. You get what you truly believe you are capable of receiving. But you can‚Äôt deceive the universe the way you can your own mind. There is no hiding or contorting the truth. If you don‚Äôt get what you want, you‚Äôre not unlucky, you‚Äôre undeserving.‚Äù

 Any time I‚Äôve found myself disappointed in an outcome, it‚Äôs because I failed to remember the truth above.

 There‚Äôs been periods in business where I felt like I deserved more than what I received.

 That could go on for a while until eventually I‚Äôd make some sort of adjustment and my income would grow exponentially.

 Only after that could I see the picture clearly.

 Beforehand, I wasn‚Äôt ready.

 There was a skill gap, mental hurdle, or some other form of maturing I needed.

 The delay was a result of that fact and it was equipping me with whatever I was missing.

 When I was disappointed, it was a result of not seeing reality clearly.

 This is what I learned:

 If you think you deserve a different outcome than you received, it‚Äôs because you‚Äôre fooling yourself or being impatient.

 There‚Äôs an inkling in your gut that knows exactly that.

 If you‚Äôre too closely attached to your income, your bank account won‚Äôt grow.

 If you‚Äôre heavily reliant on validation from others, you‚Äôll feel empty even when you get it.

 If you refuse to make the necessary adjustment to reach a goal, and you fool yourself into thinking that you can get around it‚Ä¶

 The universe will remind you that you cannot outsmart it.

 You reap what you sow and there is no cheating.

 You know what you truly deserve and you know if there are things you‚Äôve been running from.

 Continue to run, continue to lie to yourself, continue to be disappointed.

 Or accept that you will not get what you want out of life until you slay the necessary dragons.

 And remember‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã You can‚Äôt outperform your own self-image. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: You're thinking too much
body:
Most of your problems are not real.

 They're illusions you've created in your own head as a result of habitual over-thinking.

 Stop contemplating, you're making it worse.

 The issue can be solved in an instant.

 Make the decision. It's not daunting as you've made it out to be in your mind.

 Stop dwelling.

 Nobody remembers the "embarrassing" thing you said.

 Stop fixating.

 Your date doesn't notice that your shirt isn't perfectly ironed.

 Stop analyzing.

 The perfect route to financial success doesn't exist, start now.

 You can override your conscious mind through action.

 Post the content you want to post.

 Carry yourself with confidence.

 Act as the person you want to become.

 You will become that person.

 The voice that tells you to flinch loses it's power as you separate from it.

 It does not dictate your actions, you do. Only in the present moment.

 And that's all you'll ever have.

 Stop creating an internal hell because your external world is void of real problems.

 ‚Äã You're thinking too much. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: This is a necessary evil
body:
I‚Äôm back.

 It‚Äôs a frigid morning here in Miami.

 I got a hot vanilla latte today because of this.

 The weather app says it‚Äôs 61 degrees out but I swear it feels like it‚Äôs in the 20‚Äôs.

 Anyway, I have to apologize to the nerds today.

 You know the guys you see on Instagram who constantly talk about the importance of routine?

 They‚Äôre the steak, eggs, standing desk, blue light blocker, and supplement stack types.

 For some reason they post 178 Instagram stories per day, showing you the same thing‚Ä¶

 Every. Fucking. Day.

 Wake up 5am, meditate to David Goggins poster, kettlebell workout, sales call, rant about positivity, involuntarily celibate disguised as ‚Äòno fap.‚Äô

 (Sorry that last one was mean)

 It‚Äôs corny as fuck.

 But it works.

 And recently, I forgot that.

 The most productive era‚Äôs of my life have typically come when my habits are in check.

 I‚Äôm getting up early, taking walks, journaling, writing emails, making content‚Ä¶

 Everything is consistent.

 And this consistency builds momentum.

 Getting work done feels easier. Each day is a productive step in the right direction.

 The chatter in my mind begins to quiet.

 And once again, I‚Äôm able to find that intuitive feeling in my gut that just knows the way.

 Even though I don‚Äôt know exactly where I‚Äôm going.

 When I‚Äôm moving, things unfold in my favor.

 Movement is the solution -- And it‚Äôs easily created through these corny ass habits that won‚Äôt directly make you rich.

 Obviously ‚Äì Sitting in the sauna isn‚Äôt gonna put millions in your bank account.

 5 minutes in the cold plunge won‚Äôt put a Patek on your wrist.

 Meditating won‚Äôt buy you a Porsche 911 Turbo.

 But if you don‚Äôt take the time to be with yourself and prove to your little monkey brain that you can exercise discipline‚Ä¶

 Then how do you expect to scale and maintain a business?

 Sure you don‚Äôt always have to be ‚Äúlocked in‚Äù but if you neglect things for too long, they die.

 If you don‚Äôt workout, your muscles begin to atrophy.

 And that goes for every ‚Äúmuscle‚Äù including discipline, mental aptitude, creativity, etc.

 Use it or lose it.

 Habits are a cheat code to continual growth. Just don‚Äôt be weird about it and start posting your whole day on Instagram.

 No one really cares. I promise.

 But thank you, Nerds for the reminder.

 Feels great to be back :)

 Ben

 PS Hope you had a great Thanksgiving and Black Friday. Mine was good but the turkey was kinda dry.

 Although I didn‚Äôt run a BF sale, I added a special bonus inside of Artisan Lab and have made it nearly impossible to fail.

 My members are getting rich. I‚Äôve got 21 year old kids making $100k+ per month.

 Others are closing famous people as clients.

 And others got their first two (PAYING) clients in their first week.

 ‚Äã Join me here now and you will get richer, happier, and better looking. ‚Äã

 Legally I can‚Äôt guarantee that, but illegally, I pinky promise.

 ‚Äã

subject: 10 principles that helped me scale to $100k/mo
body:
Here are 10 things you need to understand if you want to build a successful info-product agency.

 Whether you're just starting out, or you already have some clients, these lessons will help you scale rapidly.

 Let's go:

 The singular ‚Äúbest‚Äù outreach system doesn‚Äôt exist. Anything can work, if you take the time to be creative and stand out in your pitches. Take initiative in solving issues that are in the best interest of the business, even if you are not directly responsible for them. Think for yourself before asking questions. In most cases the answer is obvious and you just need to take the obvious action. Your conscious brain is typically not your friend. When you find yourself thinking that you need more information before you can act, you are fooling yourself. If you don‚Äôt feel like you‚Äôre in over your head, you‚Äôre not saying ‚Äúyes‚Äù enough. The best way to learn is on the fly. Do not obsess over systems and processes. Make money first, worry about efficiency later. Non-scalable actions differentiate you from your ‚Äúcompetition.‚Äù Everyone can send dozens of mediocre pitches daily. Not everyone will take the time to correctly assess a situation and personalize a pitch to solve a specific problem. Not every client is going to be a homerun. There are two sides to the equation and if your client isn‚Äôt holding up their end of the bargain, there‚Äôs only so much you can do. Find a way to get your foot in the door. It can make sense to offer one service, perform well, and take over other parts of their business once you earn their trust and have a better understanding of the gaps in their business. The best opportunities are found when a client is making good money, despite the fact that their systems are being overlooked. Fixing those problems is like pouring gas on the flame. There we have it.

 Remember these 10 things and you'll be driving an SVJ in no time.

 ‚Äã And if you want my personal help in growing your info-product agency or coaching business, click here. ‚Äã

 See you at the top,

 Ben
