subject: If you don't know where to start, do this
body:
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where to start.‚Äù

 Sound familiar?

 I was combing through Artisan Lab applications this morning and found a theme.

 There‚Äôs a question that asks applicants to share any roadblocks they‚Äôre facing.

 Around 90% of the answers are long-winded variations of ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where to start.‚Äù

 Whether it‚Äôs picking a business model, starting outreach, or creating content‚Ä¶

 Everyone finds a scapegoat as to why they aren‚Äôt taking action.

 Perhaps a better way of putting this dilemma is ‚ÄúI want to be told where to start.‚Äù

 You feel stuck because you have an abundance of options and you're not doing anything about it.

 Any business model can work.

 Any style of content can garner attention.

 Any outreach method can get you a client.

 But instead of trying something and seeing if it works, you convince yourself that you need more information.

 You‚Äôre left in a perpetual cycle of looking for more information rather than actively creating data that steers you in the right direction.

 One thing I know for sure is that everything that‚Äôs ever been created was done so from scratch.

 Someone, like you, didn‚Äôt know where to start.

 They tried something and it probably didn‚Äôt work the first time.

 So they tried a different method, now with more data.

 They do this over and over until they‚Äôve crossed off many of the ‚Äúwrong‚Äù answers.

 In doing so, they came closer to the answer‚Ä¶

 And then it clicks.

 Action creates clarity.

 The route to success is found after knifing through tens, hundreds, or even thousands of routes that don‚Äôt directly lead you to where you want to go.

 But they continuously reroute you until you arrive at your destination.

 And the once ‚Äúdirectionless‚Äù version of you ceases to exist.

 I can‚Äôt tell you with full certainty what will work for you. Neither can anyone else.

 We‚Äôre all different people with various natural advantages and inclinations.

 That‚Äôs life.

 The ones who are rewarded are those who act despite the fact that there is no universal rulebook.

 You just gotta start moving and trust that you‚Äôll find the answers while you‚Äôre running the race.

 There‚Äôs no way around this truth.

 ‚Äã Trust yourself, and you‚Äôll be rewarded. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: This is a privilege
body:
About 3 years ago, I got recognized from social media in person for the first time. 

 I was walking on 5th avenue in Playa Del Carmen, Mexico. 

 This is the main strip in the city, filled with restaurants, clubs, and a lot of people discreetly trying to offer you drugs. 

 If you made eye contact with one of these vendors they‚Äôd go directly into their pitch. 

 ‚ÄúAmigo! cocaine, ecstasy, molly, women‚Ä¶. tengo todo. What you want?‚Äù 

 Solid offer, but I refrained from ever taking them up on it. 

 As I walked through the chaos, I could feel someone staring at me. 

 I looked over and saw this guy who appeared to be around my same age. 

 He came running up to me and asked, ‚Äúis your name Ben??‚Äù 

 I answered ‚Äúyes‚Äù and he told me knew me from Twitter. 

 We chatted for a bit and got a picture together. 

 That was a surreal feeling. 

 You mean to tell me that by simply making content through the little device I‚Äôm typing this on right now, people from all over the world could see it? 

 And it could have enough of an impact on their life that they feel impelled to come up to me and say something? 

 In Mexico of all places? 

 That‚Äôs pretty cool. 

 Now, as I sit here writing this from a Starbucks in Brickell, two people have come up to me saying they‚Äôve seen my content. 

 This typically happens multiple times a day now. 

 But like anything, over time that surrealistic feeling from the beginning starts to wear off. 

 It feels normal. I find myself taking it for granted. 

 This isn‚Äôt an attempt to brag, sound like an asshole and tell you how famous I am. Although it may read that way. 

 Rather it‚Äôs a reminder to myself and to you reading this ‚Äî don‚Äôt take special for granted. 

 It‚Äôs a privilege to wake up in the morning. 

 It‚Äôs a privilege to work on something you care about. 

 It‚Äôs a privilege to make your own schedule, travel, and take care of those around you. 

 And it‚Äôs a privilege to be born in an era where you can use the device you‚Äôre reading this on as an all-powerful tool. 

 You can make money. You can meet your best friends. You can create content that inspires, entertains, and helps others. Whether it‚Äôs one person, or thousands. 

 That‚Äôs really fucking cool. And we‚Äôre lucky to be a part of it. 

 No matter how big you get, how much money you have, or how many people want your time and attention‚Ä¶ 

 You‚Äôre never too important to appreciate the little things. 

 ‚Äã Don‚Äôt take special for granted, ‚Äã

 Ben 

 ‚Äã 

 ‚Äã

subject: This is really, REALLY bad
body:
I‚Äôm going to fear monger you today.

 Last night I listened to a podcast about the economic and social state of young men in America.

 Long story short, the average guy between 18-30 is down horrendous.

 I used to hear guru‚Äôs talk about this and I‚Äôd write it off as a marketing angle.

 But when you look at the data, it‚Äôs entirely true (and absolutely fucked).

 Here‚Äôs some stats for you:

 Over 41% of men ages 25 to 34 make less than $30k per year, compared to just 25% in 1975 (adjusted for inflation). Young men are 4x more likely to commit suicide compared to women and 3x more likely to overdose on drugs. 20% of men (24-35) still live with their parents compared to just 12% of women. 1 out of every 3 men (18-24) hasn‚Äôt had sex in the last year. Marriage rates have gone down from 70% in 1970 to just 30% today. The average man doesn‚Äôt buy their first home until age 38, up from age 29 in 1981. The median income of young men has dropped from $73k in 1975 to just $40k today (adjusted for inflation). I‚Äôm not much of a numbers guy but this is completely insane.

 Young guys are poorer and more isolated than ever.

 The days where you could follow the beaten path and live comfortably are gone.

 If you don‚Äôt have high value skills that you can use to either build your own business of get a high paying job, you‚Äôre fucked.

 Unless you have an ivy league degree, you‚Äôre gonna be a doctor, or you have a clear path to making 6 figures in a 9-5, you‚Äôre left with two options‚Ä¶

 Be poor, unattractive to women, and live a miserable exist where you‚Äôre more likely to kill yourself or overdose on drugs than you are to become a millionaire. Bet on yourself. Start learning skills. Start a business and fail. Fail again and again. Want to quit. Push through the turmoil. Find success. Become a millionaire. Buy your dream car(s). Build an amazing circle of friends. Be desirable to women. And live the life you‚Äôve always wanted to live. Which of the two options sounds better to you?

 The answer is obvious.

 But you gotta get through the hard part in the beginning where you want to flinch.

 And when you consider the alternative, that should make it a bit easier.

 I believe in you.

 ‚Äã Go here to adopt the mindset that saved me from a life of mediocrity. ‚Äã

 Let me know if you liked this one,

 Ben

subject: Why, {{ subscriber.first_name }}?
body:
The other day, a member in Artisan Lab told me that he was having trouble staying motivated.

 He asked me, ‚ÄúWhat's your why?‚Äù (meaning the deeper motivating purpose that drives me to succeed).

 Here‚Äôs my answer:

 When I first started in online business, I just wanted to make money.

 Not having to work a 9-5 sounded cool.

 Traveling sounded cool.

 Having the freedom to create my own schedule sounded cool.

 My ‚Äúwhy‚Äù was mostly made up of self-serving factors.

 I didn‚Äôt have to rescue my family from poverty and I didn‚Äôt have a grand vision to save endangered turtles.

 I wanted money because it looked fucking sick.

 And the idea of clocking in and out for the better half of my life sounded wayyyy less sick.

 Sickening, if you will.

 Furthermore, I had this feeling in my gut that you‚Äôre likely familiar with.

 It‚Äôs the feeling that told me that I couldn‚Äôt live a dull life.

 I‚Äôd try to suppress it sometimes, but it never worked.

 I simply knew that if I didn‚Äôt take a chance and at least attempt to gain full agency over my life, I‚Äôd be absolutely miserable.

 I‚Äôd rather end up homeless.

 So when I looked at it that way, there was one glaringly obvious option‚Ä¶

 Build the life that I actually wanted to live.

 Not for anyone else. Not for a greater purpose. But for me.

 I wanted to escape the inevitable future pain of mediocrity.

 Is that selfish? Sure.

 But had I deluded myself into believing that I needed a stronger ‚Äúwhy,‚Äù perhaps I never would‚Äôve started.

 I could‚Äôve rationalized, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not motivated and I can‚Äôt work because my life is decent as it is.‚Äù

 Don‚Äôt let Simon Sinek (author of It Starts With Why ) fool you.

 Your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù can be ripping an SVJ through the Hollywood hills.

 Your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù can be having the autonomy to wake up at noon every day.

 Your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù can be club-hopping in Ibiza with a bunch of ungrateful models.

 My point is stop worrying about your fucking ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and make money.

 Do you want to be miserable?

 Do you want to be poor?

 Do you want to be an incel?

 No?

 Okay! Then what the fuck else are you gonna do with your time? Lol.

 Eventually, your motivating factors will naturally evolve.

 Once you check off the superficial desires, perhaps your focus will shift to retiring your parents, setting up future generations, or saving the Goddamn turtles.

 But right now, you probably don‚Äôt care much about any of that.

 If you‚Äôre honest with yourself, you just don‚Äôt want to worry about spending money.

 And that‚Äôs completely fine.

 You don‚Äôt need to find some moral justification to stay motivated.

 It‚Äôs okay to want something, simply because you want to prove to yourself that you can get it.

 ‚Äã Ready to get rich now? ‚Äã

 See you at the top,

 Ben

subject: Indecision will kill you
body:
If there‚Äôs one core message from my recent content, it‚Äôs this‚Ä¶

 Indecision will kill you.

 You‚Äôll pass up the open shot and throw the ball to the other team.

 Your foot will hover between both pedals as you slam into the car that merged in front of you.

 The girl who could‚Äôve been your wife will get up and walk away while you sit there contemplating the perfect line.

 Indecision will kill you.

 You‚Äôll stand there, idle on the sidelines, watching what could be pass you by.

 Frame by frame, day by day. Missed opportunities stack up. You‚Äôre just waiting for the next one though‚Ä¶right?

 At least that‚Äôs the story you‚Äôre telling yourself.

 But even you don‚Äôt truly believe that anymore.

 You can live your entire life half in, half out, as most do.

 Indecision will kill you.

 It‚Äôs a slow, painful death.

 You‚Äôll learn to numb the pain, but with it will go your spark.

 Your exuberance, your hopefulness, your natural childlike spirit will be beaten down to a flicker.

 Fake laughs. Forced smiles. An artificial version of you, stripped of any charm or charisma.

 Floating from one day to the next.

 Not living, but existing.

 Indecision will kill you.

 ‚Äã Decide, commit, attack. ‚Äã

 Happy Friday,

 Ben

subject: Why you're not motivated
body:
Good morning {{ subscriber.first_name }},

 I started this beautiful Monday with a 30 minute walk and now I‚Äôm back at my desk.

 Important topic today ‚Äì motivation.

 A subscriber left a comment on my recent video saying he doesn‚Äôt feel like he has enough drive to be successful.

 He wants the things that come with success but just can‚Äôt get himself to do the work.

 This makes me think of a quote from a super rich guy you may have heard of named Jim Rohn.

 He said, ‚ÄúWe generally change ourselves for one of two reasons: inspiration or desperation.‚Äù

 This theory generally holds up when you listen to the stories of successful people.

 They were either in a horrible situation and had no choice but to claw their way out.

 Or they created the internal willpower required to take consistent action.

 I‚Äôm in boat number two.

 I was lucky enough to grow up in an affluent environment in a first world country with access to abundant resources including the internet.

 To end up in a position of desperation, I would‚Äôve had to make some seriously poor choices.

 And if you‚Äôre reading this right now from your phone or laptop in 2024, odds are you‚Äôre in a fairly similar spot.

 Even if you don‚Äôt come from any money, there are guardrails in place that will likely keep you from ending up as a homeless man under a bridge.

 Because of this, you have the ‚Äúluxury‚Äù of choice.

 You can follow the rules and live a semi-decent life.

 It won‚Äôt be extraordinary and you won‚Äôt exceed expectations, but you‚Äôll survive.

 To me, the idea of simply getting by and forgoing my natural desire to create an extraordinary life sounded like misery.

 I knew that if I allowed myself to choose comfort and familiarity over the slight possibility that everything in my dreams could come true, I‚Äôd hate myself.

 That‚Äôs where my inspiration came from.

 Although I wasn‚Äôt truly desperate, it felt like I had no other choice but to go after everything I wanted.

 If it didn‚Äôt work out, the guardrails I referenced earlier would still be there.

 So why not attack life with ferocity?

 Why not try to build myself into someone I am proud to be?

 Why not trade a dull life for one with ups, downs, and everything in between?

 Where I‚Äôm entirely in control of my own destiny and I have the power to make my reality as beautiful as I‚Äôd always dreamed.

 That was my inspiration and desperation in one.

 Inspired because I knew it could all be possible.

 Desperate because I knew I wasn‚Äôt put on this earth to be another brick in the wall.

 You‚Äôre capable of becoming everything you want to be.

 If you feel like you‚Äôre too comfortable to change, it‚Äôs because you‚Äôre not genuinely considering just how uncomfortable life would be if you let others make your decisions for you.

 That‚Äôs enough motivation for me.

 Reply and let me know if you liked this one.

 Happy Monday :)

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: This makes growth effortless
body:
I walked home from the coffee shop with my left shoe untied.

 And when I say untied, I mean it.

 Laces dragging on the ground. Everyone looking at me like I‚Äôm some sort of neanderthal with no regard for safety.

 Did I trip? Of course not.

 Imagine tripping due to a little string wrapped around your foot. Are you 12?

 Couldn‚Äôt be me.

 Although, my formerly white laces are now black from stepping on them into the pavement.

 Anyway, isn't it crazy that 2024 is almost over?

 The end of the year is always a good time to reflect.

 Odds are, you set some goals about 12 months ago.

 Let‚Äôs check in on them.

 Where are you settling?

 What are the things you told yourself that you‚Äôd do that you‚Äôre not doing?

 What areas of your life require more focus and attention?

 Personally, 2024 was a solid year but I feel like I didn‚Äôt squeeze as much juice out of it as I could have.

 I‚Äôm ready to step into a new reality.

 I feel like I have a real opportunity to grow my personal brand and I‚Äôve been settling a bit too much.

 If you‚Äôre in a similar spot when it comes to your business or any other area of life, here‚Äôs my advice to you:

 You must be the agent of change in your own life.

 Nothing happens unless you make it happen.

 If you don‚Äôt create order, it will be created for you.

 With new habits comes an increased level of pressure and responsibility.

 This will make you want to flinch.

 That voice in your head will attempt to pull you back down to where you were previously.

 The actualization of your goals and the new version of yourself that you‚Äôre aiming to become relies on your ability to shut out that voice.

 So make it easier on yourself.

 Implement small habits that allow you to stay on track with your goals.

 That could be jotting down some action items each night before bed or making a list of prospects you‚Äôre going to reach out to.

 It‚Äôs small changes like this that create a ripple effect over time.

 Momentum will start to carry you once you get the ball rolling.

 But you have to commit.

 Set a new standard for yourself and abide by it.

 Come this time next year, you‚Äôll be a completely different person. Likely with a much bigger number in your bank account.

 And you‚Äôll be incredibly grateful that you didn‚Äôt let your previous self stop you.

 You‚Äôre just a few small changes away from a completely different life.

 Get after it,

 Ben

 PS Use this to kickstart your journey and make 2025 the best year of your life. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: It's simple, but it makes you magnetic
body:
It‚Äôs impossible to be unhappy when you‚Äôre loved by everyone around you.

 A few months ago, I started working out with a personal trainer named Earl

 From the very first session I could tell we‚Äôd get along.

 You know when you meet someone and instantly click?

 That was Earl (no diddy).

 But it‚Äôs not just me.

 Everyone loves this guy.

 At the gym people constantly stop to greet him with warm smiles and choreographed handshakes.

 Last weekend, he had a birthday party with over 100 people in attendance.

 There‚Äôs just something magnetic about him.

 It sounds like I‚Äôm writing a love letter, but there‚Äôs an important lesson here.

 Everyone craves connection.

 Yet most of the interactions that people have in their day to day lives are dull.

 They‚Äôre just going through the motions ‚Äì no smiles, no small talk, no genuine compliments.

 It creates this energetic lull where life just doesn‚Äôt have any spark to it.

 But here‚Äôs the good news ‚Äì one small interaction can break this cycle.

 A simple smile.

 A quick compliment.

 A lighthearted conversation with a stranger.

 When you choose to be a bright spot in someone's day, your life gets brighter too.

 Why?

 Because your actions influence your emotions.

 When you act like someone who radiates joy and confidence, your brain begins to believe it ‚Äì and you become that person.

 If you‚Äôre low energy, angry, or sad remember:

 You have the power to snap out of it right now.

 Stop spending too much time alone.

 Stop being afraid of real human connection.

 Stop replaying negative thoughts.

 Instead, focus on making others smile, and that energy will find its way back to you.

 You‚Äôll become the kind of person who‚Äôs magnetic, confident, and happy ‚Äì like Earl.

 And when that happens, life gets a lot brighter.

 Be the light,

 Ben

 P.S. I made a banger Youtube video with my friend Phillip who turned $1 into millions of dollars. You can check it out here. ‚Äã

subject: Here's your answer
body:
Happy Friday,

 I just put up a Q&A on my second Instagram and will be answering some questions in this email.

 Here we go:

 ‚ÄúWhat's the piece of advice for the college kid grinding building a biz while others coast?‚Äù 

 You will look back at this time period in a few years and be grateful that you made the decision to start now.

 A wake up call is coming on graduation day.

 Most of your peers will get slapped in the face with the harsh reality that their actions over the last 4 years have put them in a tough spot.

 A degree (in most cases) no longer equals security ‚Äì Building a valuable skillset and network does.

 If you can block out the noise and the FOMO, your life can be everything you want it to be plus more in the near future.

 ‚ÄúHow do you know when you should change things up?‚Äù 

 Simple.

 Ask yourself ‚ÄúDo my actions align with the reality I want to create?‚Äù

 If not, adjust accordingly.

 You likely have this pit in your stomach that knows the truth.

 As every waking hour goes by it reminds you that you‚Äôre wasting your life.

 If you don‚Äôt change, that pit won‚Äôt go away on its own.

 It‚Äôll drain you every single day until you become a dull, lifeless version of the infinite being with limitless potential that you once were.

 That sounds fucking horrible.

 Don‚Äôt let that be you.

 ‚ÄúHow did you network at the beginning of your journey?‚Äù 

 The first element of building an amazing circle of friends who are all winners, is being on the path to become a winner yourself.

 You need to be building ‚Äì create better habits, start the business, audit and remove the broken pieces of your mindset that are holding you down.

 Begin documenting your journey on the internet.

 Naturally people who align with you will find you and vice versa.

 Hop on calls with those who you want to connect with. Plan a trip together. Become homies.

 Easy as.

 ‚ÄúHow can I get like you?‚Äù 

 By not trying to be like me or anyone else.

 By listening to your internal compass that knows the way.

 By following your natural curiosity with a childlike spirit.

 By creating your own standards and upholding them.

 This is how you become the fullest version, most authentic version of yourself.

 It takes life from black and white to color.

 It allows you to figure out who you really are and bring your uniqueness to the surface.

 Hope you enjoyed this one :)

 If you're not following my business Instagram account, you can do so here. ‚Äã

 Will be much more active on there in the near future.

 Have a good weekend,

 Ben

subject: Do this NOW (Or 2025 will suck)
body:
I‚Äôm 40,000 feet in the air, writing this from seat 4A.

 Heading home to Cincinnati over the Holidays.

 It‚Äôll be my first time back since last Christmas.

 This year has absolutely flown by, hasn‚Äôt it?

 I‚Äôm using this last week and a half of the year to prepare for 2025 and go into the new year with momentum.

 This is something I didn‚Äôt do a great job of going into 2024.

 I had a rough idea of what I wanted to accomplish and some goals written down, but I wasn‚Äôt very precise on the key levers that would make success inevitable.

 Because of this, it felt like I was playing catch up for the first few months of the year.

 This reminds me of something one of my high school basketball coaches used to always say‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre not 15 minutes early, you‚Äôre late.‚Äù

 It takes time to stretch out, tie your shoes, and get some shots up before practice.

 If you show up ‚Äúon time‚Äù you‚Äôll miss your chance to get ready and be underprepared.

 This is how I‚Äôm thinking of this period until January 1st.

 It‚Äôs the 15 minutes before ‚Äúgame-time‚Äù that will dictate whether or not I go into the new year ready to make it the best one yet.

 I‚Äôm ready to make more money than ever, explode on social media, build a bigger team, and simply turn up the dial in all facets of my life.

 So if you want to go into 2025 like a rocket shot out of a cannon while others kick their feet up till the new year‚Ä¶

 Here are some things you should get clear on:

 What's the one thing that would make 2025 a success? 

 This can be an income goal, fitness goal, social media growth, etc.

 Set your standards high and arrow it down to one thing that will make you feel accomplished.

 Be as specific as possible.

 How will you measure your progress towards that goal? 

 If you don‚Äôt track it, you don‚Äôt improve it.

 Create a system where you can continually measure your progress and make sure you‚Äôre staying on par.

 This can be as simple as using a google doc or notion sheet.

 Again, be specific and write down exactly how you‚Äôll keep track of growth.

 What processes can you put in place that will make the achievement of your goal inevitable? 

 These are the big levers.

 If you set an income goal, this could look like ‚Äúsend 10 quality outbound pitches per day.‚Äù

 You can write down a few things here that have a direct impact on the achievement of your main goal.

 There we have it‚Ä¶

 I highly encourage you to not overlook these three questions.

 I know it might look corny or basic ‚Äì I tend to have an aversion to doing things like this too.

 But this simple exercise can be the difference between a reality-changing 2025, versus yet another year where you feel like you didn‚Äôt make the strides you could‚Äôve.

 Be different. Put both feet on the gas. And lap all the dorks sipping eggnog in pajamas for the next 10 days.

 And if you REALLY want to get ahead ‚Äì go here now (only if you‚Äôre a psycho who‚Äôs ready to run through a fucking wall in order to make this your best year ever).

 Cheers,

 Ben

 P.S. If you noticed a new font in this email, congrats on being observant. I was re-reading some of my old emails and found the last font a bit hard to read. Do you like this one better?

subject: Is goal setting corny?
body:
In yesterday‚Äôs email I implored you to set clear goals going into 2025.

 There was a time where I thought doing this was a rather silly act.

 This was because when I started my business journey, I was sort of autistic about goal setting.

 Every few months I‚Äôd map out new 3, 6, and 12 month goals.

 I had clear targets to hit and planned exactly how I‚Äôd do so.

 After following this protocol for a while, I noticed that things almost never happened the way I planned.

 Although I‚Äôd make progress and typically come close to hitting my goals, I‚Äôd get rerouted a dozen times in the process and felt like an idiot for ever trying to map out the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù route.

 So I came to the conclusion that goal setting was corny.

 It‚Äôs for the Instagram coaches who‚Äôve never built a real business.

 The room temperature IQ neanderthals who get an erection when talking about their morning routine.

 I‚Äôm not naive enough to think that things will happen the exact way I plan them, so I don‚Äôt need to set goals.

 Or at least that‚Äôs what I thought‚Ä¶

 Looking back, when I set clear targets I progressed quicker.

 Sure the path comes with twists, turns, and hurdles that I could‚Äôve never anticipated, but that‚Äôs not important.

 What IS important is the fact that goal setting gives you a starting point.

 You have a target you want to hit.

 A method to track your progress.

 And daily actions to make it happen.

 That‚Äôs all that matters.

 Obviously unexpected events will occur ‚Äì you might find an alternative vehicle that proves to be a better fit.

 You‚Äôre not a genie with a crystal ball.

 But don‚Äôt let that stop you from giving yourself that clear mission and starting point.

 Objectively, you will operate better when doing so.

 Don‚Äôt fool yourself into thinking you‚Äôre smarter than other people because you don‚Äôt ‚Äúneed‚Äù to set goals.

 Accept that your plans will likely change and adapt to future circumstances.

 That‚Äôs okay.

 Alright?

 This might‚Äôve been more of a message to myself than it was for you, but it‚Äôs an important thing to note nonetheless.

 Let me know if you liked this one {{ subscriber.first_name }} :)

 - Ben

subject: is the American dream dead?
body:
I remember being around the age of 12 or 13 when I first started to conceptualize money. 

 Many of the houses in the area I grew up in were $1m plus.

 At the time I was told that $100k per year is a really good salary.

 After doing some math in my head, it didn‚Äôt make sense.

 If a nice house costs one million dollars‚Ä¶

 And a good salary was $100k‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôm supposed to work for 10 years and somehow miraculously save every penny before I can buy a house?

 Obviously I was oversimplifying it but this broke my adolescent brain at the time.

 It just didn‚Äôt make sense.

 Not long after I realized that if I want to live a good life, I have to get rich.

 Not a couple million dollars net worth by 65, rich ‚Äì But real rich. Fast.

 Millions in my 20‚Äôs, tens of millions in my 30‚Äôs and so on.

 After coming to this realization about the world, my life changed forever.

 I began to see reality through a new lens.

 And in this one, I was in control.

 ‚Äã Is the American dream dead? ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: How to use "loss aversion" in your favor
body:
Merry Christmas {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Hope you‚Äôre enjoying the day with your fam.

 I bought myself a fancy new camera today.

 I was long overdue for an upgrade so I got the Canon R5 with the 15-35mm lens.

 All in, it cost me a little over $5k.

 But I didn‚Äôt buy it because of the quality upgrade (that‚Äôs a bonus).

 Personally, I think equipment is somewhat overrated.

 If your content is good enough, it will perform if you film on a potato.

 The main reason I upgraded is because it‚Äôs a commitment to myself.

 Since I spent the money on a new camera I‚Äôll have more pressure to put it to good use.

 I‚Äôm using this concept in psychology called loss aversion to motivate myself.

 Basically it means that people value keeping what they have even more than they value acquiring things they don‚Äôt have.

 I spent enough money to where it stings a bit and I don‚Äôt want to feel like I wasted it.

 So with this additional motivation, I have a lot of content coming for you in the new year.

 I feel like I left some gas in the tank in this area in 2024.

 Sure my audience grew, but I didn‚Äôt put in nearly as much effort as I could‚Äôve.

 There was one 3 month streak where I was consistent on Youtube, posting 3x per week.

 Over that time, I went from basically zero to 10k subscribers.

 Even then, there was minimal planning or strategy behind my videos.

 I can‚Äôt help but wonder what I could do with more intentionality and consistency.

 Time will tell.

 Since we‚Äôre on this topic ‚Äì that‚Äôs a good way to find new opportunities that can offer you asymmetric returns.

 Audit your efforts right now and see if there‚Äôs anything where you‚Äôre getting more out than what you‚Äôre putting in.

 Maybe there‚Äôs a part of your business that comes easy to you and whenever you focus on it, you make more money.

 And maybe it would be wise to double down on that thing.

 However I must add a disclaimer ‚Äì this advice is dangerous in the wrong hands.

 If you‚Äôre in the beginning stages of your journey, odds are nothing is easy right now.

 You‚Äôre fighting an uphill battle.

 Don‚Äôt look for the easy way out because there isn‚Äôt one.

 You have to keep climbing until you break through a lot of the natural barriers that come with change.

 Only once you do that, can you position yourself to go ‚Äúdownhill‚Äù where you have gravity working in your favor.

 I know this email has been a bit jumpy, so thanks for sticking with me here.

 I encourage you to do something in these next few days that will force you to commit.

 Risk something that you have to get something you don‚Äôt.

 You‚Äôll likely end up with more than you could‚Äôve imagined.

 Merry Christmas,

 Ben

 P.S. Go watch this if you haven't already ‚Äã

subject: Business is like hot wheels
body:
Business success is like a battery powered toy car.

 Imagine you‚Äôre an 8 year old with snot on your face.

 For Christmas, you got a miniature brown Bugatti with a bald action figure sitting in the passenger seat.

 You rip it out of the box and put it on the ground.

 Excitedly, you click the ‚Äúon‚Äù button and‚Ä¶

 Nothing happens.

 You turn it off and on again‚Ä¶

 Nothing.

 And then it clicks inside your little pea brain.

 Batteries!

 Your Bugatti needs 2 double A batteries.

 You run upstairs and say ‚ÄúMom! Get me some fucking double A batteries ASAP no rocky!‚Äù

 To your disappointment, your Mom is hammered.

 She caught your Dad cheating on her with your Uncle so she‚Äôs numbing the pain with two bottles of Ros√©.

 ‚ÄúDammit! She won‚Äôt be able to drive to the store,‚Äù you think to yourself.

 Time to take matters into your own hands.

 You scour the house for batteries, opening the back of every TV remote.

 None of them fit into your toy car.

 You‚Äôd ask your Dad for help but he‚Äôs upstairs with Uncle Timmy.

 So you decide to hop in his Ford F-150.

 You can barely see over the steering wheel so you grab a pipe from the garage as an extension to your foot.

 Next thing you know you‚Äôre pulling out of the driveway.

 Luckily you‚Äôve played a lot of GTA.

 By some miracle, you make it to the store, find the batteries, check out, and make it back home.

 Finally you put the batteries in the bottom of the car and you‚Äôre off to the races.

 Congrats kid.

 Now {{ subscriber.first_name }} you‚Äôre probably thinking...

 ‚ÄúAre you going anywhere with this or are you just telling me a fabricated, alarming story about an unsupervised child with an alcoholic mother and gay father?‚Äù

 Here‚Äôs how this relates to you and your business success:

 Right now, you‚Äôre that toy Bugatti.

 If you‚Äôre a complete beginner, you have to get batteries before you can start moving.

 That means you go down Youtube rabbit holes, read books, watch courses, and start practicing your skills.

 The car won‚Äôt start moving yet (you won‚Äôt make any money).

 But you‚Äôre installing the necessary batteries that will allow you to go fast.

 Welcome to the trenches :)

 It‚Äôs impossible to say how much time you‚Äôll spend here, but I can promise you that on the other side is everything you‚Äôve ever wanted.

 Once you get through, you‚Äôll hit the gas.

 And if you're someone who's already been through the trenches...

 Maybe you've been trying to build an agency for a while or you've been grinding in a sales gig.

 All you need now, are the right batteries -- A higher leveraged opportunity.

 Finally, you‚Äôll be rewarded for all of your previously unrewarded effort.

 Just don‚Äôt quit before you even get the right batteries installed.

 Let me know if you liked this one,

 Ben

subject: If you're ready to lock in, do this
body:
Happy final Monday of the year, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 I‚Äôve been so focused on building momentum going into 2025, that it feels like it started 2 weeks ago.

 Typically I would have plans for New Years Eve, but I‚Äôm leaning towards staying in.

 This year I learned an important lesson‚Ä¶

 Over the past 12 months, I‚Äôve had a lot of fun.

 I‚Äôve traveled a bit, gone out frequently, have met a lot of new people, and taken on some side quests.

 There was a period before that where I was barely doing anything.

 Work, gym, eat, sleep. The business was growing, but life felt a bit dull.

 So throughout 2024, I sort of fucked off.

 I realized that I could still make solid money without being at my desk all day.

 My income fluctuated from $60K-$140k/mo throughout the year.

 I‚Äôve been maintaining ‚Äì but not growing.

 Now I‚Äôve reached a point where I feel the same way I did towards the end of my ‚Äúgrind phase,‚Äù except it‚Äôs reversed.

 I want to work more.

 Sure, I can maintain my current income level with minimal effort, but what happens if I push?

 I want another supercar. I want a penthouse. I want to invest $50k/mo.

 In that order, lol.

 This speaks to the seasons in life. I‚Äôm glad I turned on ‚Äúcruise control‚Äù for a while because it reignited my visceral urge to get richer.

 So now, we‚Äôre here.

 If you‚Äôre in the same boat and you want to put all 3 of your feet on the gas heading into the new year, this video will give you a blueprint. ‚Äã

 I‚Äôve never been more bullish on the opportunities inside of the online education space.

 And I‚Äôll show you how you can get a sliver of this $180 billion market‚Ä¶

 To locking in,

 Ben

 P.S. This industry will make you a millionaire in 2025 ‚Äã

subject: The world is yours
body:
It‚Äôs a beautiful 75 degree, sunny day in Miami.

 And it also happens to be January 1st.

 4 years ago, this month was a pivotal one in my online business career.

 I drained my bank account and bought a $5,000 coaching program.

 I began journaling every day, describing the new version of myself that I was becoming in vivid detail.

 I got my first few free trial clients for my agency.

 Here‚Äôs an excerpt from my journal entry on January 15, 2021:

 ‚ÄúI am building my business that generates $10,000 per month with little of my time. I am able to go where I want, buy what I want, and meet who I want. Reality bends itself to my desires. I am in the driver‚Äôs seat, steering the ship on how my life goes. I am in full control. Money loves me. I attract more and more of it daily. I find new ways to make money with ease. I live a life that has no bounds. My friends look up to me. My parents are proud of me. I am able to help my brothers. I am the person I have always wanted to be.‚Äù

 None of this was true at the time.

 But 2 months later I closed my first 3 paying clients at $1k per month each.

 By August, I hit $10k months and dropped out of college.

 I moved to Mexico and reached $15k months.

 Now as I sit here writing to you 4 years later, my life looks even better than the way I used to dream of it.

 I‚Äôve built a 7 figure agency, grown my personal brand, and started helping others replicate my success. ‚Äã

 I‚Äôm telling you all to show you that I‚Äôm not special.

 I was once lost, undisciplined, and unfocused.

 But a series of decisions led me here.

 I began taking life seriously and I understood that nothing would change unless I made it change.

 New year's resolutions are corny and perhaps this is just some arbitrary date on the calendar‚Ä¶

 But your words are powerful.

 Today, you can decide that you‚Äôll no longer accept mediocrity for yourself.

 You can begin keeping the promises you‚Äôve made internally.

 You can take full control of your life and commit to your goals.

 And I promise you‚Ä¶

 In a few months you‚Äôll start to see your dreams come to fruition.

 In a year you won‚Äôt recognize the old you.

 In a few years, your life will be better than you ever imagined.

 And you‚Äôll be glad you started today.

 The world is yours‚Ä¶ if you‚Äôre ready for it. ‚Äã

 Happy New Year,

 Ben

subject: RE: Using the law of attraction to get rich
body:
Before I get into today's email, let me show you some recent W‚Äôs from Artisan Lab:

 ‚Äã Briar quit his 9-5 and went from 0-$20k/month in 6 months. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã Kabrin scaled to $35k/month in 5 months building simple VSL funnels for clients. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã Dean went from being a burnt out closer to making $27k/mo in 3 months. ‚Äã

 If you‚Äôre in the info-product agency space or thinking about getting into it, the student interviews above should be incredibly valuable for you.

 Alrighty.

 I hope you‚Äôve taken time to give yourself clarity on your goals and you‚Äôre ready to crush 2025.

 If so, congrats.

 You‚Äôve completed phase one.

 Just as important is phase two, which you‚Äôll be entering soon.

 As you execute on your plan over the following weeks and months, you will inevitably hit a wall.

 One day you will wake up and think to yourself, ‚ÄúFuck this. I‚Äôve been putting in all of this work and I‚Äôve gotten nothing in return.‚Äù

 Maybe that voice will temporarily win and you‚Äôll go back to your old ways for a few days.

 That‚Äôs normal.

 But what you do at this point will determine how the rest of the year goes for you.

 You can right the ship and get back on track.

 Or you can continue to spiral and discard the goals you set.

 This is a decision you‚Äôll likely have to make within the next month or so.

 Once the motivation and excitement fades a bit, resistance will rear its head.

 When it does, remember this:

 You set those goals for a reason.

 There is a version of you who is living the exact life you outlined.

 You‚Äôre driving your dream car, you‚Äôve become friends with incredible people, you live where you want, etc.

 You‚Äôre proud of the person you‚Äôve become.

 That doesn‚Äôt happen overnight and it doesn‚Äôt come easily.

 When you feel resistance, you‚Äôre being tested.

 Is {{ subscriber.first_name }} actually committed this time?

 Can your spirit be deflated?

 Are you worthy of having the things you want?

 If you pass these tests consistently, eventually you will become that 2.0 version of yourself.

 Because you are actively creating data to prove this.

 You‚Äôve held yourself accountable, raised your standards, and thus become a person who has reached a higher level of consciousness.

 And then, you attract everything you‚Äôve ever wanted.

 Not trying to get too spiritual on you here, but this is the basic premise of the law of attraction.

 Or I guess you could just throw crystals under your pillow and hope for the best.

 Either way, good things are coming if you remain steadfast in your commitment to yourself.

 Let‚Äôs get rich,

 Ben

 P.S. Reply and lmk if you liked this one :)

 ‚Äã

subject: The 3 phases to reach $100k/month
body:
Okay, I have a less philosophical email for you today‚Ä¶

 You could be the most profound thinker of the 21st century.

 But no one will listen if you‚Äôre poor.

 Everything you say will have an asterisk next to it.

 *Take any advice or opinion with a grain of salt. This person lacks the basic competence necessary to provide for themself and their family.*

 ‚ÄúOMG Ben, that's so insensitive‚Äù‚Äì shut up.

 Let‚Äôs talk about how to get fucking rich‚Ä¶ Specifically working with people who sell info.

 I‚Äôm gonna break this down into phases for you (if you already have a client or two you can skip to phase 3):

 Phase 1: Exit the clueless monkey 

 You‚Äôre lost.

 You hear about all these people making money online and the different ways of doing so.

 You don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs legit and what isn‚Äôt.

 You feel like a monkey who was taken out of the wild and placed at a dinner party.

 Here‚Äôs how to change this ‚Äì Immerse yourself into the online business space.

 Tailor your social media feed to show you less baddies and more money.

 Build a swipe file of funnels, email copy, VSLs, etc.

 Phase 2: Enter the arena 

 Once you understand the basics, you need to start getting real practice.

 Write samples. Ask Chat GPT or Claude AI to grade them.

 Keep improving and start doing outreach.

 Don‚Äôt listen to the voice that tells you that you‚Äôre not ready.

 Send as many high quality outreach messages as you can daily (I will teach you how to do this). ‚Äã

 Don‚Äôt stop until you get a client.

 Phase 3: Squeeze the lemon 

 Congrats. You got a client or two.

 What you do now, can change your life.

 Imagine a billionaire hires you as a personal assistant.

 He tasks you with getting his coffee in the morning and that‚Äôs it.

 So, you spend the rest of your day finding ways to make his life easier.

 He sees your hard work and makes you his next of kin.

 This is *basically* what can happen if you maximize the opportunity with one solid client.

 Go above and beyond to improve any area of their business, even if you‚Äôre not directly responsible for it.

 This can snowball into a 5 figure rev share from that client. Plus a case study you can use to get more clients.

 There‚Äôs your 0-$100k/month blueprint.

 I know it sounds simple.

 The only part that‚Äôs more complicated is the identification of bottlenecks.

 Once you get a client, you have to be able to correctly assess the levers which need to be pulled to scale them.

 And before that, you have to determine if they‚Äôre even in a position that will allow them to scale.

 In Artisan Lab, you‚Äôll learn how to do all of this.

 You‚Äôll know who to reach out to, what a high quality pitch looks like, what to offer, how to close the deal, and how to make your clients a boatload of money.

 ‚Äã Go here now and apply to join the winning team :) ‚Äã

 Talk soon,

 Ben

subject: A new way to view risk
body:
Before I get into it, I just made a new video that‚Äôll show you how to make $20k/mo partnering with online coaches.

 ‚Äã You can watch it here. ‚Äã

 It‚Äôs an incredible day here in Miami.

 Did you know I live on the 80-somethingth floor?

 I can basically see the end of the Earth from up here. It‚Äôs definitely flat.

 I‚Äôm on my balcony watching the boats go by.

 The water is this beautiful blueish-greenish color and the sun is beaming, so it looks even more vibrant than usual.

 Switching gears to a much more somber note ‚Äì I truly think some people are just NGMI (not gonna make it).

 It‚Äôs not that they can‚Äôt ‚Äúmake it‚Äù but rather that they won‚Äôt allow themselves.

 They‚Äôre too comfortable in their current self-image.

 Things aren‚Äôt bad enough because their perception of risk to reward is flawed.

 Going after what they want seems like this big leap of faith where if they fail their life is over.

 Obviously that‚Äôs almost never the case. If you put your all into anything, you will naturally unlock an abundance of additional opportunities.

 But they don‚Äôt understand this.

 So even though they may be unhappy, the desire to change doesn‚Äôt outweigh the perceived pain of it.

 From the outside looking in it‚Äôs easy to see that the ‚Äúpain‚Äù really isn‚Äôt that bad.

 Sure, upgrading any area of your life comes with challenges ‚Äì whether it‚Äôs financial pursuit or a different quest.

 And sure, there may be some level of risk involved but when you truly weigh your options, you see reality clearly.

 You can stay the same forever, merely flirting with the idea of success.

 Or you can think, ‚ÄúWhy not? I‚Äôll put my all into this endeavor and worst case scenario I end up back where I was beforehand.‚Äù

 Does that sound incredibly risky?

 To me, it doesn‚Äôt.

 And that‚Äôs why I think I was able to muster up the courage to attack my dream life despite the fact that I never had it that bad.

 As Socrates once said, ‚Äúfuck it, we ball.‚Äù

 So as I sit here, writing this from my castle in the sky, I‚Äôm grateful that I‚Äôve been able to view risk through this lens.

 It will work out for you too.

 But you actually have to allow yourself to try.

 I‚Äôll leave you with a tweet I wrote over two years ago ‚Äì ‚ÄúYou're hesitant to hit the gas because you know it raises the bar. The further you get from the bottom the harder it‚Äôll be to go back. You know what you're capable of but you're afraid to hold yourself to that standard. Then it's no longer an option to show up every day.‚Äù

 Go after everything you desire.

 ‚Äã It will be worth it, ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: AI is going to take your job
body:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}. This is important.

 There‚Äôs a popular meme amongst NBA fans.

 When a player can‚Äôt compete in the league, they often go play in China or another country.

 ‚ÄúGet ready to learn Chinese buddy‚Äù has become a popular phrase because of this.

 When a player is struggling, you‚Äôll find that sentence in the comment section.

 There is a similar phenomenon going on in the copywriting world‚Ä¶

 AI is going to take your job.

 I‚Äôm 100% serious. This is not a drill.

 If you‚Äôve been neglecting it, I‚Äôd highly advise you to stop.

 You will be demoted to putting fries in the bag for a living quite soon.

 Get ready to learn minimum wage buddy.

 Up until recently, this was me.

 Although I‚Äôve been using AI for some time, I felt like I was just scratching the surface.

 I‚Äôd have it write or critique email copy, VSL‚Äôs, content ideas and more.

 It was a useful tool, but I wasn‚Äôt amazed.

 And when I‚Äôd try to have it write copy for me, it‚Äôd do so a 4 or 5 out of 10.

 It wasn‚Äôt horrible, but it read like a non-native english speaker who just discovered a dictionary.

 Bland and robotic. When I‚Äôd try to get it to spice things up it‚Äôd sound too try-hardy.

 Nonetheless, it was somewhat useful.

 That was until I got better at prompting and training it.

 This took it from a 4/10 to an 8/10.

 And I STILL think I‚Äôm just scratching the surface.

 When you input enough data with the right prompt(s) it‚Äôs capable of writing a sufficient email that‚Äôs indistinguishable from human copy.

 I‚Äôd be willing to bet it‚Äôs better than 99% of beginner to intermediate level writers.

 Here‚Äôs what this means for you:

 It‚Äôs a tool that you NEED to utilize.

 Go down the rabbit hole and become familiar with popular AI softwares (not just Chat GPT).

 Once you do so, it will make you better, more efficient, and nearly do your job for you.

 It‚Äôs not something to fear, IF you learn it.

 If you don‚Äôt‚Ä¶ well N«ê h«éo, my friend.

 Extra large fries please.

 If you want to see how I‚Äôm using it inside of my business‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã I‚Äôll be sharing everything I learn about AI in the coming months here. ‚Äã

 Don‚Äôt get left behind,

 Ben

subject: One DM changed my entire business model
body:
Let me take you back to November, 2021.

 I‚Äôm living in Merida, Mexico after spending the last couple months in Playa Del Carmen and Tulum.

 My days are simple.

 Wake up at 8am, bike 15 minutes to the gym, and try to get agency clients.

 It‚Äôs working‚Ä¶ sort of.

 I hit a new high score, of $16,037 profit for the month.

 The only issue?

 It took SIXTEEN clients to get here.

 Most of them are local basketball trainers paying me $1k/month for lead gen and automation.

 Many of which have broken sales processes, so getting results is difficult.

 They‚Äôre constantly churning, I‚Äôm constantly replacing, and it's leaving me constantly stressed.

 Then, one small pivot changed everything.

 I‚Äôm scrolling through Instagram and decide to pitch a slightly different type of prospect.

 Instead of selling in person training, he‚Äôs selling online training.

 He has a big personal brand and I actually used to watch his content.

 His business partner replied the next day.

 3 months later, he became a paying client.

 5 months after that, I‚Äôm still making $16k/month.

 But this time, only with 6 clients.

 All of which are selling online coaching, not just basketball anymore.

 A Youtube coach, Amazon FBA offer, and sales trainer.

 Your typical make money online gurus.

 Fast forward one year‚Ä¶

 I hit my first $100k month with just 7 clients.

 The difference maker?

 I applied my existing skill set to higher leverage opportunities.

 While I was running the basketball trainer agency, I got really good at one thing:

 Copywriting.

 I used it to write emails, VSLs, and build funnels.

 Because I handled all of their marketing, they were happy to pay me a rev share.

 That‚Äôs how I went from charging just $1k/month to up to $45k/month.

 And now, AI has made this easier than ever.

 Feed it the right data, master the prompts, and it'll write 80% of your copy.

 Inside Artisan Lab , I‚Äôll teach you this exact system.

 With the right skills and opportunity, one client can pay you more than a neurosurgeon.

 Which is exactly what many of my students are doing.

 ‚Äã Join us here. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: RE: your resolutions
body:
This is the breaking point.

 Remember the goals you set 8 days ago?

 It‚Äôs this time of the year where most people revert back to old habits.

 The motivation and excitement fades.

 And the excuses are creeping back in.

 This is the emotional cycle of change at work.

 Stage 1: Pure excitement "This is it. I‚Äôm finally committed."

 Stage 2: Reality check "Damn, this is actually a lot of work..."

 Stage 3: The dip "Maybe I'm not ready for this..."

 Stage 4: The breakthrough "Wait... I think I'm figuring this out..."

 Stage 5: Momentum "Can't believe I almost quit."

 Right now, you're probably somewhere between stages 2 and 3.

 The initial excitement has worn off.

 The path feels harder than expected.

 Your old comfort zone is looking enticing.

 This is exactly where most people quit.

 They think because it got hard, something's wrong.

 But difficulty isn't a sign to stop.

 It's a sign you're finally playing the game.

 Welcome, my friend.

 What you do right now will make or break the rest of your year.

 You can decide to step into the 2.0 version of yourself and actualize the goals you‚Äôve set‚Ä¶

 Or you can let the natural desire to resist change, win.

 Just remember this:

 Goals aren't achieved through motivation.

 They're achieved through showing up when motivation dies.

 Through pushing forward when everyone else quits.

 Through accepting that it's supposed to feel hard.

 Show up for yourself today.

 Lambos, champagne, and models feeding you grapes on a Yacht in the South France await.

 But you have to push through this part.

 By the end of the year, you‚Äôll be unrecognizable.

 ‚Äã Ready to make this the best year of your life? I‚Äôll help you here. ‚Äã

 To overcoming resistance,

 Ben

 P.S. AI wrote 80% of this email. In the future I‚Äôll keep it 100% real me, but I just wanted to show you what AI is capable of when you feed it the correct prompts. More on this in here :) ‚Äã

subject: Stop resisting your dream life
body:
The secret is that you already know the secret.

 You‚Äôre looking for solutions to problems that you have the key to unlock.

 The anxiety ridden cloud in the back of your mind can be gone in an instant.

 But you keep searching.

 ‚ÄúMaybe if I move across the country.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúMaybe if I watch another Youtube video.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúMaybe if I try a different business model.‚Äù

 You‚Äôll do anything to avoid taking the obvious action.

 In Steven Pressfield‚Äôs book, The War Of Art, he calls this ‚Äúresistance.‚Äù

 It‚Äôs the internal force stopping you from pursuing creative endeavors and personal growth.

 Most succumb to it and live dull lives void of any self expression.

 Every day, you have the option to overcome this.

 Only once you start acting despite this resistance, will it lose power over you.

 Although it‚Äôll never disappear entirely, you‚Äôll learn that it‚Äôs okay to not know exactly how things will work out.

 You never will.

 This morning, someone commented on my recent Youtube video asking, ‚ÄúCan I do this as a complete beginner?‚Äù

 Here‚Äôs my answer:

 No‚Ä¶ at least, not with that mindset.

 No one will ever grant you permission to begin going after what you want in life.

 You will never feel ready, especially if you think that some external opinion or event will make you ready.

 I am not the guard at the gate of your desires holding a magic wand.

 Neither is anyone else.

 You hold the wand.

 You are making the conscious decision to either let your fear control you or accept that it‚Äôll never go away.

 You decide when you are going to overcome resistance.

 Win that battle. Your dream life awaits.

 Ben

 P.S. I just created what‚Äôs likely the most informative Youtube video I‚Äôve ever posted.

 It‚Äôll show you step by step how to land a great client that you can actually get results for.

 Then how to scale with them and leverage that case study to get more clients and scale past $20k/month.

 And in the process, you‚Äôll beat the resistance that‚Äôs holding you back.

 ‚Äã Go here to watch the video now. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: The plague that no one is talking about
body:
There‚Äôs a plague happening right now.

 It‚Äôs incredibly common but people rarely talk about it online.

 I‚Äôve gotten it, as well as my friends, and nearly every successful entrepreneur I know.

 And you‚Äôre bound to get it too, if you haven‚Äôt already.

 But when you scroll through social media, you‚Äôd think everyones immune‚Ä¶

 It‚Äôs Monday morning.

 Your favorite guru is up before the sun.

 He just went through his 7 step morning routine.

 Now he‚Äôs sitting at his desk making moves that‚Äôll result in generational wealth.

 Or at least, that‚Äôs what he wants you to think.

 Unseen is the plague ‚Äì the constant battle against complacency.

 It affects some more than others, but anyone who tells you they‚Äôve never experienced it is smoking crack.

 And it‚Äôs not exclusive to those who are already successful.

 Before I made any money online, there was a period where I just couldn‚Äôt get myself to do the work.

 I‚Äôd sit there at my computer, knowing that all I needed to do was send outbound messages.

 My finger would hover over the keyboard for a bit and next thing you know I‚Äôm watching Derrick Rose basketball highlights from 2010.

 Objectively, I was nowhere near the point where I should be complacent.

 But somehow, complacency would win.

 Though I eventually beat it, it never went away entirely.

 I‚Äôd feel the constant battle against this plague at every level of income I reached.

 And last year I reached a point where my life was pretty damn good.

 I bought my dream car. $100k months were easy. My lifestyle was incredibly fun.

 And complacency reared its ugly head again.

 For a while, it won.

 Until one day I woke up and thought to myself‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúBrother, you‚Äôre putting in a fraction of the effort you could be, and things are still working. What would happen if you go all in?‚Äù

 Perhaps this sounds familiar.

 Whether you‚Äôre just starting out, or you‚Äôve gotten comfortable at your current level of income.

 I‚Äôll offer you some advice a mentor of mine gave me recently‚Ä¶

 If life‚Äôs already good at this level, imagine how much better it is at levels above this. 

 We‚Äôre playing a never ending game here.

 The higher you go, the better life gets.

 Not because you can buy another supercar, move to a better place, and take care of those around you (although that‚Äôs a nice plus).

 But because you‚Äôre actualizing the potential you know you have inside of you.

 With each level you progress, you unlock an upgraded version of yourself.

 And after all, what else is there to do?

 ‚Äã Resist the plague and life will keep getting better. ‚Äã

 To overcoming complacency,

 Ben

 It‚Äôs incredibly common but people rarely talk about it online.

 I‚Äôve gotten it, as well as my friends, and nearly every successful entrepreneur I know.

 And y

subject: The Tik Tok Ban
body:
Tik Tok is NOT getting banned.

 Although I can‚Äôt make a logical argument to support that claim, I‚Äôve been through enough breakups and make-ups to know this is a smokescreen.

 You know when your girlfriend says ‚ÄúOk, this is it I‚Äôm actually done this time!‚Äù

 And then she ‚Äúforgets‚Äù her bag at your place and has to come get it the next day‚Ä¶

 What happens?

 Exactly.

 This is one of those.

 At least I think.

 If it does get banned, it‚Äôll be interesting to see what happens next.

 More traffic to Instagram reels?

 YT shorts?

 A new platform?

 Who knows. But honestly I think the Chinese algorithm is better than all of them.

 It just knows me so well.

 My fyp consists of Johnny Walker, NBA highlights, and random comedy I didn‚Äôt know I was even interested in beforehand.

 This whole situation is like the normie super bowl.

 ‚ÄúWoohoo course seller! Now you have to go get a real job like the rest of us!!‚Äù

 Little do they know‚Ä¶ If the ban strikes, we will stand here, unfazed .

 Ready to pounce on whatever opportunity this creates.

 Plus many personal brands have built an email list, Instagram, and Youtube. So one platform getting shut down isn‚Äôt the end of the world.

 This reminds me of the common skepticism that unaware people have when you tell them you‚Äôre starting a business.

 They‚Äôll say some shit like, ‚ÄúWell what happens when that gets too saturated! What if AI takes your job? Can‚Äôt a business owner just do that on their own?‚Äù

 Lol.

 Yes, unforeseen events can occur.

 Yes, there will be times where you are forced to adapt.

 Yes, AI is advancing at a rapid rate.

 Good thing you‚Äôre a business owner who‚Äôs built a plethora of skills, a network, and developed a mental fortitude that allows you to thrive in any environment.

 Hold that L skeptic.

 Fries. Bag. Now. Extra large coke. Keep the change. You filthy animal.

 I am an infinite being with limitless potential. My unmatched perspicacity coupled with sheer indefatigability makes me a feared opponent in any realm of human endeavour.

 Damn that really is a bar.

 Anyway this email has gone off the rails a bit but I assure you:

 No matter what happens with Tik Tok, AI, and any other unforeseen events‚Ä¶

 If you focus on mastering your craft, innovating, and creating leverage ‚Äì there will always be endless opportunities at your fingertips.

 ‚Äã Your success is inevitable. ‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. Reply and lmk if you liked this one

 ‚Äã

subject: Rules are for ugly people
body:
It‚Äôs an early one today.

 I‚Äôm starting this at 8:17am from my phone, sitting outside of Starbucks.

 They‚Äôre playing ‚ÄúNice N Easy‚Äù by Frank Sinatra.

 It‚Äôs 60 degrees and sunny-ish, which is cold for Miami but it feels good.

 I took the scenic route here - a 25 minute walk along the water, circle around and walk back towards my apartment to get to the coffee shop.

 They didn‚Äôt put the lid on all the way but luckily I spotted it before dumping the cup on myself shirt.

 You know, most copywriters will tell you that the way I‚Äôm writing right now is flawed.

 1 topic per email.

 Don‚Äôt get sidetracked.

 Don‚Äôt use more than 14 words per sentence.

 Blah blah blah.

 Rules like that are made for people who aren‚Äôt good enough to break them.

 This applies to any realm of human endeavor (lol).

 If you lean in to your authentic edge ‚Äî and you‚Äôre good, you can do most things ‚Äúwrong‚Äù and still win.

 Everyone advises you to follow some content system‚Ä¶

 You do the opposite. It works. They copy you.

 The Golden State Warriors shoot too many threes. They win four NBA championships. Now everyone‚Äôs chucking threes.

 See my point?

 Lean into your own unique edge.

 This is not school. You won‚Äôt get expelled for carving your own path.

 Walk through life with that spark in your eye that only ignites when you‚Äôre authentically you.

 Most never get to access it past childhood.

 And sure, there are times where the common system is best to follow.

 Remain aware of the norm and let it serve as a starting point, not an unbreakable rule book.

 Got it?

 Good.

 When you‚Äôre authentically you, you leave an indelible mark on everything around you.

 And your success is undeniably, inevitably, certain.

 Break more rules,

 Ben

 P.S. If you're an existing copywriter, agency owner, or closer‚Ä¶ this will help you. ‚Äã

subject: How I landed a 9 figure client
body:
A client of mine ran his first webinar last night.

 He‚Äôs a Miami resident, so my partner and I pulled up to his studio to help him get set up.

 It was my first time meeting him in person and let me tell you ‚Äì this guy is a savage.

 For the sake of the email let‚Äôs call him Tony.

 Tony‚Äôs made 9 figures in Real Estate and recently hopped on social media, sharing his story.

 His audience has grown to the hundreds of thousands fast.

 He‚Äôs got 4 decades of experience in RE. Billions of dollars in transactions.

 When someone is this successful for this long, obviously there‚Äôs a lot to be learned.

 My first observation was how energetic he is.

 Although he's in his 60‚Äôs, he‚Äôs sharp as a tac.

 The guy goes through a pack of Neurogum a day (lol) and is always on the move.

 He was telling me about this new office they‚Äôre moving into‚Ä¶

 Then how he‚Äôs shooting content 3 days a week‚Ä¶

 Then about the new properties he‚Äôs developing.

 He just doesn‚Äôt stop.

 Working like this definitely keeps him young.

 I pitched Tony about 6 months ago and we started working together.

 He told me ‚ÄúI went with you because I liked your confidence. It was almost arrogance but that‚Äôs what you need in a team. I didn‚Äôt want someone who was timid.‚Äù

 Since then we‚Äôve scaled from zero to multiple six figure months with him.

 As I‚Äôve met more older, wealthy people over the past couple years, I‚Äôm always astounded by how normal they are.

 I used to think deca-millionaires and centimillionaires must be so unrelatable and serious.

 But as we sat at this burger restaurant after the webby, Tony was cracking jokes and telling stories.

 He‚Äôs a normal guy ‚Äì just with decades of hard work and calculated decisions under his belt.

 And that's the thing about success...

 The people who achieve it aren't superhuman.

 They're just normal people who make different decisions consistently.

 Tony's not successful because he's special.

 He's successful because he shows up with energy every day, takes massive action, and makes calculated moves.

 But here's what really struck me...

 At 60+ years old, he's still pushing. Still learning. Still adapting.

 While most people his age are slowing down, he's speeding up.

 This is what separates the elite from everyone else.

 Want to see exactly how I landed Tony as a client and scaled him to multiple six figures per month?

 ‚Äã Get access to the full breakdown inside of here. ‚Äã

 To calculated confidence,

 Ben

 P.S. Using the exact same pitch that landed Tony, my students are now closing their dream clients every week. You can be next. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: I'm buying a Penthouse
body:
Hello and happy Friday, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Good news‚Ä¶

 I got my business Instagram account back.

 If you‚Äôre not following yet, you should ‚Äì the movement has commenced and I want you to be a part of it.

 Yesterday, I was browsing condos for rent in Miami.

 My current place is nice, the view is incredible, and it‚Äôs in a great location.

 But I want to hear echoes.

 High ceilings. Wrap around floor to ceiling windows. And more space than I know what to do with.

 During my search, I found this penthouse for $19k/mo.

 It‚Äôs 2,500 square feet, marble floors, huge living area, big balcony etc.

 Basically everything I want.

 To move there, I‚Äôd pay at least $10k to break my current ($5k/mo) lease.

 Then another $30k+ furnishing the new place.

 And then obviously my rent would quadruple.

 It‚Äôs not that I couldn‚Äôt do it, but it would sting.

 And that pissed me off.

 There‚Äôs something I want.

 And I can‚Äôt get it.

 Because it‚Äôs too‚Ä¶ expensive ?

 My fingers hurt just typing the word expensi‚Äì I can‚Äôt do it again.

 Am I a child?

 Should I start asking permission to go to the bathroom too?

 This lit a fire under me.

 My lease is up in July and by then, I want to be in a position where I can spend $15k+ on rent without batting an eye.

 If I can‚Äôt, I‚Äôve dishonored my entire bloodline.

 People often tell you to find a strong ‚Äúwhy‚Äù ‚Äì some altruistic motive that drives you.

 And while I‚Äôm motivated by actualizing my potential and being able to take care of the people around me, sometimes that‚Äôs not enough.

 My family isn‚Äôt in poverty.

 Mom‚Äôs already retired and my Dad has more money in cars than most do in savings.

 I don‚Äôt need to rescue anyone.

 So sometimes, I‚Äôll lean on superficial things as a source of motivation.

 I‚Äôll picture myself hopping out of a new supercar and walking into my penthouse.

 And guess what?

 In case no one‚Äôs ever told you this, allow me ‚Äî it‚Äôs okay to want what you want.

 If you‚Äôre not motivated, maybe you‚Äôre just not being honest with yourself.

 You listened to dorks online tell you that you can‚Äôt want the flashy lifestyle.

 Now you‚Äôre mad at your parents for raising you in a good home because you don‚Äôt have a strong enough ‚Äúwhy.‚Äù

 Be real with yourself. If you want to make money so you can hangout with baddies on the beach all day, then work really hard so you can do exactly that. ‚Äã

 Sure, at some point you‚Äôll probably need a deeper reason to keep pushing.

 But that‚Äôs not a worry right now.

 ‚Äã Get to the bag. You‚Äôll find your purpose along the way.

 I‚Äôll see you in the Penthouse,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: Opportunity is here. Don't miss it
body:
Do you remember where you were when you realized COVID was gonna be a big deal?

 I was nearing the end of my freshman year of college.

 The rumblings about the virus were becoming more prevalent.

 Still, I didn‚Äôt think much of it.

 Then it all started to happen‚Ä¶

 I remember checking my phone and seeing that the NBA postponed the games that night.

 Not long after, I got an email from my school saying that we‚Äôd have to evacuate.

 ‚ÄúUh oh‚Ä¶ this is starting to feel real,‚Äù I thought.

 Next thing you know, the whole world is on pause and everyones wearing diapers on their faces to avoid the equivalent of a common cold.

 Last night, I got a similar feeling when I opened Tik Tok.

 ‚ÄúHoly shit‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs actually banned.‚Äù

 It seems likely that it‚Äôll be back in the coming days or weeks once Trumps in office and everything will return to normal.

 But you can‚Äôt ignore the fact that this is a big deal.

 In 2023 alone, Tik Tok contributed $24.2 BILLION to the U.S. GDP.

 And obviously that number has grown since then.

 When an event of this magnitude occurs, opportunity arises.

 The money doesn‚Äôt vanish, it gets redirected.

 Other platforms would benefit from an influx of users.

 Instagram reels, Youtube shorts, maybe Snapchat or a completely different app.

 The first adopters would be heavily rewarded.

 Again, it seems like this will get resolved sooner than later.

 But the point about opportunity remains.

 Whatever happens in the next couple weeks, you can use this as an excuse to get moving.

 When the COVID lockdowns happened, all my friends and I took advantage of it.

 We laid the foundation that allowed us to make more money than we ever thought possible and completely change our lives over the next couple years.

 Could we have done this without the impact of the pandemic?

 Yes.

 But did it help spur us into action and get rich while everyone else was pouting?

 Also yes.

 You don‚Äôt want to look back on these crazy times and feel like you watched from the sidelines.

 Crypto‚Äôs pumping.

 The creator economy is booming.

 AI is evolving.

 Trumps getting inaugurated.

 Money is everywhere. 

 Pick a lane and move as fast as you fucking can.

 Because you don‚Äôt know when this run will end.

 But if you follow the money, build your skillset, and adapt to the shifts in the market‚Ä¶

 Nothing can phase you.

 Not a ban. Not a fake virus. Not a robot with 1,000x your mental capacity.

 ‚Äã Become undeniable. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: I need some advice...
body:
I‚Äôm advising you to stop taking advice.

 Ironic, but important.

 Everyone has their own biased beliefs, ideas, and perceptions.

 And they‚Äôre not necessarily wrong.

 But if you‚Äôre not careful, you‚Äôll listen too much.

 The habit of asking others for their thoughts will consume your own thoughts.

 Any time you reach a crossroad, obstacle, or internal conflict, you'll feel helpless.

 Consider what this signals to your subconscious‚Ä¶

 {{ subscriber.first_name }} isn't self-reliant.

 {{ subscriber.first_name }} doesn‚Äôt trust himself (or herself).

 {{ subscriber.first_name }} can‚Äôt speak with conviction because their beliefs come from others.

 You‚Äôre an infant. Basically asking for permission to think.

 You‚Äôll be the person who asks Google-able questions.

 And worst of all, the excess of opinions will stun you.

 Different potential solutions to problems get jumbled around in your head.

 Any of which could work.

 But because you haven‚Äôt built up internal conviction by making your own decisions, you can‚Äôt decide and commit. ‚Äã

 And even the smallest amount of resistance can pull you back to inaction.

 So how do you fix this?

 How do you start trusting yourself and feeling like you're in the driver‚Äôs seat of your life?

 How do you begin to rely on your inner voice?

 Here‚Äôs the solution‚Ä¶

 Stop waiting for me (or anyone else) to give you an answer that you already have.

 Ask yourself ‚ÄúHow do I start building internal conviction?‚Äù

 Ponder that question and come up with some simple ideas‚Ä¶

 It can be minor changes to your habits.

 Starting a hobby you‚Äôve been putting off.

 Pursuing a new opportunity in your business.

 Whatever it is, it doesn't have to be anything wild or crazy.

 But you need to show yourself that you can take actions simply because you want to.

 You don‚Äôt need permission.

 You don‚Äôt need advice.

 You need you.

 And luckily, you‚Äôre all you‚Äôll ever have. ‚Äã

 Conviction is the great equalizer. You can‚Äôt win without it, you can‚Äôt lose with it.

 The only way to build it is by listening to yourself.

 Start today, right now. Don‚Äôt go looking for answers that you already have.

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 P.S. Obviously there is nuance to this and there are times where guidance from people you trust is 100% helpful. Just don‚Äôt make it a habit to ask others before you ask yourself.

 ‚Äã

subject: You're overcomplicating this
body:
A little over a year ago, a friend of mine started building his first software company.

 It‚Äôs now worth multiple 7 figures, soon to be 8.

 Software is a difficult space to get into.

 It‚Äôs especially harder than building an agency or coaching business.

 In watching him get this off the ground, I learned a valuable lesson that can be applied to any endeavor‚Ä¶

 Do not over complicate the uncomplicated.

 There will always be a variety of things you don‚Äôt know.

 You‚Äôll likely have a tendency to want to feel ready, but it‚Äôs impossible to solve tomorrow's problems, today.

 If you feel like you‚Äôre in over your head, you‚Äôre doing something right.

 Nearly every successful business owner follows a similar path:

 1. They learn the basics.

 2. They dive in well before they feel ready.

 3. They solve problems on the fly.

 4. They adapt, carve their lane, and find success.

 There is no way around this.

 Most people get caught up in step 1 and 2 because they start overcomplicating it.

 Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôre building an info-product agency.

 You need to do two things‚Ä¶

 Learn the fundamentals of copywriting for coaching businesses.

 Do outreach.

 Everything else is a waste of time.

 You can spend weeks or months contemplating a niche, offer, what to say in your outreach, etc.

 All you‚Äôre doing is avoiding action.

 When you get a client, you‚Äôll then have a better vantage point to understand what bottlenecks need to be solved.

 You just can‚Äôt let the unknown stop you from putting one foot in front of the other.

 Steve Jobs didn‚Äôt know how he‚Äôd build Apple.

 Zuckerberg didn't have Facebook mapped out.

 They just started and figured it out along the way.

 The same applies to you.

 You don't need to know how you'll get to $100k months.

 You just need to know your next step.

 For you, that's probably sending your first outreach message.

 Or jumping on your first sales call.

 Or closing your first client.

 Everything after that?

 You'll figure it out when you get there.

 ‚Äã Ready to take your first step? Let me show you exactly where to start. ‚Äã

 To keeping it simple,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: Shortcuts DO exist...
body:
When I first got into online business, all I wanted was fast success.

 I was one of the idiots in the comment sections saying‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúHow long will it take to get a client?‚Äù

 ‚ÄúHow long will it take to get to $10k/month?‚Äù

 ‚ÄúHow long will it take to buy my dream car?‚Äù

 My perception of time was skewed.

 Even hearing that it could take 6 months of hard work before I make financial progress sounded like eternity.

 I wanted money and I wanted it now!

 Because of my flawed mindset, it ended up taking longer.

 I hopped from one business model to the next.

 I‚Äôd look for someone to give me a defined, step-by-step roadmap with a timeline.

 Obviously that didn‚Äôt exist.

 After spending nearly a year flirting with the idea of success and making half-hearted attempts at a few businesses, I finally accepted it‚Ä¶

 This shit is gonna be hard.

 It‚Äôs gonna take time.

 I‚Äôm gonna have to learn A LOT.

 And even with all my hard work, nothing is guaranteed.

 As grim as that may sound, accepting this made it a hell of a lot easier.

 Instead of looking for shortcuts I started planting seeds.

 My inner dialogue shifted from, ‚Äúhow can I make money this month?‚Äù to ‚Äúhow can I set up a solid foundation over the next 3 months?‚Äù ‚Äã

 And when I finally did that, guess what?

 I found the fast success I was looking for.

 Ironic, huh?

 The shortcut is understanding that there is no shortcut.

 When you stop searching for it, you start focusing on what‚Äôs important.

 And when you focus on what‚Äôs important, you make progress.

 (Relatively) Fast.

 ‚ÄúThe day you plant the seed is not the day you eat the fruit.‚Äù 

 Build skills.

 Commit to continuous learning.

 Make connections.

 Improve your habits.

 Fortify your mind.

 And accept that anything fast, doesn‚Äôt last.

 ‚Äã You‚Äôll be in your dream car in no time. ‚Äã

 Godspeed,

 Ben

subject: What makes a good copywriter?
body:
I‚Äôm writing to you from the clouds.

 Let me show you:

 ‚Äã A parakeet just landed on my balcony.

 He said ‚ÄúBen, what makes a good copywriter?‚Äù

 Here‚Äôs my answer‚Ä¶

 A good copywriter accurately articulates a prospect's current situation in detail.

 He makes a logical argument overcoming all objections that would prevent them from purchasing the product.

 That‚Äôs about it.

 I‚Äôll show you in action.

 My goal is to get you to book a call and join Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 Right now, there‚Äôs a variety of factors that could be stopping you:

 1. You think you can learn everything for free on Youtube

 2. You don‚Äôt fully understand the info-product agency model

 3. You‚Äôre worried you won‚Äôt be able to get clients

 4. You‚Äôre unclear on what you‚Äôd do for clients and how you‚Äôd pitch them

 5. You think it sounds too complex to start right now

 There are more potential objections, but those are the 5 most prevalent I hear.

 I‚Äôll show you how I‚Äôd overcome a couple of them‚Ä¶

 Objection 1: 

 The truth is, you can learn most of what you'd need to know on Youtube.

 But it‚Äôll slow you down immensely.

 Instead of having a step-by-step roadmap showing you what to do every day for the next 90 days‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôll have to spend hours digging through mud to find gems on social media.

 And even then, how will you know what information to trust?

 It‚Äôs a gamble.

 If you have time to waste, by all means figure it out on your own.

 But if you want a sure thing?

 Coaching is the way to go.

 Objection 2: 

 So you‚Äôve heard people talk about building an info-product agency but you‚Äôre unsure where to start.

 After 2-4 weeks of active studying and practice reps, you‚Äôll be ready to start outreach.

 See what I‚Äôm doing here?
