subject: Why AI *won't* take your job
body:
Two days President Trump announced the formation of Stargate.

 A few of the largest tech firms came together and will be investing $500 BILLION into AI infrastructure over the next four years.

 Big news.

 So what does this mean for you?

 Will AI replace you and you‚Äôll resort to mopping the floors at your local high school?

 Quite the opposite, actually.

 Trump says this project will create around 100,000 jobs.

 It‚Äôs impossible to predict what will be built over the coming years.

 But in the short term, here‚Äôs my recommendation for you‚Ä¶

 Do not neglect the utilization of AI in your business.

 It‚Äôs a tool that can make you wildly more efficient, improve your copy, and expand your service delivery.

 A marketer who uses AI effectively will outperform one who doesn‚Äôt.

 Simple as that.

 Now this brings me to the question‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúIf AI can do most of the legwork, why would online coaches still hire copywriters?‚Äù

 There are two main arguments here:

 1. Laziness/unawareness

 ChatGPT and Claude have been around for a while now.

 Most info-product sellers already know this.

 But still, they haven‚Äôt taken the time to use them effectively on their own.

 They prefer bringing someone on to do the work for them rather than diving into the AI world themselves.

 2. A vast skill set makes you irreplaceable

 An email copywriter who writes a few half decent emails a week is expendable.

 You could be replaced with AI or by any of the other horny copywriters in your clients DMs.

 But if you‚Äôre offering a multitude of services ‚Äì funnels, VSLs, offer creation, sales management, automations, etc‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôre invaluable.

 AI can‚Äôt do all of that on its own (although it can help you do it more effectively).

 We‚Äôre entering a golden era. ‚Äã

 There‚Äôs a lot of money to be made over the next 4 years.

 And it‚Äôd be a shame if you don‚Äôt capitalize on it.

 ‚Äã Go here and I‚Äôll show you how you can use AI to your advantage. ‚Äã

 Have a good weekend,

 Ben

subject: The fast lane to millions
body:
Good morning.

 I‚Äôm on my balcony squinting at my computer screen.

 If you‚Äôre somewhere cold and gloomy right now, I feel bad for you.

 It‚Äôs 73 and sunny here.

 I‚Äôm shirtless with a zyn in my upper lip, looking down at the water.

 Serenity.

 Alright, let‚Äôs cut the chit chat.

 You want to get rich fast?

 Easy.

 Have an idea?

 Yes.

 Or you can remain on the sidelines and keep making excuses.

 It‚Äôs all up to you, my friend.

subject: Organic vs paid traffic for info-products
body:
Last night, I was hanging out with my rich uncle, Rob (@robthebank).

 We mostly chatted about content and selling info.

 Most coaching businesses seem to have a relatively short life span.

 A personal brand gets hot, capitalizes on (or creates) a trend, and makes a bag.

 All they have to do is make organic content.

 Their systems typically aren‚Äôt great and their product might not be the best‚Ä¶

 But they‚Äôre swimming with the tide ‚Äì right place, right time, right offer.

 They print with ease.

 This can last for as short as a few months and probably as long as a handful of years.

 But eventually, the tide shifts‚Ä¶

 Views decline.

 Reputations get tainted.

 The market gets flooded with competition.

 The offer isn‚Äôt as hot as it used to be.

 Any of the above can occur and when this happens, the once simple and easy cash flow business starts to get complex.

 Used to 80% margins with organic traffic?

 Hope you‚Äôre ready for that to decline when you have to pay for every eyeball.

 And if you have subpar systems, aren‚Äôt tracking your metrics, and your attention to detail isn‚Äôt rock solid‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôre in for a rude awakening.

 This is how info-businesses end up collapsing quickly.

 Their organic traffic dies down and they don‚Äôt build the infrastructure to be successful selling to cold traffic.

 Scaling through paid ads is a completely different game.

 First, your margins will likely get cut down to around 50% or less as you scale.

 A friend of mine made $2m in a month last year, almost all through paid.

 He kept around $600k.

 Sure it‚Äôs great money, but it‚Äôs 10x the work and the stress of organic traffic.

 And there‚Äôs (almost always) no real enterprise value.

 The goal is cash flow.

 If you have to spend $1m/mo, build a huge team, constantly test new offers, and sell your heart out to keep a couple hundred grand?

 It definitely gets draining.

 The game is to stay relevant organically (which is hard to do for more than a few years)...

 While also building the infrastructure that can work on cold traffic.

 If you rely solely on one or the other, you‚Äôre running a risky business.

 Just my 2 cents,

 Ben

 P.S. If you want to learn how to build an info-product agency the right way ‚Äì with systems that work for both organic and paid traffic ‚Äì I can show you here. ‚Äã

 You‚Äôll learn how I‚Äôve scaled offers all the way up to $700k/month, how I get the best clients in the business, and how you can do the same.

 ‚Äã Go here to apply for a strategy call. ‚Äã

subject: How to make hard tasks feel easy
body:
One day life will be all peace and joy.

 You‚Äôll spend your time only doing things you love.

 All of your problems will vanish.

 And you‚Äôll never have to do things you don‚Äôt want to do.

 At least, that‚Äôs what I used to think‚Ä¶

 But this, my friend, is what we call a delusion.

 There will always be things in business (and in life) that feel like a chore.

 Sorry to burst your bubble.

 Now, this doesn‚Äôt have to be a bad thing.

 All it takes is a simple reframe‚Ä¶

 Think of a task that you typically dread doing.

 Maybe it‚Äôs outreach, building systems, calls, etc.

 Instead of looking at it like this daunting activity that you want to avoid at all costs‚Ä¶

 Simply accept that it will suck.

 You won‚Äôt enjoy the time that it takes to complete said task.

 But once you get through it, you‚Äôll feel good.

 You‚Äôll move the needle forward and that‚Äôs all that matters.

 When you do this, the daunting tasks begin to lose their power.

 Instead of fighting two battles ‚Äì one against your mind and one against the thing you‚Äôre dreading‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôre only fighting one.

 Just embrace that it won‚Äôt be fun.

 And get it done.

 Eventually that resistance will feel like curling 5lb dumbbells.

 It gets easier.

 You just have to overcome the voice in your head that‚Äôs telling you to run from the pain.

 Soon you‚Äôll be enjoying the fruits of your labor.

 ‚Äã If you want me to guide you through the trenches, join me here. ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

subject: Why people aren't buying from you
body:
I've worked with 46 total clients in the past 2.5 years.

 All of which sell info.

 I've sold low ticket communities, mid ticket, and high ticket offers.

 I helped a client make $600k in a week through a webinar funnel.

 I've scaled dozens of offers past $100k/mo and a handful past $500k/mo.

 But my success has little to do with my copywriting ability...

 I've been successful because I know who I'm talking to.

 And after working with all these clients, I've discovered something crucial:

 Most marketers are trying to convince the wrong person to buy the wrong thing.

 ‚Äã In this video, I break down exactly how to avoid this mistake.

 You'll learn:

 ‚ó¶ The 3 psychological triggers that make people buy

 ‚ó¶ How to identify what your market REALLY wants (not what they say they want)

 ‚ó¶ The exact questions to ask to uncover true objections

 This is the most important piece of marketing... If you get this wrong, your offers simply won't convert.

 But if you get it right?

 Writing copy becomes easy.

 Selling becomes effortless.

 And scaling is just a matter of adding more fuel to the fire.

 ‚Äã This video is basically a degree in marketing psychology. ‚Äã

 And I've never shared this framework publicly before.

 See you over there,

 Ben

body:

 Yesterday, someone commented on a video of mine where I broke down my top 3 businesses in 2025.

 YOU ARE RETARDED IF YOU THINK YOU‚ÄôLL GET RICH TRADING.

 Kabrin, a member inside of Artisan Lab just closed a trader for $7k and a 15% rev share.

subject: Diversifying your income is for the poors
body:
‚ÄúThe average millionaire has 7 different income streams.‚Äù

 Shut up.

 This is some shit your broke uncle puts on his Instagram story with a üíØ emoji.

 Fuck off Uncle Tony, you work at Dennys.

 Do not let poverty advice like this fool you‚Ä¶

 I spent the majority of 2024 haphazardly chasing random projects.

 I‚Äôd consider scaling my agency, launching a new offer, coaching, crypto, etc.

 After considering each thing for a week or two, I‚Äôd move on to the next shiny solution.

 This was quite idiotic and it halted my progress.

 Because I was always half in, half out, I never put enough attention or time into any one thing.

 Now, I‚Äôm the opposite.

 I have one objective every day:

 Create content that makes more people know, like and trust me.

 My main focus is solidified.

 And after being on both sides, I can tell you with full certainty, it‚Äôs much better this way.

 When I was unfocused, there were days where I‚Äôd wake up and not know what to do.

 Although there was plenty of work to be done, I couldn‚Äôt pick one thing.

 It‚Äôs impossible to make progress this way.

 But when you have one main objective, you wake up every day knowing the levers you need to pull.

 It feels amazing because you have clarity.

 This allows you to perform effectively without constantly pondering if you‚Äôre doing the right thing.

 And if you‚Äôre stressed right now, it‚Äôs likely because you‚Äôre not giving yourself that clarity.

 You‚Äôre listening to Uncle Tony and Instagram theme pages.

 To be entirely clear, this doesn‚Äôt mean you can never have multiple businesses.

 As you progress as an entrepreneur, opportunities fall into your lap.

 Oftentimes, those opportunities can complement one another.

 But when you try to start too many new things at once without having concrete objectives, you‚Äôre just distracting yourself.

 Instead, focus on one main thing at a time.

 Build it to a point where it doesn‚Äôt require your full attention.

 And then think about other ways to grow.

 Don‚Äôt get fooled into thinking you need 7 unprofitable businesses.

 You don‚Äôt get an award for opening up an LLC.

 Money won‚Äôt magically start falling into your lap.

 ‚Äã Start with one cash flowing business and put your sole focus into it. ‚Äã

 You'll grow much faster.

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

subject: How to be comfortably irresponsible with money
body:
I hit a new high score today.

 $8.51.

 Eight dollars and fifty one cents on an iced latte. Before tip.

 To be fair, I added vanilla.

 And yes, the vanilla does in fact cure cancer.

 Pretty cool, right?

 This got me thinking‚Ä¶

 If you were to spend $8.51 on coffee every day, that‚Äôs $3,106.15 over the course of a year.

 Meaning if you make $60k per year, you‚Äôre blowing over 5% of your income on coffee.

 ‚ÄúWeLl aCtuAlLy, YoU cOulD JuSt MaKe iT aT hoMe.‚Äù

 Stop.

 Here‚Äôs how to make enough money to enjoy your morning stroll in the Miami sun and happily buy whatever coffee you want:

 First things first, this will likely take two years.

 Hey now, don‚Äôt leave just yet.

 I know that sounds like a while but stick with me here‚Ä¶

 Two years isn‚Äôt that long!

 Okay, we just lost everyone else reading this so it‚Äôs just you me now, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Here are three steps to escape the cubicle‚Ä¶

 Step 1. Learn copywriting 

 I‚Äôm not saying this to sell you, I‚Äôm saying this because it‚Äôs the most versatile skill you can learn.

 You can pitch local businesses, eCom brands, agencies, or coaching businesses.

 To reach escape velocity, you only need $5-10k/month.

 That‚Äôs like two or three clients on retainer. Or one solid client on a rev share (tutorial). ‚Äã

 If you‚Äôre starting from zero, pitch anyone and everyone.

 Take $500 retainers.

 Do free work for a testimonial.

 Work with your Grandma‚Äôs friend's niece who owns a wildly unprofitable bakery (even though she sells $8 coffee).

 You just need experience and money.

 Do this for six months and you‚Äôll be in a decent spot.

 Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôre making around $5-7k per month‚Ä¶

 Step 2. Move somewhere cheap 

 Get your passport, buddy. I hope you like latinas.

 Head over to Tulum, Mexico or somewhere similar.

 Bonus points if you make sure you‚Äôre not gonna get captured by a local gang.

 Now it‚Äôs time to lock in.

 You‚Äôll save most of your money and spend the time you‚Äôre not working on a beach.

 Stay here until you start making software engineer money. 

 For me this phase was four months.

 By the end, I was making around $15k per month and had nearly $100k in savings.

 Step 3. Bienvenidos a Miami 

 Time to up the stakes.

 You‚Äôve proven to yourself that you can consistently make money on your own.

 It doesn‚Äôt appear the business will randomly collapse any time soon. And if it does you‚Äôve got some cash in the bank.

 Open up your wallet and find a spot in a bigger city.

 You‚Äôll likely spend more on rent than you were spending total the previous few months.

 That‚Äôs okay, you need pressure.

 Between the pressure, your now year of experience in the game, and the connections you‚Äôll make in your new city‚Ä¶

 It‚Äôs inevitable you‚Äôll get to $30k, $50k, and eventually $100k/month plus.

 And maybe I‚Äôll run into you in line to get a cancer-curing latte :)

 If you made it down here and you‚Äôre ready to do this‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã Here‚Äôs a good place to start. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: You're afraid of success and you know it
body:
Success comes with downsides‚Ä¶

 More pressure.

 Increased responsibility.

 Higher standards.

 Added expectations.

 And greater consequences.

 Sure, these are better problems to have.

 But problems are problems, nonetheless.

 There‚Äôve been times in my life where I‚Äôve sabotaged my own growth in order to avoid these downsides.

 It was almost subconscious.

 I didn‚Äôt want the pressure of dealing with more clients, so I‚Äôd ‚Äúforget‚Äù to follow up with a lead.

 Or I‚Äôd disqualify someone that I could‚Äôve pitched and closed.

 And as my brand has grown on social media, I‚Äôve become more particular with what I share.

 A louder microphone means more attention.

 More attention means greater consequences ‚Äì for better or worse.

 You can only grow as big as you allow yourself to be.

 Yes, there are future repercussions that come with success.

 But you want to know the key to getting over your fear?

 Accept your unpreparedness.

 You probably aren‚Äôt equipped to handle an abundance of responsibility, attention, or expectations.

 If tomorrow, you were given one million followers on social media, a $500k/mo business, dozens of clients and a big team‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôd probably crumble.

 You‚Äôd be too nervous to post any content and continue growing your brand.

 Your clients and team members would leave because you don‚Äôt know how to lead.

 And the business would go to shit‚Ä¶

 But that‚Äôs exactly why the journey exists.

 It‚Äôs there to mold you into the person capable of receiving success.

 Go through challenges and tribulations. You‚Äôll be forced to grow.

 The more you overcome, the more prepared you become. 

 By the time you reach the top of the mountain, you‚Äôll have won so many battles that you‚Äôre bulletproof.

 The ‚Äúdownsides‚Äù you were once afraid of no longer hold any power over you.

 Congrats, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 You‚Äôve stopped running from the pressure.

 Soon enough it‚Äôll feel weightless,

 Ben.

 P.S. I‚Äôm taking on up to 20 new members inside of Artisan Lab this month.

 If you want to build and scale an agency/copywriting business working with online coaches, I can help you.

 This is best for existing copywriters, closers, agency owners, and content creators.

 If you‚Äôre a complete beginner, you‚Äôll only be let in if you prove that you‚Äôre competent and committed.

 ‚Äã Go here and apply now for small group and 1-1 coaching. ‚Äã

 Key difference #1 ‚Äì The ability to identify opportunity vehicles.

 Key difference #2 ‚Äì Who I believe I am.

 When I take someone on as a client, I am doing them a favor.

 It is the best possible investment they can make.

 Because we‚Äôre the best at what we do, that comes with a higher price.

 This is the frame you need to take to be successful.

 You can be confident in your willingness to figure out problems on the fly.

 And you can be confident in your work ethic.

 With that, you‚Äôll create data (making clients a bunch of money) that solidifies your beliefs.

subject: The antidote to shiny object syndrome
body:
The grass is greener where you water it.

 I‚Äôve been in the online business world for about four years now.

 Every project I‚Äôve worked on follows a similar timeline:

 I start something new ‚Äì it‚Äôs exciting and I‚Äôm eager to get the ball moving.

 Soon after, the initial excitement wears off. 

 The work starts to feel less like play and more like work.

 But the momentum I‚Äôve built up carries me and I keep progressing.

 This is typically where exponential growth occurs.

 It feels new enough to keep me engaged and I‚Äôve accepted the reality that it requires intentionality and focus.

 Eventually the novelty completely fades.

 I start dreading many of the tasks that used to feel easy.

 I‚Äôm now solely relying on willpower, my enjoyment of the process is gone.

 This period continues until one of two things occur‚Ä¶

 I find a way to spice things up and the potential for growth reignites my spark.

 Or I become completely uninterested with the project at hand and pivot to something fresh.

 This is a natural progression I see amongst nearly all of my friends.

 It‚Äôs not a bad thing, if you‚Äôre aware of it.

 But if you‚Äôre unaware, you can convince yourself that the business ‚Äúdoesn't feel right‚Äù it‚Äôs time to shift.

 You‚Äôll find a shinier objective and pursue it until the luster inevitably wears off.

 Again, you‚Äôll search for something new and the cycle repeats.

 This won‚Äôt lead to any meaningful progress.

 On the contrary, you can accept that eventually the work will become dull.

 That doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre going in the wrong direction.

 It means you have to keep ‚Äúwatering the grass‚Äù even though it‚Äôs redundant.

 Excitement can only take you so far.

 If you‚Äôre too reliant on it, your eyes will constantly wander.

 But if you stay engaged, keep moving, and accept that the excitement will come and go‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã That‚Äôs where the grass is greenest. ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

 I get around 50% open rates.

 Countless people have come up to me in real life telling me they love my emails.

 In fact, a few months ago I ran into a kind Australian guy who was reading an email of mine as I walked into a coffee shop in Brickell.

 That was cool.

 Of everything I‚Äôve built online, this list is something I‚Äôm most proud of.

 I‚Äôm not telling you all of this to brag‚Ä¶

 My approach here has never been very calculated.

 I write these because I enjoy it.

 Sure it‚Äôs made me money now, but I‚Äôd sent hundreds of emails before ever pitching anything.

 And I think that‚Äôs what makes it special.

 Even if you‚Äôre not interested in anything I sell, you know that when you open an email of mine you‚Äôll get value from it.

 Instead of viewing each email as a mini sales pitch, I write about what I find interesting.

 ‚Äã My coaching is here if you want it but I‚Äôm not shoving it down your throat.

 This leads me to my main point:

 You are rewarded most when your intentions are pure and honest.

 In any interaction ‚Äì business, dating, or socially‚Ä¶

 You can feel it when someone wants something from you.

 Every word out of their mouth is an attempt to get you to give them what they want.

 When they try to conceal that objective, you lose trust in them.

 Now I‚Äôm not telling you that you can‚Äôt sell others on you.

 But rather be open about the desired exchange in value.

 If you‚Äôre trying to close a prospect, you need to show them why they should buy from you.

 Give them advice.

 Tell them what they could do, even if they don‚Äôt work with you.

 Prove that you are competent and you know what you‚Äôre talking about.

 The law of reciprocity is real.

 As corny as it sounds, the more you give, the more you get.

 Remain transparent with your motive behind giving.

 And you will be rewarded with the things you want.

 If you liked this one and want to work with me more closely, you can do so here :) ‚Äã

 Happy Monday,

 Ben

subject: The AI prompt that cut my workload in half
body:
The setup is often more difficult to overcome than the implementation.

 It‚Äôs hard to get in the car and drive to the gym.

 It‚Äôs easy to workout once you‚Äôre there.

 Similarly, when I write these emails, the idea is half the battle.

 I‚Äôll take a walk, stare at a blinking cursor, or scroll through social media‚Ä¶

 Dozens of potential topics come to mind, most of which I discard.

 But finally, an idea that seems worthy of an email will emerge.

 After that, the assembly of the words you‚Äôre reading now is the easy part.

 All I need is a rough idea.

 Then I start typing, my brain starts cooking, and 20 minutes later we‚Äôve completed the task.

 50% of my energy is spent on ideation, the other 50% on implementation.

 Here‚Äôs how AI can cut this time in half:

 To be clear ‚Äì it could write the entire email for me, but I like writing these.

 Instead, I‚Äôll have it source an idea.

 First I‚Äôll upload a handful of my previous emails and/or Youtube videos into Claude.

 Next, I‚Äôll prompt it with something like:

 ‚ÄúBased on my previous content, give me five potential topics I could write an email on in the future that align with my brand.‚Äù

 Obviously I can get more specific here as well if I want to.

 If I like the five ideas it gives me, I‚Äôll ask it to generate another 20.

 And just like that, I have a month's worth of email topics ready to go.

 If you have a copywriting client or your own list, I encourage you to try this out.

 It‚Äôs a step you can take to start using AI that will make you wildly more efficient.

 Stop being afraid of AI.

 It‚Äôs here to help you (at least for now).

 It won‚Äôt replace you, but someone using it will.

 ‚Äã Be the hunter, not the hunted. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: You're being tricked
body:
You‚Äôre under attack.

 Every day, hundreds of destructive thoughts enter your mind.

 They‚Äôre deceptive and deceitful.

 Their goal?

 Keep you where you are and who you are.

 They‚Äôll try to convince you you‚Äôre underprepared or going in the wrong direction.

 ‚Äú{{ subscriber.first_name }}, you‚Äôre not ready to start yet‚Ä¶ but maybe if you watch 12 more Hormozi videos you will be!‚Äù

 Or ‚Äú{{ subscriber.first_name }}, this business model is too difficult, you should rent a Corvette C8 (the lambo‚Äôs too expensive) and sell dropshipping courses instead.

 Sound familiar?

 Your success is dependent on your ability to resist these tricks.

 This magical utopia you envision where you love every second of the journey doesn‚Äôt exist.

 At least not on this spiritual plane.

 There is no way to get around the fact that at times, work will feel like work.

 You‚Äôll often feel underprepared.

 Temptations of alternative routes will always be there.

 These thoughts are natural.

 But you must remember you live in reality ‚Äì where nothing is ever as good or as bad as it looks in your head.

 Change is difficult.

 Growth brings higher expectations.

 And work gets redundant.

 A sexier business model or new Youtube video are not the way around this.

 That‚Äôs your ego luring you into a trap.

 Resist, my friend.

 You know what needs to be done.

 You don‚Äôt need more advice.

 You don‚Äôt need a better vehicle.

 Hit the gas and throw your rearview mirror out the window.

 Ben

 P.S. If you‚Äôre a copywriter, closer, or agency owner who wants to be able to charge clients 5 figures a month, check out Artisan Lab here. ‚Äã

subject: The strategy behind 6 figure launches
body:
In the past few years I‚Äôve launched countless new offers for my clients.

 A few flopped.

 A handful did okay.

 And almost a dozen made six figures in the first 30 days.

 In terms of percentages, we‚Äôre talking Barry Bonds PED era numbers.

 Our best was a $600k week.

 Our worst was a single $997 sale.

 But it's safe to say we‚Äôve had a lot more winners than losers.

 Here‚Äôs how to successfully crush a new info-product launch:

 Phase 1: The offer

 Half the battle is identifying what the audience wants.

 That‚Äôll be contingent on the type of content the client makes and their field of expertise.

 If they‚Äôve attracted a mass market B2C audience, perhaps a mid-ticket offer ($500-$2,000) will work better.

 If it‚Äôs a more mature audience and the bulk of the value is in access to the client, high ticket is the way to go.

 99 times out of 100, avoid low ticket like the plague.

 Our success has come through selling mid ticket via sales pages and webinars, or high ticket through a VSL call funnel.

 As a general rule of thumb, either price it at $3k+ and sell over the phone.

 Or price it between $500 to $2k and sell through a sales page/webinar.

 Phase 2: Pre-launch

 Once you‚Äôve decided on your offer and price point, now it‚Äôs time to build hype.

 Roughly two weeks before launch, make an announcement on all channels.

 Email, Instagram stories, existing communities, etc.

 Your goal is to get people excited.

 Identify the problem the audience is facing.

 Use these channels to exacerbate their pain and explain how you have a solution coming soon.

 You can also build up a waitlist or start getting people to sign up for a webinar.

 As the launch approaches, increase the frequency of reminders.

 Phase 3: Launch

 Offer goes live.

 Announce it on all channels.

 Hammer the scarcity and urgency ‚Äì why should they buy now?

 The first batch can get special bonuses and/or discounted pricing.

 Set a date or (real) limit on how many people get access.

 You‚Äôll typically have a spike in sales immediately, it‚Äôll sustain for a few days, and then it‚Äôs time to remind them what they‚Äôll miss out on if they don‚Äôt get in now.

 This should create an additional spike towards the end of the launch.

 Once all spots are filled, or the window is over, don‚Äôt go back on your word.

 Just like that, you‚Äôve successfully made a doctor's annual salary in a week or two.

 And you didn‚Äôt even have to cheat your way through medical school.

 Congrats,

 Ben

 P.S. I share full breakdowns of this kind of stuff inside Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 If you want to see this entire process in depth, including:

 - How to craft a winning offer that the audience will actually want

 - Selecting the perfect price point for the offer

 - The exact emails/ strategies I‚Äôve used to build hype

 - How to write a launch VSL

 - The full webinar template we‚Äôve used to make six figures in a single day

 And much more‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã Go here to apply for coaching and steal everything I‚Äôve learned in the past couple of years. ‚Äã

subject: Why Growth Operating never truly worked
body:
Remember the whole ‚ÄúGrowth Operating‚Äù trend about a year ago?

 It appears to be dead.

 Brady and Eddie (the guys who popularized the model) are friends of mine.

 They actually paid me for a few consulting calls right before Eddie‚Äôs brand started to blow up.

 In no way am I intending to throw shade at them, but rather objectively breakdown why the offer fell apart.

 The traffic was great.

 Eddie‚Äôs awesome on camera.

 Brady‚Äôs a wizard on the backend.

 And the online education industry is growing, so teaching people how to capitalize on it makes sense.

 The problem?

 Positioning.

 From the outside looking in, this appears to be the core problem.

 The business model was drastically oversimplified.

 It was marketed to beginners, with little focus on skill acquisition and service delivery (at least front facing).

 When you have a bunch of little idiots running around in a community thinking it‚Äôll be easy to make money online, that creates some problems.

 It‚Äôs not that what they taught was wrong, but the way they positioned it was.

 They clearly had many successful students.

 But when you scale as high and as fast as they did, the majority of your students will be complete beginners.

 Most beginners fail.

 The ones who succeed take longer to do so.

 Couple this with the fact that it seemed like there was a new hit piece going out on Eddie every day‚Ä¶

 And the negative word of mouth associated with the term ‚ÄúGrowth Operating‚Äù spreads.

 Next thing you know, the decline is steep and fast.

 This is why I‚Äôll never tell you that building an Info-Product Agency is easy.

 You‚Äôll have to learn a lot.

 It might take a while to get a really solid client.

 If you‚Äôre not resilient, you‚Äôll quit before you succeed.

 But if you commit to the process?

 A single client can change your life.

 And soon enough, you can be one of the successful case studies we have here. ‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. I just made a video going more in depth on everything I talked about here.

 ‚Äã Come check it out. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: The gap gets wider
body:
‚ÄúA good marketer can fully articulate why two opposing arguments can both be true.‚Äù - Ben Bader 

 I‚Äôve talked a lot about the benefits of AI.

 It‚Äôs helped me become more efficient.

 It‚Äôs given me content ideas.

 And it‚Äôs helping the members inside Artisan Lab get clients.

 Although we‚Äôre just scratching the surface of potential use cases, it‚Äôs already been an incredibly powerful tool.

 But as stated in my quote above, I'd be a bad marketer if I didn‚Äôt tell you about the downside of AI.

 So without further ado, here‚Äôs how artificial intelligence could ruin your life:

 AI won‚Äôt save you, it‚Äôll dig your grave for you.

 Someone smart once said, ‚Äúwinners win and losers lose.‚Äù

 In this case, AI won‚Äôt turn you from a loser to a winner.

 It‚Äôll make you a bigger loser.

 If you get fooled into thinking you don‚Äôt have to work on your craft because a robot will do your entire job for you, you'll wind up replacing yourself.

 Natural human creativity will be removed from the equation and your quality of work will decline and become bland.

 As implementation becomes easy, the one with the best idea wins.

 This is especially true in the copywriting world.

 If you think like everyone else, you‚Äôll write like everyone else.

 You won‚Äôt understand the difference between a good idea and a bad idea.

 You‚Äôll sound like a robot.

 And eventually, your over-reliance on AI will make you obsolete.

 Congrats, you played yourself.

 Now, if you use AI the right way‚Ä¶

 As a tool to turbocharge your own ability, not as a replacement.

 And you keep innovating, testing, and improving your craft.

 You‚Äôll be lightyears ahead of everyone else.

 The gap gets wider.

 Winners win, and losers lose.

 If you want to avoid being on the losing team, don‚Äôt listen to anyone who says AI can do your entire job for you (nothing is as easy as it sounds).

 And if you want to be on the winning team?

 ‚Äã Join me here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Why some are allergic to success
body:
I figured it out‚Ä¶

 There‚Äôs a way to guarantee failure.

 If you follow this foolproof failure formula, you‚Äôll become helpless and bitter.

 And no matter what happens, it‚Äôll never be your fault.

 Last night, I was scrolling through Twitter before bed.

 I saw a post that gave me nightmares.

 It beautifully encapsulated the mindset required to lose.

 A grown man said publicly‚Ä¶ to thousands of people on the internet‚Ä¶ the following‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúI fucked up. 

 Burned through $18K in 5 months. Got about $20K left. 

 I should‚Äôve gone to Asia instead of Canada. 

 If you‚Äôre living on savings, DO NOT move to the West. The same money would‚Äôve taken me 10x further. 

 Made no money while I‚Äôve been here. Just watching my bank balance shrink. 

 My X account is dead because I barely tweet. Years of growth, gone. 

 Meanwhile, some people are making millions per month by selling some stupid course on how to get rich. 

 I hate how unfair life can be.‚Äù 

 As I began reading the tweet I figured he‚Äôd turn it around at some point.

 You know like, hook you with a sob story and then tell you how he persevered.

 But there is no perseverance in sight.

 Just pity and blame.

 Normally I‚Äôm empathetic but this guy lost me when he started hating on course gurus and said how life is unfair.

 You can argue with reality, or you can learn the rules and win the game.

 Whatever you do, don‚Äôt start feeling sorry for yourself.

 Don‚Äôt blame your inadequacies on external factors.

 Don‚Äôt harbor resentment for those who find success.

 And perhaps most importantly, don‚Äôt quit before it‚Äôs even close to over.

 That guy said he had $20k left and based on his spending that‚Äôs another 6 months of expenses.

 Even if he blew through that, there‚Äôs always another option.

 You are as resilient as you allow yourself to be.

 Nothing worth having comes easy. 

 You‚Äôll be tested and tricked. But if you make it through, the other side is beautiful.

 And you‚Äôll know that you earned it.

 You only lose when you throw in the towel.

 Don‚Äôt go crying to strangers on the internet,

 Ben

 P.S. While that guy wastes his last $20k feeling sorry for himself, my students are building 6 and 7 figure agencies. Join them here. ‚Äã

subject: Most course sellers are lying about this
body:
‚ÄúIf what they taught actually worked, they wouldn‚Äôt be selling a course on it.‚Äù 

 This is a common argument you‚Äôve probably heard against course sellers.

 It‚Äôs a valid concern and true in some cases.

 Many reach an iota of success from their business and immediately start selling info on it.

 That annoys the hell out of me.

 A singular $10k month does not make you an expert.

 Personally, I made over $100k/mo with my agency before I ever sold coaching.

 Here‚Äôs a literal screenshot from my bank statement in September 2023 for proof:

 ‚Äã That being said, different business models scale to varying levels.

 For example most closers cap out around $20-30k/mo.

 Let's say a closer reaches that number for a while.

 After a year or two in sales, they begin selling info on it and get to $100k/mo as a coach.

 I see no problem with it as long as they‚Äôre not claiming you can make 6 figures monthly from sales.

 It‚Äôs a good beginner business model to make your first $10-30k/mo.

 But it‚Äôs quite the anomaly to scale past that.

 This is the case for many of the other popular business models as well.

 However, the Info-Product Agency is different.

 Even if you‚Äôre just starting out, a few retainers and/or rev shares can get you past $10k/month.

 Once you do that, you‚Äôll be much more skilled.

 And then you can start getting bigger clients and higher rev shares.

 That can take you to $50k or even $100k/month like it did for me.

 I made over $2m in about two years from my agency.

 I got a high rise in Miami from my agency money.

 I bought my dream car from my agency money.

 Most people who sell coaching can‚Äôt say that the business they teach made them rich.

 They made good money from it, but great money from info.

 I‚Äôm doing both.

 So my question for you is this‚Ä¶

 Would you rather pick a business model that inevitably caps out at a relatively low income threshold?

 Or would you rather pick a model that can scale to 7 figures annually?

 (Which is not easy whatsoever but it is possible, as I am living proof).

 That‚Äôs a choice you‚Äôll have to make.

 But if you wanna learn from someone who got rich by doing, not teaching‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã Go here now and get access to my blueprint. ‚Äã

 To ethical info,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: I accidentally replaced myself
body:
Each morning as I open a blank Google doc to write to you, I consider using AI.

 It could write the whole thing for me.

 I‚Äôd skim the copy, making sure it didn‚Äôt say anything super cringey.

 And after a few edits, we‚Äôd be done.

 You‚Äôd probably never know it‚Äôs robot Ben and not real Ben.

 It‚Äôs tempting, but I‚Äôll never do it.

 Or maybe I‚Äôm doing it right now and tricking you?

 Either way, here‚Äôs what I would do if I were a lazy piece of shit who didn‚Äôt want to write these emails manually:

 Step 1. Open a new project in Claude.

 I‚Äôd upload my last 25+ emails as PDFs.

 Then prompt Claude to build a full breakdown of my style and tone.

 Perhaps I‚Äôd have it create a list of frequent topics I write about as well.

 This would likely be the most time consuming part, but once it‚Äôs done, we‚Äôre smooth sailing.

 Step 2. Transcribe my Youtube videos

 Let‚Äôs say I make a Youtube video about why eating seed oils gives you superpowers.

 I could take that transcript and upload it to Claude.

 Then I‚Äôd say, ‚ÄúHey Mr. Claude. Please write a complete email to my list in my tone and style using a topic from the seed oil superpower video. P.S. You look really handsome today.‚Äù

 My glorious robot would then give me a complete email.

 And after a few tweaks, you‚Äôd be sitting here reading it with no idea it‚Äôs AI copy.

 The only downside here is transcribing the videos could take a bit.

 I share a way where you can drastically speed up that process here. ‚Äã

 Step 3. Get creative

 Once I have this AI version of me (which I could actually make even better by fine tuning it, but that‚Äôs a bit harder), the sky‚Äôs the limit.

 I could give it an idea and analogy to use and have it spit out an email.

 I could tell it to reference a book I‚Äôm reading or use a lesson from a certain movie.

 I could have it write a complete email based on one of my Tweets.

 As long as I‚Äôm creative with my prompts, the emails would never get redundant or feel like AI.

 Now I enjoy writing these so I‚Äôll never do that.

 But if I wanted to, I could.

 Which is pretty cool.

 However I must add a big caveat here:

 If you‚Äôre not already a decent copywriter, this won‚Äôt work for you.

 I‚Äôve written hundreds of emails. I easily come up with creative analogies and metaphors.

 The process is second nature at this point.

 Because of these reasons, AI can be useful.

 But without them, it‚Äôs like giving nuclear launch codes to a squirrel on meth.

 No bueno.

 Still typing my own damn emails,

 Ben

 P.S. There‚Äôs a way to make the process I outlined here take minutes instead of hours. I‚Äôve built a system that cuts the time down by 80%. Soon I‚Äôll be able to share it publicly, but for now you can get exclusive access by going here. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: Value is overrated
body:
I really could care less about you today.

 No offense.

 I‚Äôm not gonna pretend to give you value here.

 It‚Äôs a rather low status action.

 ‚ÄúI need to give my audience VALUE, so they will like me and buy from me.‚Äù

 Grow up.

 I‚Äôd rather you buy from me because I made you laugh.

 Anyway, I‚Äôm getting a haircut in two hours.

 I considered canceling because my barber is being a dick.

 I texted to confirm.

 He liked the message.

 No ‚Äúawesome, see you then!‚Äù or even a simple ‚Äúbet, locked you in.‚Äù

 Just a thumbs up üëçüèº.

 That‚Äôs a man who really doesn‚Äôt care about giving value.

 But I won‚Äôt leave him -- finding a solid barber who speaks English in Miami is like finding a virgin in a brothel.

 Impossible.

 The thing about ‚Äúvalue‚Äù is it‚Äôs finite.

 Every creator eventually runs out of new things to say.

 Once they‚Äôve said it all, they just repeat themselves -- like actors reciting lines they know will resonate.

 People feel indebted to them, so they keep buying their stuff.

 But let's be real ‚Äì people don't stay subscribed to my emails because I'm constantly dropping value bombs.

 They stay because they like how I communicate.

 Because I'm not afraid to say what everyone else is thinking.

 Because sometimes, reading an honest email is more refreshing than another "7 tips to crush your goals" bullshit.

subject: The Kobe and Shaq of webinars
body:
Good morning, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 It‚Äôs a sunny one today.

 I‚Äôm out on the balcony squinting at my screen.

 I was talking to Chat GPT before bed last night and he told me something crazy.

 Did you know the average 24 year old in America makes $40,768 a year?

 This made me realize how the info-product world has warped my perception of money.

 My biggest client wins in this space have come through live webinars.

 You get as many people as possible on a stream, go through a calculated, 45 min presentation, and pitch.

 They‚Äôve been money printers.

 Imagine you‚Äôre watching the stripe dashboard as your client pitches.

 Sales start rolling in‚Ä¶

 Refresh and you‚Äôre at $20k‚Ä¶

 Three minutes later you‚Äôre at $35k‚Ä¶

 Then $53k‚Ä¶

 And 20 minutes later you just made six figures in about an hour.

 It‚Äôs insane.

 Throughout the majority of 2023, I had one client who was the Shaq to my Kobe.

 For nearly a 10 month span, we were printing $50k+ on each weekly webinar.

 My client would drive a bunch of sign ups through short form content.

 I had the backend dialed in with email, SMS, and a bunch of automations.

 And like clockwork, we'd clear our age group‚Äôs yearly salary every Thursday night."

 But it didn‚Äôt stop there‚Ä¶

 After selling a mid-ticket offer on the webby, my next job was to get purchasers on calls for the high ticket offer.

 That made up the other half of our revenue and we scaled this model past $500k/month.

 It was electric.

 This worked so well for a few reasons:

 First, my client was a wizard at content and pulling in consistent views.

 That said, most people struggle to convert viewers from short form content.

 That‚Äôs why the webinar played such a crucial role.

 No one's gonna spend a meaningful amount of money after watching a single minute long video.

 But they will sign up for a ‚Äúfree live class‚Äù if you get them curious.

 Every piece of content was like an ad (that we didn‚Äôt have to pay for).

 The goal was simply to get them to give me their contact info on the registration page.

 I‚Äôll get them to actually show up.

 Then we indoctrinate them as they sit through our presentation‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúKobe sees an opening, drives right‚Ä¶ lobs it up to Shaq‚Ä¶ SLAM!

 They buy.

 This model prints money when done right.

 If you want to execute it yourself, I‚Äôll hand you the entire playbook. ‚Äã

 Mamba out,

 Ben

 P.S. If you want to learn the entire system that we‚Äôve built for live webinars‚Ä¶

 Which is responsible for generating too many millions to count‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã I‚Äôm giving away the entire system ‚Äîbut only for those who move fast.

 The funnel, the slides, the emails, the texts, the pitch, the upsells.

 Everything.

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }}, meet Phillip
body:
If I could give you a phrase to live by it‚Äôd be:

 ‚ÄúEh, fuck it.‚Äù

 I have a friend named Phillip.

 I originally met him because he stalked me, sent me a dollar on Venmo, and I sent him $1,000 back.

 He was a stranger at the time.

 Fast forward a couple years and he lives a dozen floors below me in Miami.

 For the past year or so, he‚Äôs been closing and managing the sales team for a former client of mine.

 He‚Äôs made great money doing it and has helped the business scale.

 But he ran into an issue‚Ä¶

 Over half of his income came from him personally closing deals.

 Meaning if he wanted to continue making the same amount of money, he had to be on Zoom for the majority of each day.

 Nearly anyone would get exhausted after spending the better half of the past year on calls.

 So, he decided to take a step back.

 His goal?

 Get off sales calls and acquire new clients as a marketer/ops manager ‚Äì not a closer.

 That meant he‚Äôd take a pay cut.

 And if he wanted to even cover living expenses for the next month he‚Äôd have to go get clients.

 But as Plato said, ‚ÄúEh, fuck it.‚Äù

 Or maybe it was ‚ÄúNecessity is the mother of invention.‚Äù

 Regardless, Phillip's info-product agency was born and here‚Äôs what happened next:

 ‚Äã If you‚Äôre looking for an excuse to bet on yourself, now is the time.

 The price of Artisan Lab ‚Äì the exact blueprint Phillip followed ‚Äì is going up in 2 days.

 You‚Äôll learn everything from outreach, to fulfillment, to scaling with your clients.

 If you want the full roadmap, plus 1-1 coaching and access to a community of others who are on the same journey as you‚Ä¶

 Ben

subject: The most powerful psychological force
body:
When I first got into online business, I got a role as an appointment setter.

 2 days later I realized what that entailed, so I quit.

 But during that 48 hour excursion, I made one core memory.

 On the phone with the sales manager, I told him my goal was to get to $10k/mo.

 He said, ‚Äújust wait until your first $10k day.‚Äù

 That was an amount of money I couldn‚Äôt even conceptualize.

 At the time, I thought a $10k day was impossible.

 But I was wrong.

 It wasn‚Äôt about luck or talent‚Äîit was about following the right path.

 That‚Äôs exactly why I created Artisan Lab: to show others how to get there faster.

 And the recent price increase proved something powerful‚Ä¶

 Urgency works, even for people who knew they already wanted in.

 I was surprised how many people were on the fence, waiting for an excuse to pull the trigger.

 Obviously the extra $800 is irrelevant to someone who is serious‚Ä¶

 They‚Äôll make 1000x that if they‚Äôre committed to doing what we teach inside.

 So, the right student is going to buy either way.

 But even so, urgency nudges buyers off the fence faster than any other psychological force.

 It‚Äôs that extra push that takes them from ‚Äúthinking about it‚Äù to ‚ÄúOk, let‚Äôs do it‚Äù.

 Furthermore, the value must exponentially exceed the price.

 Artisan Lab was already cheap compared to the value inside and results students are getting.

 I‚Äôve now added full sales management and paid ads courses.

 These alone could be sold for thousands of dollars.

 But that's not the point.

 The point is that what I'm teaching works.

 It's responsible for my $10k+ days (and $100k days for clients).

 It's responsible for Michael (15 years old) making more than his teachers.

 It's responsible for Briar going from $3k/mo to over $30k/mo.

 And for Phillip closing three clients in two weeks.

 All of whom had less material and resources when they joined compared to what we‚Äôve just added.

 They simply committed, implemented, and won.

 Could you get these results on your own?

 Absolutely.

 But why take the scenic route when the highway is right there?

 Artisan Lab is now at its new price point, but here's the truth - it's still underpriced for what's inside.

 And it's definitely underpriced for what it'll help you build.

 Your first $10k day awaits,

 Ben

subject: Underwhelming advice from a $500M man
body:
I‚Äôve been reading How To Get Rich by Felix Dennis.

 He was a goofy looking British guy who made multiple 9 figures through his publishing company in the 90s.

 There are plenty of great quotes in the book but here‚Äôs one that‚Äôs stood out to me:

 ‚ÄúThe key to successful business is self-belief and application.‚Äù 

 It‚Äôs underwhelmingly simple.

 On the surface, you might pass it off as generic, bland advice.

 But as I consider my own success, these two elements are at the core of it.

 I believed I could do something cool with my life.

 I took the necessary actions required to do so.

 And eventually things clicked.

 I had no idea how everything would work out, although I naively thought I did.

 Countless reroutes, poor decisions, and overly ambitious timelines later, I‚Äôm where I wanted to be.

 The elements of luck, chance, leverage, and opportunity have played roles as well.

 But they‚Äôre outputs of the first two elements (self-belief and application).

 Without these, you have nothing.

 You are basically a Miami wannabe scammer who swipes up on Instagram stories saying ‚Äúput me on fam üíØ.‚Äù

 Felix Dennis rolls in his grave.

 If you‚Äôre not making the progress you‚Äôd like right now, consider this:

 Do you actually believe you can be successful?

 If no, fix that first.

 If yes, what are the most obvious daily actions you need to take to move the needle?

 Even if these actions aren‚Äôt particularly clear, that‚Äôs okay.

 You just need to use your best judgment and move.

 The path is only illuminated once you begin walking.

 ‚Äã This can be your flashlight. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: The art of figuring it out
body:
You learn the most while flying the plane.

 I‚Äôve always been fairly confident in my figure-it-out-ability. 

 When I was growing up, I‚Äôd hold ‚ÄòA‚Äô to skip through the directions when playing a new video game.

 After a brief period of being completely lost, I‚Äôd get the hang of it.

 This attitude carried into school as well.

 I regularly wouldn‚Äôt study for tests, breeze through instructions, and complete homework assignments while walking in the door.

 Surprisingly, it‚Äôd work out more often than not.

 I‚Äôd end up sitting next to the smart kid who wrote big enough for me to see his answers or I‚Äôd find another creative way to cheat.

 This is how I began to learn the art of figuring it out. 

 There‚Äôs one arena where this figure-it-out-ability has been rewarded tremendously.

 It‚Äôs almost like the less you try to contemplate and prepare, the more you win.

 Not in a chaotic, irresponsible way, but rather in a way that relies on internal trust.

 It‚Äôs an approach that sounds like this:

 ‚ÄúI‚Äùm gonna try this‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôll prepare enough to put myself in a position for success.

 But I understand that most of my learning will be done on the fly.

 And I trust my ability to overcome future obstacles.‚Äù

 This is the world of entrepreneurship.

 Where critical thought is your double edged sword.

 Too little, and you‚Äôll scramble like an ant on a bathroom sink‚Äî

 Aimless, frantic, and one wrong move from getting washed away.

 Too much, and you‚Äôll hesitate, overanalyzing until opportunity slips through your fingers.

 Success is found in the middle ground between YOLO and over preparedness.

 But when in doubt, err on the side of YOLO.

 Seriously ‚Äì when I got into the online business world, I studied a lot.

 I was constantly reading books, watching YouTube videos, taking notes, etc.

 That helped, but NOTHING compares to getting real, in game reps.

 At first you stare at your computer screen like a dyslexic monkey trying to read Chinese backwards.

 But after some trial and error‚Ä¶

 Next thing you know, n«ê zh√®ngz√†i zu√≤ (you‚Äôre doing it).

 To learning on the fly,

 Ben

 P.S. If you're ready to start flying instead of reading manuals, I‚Äôll give you the exact blueprint to build and scale an Info-Product Agency.

 You'll still learn on the fly, but with me as your co-pilot.

 ‚Äã Go here to apply now. ‚Äã

body:

 Jace got here by mastering a few key things:

subject: I sent $1,000 to a stranger (again)
body:
I‚Äôm back in Miami, writing to you from my balcony.

 I‚Äôve spent the last few days in Dorado, Puerto Rico and I‚Äôm heading to LA tomorrow.

 Four years ago when I started a business, this is pretty much all I wanted.

 A nice apartment with a Porsche 911 in the garage, time and location freedom, plus a cool friend group to share experiences with.

 Done.

 My motivation has been mostly selfish and superficial.

 I don‚Äôt have an impoverished family to rescue and I don‚Äôt care about saving the turtles or whatever other driving forces people come up with.

 I wanted to get rich because it sounded way cooler than the alternative ‚Äì sitting in a cubicle and listening to some blue haired woman they/them or skinny-fat balding man tell me when to use the bathroom.

 No thank you ma'am‚Ä¶ or sir I mean.

 Although my initial motivation wasn't altruistic, this selfish pursuit has seemed to end up as the most selfless thing I can do‚Ä¶

 Sunday night, we‚Äôre heading home from dinner in Puerto Rico.

 I‚Äôm on the back of the golf cart as my friend Jimmy drives as if we‚Äôre in a stolen hellcat.

 I check my phone and see a DM from a server at my local lunch spot in Miami.

 He doesn‚Äôt speak much English, but we‚Äôve become friends purely through vibes and Google translate.

 Let‚Äôs call him Juan for the sake of the story (sorry if that‚Äôs racist but I can‚Äôt call him John, because why would someone named John not know English lol).

 Juan tells me he had a family emergency and asks if I could loan him $1,000.

 I get his number, go to Zelle, and send it before we get home.

 I‚Äôm not telling you this to brag about how virtuous I am.

 But rather to tell you not to be ashamed of your ‚Äúwhy.‚Äù

 Many people say you need a strong, unselfish reason to pursue wealth.

 And for those that have one, that‚Äôs great.

 I didn‚Äôt.

 But along the way, nothing has compared to the feeling I get when I can impact the lives of others.

 Seeing people win inside Artisan Lab feels incredible.

 A server thanking me after I tip 100% on a $200 bill feels incredible.

 Being able to send money to people I care about without expecting anything in return feels incredible.

 Just start with whatever motivation gets you moving.

 Even if it's a Lambo with a baddie in the passenger seat.

 Your deeper purpose will often reveal itself later.

 And when it does, it'll fuel you to go further than you imagined.

 Whether you're trying to help your family, escape the cubicle, or just want nice things - you need money to make it happen.

 If you want to learn how to build an info-product agency that could give you the income and freedom to live life on your terms, go here. ‚Äã

 I'm not promising you a Porsche or balcony views.

 But I am showing you a path that worked for me and many of my students.

 Where it takes you is up to you.

 To finding your why along the way,

 Ben

subject: It's irresponsible not to try to get rich
body:
I‚Äôm writing to you from 1B.

 I flew private to LA a few months ago, but times are tough now.

 Or maybe my brain is just closer to being fully developed.

 I‚Äôve got two more years of using an underdeveloped brain as an excuse.

 ‚ÄúSorry I ran over your Grandma, I‚Äôm only 24!‚Äù

 Lol.

 On to more important matters‚Ä¶

 It‚Äôs quite honestly irresponsible for any young semi-competent man to not at least *try* to get rich.

 I grew up in a very affluent area in Ohio.

 Ranked 17th nationally with an average household income of $318,319.

 Many kids from my high school go on to Ivy Leagues.

 Some end up at their parents' companies.

 Others bounce from real estate to random finance jobs.

 It‚Äôs reasonable to assume growing up in an area like this offers great advantages and breeds excellence.

 But many of my high school peers are just not‚Ä¶ doing much.

 It‚Äôs not like they‚Äôre entirely miserable or crash outs.

 They‚Äôre just idle.

 Basically watching the clock until they get whatever‚Äôs in their trust or inheritance.

 They‚Äôll go their entire lives never truly feeling risk.

 They‚Äôll never be in sole control of their path.

 I know these are privileged problems and this may sound like an ideal scenario but I can promise you it typically doesn‚Äôt lead to a full life.

 Even with all their advantages, these people often end up with less fulfillment than someone who built something from nothing.

 Privilege without purpose is just comfortable emptiness.

 It‚Äôs like watching an 80 year long movie where you already know the ending.

 And in search of meaning, you grow bitter, finding silly problems to stress about.

 Yes, it‚Äôs an incredible privilege to never have to worry about money.

 But it doesn‚Äôt guarantee you live a life you enjoy.

 And to me - that‚Äôs what winning is.

 So no matter your situation‚Ä¶

 Whether you‚Äôre born in the 17th wealthiest place in America or the 17,000th.

 Why wouldn‚Äôt you go after what you want?

 You either get it all, or end up somewhere in between. 

 But at least you have a much better story to tell.

 If you‚Äôre ready to take the risk and bet on yourself‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã I can help you here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: The missing piece I've been lying about
body:
Good morning.

 Apologies for the short hiatus, we‚Äôre back in full swing now.

 After a bunch of delays, I finally returned from LA last night.

 While I was there, I met up with James, one of my members inside Artisan Lab.

 We drove around in the hills in my rented 911 Targa.

 As we talked about business, I realized I‚Äôve been lying to you.

 I frequently discuss the hard skills required ‚Äì copywriting, sales, marketing, etc.

 I also talk about the mindset shifts that helped me find success.

 But I‚Äôve been leaving out the last (and potentially most important) piece of the puzzle.

 It‚Äôs the piece that opens doors that are impossible to see.

 Opportunities fall into your lap and you wonder how you got so lucky.

 This is the infinity stone that puts your hard skills on steroids.

 And truthfully, it even makes up for a mediocre skillset. 

 This missing piece?

 People skills.

 You can network your way to wealth.

 You‚Äôre one connection away from a lifetime of referrals.

 You‚Äôre one connection away from hitting a 1,000x on a meme coin.

 You‚Äôre one connection away from landing your dream client.

 Who you know (or who you don‚Äôt know) is actively working for or against you right now.

 If you‚Äôre a normal, socially adept person who makes an effort to meet others in your industry without coming off as a needy cornball, you‚Äôll win.

 I was reminded of this as I was driving through the hills with James.

 He told me about one of his clients who was a referral from another member in Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 And another client I‚Äôd given him directly from my network.

 Not because he‚Äôs an incredibly exceptional marketer who‚Äôs way better than everyone else I know.

 But because he‚Äôs chill and I knew he wouldn‚Äôt sound like a desperate socially inept Apple store employee.

 Now, I‚Äôm not saying you have to be the most charismatic person in the world‚Ä¶

 If you‚Äôre genuine, you offer value, and don't reek of desperation, you‚Äôre in good shape.

 One of my older members inside Artisan Lab networked her way to $70k/mo purely by being normal and asking for referrals.

 Want access to both the skills and network that will drastically expedite your success?

 ‚Äã Join me here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Being a great copywriter is overrated
body:
Being a great copywriter is overrated.

 I know this might sound like backwards advice coming from me, but allow me to explain.

 The info-product space has changed a lot.

 Organic content is more of a necessity now than ever.

 You used to be able to spin up an offer, build a landing page, run ads, and print.

 This has become increasingly difficult as consumers have gotten more skeptical.

 Why would they buy from a stranger in an ad when they‚Äôve consumed hours of free content from someone else?

 They‚Äôll go with the person they trust more.

 And unless you‚Äôre a world-class copywriter, you don't have much of a shot.

 So wouldn‚Äôt that mean that being incredibly skilled at copywriting isn‚Äôt overrated?

 Yes and no.

 For organic audiences you need to be good enough, not great.

 An okay copywriter on a great offer with the right funnel and sales process will outperform a great copywriter without the above.

 The organic content does the heavy lifting.

 As long as you know who you‚Äôre talking to and what their pain points are, simple copy is just fine.

 Additionally your clients don't care about literary brilliance.

 They care about ROI.

 A "good enough" copywriter who understands marketing fundamentals beats the wordsmith who obsesses over minuscule details.

 The gap between "good" to "amazing" rarely justifies the time investment.

 And honestly, with AI tools today, achieving "good enough" copy has never been easier.

 The real skill is knowing which questions to ask and what problems to solve.

 My most successful students aren't the grammar perfectionists or the ones who can recite Breakthrough Advertising by heart.

 They're the ones who:

 Understand their audience deeply Build systems that convert reliably Move quickly and iterate often Prioritize relationships over word choice Don't get me wrong ‚Äì you still need a baseline of competence.

 But if you're obsessing over becoming the next Gary Halbert instead of building connections and refining your offer, you're optimizing the wrong variables.

 ‚Äã Inside Artisan Lab, we focus on the complete picture ‚Äì the copywriting fundamentals that actually matter, plus the systems and relationships that truly scale an info product agency.

 If you want to learn the full blueprint instead of just one skill with decreasing value -- go here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Do not buy Artisan Lab
body:
I have a boring topic for you today.

 It‚Äôs the thing that makes most info sellers roll their eyes.

 They ignore it until there are dozens of reddit threads rightfully slandering them.

 Many info businesses crash and burn quickly because of it.

 This topic?

 It‚Äôs called ‚Äòproduct.‚Äô

 Yes, product, meaning the thing you actually give to the people who pay you.

 I know it‚Äôs rare to hear someone talk about such a foreign concept.

 But this weird little term ends up making or breaking you.

 And most people overlook it until it‚Äôs too late.

 Let‚Äôs say you sell a high ticket coaching program.

 You have a bunch of course content, a couple weekly group calls, and a community.

 At first, it‚Äôs easy to answer questions and make sure people are staying on track.

 It‚Äôs a smaller, tight knit community and students get results.

 However as time goes on and you start scaling, this once small community has turned into a big one.

 There are too many students and not enough of you.

 It‚Äôs effectively become a daycare and you‚Äôre a babysitter trying to stop the kids from revolting.

 Eventually it becomes this big mess where everyones lost, no one gets results, and you hate your own business.

 But here‚Äôs the thing:

 Hiring more coaches doesn't fix this.

 A better course doesn‚Äôt fix this.

 Even more support and clearer roadmap doesn‚Äôt fix this.

 The root of the problem is who you begin selling to.

 Oftentimes to scale, you start selling anyone and everyone who wants to buy your offer.

 And now you have loser idiots who expect to get rich in 24 hours acting as parasites inside your community.

 (What a surprise! The person with a 520 credit score who‚Äôll be paying off your course for the next 76 years isn‚Äôt a competent, responsible human being lol).

 They‚Äôre unrealistic, lazy, and don‚Äôt take accountability.

 This turns off serious prospects because no one wants to be surrounded by a bunch of room temperature IQ smooth brains.

 You‚Äôve created a little idiot army. Congrats.

 Here‚Äôs how to avoid this:

 Do not overpromise.

 Do not take customers' last dollar.

 Do not claim they won‚Äôt have to work hard

 When you‚Äôre realistic in your marketing, people get results like this:

 ‚Äã Dom got a new client 3 days in (this is rare but not impossible).

 ‚Äã Marcus got a new client less than 4 weeks in (also rare, not impossible).

 ‚Äã And Vander, struggled for a couple months (perhaps the most realistic timeline) but is now breaking through, signing two clients in the past week.

 I will not promise you get rich.

 I will simply give you the resources, information, and network that has made me (and many students) rich.

 What you do that this is up to you...

 Do not click here and apply for Artisan Lab if you‚Äôre stupid.

 Do not click here and apply for Artisan Lab if you think it‚Äôll be easy.

 But if you‚Äôre a winner‚Ä¶

 There‚Äôs no better place to be.

 Ben

subject: Hard work won't make you rich
body:
Hard work matters, but not as much as you think.

 I consider it a prerequisite.

 Everyone who finds success goes through a phase where they‚Äôre in the trenches.

 This part sucks, but if you‚Äôre consistent and actually try for two years, you basically guarantee that you‚Äôll make it.

 It doesn‚Äôt mean that you‚Äôll be abnormally successful.

 But enough to where you can make a solid living on your own.

 After that, hard work seems to have diminishing returns.

 Two other factors become increasingly important in your pursuit of wealth:

 Your ability to create leverage. Your speed of execution. I used to never understand what people meant when they discussed leverage.

 It sounded like a buzzword that guru #138 would throw around while wearing dorky blue light blockers.

 And then, I started to actually understand leverage (in this context).

 Leverage is when you can write one email or make one video and generate six figures.

 Leverage is when one hire frees up a month‚Äôs worth of time and energy.

 Leverage is when you can build something once and create systems that allow for exponential growth.

 The more connections, influence, and manpower you have, the more leverage you have, and the richer you get.

 Secondly, your speed of execution dictates everything.

 Life and entrepreneurship are just games of data.

 You have to experience things to know what you like, what you don‚Äôt like, what works, and what doesn‚Äôt.

 The quicker you implement ideas, the quicker you get more data.

 More data creates better decisions.

 Better decisions create more wealth.

 I don‚Äôt want to be the hardest worker in the room.

 I want to be the one with the most leverage and the quickest to execute.

 Then I‚Äôll be doing donuts on a Jetski in the Atlantic ocean while the hardest worker is at a desk in a dark room trying to figure out something I did months ago.

 To working smarter,

 Ben

 P.S. Inside Artisan Lab, you‚Äôll learn how to create leverage and move faster - the exact way I built a 7-figure agency without working myself to death.

 If you‚Äôre ready to stop grinding endlessly and start building real leverage (with the help of AI), go here to apply. ‚Äã

subject: 5 traits of people who will never succeed
body:
Some people just aren‚Äôt gonna make it.

 No matter what they do, they‚Äôll find a way to sabotage themselves.

 You could tell them that all they have to do to get rich is tie their shoes daily.

 They‚Äôd come back to you a week later and tell you they‚Äôre not passionate enough or they didn‚Äôt know what kind of knot to tie.

 They are the kamikaze pilots of entrepreneurship.

 They‚Äôre true masters at one thing and one thing only:

 Self-destruction.

 This has little to do with intelligence and it‚Äôs independent of the business model they choose.

 So what‚Äôs the problem?

 They have unwavering loyalty to a broken mindset.

 While almost no one starts out with the ‚Äúright‚Äù mindset, the game is to discard the beliefs and habits that don‚Äôt serve you.

 Successful people become successful after doing the wrong thing and then correcting it.

 ‚ÄúKamikaze entrepreneurs‚Äù find creative ways to keep doing the wrong thing while convincing themselves they‚Äôre doing the right thing.

 It‚Äôs honestly impressive.

 Here are some traits of those who are not gonna make it:

 - They‚Äôre too distracted, jumping from one thing to the next.

 - They always have an excuse as to why their lack of success isn‚Äôt their fault.

 - They‚Äôre incredibly skilled at deluding themselves into believing they know best.

 - They're unlikable and not smart enough to make up for it.

 - They always feel like they‚Äôre ‚Äúmissing something,‚Äù like there‚Äôs a secret success formula they don‚Äôt have.

 If you identify with any of the above and refuse to change, your failure is inevitable.

 I didn‚Äôt include laziness because typically these types aren‚Äôt lazy.

 The mental gymnastics they're doing to avoid taking action requires an incredible amount of energy.

 But the good news is everyone starts with some of these traits.

 Successful people are self-aware enough to recognize and discard them.

 If these patterns sound familiar, it's your job to begin adapting.

 Only then can everything I'd teach you in here actually help you.

 Choose evolution over self-sabotage.

 Your future is depends on it.

 Ben

subject: "it‚Äôs only cringe until it works"
body:
I was just sitting outside Starbucks trying to start this email.

 There was this jacked dude to my left in a full salmon-colored workout set.

 Didn‚Äôt catch his face, but he had a disheveled videographer taking pictures of him sipping coffee.

 Between the outfit and the coffee photoshoot, I couldn‚Äôt help but start mentally clowning him.

 It felt like a live-action version of the morning routine guy who just went viral on Twitter.

 Then he turned slightly and I got a better look.

 He sort of looked like this popular fitness influencer/podcaster you‚Äôve probably seen on YouTube.

 And when I got up to throw out my coffee, I realized it was Mike Thurston.

 So I stopped clowning him and walked home to write this to you.

 There‚Äôs probably a lesson in there somewhere ‚Äî

 ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt judge a book by its cover‚Äù or ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only cringe until it works.‚Äù

 Whatever. A lol ‚Äî that story was a detour.

 Here‚Äôs what I actually wanted to share:

 Do you remember what you were doing at 15?

 I‚Äôd just gotten my driver‚Äôs permit and was riding around listening to ‚ÄúHotline Bling‚Äù by Drake.

 Like any normal teenage kid my top priorities were sports, keeping my Snapchat streaks alive, and cheating on my homework.

 That was 2015.

 Now it‚Äôs 2025 ‚Äî and meanwhile, Michael, the youngest member inside Artisan Lab, is out here pulling in $10k/month with his Info-Product Agency.

 He‚Äôs 15.

 I sat down with him for a short interview where he breaks down how he went from $3k/month a few months ago to 5-figure months.

 ‚Äã Watch the full interview here -- it‚Äôll probably make you rethink how you spent your freshman year of high school.

 Ben

subject: Boredom is a superpower
body:
The best decisions I‚Äôve made have almost never been extremely calculated.

 Typically, they‚Äôre a result of boredom and curiosity.

 There‚Äôs no 10 step foolproof roadmap.

 There‚Äôs a desire and an idea.

 After some procrastination, one day I‚Äôd wake up too fed up with myself to not act.

 Next thing you know I‚Äôm finally doing it ‚Äì I swatted the gnat buzzing in the back of my mind.

 One day, I was bored so I searched up ‚Äúhow to make money online.‚Äù

 One day, I was bored so I sent my first outreach message.

 One day, I was bored so I began posting videos online.

 The first of those three led me into this space.

 The second got me my first client.

 And the third has made me a couple million dollars.

 All because there was a split second where I decided:

 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna do it now. Not in one hour, not tomorrow and definitely not on the arbitrary date I told myself I‚Äôd start. Right. Now.‚Äù 

 About a year ago, that‚Äôs exactly how I started posting on Youtube.

 I remember sitting in the office of my last apartment and thinking, ‚Äúdamn, I‚Äôve really been putting off this Youtube thing for a while.‚Äù

 Two minutes later, the camera was out and an hour later, I clicked upload.

 That exact decision has made me lots of money, led to many connections, and might be the reason you‚Äôre reading this right now.

 So {{ subscriber.first_name }}, what's the gnat buzzing in the back of your mind?

 What idea keeps popping up that you've been putting off?

 Maybe it's time to get "too fed up" with yourself.

 Maybe today is your "right now" moment.

 Or maybe you should keep watching thirst traps on TikTok and forget you ever read this.

 I‚Äôm not judging you and I‚Äôm not your therapist.

 Hell, I‚Äôd probably keep scrolling too.

 But I will say ‚Äì doing the things you‚Äôve been putting off makes you feel good.

 And being (relatively) rich is fun ‚Äì Definitely more fun than sitting in a cubicle taking orders from some overweight, soy milk drinking, mouth breathing buffoon. 

 So why not try?

 Stop being a [redacted].

 That's it.

 ‚Äã Go here if you want my help along the way. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Abraham Lincoln taught me how to use AI
body:
I got coffee with Chat GPT this morning.

 We were trying to generate an image of Abraham Lincoln and me in the back of a carriage shaking hands.

 At first I gave him two images of me to work off.

 The first response was decent but it made me look like I‚Äôd been born in Brooklyn and was raised on lox and bagels.

 My eyes were too far apart and other features were just a bit off.

 I asked Mr. GPT how we can get it closer to looking like the real me.

 He instructed me to upload more photos of myself, from various angles, so I did.

 We generated the image again and it improved, but I still looked like a close relative of mine, not me exactly.

 I asked him how we could get it to be exact.

 He told me the best route is to train a custom model.

 Now, I know there are softwares that make it easy to generate more realistic images of yourself, but this got me thinking about the learning curve with AI.

 Some people are telling you to be afraid of it, others are saying it‚Äôll do your whole job for you, even if you suck.

 In the info-product/copywriting world, the true answer seems to be somewhere in the middle.

 Here are both sides of the coin:

 AI is incredible and it‚Äôs only getting better but as of now, it can‚Äôt do everything for you.

 You should only be afraid of it if you‚Äôre unwilling to learn how to utilize it.

 A marketer or copywriter empowered by AI is vastly more efficient and accurate than one who isn‚Äôt.

 On the contrary, AI will not save you.

 The notion that you don‚Äôt have to be a good marketer anymore is a complete lie.

 If you don‚Äôt have a solid understanding of what you‚Äôre doing and haven‚Äôt found success pre-AI, it‚Äôs basically useless until you reach a baseline level of competence.

 It won‚Äôt effectively do your outreach, take your sales calls, demonstrate competence, or do your work for you.

 Think of AI as power tools for a carpenter.

 They make a skilled craftsman more efficient, but give a table saw to someone who's never built anything and you'll end up with a missing limb.

 ‚Äã Inside Artisan Lab, you‚Äôll learn both the foundational skills and how to leverage AI as a multiplier.

 Not as a replacement, but as an accelerator.

 Ready to build the skills AI can't replace while learning to use it as your secret weapon?

 ‚Äã Join me inside here. ‚Äã

 To augmentation, not replacement,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: The 2 worst places in America...
body:
This isn‚Äôt gonna be a typical email.

 I won‚Äôt offer you any word of advice and in no way will this help you make more money.

 Actually, I‚Äôll probably say something that offends you.

 Here we go:

 Austin and Tampa are my two least favorite cities.

 I have a deep disgust for both of them (aside from Terry Black's BBQ in Austin) and I‚Äôd pick a vacation to Gary, Indiana over these two places.

 Austin is just weird.

 Their literal slogan is ‚Äúkeep Austin weird.‚Äù

 When I think of this city, images of the following starter pack come to mind:

 A bag of granola, muddy hiking shoes, a cold plunge, and sweaty shirtless men that eat raw meat.

 Tampa is a different story.

 It looks sort of dystopian to me.

 The main thing I dislike is that everyone tries to convince you it‚Äôs like Miami, but smaller.

 Tampa is not a mini Miami.

 There is a meat market, an Edition hotel that smells like garbage, and a cigar lounge.

 That‚Äôs it.

 It‚Äôd be a fine city if everyone stopped trying to push the narrative that it‚Äôs Miami‚Äôs younger brother.

 If anything, it‚Äôs Miami‚Äôs adopted cousin from China with a speech impediment.

 You just feel obligated to be nice.

 Anyway, this thought sparked because there‚Äôs been a lot of Miami slander on social media recently.

 I get it.

 I‚Äôm tired of the scammers, excess of huracans, and OF girls too.

 It‚Äôs a party city and easy to get caught up spending money that you don‚Äôt actually have.

 But here's the cool thing about Miami ‚Äì and life in general‚Ä¶

 You have the power to choose.

 If you‚Äôre disciplined, the above is a non issue.

 Lol nvm ‚Äì I‚Äôm not gonna try to turn this rant into a lesson.

 ‚Äã Here‚Äôs something you might find valuable though. ‚Äã

 Have a good weekend,

 Ben

 P.S. I was initially trying tell you about what's happening inside of Artisan Lab but it wasn't working, so this is what we ended up with.

 Here's what I should've shown you:

 The craziest win of the week -- Jace is casually ripping 6 figure days with clients and may quadruple his personal monthly income (TO $200k) in just a few months.

 ‚Äã ‚Äã And some new clients being signed...

 ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã Join us here. (As long as you're not gonna tell me that Tampa is a mini Miami).

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã
