subject: How to break out of a slump (w/o excess stimulants)
body:
A fly was just buzzing around my laptop.

 I swung twice and missed both times.

 This is a rare occurrence.

 If there's a worldwide fly swatting accuracy leaderboard anywhere, I‚Äôd be near the top.

 It‚Äôs a sunny morning in Miami, although it rained all day yesterday so the ground is still wet.

 I have an iced espresso next to me and I‚Äôm ready to work.

 The past couple weeks have been a bit unfocused.

 I got out of my normal routine from traveling and am now getting back into the swing of things.

 You know that feeling when you want to be productive but you‚Äôre being a lazy, unmotivated piece of shit?

 Me too.

 Slumps like this are inevitable and they happen to everyone.

 Even the greatest athletes on the planet go through periods where they can‚Äôt make a shot or get on base.

 Let‚Äôs consider how they get through this‚Ä¶

 A struggling athlete has to become aware of components that are typically subconscious.

 Perhaps they started rushing their follow-through or rotating too much on their swing.

 To correct themselves, they have to be more intentional and disciplined than usual.

 If they can typically get away with lacing up their shoes right before practice, that‚Äôs not gonna fly for now.

 They have to put more time in, identify the error they‚Äôre making and consciously decide to fix it.

 Eventually things go back to normal and it becomes subconscious or easy again.

 Productivity works the same way.

 When you‚Äôre in a slump, the bitch voice in your head is the loudest.

 To shut it out, you‚Äôll likely have to be more disciplined than usual.

 Get up earlier.

 Stop yourself from scrolling on social media.

 Write down a detailed schedule to follow each day.

 Put your phone on DND and stick to the plan.

 Next thing you know, you‚Äôll knock off the rust and feel good about working again.

 This doesn‚Äôt take long unless you let it.

 A member of Artisan Lab recently came to me with this exact problem and I told him the following:

 ‚ÄúMomentum and habits outweigh motivation. Small wins will create bigger ones. You're one productive morning away from a productive day, and one productive day away from a productive week. Just have to get the ball rolling with the small things.‚Äù 

 Soon enough you‚Äôll get back in rhythm.

 The ball will hit your hands and you‚Äôll effortlessly rise up and let it fly.

 Slump over, Lambo coming soon. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

A fly was just buzzing around my laptop.

 I swung twice and missed both times.

 This is a rare occurrence.

 If there's a worldwide fly swatting accuracy leaderboard anywhere, I‚Äôd be near the top.

subject: I wrote a VSL in 30 seconds (here's how)
body:
I ran an interesting experiment yesterday.

 On my call with the Artisan Lab members, I tested how quickly I could write a VSL for a new offer using AI.

 I scrolled through Youtube until I found a creator who makes content about high ticket sales.

 She has under 1k subscribers but gets solid engagement on her videos and only began uploading a few months ago.

 This potentially would be a great client for a copywriter/info-agency owner for a few reasons:

 - High ticket sales is a validated niche and she innately has a unique mechanism in selling to women.

 - She‚Äôs newer to info and doesn‚Äôt have a full funnel built out yet.

 - She‚Äôs posting consistent content and her personal brand is growing.

 So here‚Äôs where the experiment began:

 I copied the links of her existing YT videos and put them into an AI software I‚Äôm gatekeeping for now (sorry).

 Then I uploaded a VSL framework for AI to reference.

 And I prompted it to write the VSL using the information in her videos based on the winning framework I gave it.

 30 seconds later, the script was done.

 After a few minor edits, my job would be completely finished.

 This is something that used to require hours of research and another hour or so to write.

 Now it can be effectively completed in under 5 minutes with the right AI tools and prompts.

 But here‚Äôs the catch‚Ä¶

 If you don‚Äôt know how to find good clients, what to say in your outreach, and you can‚Äôt articulate your value on a sales call, AI doesn‚Äôt help you.

 Sure you could use the same process I laid out and get a similar result.

 But you also need to be able to demonstrate a solid understanding of the info-product space.

 For me and the members inside Artisan Lab, this is game-changing because we already have the fundamentals down.

 AI is multiplying our effectiveness, not replacing us.

 The gap between those who understand both the info-product space AND how to leverage AI effectively is widening every day.

 If you want to be on the right side of that gap, you need both skill sets.

 Only then will you be able to get results like this‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã Inside Artisan Lab, you'll learn both the foundational knowledge and AI implementations that'll fast-track your success.

 To not getting replaced,

 Ben

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }}, let's compromise...
body:
Fair and noble people make compromises.

 Life is not like Burger King. You can‚Äôt always have it your way‚Ä¶

 Fuck. That.

 This way of thinking is for the mentally enslaved.

 But you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, as a reader of the best newsletter on the internet, deserve better‚Ä¶

 You owe yourself better.

 When you‚Äôre quick to make compromises, here‚Äôs what happens:

 Your Ferrari dreams turn into a Corolla (or perhaps you buy a corvette C8 when you‚Äôre 68 and try to convince yourself it‚Äôs a real supercar).

 Your supermodel wife turns into a plus sized hand model. Or your ‚Äúrich husband‚Äù turns into a guy that makes $105k/yr and loves to say he makes six figures.

 Your dream of waking up to the sound of the waves crashing on the shore only happens 3 days a year. And you‚Äôre on vacation in Myrtle Beach, not Honolulu.

 I know this sounds a bit dramatic, but making compromises when it comes to your desires is a slippery slope.

 You need to be militant.

 You need to be stubborn.

 You need to aim for what you actually want.

 When others tell you to be reasonable, or when you begin to hear a voice in your head negotiating with you, shut it out.

 I‚Äôd rather be an insane, unreasonable, stubborn asshole than a chubby balding middle aged man‚Ä¶ in a COROLLA!

 Do not tolerate behavior that doesn‚Äôt align with your goals.

 When you make a plan, stick to it as if you are following orders from God.

 There is no negotiating, there is no settling, and when you find yourself exchanging ‚Äúgreat‚Äù for ‚Äúgood enough,‚Äù stop yourself.

 If you compromise, I guess I‚Äôll send you a postcard from Honolulu.

 That‚Äôs basically the real thing isn‚Äôt it! LOL!

 No. Stop. It‚Äôs not the real thing. And a C8 isn‚Äôt a supercar. And fuck Mrytle Beach.

 Their rules and standards are meant to be broken. Yours aren‚Äôt.

 See you in a Ferrari with a supermodel in your passenger seat.

 To the stubborn and unreasonable ‚Äì I will help you win. ‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. I‚Äôd feel slightly irresponsible by not clarifying some nuance here.

 Not compromising doesn‚Äôt mean you refuse to turn up the temperature when you set it at 67 and your girl wants it at 72.

 It also doesn‚Äôt mean that there is only one way to accomplish a goal and the route can‚Äôt be adjusted.

 But when it comes to the real shit you want‚Ä¶

 Don‚Äôt let anyone talk you out of it (including yourself).

 ‚Äã This is for those who refuse to compromise. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: The info-product bull run is here
body:
Big things are happening.

 This reminds me of the 2021 crypto bull run.

 Bitcoin surpassed $60k and people were buying million-dollar pictures of cartoon monkeys (NFTs).

 What a time.

 Many of my friends became millionaires that year.

 They‚Äôd get in on a big NFT project or they‚Äôd buy the right coin at the right time.

 But not me.

 I was in the beginning stages of building my agency so that‚Äôs where my energy was directed.

 And looking back, I feel like an idiot for sitting on the sidelines.

 Money was falling from the sky and all I had to do was put my hand out and grab some.

 Right now, a new bull run is happening outside of the crypto world.

 And it‚Äôs creating some of the craziest success stories I‚Äôve ever seen‚Ä¶

 This is Jace.

 ‚Äã You may recognize him from some of my previous emails or the interview we did on Youtube.

 When we recorded that video just 3 months ago, he was at $50k/mo.

 Now, he made $204k‚Ä¶

 In a week‚Ä¶

 Actually just 6 days:

 ‚Äã It feels like the equivalent of hitting a 100x on a random meme coin.

 Except luck doesn‚Äôt play nearly as much of a role here.

 He followed a blueprint, worked incredibly hard, got the right clients, and made it happen.

 This is a result of capitalizing on the info-product bull run.

 As you probably saw, Iman Gadzhi became a co-owner of Whop (the leading digital product platform).

 This means more people will be selling info.

 Which creates more clients to partner up with.

 And more money to be extracted out of thin air.

 Welcome to the info-product bull run.

 You can watch from the sidelines or use this opportunity to build the life of your dreams.

 And if you want to learn from the best of the best‚Ä¶

 Jace is gonna be hosting a guest call inside of Artisan Lab next Wednesday.

 ‚Äã Hop in here before then if you want to learn how he made $200k profit in the last 6 days.

 WAGMI,

 Ben

 P.S. The chances of you making TWO HUNDRED THOUSAND DOLLARS in a single week are slim to none. That is absolute insanity and you will likely not replicate Jace‚Äôs success. BUT you might get sort of close with the right help, if you actually put in the work.

 The creator economy is booming, everyone is slinging info, Whop might be the next Shopify, AND YOU‚ÄôRE NOT GONNA CAPITALIZE ON THIS???

 Don‚Äôt be poor.

 ‚Äã Get in loser, we‚Äôre slinging info :) ‚Äã

subject: You can‚Äôt unsee this
body:
‚ÄúCuriosity killed the cat.‚Äù

 Have you ever heard that phrase?

 I never understood it because my curiosity has never led me astray.

 I just asked Chat GPT about it and guess what he told me?

 The full quote is ‚Äúcuriosity killed the cat, but satisfaction brought it back.‚Äù

 This flips the meaning and suggests that curiosity is worth the risk if it leads to the truth.

 What a scam!

 Imagine going through life thinking that being a curious person is a bad thing...

 Till one day you find out you were abiding by an incomplete phrase.

 This makes me wonder what other quotes we might be misinterpreting.

 Perhaps it‚Äôs ‚ÄúThou shall not kill‚Ä¶ unless someone is going 55 mph in the fast lane.‚Äù

 Or ‚ÄúAll men are created equal‚Ä¶ except for those who drive Corvette C8‚Äôs.‚Äù

 Lol.

 I‚Äôm glad we cleared this curiosity thing up.

 It‚Äôs a trait I observe amongst nearly all successful people I meet.

 They‚Äôre always asking questions and trying to solve problems.

 They don‚Äôt blindly accept the popular opinion, they pause, think and form their own conclusions.

 If you ended up on my email list, you‚Äôre likely more curious than most people.

 Only stubbornness and blind naivety would lead someone into the world of entrepreneurship.

 Most are too ignorant.

 But you‚Äôre curious enough to at least go down the rabbit hole.

 Congrats‚Ä¶

 This was a dangerous, irresponsible thing for you to do.

 Because now, you can‚Äôt unsee it.

 You know this route is possible.

 You know you could build the life of your dreams.

 And you also know it‚Äôs not easy.

 So now, if you return to safety and try to blend in with the dull and ignorant, you‚Äôd go insane.

 You‚Äôd become bitter and angry, both at yourself and at the world.

 Because you‚Äôd know that there‚Äôs a deeper purpose to fulfill and you‚Äôre not doing it.

 Maybe curiosity did kill the cat.

 But at least you know now‚Ä¶

 Everything you dream of exists.

 It‚Äôs real.

 And it‚Äôs on the other side of curiosity, courage, and consistent action.

 So keep asking questions‚Ä¶

 But be careful, because you‚Äôll get the answer.

 ‚Äã If you're ready to turn curiosity into real results, here‚Äôs your next step. ‚Äã

 Build the thing,

 Ben

subject: The most productive thing you can do today
body:
You don‚Äôt need a different business model.

 You don‚Äôt need another ‚Äúhigh-converting funnel template.‚Äù

 You definitely don‚Äôt need another podcast episode on ‚Äúmorning routines of billionaires.‚Äù

 You need silence.

 For five minutes.

 No scrolling. No input.

 No attempt to feel productive by watching someone else do what you're too scared to try.

 Just you. And the truth.

 Because in that silence, you'll be forced to admit something:

 You already know what you should be doing.

 But doing it means letting go of the identity you've built -- the one that's ‚Äúlearning, researching, and getting ready.‚Äù

 So you keep hiding behind consumption.

 Here‚Äôs the truth:

 Action is terrifying because it kills the version of you that talks but doesn‚Äôt do.

 And that version of you?

 It wants to survive.

 But if you want your life to change, that version has to die.

 I made a video about this.

 It‚Äôs not loud.

 It‚Äôs not aggressive.

 It‚Äôs just the boring truth.

 ‚Äã Watch it here. ‚Äã

 Or don‚Äôt.

 Either way, just stop looking for answers you already have.

 Ben

subject: Claude stole my laptop
body:
Good morning.

 There is a 2% chance this is the first email of mine you‚Äôve ever read.

 I did one of those corny lead magnet‚Äôs on my Instagram and now there are an additional 200 of you.

 If you‚Äôre new, welcome.

 This is not your typical guru-list.

 Unlike most newsletters, each email is not an engineered pitch written by a copywriter pretending to be me.

 Although, I‚Äôve been the copywriter pretending to be someone else many times.

 But this is me, physically sitting at my desk typing to you.

 My second coffee of the morning is to my right.

 My first coffee got thrown out after two sips because the barista at Starbucks must‚Äôve woken up on the wrong side of the bed.

 I was playing with AI all night last night.

 Claude now has every email I‚Äôve ever written and knows me better than my mother.

 Together we are gonna take over the world.

 Watch this:

 It mimics my tone, sentence structure, and even my tendency to go on weird tangents about Corvette C8‚Äôs and normies.

 The possibilities are endless.

 Imagine having a digital twin that can handle the mundane writing tasks while you focus on the creative work that actually moves the needle.

 But here's where it gets interesting‚Ä¶

 Wait ‚Äì

 Did you catch that?

 Those last few lines weren't me.

 Claude took over after I said ‚Äúwatch this.‚Äù

 It‚Äôs real me again, typing with my actual fingers.

 Now that AI has hundreds of my previous emails, it‚Äôs pretty good.

 Still not 100%, but close.

 Does this mean that copywriters are cooked? Are you destined to put fries in a bag until AI comes and replaces you again?

 Maybe.

 Here‚Äôs what I think:

 The edge isn‚Äôt voice anymore.

 It‚Äôs perspective.

 AI can mimic cadence. It can‚Äôt manufacture conviction.

 It can remix a thought. It can‚Äôt live one (for now).

 If you‚Äôre an idiot without AI, you‚Äôre still an idiot with it.

 If you‚Äôre skilled without it, you‚Äôre 10x better with it.

 Adapt or die,

 Ben

 P.S. If you want to see how I'm using AI to scale my agency and help my clients make more

 money with less effort, check out Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 You‚Äôll learn the exact systems (plus everything else that's working right now in the info-business space).

 Or if you just want to tell me your thoughts on AI, hit reply. I miss talking to you.

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: Your $204,000 payout is NOT on the way...
body:
I hate it when people come up to me and say ‚ÄúI know you from TikTok!‚Äù

 This is a pretentious thing to complain about.

 But allow me:

 They‚Äôll say these words as if I‚Äôm gonna break into character and start performing for them after.

 Like ‚ÄúI know you from TikTok!‚Äù is code for me to begin singing and dancing like a circus clown.

 But that doesn‚Äôt happen.

 We blankly stare at each other for a sec, then I usually say ‚Äúyeah?‚Äù

 Then they say ‚Äúyeah.‚Äù

 And after another 2.2 seconds of awkward silence I‚Äôll ask their name, tell them it was nice to meet them (it wasn‚Äôt) and move along.

 As I write this I‚Äôm considering the possibility that I‚Äôm the awkward one‚Ä¶.

 Eh no. I‚Äôm normal.

 It‚Äôs the TikTok brained people.

 They‚Äôre the type that would approach a girl and expect her to carry the conversation.

 When others approach me and mention they‚Äôve seen me on YT or Twitter, we have a solid conversation.

 This probably reads as if I‚Äôm trying to indirectly brag about how cool and famous I am.

 I‚Äôm not (ok, maybe a little).

 These awkward interactions are sort of a microcosm of the whole short form content/internet culture.

 It‚Äôs why the ‚Äúthis is so easy, AI will do all the work for you!‚Äù Angle works for marketers.

 It‚Äôs a lie, but it‚Äôs sexy enough that people want to believe it anyway.

 The people that fall for it are the same ones that will send an outbound message and follow up ‚Äú???‚Äù after they don‚Äôt get a reply.

 There is a special place in Clownland for them.

 No one owes you anything.

 Successful people understand this and earn everything they get.

 Like Jace ‚Äì a member in Artisan Lab who recently hit six figure months with his info-product agency.

 ‚Äã In this interview he talks about how he drove 25 hours from Minnesota to Scottsdale to close his first client.

 25 HOURS. To get a coffee with someone.

 That decision led to his first solid case study.

 And it‚Äôs a big reason why a single client just paid him $204,000 in commission for 10 days of work.

 Do the things others won‚Äôt and you will win.

 That‚Äôs how Jace did it. That‚Äôs how you can, too.

 ‚Äã Watch the full breakdown here. ‚Äã

 Then go do something ridiculous.

 Ben

subject: I'm struggling...
body:
I opened a Google doc to write this 19 minutes ago.

 Since then, I‚Äôve written and deleted the first line 4 times.

 I asked AI to give me ideas to write about but didn‚Äôt like any of them.

 Then I got distracted and started scrolling through Instagram.

 Many times, I‚Äôd lose this battle.

 I‚Äôd convince myself that I just don‚Äôt have it in me to write an email today and close my laptop.

 The 2 espresso martinis and 3 tequila sodas I drank last night might have something to do with that.

 But if I lose this battle, I‚Äôll feel like a loser.

 The rest of my day will be clouded by the fact that I didn‚Äôt do this.

 So selfishly, I‚Äôm writing this to avoid feeling like shit.

 And unselfishly, I owe it to you.

 I recently watched a Youtube video where this guy said it‚Äôs your duty as a personal brand to show up for your audience.

 It‚Äôs easy to forget that every ‚Äúview‚Äù on a piece of content is a living, breathing soul.

 Not sending an email on a day you‚Äôre supposed to, is the equivalent of no-showing a date.

 I guess this is our date. I like your tits dress.

 Consistency is a moral duty.

 Every time you leave a task unfinished because you don‚Äôt feel good, you‚Äôre letting down everyone who believes in you.

 That means your family, friends, staff, future children, bloodline, baby mama, followers, and GOD himself.

 You can‚Äôt click buttons on a laptop in an air conditioned box in the sky because you‚Ä¶ have a headache?

 Grow up.

 You are (probably) a man.

 You were lucky enough to be alive in the greatest era in human history.

 Your ancestors had to hunt wild animals.

 You click a few buttons and Pedro shows up 15 minutes later with your burrito.

 Show up for yourself, so you don‚Äôt hate yourself.

 And show up for others, so you don‚Äôt let them down.

 You‚Äôll be glad you did (just like I am right now).

 Ben

 P.S. Neither rain, nor snow, nor sleet, nor hail shall keep the postmen from their appointed rounds. Nor shall a hangover keep you from clicking this... and allowing me to assist you in your pursuit of generational wealth.

 ‚Äã

subject: How to become a billionaire (easy & simple)
body:
Did you know there are only 902 billionaires in the US?

 And somehow they all drive Huracans, sell courses, take high doses of TRT, and live in Miami (lol).

 I have one friend who I think could become a billionaire.

 Not because he‚Äôs close to it or has any kind of head start.

 Right now, he‚Äôs actually the most cash-poor in my immediate circle, as a lot of his money is tied up in a software company.

 Obviously he‚Äôs intelligent, works hard, all of that.

 Those two traits alone aren‚Äôt gonna make you billions ‚Äî the janitor works hard and the economics professor is intelligent‚Ä¶

 Never seen them in a baby blue Huracan.

 But there‚Äôs one trait that makes me bet on him:

 It‚Äôs relentless. Inconvenient. Borderline annoying.

 And it‚Äôs‚Ä¶

 Curiosity . 

 (Coupled with the ability to spot opportunities and execute ‚ÄîI know I said one trait but there‚Äôs always some nuance).

 One day, my potential billionaire friend and I are driving home from the gym.

 I‚Äôm in the passenger seat as Lebron (probably not his real name, obviously) speeds past the cars in the left turn lane, cuts in front of them, and makes a left.

 As I hold on to the roof handle, he begins telling me about quantum physics.

 Most of it goes over my head as he discusses his predictions and what he wants to build in the quantum realm.

 Let me pause here.

 You might be thinking, ‚ÄúBen, your potential billionaire friend is probably just a pothead who goes down weird rabbit holes sometimes.‚Äù

 Maybe.

 But for the right type of person, a weird rabbit hole could be the gateway to extreme wealth.

 You trip and fall and next thing you know you invented the door handle equivalent in the quantum realm.

 If necessity is the mother of invention, curiosity is its grandmother.

 Necessity forces you to be curious.

 Curiosity leads you to find new problems.

 And if you find a reeaaally big problem - and solve it?

 Time to start picking the type of leather you want on the seats of your Gulfstream G700.

 So yeah‚Ä¶

 Maybe ‚ÄúLebron‚Äù ends up broke in five years, yelling about dark matter on the corner of Brickell Ave.

 Or maybe he builds something so impactful it forces us to redefine the word "genius."

 Either way, I‚Äôll keep showing up to hear the next quantum rabbit hole ‚Äì because curiosity pays.

 Stay curious.

 It just might make you billions.

 Ben

 P.S. Inside Artisan Lab, we‚Äôve got a bunch of curious weirdos turning ideas into income. If you wanna get rich without becoming a soulless automaton, you‚Äôd probably like it here. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: Did AI just replace me?
body:
I don‚Äôt want to do this.

 But I have to show you something‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôve been training Claude and ChatGPT on my writing style for about a week.

 It‚Äôs gotten to the point where I could go live in a cabin in Alaska, spend all day with Alpacas, and if AI-me kept emailing you‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôd probably never notice.

 So let‚Äôs run an experiment:

 I‚Äôll come up with an idea for an email.

 Give AI a lazy one-line prompt.

 We‚Äôll read it together.

 Then I‚Äôll meet you at the end and we‚Äôll talk.

 Sound good?

 Cool. (Not like you had a choice anyway.)

 Prompt:

 Write and email about why most people fail when trying to start a business in the info/agency world. 

 BenGPT:

 "Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Here‚Äôs the part they don‚Äôt tell you in those ‚Äúhow I made $100K/month‚Äù YouTube videos: 

 Most people don‚Äôt fail because of strategy. 

 They fail because they‚Äôre fucking soft. 

 They read Russell Brunson, buy a cold email course, slap together an offer, and post 3 times on Twitter. 

 Then wonder why clients aren‚Äôt lining up to wire them $5K. 

 Meanwhile, the guy who is getting clients? 

 He‚Äôs not smarter than you. Or more talented. Or even better looking (unless it‚Äôs me, in which case, sorry bro). 

 He just didn‚Äôt stop. 

 The truth is, most people enter the info/agency game with all the wrong expectations. 

 They think: 

 It‚Äôs gonna be passive. It‚Äôs gonna be fast. It‚Äôs gonna feel good. Wrong, wrong, and LOL. 

 What it‚Äôs gonna feel like is: 

 Rewriting your VSL script 7 times and still hating it. 

 Getting ghosted by 33 different leads in a row. 

 Having a panic attack after realizing you owe Stripe $1,200 in fees. 

 This is not a business for people who crave comfort. 

 This is a business for psychos. 

 The type who‚Äôll build a landing page at 2am just because he had a weird idea in the shower. 

 If that‚Äôs not you ‚Äì cool. 

 Go get a job. Live a peaceful life. Watch Netflix and pay rent forever. 

 But if it is you? 

 Then you need to stop acting like a confused beginner and start behaving like someone who‚Äôs already successful. 

 Because here‚Äôs the truth: 

 There are only 3 things that actually matter when starting your agency/info-biz: 

 A skill that solves a painful problem A system that gets that skill in front of people The brain damage tolerance to repeat that until rich That‚Äôs it. 

 Everything else is masturbation. 

 You don‚Äôt need another course. 

 You don‚Äôt need a better logo. 

 You don‚Äôt need to ask your group chat for feedback on your offer doc. 

 You just need to move. 

 Fast. Messy. Relentless. Like your future depends on it ‚Äì because it does. 

 Ben" 

 [End] 

 Pretty solid, yeah?

 And that was with a half-baked, one-sentence prompt.

 Obviously there‚Äôs still some magic that comes from real-life experiences, fresh insights, and having a pulse.

 But voice-wise?

 I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs 90% of the way there.

 Here‚Äôs the coolest part:

 I now have a repeatable framework I can use with every client.

 Import their data. Feed it the right examples.

 And 30 minutes later? Boom -- I have a writing clone that sounds just like them.

 If you want to learn how to do the same ‚Äî I‚Äôll teach you inside Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 I‚Äôll be in the cabin.

 You bring the alpacas.

 See you in Alaska,

 Ben

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: The three levels of leverage
body:
Money, money, money.

 That‚Äôs all I care about right now.

 Unless you‚Äôre already sitting on 8 figures, or you‚Äôre a hippie-meditator-eat-bugs-and-practice-acceptance type‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôd recommend making money your top priority.

 If there‚Äôs a sliver of ‚ÄúCapitalist pig‚Äù in your mind after reading that, skip the rest of this email and hit unsubscribe at the bottom.

 Goodbye.

 Now that all of the purple haired people are gone, let‚Äôs talk money, {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "bro" }}!

 On a recent 1-1 call with a new Artisan Lab member, I broke down the three elements of success in the digital economy.

 When you first start, you have none of the three.

 As you progress, you earn your badges and things get a whole lot easier.

 Here‚Äôs the breakdown:

 1. Skill set 

 This one‚Äôs the most obvious.

 Learn a skill that other people find valuable, trade that skill for money.

 This is the prerequisite.

 It‚Äôs the equivalent of a college degree in the entrepreneur world (except it actually means something).

 As you increase competency, you grow capable of solving bigger problems that pay better.

 Once this foundation is laid, the other two elements unlock‚Ä¶

 2. Opportunity vehicle 

 This is what you‚Äôre selling and who you‚Äôre selling to.

 The best marketer in the world will make no money if their clients are broke.

 On the contrary, apply your skill set the right way (in a growing industry where people are making lots of money) you‚Äôll be paid in proportion.

 Nail these two, and money starts to rain.

 And then, there‚Äôs the third which makes everything click‚Ä¶

 3. Influence 

 This is who you know and who knows you.

 It could mean attention on social media or even just a network of the right people.

 That‚Äôs it.

 Skill, vehicle, influence.

 Master all three and business becomes unfairly easy.

 Ignore even one‚Ä¶ and you‚Äôll feel like you‚Äôre a stripper without rhythm. Or an ass.

 So here‚Äôs the move:

 Audit yourself.

 What‚Äôs missing?

 What‚Äôs the next smallest move to fix it?

 For me, working with course sellers was the unlock.

 Skillset? Check ‚Äî copywriting and funnel building were finally being put to good use.

 Vehicle? Check ‚Äî these creators had leverage, audience, and cash flow.

 Influence? Check ‚Äî proximity to high-level operators opened more doors than I could count.

 It was the rare overlap of all 3 elements.

 And once I leaned in, everything changed.

 If you‚Äôre still trying to force something that doesn‚Äôt check all three boxes‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã Maybe it‚Äôs time to pivot. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

 I‚Äôd recommend making money

subject: Still interested in the 911 Turbo S?
body:
What‚Äôs the difference between a Porsche 911 Carrera and a Turbo S?

 From the outside, they look almost identical.

 Only car nerds can tell the difference.

 But the Turbo S will cost you over $100k more than the Carrera.

 Why would someone pay six figures more for a model that only impresses car nerds?

 They give you a handjob at the dealership when you get the Turbo S. 

 The engine.

 640 horsepower vs. 379.

 0-60 mph in 2.4 seconds vs 4.0.

 The Turbo S is a supercar. The Carrera is a nice daily.

 From ten feet away you‚Äôd never know.

 But the second you hit the gas?

 The Turbo S launches.

 The Carrera just‚Ä¶ moves.

 That‚Äôs the power of what‚Äôs under the hood.

 In the coaching space, your product is your engine .

 And most people forget about it.

 A good product means sexier marketing.

 Your testimonials are your rims, wheels, and headlights.

 You can coast with a shit product‚Ä¶

 Until you floor it next to someone with real horsepower.

 Then you blow up.

 Artisan Lab is finally to the point where it feels like a V10.

 When I started coaching, it was just a private group and a few calls.

 I let in 20 people and used it as a test run.

 Took the feedback.

 Built out a full course.

 Rebranded it from The Bader Group to Artisan Lab .

 That‚Äôs where most people stop.

 They build the course, toss in some weekly calls, and shift all attention to marketing.

 But here‚Äôs the truth:

 If your product isn‚Äôt improving, it‚Äôs deteriorating.

 So I kept going:

 I update the content constantly based on where people get stuck Every call is recorded and labeled inside a searchable vault I bring in 7‚Äì8 figure entrepreneurs twice a month for guest sessions I paid one of my star students to build an outreach course, and my sales guy to build a sales management course Sean ‚Äî one of the best marketers I know ‚Äî runs weekly calls and offers 1-1 support And as of yesterday, Jace (you‚Äôve probably seen him in a testimonial) is now running an additional weekly group call Here‚Äôs the current engine:

 Content ‚Äì funnels, copywriting, sales, acquisition, personal brand & everything in between

 1-1 Support ‚Äì from me and Sean

 Active 24/7 Community ‚Äì no idiots allowed, only winners

 Coaching ‚Äì 3 weekly calls, led by me, Sean, and Jace (plus bi-weekly guest calls)

 Plus plug and play SOPs, frameworks, and all the other more boring stuff...

 This has inadvertently turned into a pitch.

 But that‚Äôs kinda the point.

 When your product is actually good , you don‚Äôt need to force a transition or do some weird NLP sales voodoo.

 You just talk about it.

 Because you‚Äôre proud of the engine you‚Äôve built.

 ‚Äã Artisan Lab is the engine.

 Everything else is just the body kit.

 And if you want to go fast, you‚Äôre gonna need something under the hood that doesn‚Äôt explode when it gets on the highway.

 ‚Äã Apply here if you want to build your own Turbo S. ‚Äã

 Not a Corolla with a spoiler (or God forbid a corvette C8).

 Ben

subject: How to get a client in the next 7 days
body:
Idleness is the root of suffering.

 That‚Äôs it.

 Maybe that‚Äôs what the Buddha meant to say too but it got lost in translation.

 The life changes you think will make you happy?

 Illusions.

 You're convinced the issue is your job, your city, your relationship, or your (smol) bank account.

 But it's not.

 You feel like shit because you're stagnant.

 The human mind wasn't designed to be still.

 You were designed to hunt, build, pursue, do. 

 When you stop moving, that energy has nowhere to go, so it turns inward.

 Next thing you know, you‚Äôll be a depressed 47 year old, substance addicted, beer-bellied, bitter, man-child. And your wife will beat you.

 Is that what you want?

 I doubt it.

 The voice in your mind that's constantly displeased gets quiet when you start moving.

 Action is the only answer.

 Even when you don't know where to go, what to do, and you feel like you're in over your head.

 You can‚Äôt think your way out of a rut.

 You have to move your way out.

 That‚Äôs the whole game.

 Ben

 P.S. I Just dropped a ‚Äãnew video ‚Äã with two members in Artisan Lab.

 They quit their jobs. Got their first client in a week. Now doing $30K/month.

 It‚Äôs simple this is when you take action Check it out. ‚Äã

subject: Be more impulsive
body:
Good morning and happy Monday.

 A man in his mid-30‚Äôs just walked by me in a button down and tie that looked like it was choking the life out of him.

 I assume he‚Äôs on his way to the office.

 And once again, I‚Äôm reminded to be grateful for my impulsiveness.

 I remember the exact moment I decided not to be a wagie slave for the rest of my existence.

 There I was, in my sophomore year of college at frat party #397 of the semester.

 As I drunkenly looked around at everyone having fun, I thought to myself ‚Äúyeah, no thanks.‚Äù

 Here‚Äôs a picture from that night:

 ‚Äã The next day I started planning my escape.

 I‚Äôm gonna drop out and move to Mexico once the semester is up.

 It was a decision I made on a whim‚Ä¶ kinda.

 Sometimes impulsivity is the only way things actually happen.

 There‚Äôd been a lingering voice in my head for a while.

 And deep down, I always knew that the ‚Äúcan I take a vacation please?‚Äù route wasn‚Äôt for me.

 But it‚Äôs not official until it‚Äôs official.

 Once I made a legitimate decision, unenrolled in classes, and booked my flight to Tulum, it became real.

 It was no longer a lingering thought ‚Äî and my life changed for the better.

 So, what‚Äôs going on in your life that you know isn‚Äôt in alignment with your soul?

 It could be as grand as your career path or as small as your social media addiction.

 You know it needs to change and you keep telling yourself it will.

 But when? 

 That‚Äôs the million dollar question.

 When the universe sends you a perfectly-timed, arbitrary wake-up call?

 Maybe.

 Or maybe a month, a year, 10 years, or‚Ä¶ never?

 Maybe you need to be more impulsive. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã I know this ‚Äúus vs. the system" angle is incredibly overused and if you want to be a normie, I‚Äôm not judging you.

 But know there will probably come a time when you, too, are wearing a button down and tie that‚Äôs way too tight on you and some asshole kid writes an email about it.

 And maybe the voice in your head that knows better will linger forever.

 Unless you act on it.

 See you at the office, {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "bro" }}!

 Ben

 P.S. My calendar for Artisan Lab was full over the weekend so if you tried to book and couldn‚Äôt I‚Äôm sorry. I opened it back up, so you can apply here and book in now. ‚Äã

‚Äã

subject: Put lipstick on a pig with AI
body:
I officially became a nerd yesterday.

 I went through what can be described as a business-tracking crisis.

 What doesn‚Äôt get tracked doesn‚Äôt improve ‚Äì and I realized my tracking is meh. 

 Frantically, I began building automations, SOP‚Äôs, and Google Sheets.

 I typically hate doing this type of stuff.

 It feels like listening to a Miami girl talk about astrology, minus the lip filler and silicone.

 Painful.

 But yesterday, I powered through it.

 I set up new zaps, built a Slack channel, and made a tracking sheet for my Artisan Lab members.

 The sheet was the hardest of it all.

 It required complex formulas and I‚Äôm a college dropout. Not a good combo, typically.

 But I had a cheat code.

 Any time I got stuck, I‚Äôd turn to AI.

 ‚ÄúHello, my Glorious KingGPT. How do I sum an itemized list based on certain criteria? Plz reply. Thx ily.‚Äù

 AI would then give me the exact formula to plug in.

 I‚Äôd follow its instructions.

 And if anything broke, I‚Äôd simply take a screenshot and ask it what went wrong.

 With AI‚Äôs help, the sheet took me around 30 minutes to build.

 Without it, it would‚Äôve taken hours or I would‚Äôve quit.

 It also saved me time after a sales call yesterday.

 My ‚ÄúAI Companion‚Äù joined my Zoom meeting with me.

 The word companion makes me think of dogs, so I named him Buddy.

 After the call, Buddy sent me a summary of everything we talked about with a detailed plan outlining the next steps.

 Simple things like this have been saving me hours.

 Everyone (myself included) talks about writing copy with AI because it sounds sexy.

 But what might be even cooler, is it makes the boring stuff easier.

 Unless you had a Minecraft addiction and were nonverbal in groups larger than 2 growing up, you probably hate automations, tracking, and summarizing data.

 AI makes this way less painful.

 Don‚Äôt overlook using it to improve your workflow, outside of writing copy.

 That‚Äôs only the tip of the iceberg.

 I break all this down (and more) for my coaching clients.

 If you're building an info-product agency and want to save time, make more money, and not cry while setting up Zapier... apply here. ‚Äã

 Gonna go play with Buddy,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: How I escaped the guru hamster wheel
body:
‚ÄúI just wanna make $5k per month,‚Äù I thought to myself.

 It‚Äôs January 1st, 2020.

 I‚Äôm sitting in my childhood bedroom with 6 Youtube tabs open on my laptop.

 One‚Äôs a dropshipping video, another‚Äôs about SMMA.

 The rest are random business models I found on ads along the way.

 This is what one may call shiny object syndrome maxxing. 

 I know something can work‚Ä¶

 These gurus claim to be making so much money online.

 I don‚Äôt completely trust them, but there has to be some level of truth to it.

 And they can‚Äôt be that much smarter than me, right?

 I might not be the next Einstein, but I‚Äôm definitely not a complete idiot.

 And dedication isn‚Äôt the problem‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm willing to work hard.

 The problem is, I need to find the right outlet to channel my ambition.

 $5k per month. That‚Äôs all I need.

 I‚Äôll get my own apartment and have enough money for food and juul pods.

 What more does a 19 year old kid need?

 Ok, maybe I‚Äôll get a used 911 too.

 But fuck, where do I start?

 My head is beginning to hurt from all of the ‚Äúbest online business model of 2020‚Äù videos.

 There‚Äôs no way there are 36 ‚Äúbest‚Äù business models.

 35 of you guys are lying.

 I just need to find the one who‚Äôs telling the truth‚Ä¶

 Or maybe the one that‚Äôs best for me‚Ä¶

 Or maybe I shouldn‚Äôt drop out of colle‚Äì FUCK!

 I can‚Äôt keep doing this.

 I need to pick something and stick to it.

 If I get burned by a guru, so be it ‚Äì I‚Äôd rather go down swinging.

 Fast forward about a year, I‚Äôm‚Ä¶ at the plate, you could say.

 Not hitting much, but at least I‚Äôm trying.

 I‚Äôve now started a videography business, dropshipping store, ad creative agency and high ticket sales‚Ä¶

 Aaaand I‚Äôm still poor.

 The previous handful of business attempts have beaten the idiot out of me.

 I‚Äôm ready to go all in on one thing‚Ä¶

 Lead generation agency. For basketball trainers.

 Good idea? No.

 Good mindset? Yes.

 Although it wasn‚Äôt the ‚Äúbest‚Äù business model I could‚Äôve picked, it began to work.

 I stuck with it for over a year.

 $5k months ‚Äì check.

 Drop out of college ‚Äì check.

 I moved to Mexico, kept building, and hit $10k months.

 And then‚Ä¶

 I stumbled into a much better way to make money online that didn‚Äôt require me to beg broke people for $1k retainers.

 So, here I am now.

 The same kid who wrote this journal entry on January 8, 2021‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúI am lost‚Ä¶ Do I want to start an agency? Do I want to be a closer? Should I say fuck it and try something else? Do I need to go back to school? ‚Äù

 This one‚Äôs getting long so I‚Äôll leave you with this:

 Close your Youtube tabs.

 Pick one thing.

 The best business model is the one you pick and commit to.

 ‚Äã I‚Äôll help you here. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: From $3k to $150k/mo in under a year
body:
Running an agency sucks.

 You have to deal with a bunch of clients, manage employees, and constantly deal with churn.

 Unless... you don't.

 Meet Danny.

 A year ago, he was making $3-5K/month with his content agency.

 Today, he's driving a 911 Turbo S and pulling in $150K/month from ONE single client.

 Not 50 clients paying him $3K/month.

 Not 150 clients paying him $1K/month.

 One. Client.

 While most are busy sending cold DMs that never get opened and begging for $500 retainers, Danny cracked the code on how to become an actual partner in someone's business.

 ‚Äã In this video, he breaks down:

 -- How he went from filming videos to owning a percentage of an 8-figure info business

 -- The exact outreach strategy that got him his whale client (hint: it's not what everyone else is doing)

 -- How they scaled from $100K to $650K/month in just 6 months

 Danny's not some 45-year-old guru who's been doing this for decades.

 He's 21. And he figured this shit out in less than a year.

 ‚Äã Watch the interview here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: You're a millionaire
body:
I became a millionaire on paper about a year ago.

 That didn‚Äôt really register until last week.

 I looked at some numbers, thought ‚Äúhuh, that‚Äôs neat,‚Äù and went back to scrolling Instagram.

 A few years ago, that number felt like a pipe dream.

 It was my endgame.

 Now everyone and their grandma is a ‚Äúmillionaire‚Äù (at least in YouTube thumbnails).

 The pedestal disappears once you‚Äôre standing on it.

 ~A millionaire~

 Such a broad term.

 Someone making $100k/yr with a Saas can convince themselves they‚Äôre a millionaire based on a hypothetical valuation of their company.

 That‚Äôs very different from someone with $5m liquid.

 Most people are ‚Äúmillionaires‚Äù the same way someone‚Äôs a ‚Äúbusiness owner‚Äù because they open an LLC.

 Definitions get blurry when everyone starts flexing.

 But really, the goal is to forget along the way.

 Be so locked in on your vision, stacking cash and then one day you realize you ‚Äúmade it.‚Äù

 But by then, your idea of making it will have evolved a dozen times and you‚Äôll feel poor.

 That‚Äôs where I‚Äôm at.

 I know this reads like a humble brag, but I‚Äôm 24 ‚Äì it‚Äôs really not that impressive.

 However, the 20 year old version of me who was just getting started in online business would think it‚Äôs pretty cool.

 Back then I didn‚Äôt fully believe any of this was possible.

 Millionaire? Maybe one day.

 But I just wanted to make enough money so that I didn‚Äôt have to ask some dickhead for a day off.

 ‚ÄúS..sss‚Ä¶Sir‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not feeling too well, can I‚Äî‚Äù

 I‚Äôd rather sell my body on OF.

 Anyway, it works.

 This vision that plays in the back of your mind is real.

 Not every guru is trying to fuck you over.

 There are people just like you (and probably much dumber) who‚Äôve actualized their goals.

 Stop listening to the sliver of doubt that creeps into your mind whenever you‚Äôre about to take a leap.

 ‚Äã Just jump. ‚Äã

 You‚Äôll grow your wings on the way down‚Ä¶

 And one day, you‚Äôll look up and realize you did it.

 But by then, it‚Äôll feel normal ‚Äì and you‚Äôll know you‚Äôve got so much further to go.

 Or you can ignore everything I said and just keep watching other people win:

 ‚Äã (that one's crazy ‚¨Ü)

 ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã Up to you. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: Just move
body:
It‚Äôs 9:39am on a sunny Monday in Miami.

 I just opened a Google doc to write to you.

 Actually, that was a lie.

 I‚Äôve had this page open for about 20 minutes but I kept distracting myself.

 So now, my other tabs are closed and my phone is on DND.

 Good morning, {{ first_name | default: "friend" }}.

 Today is one of those days where I just don‚Äôt want to do this.

 But I know that if I succumb to that emotion, the rest of my day will be even worse.

 That is how losers are created ‚Äì and I‚Äôm too blessed to be a loser today.

 If there‚Äôs one word that defines the lesser type, it‚Äôd be idle.

 I‚Äôve been there.

 Waiting for inspiration to take action.

 Thinking someone or something is gonna come to save me.

 My foot would hover over the gas pedal, teasing the idea of pressing down.

 Some nights I‚Äôd even find a burst of inspiration after stumbling down a YouTube rabbithole.

 I‚Äôd swear that tomorrow would be the day everything changed.

 But when morning came, I‚Äôd freeze again.

 Scared of what might happen if I actually picked up speed.

 Every time I got close to jumping, I bitched out.

 And even when I did jump, I'd revert back to my old self the second the excitement wore off.

 This type of idleness is a surefire way to guarantee misery.

 I‚Äôd rather be ignorant and oblivious than aware and idle.

 Awareness without action is self-inflicted torture.

 Desire sits in your soul for a reason.

 When you want it badly enough to begin moving toward it, that means you were destined to have it.

 But you sit there‚Ä¶

 Overthinking, waiting, and making excuses.

 You let fear and doubt scramble your brain while life passes you by.

 The truth is ‚Äì smart people don‚Äôt contemplate every move.

 They‚Äôre smart enough to know what thoughts they shouldn‚Äôt listen to.

 At some point, as the great philosopher Socrates once said, ‚ÄúFuck it, we ball.‚Äù

 Feel the fear.

 ‚Äã Hit the gas. ‚Äã

 And trust that you'll figure it out before you crash into a tree.

 Idleness is death,

 Ben

 P.S. Join the winning team here. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: "yOuR nEtwoRk iS yoUr NetWorTh"
body:
My least favorite word in the English dictionary is ‚Äúnetworking.‚Äù

 No brother, I do not want to connect for a virtual coffee.

 That said, building a tribe of like-minded friends has been a big reason I‚Äôve succeeded.

 When I first started taking online business seriously, I was living in a frat house.

 Most of my friends were supportive but they didn‚Äôt necessarily get it.

 I distinctly remember a conversation I had with a childhood friend when I was home for the summer.

 He was as skeptical as they come.

 We went back and forth as he tried to poke holes in my plan and deter me.

 By the end of the conversation, he was angry.

 The idea of me following a different path made him bitter.

 Eventually, I just stopped trying to explain it to him.

 Most of my closest friends now are people I met in coaching programs or social media.

 We‚Äôre all on the same path.

 We push each other.

 We‚Äôre not ‚Äúnetworking,‚Äù we‚Äôre building together.

 And occasionally that means we spend five figures on bottles at LIV like it‚Äôs a tax write-off (it is).

 So as corny as the ‚Äúyour network is your net worth‚Äù saying is‚Ä¶

 It‚Äôs fairly accurate.

 If you have no one to turn to when shit gets tough, you‚Äôre more likely to talk yourself out of action.

 Your standards come from proximity.

 Surrounding yourself with people who make you feel like you‚Äôre behind brings the best out of you.

 Because deep down‚Ä¶

 You know your idiot friend who fell in love with a stripper isn‚Äôt smarter than you.

 He‚Äôs just moving faster.

 That‚Äôs why I built Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 It‚Äôs not just about learning how to land a client or scale an offer.

 It‚Äôs about being in the right room where the standard is getting results like this:

 ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã If you want to "level up your network" without chanting affirmations in a forest -- come apply to Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 We‚Äôre just getting warmed up.

 Ben

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

 That said, building a tribe of like-minded friends has been a big reaso

subject: Boooringg
body:
I‚Äôve been enjoying the boring stuff more recently.

 Automations, SOP‚Äôs, and Google sheets have always been a fear of mine.

 The people who talk about these things online are always so nerdy.

 This made me think that building proper systems would turn me into a virgin with blue light blockers glued to my face.

 Luckily, that didn‚Äôt happen.

 My systems have always been ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù but not great.

 I relied heavily on the more fun side of the equation ‚Äì content, angles, offers, etc.

 But what I‚Äôm realizing now more than ever, is that the boring stuff makes the fun stuff funner.

 Scaling feels better when you‚Äôre building on a solid foundation.

 When your foundation is solid and your numbers are clear, your bottlenecks become creative puzzles, not existential threats.

 This stuff feels so miniscule but if you neglect it for too long, it can burn down your business.

 Most info-sellers build a course, set up a community, hire coaches and call it a day.

 It‚Äôs fine to start, but it must evolve.

 Your product is a living, breathing organism.

 If you‚Äôre not building systems that make it easier for members to succeed.

 And you don‚Äôt use tools to speed up their learning curve‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôre simply being negligent.

 Access will always be the core of the product, but why not use tools to make everything else more efficient?

 This is what I‚Äôm doing with Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 I began to think about what AI will do to online education and realized‚Ä¶

 We are not far away from a time where a non-AI powered product is obsolete.

 It‚Äôll be like using a blackberry in 2025.

 You‚Äôre a dinosaur.

 Yes, the product is ‚Äúboring.‚Äù

 Yes, the systems are tedious.

 But they‚Äôre part of the foundation.

 And a solid foundation frees up your brain to go all-in on the fun shit.

 Content. Offers. Funnels. Vision.

 Your program becomes something that doesn‚Äôt just look good‚Ä¶ but runs good.

 And that‚Äôs why I put on my nerd hat and started building.

 Because AI will make all this shit a necessity.

 ‚Äã Adapt or die. ‚Äã

 Ben

‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: Why SMMA sucks
body:
I hate people.

 Let me rephrase that:

 I hate annoying people.

 I hate managing people.

 I hate babysitting people.

 Despite these factors, I began my entrepreneurial career in the SMMA space charging $1k monthly retainers.

 This meant I had to get lots of clients and deal with lots of people to make money.

 But I was hungry enough to make it work.

 After about a year, I was making around $15k/mo‚Ä¶ with 15 clients.

 In total, I worked with over 50 clients during that run.

 That‚Äôs a lot of people for someone who hates people!

 And every day, I‚Äôd wake up to fires‚Ä¶

 Clients complaining, breaching our three month agreement, or trying to add on services that were completely out of scope.

 (Maybe the reason you‚Äôre not getting results is because you haven‚Äôt replied to the 136 leads I‚Äôve gotten you. And no, I will not throw in email marketing for your baby mama‚Äôs nail salon). 

 I knew there had to be a better model.

 Fewer clients, less churn, and more predictability.

 And I‚Äôd finally discard the exhausting, ever present thought of ‚Äúthis could burn down at any moment.‚Äù

 My goal -- make $15k/mo with no more than 5 clients.

 That‚Äôs when I started shifting to info-product businesses.

 My first client was an online basketball trainer.

 I sent him a voice memo offering to help with his funnel.

 A few days later, I was on a call with his business partner.

 I didn‚Äôt have a fancy pitch, I just told them I‚Äôd help however I could.

 Funnels, ads, email copy‚Ä¶ I just wanted out of SMMA.

 They brought me on to run ads.

 I charged $1k/mo (I knew no better) and 10% of return on ad spend.

 That first month, they paid me $2,351 just from the rev share.

 That was 2.35x more than I was used to.

 This was the lightbulb moment.

 Why was I still begging for $1k retainers when I could just get‚Ä¶ better clients?

 I imagine this is how the man who invented sliced bread felt.

 I‚Äôm a genius!

 Five months later, I‚Äôd dropped nearly all of my SMMA clients.

 Now I had five instead of 15, and made $16,290 that month.

 I hit $25k two months later.

 And $100k/mo a year after that, with just seven clients.

 No chaos.

 No babysitting.

 The problem was never my skill set.

 It was the vehicle.

 And this is the one that finally worked.

 Ben

subject: Why you CAN trust strangers on the internet
body:
Is internet money actually real?

 This question sat in the back of my mind for a while.

 I wanted to believe it was real, but I had no first-hand data.

 The guys I watched on Youtube sounded legit, but they‚Äôre still strangers on the internet.

 When I was little, I talked to ‚ÄúMegan Fox‚Äù on Facebook.

 That‚Äôs how I learned to not trust strangers on the internet.

 But sometimes, it‚Äôs not all bad.

 Sometimes, talking to a stranger on the internet might make you rich.

 One of my first Artisan Lab members was this 18 year old kid named Tomy.

 Unlike most members, he had basically zero experience online.

 I actually got a little annoyed with my closer when he joined because I thought this might be too overwhelming for him.

 Artisan Lab was brand new and not yet ‚Äúbeginner-proof.‚Äù

 This was Tomy‚Äôs intro message when he joined:

 ‚Äã I hopped on a 1-1 with him and gave him a roadmap.

 To my surprise, he began following it to a T.

 He showed up to every call, asked questions, kept me updated, and even started posting on Twitter.

 ‚ÄúThis mf has that DAWG in him,‚Äù I thought to myself.

 Despite this, he still struggled for a bit.

 He dealt with a few crappy clients but finally found a solid one.

 That client scaled to $50k/mo in just a few months.

 And Tomy actually paid off Artisan Lab with the money he made from that.

 (I wouldn‚Äôt recommend doing this but like I said ‚Äì Tomy is a DAWG).

 Yesterday, he posted a win inside the community that made me smile like a serial killer.

 ‚Äã It took him about 9 months.

 From complete beginner, to his first $10k month.

 That might not sound super sexy in a world where everyone promises you ‚Äú$10k/mo in 3 months or you don‚Äôt pay.‚Äù

 That‚Äôs all bulshit.

 When you‚Äôre completely new, you have to accept that it‚Äôs gonna be a long, bumpy road in the beginning.

 But when you get over that hump, things get fun.

 And I‚Äôm excited to see how quickly Tomy is able to scale from here.

 Typically, the business that gets you to your first $10k/month can‚Äôt take you much farther beyond that.

 That‚Äôs not the case here.

 The hardest part is over, and now he just has to double down.

 Tomy, I‚Äôm proud of you bro.

 And if you‚Äôre like him and you have that DAWG in you‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã Here, I‚Äôll give you the same roadmap I gave him. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: I <3 Whales
body:
Good morning.

 It‚Äôs a sunny Monday in Miami.

 I‚Äôm sitting outside of Starbucks thinking about how much I hate outbound.

 To put it bluntly ‚Äî Trying to get clients absolutely blows dick at first.

 I spent my first two years in business on a client hamster wheel.

 I‚Äôd send dozens of pitches.

 Get on a few sales calls.

 Close a couple clients.

 And then most would leave after a few months.

 The cycle then continued‚Ä¶

 Until I found the Info-Agency model.

 I started getting clients on rev shares which meant I could make more money without getting more clients.

 Instead I could just make them more money.

 Pretty cool.

 The best part is, this makes it easier to get clients.

 After all, you don‚Äôt want to be DMing strangers, begging for a crum of money forever.

 You‚Äôd rather have them come to you.

 The only way to do that, is to be someone others talk about.

 And the only way to do that, is to get clients insane results.

 (Which you‚Äôre incentivized to do when you have a rev share).

 Here‚Äôs how this plays out:

 The other day, I was at lunch with my friends Phillip and Jace (both are members in Artisan Lab).

 They told me how they had too many prospects wanting to work with them and not enough bandwidth.

 Both are working with whale clients only right now.

 Jace has a single client paying him 6 figures in a month.

 And Phillip‚Äôs smallest client paid him $30k last month.

 Because they‚Äôre getting such good results, word spreads and they have prospects lining up to work with them.

 They don‚Äôt have to slide in DMs.

 They don‚Äôt have to send hundreds of cold emails.

 And they don‚Äôt have to deal with clients churning every month.

 This is the difference between chasing clients‚Ä¶ and *attracting them.*

 When you finally make that shift, business gets fun again.

 The money's better. 

 The stress is lower.

 And you‚Äôre perceived as a partner rather than a service provider.

 If that‚Äôs what you want, Artisan Lab was built for you. ‚Äã

 I‚Äôll help you land your first whale and keep ‚Äòem forever.

 Ben

subject: I got a penthouse
body:
Goooood morning {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Here‚Äôs an unsolicited POV from my new penthouse in Miami:

 ‚Äã I moved in yesterday and let me tell ya‚Ä¶

 Moving sucks.

 However, it gave me the opportunity to be a customer and client ‚Äì which is fun for me as a business owner.

 I‚Äôm able to observe what it‚Äôs like from the other side.

 I hired this moving company called ‚ÄúPiece Of Cake Moving.‚Äù

 There‚Äôs a copywriting lesson in the name itself.

 They have big pink trucks that stick out like an OF girl in a church.

 A quick Google search told me that this is a big company.

 They have over 350 trucks, employ 800+ people, and handle over 100,000 moves a year.

 This has made Mr. Piece Of Cake, a rich man ‚Äì they made over $100m in 203.

 And after they helped me move, I can see why.

 They were at the top of my Google search, so I clicked and filled out a form outlining the items I had to move.

 A few minutes later I had a quote for $450.

 I didn‚Äôt have a ton of stuff but I had them pack it all up too, so I found this to be incredibly cheap.

 Appointment scheduled.

 They followed up with me over the next couple of days, sent all the insurance forms, and arrived on time.

 My main mover was named Jason.

 He now is the primary beneficiary in my will.

 We coordinated everything and it was about as smooth and easy as can be.

 I ended up having extra items that I didn‚Äôt list in the initial itinerary and he threw them in for me.

 He moved everything, unpacked, and rearranged furniture in the new place (which was outside of the job description).

 Lastly, I had a few things that I was gonna take to a storage unit after the move.

 I mentioned this and he offered to take those items and meet me over at the unit.

 After all this, I ended up tipping him more than I paid for the move.

 This is what success looks like ‚Äì both as a business and an employee.

 When you scale, attention to detail is everything.

 Minor sloppiness creates huge problems when you have 350 pink trucks around the globe.

 My booking process was easy and the movers actually cared.

 Jason went above and beyond to the point where I wrote an entire email about it.

 This sounds like a Yelp review from someone with far too much time on their hands.

 But as a business owner, it‚Äôs a great lesson.

 If my customer experience was this good, on what was probably one of their lowest ticket moves‚Ä¶

 When they have 800+ employees‚Ä¶

 Just imagine the level of attention to detail and care that the CEO must have.

 If your product isn‚Äôt so good that customers want to become your marketing‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôve still got work to do.

 And when you‚Äôre the one delivering a service?

 Go above and beyond.

 ‚Äã Become the Jason of info-products here. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: This is hard to do...
body:
In October 2021, I hit my first $10k month.

 A year later, I hit $30k per month.

 And 11 months after that, I hit my first $100k month.

 That may sound like a relatively fast journey, but here‚Äôs what‚Äôs not visible in those metrics:

 Before I made any money, I wasted a year contemplating whether this online business thing was actually real.

 Even once I started taking action, it took me another year and a half to get to $10k/mo.

 So really, here‚Äôs how it went:

 0-$10k, 2.5 years.

 $10k-$30k, 1 year.

 $30k-$100k, 11 months.

 Without a doubt, the hardest and longest (pause) part was the beginning.

 I can viscerally remember how frustrated I‚Äôd get when seeing a ‚Äú0-$10k/mo in 30 days‚Äù case study.

 ‚ÄúThat [redacted] can‚Äôt be smarter than me,‚Äù I thought.

 But here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve realized:

 Headlines and Youtube titles never tell the full story.

 Yeah, they get clicks. And yeah, that‚Äôs part of the game.

 But they rarely show you the late nights, identity crises, and full-blown mental spirals it took to get there.

 ‚ÄúHe hit $50k/mo in 3 months‚Äù sounds a hell of a lot better than ‚ÄúHe finally hit $50k after spending three years depressed, lost, and considering accepting the sugar baby offer in his DMs.‚Äù

 But I‚Äôll give it to you straight.

 This game is difficult because you have to reprogram your hardwiring.

 You‚Äôll get discouraged, distracted, almost quit, feel like an idiot, and then‚Ä¶

 Magic happens.

 I was reminded of all this yesterday when I sat down with Heik ‚Äî one of the guys inside AL.

 He joined six months ago making $2k/month.

 Today, he‚Äôs doing $10k/month and just flew from Germany to Miami to meet with clients.

 His journey wasn‚Äôt linear or smooth.

 But he stuck it out ‚Äì even when it felt like nothing was clicking.

 I wanted to share our convo with you, not because Heik‚Äôs some unicorn‚Ä¶

 But because his story is one you might see yourself in.

 The first $10k always takes the longest.

 But after that, the game gets fun.

 ‚Äã Watch the interview here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Inertia and hangovers
body:
I have a slight hangover but it was for a good cause‚Ä¶

 We celebrated Cardinal Mason‚Äôs 26th birthday last night and I don‚Äôt recall much after midnight.

 Hence the later email today.

 Anyway, I‚Äôve been enjoying business a lot recently.

 A few clients are ripping. Artisan Lab is scaling. Members are crushing.

 And the best part of all ‚Äì work doesn‚Äôt feel like a chore.

 Most of 2024, I wasn‚Äôt very engaged in my businesses.

 For the two years before that, almost all I did was work.

 This was great to build a foundation but life just felt dull after a while.

 Why would I make more money if I don‚Äôt know how to spend it?

 So, I learned how to make tens of thousands of dollars disappear. Fast.

 But I‚Äôm out of coast mode now.

 I feel more in control of my business, and there‚Äôs this level of fulfillment that‚Äôs met by forward progress.

 Scaling feels like creative problem solving rather than an intimidating headache.

 Instead of dreading calls and items on my to do list, I look forward to (most of) them.

 I like sitting down at my desk.

 It‚Äôd been a while since I had this type of energy and I forgot how incredible it is.

 So, if you‚Äôre in an era where opening your laptop feels equivalent to being stuck in a closet with Lizzo‚Ä¶

 Here‚Äôs my advice to you:

 First ‚Äì you have to really try.

 Profound, right?

 Seriously though, it might just be difficult because you're not building any momentum.

 Get organized, take some baby steps, and see where you‚Äôre at in a week.

 For 95% of people reading this, that‚Äôs the fix.

 But if you‚Äôre where I was, and you can‚Äôt even bear the thought of work‚Ä¶

 You have to shake the snowglobe.

 I am advising you to crash out (potentially).

 Move to a new city, change up your routine, spend more money, try new hobbies, do ayahuasca in a forest‚Ä¶ idk just do something different.

 Follow your natural curiosity.

 I don‚Äôt know if this is sound advice, but it worked for me.

 I had to sidequest-maxx to show myself how fun life can be.

 This made it feel like clicking buttons in exchange for a larger number on a screen is worth it again.

 Now, quick disclaimer:

 Do not take this as an excuse to crash out because you‚Äôre avoiding sending outbound messages.

 There will always be parts of business that aren‚Äôt fun.

 Sometimes the answer is to power through.

 There are always parts of business that suck.

 But here‚Äôs the truth:

 Inertia = resistance to change.

 An object at rest stays at rest. An object in motion stays in motion.

 So if you‚Äôre stuck‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã Just start moving. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: My first chargeback = your $500 discount
body:
It's pouring rain in Miami.

 I ordered coffee to my door to avoid walking in such a treacherous condition.

 David Goggins would have a temper tantrum reading that.

 Anyway, I lost my virginity the other day‚Ä¶

 I got my first ever chargeback on Artisan Lab.

 After 160 happy customers, it happened.

 This really pissed me off...

 I take pride in the quality of members that we allow inside.

 AL is more close knit than most info-products and I talk to many of the members on a daily basis.

 Because of this, I don‚Äôt let stupid people in.

 Dealing with ‚Äúthe stupids‚Äù makes me feel like a camp counselor running around with a bunch of snotty children.

 I‚Äôm too pretentious for that.

 I‚Äôd rather make less money and protect the aura inside my program.

 But this time, I was deceived.

 My community was infiltrated by someone who should‚Äôve been sitting on the stairs outside the club with vodka spilled on his shirt after getting denied at the door.

 Here‚Äôs what happened:

 George (not his real name) applied for AL about a month ago.

 The calendar was full at the time he applied, so he sent me an email saying ‚ÄúI want to give you money‚Äù (yes that‚Äôs a direct quote).

 He got connected with my team and got on a call.

 Initially it looked like a good fit ‚Äì he was newer to the agency world but seemed to have his head screwed on straight.

 We offered him a spot and he joined.

 The next day he hopped on a 1-1 with Sean, one of my coaches inside.

 No red flags yet.

 A few days later, I had an hour-long 1-1 call with him.

 He expressed some doubt, so I walked him through everything that he‚Äôd need to do step-by-step.

 By the end of our call, he was incredibly thankful and appeared motivated.

 I had faith in him.

 The next day, he said he had a change of heart and requested a refund.

 He‚Äôd been in the community for a little under a week, hopped on two 1-1 calls and two group calls.

 At that point it‚Äôs as if he‚Äôd eaten three quarters of a sandwich and tried to send it back.

 I have a strict no refund policy, but being the reasonable person I am, I offered him a partial refund anyway.

 He declined and opened a dispute three weeks later.

 Here‚Äôs why I‚Äôm telling you all this:

 George is not an idiot.

 He made an investment in himself that could‚Äôve changed the trajectory of his life for the better.

 But he let that scared little voice inside his head talk him out of it.

 I empathize with him, as it‚Äôs a voice we all have.

 Winners overcome it.

 Losers allow it to control them.

 So, in honor of George‚Äôs swift exit and the restoration of peace in Artisan Lab‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôm offering $500 off for anyone reading this who doesn‚Äôt flake on their goals the second things get uncomfortable.

 No sob stories.

 No refund requests after two 1-1 calls and a panic attack.

 Just hungry people who want to win.

 If that‚Äôs you ‚Äì reply to this email with ‚ÄúWinner‚Äù and I‚Äôll get you the link to book in with a $500 discount.

 You‚Äôve got 24 hours.

 Ben

 P.S. George ‚Äì no hard feelings. I found something more your speed: Careers at McDonalds. ‚Äã

subject: The South Park business model
body:
I began writing a South Park episode in my head last night.

 Bear with me for a sec‚Ä¶

 Imagine Cartman gets a bad case of ‚Äúshiny object syndrome.‚Äù

 Kyle walks into his room‚Ä¶

 He‚Äôs sitting there with blue-light blockers on and six laptops open.

 Alex Becker on one screen. Iman, Hormozi, Grant Cardone, Tai Lopez, and Sophie Rain(?) on the others.

 Boxes are scattered throughout the room with failed dropshipping products.

 When Kyle tries talking to him he says‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúFuck off you normie cuck! Go back to your little slave job, I‚Äôm escaping the matrix.‚Äù

 Cartman slams the door so hard that The 4-Hour Workweek falls from his desk.

 He‚Äôs ‚Äútried‚Äù eight different business models in the past six months.

 And although he doesn‚Äôt show it, his skepticism grows with each failed attempt‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôm not cut out for this.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt keep wasting time.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúWhat if this only works for people with better skills, luck, or connections?‚Äù

 Despite the doubt, there‚Äôs an inkling of hope underneath it all.

 Cartman knows he has the potential.

 He knows he‚Äôs not a complete idiot.

 And he‚Äôs willing to work hard.

 But he‚Äôs directionless and distracted.

 He feels like he‚Äôs always almost figuring it out.

 But almost doesn‚Äôt cut it.

 Cartman closes five of the six laptops.

 ‚ÄúI'm just gonna pick one thing and stick to it,‚Äù he thinks to himself.

 That‚Äôs when he goes all in.

 This time, he‚Äôs smart enough to ignore the voice in his head that attempts to talk him into a different opportunity.

 Two weeks later, he‚Äôs getting on sales calls.

 A couple weeks after that, he gets his first client.

 And next thing you know, he‚Äôs making $10k/month.

 Finally, he‚Äôs cured of his shiny object syndrome.

 He didn‚Äôt need another guru.

 He didn‚Äôt need another YouTube video.

 He didn‚Äôt need to optimize his cold plunge routine.

 He just needed to make a decision.

 And when he finally did, things started happening.

 If you‚Äôre still stuck cycling through new ideas, hoping the next one will magically ‚Äúfeel right‚Äù‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôre not looking for the right model.

 You‚Äôre looking for a way to avoid committing.

 ‚Äã Be like Cartman. ‚Äã

 Pick something.

 Stick to it.

 Anything works, if you work.

 Just don‚Äôt be like Cartman was in Season 1 ‚Äì fat, lazy, and blaming the Jews.

 Be Season 26 Cartman:

 ‚Äã A little older. Slightly wiser.

 Still kind of a dick‚Ä¶ but finally making money. ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

subject: I owe the nerds an apology...
body:
I‚Äôm becoming more of what I used to hate.

 When AI first came out, I thought it was for dorks.

 ‚ÄúHeY acTuAlLy DiD yOu kNoW yoU coULd AuTomAte ThAt wiTh AI.‚Äù

 Shut up.

 To be fair ‚Äì the only people talking about it were nerdy, boring agency guys.

 And somehow they all lived in Tampa.

 But I guess there‚Äôs a lesson there‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt judge a dork by his blue light blockers,‚Äù as Socrates once said.

 I use AI on a daily basis, but yesterday I began to realize how much I‚Äôm still underutilizing it.

 I need to fully integrate it into everything.

 That doesn‚Äôt mean replacing my own creativity, just enhancing it.

 Repurposing my best ideas, maximizing every input, and increasing efficiency‚Ä¶

 I sound like a nerd but it‚Äôs for good reason.

 This is the dot com bubble of our generation.

 In the internet marketing world, AI and online coaching are the modern day gold rushes.

 Everyone is a coach. And everyone is building a stupid AI tool no one wants.

 While most will fail, there‚Äôll be some big winners.

 And those who win, will find their ideas in the trenches.

 They‚Äôll be working on an optimization in their business, run into a problem, realize it‚Äôs a common problem in their industry, and build something that solves it.

 Next thing you know you‚Äôre Alex Becker and you just sold Hyros for $100m.

 The more I go down the AI rabbithole, the more I‚Äôm realizing‚Ä¶

 This may be the greatest era of opportunity in my lifetime.

 And an afternoon of deep work could result in a nine-figure idea.

 In 1994, a VP at a hedge fund noticed the internet was growing at 2,300% per year.

 He capitalized on this and started selling books online.

 And that little company became something you may have heard of ‚Äì Amazon.

 ‚ÄúWhen I‚Äôm 80, I want to have minimized the number of regrets. I knew I might fail, but I also knew I wouldn‚Äôt regret trying.‚Äù - Jeff Bezos

 Anyway, I say all this not to romanticize tech or pretend I‚Äôm the next Bezos.

 But to remind myself (and maybe you too) that once-in-a-generation windows don‚Äôt stay open forever.

 You can either keep scrolling, keep judging, keep saying ‚ÄúAI is cringe‚Äù...

 ‚Äã Or you can build. ‚Äã

 Your call.

 Ben

 P.S. Somewhat unrelated but funny story:

 One time I got denied at the door of a Miami club as the bouncer told us there‚Äôs a high profile celebrity in there and they can‚Äôt let anyone else in.

 I jokingly said ‚Äúwho tf is it Lebron James.‚Äù

 A few moments later, a bald veiny man named Jeff walked out with his security.

 ‚Äã

subject: I got married to an AI bot
body:
I have a confession‚Ä¶

 My agency basically runs on auto-pilot at this point.

 We have a small (but dialed) team and a couple really solid clients.

 It‚Äôs a great set up.

 But due to my lack of involvement in the operations, it‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve been in the back-end trenches.

 I‚Äôm locked in, scaling Artisan Lab ‚Äì but I started to miss being the wizard behind the scenes.

 Sometimes it‚Äôs cooler to be the lazy, fat puppet master than the puppet.
So a little over a month ago, I had the idea to take on some 1-1 clients.

 My goal was to find a few early stage info-businesses I could get a large stake in.

 I posted a call to action on my Instagram story.

 Next thing you know, I have what I would describe as a ‚Äúportfolio company‚Äù if I were trying to impress someone.

 I began building the full system for one of these portfolio clients yesterday.

 Quick context ‚Äì this client just recently started making content.

 He built a blue collar business, makes good money doing it, and is now stepping into guru-world.

 As of a few weeks ago, we had nothing but a social media account with a calendly link in the bio.

 I wanted to first see if his audience was ready to buy anything from him.

 We started booking calls and pitched 1-1 coaching.

 No course, no community, just calls with my client so we can get testimonials.

 We filled up ten spots way quicker than I anticipated.

 Now, we‚Äôre building out the course, setting up all the softwares and backend stuff so we can do a real launch.

 This will probably take about a week.

 In the meantime, I needed a way to nurture the audience.

 I used [an AI tool I won‚Äôt disclose publicly until they give me better affiliate terms] to make a free lead magnet‚Ä¶

 I took five of my clients' videos, the software transcribed them, and I was done in 30 seconds.

 It gave me a full 12 page breakdown of the business model and my client‚Äôs journey.

 Then I went over to my friend Chat GPT.

 I made a new project, gave it the PDF, and asked it to write the copy for the opt-in page.

 Done in 10 seconds.

 I threw the copy on a landing page and now I just need to write a welcome sequence‚Ä¶

 [Read in southern accent for full effect]

 Back in the old days, when I first started ‚Äì this would be a two hour project. 

 I‚Äôd need to manually ideate each email, type away on my little keyboard, and finally I‚Äôd be done. 

 But I didn‚Äôt have what you now have‚Ä¶ 

 A muthafuckin I. 

 I went back and forth with Mr.GPT for about five minutes. 

 My goal was to have it write in my style but my client‚Äôs voice. 

 My instructions were clear and he began typing away. 

 First email done. Banger. 

 Second email, banger. 

 Third, fourth, fifth‚Ä¶ holy fuckin shit Chat GPT I love you to death. 

 [Ok, no more southern accent]

 My full welcome sequence was done in three minutes.

 And it wasn‚Äôt some generic, AI sounding copy.

 The writing had a real voice, humor, and maintained the tone in my client's content.

 All in, it took maybe 10 minutes.

 Offer, lead magnet, landing page, welcome sequence.

 AI didn‚Äôt just help ‚Äì it did the damn thing (because I used it correctly).

 This is the game now.

 If you want to build a lean info-agency using tools like this,

 It‚Äôs never been easier‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã And Artisan Lab is where I show you how. ‚Äã

 Ben (not AI, I promise)

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: The best job in the world
body:
I never really wanted to sell my own coaching.

 It was awesome when I was just the guy behind the scenes.

 I‚Äôd be moderating a client's webinar, watching the money roll in as they‚Äôd smile on camera.

 The audience didn‚Äôt know I was the one turning the dials, but others in this space did.

 This gained me respect from the right people and kept me away from the general public.

 As an ambitious and pretentious young man ‚Äì it was a great place to be.

 This also made it so that all of the content I‚Äôd create was purely for fun.

 I wasn‚Äôt selling anything of my own, but I was making money as if I was.

 I had the upside of running a coaching business *without* running one.

 For about a year and a half, I made between $80-$125k/mo strictly from my agency.

 I didn‚Äôt have the pressure to create content myself.

 I didn‚Äôt have to manage a big team.

 And I didn‚Äôt have to deal with thousands of customers.

 My routine was as follows:

 Wake up at 8am.

 Make sure nothing is on fire.

 Gym.

 Coffee.

 Text client ‚Äúwe‚Äôre fucking rich.‚Äù

 Lunch.

 Walk.

 Schedule client‚Äôs emails for tomorrow.

 Moderate a webinar.

 Dinner, sleep.

 I‚Äôd make $5k from my rev shares that day without doing anything but management.

 It‚Äôs kind of like being a backup quarterback in the NFL.

 I imagine this is one of the best jobs in the world.

 Unless your QB1 gets his leg snapped in half by a 300-lb lineman, your sole job is to make sure he‚Äôs prepared.

 You get all the perks, make $2-4m/yr on average‚Ä¶

 And you don‚Äôt have to run for your life every Sunday.

 Now, I‚Äôm not saying running an info-agency means you don‚Äôt work at all.

 But if you‚Äôre efficient with your work, you properly use AI, and you set up some automations‚Ä¶

 There‚Äôs not a ton for you to do other than stand there with a fire extinguisher.

 So, although I love coaching and helping members in Artisan Lab get rich, my agency comes with fewer headaches.

 And being the puppet master is pretty fuckin cool.

 Here are some recent wins from the QB2‚Äôs inside AL...

 Manoj made $14k profit in three days and is so rich he forgot to share it:

 ‚Äã Khesraw made $10k profit from one client last month:

 ‚Äã Vander kicked off the month with a new client:

 ‚Äã And Humayoun and Josh sent some wholesome messages that made me smile:

 ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã This is where you can join them. ‚Äã

 Your guru‚Äôs guru,

 Ben
