subject: AHHHH
body:
I have a mountain of things on my to-do list today.

 So many that I might end up doing nothing.

 That‚Äôs the worst outcome, so I‚Äôm trying to avoid the nothing part.

 But I already wasted 30 minutes talking to ChatGPT and scrolling on Amazon.

 My office in the new place is still cluttered and echoey.

 I need to move a dresser, add a couch, install new curtains, and text my undocumented amigo to do all of that for me.

 The couch was supposed to get here days ago but it got delayed.

 Mr. GPT told me a more plush rug would help with the echo, so that‚Äôs on the way too.

 But now I‚Äôm sitting here, blaming my lack of focus on the disorganization of this room.

 If I were to give advice to myself, it‚Äôd be this:

 ‚ÄúAre you a toddler? You can‚Äôt work because your office isn‚Äôt perfect? Grow up.‚Äù

 Sound advice.

 But instead, I‚Äôll just complain to thousands of strangers on the internet.

 I‚Äôve now written 178 words here and still said nothing of value.

 At least you know this isn‚Äôt AI because AI isn‚Äôt dumb enough to write like this.

 I could connect the intro to a lesson on ignoring mental excuses or creating a peaceful work environment.

 But I won‚Äôt.

 It‚Äôs Monday.

 You‚Äôre alive.

 You‚Äôve got working senses, a smartphone, and internet access.

 And someday in the future, you‚Äôll wish you could relive this exact day.

 You don‚Äôt need me to give you advice.

 You just need to move.

 This the youngest and handsomest you‚Äôll ever be.

 So let‚Äôs make the most of it.

 Stop blaming your productivity problems on curtain rods and go make some money.

 Deal?

 Deal.

 ‚Äã Let‚Äôs get rich. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: How to spot a fake guru
body:
I have another incredibly boring email for you today.

 It‚Äôs about a stupid little topic called "product.‚Äù

 80% of the info gurus just clicked away.

 So now that it‚Äôs just you and me, I‚Äôll be incredibly honest here:

 I used to not give a solitary shit about this side of the business.

 It wasn‚Äôt in my job description to care.

 I was the marketer.

 The rainmaker.

 The guy behind the scenes who‚Äôll never deal with the customers.

 My job was to sell.

 So as long as my clients weren‚Äôt absolute scumbags ‚Äì I‚Äôd do just that.

 But after running my own info-business, that‚Äôs changed.

 People turn their hard earned money into my money.

 They trust me to care about them and deliver on my promises.

 And I‚Äôd be an absolute shithead not to.

 This is gonna feel like I‚Äôm indirectly pitching you.

 I‚Äôm not, but I kind of am too.

 Artisan Lab isn‚Äôt perfect, but it‚Äôs always improving.

 I personally talk to every member, have incredible coaches, bring on guests, and add more content.

 Yesterday, a new member joined who we‚Äôll call Joe.

 Before joining, Joe DM‚Äôd nearly everyone he could find in the program.

 Because I‚Äôm not a sleazy, lying, piece of shit, the responses he got were overwhelmingly positive.

 Here‚Äôs what he said in his intro message:

 ‚Äã (he joined on his bday so we sang to him on the group call lol).

 I say all this because I truly don‚Äôt understand how people can sell something they know isn‚Äôt up to par.

 They‚Äôll do anything to get the deal done, but once you buy, you‚Äôll never hear from them again.

 And perhaps the worst part ‚Äì they get people to take out a loan to buy their shit product.

 There is a special place in hell for you people.

 Sure, not everyone will succeed.

 Most will buy and do nothing with the info inside.

 But that‚Äôs not a cop out to neglect your product.

 And it feels 10x better when you produce results like this:

 ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã Don‚Äôt get scammed by a fake guru. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: People dumber than you are getting rich
body:
Good morning {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "friend" }}.

 Here‚Äôs our affirmation for the day:

 ‚Äú The world is full of money. Some of it has my name on it. All I have to do is collect it.‚Äù 

 Felix Dennis told me to say this to myself, so I figured I‚Äôd share it with you.

 Today I'm thinking about dumb people.

 More specifically, how people who are dumber than me are richer than me.

 That‚Äôs wack.

 Now I‚Äôm not a genius‚Ä¶

 I can‚Äôt change a tire, I‚Äôm severely directionally challenged, and I often misspell simple words.

 But everyone has their pitfalls.

 Strip Elon Musk of his fame and put him at LIV in Miami.

 He‚Äôd look like the kid who gets picked last in high school gym class. 

 Everyone has their strengths and weaknesses.

 Your job is to lean into what you‚Äôre good at and stop wasting time pretending to be someone you‚Äôre not.

 Let me show you what I mean.

 I have two friends ‚Äì let‚Äôs call them Nikola and Anthony (Basketball fans, you already get the analogy).

 Nikola‚Äôs an operator.

 He‚Äôs analytical and calculated.

 Excel sheets give him an erection and he uses Zapier to automate his breakfast order and bathroom schedule.

 But if you put him in a room full of people, he‚Äôll complain about how he wants to go home.

 He has trouble making eye contact with women and freezes up on camera.

 Still, he‚Äôs rich.

 He‚Äôs the COO of an 8 figure eCom brand.

 Anthony‚Äôs the opposite.

 He‚Äôs incredibly articulate, he can simplify complex ideas, and he loves the spotlight.

 But if you told him to build a funnel or set up an automation‚Ä¶ it‚Äôd take him 6 hours, 3 breakdowns, and a YouTube tutorial.

 So he doesn‚Äôt.

 He stays on camera, grabs attention, and outsources the rest.

 Both are successful. Because they play their role.

 Most people try to ‚Äúfix‚Äù their weaknesses instead of weaponizing their strengths.

 Don‚Äôt be like most people.

 Figure out your edge. Go all in on it.

 And if you suck at the rest, improve it or get help.

 ‚Äã Now go collect what‚Äôs already yours. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

subject: This self-help guru scammed me
body:
I got scammed by Mark Manson this morning.

 The first thing I saw after opening my eyes was a charge for $79.99 ‚Äì MarkManson.net.

 I guess I signed up for his paid newsletter three years ago.

 Haven‚Äôt opened a single email other than the payment receipts I just found.

 This makes me wonder what other subscriptions I forgot I‚Äôm paying for.

 I‚Äôd make a great target for a blackhat MRR scammer.

 Anyway, I read The Subtle Art Of Not Giving A F*ck a few years ago.

 I hate admitting this because Mr.Manson has turned into a corny, platitude writing, lesbian‚Ä¶

 But that book began to open my eyes.

 It‚Äôs one of three books that I recall having an impact on my mini spiritual awakening.

 Millionaire Fastlane and Think And Grow Rich are the other two.

 All three are fairly broad money/self help books, but at the time that‚Äôs exactly what I needed.

 So, I‚Äôm gonna continue my donation to marklesbian.net as a thank you.

 There‚Äôve been so many books that helped me over the years.

 And the fact that you can just buy someone's brain for sub $20 is a cheat code.

 Books changed my life.

 But eventually, I needed proximity.

 Real conversations with people more successful than me.

 I found this through online communities and recreated it inside Artisan Lab.

 Twice a month, I bring in people from my network for a guest call.

 These are friends who‚Äôve built multi-million dollar software companies, scaled offers to $500k+/mo, and built huge audiences.

 We‚Äôve had Cardinal Mason break down how he built Copy MBA.

 Pierre Khoury went over how he scaled his info-agency to 7 figures.

 And 20+ others who‚Äôre incredibly good at what they do.

 Next Wednesday, Rob Oliver (@robthebank) is coming on to talk about how he‚Äôs built and sold 8-figure eCom brands, grown a massive audience, and more.

 This kind of access is rare.

 And it‚Äôs one of my favorite bonuses we have inside the community.

 So, I‚Äôll keep funding Mark‚Äôs retirement as a thank you.

 But if you want to learn from killers actively building ‚Äì apply here. ‚Äã

 Rob‚Äôs on next Wednesday. Don‚Äôt miss it.

 Ben

 Thing #1: Price of Artisan Lab is going up June 1st. 

 I met up with a member for lunch yesterday.

 He said it felt like he robbed me by getting in at the current price point.

 I don‚Äôt like getting robbed.

 So on June 1st, the price is going up. That same day, I‚Äôm adding:

 Another coach (now 4-5 calls/week) Extra 1-on-1 calls AI modules that‚Äôll help you train ChatGPT to do 80% of client work If you go here and apply before June 1st, you‚Äôll get access to everything we have now, plus the additions at the current price.

 But once these updates are live, there's no going back.

 ‚Äã Commit a highway robbery here. ‚Äã

 Thing #2: Phillip made $87k last month. 

 He can‚Äôt legally drink alcohol (he‚Äôs 20).

 He only has three clients.

 And he transitioned from high ticket sales to info-agency just four months ago.

 Meaning he basically went from 0-$87k/mo in four months.

 The kid is a DAWG.

 ‚Äã So, I had him on the channel for an interview that you can watch here. ‚Äã

 Alright, announcements are over.

 Here‚Äôs a quick AI cheat code for writing email copy: 

 Take 10-20 solid emails you like (yours, mine, etc.) Drop them in a Google Doc Feed it into ChatGPT/Claude with this prompt: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to give you example marketing emails. 

 Your job is to extract the tone, writing style, voice, and structure used and turn it into a clear style guide and persona that I (or my team) can follow. This should be an extensive guide that we can replicate with any personal brand. 

 Break down: 

 Tone and personality traits 

 Formatting and structure 

 Common themes and messaging angles 

 Do‚Äôs and Don‚Äôts 

 Example CTA styles‚Äù 

 Now you have a custom template.

 Upload client info, tell the AI to follow your style guide, and boom‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôll never have to write an email from scratch again.

 Enough yapping.

 Later,

 Ben

subject: How I hit $100K months (after hating my life)
body:
Happy Memorial Day.

 Over the past few years, I‚Äôve subscribed to countless newsletters.

 So many that I don‚Äôt remember a lot of the names I see in my inbox.

 But this morning, one of them stood out.

 They said ‚Äúwe‚Äôre discounting our price from $7995 to just $995 for the next 48 hours!‚Äù 

 I understand Holidays are great excuses to run discounts ‚Äì and much respect to all of those who‚Äôve served in the military.

 But my brother in Christ‚Ä¶

 SEVEN THOUSAND DOLLARS OFF?

 For Memorial Day??

 Are you gonna throw in a free hand job for customers during Christmas???

 Shit like that just makes me laugh.

 Anyway, here‚Äôs what I really wanted to talk about today:

 ‚ÄúWhat you‚Äôre aware of you‚Äôre in control of, what you‚Äôre not aware of controls you.‚Äù - Anthony de Mello 

 This obviously applies to the big decisions in life.

 But just as important, are the small ones.

 You can ‚Äúescape the matrix,‚Äù create your own income, and travel the world‚Ä¶ and still be asleep at the wheel.

 You look free, but you‚Äôre more enslaved than the guy who‚Äôs stoked for his day off today.

 Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs easy to forget:

 Everything is a conscious decision.

 If you want your life to look different, you have to change it (duh).

 But if you don‚Äôt define what change looks like, you‚Äôll drift.

 You‚Äôll be aware enough to know something‚Äôs off, but too unclear to do anything about it.

 I found myself in this very position about two years ago.

 I‚Äôd been living in Miami for just under a year and was starting to make some real money.

 My income climbed from $15k/mo to $70k/mo (thanks to my Info Agency).

 But I wasn‚Äôt enjoying it at all.

 Here‚Äôs an excerpt from my journal entry in August 2023:

 ‚ÄúI feel uninspired. Almost like I was sold a lie. I go accomplish all these things, hit numbers, buy fancy shit ‚Äî and my life would feel a whole lot different. But I‚Äôm here and it doesn‚Äôt live up to that.‚Äù 

 What I didn‚Äôt understand then, was that the same way making money is a conscious decision‚Ä¶

 So was my lifestyle.

 I didn‚Äôt have any hobbies.

 I didn‚Äôt make a conscious effort to meet new people.

 I didn‚Äôt design my life outside of the money part.

 So there I was. Making more money than I knew what to do with‚Ä¶ But no motion.

 And then, I regained consciousness.

 Started boxing. Started going out. Started playing tennis.

 Two months later, my lifestyle was exactly the way I envisioned.

 Plus I hit my first $100k month and bought my dream car.

 All of it came from conscious decisions‚Ä¶

 And the same system I now teach inside Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 It‚Äôs what let me charge $10k+ per client, build real freedom, and actually enjoy the life I worked for.

 The price goes up June 1st. 

 ‚Äã If you‚Äôve been waiting for a sign, this is it. ‚Äã

 Talk soon,

 Ben

subject: I woke up at 5am for nothing
body:
There was a stretch in high school when I‚Äôd wake up at 5am to get shots up before class.

 I wasn‚Äôt naturally gifted or the most athletic.

 But I figured if I outworked everyone, I‚Äôd win.

 The gym was cold and dark because I‚Äôd get there before they turned the lights on.

 Every single morning was a battle.

 ‚ÄúWhy the fuck are you doing this?‚Äù I‚Äôd think when my alarm sounded.

 The sound called ‚ÄúBulletin‚Äù brings up horrid memories.

 But I‚Äôd get up, put a hoodie on, and walk out the door with a little mantra in my head:

 ‚ÄúIf I don‚Äôt do this I‚Äôm gay a bitch.

 So I did.

 And I fully convinced myself that if I just worked harder than everyone else, I‚Äôd play D1 basketball.

 I was wrong.

 I didn‚Äôt end up playing past high school.

 But do you know what happens when you actually try?

 When you actually give something your all?

 The forces of the universe begin working in your favor.

 One door closes, another opens.

 Basketball ended.

 But discipline was instilled forever.

 I learned to ignore the voice in my head who wanted to hit snooze.

 It‚Äôs the same voice who doesn‚Äôt want to send outbound, turn on the camera, or get on a sales call.

 It‚Äôll keep you stuck until you realize you don‚Äôt have to listen to it.

 You‚Äôll wait another week‚Ä¶

 Then another month‚Ä¶

 Then wonder why nothing changed at the end of the year.

 So here‚Äôs my push to get you moving:

 Artisan Lab is going up in price June 1st. 

 If you‚Äôre serious about building an info agency where:

 You can make $10k/mo+ from just one client.

 You don‚Äôt have to send hundreds of outbound messages.

 You don‚Äôt have to build a huge team to scale.

 And you work with clients who become friends‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã This is for you.

 I threw together a doc that breaks everything down -- what you get, how it works, and what it costs.

 ‚Äã You can check it out here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: The 2025 online business power rankings
body:
This is a longer one so strap in, {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "buddy" }}.

 Let‚Äôs break down the popular online business models in 2025.

 Here are the main ones that come to mind:

 Dropshipping High ticket sales Trading ‚ÄúAI Copywriting‚Äù ‚ÄúAI Automation‚Äù Being a TikTok Shop creator Aaaand Info Agency Obviously I have a bias for the Info Agency, but I‚Äôll be as objective as possible here.

 Ranking from worst to best:

 Trading takes the major L.

 It‚Äôs a casino.

 I‚Äôve met many of the trading influencers and they all made their money from the 2020 crypto bull run, selling info, or owning a prop firm.

 Almost none of them are profitable traders.

 You simply have to be world class to make money ‚Äì but I will say the upside is tremendous.

 If you are 1/10,000 who becomes really good, it can and will make you rich.

 But there is a 99.9% chance you never get there and waste all your money.

 Dropshipping is my second worst on the list here.

 It can work, but similar to trading, most eCom gurus made their money from courses.

 And the successful ones, nine times out of ten are running a blackhat MRR scam.

 Cons:
Many skills to learn, low margins, excess variables outside of your control.

 Pros:

 Scales fast IF you crack it (most don‚Äôt) and has enterprise value (most won‚Äôt get there).

 To be entirely fair ‚Äì trading and dropshipping both have about as high of an upside as any other model on the list.

 But they generally require more capital and higher business acumen.

 Next up, ‚ÄúAI Automation.‚Äù 

 It‚Äôs just SMMA repackaged with AI in the title.

 Decent for beginners because you‚Äôll learn some core skills.

 But I hope you‚Äôre ready to deal with shitty clients, constant churn, and build a big team.

 You‚Äôll need dozens of clients to make real money and will have to work with dentists, realtors, or some other industry you likely know nothing about.

 It can work, but it‚Äôs definitely a grind.

 Next, TikTok shop creator. 

 It was an infinite money glitch a year ago.

 Absolute monkey buffoon retards were getting rich.

 But the faucet has started to turn off.

 It‚Äôs basically like playing the lottery now.

 If you‚Äôre consistent, you make really good content, and you keep iterating, eventually you‚Äôll go viral and make money.

 Most will quit before that happens and I‚Äôve also heard some nightmares about not getting paid out commissions.

 It can be decent cash flow but it‚Äôs declining and you don‚Äôt learn any real valuable skills.

 Moving on, we‚Äôve reached the top three:

 AI Copywriting, High Ticket Sales, and Info Agency.

 ‚ÄúAI Copywriting‚Äù is not a business model, it‚Äôs a skill.

 The application of said skill determines how much money you make.

 Sales is similar ‚Äì get good, find a good offer and you‚Äôll make solid cash.

 Both of these are incredible things to learn.

 But they both end up pointing to the Info Agency model.

 Learn ‚ÄúAI Copywriting‚Äù ‚Äì who are the best clients to work with?

 Info sellers.

 Learn sales ‚Äì who are you closing for?

 Info sellers.

 So why not skip the line?

 Fuck being the copywriting intern.

 Fuck closing leads for someone else‚Äôs offer.

 Just build the machine yourself.

 Control the funnel.

 Control the offer.

 Control the money.

 That‚Äôs the Info Agency.

 It‚Äôs the only model where:

 ¬∑ You don‚Äôt need 20 clients to scale

 ¬∑ You don‚Äôt need a ton of capital

 ¬∑ You don‚Äôt need to sell "AI lead gen" to boomers

 And you can scale to $50k/mo+ with one Google folder, one system, and one client.

 It‚Äôs not as sexy as some of the other models.

 But it‚Äôs effective ‚Äì if you‚Äôre willing to work.

 So if you want to learn how to build one that doesn‚Äôt suck‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã You know where to find me. ‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. Price goes up in three days.

 If you‚Äôre even thinking about doing this, now‚Äôs the time to move.

 After that, it‚Äôs gonna cost more. Simple as that.

 If you want a full breakdown of what's inside, go here. ‚Äã

subject: The banana bread problem
body:
Get in {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "amigo" }}, we‚Äôre going to the store.

 We‚Äôre making banana bread and have one very simple goal:

 Get three overripe bananas.

 They need to be the color of black coffee because that‚Äôs when they‚Äôre the most flavorful.

 We walk into Publix and head to the produce section.

 There, we see two overripe bananas.

 We grab them and toss in a third that‚Äôs just yellow.

 Close enough.

 We hop in the car, go home, and make the bread.

 It‚Äôs good.

 Not quite as good as it could‚Äôve been, but only a banana bread purist (fuckin weirdo) would notice.

 Fast forward a month.

 Same plan.

 This time, there‚Äôs only one overripe banana.

 We grab it, plus two yellow ones.

 Close enough.

 Get home, make the bread, it‚Äôs decent.

 Now, fast forward a year.

 We head to the store and buy the shitty Publix brand bread in a plastic container.

 It‚Äôs aiight‚Ä¶ if you‚Äôre high.

 Close enough. 

 Here‚Äôs what these bananas mean to you:

 Your tolerance for misalignment determines your life.

 There is a version of you, buried in there, that just knows.

 When you do things that betray that intuition, it knows.

 At first, it‚Äôs subtle.

 But eventually, you‚Äôre living a life that doesn‚Äôt feel like yours.

 You‚Äôll convince yourself it‚Äôs fine.

 Not great, not awful. Just‚Ä¶

 Close enough.

 Or‚Ä¶

 You can have a low tolerance for misalignment.

 When it doesn‚Äôt feel right, you change it.

 Whether it‚Äôs your career path, where you live, or even your routine.

 It‚Äôs up to you.

 And you know the answer, even if it‚Äôs buried under a mountain of excuses.

 So my friend, here‚Äôs the pitch:

 Do you want to keep settling for close enough?

 Or do you want to make the change?

 You already know the life you want.

 The question is how long you‚Äôll pretend that shitty banana bread is enough.

 ‚Äã Price of Artisan Lab goes up in 2 days. ‚Äã

 If you‚Äôre gonna move, move now.

 Ben

 P.S. If you‚Äôd rather skip the application process because the clock is ticking here‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã This doc will go over what‚Äôs inside and pricing. ‚Äã

subject: This might not work
body:
Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich. 

 Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich. 

 Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich. 

 ‚ÄúBen, why are you saying that on the day of the price increase?‚Äù

 Great question, {{ subscriber.first_name | fallback: "friend" }}.

 On April 25th, 2020 I hopped on my first ever sales call.

 Not as a closer. As a prospect.

 It was for Nate Schmidt‚Äôs eCom mentorship, ‚ÄúBoss Builder.‚Äù

 I paced around my childhood bedroom on the call.

 When we got to the pitch and he dropped the price‚Ä¶ I hesitated.

 ‚ÄúIs there any way that I won‚Äôt succeed if I do everything in the program?‚Äù I asked.

 Quite a silly question, as no one has a crystal ball.

 But here‚Äôs how I‚Äôd answer it today, if I could talk to my 19 year old self:

 Yes. 

 It‚Äôs entirely possible that you follow every step and don‚Äôt get the outcome you want.

 There are variables that neither me, you, or Lebron James could possibly foresee.

 Also possible, is that you have an easier time than most.

 Your first product could be a winner and next thing you know you‚Äôre sitting in the frunk of your Huracan in a Chrome Hearts hoodie.

 I can‚Äôt predict your future.

 But what I can tell you is this:

 If you follow a proven roadmap that‚Äôs worked for others‚Ä¶

 You show up every single day, even when you want to quit‚Ä¶

 And you don‚Äôt get discouraged if things happen slower than you‚Äôd like‚Ä¶

 Your success becomes inevitable.

 I didn‚Äôt end up buying that eCom program.

 Not because I didn‚Äôt believe in it.

 But because I didn‚Äôt believe in me.

 About a year later, I mustered up the conviction to buy an SMMA program.

 Fast forward to now and I‚Äôm writing this at my desk in my Miami penthouse.

 So no, {{ subscriber.first_name | fallback: "friend" }} I can‚Äôt promise you that Artisan Lab will make you rich.

 You will.

 If you‚Äôve got the balls to commit.

 If you stop overthinking.

 And if you finally decide to bet on yourself.

 Not just in your head, but with your actions.

 Because the only thing standing between you and the life you want‚Ä¶

 Is the version of you that keeps hesitating.

 ‚Äã Let him die here. ‚Äã

 I‚Äôll hand you the same blueprint that changed my life and dozens of others.

 ‚Äã Go here now before the price goes up at midnight.

 Ben

subject: You‚Äôre not burnt out, you‚Äôre just overthinking
body:
It‚Äôs rare I open a Google doc and can‚Äôt think of a topic to write about within a few minutes.

 But today, it‚Äôs not working.

 It‚Äôs been 27 minutes and this is all I got.

 Maybe it‚Äôs over.

 Maybe I‚Äôve told you everything of value I have to say.

 Maybe I should sell my car and move back home with my parents.

 Or maybe, it‚Äôs just a mini, temporary hurdle.

 There‚Äôs a book called ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Sweat The Small Stuff ‚Äì and It‚Äôs All Small Stuff.‚Äù 

 I haven‚Äôt read it but I think I got the gist from the title.

 Small problems feel like big ones when you look at them under a microscope.

 An issue that would‚Äôve taken 30 minutes to resolve can turn into a month, year, or lifetime.

 Let‚Äôs say there‚Äôs something you‚Äôre struggling to complete.

 Maybe it‚Äôs outreach, content, or in my case, this very email.

 Instead of powering through it, you convince yourself it means you‚Äôre misaligned.

 You create a mental narrative of ‚Äúthis business isn‚Äôt for me, I need to do something else.‚Äù

 The next day, it‚Äôs time to do the thing you don‚Äôt wanna do again.

 That narrative acts as a parasite in your mind.

 ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt for me!‚Äù it screams, so you don‚Äôt do it.

 By the following week, you‚Äôre completely disengaged and trying to find a new ‚Äúpassion.‚Äù

 You‚Äôll dress it up with logic and fool most people.

 But in reality, all it took was a brief moment of concentrated effort.

 You don‚Äôt have to reroute your entire career.

 You just have to finish your cold brew, grab a zyn, and write the fucking email.

 I‚Äôve bailed on businesses and ideas that could‚Äôve been really fruitful.

 I‚Äôve gone through the entire story I laid above.

 I‚Äôve convinced myself it was ‚Äúinauthentic‚Äù and found data to back it up.

 But it was all a lie.

 You know when something is actually misaligned.

 And you know when you‚Äôre convincing yourself of it.

 So no, I‚Äôm not moving back in with my parents.

 I‚Äôm just finishing the email.

 Because not everything needs to feel inspired.

 Sometimes it just needs to be done.

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 P.S. For those of you who joined Artisan Lab before the price went up ‚Äì congrats on taking the leap.

 For those who didn‚Äôt ‚Äì congrats on not giving in to FOMO.

 That said, the price didn‚Äôt just go up for fun.

 We added another coach (Kabrin), a 4th weekly call, and a deeper level of support than ever before.

 It‚Äôll cost you about the price of a steak dinner more.

 But if you actually use it, you‚Äôll still feel like you‚Äôre robbing me.

 ‚Äã Apply here if you're done hesitating. ‚Äã

subject: I got punched in the face
body:
I started boxing about a year and half ago.

 My original trainer was‚Ä¶ a homie.

 He was a super funny dude and a really good fighter.

 But he wasn‚Äôt very technical.

 When we first started training, I remember feeling like we skipped the basics.

 I barely knew how to throw a punch and he had me learning Mayweather combos.

 Even still, I got a lot better.

 Well‚Ä¶ so I thought.

 As I continued working with him, my suspicion in his expertise grew.

 But I didn‚Äôt have anything to compare him to‚Ä¶

 Until I worked out with Rob Oliver and his trainer.

 I‚Äôd throw a jab, he‚Äôd tap me on the cheek so I knew I dropped my right hand.

 I‚Äôd throw a hook, same thing.

 He‚Äôd point out when I was off balance ‚Äì which was quite often.

 By the end of the workout, my head was spinning.

 Not from getting hit, but from realizing how many things I‚Äôd been doing wrong.

 Like most things in life, the difference is in the details. 

 You can get away with being sloppy for a bit.

 It‚Äôs ‚Äúno big deal‚Äù until one day you drop your guard and get hit with a hook that makes you see God.

 It‚Äôs ‚Äúno big deal‚Äù until you realize your business is leaking money.

 It‚Äôs ‚Äúno big deal‚Äù until you end up living a life you never wanted because you weren‚Äôt meticulous.

 The longer you ignore the details, the shakier your foundation gets.

 Everything feels fine, until it doesn‚Äôt.

 I recently started boxing again with a new trainer.

 I‚Äôm discarding all of my bad habits and replacing them with a more solid foundation.

 And honestly it sucks.

 There‚Äôs nothing sexy about going slow and fixing your fundamentals.

 But I know it‚Äôs required if I actually want to improve.

 It‚Äôs the same in business.

 You might be making some money right now.

 You might even feel like you‚Äôre ‚Äúpretty good.‚Äù

 But if your backend systems are messy‚Ä¶

 If you‚Äôre guessing instead of tracking‚Ä¶

 If you‚Äôre winging it on client work, outreach, or systems‚Ä¶

 Then you‚Äôre basically shadowboxing with your eyes closed.

 Artisan Lab was built for this exact phase.

 I won't teach you hacks or gimmicks.

 I'll be in your corner, holding you accountable to the shit that actually matters.

 ‚Äã Join me here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: AI is gonna steal your girl
body:
Good morning.

 It‚Äôs raining today so I was forced to split test my routine.

 Typically I like to start the day off with a quick walk to Soybucks.

 But obviously, I‚Äôm not gonna venture out in the rain.

 So I clicked a couple buttons, spent $21.46, and 20 minutes later a coffee was at my door.

 ‚ÄúBen why don‚Äôt you just make it at ho‚Äì‚Äù

 Shut up.

 Anyway,

 AI is gonna steal your girl.

 Impregnate your mom.

 Make you the family pet.

 And if you‚Äôre lucky, he‚Äôll serve you Chipotle twice a day in a bowl labeled ‚Äúhuman.‚Äù

 Extra chicken if you don‚Äôt complain.

 That‚Äôs not even the scary part.

 The scary part is how stupidly simple it is to use this stuff if you actually know how.

 Let‚Äôs say you wanted to land a client this week.

 Here‚Äôs what that could look like:

 You pop a prompt into ChatGPT ‚Äì something like ‚ÄúGive me 20 less popular niches where people sell $2k+ coaching or courses and post content regularly.‚Äù

 Boom, it spits out a list.

 Pick one.

 Go find someone on Instagram or YouTube who fits the mold.

 Take a couple of their posts or scripts.

 Drop that content into AI.

 Add the right copy prompts (like the ones I give you in here ).

 And watch what comes out.

 Your emails, VSL, and even a sales call framework can be done in 20 minutes.

 ‚ÄúBut Ben, if it‚Äôs so easy, why would they hire me?‚Äù

 Same reason I didn‚Äôt make my own coffee this morning.

 Not because I couldn‚Äôt.

 Because I didn‚Äôt want to.

 And here‚Äôs the cool part‚Ä¶

 Most creators don‚Äôt even know what levers to pull.

 They have traffic, content, and followers‚Ä¶

 But no system.

 You walk in with a few AI prompts and a baseline level of competence.

 And you become the operator.

 You‚Äôre the missing piece ‚Äì the guy who turns eyeballs into dollars.

 So everyone‚Äôs yapping about AI and you might be sick of it‚Ä¶

 But the truth is, you don‚Äôt need to build some complex AI bot.

 You just need to use it to compliment what‚Äôs already working.

 In a Gold Rush‚Ä¶ sell the AI-powered shovels.

 Or sit by the door and hope someone tosses you scraps.

 Up to you,

 Ben

 P.S. I actually did this exact process yesterday for a YouTube video.

 If you‚Äôre curious what it actually looks like in action, you can go watch it here. ‚Äã

 It‚Äôs not sexy, but it‚Äôs the most in depth video I‚Äôve made to date.

subject: The "AI Agency" model is likely not for you
body:
I‚Äôm starting a revolution.

 Two weeks ago, this 15 year old kid named Rocco joined Artisan Lab.

 He‚Äôd been running an ‚ÄúAI Agency‚Äù but began to realize all of the real money was in info.

 So he made the pivot.

 Just seven days in, he‚Äôs signed two clients:

 ‚Äã This got me thinking about the whole AI Agency/AI Automation model.

 On paper, it sounds great.

 Learn a few AI tools.

 (Chatbots, automated callers, facebook ads, etc.)

 Find boomer businesses that would need them.

 Charge a few grand to install.

 And then slap a monthly retainer to keep it going.

 It‚Äôs basically the SMMA model with AI wrapping paper.

 Sounds easy, right?

 Well, the service delivery part is.

 Spend 30 minutes on Google and you‚Äôll figure it out.

 But getting clients?

 Keeping clients?

 Building and managing your team?

 Spending your days talking to roofers, plumbers, or realtors?

 Sounds‚Ä¶ interesting.

 Now don‚Äôt get me wrong, this model can work.

 But it becomes a logistical nightmare as you scale.

 You‚Äôll need dozens (if not hundreds) of clients.

 A big team, dialed systems, and you'll likely hate your life.

 Most of the guys I know who‚Äôve scaled AI Agencies either‚Ä¶

 Built themselves a 9-5 job‚Ä¶ Or they're incredibly autistic. I mean that in the nicest way possible -- you have to be obsessive, systematic and nerdy.

 The kind of person who goes nonverbal in social settings.

 So why are there so many people trying to build AI powered SMMAs?

 Especially when you can use a very similar skill set‚Ä¶

 Apply it to an industry that‚Äôs growing rapidly‚Ä¶

 Work with ‚Äúclients‚Äù who typically become your friends‚Ä¶

 And make as much money with one client as you would with a football team worth of plumbers.

 Unless you exclusively wear button ups, you get a boner when someone says ‚Äúautomation,‚Äù and you haven‚Äôt touched a woman since birth‚Ä¶

 Let‚Äôs build a cool business, shall we?

 Revolution commenced,

 Ben

subject: What no one tells you about ‚Äòmaking it‚Äô
body:
‚ÄúThis car will be a Porsche 911 and I‚Äôll have the top down, cruising around LA‚Ä¶‚Äù

 I said to the girl in the passenger seat of my Honda Civic.

 She replied ‚ÄúAnd the girl next to you will probably be way hotter than me.‚Äù

 I laughed but the voice in my head agreed. She was right.

 It was early 2021.

 I‚Äôd just started my agency and decided I was gonna drop out of college.

 All I wanted was freedom..

 And a 911‚Ä¶

 And a dozen girlfriends‚Ä¶

 Aaand to never have to take orders from some skinny-fat fucktard.

 Lol.

 I‚Äôd watched the show Californication a few too many times and I was set.

 That was gonna be my life.

 About two and half years later, it was ‚Äì just swap LA for Miami.

 I have the top down in my nardo grey 911 Turbo.

 The girl in my passenger seat is indeed hotter.

 And I‚Äôm going on my third consecutive $100k month.

 Life is good‚Ä¶ at least from the outside.

 I hadn‚Äôt really thought this far ahead.

 Like, what happens when you actually get all the superficial shit that you want?

 It‚Äôs not quite the life you see on TV.

 The scene you don‚Äôt see is the existential crisis you have when looking at yourself in the mirror.

 You realize the version of life you sold yourself isn‚Äôt the utopia you thought it‚Äôd be.

 You‚Äôve still got problems.

 There‚Äôs still things you don‚Äôt wanna do.

 And you‚Äôre still you.

 Now you gotta figure out what your next goal is ‚Äì and this time, maybe dig a little deeper.

 So I‚Äôm not telling you to not go after the more shallow stuff.

 Actually, if you take a look at Maslow‚Äôs hierarchy of needs, it‚Äôs sort of a rite of passage.

 Your physiological needs (food, shelter, water) are covered.

 Your safety needs are next, then you move on to belongingness and love‚Ä¶

 And finally your esteem needs ‚Äì feeling of accomplishment.

 I‚Äôd climbed the ladder to this point, but I didn‚Äôt account for the top ring.

 Self-actualization.

 I began asking questions like:

 Who am I? 

 What‚Äôs my deeper purpose? 

 Was I led astray? 

 I had to climb the superficial ladder to reach a point where I could think on these clearly.

 Although it felt like a quarter life crisis‚Ä¶

 It was the greatest gift I could give myself.

 And it‚Äôs something you owe to yourself.

 So yeah, chase the car, the girl, and whatever else you fantasize about.

 Just know that if you‚Äôre lucky enough to catch it, there‚Äôs a new game waiting for you on the other side.

 A quieter one.

 Where the scoreboard isn‚Äôt just revenue or the hotness of the girl next to you.

 It‚Äôs purpose.

 It‚Äôs waking up and actually liking who you are when no one‚Äôs watching.

 And funny enough‚Ä¶

 That might be the real flex after all.

 If that‚Äôs the direction you‚Äôre trying to head in, I can help you here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Getting rich is boring
body:
Over the weekend, I got lunch with my friend Tim.

 Tim runs an 8-figure info business.

 Up until recently, he‚Äôd been a ghost online.

 No content, no personal brand, and no rented Huracan‚Ä¶

 Doing $10m+ in annual revenue.

 His business was built by giving Zuckerberg a dollar and getting a few bucks back.

 As he sat there, with a red Richard Mille on his wrist, it became clear to me why he‚Äôs so successful.

 This guy knew just about every metric off the top of his head.

 Not just the basic show up rate, close rate, etc.

 But all the stuff most people wouldn‚Äôt even think to track.

 The percentage of people who watch until a certain minute in the VSL and how it correlates to lead quality.

 Percentages based on days, times, and periods of the calendar year.

 He had a crystal clear pulse on everything.

 Data, tracking, analytics, all of this shit sounds boring and tedious.

 Marketing is fun.

 Closing deals is fun.

 Crafting a new killer angle that you‚Äôre sure will be your ticket to the promised land is fun.

 But you won‚Äôt know what‚Äôs working (and what isn‚Äôt) if you don‚Äôt track it.

 If you‚Äôre willing to obsess over things most people overlook‚Ä¶

 That‚Äôs how you scale predictably with longevity.

 And that‚Äôs how you‚Äôre able to take nearly a full month off to get fucked up at Coachella like Tim did last month lol.

 My main point (and reminder to myself) is this:

 Data isn't boring when it's making you rich.

 Every metric you track provides clarity on the lever that needs to be pulled.

 Most throw spaghetti at the wall, find something that sort of works, and then react when it stops working‚Ä¶

 But if you‚Äôre willing to be a nerd sometimes, you stay proactive.

 And you build a better foundation.

 This Thursday, Tim‚Äôs running a guest call inside of Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 He‚Äôll be sharing the exact playbook he used to build an 8-figure business in his 20‚Äôs.

 ‚Äã Would be a shame if you missed it :) ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

subject: Buy info
body:
This is gonna sound like a pitch but it‚Äôs not.

 Well, technically it is.

 But non-technically, it‚Äôs merely an observation of highly successful people.

 Alright, you ready?

 Good.

 You are a fucking idiot if you don‚Äôt invest in coaching and courses.

 You are dumber than sheep. And sheep are so dumb that they follow each other off cliffs.

 I know that‚Äôs incredibly convenient for me to say considering I sell coaching (hence the pitch warning).

 But I was once one of the idiot sheep.

 Now, I can‚Äôt name a single rich friend of mine who hasn‚Äôt paid for information.

 Off the top of my head, here are some of the bigger things I‚Äôve invested in over the past few years:

 SMMA coaching: $5k (I spent all the money I had on it)

 High ticket sales coaching: $2k

 Jeremy Haynes Inner Circle: I‚Äôve been paying him for over 2.5 years. I don‚Äôt want to do the math, but it‚Äôs close to six figures.

 Iman Gadzhi‚Äôs 8FL: $18k

 1-1 coaching: $10k ++

 I‚Äôm definitely forgetting a handful of others, but there‚Äôs my diploma.

 Not once have I felt ripped off, even when I didn‚Äôt end up utilizing much of a program.

 Because you're not just buying information -- you're bullying yourself into an identity shift.

 I don‚Äôt know if I would‚Äôve ever ‚Äòmade it‚Äô online without doing that.

 When you start paying for info, it's scary.

 The online cattle love to tell you that all courses are scams.

 They comment ‚Äúnice try Diddy‚Äù and ‚Äúput the fries in the bag.‚Äù

 Your family members and friends will think you‚Äôre involved in a pyramid scheme.

 But to the universe ‚Äì and to yourself‚Ä¶

 It‚Äôs a declaration of change.

 As you type your card info into a Whop checkout page, as some sweaty 19 year old closer prays you don't leave the zoom call‚Ä¶

 A part of your soul becomes free.

 You‚Äôll feel a rush of anxiety and excitement.

 You went against what 95% of people believe to be the norm.

 You bet on yourself and spent an uncomfortable amount of money to solidify that commitment. ‚Äã

 Hopefully you didn‚Äôt buy some bullshit. Lol.

 But even if you did, it‚Äôll make for a good story.

 Because now you‚Äôre in the arena.

 It takes courage to reject the opinion of the masses ‚Äì the same way it takes courage to build a successful business.

 So, that concludes my indirect pitch.

 ‚Äã Buy info, retard friend. ‚Äã

 Talk tm,

 Ben

subject: Second-order thinking
body:
‚ÄúAnd then what?‚Äù

 That simple question can be the difference between prosperity and poverty.

 It can lead you to potential problems before anyone else finds them.

 If you solve those problems, you might get rich.

 But most people never think deeply enough to consider second order consequences.

 Here‚Äôs an example‚Ä¶

 First-order consequence:

 ‚ÄúThis girl is hot. I want to date her.‚Äù

 Second-order consequence:

 ‚ÄúShe keyed my car, stole my Rolex and threw a chair off my balcony.‚Äù

 If you considered the second order consequence from the beginning, you probably wouldn‚Äôt have made decision number one.

 Make sense?

 Cool.

 The same principle applies to business, especially with AI.

 Hold on now, don't click off yet ‚Äì I know you‚Äôre probably sick of those two letters.

 Most agency owners, copywriters, and marketers are thinking‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúOh this is really cool, AI will do my work for me hurr durr.‚Äù

 And what‚Äôs the reaction to this?

 Their clients realize they don‚Äôt need them.

 Low skill, basic service providers get replaced.

 But this doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre doomed‚Ä¶

 Because high level service providers become indispensable.

 An online coach (or really any business owner) doesn‚Äôt need doers.

 They need thinkers who can identify bottlenecks, strategize, and steer the ship‚Ä¶

 While leveraging AI to improve efficiency, quality, and everything in between.

 In simple terms, this means‚Ä¶

 Information gets commoditized.

 Everyone will have the same tools.

 ‚ÄúI can build your funnel‚Äù is not a MOAT.

 And differentiation comes through thinking, experience, and context.

 People who understand psychology, systems, and nuances will use AI to multiply their impact.

 Everyone else will get drowned out.

 Pricing power shifts to those who own outcomes, not just provide services.

 Imagine you build and manage the entire back-end of a $200k/month info biz.

 You track KPIs, manage the team, improve conversions, and build the whole system.

 You‚Äôre not an expense, you‚Äôre a partner.

 And that‚Äôs why they‚Äôll pay you $40k/mo, instead of $2k/mo.

 Meanwhile, the ‚ÄúAI agency, copywriter and arbitrageurs ‚Äù are fighting over scraps, praying someone throws them a $1,500 bone.

 All the tools are accessible now. The difference is the application and positioning.

 If you can tie yourself to revenue, AI becomes your leverage not your replacement.

 ‚Äã Go here if you wanna stay ahead of the curve. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: The worst idea of all time
body:
Every morning, I ask myself‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúWhat am I gonna write about today?‚Äù

 I wake up, do the usual routine -- brush teeth, shave, make sure business isn‚Äôt on fire.

 Then I walk to get coffee.

 That‚Äôs usually when the ideas start spawning.

 I observed my thoughts as I went back up the elevator ‚Äì iced latte in hand.

 I‚Äôd probably considered ten different potential angles.

 ‚ÄúThat one‚Äôs good, but I can do better.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúEh, that‚Äôs too similar to what I wrote about yesterday.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúNah, that‚Äôs too boring.‚Äù

 As the elevator took me up to the top floor, I picked the idea that you‚Äôre now reading about.

 You don‚Äôt need a great idea.

 You need a good enough idea and the balls to go all in.

 ‚ÄúIdeas are not worth anything. The ability to execute them is worth millions.‚Äù - Felix Dennis

 There comes a point where you have to accept ‚Äúgood enough.‚Äù

 I know this is ironic considering I frequently say good enough will make you miserable.

 But in the context of business and creativity, something being ‚Äúgreat‚Äù is subjective.

 You take a good enough idea and make it great.

 Not through contemplation but by putting your gloves on and getting in the ring.

 You can waste a lifetime trying to pick the best idea.

 They‚Äôre endless.

 They all could work.

 And that‚Äôs the problem.

 I made my first $100k selling leads to basketball trainers.

 That was a horrible idea.

 But I made it work because I executed.

 And it gave me the skills to spot (and sell) much better ideas later on.

 Like selling money to money-hungry gurus.

 Could I have started there? Sure.

 Would I have had the same level of grit and competence to capitalize on it the way I did?

 Nope.

 So, my friend‚Ä¶

 Stop fooling yourself into thinking you need a better idea.

 A better business model.

 A better mentor.

 A better whatever.

 Perhaps you‚Äôll find something that aligns almost perfectly down the line.

 But you‚Äôll only get there by taking the first imperfect step.

 Anyway, here‚Äôs a bright idea for ya if you want to make money selling shovels in a Gold Rush.

 Later,

 Ben

subject: Avoid this type of person at all costs
body:
I don‚Äôt like poor people.

 ‚ÄúBen, that‚Äôs insensiti‚Äî‚Äú

 Shut up.

 Being poor is a paradigm, not a financial state.

 I know a guy who sold a brand for several million dollars in his early twenties.

 That same guy measured his bedroom down to the inch so he could argue his roommates should pay more rent.

 No matter how rich he gets, he‚Äôll always be poor.

 I stay far away from people like that.

 It‚Äôs like an infectious disease that I don‚Äôt wanna catch.

 A friend of mine recently learned this the hard way.

 He has a big audience on social media.

 Last year, he wanted to launch his first offer, so we hopped on a call.

 He was torn between low ticket or high ticket.

 I implored him to launch a $5k+ offer for entrepreneurs and high achievers.

 He didn‚Äôt listen.

 Instead, he went with a $30/month discord.

 The launch flopped.

 Less than 50 people joined and many were constantly complaining.

 He shut down the group and refunded everyone within a week.

 Not long after, he launched a high ticket offer.

 He made nearly 100x the money and attracted quality customers who are loving the community.

 This is why I don‚Äôt sell a low ticket offer.

 Artisan Lab was built for winners.

 My members move fast and execute.

 They understand that success is reserved for those who fully commit.

 And that‚Äôs why we produce results like this:

 Marcus closed a $3k + 15% deal with a big influencer.

 ‚Äã Rocco got his third client in two weeks (he's 15 lol).

 ‚Äã And Jayden got a new client at a 25% rev share, just one week after joining AL.

 ‚Äã If you‚Äôre serious about building a real business and you understand that‚Äôll require consistent hard work‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã This is for you. ‚Äã

 We‚Äôre not for everyone.

 But if you‚Äôre ready to stop playing small and actually commit, the results speak for themselves.

 ‚Äã Apply here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: $250k months from ONE client
body:
It‚Äôs 9:47am on a Monday.

 I have one sip left in my iced latte.

 And Chat GPT just made this image for me:

 ‚Äã You may have seen this concept before‚Ä¶

 The emotional cycle of change.

 Almost five years ago, I sat in my college dorm room watching a Jason Capital video.

 As he articulated this concept, it matched up perfectly with my endeavours over the previous year.

 Everything I tried, I failed.

 Well‚Ä¶ I‚Äôd quit and start something new before I could really fail.

 But as I learned about the five stages of change, I finally felt understood.

 I thought I was broken‚Ä¶

 It felt like this whole online business thing worked for everyone but me.

 And only now, did I learn that what I experienced was normal.

 1. Uninformed optimism 

 ‚ÄúThis new business is gonna print and I‚Äôll be in a red LaFerrari with a baddie in the passenger seat in no time.‚Äù 

 2. Informed pessimism 

 ‚ÄúUhhhh why is no one replying to my outreach messages? I thought this was gonna be easy.

 3. Valley of despair 

 ‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôm not cut out for this‚Ä¶ Or maybe I just need to try a different business model. Yes, that‚Äôs it! I‚Äôm gonna be an AI Fighter Jet pilot.‚Äù

 4. Informed optimism 

 ‚ÄúNah, I‚Äôm gonna stick this out. I know it‚Äôll be difficult but I can do it.‚Äù

 5. Success and fulfillment 

 ‚ÄúHello, MTV welcome to my Penthouse.‚Äù

 If you‚Äôre in stage three right now, here are my words of encouragement.

 Over the weekend, I recorded this interview with Artisan Lab member, Brady.

 He‚Äôs made $250,000 from one client‚Ä¶ in the past 30 days.

 Yes, you read that right.

 After we did the interview, he told me that he almost quit a year ago.

 He was grinding but making no money -- and fell deep into the valley of despair.

 Around that time, I made a Youtube video about the emotional cycle of change.

 He said that video convinced him to keep pushing‚Ä¶

 Fast forward just one year, and he‚Äôs hitting six figure months.

 If you‚Äôre stuck in the trenches, this might be the push you need -- watch Brady‚Äôs full story here. ‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. This is the original video I made last year that helped him.

subject: How to escape the outbound trenches
body:
Doing outbound sucks.

 It‚Äôs arguably the worst part of starting a service based business.

 You sit there typing, pitching, and praying someone will reply with words other than ‚Äúfuck off.‚Äù

 Finally you get some replies, go back and forth, and get ghosted.

 Maybe you get a call scheduled‚Ä¶ only for it to get rescheduled for next week (which is code for ‚Äúfuck off").

 But if you do it the right way, this period doesn‚Äôt last forever.

 It‚Äôs a temporary phase that you look back on and laugh about.

 Over time, it becomes easier to get clients ‚Äì assuming you even want more after you get one or two good ones.

 However most people never get out of the ‚ÄúI hate my life, outbound is so difficult, no one replies to me‚Äù phase.

 And that‚Äôs simply because they‚Äôre doing it wrong.

 Instead of turning this email into an outbound masterclass, I‚Äôll give you one piece of advice that‚Äôll be just as effective:

 If you do what everyone else does and expect a different result, you are either stupid, lazy, or you don‚Äôt actually want to make money.

 Maybe a combination of all three.

 Personally, I get hundreds of pitches a week.

 I skim through all of them.

 99% are copy and pasted.

 They get ignored.

 In the rare event I get a pitch that‚Äôs real and considerate ‚Äì like a Loom showing how my YouTube funnel could double call bookings by fixing the drop-off at minute 3‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôll actually take a look.

 But that only happens when it‚Äôs clear they did their homework and found a real gap.

 When people say ‚Äúsend personalized messages,‚Äù that doesn‚Äôt mean offer some random, retarded compliment like‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúHey Ben, I saw you played basketball in high school! Anyway, do you want a clipping army that‚Äôll make you an extra $7.56 a month!‚Äù

 Fuck off.

 Stop being an idiot.

 Stop the spray and pray approach.

 And stop offering irrelevant compliments.

 Be normal, creative, and lead with a solution to their potential problems.

 There‚Äôs your stupid little masterclass.

 ‚Äã Join Artisan Lab if you don‚Äôt want to spam strangers in DMs forever like a monkey with an iPhone.

 Ben

subject: Two truths and a lie (sales edition)
body:
Let‚Äôs play a game.

 I‚Äôm gonna tell you three statements you‚Äôve probably heard on the internet.

 Two of them are true, one is a lie.

 Ready?

 1. High ticket sales is a great way to stack cash.

 2. Good sales people are in high demand.

 3. If you get into sales, you can make your own hours and work from the beach.

 Could you spot the lie?

 Many sales guys have joined Artisan Lab in the past few months.

 I hear the same story time and time again.

 Someone gets started in sales.

 They find a good offer to close for.

 They spend all day on zoom persuading prospects into pulling out their credit card.

 Maybe they get to $10k, $20k, or in rare cases, even $30k+ monthly.

 But eventually, they hit a ceiling.

 Their income stagnates.

 Every day becomes the same.

 They begin to hate it.

 They got into online business because they wanted freedom‚Ä¶

 But they've worked themselves into a high paying job with no leverage and no upside.

 Now they're stuck asking themselves:

 ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs next?‚Äù

 Now this isn‚Äôt a bad spot to be in.

 But there‚Äôs a smarter play if you really want freedom and leverage.

 Instead of spending your days on Zoom, hoping you don‚Äôt see another +91 on your calendar‚Ä¶

 What if you owned the system itself?

 This is the logical next step if you're capped in sales.

 You already know how to close.

 You already understand buyer psychology.

 Now you just need to control more of the process and get a bigger piece of the pie.

 With an info agency, you help the same entrepreneurs you're closing for by:

 Scripting VSLs.

 Building funnels.

 Writing emails.

 Optimizing backend systems.

 And thanks to AI, learning these skills has literally never been easier.

 You can go from one-trick pony to a capable operator in weeks.

 Then use your existing sales skills to close a client or two‚Ä¶

 And welcome to the side of the game where the real money (and freedom) is made.

 If you're ready to stop chasing commission checks...

 ‚Äã Here where you can build something that actually scales. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Why staying poor is unethical
body:
I ran into my rich friend Josh at the coffee shop this morning.

 He‚Äôs this southern guy in his mid-thirties who sold a manufacturing company a few years ago.

 He‚Äôs been retired since.

 I sat with him and chatted for a bit.

 ‚ÄúYou can only sip so many margaritas on the beach, buy a few supercars, and stack the watch collection‚Ä¶ until it gets boring,‚Äù he said.

 He wasn‚Äôt complaining, just being honest.

 He‚Äôd spent the past few years floating around Europe with nothing to do and unlimited money.

 And now, he‚Äôs restless.

 He wants to build again.

 The game continues‚Ä¶

 Even when you win, you still have to figure out who you are.

 Money buys freedom.

 But it doesn‚Äôt tell you what to do with it.

 Real life starts after you ‚Äúmake it.‚Äù

 Success removes your excuses.

 And suddenly you‚Äôre forced to confront the question you‚Äôve been avoiding:

 ‚ÄúWhat do I actually want?‚Äù

 Unless you‚Äôre a monk or some kind of hippy, you have to buy the right to have this sort of internal clarity.

 One of my mentors once told me, ‚Äúmaking money is such a waste of time‚Ä¶ but you have to do it.‚Äù

 At first I didn‚Äôt get it.

 But now I do.

 Because until you make money, you‚Äôre not really thinking clearly.

 You‚Äôre just reacting.

 Money (or the lack of it) makes all of your decisions.

 But once you‚Äôve made it and the noise quiets down‚Ä¶

 That‚Äôs when the real questions start to surface.

 What do I actually care about?

 What do I want to spend my time on?

 What kind of life do I want to wake up and live every day?

 You don‚Äôt get honest answers to those questions when you‚Äôre broke.

 Maybe chasing money is a waste of time.

 But avoiding it guarantees you‚Äôll be lost forever.

 It‚Äôs your duty to get rich.

 Not just for the lifestyle, or the validation, or the Patek.

 But because it‚Äôs the only way to earn the clarity required to live on your own terms.

 You can‚Äôt build a life you love if you‚Äôre stuck in survival mode.

 So go get the money. ‚Äã

 Buy the clarity.

 And then decide what really matters.

 Ben

subject: Why all roads lead to info
body:
My business model isn‚Äôt for everyone.

 It‚Äôs easier to make endless content and try to go viral as a Tik Tok Shop affiliate.

 It‚Äôs easier to learn sales and sit on zoom all day.

 It‚Äôs easier to sell products on Amazon.

 So if you‚Äôre a complete beginner and when you hear the word ‚Äúfunnel‚Äù you think of beer‚Ä¶

 Building an info agency probably isn‚Äôt for you right now.

 And that‚Äôs okay ‚Äì go try one of the three businesses above and come back to me later.

 But let‚Äôs zoom out.

 Who‚Äôs actually profiting the most in each of these?

 I know plenty of TTS affiliates who‚Äôve made good money.

 But the people who make the most in that niche are the ones selling info on it.

 I know plenty of closers who make $10-$50k/month.

 But the people who get past that, sell info on it.

 And I know guys who‚Äôve scaled their Amazon business to six figures a month (at 10% margins)...

 But the people who profit six figures a month‚Ä¶ sell info.

 Interesting.

 Over the past year, I‚Äôve helped eight people hit $100k+ in monthly profit.

 Not from selling info themselves, but by partnering with people who sell info.

 And personally, I made my first $2m doing this.

 Now I‚Äôm not gonna sit here and tell you it‚Äôs the easiest business model on Earth.

 Truthfully, if you have zero experience and don‚Äôt understand the difference between copywriting and copyright‚Ä¶

 You will struggle.

 But if you‚Äôve been through the online business gauntlet‚Ä¶

 And you now want something that‚Äôs more predictable, scalable, and doesn‚Äôt require you to do outreach all day‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã This is the best model for you.

 It‚Äôs made Jace $200k in a month from one client.

subject: The bag is right in front of you, {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "bro" }}
body:
Getting rich is easy, actually.

 Find a problem, create a solution, and sell.

 Sounds braindead simple to me.

 The hard part is deprogramming old habits and standards to replace them with new ones.

 For some, this seems to happen fast.

 For others, it can be a few months or a couple years.

 And for most, it never really happens, and they stay miserable.

 Don‚Äôt do that.

 One of the most prevalent paradigm shifts you have to make is the ability to identify and seize opportunities.

 Most people don‚Äôt think critically enough to do this.

 They think,‚Äùhurr durr dis not working right now, maybe i do something else.‚Äù

 A few years ago, my inner dialogue sounded something like the above.

 I ran a marketing agency for basketball trainers and just couldn‚Äôt seem to scale.

 No matter what I tried, nothing worked.

 But then I spotted a better lane.

 I applied my skill set to digital products instead of local businesses‚Ä¶

 I got a couple big clients‚Ä¶

 And even though I felt like I was in way over my head, I worked like a dog.

 I took every chance to prove myself.

 I did more than what was asked.

 And said yes to things I didn‚Äôt know how to do.

 That season of being overworked and underpaid is what set me up for everything I have now.

 A few months ago, my top sales guy on one of my offers was in the same spot.

 It was a newer offer and he wasn‚Äôt making a ton of money at first.

 Despite this, he went above and beyond to help the business grow.

 Not only did he do his job well, but he also spent hours building systems, creating tracking sheets, and making course content.

 No one asked him to do any of this, but his income grew as a result.

 Now, he‚Äôs working for one of the most famous marketers in the world.

 And unsurprisingly, he's now their top sales guy.

 Had he not maximized a lesser opportunity, he wouldn't have been competent enough to get that role.

 But he did. And now, he will quite literally be set up for life.

 Ask yourself what you would‚Äôve done in that position.

 You‚Äôre underpaid.

 Your income doesn‚Äôt reflect your skill set.

 And no one is asking you to take any initiative.

 Would you go above and beyond?

 Or would you get complacent?

 The answer to that question determines the rest of your life.

 There‚Äôs no secret.

 ‚Äã Just a moment where you decide to act like the person you want to become.

 No pressure,

 Ben

 P.S. ‚ÄúOpportunities are all around you, you‚Äôre just too fucking retarded to spot them.‚Äù - Socrates

Getting rich is easy, actually.

 Find a problem, create a solution, and sell.

 Sounds braindead simple to me.

 The hard part is deprogramming old habits and standards to replace them with new ones.

subject: Get off the rollercoaster
body:
‚ÄúMy confidence isn‚Äôt a rollercoaster,‚Äù my high school basketball teammate said.

 I‚Äôd asked him how he stays consistent when shots aren‚Äôt falling.

 That simple answer is a big reason why he became the all time leading scorer at our school.

 He was the type of athlete that would just win.

 No matter what was going on, how big the moment was, or even how he was playing up until that point‚Ä¶

 There was this ever-present stillness in his demeanor.

 Every game he‚Äôd show up, do what‚Äôs needed, and go home.

 Completely emotionless.

 And although he wasn‚Äôt exceptionally athletic or way more skilled than everyone else‚Ä¶

 He did the basics a whole lot better.

 Almost a decade after that conversation, I‚Äôve watched this same principle make a lot of people rich.

 Those who win in business aren‚Äôt the ones constantly jumping from one thing to the next.

 They‚Äôre the quiet, consistent killers who execute the basics day after day.

 And their confidence isn‚Äôt tied to immediate results.

 If you can wake up each morning, do what‚Äôs needed, and move forward‚Ä¶

 Maintain consistency, even when you hit setbacks or your outreach is met with silence.

 You will win.

 Because business, like sports ‚Äì is often a war of attrition.

 Consistency wins.

 Show up and do the simple things repeatedly.

 Even when it‚Äôs boring, difficult, and when no one is watching.

 And the next time your confidence feels like it‚Äôs on a rollercoaster, remember this:

 You are being tested by the universe.

 Will {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "you" }} execute relentlessly, despite that fact that you‚Äôre not getting the result you want?

 Or will you be like the masses and quit or jump to a different shiny object?

 The answer to that question will determine everything about your future.

 Someone has to put the fries in the bag.

 ‚Äã Don‚Äôt let that person be you. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: The difference between $10k & $100k/month
body:
I have good news and bad news.

 The bad news:

 If you want to get rich, you have to get lucky.

 The good news:

 You can rig luck in your favor.

 Consistent hard work plus a decent skill set will ensure some success.

 Even if you have a room temperature IQ, you can brute force your way to low six-figs a year.

 But beyond that?

 You need leverage.

 I‚Äôve had calls with two new Artisan Lab members recently where this stood out to me.

 One of them is a sales guy.

 He‚Äôs closing on one of the best offers you can be on in the info space.

 Making good money, but spending 8+ hours a day on zoom.

 The other guy is running a content agency.

 He‚Äôs got almost 10 clients on monthly retainers and is crushing it for them.

 His systems are incredibly detailed and he has a decent sized team.

 Both are hard-working, smart, and have the talent they need to get to six-figure months.

 But they don‚Äôt have much leverage.

 They‚Äôre making commissions or flat fees and getting paid for effort, instead of outcomes.

 That‚Äôs the cap.

 Those who break through to $100k/month aren‚Äôt necessarily better.

 They‚Äôre just riding a better vehicle -- a business model that multiplies their output.

 That‚Äôs what changed everything for me.

 I went from $15k/month with my SMMA to $120k/month within a year.

 Not because I learned new skills.

 Not because I worked harder.

 Because I switched vehicles.

 If you want to be ‚Äúlucky,‚Äù this is how you do it. ‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. I just made a new video about how you can use AI to write banger VSLs and emails in seconds. Watch it here. ‚Äã

subject: Tell better stories
body:
‚ÄúWhat story or analogy can I use to articulate this idea?‚Äù 

 That‚Äôs the question I ask myself at the beginning of every piece of copy I write.

 Coming up with the idea is the easy part.

 Wrapping It up into a 400 word hero's-journey is the trickier part.

 The best marketers on the planet are just really good storytellers.

 I was first exposed to this subconsciously.

 Right before I dropped out of college, I was watching Jason Capital videos religiously.

 I‚Äôd sit at the desk in my bedroom of the frat house.

 I had this white and black gaming chair and notebook in front of me.

 I‚Äôd take pages of notes and even started using flashcards to memorize marketing and psychology principles.

 Off the top of my head, I can‚Äôt remember a single concept I wrote down.

 But what I can remember is the story‚Ä¶

 He quits college basketball, gets into online marketing, pays Craig Ballantyne who writes down a business plan on a napkin‚Ä¶

 Then starts making $20k/mo in his dorm room‚Ä¶

 Leaves college, lives at the Ritz Carlton, blah blah, blah.

 Similarly, I‚Äôve watched a good amount of Hormozi content and can‚Äôt recite many of his lessons.

 But I vividly remember the beginning of $100M Offers.

 Four years ago, I opened that big ass purple book.

 It was the second month after I dropped out of college, as I sat in this knit chair on the balcony of my villa in Tulum, Mexico.

 He starts by telling the story of how a business partner stole all his money.

 At his girlfriend's parents' house, he told her what happened and said he wouldn‚Äôt blame her if she left him.

 She replied, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd sleep under a bridge with you.‚Äù

 I remember all of that off the dome.

 And I promise I‚Äôm not a weirdo, that's just how our brains are wired.

 We remember stories.

 The better stories you tell, the better marketer you will be.

 If you‚Äôve been reading my newsletter or watching my content for a while, what do you remember?

 Probably not much.

 But hopefully a few stories if I did my job well.

 So next time you‚Äôre at an impasse, thinking about taking a leap‚Ä¶

 Maybe just do it for the plot.

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

subject: You‚Äôre early
body:
Have you ever watched someone do something so well that it sort of made you want to quit?

 They perform at a level that seems inconceivable to reach.

 It makes you feel like you‚Äôre lightyears behind‚Ä¶

 And you should pack it up and do something else with your life.

 Sometimes that signal is accurate.

 The game is rigged in their favor and they have a natural ability that you don‚Äôt.

 The first time I ever watched an NBA player workout, I realized I wasn‚Äôt going to the NBA.

 But most of the time -- especially in a business setting‚Ä¶

 The people who seem to be on another level are normal.

 They‚Äôre absent of advantages‚Ä¶ other than hundreds or thousands of reps and split tests.

 Data is the difference.

 And life is basically an ad campaign.

 When you set up a campaign on Meta, its AI has a general understanding of who you‚Äôre targeting based on what you say in the ad.

 As you start spending money, it gets more data.

 That data indicates ‚Äúyes, this is the type of prospect we are looking for‚Ä¶‚Äù

 Or ‚Äúno, this person is homeless and addicted to fent, he probably can‚Äôt invest $25k into a DFY AI Arbitrage Agency.‚Äù

 Meta‚Äôs machine learning adapts and stops looking for unqualified drug addicts.

 The more money you spend, the more data it gets, and the faster it knows exactly who to target.

 Think of yourself like an AI machine.

 You can master anything if you input enough data.

 Speaking, dating, business, copy, sales, boxing‚Ä¶ the list goes on.

 Your rate of improvement is dependent on the amount of reps you get in the allotted time.

 If you send 100 outbound messages in a week‚Ä¶

 You test different styles and approaches‚Ä¶

 You listen to the data and adapt‚Ä¶

 You will basically be a different person than you were 7 days prior.

 Extrapolate this to anything in life -- and work towards mastery.

 And when you feel behind‚Ä¶

 Don‚Äôt quit the game.

 Just double the spend -- figuratively or literally.

 More reps, more data, more progress.

 Because most of the time, the people ahead of you aren‚Äôt superhuman, they‚Äôre just further into the campaign.

 With enough inputs, your results will catch up.

 Just don‚Äôt close your laptop before you learn how to deter homeless people from booking a call on your sales team's calendar.

 ‚Äã Start your campaign here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: How Chrome Hearts ruined online coaching
body:
Good morning, happy Monday.

 Let‚Äôs talk about the ‚Äútrust recession.‚Äù

 You‚Äôve probably heard marketers throw this term around recently.

 Consumers are more skeptical than ever and there‚Äôs data to back it up.

 In hindsight, it seems obvious as to why.

 Remember the ‚Äúautomation‚Äù phase a few years ago?

 People started slinging ‚ÄúDFY passive income streams‚Äù for multi-five figures a pop.

 Imagine you‚Äôre a depressed middle aged man named Jerry.

 You live paycheck to paycheck in Gary, Indiana with your 248lb wife.

 On a random Tuesday night, you‚Äôre scrolling through Instagram.

 You see a 30-second ad from a tattooed man, draped in Chrome Hearts standing in front of a Huracan.

 He says ‚Äúwe‚Äôll build you an Amazon store and guarantee $15k/mo in 90 days!‚Äù

 You‚Äôre hooked.

 You get on a sales call with some 19-year-old kid who convinces you to take out a loan.

 After spending $40k that you don‚Äôt have, 90 days later you‚Äôve made nothing and can‚Äôt get a hold of the automation company.

 No shit there‚Äôs a trust recession!

 Thousands of people, like our friend Jerry, are now in generational debt.

 Rightfully so, events like this have given online coaching a bad rap.

 But I still believe it‚Äôs one of the most ethical and impactful businesses‚Ä¶

 *If you do it the right way* (most don‚Äôt).

 When there‚Äôs something you want to master, having a coach makes it infinitely easier.

 Someone taught you how to drive.

 Someone taught you how to play an instrument.

 Someone taught you how to shoot a jump shot.

 You could‚Äôve figured all of these things out on your own, but that‚Äôd be illogical.

 It would take you exponentially longer, and you know that.

 So, you take a shortcut ‚Äì you get help from someone who‚Äôs done what you‚Äôre trying to do.

 Making money is no different.

 Over the past year I‚Äôve invested close to six figures to learn from people like Jeremy Haynes, William Brown, Taylor Allan and Iman Gadzhi.

 Could I learn everything they‚Äôve taught me through Youtube plus trial and error?

 Maybe.

 But why would I take the longer road, when an express lane is available?

 That‚Äôs what idiots do. And I don‚Äôt consider myself an idiot.

 So {{ subscriber.first_name }}, I‚Äôm imploring you to get coaching.

 Whether it‚Äôs from me or someone else, I‚Äôm pitching you for your sake.

 ‚Äã Go here and buy this. ‚Äã

 Or go somewhere else and buy something else (preferably not from someone wearing Chrome).

 Just don‚Äôt end up like Jerry.

 And don‚Äôt buy anything with automation in the title.

 Alright bye,

 Ben

subject: The most pretentious email you'll read today
body:
I have a flight to New York in a few hours and I still need to pack.

 This is unfortunate, because I hate packing.

 Even more unfortunate, is that I‚Äôm flying commercial!

 It‚Äôs Phillips' birthday tomorrow so we‚Äôre celebrating in NYC and then heading to the Hamptons for the 4th of July.

 Danny, who you may recognize from my Youtube, is coming along as well.

 At first I was fine with flying commercial.

 It‚Äôs not thaaaat bad‚Ä¶

 But I texted my jet guy last minute for the hell of it.

 He found a solid deal that would get us from Opa Locka to Teterboro airport for under $20k.

 I‚Äôm not one to pass up a half decent deal.

 So I texted Phillip and Danny to see if they‚Äôd be down to split it‚Ä¶

 And they said no.

 Phillip spent his last dollar on another pair of Chrome jeans and Danny just bought a Patek.

 You‚Äôd think when you rescue people from poverty and help them make $100k/mo+ they‚Äôd be a bit more eager to split a jet right?

 I guess not.

 But it‚Äôs crazy to me that all three of us run info agencies.

 Danny has one great client who he‚Äôs helped scale to multi-seven figures and personally nets six-figures a month from his rev share.

 Phillip got off sales calls five months ago, and hit his first $100k month last month, with just three clients.

 This is a business model I randomly stumbled into three years ago.

 It worked for me, but I thought I was the anomaly.

 I had a decent network and a vast skill set.

 Because of this, I never imagined this model would work for others the way it has for me.

 So even though Phillip and Danny are being frugal today, it‚Äôs cool to see.

 But maybe they‚Äôre anomalies too‚Ä¶

 Maybe we all just got lucky and the stars aligned for us.

 Just like they did for Elijah, who made $25k+ from one rev share client last month:

 ‚Äã Or Alo, who made $34k from one client...

 ‚Äã Or Khesraw who had record months with two clients and will make over $15k from his rev share.

 ‚Äã We all got lucky.

 We're all anomalies.

 Or maybe we just stopped overcomplicating things and picked the right vehicle. ‚Äã

 Alright, I gotta go pack.

 See you on Delta,

 Ben

subject: I lied again!
body:
I lied to you.

 In yesterday‚Äôs email I told you I was about to fly to New York with my friends Phillip and Danny.

 30 minutes later, our flight got delayed from 3pm to 8pm.

 Delays always scare me because there never seems to be just one.

 First it‚Äôs 8pm, then 10pm, and then somehow you‚Äôre leaving at 1am and going to Kazakhstan instead of JFK.

 I did not want to end up in Kazakhstan.

 So after a dozen phone calls, a lot of convincing, and a five figure wire‚Ä¶

 Our new flight now takes off in an hour and 45 minutes.

 And instead of Delta, well‚Ä¶

 It‚Äôs a jet.

 ‚ÄúWow bro you‚Äôre so cool! Stupid ass guru.‚Äù

 Thank you.

 Anyway, I gotta finish packing and don‚Äôt have any lessons for you today‚Ä¶

 (Other than don‚Äôt stay in school and say maybe to drugs.)

 But I don‚Äôt want to leave you empty handed so here‚Äôs a video I made recently about how business gets easier over time.

 If you‚Äôre in the trenches right now‚Ä¶

 And you‚Äôre reading this email from some pretentious asshole bragging about flying private‚Ä¶

 Just know, it gets easier.

 You‚Äôre in the part that sucks.

 It's a training camp that everyone has to go through.

 You‚Äôre earning stripes every day that you show up and blindly throw spaghetti at the wall.

 Even though you might have nothing to show for it and feel like you‚Äôre spinning in circles‚Ä¶

 There will come a time where things click.

 I can‚Äôt tell you when, how, or why.

 But if you just stick it out for long enough, eventually the universe will decide:

 {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "You‚Äôre" }}'s ready now.

 You won‚Äôt be flying commercial forever.

 See you at Opa-Locka Airport,

 Ben

 P.S. If you read this one and want to chat about anything, hit reply. I‚Äôve got three hours to kill on this flight.

subject: Spent all my money & now I'm sad :(
body:
I had a quarter-life crisis yesterday.

 As I sat in 2A on my flight home from the Hamptons, I got this pit in my stomach.

 Not because I was on a commercial flight.

 And not because my friends and I spent an accountant's annual salary over the past four days.

 Let me rewind a bit‚Ä¶

 We flew to New York on a jet (I know, I know ‚Äì I‚Äôve rinsed this story. Last time I mention it lol).

 We stayed at the St. Regis ‚Äì one of the nicest hotels in the city.

 We celebrated my friend Phillip‚Äôs birthday at a restaurant you typically have to reserve a year in advance.

 The next day, we were driven to Montauk, where we stayed in a beautiful AirBNB right on the beach.

 Over the following two nights, we spent five figures at the club.

 And on our last night, we went to the biggest, most exclusive party in the Hamptons.

 Phillip was on stage next to Livvy Dunne and Bobby Shmurda (lol) and I said cancelable things on Sneako‚Äôs stream.

 If you told me this was my life four years ago, I‚Äôd be over the moon.

 But on the flight home, I felt numb.

 ‚ÄúWhat the fuck is wrong with me?‚Äù I thought.

 I just went on this amazing trip.

 And everything in my life is objectively great right now.

 I‚Äôve hit a new record in my business each of the past three months.

 I‚Äôve helped people make their first dollar online ‚Äì and others hit their first six figure month.

 I have my dream car, an incredible circle of friends, and a close relationship with my family.

 But it all just feels‚Ä¶ normal.

 What the fuck.

 I thought every day would be blissful.

 I thought everything would feel perfect.

 I thought my only problem would be choosing between the blonde or brunette.

 But I was wrong.

 That‚Äôs not how life works.

 As you reach new levels, your standards rise.

 The jet is just a flight.

 The supercar is just a car.

 The penthouse is just an apartment.

 And you‚Ä¶

 Are still you.

 It feels incredible to earn a lifestyle you dreamt of.

 But probably not as incredible as the Utopia you created in your head.

 This is not a ‚Äúsell your things and live like a monk‚Äù email.

 Nor is it a cry for help.

 Just a reminder that even as you start to get the things you want‚Ä¶

 The best part of your day will likely be something simple.

 A peaceful walk.

 A conversation with a friend.

 Or a morning coffee and email to your list.

 Life is amazing, don‚Äôt forget to appreciate it.

 ‚Äã And keep getting richer just so you can know for sure that it won‚Äôt fix everything :)

 Alright, glad to be back.

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 P.S. If you liked this one, reply and let me know <3

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "Yo" }}, you got cheated on
body:
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the best business model to start that‚Äôll get me to $10k/mo in 90 days?‚Äù

 I spent six months Googling that question every day.

 Because of that, it took me about two years longer than it should‚Äôve.

 Instead of locking in to build one thing, my eyes always wandered to the badder bitch.

 Social media is like the playboy mansion for business models, so there were plenty.

 This is a common mishap.

 Nearly everyone goes through a phase where they‚Äôre in a situationship with eight different businesses.

 Somehow you convince yourself that they‚Äôre all mid or not ‚Äúwifey material.‚Äù

 So you refuse to commit to any one of them and proclaim every business is a whore! 

 The other day, I met an uber driver with possibly the worst case of shiny object syndrome I‚Äôd ever seen.

 First he told me about his dropshipping business where he sold Donald Trump t-shirts.

 Then his ‚Äútinder for injury lawyers.‚Äù

 Then his contracting business.

 Then his AI only fans agency.

 Then he showed me a demo account where he allegedly turned $1k into $10m.

 Oh, and then he asked me for $100k so he could do it with real money.

 I politely declined.

 The thing is, this guy actually seemed pretty intelligent.

 He showed me the websites he built for each business and they were clean.

 His ideas were thorough and it‚Äôs clear he was doing his research‚Ä¶

 Too much research.

 You can convince yourself any business is better than what you‚Äôre doing.

 They all look sexy from afar.

 But one day, you‚Äôll wake up next to it and see it without makeup.

 And only then will you realize it‚Äôs been using Facetune and AI filters.

 You‚Äôll find the shortcut once you stop looking for it.

 You commit.

 You ignore the temptation.

 And you build with speed and enough patience.

 Just don‚Äôt wife a hoe, pick the right model. ‚Äã

 Ben
