subject: The only "manifestation strategy" that works
body:
‚ÄúI manifested this shit!‚Äù

 Says the black-hat MRR scammer turned grifter who‚Äôs financing a Huracan on a balloon loan.

 He'll default on his payment and make a story post saying‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúGod gives his toughest battles to his strongest soldiers.‚Äù

 No retard, you just have a 27% chargeback rate because you sell air for $8k.

 Not long ago, I began to hate ‚Äúmanifestation‚Äù because I associated it with those guys.

 And then I remembered how I got here.

 During my last year in college (before I dropped out) I entered my ‚Äúspiritual entrepreneur‚Äù phase.

 I had sticky notes with affirmations scattered around my room.

 ‚ÄúMoney flows to me easily.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúI am not chopped.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúI make $10k/month effortlessly.‚Äù

 There were incense sticks next to my bed and a vision board on my Notion homepage.

 Although, there was still a little voice in my head saying:

 ‚ÄúThis is gay.‚Äù

 But I kept doing it.

 Because everyone I followed said that‚Äôs how success happens.

 I was confused why selling leads to basketball trainers required me to become one with the Universe.

 Years later when the goals actually started coming true, I realized manifestation is just a rebranded version of planning.

 It only looks magical from the outside.

 Because when you set a specific target, train your brain to see it constantly, and take relentless action toward it‚Ä¶

 Things start to work out.

 It‚Äôs not some mythical awakening but rather the compound interest of commitment.

 So here‚Äôs the ‚Äúlaw of attraction‚Äù in simple terms:

 1. Set precise goals.

 ‚ÄúLand one client on a 20% rev share, get them to $100k/mo.‚Äù

 2. Reverse engineer it.

 How many outbound messages do I need to send daily to get a client?

 3. Execute.

 Actually do it.

 There‚Äôs your spiritual alignment manifestation guru guide ‚Äì no crystals required.

 Just set a goal, make a plan, and do the work.

 If you want to manifest $20k/month without becoming a hippy, join me here. ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 P.S. I just dropped a new YouTube video on how AI is doing 90% of my client work. Check it out here. ‚Äã

subject: I got scammed for $5k and filed a dispute
body:
I filed my first ever dispute yesterday.

 After 24 years on this beautiful Earth, I finally had to do it.

 Here‚Äôs what happened:

 On our way to the Hamptons, we had a driver take us from NYC to Montauk.

 He showed up on time and his car was clean‚Ä¶

 But the second I got in his black suburban, I regretted it.

 This fucker smelled like he‚Äôd just eaten a bowl of curry and ran a marathon to 7/11, where he then bought a bag of beef jerky.

 My shirt was over my nose and I had the window open for the majority of the ride.

 It was still torture ‚Äì I wouldn‚Äôt even wish such a thing on George (my enemy from previous emails if you remember that dork).

 That said, at least he got us there safely.

 I didn‚Äôt chargeback on the guy just because he smelled like a math convention.

 But that ride left a bad smell in my nose.

 So on the way back, I decided we‚Äôd take a helicopter to NYC and then catch our flight at JFK.

 It was about 10x the price but 1/5th of the time and had a lower likelihood of a smelly driver.

 Worth every penny in my humble opinion.

 On the morning of our flight, I got an email from the helicopter company.

 It said if we had any luggage over 25 lbs, we‚Äôd have to schedule a car service.

 The only way to do so was to call them.

 First of all, why was I not prompted to do this until 3 hours before we‚Äôre scheduled to leave?

 Whatever.

 I give them a call, the guy tells me the bags might not arrive on time, so he‚Äôd have to check and call me back.

 We go back and forth for the next hour as he gives me a dozen different answers.

 Basically it‚Äôd be $500 to send the luggage to the airport for us and he was unsure if it would arrive on time for our flight.

 Finally, I‚Äôm fed up so I told him to cancel it and I booked a driver.

 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry sir, your flight is non-refundable.‚Äù

 I end up talking to his supervisor, go back and forth, they won‚Äôt budge, and basically tell me to get fucked.

 So we didn‚Äôt take the $5,000 helicopter and now it‚Äôs in Amex‚Äôs hands.

 It felt kind of cool clicking the dispute charge button.

 Now I understand what it‚Äôs like to be poor.

 If I win, it‚Äôs a free $5k, if I lose, I‚Äôll have forgotten about it by the time they make a decision.

 I guess there‚Äôs no lesson in here for you today, I just wanted to tell you that I‚Äôm now a proud member of the dispute club.

 Later,

 Ben

 P.S. Artisan Lab‚Äôs 1 year anniversary is coming up in 2 days.

 I asked our members to leave a quick review and wanted to share this one from Jack: 

 ‚Äú48 hours into Artisan Lab hands down one of if not the best purchases in my life. I know I‚Äôm glazing rn but honestly wtf it‚Äôs gone to a point of over delivering. It‚Äôs not just info, it‚Äôs every single skill it takes to make money online in one package.‚Äù 

 If only the helicopter company over delivered half as much as we do inside Artisan Lab‚Ä¶

subject: The fastest path to $20K/mo+
body:
I have a confession‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôm a scammer.

 Over the last year, I‚Äôve convinced over 200 people to give me their hard earned money.

 Not just a couple bucks, but multiple thousands each.

 Eight of my victims have gone on to hit $100k/mo+.

 Nearly 30 have hit their first $10k month.

 Several are in the $20k-$50k range.

 And many are building the skill set that‚Äôll allow them to reach the numbers above.

 Quite a fruitful scam if you ask me.

 Exactly a year ago tomorrow, Artisan Lab was born.

 For the anniversary, I asked all the members to fill out a feedback survey and incentivized them with free prizes.

 (Yes, this is me telling you I bribed them).

 Bribe or not, here‚Äôs what they‚Äôre saying about their experience:

 "I transitioned from low to high ticket model since being in AL. I‚Äôve generated roughly $100k for my clients, left my job in the Australian Navy, and now I‚Äôm traveling the world... Hands down best community in the info space." ‚Äì Ellis Deakin ‚Äã 

 "I started at $3K/mo. Hit $15K/mo in my 4th month. Just signed someone who did $1.6M last month. Haven‚Äôt done outreach in a month and probably never will again." ‚Äì Dominic Morrell ‚Äã 

 "Going from $7K/mo to my first $17K/mo in 3 months of joining." ‚Äì Khesraw Gulestani ‚Äã 

 "Ben‚Äôs coaching reshaped how I thought about business. I went from charging $500 per client to $7K+ upfront‚Äîand I actually own equity in a client business now." ‚Äì Adam Wieczorek ‚Äã 

 "Last month my main client did $15K. On a 50% rev share, I took home $7.5K‚Äîand it‚Äôs growing. I‚Äôve leveraged that case study to land more clients. Artisan Lab gave me the confidence to go full gas." ‚Äì Lloyd Johnsrud If there‚Äôs one thing I‚Äôve learned this year, it‚Äôs that change can happen fast ‚Ä¶

 For the right person.

 If you have a bit of foundation underneath you, all you need is alignment.

 Environment + skill + pressure = results.

 That‚Äôs the formula.

 If you‚Äôre already in motion, all you need is the right room and the right model. ‚Äã

 Cheers to year one, year two's gonna be even crazier.

 ‚Äã Scam yourself to success here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Do you actually want to make more money?
body:
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre making a measly $100k/month and you‚Äôre comfortable!‚Äù he told me.

 Over the weekend, I went to Jeremy Haynes‚Äô Mastermind.

 You may have seen him on YouTube yelling about hitting million dollar months.

 For two and a half years now, I‚Äôve been in his Inner Circle program.

 I‚Äôve been to countless of his quarterly in-person events and he never disappoints.

 Jeremy is a very intense person.

 He gets hypnotized every year to ‚Äúget richer.‚Äù

 I thought that was bullshit until I saw how disgusted he is with stagnation.

 My friend Mason told me Jeremy almost made him cry on a 1-1 call recently.

 Mason is a 26 year old making $5m+ per year.

 If you‚Äôre settling, Jeremy will call you out on it.

 Three months ago at the last Mastermind, he did just that.

 I‚Äôm walking around, making small talk and enjoying the food.

 Jeremy comes up and a few of us start talking.

 Then he looks me dead in the eyes and says‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúAre you still doing pussy numbers?‚Äù

 Uh oh.

 He‚Äôs known to do this thing where he‚Äôll just berate you if he thinks you need it.

 And in this moment, I realize I might be today's target. Gulp.

 ‚ÄúUhh ye‚Ä¶ yeah I‚Äôm working man‚Äù I respond.

 Wrong answer.

 You can‚Äôt do that with him.

 If you try to virtue signal, he sees that as a personal attack in his ‚Äú get richer" culture.

 For the next 5-10 minutes, this guy just goes in on me (pause).

 ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been making the same amount of money for two fucking years!‚Äù

 I honestly don‚Äôt remember much else of what he said because I think my brain categorized this as a traumatic event.

 But I know it was all out of love.

 Or maybe disgust.

 Afterwards, he messaged me and said:

 ‚ÄúSend me the reasons you‚Äôd want the revenue to grow. You‚Äôre sold on current reasons to stay where you‚Äôre at for perspective to reflect on.‚Äù

 I started thinking.

 ‚ÄúWhat would I actually do with 3x the money?‚Äù I considered.

 I made a list.

 The first things on there were superficial lifestyle upgrades.

 Second were long term investing goals.

 And third were more personal desires.

 I sent them to Jeremy and he replied, ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt see a lift in productivity and revenue, you‚Äôll know you don‚Äôt care about these things listed.‚Äù

 Over the following three months, I‚Äôve kept this list top of mind.

 My income has grown, I‚Äôve seized new opportunities, and have felt more in control.

 So {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "friend" }}, I encourage you to ask yourself the same question‚Ä¶

 Why do you want to make more money?

 Get crystal clear on this and write down a list.

 These reasons should provoke emotion when you think about them.

 And next time you don‚Äôt feel like doing something you know you should, take a look at that list.

 There‚Äôs the advice I had to get yelled at for.

 If you want more lessons from me that I learned the hard way‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã Join me here. ‚Äã

 Happy Money Monday,

 Ben

subject: The 3 phase path to six-figure months
body:
One of my first clients texted me the other day.

 It reminded me just how far things have come‚Ä¶

 He said: ‚ÄúHey brother, hope you are great. Just sending a message your way to say how cool it is seeing you grow. You‚Äôre crushing it.‚Äù

 This was from Mike, a basketball shooting coach who I worked with a few years ago.

 He was one of my first few info clients.

 I built a low ticket ascension funnel for him in March, 2022 and ran ads for a handful of months after that.

 That was a pivotal era in my journey.

 I‚Äôd begun dropping my local business clients and replacing them with info guys.

 At the start of that year, I had 14 local clients and somehow only made $10k in January.

 By June, I had five info clients and made $16k.

 Three of my clients were the top personal brands in online basketball training.

 Another was a YouTuber with over 500k subs who I used to be a fan of.

 And the last was one of my best friends at the time, selling a high ticket sales coaching offer.

 This was phase one of my info business.

 I‚Äôll refer to it as the ‚Äúfreelancer model.‚Äù

 I hadn't really tapped into rev shares yet, but I was charging higher prices.

 I‚Äôd offer anything copy related ‚Äì emails, ads, funnels, and VSL‚Äôs.

 By October 2022, I got to $28k/mo this way.

 But two months later, I found an even better model and entered phase two‚Ä¶

 The ‚Äúpartner model.‚Äù

 This is where I went all in on rev shares.

 Because of that, my biggest client in December 2022 paid me $12,900.

 In total, I made $31k that month with just six clients.

 Check out what happened next:

 ‚Äã This new partner model got me as high as $124k profit in one month by the end of 2023.

 I‚Äôd have 5-8 clients at a time, who I‚Äôd typically become friends with.

 Using this model, I‚Äôd make between $80k-$120k/mo for the following 12 months.

 Since then, I‚Äôve entered phase 3 which I‚Äôll call the ‚Äúowner model.‚Äù

 Although I still have a few partner clients ‚Äì I‚Äôve built my own offer in Artisan Lab and have majority share in a couple other offers.

 This seems to be a common progression.

 You start off by offering anything you can ‚Äì prove that you can be trusted to not run away after someone gives you money. 

 Once you do that, you gain confidence in your skillset and start getting a piece of the pie.

 You now have a handful of clients on 10-30% rev shares.

 This alone can get you to $100k/mo+ as it has for me and many members in AL.

 I‚Äôm not saying this is the only path.

 But if you‚Äôre trying to escape the client hamster wheel and build something meaningful‚Ä¶

 This is the one I‚Äôd bet on.

 Start by doing great work for cheap Build real skill and trust Shift into higher-paying, higher-leverage partnerships Eventually own the assets yourself Three years ago, I was charging as low as $1k/mo to write emails for clients.

 Now I‚Äôve had clients happily send $50k wires.

 If you don‚Äôt wanna wait three years to figure this out the hard way‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã Join me here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Play fast, but not in a hurry
body:
Money flows to those who deserve it.

 If you‚Äôre not making as much as you want, it‚Äôs NOT because you‚Äôre missing a strategy.

 A better business model isn‚Äôt the solution.

 A new outreach script won‚Äôt save you.

 And whatever excuse you‚Äôre coming up with is pure cope.

 I shouldn‚Äôt be telling you this.

 Instead I should tell you that if you‚Äôre not making the money you want, it‚Äôs not your fault‚Ä¶

 You just need a better system.

 You‚Äôve been lied to by the gurus, school system, society, blah blah blah.

 To be fair ‚Äì maybe 10% of the people reading this are actually in a bad vehicle and need to switch.

 But for the other 90%, I‚Äôll hold your hand when I say this‚Ä¶

 You. Are. The. Problem.

 I‚Äôm sorry to burst your bubble, but the reason your life sucks is not because of the people who run Hollywood.

 It‚Äôs because you have a skill deficiency.

 No replies to outreach? Skill issue.

 No views on your content? Skill issue.

 Women run away from you? Skill issue.

 I know I‚Äôm being harsh here and I empathize with you if you‚Äôre in the trenches right now.

 But when you take full ownership and fix your skill gap‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôll notice something strange start to happen ‚Äì because skill isn‚Äôt the only variable.

 There‚Äôs an invisible element that amplifies or blocks your results.

 It‚Äôs your energy and your intention.

 People can just feel it.

 Let‚Äôs use outreach as an example.

 I‚Äôve seen people come into Artisan Lab and get clients in their first week.

 Others seem to struggle for months.

 The interesting part is they‚Äôre using the same outreach strategies.

 Why does Person A send 10 outbound messages and get 3 clients when Person B sends 30 and gets 0 replies?

 Intention.

 People can tell whether you‚Äôre moving from confidence or desperation.

 When you‚Äôre desperate, they can smell it through the screen.

 You try to rush the process‚Ä¶

 You get angry when people don‚Äôt reply.

 You get bitter when you see others win.

 I had a basketball coach who‚Äôd always say ‚Äúplay fast, but not in a hurry.‚Äù

 When you hurry, you get sloppy.

 You forget about the details.

 You try to run too fast and trip over your feet.

 Business is no different.

 Desperation makes the Universe say‚Ä¶ ‚Äúnah, you‚Äôre not ready yet.‚Äù

 Move with speed. But don‚Äôt rush.

 Your time is coming, you just have to stop scaring the money Gods.

 If you're ready, I can help you here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Exclusive invitation for {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "you" }}
body:
On October 16th, 2022 I got a $5,000 payment that changed my life.

 Not because of the money, but what happened after.

 I had this client who was paying me $2k-$3k/mo for emails and funnel copy.

 After working together for a few months, I started to consider how else I could help the business grow.

 That‚Äôs when I stumbled upon this book called One To Many. 

 It‚Äôs written by a guy named Jason Fladlien ‚Äì many refer to him as the ‚ÄúWebinar Goat‚Äù (like Bonnie Blue but for virtual events).

 Here‚Äôs what I learned:

 Why sell to only one person at a time, when you can run a live event and sell to many people?

 Good point, Jason.

 So I followed his framework, added in my own sauce and sold my client on running a webinar.

 I spent a few days putting everything together.

 We promoted it through organic content for a week.

 And we ended up with around 2,000 registrants by the time of the webby.

 It's Thursday night, 7pm EST.

 Close to a thousand people show up.

 The training goes well.

 But then, we get to the end.

 This is the part where we say‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúHey, hope you enjoyed all the free game we just gave you. If you want more coaching, here‚Äôs an offer.‚Äù

 We pitch‚Ä¶ and nobody buys.

 I‚Äôm thinking, ‚Äúdid Jason Fladlien lie to me? Does this shit not actually work?‚Äù

 And then I see a few messages in the chat.

 ‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt let me buy.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúIt says purchase invalid.‚Äù

 I test a payment myself. It doesn‚Äôt work.

 After sending a threat to Russel Brunson and his family, I replace our Clickfunnels link with a direct checkout Stripe link.

 The money starts coming in.

 $5k‚Ä¶$10k‚Ä¶$20k‚Ä¶$40k.

 It just spawned out of thin air.

 That‚Äôs when I knew I stumbled into something special.

 We started running weekly webinars.

 I pulled the strings on the backend, and my client put on a show each week.

 Although I only had a 10% rev share, I made $12,900 from that one client in December 2022.

 That‚Äôs when it clicked.

 Why would I try to get a bunch of clients, when I can focus on scaling with a few?

 Since then, I‚Äôve built webinar funnels that generated up to $600k in a week and got me paid handsomely from my rev share.

 Not because I‚Äôm special‚Ä¶

 But because I found a system that works.

 This Wednesday (July 23) at 7pm EST, I‚Äôll be showing you that system‚Ä¶

 On a free live webinar :)

 ‚Äã How To Make $20,000+/Month From ONE Client Using AI Operating. ‚Äã

 If you want to escape retainers and start earning rev share by printing money for personal brands‚Ä¶

 Sign up here: https://go.benbader.com/register ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Dr. GPT diagnosed me with a serious condition...
body:
Today is one of those days.

 I‚Äôve been looking at this screen for 20 minutes.

 I typed a few words five minutes ago, but deleted them.

 Since I don‚Äôt have anything to talk about yet, I‚Äôll remind you to sign up for my free live webinar if you haven‚Äôt already.

 Now back to our regularly scheduled programming‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôm four days Zyn free.

 I kept seeing people online talk about how much better their life has gotten since they quit.

 So I considered it a sign from the Universe‚Ä¶

 Or maybe it‚Äôs just the Chinese social media algorithm fooling me into being less powerful.

 But I figured what the hell, I‚Äôll try it out.

 I‚Äôve been a semi-regular user of these little nicotine pouches for about two years.

 I‚Äôd typically take 3-5 a day, which is light compared to most Zyners.

 So I assumed quitting would be easy.

 I was wrong.

 Over the last few days, I‚Äôve been irritable, sluggish, and weirdly indifferent to everything.

 At first, I thought it was just a temporary lull.

 But then I asked my doctor (Chat GPT) about common nicotine withdrawal symptoms.

 And Dr. GPT told me I‚Äôm experiencing them.

 So here I am, struggling through this email, zynless.

 I‚Äôve got no punchline for you today.

 The only reason I‚Äôm continuing this little experiment is because of data.

 Allegedly, symptoms peak in the first 3-5 days.

 Then, after a month or so, your dopamine starts to recalibrate and you return to ‚Äúnormal‚Äù ‚Äì but better.

 I wanna see if that‚Äôs true.

 I also want to see if I can still write a decent email when I‚Äôm brain-fogged and mildly homicidal.

 Anyway, I‚Äôll leave you with this:

 Most people quit hard things right before it starts to get easier.

 Sometimes you just need a little faith in the data.

 See you on the webinar. ‚Äã

 Zynlessly yours,

 Ben

subject: Stop picturing your dream life
body:
Happy Monday, let‚Äôs make some money this week.

 We‚Äôre only 2 days away from this (and it should help you do the above).

 See you there.

 Anyway, we‚Äôre gonna try an exercise today.

 Yes, you and I are gonna exercise in this email.

 Let‚Äôs begin:

 Everyone tells you to picture your dream life.

 Imagine‚Ä¶

 You wake up in Bali.

 You‚Äôre surrounded by nature.

 The random chick you brought home last night didn‚Äôt steal your Rolex.

 And you‚Äôre working a few hours a day from your laptop. 

 What a life.

 This type of visualization is sexy.

 And it works ‚Äì to an extent. 

 But sometimes, you need the opposite motivation.

 Instead of chasing pleasure, let's run away from pain.

 Imagine it doesn‚Äôt work out.

 You never actually put your all into it.

 You blame the gurus, your Mom, and big pharma.

 You try to convince yourself that the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù life isn‚Äôt that bad.

 And to be fair, it‚Äôs not.

 A Corolla will still get you from point A to point B.

 You‚Äôll pretend to be in love with the girl you felt pressured to marry because you were getting older.

 And every day will be predictable.

 Clock in, clock out. Get a beer after work.

 Roll your eyes when you see young people on social media driving supercars.

 Tell yourself, ‚ÄúThey aren‚Äôt happy! They‚Äôre victims of materialism and capitalism.‚Äù

 Maybe you‚Äôre right, maybe you‚Äôre coping. Doesn‚Äôt really matter.

 At the end of the day, this isn‚Äôt a bad life.

 But if you‚Äôre wired like me, you know it would drive you insane.

 The question ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù would always linger.

 You‚Äôll avoid looking at yourself in the mirror because you don‚Äôt want to face it.

 You knew you wanted more, but you got really good at pretending you didn‚Äôt.

 And even if on the outside it doesn‚Äôt look that bad‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôll be miserable knowing you settled.

 Is that the life you want?

 I doubt it.

 I know that wasn‚Äôt as fun as visualizing a supercar and supermodel.

 But sometimes you need a harder push.

 If you want to give yourself a shot at the other life (the one you actually want)...

 I‚Äôll see you Wednesday at 7pm EST. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: I work at McDonalds.
body:
Quick one for you today.

 I'm looking out the window at a McDonald's down the street from me.

 Chat GPT told me that the average franchise owner makes between $150k-$460k in annual profit per location.

 Maybe putting fries in the bag actually does work?

 I recently hit the 1 year mark with a client.

 Over the past 13 months, he's paid me $245k.

 And today I realized I'm basically a McDonald's franchise owner.

 Here's how the franchise model works...

 McDonald's (obviously) has the brand, systems, and shitty burgers.

 The franchise owner comes in with capital and ops skills.

 He leverages the McDonald's brand and executes their proven system locally.

 And based on his cut, he keeps 6-15% of gross sales at the end of each year.

 The franchise owner didn't have to build anything from zero.

 He just used a proven system and ran it properly.

 Which is exactly what I do with my clients‚Ä¶

 They have the audience, I install the systems.

 ‚Äã Tomorrow at 7pm EST, I‚Äôll show you how to put the fires in the bag (basically).

 This is the exact model I‚Äôve used to make hundreds of thousands from a single client - without using my own audience, running a big team, or becoming a virgin agency owner.

 ‚Äã Sign up here if you‚Äôre not already.

 And I‚Äôll see you tomorrow.

 Extra fries please,

 Ben

subject: This won‚Äôt change your life
body:
I just swatted a mosquito.

 Little buddy was buzzing around in front of my computer.

 A split second later, he got evaporated by my hand and never saw it coming.

 Sorry bro.

 Speaking of heroic acts, the AI Operating Masterclass is tonight at 7pm EST.

 ‚Äã Here‚Äôs your last chance to register. ‚Äã

 I woke up in a good mood today, so I‚Äôm also giving away an hour-long outreach workshop to everyone who attends (for free).

 Anyway, tonight's webinar won‚Äôt change your life.

 90% of you will do absolutely nothing with the information I give you.

 After the class, you‚Äôll think to yourself‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúWow this is really cool! I‚Äôm gonna follow the proven roadmap Ben just laid out for me.‚Äù

 Maybe you‚Äôll try it for a week.

 The emotional high will wear off.

 And you‚Äôll start thinking ‚ÄúI should start an AI OF Agency instead!‚Äù

 The cycle continues.

 I don‚Äôt mean to be a doomer here but that‚Äôs just how it goes.

 But for you, {{ subscriber.first_name }} it could be different.

 You could be one of the few people who make tonight the domino that knocks over the following 20.

 I‚Äôve seen it happen live.

 As I‚Äôve told you the story about Philip (the kid who Venmo‚Äôd me a dollar and got $1k back), a part I left out is this‚Ä¶

 A few weeks after that happened, I told him to join a webinar one of my clients was hosting.

 It was on high ticket sales.

 At the end, when my client pitched his offer, Phillip facetimed me in a panic.

 He couldn‚Äôt decide whether or not he wanted to do it.

 I listened to him contemplate and gave him some words of encouragement.

 But ultimately, it was up to him.

 He decided to pull the trigger.

 And you know how the rest of that story goes.

subject: I almost canceled the webinar
body:
I have a confession‚Ä¶

 I almost canceled yesterday's webinar.

 On Tuesday (the day before), I mentally constructed an excuse I‚Äôd potentially send out on Wednesday.

 I‚Äôd either say I had food poisoning, or ‚ÄúCOVID‚Äù and reschedule it.

 Food poisoning is my go-to if I ever need to get out of a big commitment.

 You can‚Äôt really argue with it because it‚Äôs so horrible and gross.

 ‚ÄúBabe, why did you miss our wedding!‚Äù

 ‚ÄúSorry bitch I had food poisoning.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúOh, my bad honey, I hope you feel better.‚Äù

 You see?

 It‚Äôs truly undefeated.

 Anyway, I obviously didn‚Äôt cancel it and I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt.

 I contemplated doing so because the day before, I was going through it.

 I think I slept on my neck wrong. It tensed up and I had a tension headache all day.

 Plus I was stressed because I‚Äôd been procrastinating my webinar presentation.

 Tuesday was supposed to be the day I‚Äôd finally get it done.

 But looking at the computer screen hurt my eyes.

 So instead of doing anything productive, I laid on the floor for the majority of the day.

 When webby day rolled around, I had 10% of my slides ready.

 Plus I still had to set up all the automations, reminders, etc.

 Fuck me.

 But I powered through it.

 I got up at 5am, put on David Goggins playlist and got everything done by 9am.

 Just kidding, lol.

 I woke up around 8, and leisurely got ready.

 Still I procrastinated the slides, and started with the backend tasks that needed to be set up.

 Around 1pm (6 hours before I went live) I opened my Google Presentation.

 The good news was I had 27 slides already completed.

 The bad news was that I ended up with 284 slides.

 But I started cooking.

 I recently saw a video of Hunter Biden explaining what it‚Äôs like to be on crack ‚Äì and now I fully understand it.

 Although I wasn‚Äôt on crack (to be clear), I was hearing colors and seeing sounds.

 The words for each slide came to me effortlessly.

 By 6:30pm EST (30 minutes before) I‚Äôd finished 90%.

 The pitch was the only thing I didn‚Äôt finish because I wanted to quickly review the training.

 So I said ‚Äúfuck it‚Äù and just winged the pitch.

 And today, I‚Äôm really glad I didn‚Äôt cancel it.

 I had a great time, people seemed to love it, and hopefully we‚Äôll get many new Artisan Lab members and change a lot of lives.

 If you were there, thanks for coming.

 If you weren‚Äôt, I‚Äôll run it back at some point down the line because I‚Äôm now addicted to crack.

 Either way, you can get rich with me here. ‚Äã

 Later,

 Ben

 P.S. If you registered and weren't able to attend, I have a present for you.

 A bunch of Europeans DM‚Äôd me and said they were busy smoking cigarettes and bumping house music since it was 1am in Ibiza.

 Look out for an email from me shortly titled ‚ÄúSince you flaked.‚Äù

subject: I got punched in the face (again)
body:
In yesterday's email, we talked about procrastination.

 I told you how I waited until the last minute to make slides for Wednesday's webinar.

 But what I didn‚Äôt tell you about were the three months of procrastination before that.

 In April, I decided I‚Äôd start running webinars.

 I told myself I‚Äôll get it set up ‚Äúsometime in the near future.‚Äù

 Those five words signify something that‚Äôll never happen.

 There‚Äôs some 63 year old out there still waiting to start his SMMA after seeing a Tai Lopez ad ten years ago.

 ‚ÄúSometime in the near future,‚Äù he continues to say.

 Whenever I catch myself continually delaying an action, I eventually reach a breaking point.

 I figuratively punch myself in the face for being an idiot.

 And then I start moving.

 Exactly two weeks ago today, I reached that point.

 I was on my morning walk to get coffee and I opened a newsletter email from a mentor of mine, Taylor Allan.

 He wrote about ‚Äúbiting off more than you can chew‚Äù and forcing yourself to figure it out.

 You‚Äôll quickly realize you‚Äôre capable of more than you thought.

 And at the end of the email, he gave some examples.

 One of which, was:

 ‚ÄúOrganize a launch before you‚Äôve built the product ‚Äî with a date, a sales page, and people expecting delivery ‚Äî and you will find a way to build it in time.‚Äù

 That clicked.

 When I got home from the coffee shop, I picked the date for the webinar.

 Two days later I had the sign up page, backend set up, and promo videos ready.

 I started promoting it a week out.

 And finally‚Ä¶

 I forced myself to build the presentation (at the very last minute).

 So I guess this is my attempt to do for you, what Taylor‚Äôs email did for me.

 Here are a few ideas for you:

 - Start doing outreach and book a sales call before you know how to fulfill.

 - Make a reservation for two at the nicest restaurant in your city tonight and find a 10 to go with you.

 - Buy a plane ticket and book a trip somewhere you‚Äôve been wanting to go.

 - Apply for Artisan Lab, and you‚Äôll feel the pressure to 10x your investment :)

 Hope this motivates you to get moving.

 If not, there‚Äôs always next year.

 Have a good weekend,

 Ben

body:

 ‚ÄúYour life will become a perpetual cycle of "almost." 

 You'll almost start a business. 

 You'll almost approach the pretty girl.

subject: (Tutorial) How to buy a Ferrari 488 Pista
body:
Good morning.

 Yesterday I decided I want a Ferrari 488 Pista.

 I‚Äôd been trying to convince myself to want a McLaren 720s, but they just look plasticy to me.

 The only problem is, Pistas are around $600k.

 That‚Äôs about double what I‚Äôd be comfortable spending right now.

 So‚Ä¶ I have to make more money.

 After this material awakening, I began thinking about how to do that.

 There are three ways to grow any high ticket service or coaching business:

 1. Increase traffic

 2. Increase conversions

 3. Increase LTV

 At first, traffic is the most important ‚Äì without it, you don‚Äôt have a business.

 But conversions and LTV start to matter more once traffic is flowing.

 I recently helped a client launch from scratch.

 He started posting short form content a few months ago and quickly gained traction.

 We threw together a lead magnet, captured emails and nurtured them through the list.

 About 60 days ago, we started selling.

 Prospects go through a short VSL, fill out an application, and book with our sales team.

 We‚Äôre making some money, but our conversion rate sucks.

 The leads are low intent, low trust, and just don‚Äôt seem to care enough about what we‚Äôre selling.

 This is a good problem to have because it‚Äôs fairly easy to solve.

 Maybe the way we position the offer isn‚Äôt resonating.

 Maybe we‚Äôre selling to the wrong type of people.

 Maybe we simply need to bombard prospects with way more proof.

 Fixing this is just a matter of tests and tweaks. Here‚Äôs a few I‚Äôm exploring:

 ‚Äì Adjusting the pitch

 ‚Äì Adding more proof to the funnel

 ‚Äì Increasing touch points pre-call

 ‚Äì Swapping to a webinar

 ‚Äì Revising our DM setting flow

 My job as a marketer/operator is to fuck with all of the above until numbers improve.

 Once they do, we can allocate more attention and focus to the other two buckets.

 To get more traffic, run ads and/or make more content.

 To increase LTV, sell more expensive shit.

 It‚Äôs quite simple.

 If you see me post in a 488 Pista in the next few months, you‚Äôll know I found the solution.

 If you don‚Äôt, I‚Äôm getting there.

 ‚Äã Go here if you want my help in building and/or scaling your info agency.

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: I stole this $100M man's business...
body:
Everyone is a liar.

 I was browsing through YouTube yesterday and saw three different videos all titled a variation of:

 ‚ÄúHow I made $X Million selling digital products.‚Äù

 Interesting‚Ä¶

 I could‚Äôve sworn you‚Äôd been saying you got rich from dropshipping for the past three years!

 But who am I to judge?

 This shift actually benefits me and my Artisan Lab members immensely.

 Let‚Äôs think about the domino effect this is creating‚Ä¶

 Domino #1: 

 Big personal brands like Alex Hormozi, Iman Gadzhi, and William Brown make content about building a coaching business.

 Domino #2: 

 More people want to build coaching businesses.

 Domino #3: 

 Everyone copies the industry leaders, now everyone and their mother is a coach.

 And finally‚Ä¶

 Domino #4: 

 There are too many coaches and not enough operators.

 Backend services are needed more than ever and there are plenty of good clients to go around.

 I guess Domino #5 is Ferrari having to make more cars because me and everyone else who capitalizes on this buys up the inventory.

 (Legally I cannot promise you a Ferrari or even a Civic for that matter). 

 But to be clear ‚Äì we're already on Domino #4.

 And it‚Äôs only gonna get better.

 What do you think all of the successful coaches will do if/when their current offer dries up?

 ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs how I made $10m selling digital products over the past two years!‚Äù

 The cycle continues.

 It‚Äôs like being an NBA agent.

 As the league grows and players get paid more, so do agents.

 Rich Paul (Lebron's agent and founder of Klutch) is worth over $100m.

 He doesn‚Äôt need to drop 30 every night, he just helps the guys that do.

 They have the spotlight, the attention, and the leverage‚Ä¶

 He builds the infrastructure behind the scenes ‚Äì negotiates the deals, monetizes the attention, and takes a cut.

 Sounds familiar.

 This is how you win without needing to be the face.

 Unless you‚Äôre 6‚Äô9, 250lbs with a 40 inch vertical‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã Domino #5 is waiting for you,

 Ben

subject: How to break out of slump (Certified Hood Classic)
body:
Today's email is a CHC (Certified Hood Classic) I originally sent in March earlier this year. 

 It was a subscriber favorite -- So if you're in a bit of a slump right now, it might be the catalyst that gets you out of it. 

 Enjoy: 

 ‚Äã 

 A fly was just buzzing around my laptop.

 I swung twice and missed both times.

 This is a rare occurrence.

 If there's a worldwide fly swatting accuracy leaderboard anywhere, I‚Äôd be near the top.

 It‚Äôs a sunny morning in Miami, although it rained all day yesterday so the ground is still wet.

 I have an iced espresso next to me and I‚Äôm ready to work.

 The past couple weeks have been a bit unfocused.

 I got out of my normal routine from traveling and am now getting back into the swing of things.

 You know that feeling when you want to be productive but you‚Äôre being a lazy, unmotivated piece of shit?

 Me too.

 Slumps like this are inevitable and they happen to everyone.

 Even the greatest athletes on the planet go through periods where they can‚Äôt make a shot or get on base.

 Let‚Äôs consider how they get through this‚Ä¶

 A struggling athlete has to become aware of components that are typically subconscious.

 Perhaps they started rushing their follow-through or rotating too much on their swing.

 To correct themselves, they have to be more intentional and disciplined than usual.

 If they can typically get away with lacing up their shoes right before practice, that‚Äôs not gonna fly for now.

 They have to put more time in, identify the error they‚Äôre making and consciously decide to fix it.

 Eventually things go back to normal and it becomes subconscious or easy again.

 Productivity works the same way.

 When you‚Äôre in a slump, the bitch voice in your head is the loudest.

 To shut it out, you‚Äôll likely have to be more disciplined than usual.

 Get up earlier.

 Stop yourself from scrolling on social media.

 Write down a detailed schedule to follow each day.

 Put your phone on DND and stick to the plan.

 Next thing you know, you‚Äôll knock off the rust and feel good about working again.

 This doesn‚Äôt take long unless you let it.

 A member of Artisan Lab recently came to me with this exact problem and I told him the following:

 ‚ÄúMomentum and habits outweigh motivation. Small wins will create bigger ones. You're one productive morning away from a productive day, and one productive day away from a productive week. Just have to get the ball rolling with the small things.‚Äù 

 Soon enough you‚Äôll get back in rhythm.

 The ball will hit your hands and you‚Äôll effortlessly rise up and let it fly.

 Slump over, Lambo coming soon. ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: Zero value in here
body:
Good morning {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 As I write this, I‚Äôm simultaneously watching 22 sales call recordings at once.

 Well, an AI agent is doing that for me.

 He just gave me a comprehensive report.

 It took about 5 minutes.

 The agent began by going through the funnel.

 It read the copy on the VSL page and went through my qualifying questions.

 Then it analyzed the transcripts from all 22 recordings.

 Every lead is categorized by the outcome of the call and common objections are listed clearly.

 Here‚Äôs the conclusion it gave me:

 ‚ÄúYour low close rate is primarily due to lead quality issues, not sales performance. The current VSL messaging attracts unqualified prospects who cannot afford your service. By implementing better qualification processes and targeting higher-quality leads, you should see immediate improvements in close rates and revenue.‚Äù 

 Thank you Agent 0, you just saved me 22 hours of my life and gave me this cool graph:

 ‚Äã You might be thinking ‚ÄúWow Ben, this is incredible. You‚Äôre a wizard with AI!‚Äù

 Not really.

 I just found a tool that made the above process incredibly simple.

 ‚ÄúOh, what‚Äôs the tool called??‚Äù you say, with drool coming from your mouth.

 It‚Äôs called [redacted].

 Hahahaha.

 You haven‚Äôt paid me a dollar and you think I‚Äôd just tell you?

 ‚ÄúBut Ben, you should give free value to your audience!‚Äù

 Fuck off.

 I found this tool because it was mentioned by someone in a mastermind I‚Äôm in.

 It costs $24,000/year.

 I‚Äôm gonna normalize gatekeeping.

 Hormozi convinced everyone to ‚Äúgive it all away for free.‚Äù

 That‚Äôs a lie.

 Do you really think that roided man is telling you everything he knows about business?

 All of the (likely) grey-black hat tactics that he‚Äôs actually using?

 No.

 He gives you a sliver.

 You only get the real sauce when you pay.

 And even if someone gives you good info for free, it‚Äôs worth less because you don‚Äôt value it.

 I know this is convenient for me to say‚Ä¶

 But if you have some money and you‚Äôre not spending it to buy information and access‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôre retarded.

 Stop being retarded and buy this now you monkey. ‚Äã

 Bye,

 Ben

subject: I need to apologize
body:
In yesterday's email I insulted you.

 Today, I want to apologize.

 I shouldn‚Äôt have said ‚Äústop being retarded and buy this now you monkey.‚Äù 

 Instead, I should‚Äôve called you a buffoon.

 Because only a buffoon wouldn‚Äôt spend money to expedite their journey.

 And yesterday, I realized I‚Äôve been doing just that.

 For the last month, my upper back‚Äôs been constantly tight.

 Most days it‚Äôs manageable until I move wrong or piss it off.

 Then it spazzes.

 If you‚Äôve had back spasms, you know how much this sucks.

 Imagine Lizzo sitting on your back.

 Then multiply her by four and give her a knife.

 Shit hurts.

 I went to a physical therapist a month ago.

 He gave me a bunch of stretches and exercises to do.

 I‚Äôve done them maybe twice.

 I figured I‚Äôd just take a break from physical activity, get a massage, and my back would fix itself.

 That‚Äôs where I went wrong.

 Real problems don‚Äôt fix themselves.

 You‚Äôre not gonna wake up one day and magically be healed from poverty.

 You have to actively pursue the solution. 

 When I realized my hypocrisy around back pain, I got fed up with myself and started acting.

 I booked another session with the PT.

 Then I went on Amazon and ordered the most expensive massage table I could find.

 I‚Äôd been telling myself that I didn‚Äôt have space to do the exercises.

 So I‚Äôm gonna remove that scapegoat and put the table next to my bed.

 Here‚Äôs the deeper lesson:

 I‚Äôm creating a catalyst for change.

 I didn‚Äôt need a $500 massage table.

 I don‚Äôt need to spend $300 to have the PT come to my house when there‚Äôs one across the street for $50.

 But I know myself.

 And I know I won‚Äôt do shit unless I‚Ä¶

 1. Spend a little bit of money

 2. Am constantly reminded (the table is a visual cue)

 3. Make it convenient and enjoyable

 Getting rich works the same way.

 In college I‚Äôd write goals and affirmations on sticky notes and place them around my room.

 Every time I walked into my bathroom I‚Äôd see ‚Äúyou are who you think you are.‚Äù

 Every time I sat at my desk I‚Äôd see ‚ÄúBen made $10,000 this month.‚Äù

 I spent almost all the money I had on a coaching program.

 I created a ritual where I‚Äôd light a candle, put on music, and make myself this yogurt bowl when I sat down to work at night.

 I forced myself to do it. And I made it as enjoyable as possible.

 I‚Äôm writing to you from a penthouse in Miami because of this.

 I have liquid 7 figures because of this.

 The car I‚Äôve wanted since I was 10 years old is in the garage because of this.

 I‚Äôm not bragging.

 But I‚Äôm imploring you that success is no accident.

 Wake up.

 Your problems will never fix themselves.

 You‚Äôre too comfortable at your current standards.

 You tell yourself you want to change but you do nothing about it.

 When are you gonna put your foot down and act, you buffoon!

 Don‚Äôt wait until it‚Äôs too late.

 Love you,

 Ben

subject: The most terrifying thing I've ever done...
body:
It‚Äôs only scary the first time you do it.

 That applies to most things in life.

 The first time you jumped off a diving board, it was nerve-wrecking.

 The first time you got in the driver's seat of a car, you were terrified.

 The first girl that let you‚Ä¶ never mind.

 You get the point.

 The other day I spent $15k to renew a mastermind I‚Äôm in.

 I paid the invoice as if I were paying for a coffee and forgot about it 5 minutes after.

 There were absolutely zero nerves involved.

 But if I rewind a few years, I vividly remember the fear I had when making an investment in myself.

 I was on a sales call for this SMMA coaching program.

 The closer‚Äôs name was Kyle.

 Going into it, I was prepared to spend about $2k.

 Everything sounded good, we got to the pitch and he said the price‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúFive thousand dollars.‚Äù

 Fuck me.

 I could instantly feel the internal pressure.

 I began physically squirming in the gaming chair at my desk in my college dorm room.

 After a long pause and some incoherent sounds of nervousness coming from my mouth, I said‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúUhhhh‚Ä¶ I know you probably get this objection all the time but uhhh‚Ä¶ 

 Can I like take a day or two and think about it?‚Äù 

 Kyle smiled knowing he was about to aikido the fuck out of my stupid little objection.

 He replied by asking me what I liked about the offer.

 I began selling myself.

 ‚ÄúWell this sounds really good because of the support and I need to learn this‚Ä¶‚Äù blah blah.

 Once I finished, he gave me a basketball analogy because I‚Äôd told him earlier that I grew up a hooper.

 I was cooked.

 The analogy ended with him asking me ‚Äúdebit or credit?‚Äù

 I pulled out my card and spent $5,000.

 The next few days were a mix of ‚Äúthis is awesome, I‚Äôm finally taking action to change my life,‚Äù and ‚Äúwhat did I just do, I‚Äôm an idiot.‚Äù

 I wish I could tell you it was smooth sailing to $10k/mo after that‚Ä¶

 But I got distracted (again), started chasing another business model, and wasted a month.

 Eventually I locked in and hit $10k/month six months later.

 After 4 years and six figures invested in coaching, now I‚Äôm here.

 This is such a perfect time for me to segue into why you should invest in Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 But I‚Äôm gonna ruin it.

 If you‚Äôre scared, don‚Äôt do it.

 Listen to that fear.

 Let it control your life.

 Don‚Äôt approach the pretty girl.

 Don‚Äôt post content on social media.

 Don‚Äôt send outreach messages.

 Live a life of quiet misery because you don‚Äôt have the balls to bet on yourself.

 Or do the opposite and see where it takes you. It‚Äôs all up to you.

 Happy Monday,

 Ben

subject: The DNA of a winner
body:
Most people are losers.

 I‚Äôm not trying to be mean‚Ä¶well, maybe I am.

 But this is a simple fact.

 They don‚Äôt know how roundabouts work.

 They stand in the middle of crowded doorways.

 And they don‚Äôt have TSA pre-check. (That one is a bit of a stretch, but seriously if you live in the US and travel at all, why the fuck would you not have pre-check?) 

 If you‚Äôre reading this, I‚Äôm gonna assume you‚Äôre not a loser.

 You likely wouldn‚Äôt enjoy my emails if you were.

 I once let a loser into Artisan Lab by accident, as you may remember.

 He immediately sensed he was out of his jurisdiction and ejected himself back to Normieville.

 The simple, winner DNA that he didn‚Äôt have is this:

 Winners just do things.

 They hear that same voice that the losers have.

 It says‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where to start!‚Äù

 ‚ÄúHow will I get a client if I don‚Äôt have any case studies?‚Äù

 ‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôm gay in over my head.‚Äù

 They choose to not listen to these thoughts.

 They use their best judgment to move in somewhat of a positive direction.

 And they allow the Universe to naturally redirect them if there‚Äôs a better route.

 That‚Äôs it.

 ‚ÄúThe real utility of thinking is knowing what thoughts you shouldn‚Äôt listen to.‚Äù - Brute

 Stop talking yourself out of it.

 Contemplation isn‚Äôt progress.

 You don‚Äôt need to ‚Äúthink about it‚Äù or talk to your wife (cuck).

 You need to decide, commit, and act.

 Only then will you escape Normieville.

 Just like these winners have...

 Elijah just hit his second consecutive $20k month (he made $2k the month before he joined AL 6 months ago):

 ‚Äã James helped a client make $121k... In an hour and a half. I actually gave him this client a few months ago and now he'll make 5 figures from his rev share:

 ‚Äã Oh shit. I almost forgot about Yahya. He made his client the equivalent of a 2024 Porsche GT3RS... in a few days. He will make more money from his rev share than the average American does in one year:

 ‚Äã Sorry, I didn't mean to start bragging so much here but I forgot how hard the people of Artisan Lab are winning.

 I can't promise you results like the people above.

 But I can promise you that if you do nothing, you will stay where you are now.

 And if you don't like where you are now, I'd advise against doing nothing.

 So maybe... do something. ‚Äã

 The winning team is waiting,

 Ben

subject: I got a 9-5 j*b
body:
I‚Äôm in a hurry.

 I woke up to the alarm sound ‚Äúchimes‚Äù blaring next to me.

 I closed my eyes for an extra 15 seconds before rolling out of bed.

 I‚Äôd regret that 15 second nap later, but I didn‚Äôt know that yet.

 I showered, threw on my only non-wrinkled button down, and hopped on my scooter.

 It was 8:47am.

 That meant I had 13 minutes to get to the office.

 Which meant if I was late again, I probably wouldn‚Äôt get the promotion I‚Äôd been hoping for.

 I weaved through traffic on my scooter.

 Some kid in a Porsche yelled ‚Äúwagie cuck‚Äù out the window at me.

 Asshole.

 I looked down to check my Apple watch.

 At this pace, I‚Äôd get to the office at 8:58am.

 But as I approached the bridge to get downtown, I heard the sound of horror.

 There was a bell.

 This bell indicated the bridge was about to go up.

 If I didn‚Äôt get there in time, I‚Äôd surely be late.

 I went as fast as my scooter could go.

 My water bottle fell from the side pocket of my backpack and I didn‚Äôt even try to stop to pick it up.

 But five seconds before I got to the gate, it closed.

 Shit.

 If only I didn‚Äôt waste 15 seconds before getting up earlier.

 Alright, back to reality ‚Äì luckily that was a fictitious story.

 It‚Äôs what I imagine an average morning in my life would look like had I stayed on the path.

 And to me, that sounds like a horror film.

 I hate scooters.

 I hate the alarm clock sound ‚Äúchimes.‚Äù

 I hate Apple watches.

 And most of all, I hate rushing.

 That‚Äôs hypocritical of me because I still feel like I‚Äôm always rushing but at least now it‚Äôs on my own clock.

 The life above is exactly what I wanted to avoid.

 I successfully did so, and can tell you with full certainty‚Ä¶

 Even though it isn‚Äôt a perfect utopia, absent of problems ‚Äì it‚Äôs way better than having to say ‚Äúsorry I‚Äôm late boss.‚Äù

 (Plus you get to be the asshole in a Porsche calling someone else a wagie cuck.)

 It‚Äôs cooler on this side.

 ‚Äã Join me here ‚Äì or remember to iron a new button down for tomorrow.

 See ya after work,

 Ben

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "you" }} <> Baker Mayfield
body:
Today we‚Äôre talking about Baker Mayfield.

 If you know nothing about American football, you probably think that‚Äôs a shitty restaurant chain you‚Äôd find in a fly over state.

 Let me catch you up:

 Baker Mayfield is an NFL quarterback.

 He was drafted first overall to the Cleveland Browns in 2018.

 In his third year with the team, he led them to their first playoff win in nearly 20 years.

 But the following season was a disappointment.

 He played through an injury, the team fell apart, and they missed the playoffs.

 Then, Cleveland decided to make a bold move.

 They traded a total of six draft picks (including three first rounders) for‚Ä¶ get this‚Ä¶

 A man with 24 counts of sexual assault against him.

 That man also plays quarterback, meaning they‚Äôd given up on Baker.

 Plus they gave Epstein Jr. the largest ‚Äì fully guaranteed ‚Äì contract in NFL history‚Ä¶

 5 years, $230 million.

 Baker requested a trade and they sent him to another dysfunctional franchise, Carolina.

 He spent a year there, got benched and eventually cut from the team.

 After a brief stint as a backup for the Rams, it looked like he might be out of the league soon.

 And then‚Ä¶

 He found a better opportunity.

 He signed with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, led them to the playoffs, and was awarded Most Improved Player. 

 Statistically speaking, he was the 4th best QB in the league last year.

 ‚ÄúBen, why have you written 250 words glazing Baker Mayfield?‚Äù

 Great question, {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "friend" }}.

 Similar to business, Baker just needed the right ‚Äúvehicle‚Äù.

 Despite having the talent and being an incredibly hard worker, he bounced from one shitty situation to the next‚Ä¶

 Until he found the right home for him.

 Similarly, I was once overworked, overqualified and underpaid.

 I was grinding away at my SMMA and just couldn‚Äôt scale.

 Then one day I figured‚Ä¶ What if I just apply my skill set in a way that‚Äôll give me more leverage?

 So I made the pivot to partnering with info-product sellers.

 Four months later, I hit my first $50k month.

 Six months after that, I hit $100k/mo with just seven clients.

 Turns out, I wasn‚Äôt the problem. My business model was.

 The Info Agency model became my loving home.

 More leverage, fewer clients, and rev shares.

 Plus no risk of getting replaced by a freak named Deshuan.

 ‚Äã Here‚Äôs your ticket to a better vehicle. ‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. One of my Artisan Lab members just went through a similar journey.

 Yahya was running a retention agency, making $2-5k/mo when he switched to info.

 He joined AL a little over two months ago.

 Yesterday, he shared this win:

 ‚Äã He‚Äôll make a lot of money from that rev share :)

 ‚Äã You can join him. ‚Äã

subject: Spilled coffee on my laptop
body:
They changed the lids at the coffee shop today.

 I like the new ones better.

 Until now, there was a small hole for the straw with no cover.

 They‚Äôd put a tiny piece of tape over it so it wouldn‚Äôt spill.

 That tape sucked.

 I‚Äôd always try to peel it off with my fingers and could never get it.

 So I‚Äôd end up taking the whole lid off just to push it off from the inside.

 Then one day they gave me an extra coffee.

 I gave it to my friend Mason, who‚Äôs apparently a seasoned veteran in coffee lids.

 The tape was off in two seconds.

 He pushed down the front part of the plastic to create separation and easily took it off.

 Watching him do that changed my life.

 I stole his strategy and have been using it since.

 I‚Äôd been fighting with the lid for months.

 Not because there wasn‚Äôt a better way, but because I never stopped to ask if my way was stupid.

 Turns out it was.

 What a beautiful reminder to continually audit your beliefs.

 Just because something kinda works doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs the best way.

 And the longer you keep using a bad method, the more it screws you over.

 So take a second and ask yourself‚Ä¶

 Is your strategy actually good, or are you only doing it because it‚Äôs not horrible?

 Does your business really have a ceiling, or is that a story you‚Äôve been telling yourself?

 Are you working on the right things, or should you reassess what actions result in the highest ROI?

 Even if you don‚Äôt change anything, asking questions is better than living on autopilot.

 Luckily I won‚Äôt have to deal with that stupid lid anymore.

 They upgraded to the ones that have the foldable plastic flap you can just push backwards.

 Anyway, here‚Äôs a recent video of mine that you might need to hear today.

 Have a good weekend,

 Ben

subject: I'm getting married <3
body:
No one is happy and everyone‚Äôs getting divorced.

 I know that‚Äôs an uplifting thing to hear on this beautiful Monday morning.

 But when you look at the numbers, it‚Äôs true.

 The divorce rate in the US has climbed from around 25% in the 1960s to almost 50% today.

 Compare that to arranged marriages where only about 4% end in divorce.

 Now I‚Äôm not saying we should bring back arranged marriages.

 (I‚Äôd jump off a bridge if one day my parents brought me some chopped shit and said I gotta put a ring on it.) 

 Obviously not all of these marriages are actually happy and there‚Äôs added cultural pressure to stay together.

 But statistically, forcing two people together beats giving them a choice.

 So today, I‚Äôm arranging your marriage.

 I‚Äôve been watching you and to put it simply, you‚Äôre being a whore.

 You‚Äôve jumped from one thing to the next ‚Äì SMMA, sales, AI agency and so on.

 Every time you're about to fully commit, a new bad bitch seduces you.

 She whispers, ‚Äúthis is the best way to make money in 2025, baby.‚Äù

 That‚Äôs your weakness.

 You need to slap her (**HYPOTHETICALLY**).

 Then say, ‚ÄúNo, you harlot! I‚Äôm committed to {insert business model} and you‚Äôre not corrupt my virgin eyes.

 It doesn't matter what business model you insert there, but you‚Äôve gotta commit to her.

 Otherwise you‚Äôll end up contributing to a different statistic‚Ä¶

 85% of people in the US make less than $100k per year.

 If you want to avoid that ‚Äì I just made this video about why most people never actually commit.

 And if you want my guidance‚Ä¶

 By the power vested in me, I now pronounce you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}, and me, Artisan Lab, husband and wife.

 You may kiss the‚Ä¶

 Never mind.

 Let‚Äôs make some money this week,

 Ben

subject: From 0 to $75k/mo in 2 months
body:
A few years ago, I was incredibly ill.

 I couldn‚Äôt focus.

 My mind was constantly chaotic.

 And I was poor.

 I had a common illness.

 You‚Äôve probably suffered from it as well. You might even have it right now.

 It‚Äôs called‚Ä¶

 Shiny object syndrome.

 I regularly talk about avoiding this.

 Yesterday I told you that you need to get an arranged marriage in order to do so.

 But there are some instances where a pivot isn‚Äôt all bad.

 Sometimes the wrong model is holding you back.

 ‚Äã A member of Artisan Lab just proved this ‚Äì he ditched his old agency, made $0 for a bit, then pulled $75k from one client in one month.

 About a year and half into my journey, I did the same.

 I‚Äôd gotten to around $15k/mo with my SMMA.

 I had 15+ clients.

 It was the success I wanted.

 But it fucking sucked.

 I‚Äôd been stuck in the $10k-$15k/mo range for a while.

 My clients would constantly churn, so most of my days were spent doing outreach to replace them.

 I didn‚Äôt enjoy running the business.

 Plus my idiot friends were making more money with less effort‚Ä¶

 Because they were in better vehicles.

 The money and lifestyle I was looking for would be found in scaling info-products.

 I knew that.

 But there was still this inkling of doubt.

 Am I getting shiny object syndrome again or is the vehicle actually the bottleneck?

 My SMMA was my baby.

 It took me out the trenches (my air conditioned college apartment that my parents paid for).

 It made me my first $100k.

 And now I‚Äôm just gonna leave it on the side of the road?

 Yes, I will.

 I pivoted to info and made my first million.

 Well, if only it were that simple‚Ä¶

 I contemplated the decision for months and stayed stuck.

 Then finally, I got a few info clients, realized it was way better, and dropped my local business clients.

 And looking back it‚Äôs clear that the vehicle was the problem.

 But at the time, that was hard to discern.

 Yahya just went through a similar transition.

 Just two months in, he made the equivalent of a souped-up Hellcat‚Ä¶from one client.

 ‚Äã Here‚Äôs a full interview ‚Äì plus how he made his client $622k in 3 days.

 See you over there,

 Ben

subject: How to get your first $10k/month client ASAP
body:
A $9,900 payment changed how I looked at business forever‚Ä¶

 It‚Äôs May 1st, 2022.

 I‚Äôm supposed to move to Miami in a couple months.

 But I have a problem.

 I made $5,168 in April.

 That could barely buy me a coffee in Miami ‚Äì and definitely not a table at LIV.

 What‚Äôs even worse is that I thought I was starting to turn the corner with my SMMA.

 I made $17k the month before.

 Then a bunch of my clients left and I didn't do enough outreach to replace them.

 So here I am, coffee-less, needing to figure something out.

 I‚Äôm gonna go all in on info.

 I begin dropping my remaining SMMA clients and only pitching online coaches 

 And guess what?

 That shit worked!

 In July (four months later) I made $16,290 with just five clients.

 Just two months after that, I moved to Miami and hit $25k/mo with only seven clients.

 But I hadn‚Äôt even discovered the coolest part yet‚Ä¶

 December 1st, 2022 I got this payment:

 ‚Äã $9,900. From one rev share.

 That client also paid me a $3k monthly retainer so I made $12,900 from him alone.

 It was bittersweet.

 I was happy I‚Äôd finally found the method‚Ä¶

 But I was also mad at myself for being an absolute idiot for the previous year.

 Why was I only charging small monthly retainers?

 And why was I working with local businesses?

 Hindsight‚Äôs 20/20 I guess.

 That was my ‚ÄúAHA!‚Äù moment.

 Nine months later I hit $100k/mo and walked into Champion Porsche to buy my dream car.

 One client ‚Äì and one rev share ‚Äì changed my life.

 Here‚Äôs my effort to help you do the same:

 This Wednesday, (August 20th) at 7pm EST I‚Äôm going live.

 I‚Äôll give you everything you need to sign your first $10k/mo client in the next 90 days. ‚Äã

 Once you do that, everything gets easier.

 You can continue to scale.

 Clients start coming to you.

 And you finally feel confident, knowing you‚Äôre in control.

 I‚Äôve watched five(!) new Artisan Lab members hit their first $10k-$75k months from single clients over the past 30 days alone.

 ‚Äã So sign up here and you‚Äôll get the same blueprint they used.

 Ben

 P.S. I just recorded two new interviews that you should check out after you register:

 ‚Äã James went from 0-$14k/mo in 4 months (one client). ‚Äã

 ‚Äã Cetin hit $20k/mo in 3 months (also one client). ‚Äã

subject: Business is like hot wheels (Certified Hood Classic)
body:
Today's email is a CHC (Certified Hood Classic) originally sent Dec 28th, 2024. 

 It might be my most replied-to email of all time. It's a bit unhinged, but a good read. 

 Quick reminder before we get into it -- I'm hosting a free live webinar next Wednesday where I'll give you the exact playbook you need to sign a $10k/mo client. Sign up here. ‚Äã

 Alight, enjoy: 

 I want you to think of business success like a battery powered toy car.

 Imagine you‚Äôre an 8 year old with snot on your face.

 For Christmas, you got a miniature brown Bugatti with a bald action figure sitting in the passenger seat.

 You rip it out of the box and put it on the ground.

 Excitedly, you click the ‚Äúon‚Äù button and‚Ä¶

 Nothing happens.

 You turn it off and on again‚Ä¶

 Nothing.

 And then something clicks inside your little pea brain.

 Batteries!

 Your Bugatti needs 2 double A batteries.

 You run upstairs and say ‚ÄúMom! Get me some fucking double A batteries ASAP no rocky!‚Äù

 To your disappointment, your Mom is hammered.

 She caught your Dad cheating on her with your Uncle so she‚Äôs numbing the pain with two bottles of Ros√©.

 ‚ÄúDammit! She won‚Äôt be able to drive to the store,‚Äù you think to yourself.

 Time to take matters into your own hands.

 You scour the house for batteries, opening the back of every TV remote.

 None of them fit into your car.

 You‚Äôd ask your Dad for help but he‚Äôs upstairs with Uncle Timmy.

 So you decide to hop in his Ford F-150 and drive to the store yourself.

 You can barely see over the steering wheel so you grab a pipe from the garage as an extension to your foot.

 Next thing you know you‚Äôre pulling out of the driveway.

 Luckily you‚Äôve played a lot of GTA.

 By some miracle, you make it to the store, find the batteries, check out, and make it back home.

 Finally you pop the batteries in the bottom of the car and you‚Äôre off to the races.

 Congrats kid.

 Now {{ subscriber.first_name }} you‚Äôre probably thinking...

 ‚ÄúAre you going anywhere with this or are you just telling me a fabricated, alarming story about an unsupervised child due to his alcoholic mother and gay father?‚Äù

 Here‚Äôs how this relates to you and your business success:

 Right now, you‚Äôre that toy Bugatti.

 If you‚Äôre a complete beginner, you have to get batteries before you can start moving.

 Go down Youtube rabbit holes, read books, watch courses, and start practicing your skills.

 The car won‚Äôt start moving yet (you won‚Äôt make any money).

 But you‚Äôre installing the necessary batteries that will allow you to go fast.

 Welcome to the trenches :)

 It‚Äôs impossible to say how much time you‚Äôll spend here, but I can promise you that on the other side is everything you‚Äôve ever wanted.

 Once you get through, you‚Äôll hit the gas. ‚Äã

 And finally, you‚Äôll be rewarded for all of your previously unrewarded effort.

 Just don‚Äôt quit before you even get the batteries.

 Let me know if you read this one,

 Ben

subject: Thank you, Money
body:
Having money is overrated.

 When I was at 0, I thought $5k/mo would solve all my problems.

 When I hit $5k/mo I thought $10k/mo would finally do so.

 Fast forward past $100k/mo, and I have more problems than I ever did before.

 What a scam!

 Every day, I extinguish between 1 and 20 fires in my business.

 I have more problems than I can count and new ones popping up daily.

 There‚Äôs a constant pressure to go faster.

 Need to fix things.

 Need to start new things.

 Need to buy more expensive things because the old things got boring.

 I guess Jay Z was right when he said ‚Äúmore money, more problems.‚Äù

 But ya know what makes it worth it?

 The problems get better.

 The other day, my friends and I decided we wanted to go to the Weeknd concert.

 I texted my ‚Äúticket plug‚Äù and asked if he had any suites left.

 ‚ÄúYep, one more 20 person suite for $7k.‚Äù

 Honestly I was shocked.

 He could‚Äôve told me it was $15k and I would‚Äôve thought it was a steal. 

 Money sent.

 He told me Ubering would be a nightmare and gave me a parking pass.

 The only problem is my 911 Turbo fits two normal sized adults.

 Maybe two vertically challenged ones in the back.

 But we had 12.

 So, my friend Jimmy called the sprinter guy.

 $1k for the night, can fit up to 18 people.

 Money sent.

 We pulled up and were escorted to the ‚ÄúVIP Parking area.‚Äù

 After a two minute walk through security, we were at our private suite.

 Food and drinks were delivered directly to us, and the driver took us to the club after.

 I‚Äôm not telling you this just to brag about how cool my life is.

 More so to explain that one of the best things money does is eliminate inconveniences.

 Without spending $8k to go to that concert, everything would‚Äôve been a headache.

 Ubering, finding the seats, getting food, the noise, the heat, the crowd, etc.

 Instead it was easy.

 Thank you, money.

 The poorer you are, the more decisions money makes for you.

 It decides where you live, what you eat, and what you do.

 But the more money you accumulate, the less power it holds.

 Decisions flip from ‚Äúcan I afford this?‚Äù to ‚Äúwill this make my life easier or better?‚Äù

 If the answer is yes, you send the money.

 It doesn‚Äôt remove all problems, it changes which ones you deal with.

 So {{ subscriber.first_name }}‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs get rich. ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 P.S. My free live webinar is coming up in two days‚Ä¶ If you‚Äôre not signed up yet (and you want to learn how to make $10k/mo from one client) go here now. ‚Äã

subject: Most questions are stupid, here‚Äôs why
body:
The only dumb questions are the ones you don‚Äôt ask yourself (or ChatGPT) first.

 If there‚Äôs one trait that contributes to success above all others, it‚Äôs:

 Your figure-it-out-ability.

 There‚Äôs probably a much better word for that.

 But if you refuse to think for yourself, you will never win.

 Last night I was watching the new season of Dexter.

 There‚Äôs this billionaire midget in the show named Max.

 His assistant came to him complaining about being unable to complete a task he‚Äôd given her.

 In return Max said, ‚ÄúI hired you to make problems go away‚Ä¶ did I make a mistake?‚Äù

 She nodded and understood the assignment‚Ä¶

 Figure it out. 

 Treat your own life as if you have a billionaire midget boss who‚Äôll kill you if you disappoint him.

 Whoever said ‚Äúthere is no such thing as a stupid question‚Äù is a liar.

 There are plenty of them.

 I see DM‚Äôs and comments every day that would fall under that category.

 What makes a question stupid, is the complete outsourcing of critical thought.

 Let‚Äôs use the example question, ‚Äúhow do I do outreach?‚Äù

 Ask yourself‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúIf I were my prospect, what would pique my curiosity?‚Äù

 By simply pondering for a few minutes, you‚Äôre ahead of 80%.

 Only then should you consider your accessible resources.

 What videos can you watch about the subject?

 Is there an all-knowing, all powerful robot anywhere that might be able to help you out?

 Yes! There's this thing called ChatGPT.

 You can go to it and say‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs my goal, here‚Äôs the context, here‚Äôs what I think would be the best strategy.

 Analyze and critique my plan.‚Äù

 There you go!

 You‚Äôre now a 160 IQ giga-brained genius.

 All that‚Äôs left to do is take action.

 Act, get data, adjust.

 That‚Äôs how you ask smarter questions and get better answers.

 And when you pair the right strategy, with figure-it-out-ability‚Ä¶

 The world is yours.

 If you‚Äôve got the drive to think for yourself, tomorrow night at 7pm EST I‚Äôll give you the framework that makes the figuring-out part a whole lot faster.

 Spots are limited to 500 on this one ‚Äì lock yours in here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: Why my webinar will be waste of your time
body:
Tonight I‚Äôm giving you everything you need to get your first $10k/mo client. ‚Äã

 You‚Äôll know exactly who to pitch‚Ä¶

 Where to find them online‚Ä¶

 How to use AI to send 10/10 pitches in minutes‚Ä¶

 And it won‚Äôt matter at all.

 You won‚Äôt do anything with it.

 Once the dopamine high wears off after a few days, you‚Äôll quit.

 ‚ÄúBen, shouldn't you be telling me that it‚Äôs so simple and easy that anyone can do it?‚Äù

 Yes, I should be.

 And while the above is true, it doesn‚Äôt work that way.

 Your success is contingent on a separate element‚Ä¶

 Obsession.

 Jeff Bezos could dedicate the rest of his life to making you rich, but without obsession‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôd still fail.

 I know that probably sounds daunting ‚Äì especially when all you really want is some extra cash.

 But it‚Äôs actually quite simple.

 Obsession is the only thing that‚Äôll carry you through the process of growth.

 And the best part is, it takes life from black and white to color.

 Think back to a time in your life where you were obsessed with something.

 It could be as simple as a video game, the gym, a sports team, TV series, etc.

 Whatever it was, consider how you felt in that process.

 You thought about it constantly, studied it, lived it‚Ä¶

 That‚Äôs the feeling you need here.

 You must become a student of the game ‚Äì not just because of the goal, but because it makes you feel alive.

 So if you‚Äôre looking for the ‚Äúeasiest way to make money online,‚Äù this isn‚Äôt for you.

 You‚Äôll have a better chance gambling on meme coins or sports betting.

 But if you‚Äôre looking for a new reality‚Ä¶

 Where every day, the first thought on your mind is how you can move the needle forward‚Ä¶

 And you‚Äôre dying to fully commit to the pursuit of a goal‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã This can be the catalyst. ‚Äã

 If you‚Äôre ready, I‚Äôll see ya tonight at 7pm EST.

 If not, go place a futures bet on the Bengals to win the Super Bowl (literally free money).

 Ben

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }} we're going to Vietnam (CHC)
body:
I have another CHC (Certified Hood Classic) for you today -- originally sent Aug 15th, 2024. 

 If you don't like me, this is a good one to screenshot in case you ever need to get me canceled. 

 ‚ÄãSee you on the other side: 

 Good morning {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 I went for a run and then tried to meditate but it didn‚Äôt really work.

 Now I‚Äôm here, typing to you.

 I‚Äôm actually sitting at the desk in my ‚Äúoffice,‚Äù which is really just a den.

 Since I moved about three weeks ago, this has been the last area of my new apartment that still needs work.

 The lighting in here is kind of depressing and I have a bunch of random belongings on the floor.

 Because of this, I‚Äôve avoided this room.

 My phone is in the kitchen because I‚Äôve been really addicted to it recently.

 It‚Äôs cool that you can get rich and all from your fingertips but wow can that device be destructive.

 On my run earlier, I thought about what it must‚Äôve been like to be a young man who was shipped off to fight in the Vietnam war.

 Imagine you‚Äôre a 19 year old kid, fresh out of high school.

 You‚Äôre awakened in the middle of the night by Forrest Gump.

 He grabs you by the ear and takes you with him.

 Next thing you know you have an AK-47 in your hands and you‚Äôre shooting at anyone who has squinty eyes.

 What a turn of events, huh?

 All of the problems you had prior to being drafted have now vanished.

 You‚Äôre no longer worried about what career you‚Äôre gonna go into.

 You stopped thinking about what to say to the girl you have a crush on.

 And you couldn‚Äôt give a singular shit about the decor in home or clothes on your back.

 You now have one goal;

 Survive.

 If you‚Äôre reading this, I assume that the Vietnamese are not currently trying to blow your head off.

 What a lucky guy (or girl) you are.

 I‚Äôm in the same boat.

 And although this is obviously a privilege, it comes with consequences.

 Naturally, you want a war.

 You want a mountain to climb, and a communist to shoot at.

 But because life is relatively easy, you have to avoid the trap of getting caught up in bullshit problems so that you feel like you‚Äôre progressing.

 In other words, don‚Äôt stress about inconsequential things because you don‚Äôt have a life or death thing.

 You need to find your Vietnam war.

 Actually, let me rephrase that.

 You need to make your life the Vietnam war.

 Build businesses, go hard in the gym, nurture beautiful relationships, get famous, fight a homeless man (lol), travel the globe‚Ä¶

 Just do something.

 Preferably something that‚Äôs actually productive instead of worrying about things that have little impact on your life.

 That‚Äôs how you avoid becoming a Karen who gets mad at kids for skateboarding on the sidewalk.

 Or becoming a fat incel whose only joy is yelling racial slurs at the TV.

 Or even a manic 46 year old housewife who yells at the gardener because he missed a blade of grass.

 You need real(er) problems.

 Stuff that‚Äôs actually worth stressing about.

 And you‚Äôre likely not gonna get sent to Vietnam any time soon so you have to bring Nam‚Äô to you.

 You‚Äôre lucky. Don‚Äôt waste your luck. ‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. Let me know if you made it all the way down here, solider. If you liked this one -- and you're enjoying the CHC's I'll make it a weekly thing. Have a good weekend :)

subject: 5 years ago today, I almost quit
body:
It‚Äôs August 25th 2025.

 IT‚ÄôS AUGUST 25TH 2025!

 This year is flying by.

 Exactly five years ago today I started my ‚Äúsophomore‚Äù year of college.

 ‚ÄúSophomore‚Äù is in quotes because it was really a continuation of my freshman year based on credit hours.

 When you have a 1.1 GPA for a semester, I guess that really sets you back.

 But I knew I‚Äôd be out of there soon and mentally, I already was.

 I was only taking one class to keep my parents happy because it meant I was still enrolled.

 This gave me plenty of time to work on my ‚Äúbusiness.‚Äù

 Well, it wasn‚Äôt really a business yet but I was getting there.

 I was doing freelance videography, making about $1k per month ‚Äî which was an interesting phase.

 This was my ‚ÄúI finally found some direction but now I‚Äôm even more lost than I was before‚Äù era.

 But in between bong rips and frat parties, I was grinding.

 The only problem was that bong rips and frat parties were a frequent occurrence, so I wasn‚Äôt growing very fast.

 By the end of the year I was in peak shiny object syndrome form.

 Between juggling a dozen situationships in college and a dozen more in half-baked businesses, I was overwhelmed.

 I had a few videography clients, bought an SMMA course, bought a sales course, got an appointment setter role, and quit after a day.

 Here were my exact words from a journal entry on Jan 8, 2021:

 ‚ÄúFeeling a little defeated. More confused, and making less money than I did prior. Ugh. Maybe this online biz thing isn‚Äôt for me‚Ä¶ Maybe I was born to be a dreamer. Get stuck in the 9-5 with all these big ideas that never come to fruition. Maybe. Or maybe I just need to commit to something.‚Äù 

 That last line was wise, young Ben.

 My two main problems were:

 1. Although I was lost, life was still relatively comfortable. I didn‚Äôt feel enough urgency because of this.

 2. I lacked internal conviction. This made me continually find problems with each business model because in reality I didn‚Äôt believe in myself.

 If this sounds at all familiar, congratulations.

 You have entered the era that will likely determine the rest of your life.

 No pressure, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Looking back, here‚Äôs what I did that got me through it‚Ä¶

 The obvious answer is I finally picked one business model and stuck to it.

 But it was deeper than that.

 I had to become the person capable of the success I wanted.

 Small daily habits I adopted were a big reason I could do that.

 I journaled almost every day and treated each entry as a mini sparring session with myself.

 On January 27th, 2021, about a month before I got my first SMMA client, I wrote: 

 ‚ÄúBe the person who is becoming the person you want to be, and you will become the person you want to be. 

 Be the average person who wants to become great in the future, and you will stay the average person who wants to become great in the future.‚Äù 

 That first line might be hard to read, but here‚Äôs what I meant:

 Think like your future self, act like your future self, and you‚Äôll become them faster than you think.

 What habits do they have?

 How would they act in the situation you‚Äôre currently in?

 Get a clear picture.

 And today, choose to act like that version of yourself you‚Äôre aiming to become.

 Only then, will reality begin to catch up.

 Eventually you‚Äôll look back at your frat-boy-self with a 1.1 GPA and laugh at how far you‚Äôve come.

 But only if you start today. ‚Äã

 Happy Monday,

 Ben
