subject: Got caught in rain with homeless ppl
body:
Oh no.

 It‚Äôs finally happened.

 I‚Äôve run out of things to write about.

 12 minutes staring at this blank page and still nothing.

 Maybe the words will write themselves.

 The other day, I got caught in the rain.

 I was sitting outside the coffee shop and got distracted.

 A man picked up a piece of paper that someone littered and threw it in the trash.

 He was completely alone and I was the only person who saw.

 I was in awe.

 What a guy! If I did that, I'd at least make an Instagram reel about it.

 Or maybe wait until I‚Äôm walking with someone I want to impress.

 ‚ÄúWow you‚Äôre so thoughtful and kind for taking care of the planet!

 No bitch I just want to hit. 

 Hahahaha.

 A couple minutes later it started drizzling.

 Miami does this thing where it‚Äôll rain for a sec and stop five minutes later.

 I figured it would pass.

 I waited 5‚Ä¶10‚Ä¶ then 20 minutes.

 The light rain turned into a downpour.

 The weather app said it wouldn‚Äôt stop for another hour.

 I couldn‚Äôt just sit at the cafe all day. I had to get back to my desk.

 So I booked it.

 It was like the part of a romcom where the two main characters dance and sing in the rain.

 Except it was just me and homeless people, who were singing to the imaginary friends in their heads.

 I got back to my place after a few minutes, soaking wet.

 Then it stopped raining.

 Normally that would piss off but I kind of enjoyed it.

 I guess there‚Äôs a lesson in here.

 Run in the rain with homeless people.

 Or maybe the rainbow comes after the rain.

 Or the calm comes after the storm!

 I don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶

 Insert some corny quote that the 8x vaxxed 150 body health influencer chick would have in her Instagram bio.

 No lesson today ‚Äì unless you count, don't trust Miami weather and don‚Äôt wait for inspiration to strike.

 Just start moving (or writing).

 If you made it this far, you‚Äôre either entertained or bored and loyal.

 Either way, here‚Äôs the part where you buy from me. ‚Äã

 Will try again tomorrow,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 12 minutes staring at this blank page and still nothing.

subject: How to speedrun a $100k/mo info business
body:
No clever hook today, I‚Äôm in a rush.

 My good friend Jeremy Moser, who runs a $450k/mo info agency is graciously hosting a guest call in Artisan Lab in 30 minutes.

 So I‚Äôve gotta speedrun this email about how to speedrun an info business.

 On January 2nd of this year I got DM from this guy who said he had a successful blue-collar business and wanted to start selling info.

 He had no audience and no idea where to start.

 I gave him very simple direction and said ‚Äústart with short form on Tik Tok and IG.‚Äù

 And guess what?

 The guy actually listened.

 Four months later he started to get the hang of content.

 He only had 1,500 followers, but his videos were getting solid views and he was growing.

 I could see the potential and took him on as a client.

 Within a week we had everything built out.

 Lead magnet in the bio collecting emails, campaigns sending, structured the offer, etc.

 We launched three months ago.

 This month we‚Äôll make about $70k.

 Not bad for a guy who had never posted a TikTok before January.

 While it‚Äôs not an insane amount of money in the info world‚Ä¶ remember, this guy had no followers, no content, no offer, and no clue where to start.

 Fast forward to today, we will soon hit $100k/mo.

 So here are the steps we followed to spawn a soon-to-be 7-figure business:

 Content: Four months posting short form every day. 2-3x/day on TikTok. 1-2x/day on IG. Warm up: Lead magnet in the bio, built a list and started nurturing the audience further. Launch: VSL scripted and recorded, call funnel built, closer onboarded and ready. Break everything and fix it: We didn‚Äôt try to perfect the launch. We had the barebones in place for everything. Since then, we‚Äôve revised the VSL, the funnel cycled through closers and setters, adjusted the pitch, the offer, and so on.

 Now our backend foundation is solid and scaling to six figure months is mostly a matter of more traffic.

 If it sounds like I‚Äôm over simplifying it, I‚Äôm really not.

 All you need is traffic, a funnel, and an offer.

 God bless info.

 Okay I gotta get on this call ‚Äì Go here to see how we spawn seven figure info businesses from scratch. ‚Äã

 Bye,

 Ben

subject: Got lost in Chicago and now speak German
body:
I‚Äôm in downtown Chicago, sitting in a coffee shop that doubles as a bar.

 It looks exactly how you‚Äôd imagine.

 Dark walls, wooden tables, and barstools that look easy to pick up and swing at someone‚Äôs head.

 They‚Äôre playing Mr. Blue Sky on the speaker. Forgotten banger.

 It took me 22 minutes to get here, although it‚Äôs only a 3 minute walk from my hotel.

 I asked the receptionist ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the best coffee shop around here?‚Äù

 ‚ÄúJr√ºndgen ven‚Äù she said.

 She had a German(?) accent that seemed to only be thick when pronouncing the name of the cafe.

 I mostly understood the rest of her directions but wasn‚Äôt really paying attention because I was trying to make out what Jr√ºdgen ven was.

 She said something about going to the left and taking an elevator. I think.

 Drunken Bean!

 That‚Äôs what Jr√ºdgen ven means.

 Ok easy enough, I‚Äôll just put in my trusted google maps - no need for Nazi directions.

 2 minutes later I was at Drunken Bean.

 Well, my phone said I was. But unless it was hidden inside a fire station, the GPS was wrong.

 So I just started walking aimlessly.

 I figured I‚Äôd either finally find the elusive little bean (pun intended) or I‚Äôd stumble into a different cafe.

 After 15 minutes, I was basically back where I started.

 Just as I was about to give up and Uber to a different cafe, I looked to my right and saw‚Ä¶

 An elevator.

 It was practically glowing. Like when you find a gold scar in Fortnite.

 I didn‚Äôt know where it would take me or why it was on the middle of the sidewalk.

 But I knew I had to get in it.

 I put my faith in the elevator and finally a minute later the words, ‚ÄúIced latte with vanilla. Actually make it a double, bitch‚Äù came out of my mouth.

 So as I sit here, trying to extrapolate a lesson from this heroic journey, here‚Äôs what I got for ya:

 Just move ‚Äî even if you‚Äôre directionless.

 Your whole life was designed for you to think that you start with a map.

 Go through grade school, pick a major, stay the course‚Ä¶

 Internship, entry level job, marry the chubby 4, live the same day for 30 years, retire, and die.

 Sorry I‚Äôm being a harsh asshole.

 But if that sounds as miserable to you as it does to me, developing a high tolerance for uncertainty is your savior.

 If you want to carve your own path, you must accept that 90% of the time it‚Äôll feel like you‚Äôre running through a dark forest with a toothbrush as your defense weapon.

 You‚Äôll almost never be able to accurately predict what the next few years of your life will look like.

 Which is okay ‚Äì as long as you‚Äôre in motion.

 Just keep walking, turning, looking‚Ä¶

 And eventually your golden elevator will appear.

 See you at the Jr√ºndgen ven.

 Ben

subject: The easiest time of year to get rich
body:
Happy Labor Day {{ subscriber.first_name }}, I hope you‚Äôre laboring.

 I didn‚Äôt realize today was a national holiday until I got to the coffee shop.

 People who‚Äôd normally be frantically scootering to the office were just sitting there‚Ä¶

 Leisurely‚Ä¶ Enjoying their coffee.

 What the fuck.

 It‚Äôs Monday morning, shouldn‚Äôt they be asking for permission to go to the bathroom right now?

 That‚Äôs when I connected the dots and realized it‚Äôs a holiday.

 I promise I‚Äôm not this pretentious in real life.

 Well, at least not until I throw some feelers out there to figure out who I‚Äôm talking to.

 Only then do I let it fly.

 But since you‚Äôre on my email list, we're basically best friends already.

 Anyway, it‚Äôs crazy that we‚Äôre nearing the end of the year and the real holiday season.

 If you were reading my emails two Christmas‚Äôs ago, you might remember one titled ‚ÄúHolidays are for women, children and wagies.‚Äù

 That‚Äôs how I‚Äôve always felt.

 You can really only enjoy them if you‚Äôre pure enough to be excited about pretty lights, family time, and tradition‚Ä¶

 Or if you‚Äôre miserable enough that a two week vacation is the highlight of your year.

 I don‚Äôt fall into either of those categories unfortunately.

 But I do love this season for a different reason.

 September-December has always been my biggest growth window.

 First $15k month: November 2021 First $25k month: September 2022 First $100k month: September 2023 Something about this stretch puts pressure on you.

 You look up, realize the year‚Äôs basically over, and either feel like a lazy piece of shit‚Ä¶

 Or you lock in and cram 12 months of progress into the last 4.

 Q4 is the easiest time of year to make money.

 And right now, it‚Äôs Q4 eve.

 So if you‚Äôve been slacking, good news: doesn‚Äôt matter.

 You‚Äôve got 4 months.

 They‚Äôll decide how you look back on 2025, and how much momentum you carry into 2026.

 ‚Äã Let‚Äôs get to laboring. ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 P.S. If you're ready to lock in, here's what can happen:

 James hit his first $20k month (he was at $2k a few months ago).

 Jayden closed another client...

 ‚Äã And Alo closed an *inbound* client with some help from our referral network...

subject: How to go from good to great (CHC)
body:
Certified Hood Classic today -- originally sent June 25th, 2024. 

 **WARNING: This one might turn you into a super-genius. 

 Enjoy: 

 I cracked the code.

 It‚Äôs summer 2015.

 An hour in to a grueling basketball workout, my trainer makes a new rule.

 ‚ÄúIf the ball hits the rim it counts as a miss and you have to run sprints. Swishes only.‚Äù

 I think to myself ‚Äúthis mf crazy, I need a new trainer.‚Äù

 But I keep shooting, now aiming only for nylon.

 The ball hits the back of the rim and goes in. Doesn‚Äôt count.

 Front rim. Side rim. Rattles in off the glass.

 Doesn‚Äôt matter, I‚Äôm running.

 ‚ÄúThis is ridiculous. I‚Äôm literally making these shots and still being forced to run,‚Äù I complain to myself.

 But then something cool happens.

 I find the sweet spot and the ball stops hitting the rim.

 The way I‚Äôm shooting feels different now.

 I‚Äôm no longer just aiming for the basket.

 I‚Äôm aiming for a very specific part of the back of the net.

 I‚Äôm conscious of exactly how the ball has to leave my fingertips.

 Everything is incredibly precise.

 I‚Äôve reached a level of attention to detail and focus that I wasn‚Äôt accessing previously.

 This is the difference between good and great.

 It‚Äôs what keeps some business owners stuck at $10k, $50k, or $100k per month.

 It‚Äôs what causes tens of thousands of dollars worth of leads to fall through the cracks in a sales process.

 And it‚Äôs what created the opportunity for me to make 7-figures as a marketer for info-product businesses.

 I get paid to fill in the gaps.

 To improve the copy, or the sales process, or the video script.

 I bring a new level of attention to minor details and make an extra 6 figures a month for my clients.

 They pay me a percentage of it.

 This is how you win as a service provider for coaching business.

 Find the broken piece(s) of their business.

 Identify a solution using your critical thinking ability.

 Get paid.

 For example if an usually low amount of leads end up on sales calls, my job is to find the crack in the system.

 Maybe the email sequence sucks or there‚Äôs none at all.

 Maybe the leads aren‚Äôt getting dialed.

 Maybe the video sales letter is horrible.

 Maybe there‚Äôs a lack of congruence between the content and the messaging on the funnel.

 Whatever the problem is, the way to make money is to identify and fix it.

 Boom, now you‚Äôre a valuable piece to any coaching business.

 You‚Äôre turning good, into great.

 ‚ÄãCongrats, that‚Äôs how the money is made.‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. Learn how to identify & solve bottlenecks in coaching businesses by going here. And LMK if you liked this one :)

subject: Why you should shatter your phone
body:
I was playing catch with my phone yesterday.

 My goal was to throw it as close as possible to the ceiling without touching it.

 I had the accuracy of prime Aaron Rodgers.

 With each throw, I progressively got closer.

 There had to be less than a centimeter of space between my phone and the drywall.

 And then‚Ä¶

 I put too much power on it.

 My phone hit the ceiling and started wobbling down to me.

 It was spinning as fast as it was falling.

 I reached out and got a finger on it but couldn‚Äôt reel it in (not even prime Odell Beckham Jr. could‚Äôve caught it).

 It hit the porcelain tile, bounced, and landed face down.

 ‚ÄúFinally! It‚Äôs gotta be broken,‚Äù I thought.

 I picked it up and looked at the screen.

 To my surprise, it was in perfect condition. Not a single crack or dent.

 I sighed, put it in my pocket and got back to work.

 I was hoping it was damaged because then I‚Äôd have to get a new one.

 You might be thinking, ‚ÄúBen, I thought you were rich, can‚Äôt you just buy one?‚Äù

 The money isn‚Äôt the issue.

 It‚Äôs the friction that comes with it.

 Getting a new phone means transferring all my data.

 I know this can be simple, but what if something goes wrong?

 That would mean I have to make a visit to one of my least favorite establishments on Earth‚Ä¶

 The Apple store.

 I just hate everything about it.

 The lights, the people, the smell‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôd walk in, go up to one of the virgins at the ‚Äúgenius bar‚Äù and they‚Äôd say‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúSir you need an appointment‚Äù under their COVID mask.

 Then I‚Äôd have to wait 30 minutes for the little genius to finish teaching a grandma how to take a photo.

 Finally, buddy would waddle over to me and say, ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the issue, pal?‚Äù

 The first issue is my phone doesn‚Äôt work. The second issue is you calling me ‚Äúpal.‚Äù

 Then I‚Äôd wait for him to do whatever virgin witchcraft is necessary to set up my phone, and finally I‚Äôd be outta there.

 That‚Äôs just not an experience I‚Äôm willing to go through ‚Äì especially when my current phone is functional.

 That‚Äôs why I was hoping it was broken.

 Because only then, would the pain of doing nothing outweigh the cost of change.

 In life, it‚Äôs pretty easy to be comfortable.

 Even if you‚Äôre fairly miserable in your current situation.

 If you have food on the table, a girl above a 4 who lets you hit, and there‚Äôs football on TV‚Ä¶

 It‚Äôs not that bad, right?

 So despite the fact that you want to change, you‚Äôre not in enough pain to sacrifice the comfort.

 Such is life.

 This is typically the part where we come to a resolution.

 I give you some advice that wraps it all up into a positive light.

 But today, the answer doesn‚Äôt come from me.

 It comes from how much pain you‚Äôre willing to create for yourself.

 Maybe that means you intentionally destroy your life.

 Or perhaps you just needed to throw on a David Goggins video.

 Hope you can figure it out!

 ‚Äã I‚Äôll be here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: How to make "big" feel small (lol)
body:
$100,000 in one month.

 That number used to sound unattainable.

 I‚Äôd hear other people talk about it, but couldn‚Äôt conceptualize making it myself.

 Then I pivoted from SMMA to info.

 My first handful of clients sold online basketball training.

 In our biggest months, we made around $50k‚Äì$75k.

 That was their revenue not mine ‚Äì but being part of it made me realize that kind of money didn‚Äôt require solving world hunger.

 It was simpler than I thought.

 A little over a year later, I made $102,238 in one month (at 90% margins).

 I wasn‚Äôt some radically more skilled version of myself.

 But I was accustomed to seeing bigger numbers.

 The difference was my perception.

 Numbers only feel ‚Äúbig‚Äù until you spend time around people who make them feel small.

 When you see your idiot friend pull it off, you‚Äôre like‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúOh, if that retard can do it, maybe it‚Äôs easier than I thought.‚Äù

 This again leads me to why paying to join masterminds and communities is a must.

 I‚Äôll save you the full spiel ‚Äì but you can imagine how when Artisan Lab members see there‚Äôs a 16 year old kid in there making $10k/mo, it sounds a bit more feasible.

 It‚Äôs clear data indicating it‚Äôs possible.

 Yesterday I uploaded a video breaking down the four phases I went through to hit $100k/mo with an info agency.

 It‚Äôs a private recording from inside AL, and I don‚Äôt usually share these publicly.

 So if you want to watch it, check it out here. ‚Äã

 See you over there,

 Ben

subject: How to stop wasting so much time
body:
I once broke a world record.

 When I was in the beginning stages of my info agency, I‚Äôd spend almost all day at my desk.

 Outside of going to the gym, I basically never left.

 Although I was locked in, I found myself in a predicament.

 When considering what I actually accomplished each day, I could think of maybe one or two things.

 12 hours at my desk and I‚Ä¶

 Sent an email‚Ä¶

 Fixed an automation‚Ä¶

 Changed the copy on a headline‚Ä¶

 And uhhhh‚Ä¶ scrolled social media I guess.

 This shouldn‚Äôt take longer than an hour.

 Where did the other 11 hours of my day go?

 And how the fuck did I manage to not complete any of my highest priority tasks?

 I was a master at inefficient output.

 No one could spend as much time as me ‚Äúworking‚Äù without getting anything done.

 This is a discouraging feeling.

 A couple days ago, an Artisan Lab member told me this is exactly how he felt.

 He wants to be productive but‚Ä¶

 He‚Äôll get caught up doing random shit all day.

 One small task turns into a two hour job.

 A quick IG scroll turns into the sun going down. 

 Then he feels guilty for not being productive which leads to anxiety, and the cycle continues.

 If this sounds at all familiar, congratulations.

 You‚Äôre a normal human with normal emotions and obstacles.

 Here‚Äôs the advice I gave him:

 Stop being a pussy. 

 1. Make a clear daily routine with dedicated work blocks for different tasks. Highest priority tasks are first thing in the morning (duh).

 2. Use tools/apps to limit distractions. Put your phone in another room ‚Äì or lend it to a homeless man who‚Äôs instructed to only give it back if you give him $100 each day.

 3. Understand that your negative thoughts are not reality. When you take action instead of listening to them, they lose power over you (don‚Äôt be a pussy).

 4. Habits and rituals outweigh relying solely on willpower. Make ‚Äúdiscipline‚Äù easy ‚Äì give yourself a reward after completing tasks (i.e. after I send outreach, I will do crack).

 5. Focus on the feeling of accomplishment after completing difficult tasks, not just the tasks themselves.

 Boom.

 Two days after I gave him this advice, he said ‚ÄúGuys outreach is fking easy‚Äù and closed a new client:

 ‚Äã If you‚Äôre tired of breaking my record for most hours wasted in a day, go here and I‚Äôll fix it with you inside Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 Have a good weekend,

 Ben

subject: How sports betting made me a better entrepreneur
body:
My name is Ben Bader and I‚Äôm an addict.

 Over the past four days, I‚Äôve placed a total of 24 bets on NFL football.

 Yes, twenty four.

 I‚Äôm what experienced sports bettors would call a ‚Äúsquare.‚Äù

 A square is defined as ‚Äúa casual bettor who follows gut feelings, popular opinion, or media hype rather than doing sharp analysis.‚Äù 

 Bingo!

 The online betting platforms love me.

 If you want to know exactly what you shouldn‚Äôt do, just look at their advertising.

 All popular sportsbooks heavily promote parlays ‚Äì A parlay is a single bet that links two or more wagers together.

 Meaning for you to win, multiple things have to occur.

 It's higher risk, but on the odd chance that you effectively guess correctly, it‚Äôs a thrill.

 Just imagine‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôre sitting on the couch watching a game you normally wouldn‚Äôt give a shit about.

 There‚Äôs two minutes left.

 One team‚Äôs leading by 17, so it‚Äôs basically over anyways.

 But not for you, you piece of shit degenerate.

 You bet on the Texans third string wide receiver to have over 2 receptions.

 It‚Äôs the last leg of your parlay.

 All you need is number 81 to catch one more inconsequential pass and you‚Äôll turn $100 into $925.

 It would make up for the 12 other bets you placed that missed today.

 Your eyes are glued to the TV.

 The Texans run the ball.

 ‚ÄúWhy the fuck are you running the ball!? You‚Äôre down 17 with a minute 24 on the clock!‚Äù you yell, somehow not knowing they can‚Äôt hear you.

 And then, with 19 seconds left in the game, it happens.

 The quarterback throws the ball across the middle to number 81 for 7 yards.

 It‚Äôs a meaningless play, the clock runs out, and the Texans lose.

 But it meant everything to you.

 That single catch means you‚Äôre not only back to breakeven, but you‚Äôre in the green!

 One event made up for all of your losses.

 Business is the same way ‚Äî especially in the beginning.

 Most days it‚Äôs just pain.

 One loss after another, your hard work is unrewarded, you want to quit‚Ä¶

 But then‚Ä¶

 After 3 months of sending outbound messages with no luck, you get a banger client.

 After posting 150 videos that flop, you go viral and it explodes your business.

 After approaching 7,321 women in the street, one finally doesn‚Äôt run away.

 You need to adopt the mindset of the addicted gambler.

 They will not stop.

 The hole will get deeper and deeper‚Ä¶

 Until one day‚Ä¶

 ‚Äã One win makes up for everything. ‚Äã

 TOUCHDOWN!

 Ben

 P.S. This is not an endorsement of sports betting. If you‚Äôre gonna gamble, only do so with a sum you‚Äôre comfortable losing.

 P.P.S. Justin Jefferson any time TD, Caleb Williams O 218.5 passing yards, Rome Odunze any time TD (not financial advice).

subject: 9 yards short
body:
I did something irresponsible.

 At the very bottom of yesterday‚Äôs email, I gave you a parlay.

 The odds on it were +1200 ‚Äì Meaning $100 wins you $1,200 if it hits.

 There were three legs to it.

 Two players needed to score touchdowns and the Bears QB needed to throw for at least 219 yards.

 Going into the 4th quarter, neither player had scored.

 Three minutes later, touchdown Justin Jefferson.

 One down, two to go. Still improbable.

 Then with just two minutes left in the game, Rome Odunze scored.

 Oh shit.

 I‚Äôd sort of given up on the bet by halftime but it looks like it might hit.

 Those two legs were the underdogs.

 The bet with the highest statistical probability was the only one left.

 With just 5 seconds to go, Caleb Willliams is 17 yards shy of the magic 219 number.

 Sooo you‚Äôre saying there‚Äôs a chance‚Ä¶

 The Bears have one play to go the length of the field.

 They snap the ball, Williams throws for 8 yards.

 The ball gets lateraled to a different player who runs for another 13.

 That‚Äôs 21 yards!

 Game over, parlay hits‚Ä¶

 Right?

 Uhhh, no.

 Officially, Caleb only gets credit for 8.

 Lateral yards don‚Äôt count for passing stats.

 So he finished the game with 210 yards.

 Just 9 short of the magic number that would‚Äôve turned our $100 bet into $1,200.

 That‚Äôs the painful beauty of a parlay.

 Being ‚Äúclose‚Äù yields you nothing means nothing.

 You can‚Äôt carry any momentum into the next bet.

 But in business, you can.

 When you‚Äôre nine yards short in business, it means you‚Äôre learning.

 Your outreach is sharper.

 Your content is starting to hit.

 You‚Äôre stacking reps and getting closer to gold.

 Every near miss is just proof that you‚Äôre on the right track.

 Keep going‚Ä¶

 And go here if you want me in your corner.

 Ben

subject: Advice from our founding fathers
body:
I got lost in an Instagram reel vortex yesterday.

 You know when you go to check your phone for ‚Äúa minute‚Äù and three hours later you‚Äôve been hypnotized by the algorithm?

 Same.

 I stumbled on this niche where some dude stands outside filming random people.

 I don‚Äôt know his name but 90% chance it‚Äôs Kyle based on his appearance.

 Obviously nobody likes being filmed, so it sparks heated interactions.

 Cops show up, Kyle refuses to answer questions, eventually they leave.

 Then he turns the camera on himself and says something like:

 ‚ÄúHeLl yEaH! I OwNeD tHeM!‚Äù

 The point was to ‚Äústress test‚Äù the 1st amendment, Freedom Of The Press.

 It‚Äôs not illegal to film in public.

 And Kyle really wants to make sure people know that.

 I‚Äôm no founding father, but they‚Äôre probably rolling in their graves watching this shit.

 ‚ÄúI gave ya‚Äôll all these rights and this fuckin idiot decides to spend his time ragebaiting boomers. I‚Äôd rather you do OnlyFans or blackhat MRR!‚Äù ‚Äì James Madison

 This is what happens when ambition doesn‚Äôt have a positive outlet.

 Everyone wants to feel like they‚Äôre doing something.

 That‚Äôs why people get lost in sports, politics, or Kyle‚Äôs ragebait niche.

 Choose your obsession wisely.

 Do you want to be a guy in an Ohio suburb with fucked up teeth spending your days filming strangers?

 Do you want to be a purple haired gender activist with 17 cats?

 Or do you want to get rich on the internet and build an amazing life for yourself and the people around you?

 I‚Äôll take option number three.

 The time‚Äôs gonna pass anyway.

 You might as well obsess over something that yields the highest quality of life.

 If you‚Äôre gonna be addicted to anything, let it be building skills that print money.

 ‚Äã I‚Äôll teach you here. ‚Äã

 Back to scrolling,

 Ben

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }} - let's compromise (CHC)
body:
‚ÄúIf you believe in something, you need to have the courage to fight for those ideas ‚Äî not run away from them or try and silence them." - Charlie Kirk 

 Rest In Peace, Charlie. 

 On the topic of courage, today's email is a Certified Hood Classic originally sent April 3rd, 2025 

 Enjoy: 

 Fair and noble people make compromises.

 Life is not like Burger King.

 You can‚Äôt always have it your way‚Ä¶

 Fuck. That.

 This way of thinking is for the mentally enslaved.

 But you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, as a reader of the best newsletter on the internet, deserve better‚Ä¶

 You owe yourself better.

 When you‚Äôre quick to make compromises, here‚Äôs what happens:

 Your Ferrari dreams turn into a Corolla (or perhaps you buy a corvette C8 when you‚Äôre 68 and try to convince yourself it‚Äôs a real supercar).

 Your supermodel wife turns into a plus sized hand model. Or your ‚Äúrich husband‚Äù turns into a guy that makes $105k/yr and loves to say he makes six figures.

 Your dream of waking up to the sound of the waves crashing on the shore only happens 3 days a year. And you‚Äôre on vacation in Myrtle Beach, not Honolulu.

 I know this sounds a bit dramatic, but making compromises when it comes to your desires is a slippery slope.

 You need to be militant.

 You need to be stubborn.

 You need to aim for what you actually want.

 When others tell you to be reasonable, or when you begin to hear a voice in your head negotiating with you, shut it out.

 I‚Äôd rather be an insane, unreasonable, stubborn asshole than a chubby balding middle aged man‚Ä¶ in a COROLLA!

 Do not tolerate behavior that doesn‚Äôt align with your goals.

 When you make a plan, stick to it as if you are following orders from God.

 There is no negotiating, there is no settling, and when you find yourself exchanging ‚Äúgreat‚Äù for ‚Äúgood enough,‚Äù stop yourself.

 If you compromise, I guess I‚Äôll send you a postcard from Honolulu.

 That‚Äôs basically the real thing isn‚Äôt it! LOL!

 No. Stop.

 It‚Äôs not the real thing. And a C8 isn‚Äôt a supercar. And fuck Mrytle Beach.

 Their rules and standards are meant to be broken. Yours aren‚Äôt.

 See you in a Ferrari with a supermodel in your passenger seat.

 To the stubborn and unreasonable ‚Äì I will help you win. ‚Äã

 Nature loves courage,

 Ben

 P.S. I‚Äôd feel slightly irresponsible by not clarifying some nuance here.

 Not compromising doesn‚Äôt mean you refuse to turn up the temperature when you set it at 67 and your girl wants it at 72.

 It also doesn‚Äôt mean that there is only one way to accomplish a goal and the route can‚Äôt be adjusted.

 But when it comes to the real shit you want‚Ä¶

 Don‚Äôt let anyone talk you out of it (including yourself).

 ‚Äã This is for those who refuse to compromise. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã
‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: Bread, circuses, and misery
body:
‚ÄúGive them bread and circuses and they will never revolt.‚Äù - Juvenal

 Juvenal had a point.

 I spent all day yesterday on the couch watching football.

 Sufficiently fed and distracted‚Ä¶

 Until I wasn‚Äôt.

 You see, this Juvenal fucker never experienced the misery of being a fan of an ‚Äúalmost‚Äù team.

 A team that sucks for years, finally turns it around, but someway, somehow‚Ä¶

 They always find a way to fuck it up.

 I‚Äôm a closeted Cincinnati Bengals fan.

 It‚Äôs my biggest normie vice.

 They moved to 2-0 on the season yesterday‚Ä¶

 But there‚Äôs a big problem.

 Their star quarterback ‚Äî the most important position in football ‚Äî likely needs surgery on his toe.

 A fucking toe.

 At worst his season is over and at best he limps back with a few games to go in the year.

 So Mr. Juvenal, ‚Äúnever revolt‚Äù you say?

 That‚Äôs where you‚Äôre wrong.

 If I were a 32-year-old making $73k/yr at a corporate job in Cincinnati, with football as my only escape?

 I‚Äôd be storming Paycor Stadium right now with pit stains in my button-down.

 Some poor bastard is sitting in a cubicle at 9:57am on a Monday morning, down horrendous.

 Fortunately that‚Äôs not my reality.

 While I‚Äôm bummed, my life doesn‚Äôt rise and fall with Joe Burrow‚Äôs toe.

 My time, freedom, and energy are mine.

 And I get to click buttons on my laptop from a Miami penthouse, with my dream car in the garage‚Ä¶

 While making six figures a month in profit.

 Could be worse, I guess.

 No torn ligament can take that away.

 If you don‚Äôt want your whole year hinging on someone else‚Äôs toe‚Ä¶

 I just made a new video where I‚Äôll show you how I‚Äôm using AI to build 7-figure info businesses. ‚Äã

 Talk toemorrow.

 Sorry that was a bad Dad joke.

 Bye,

 Ben

 P.S. I‚Äôm coping.

 No amount of money can make up for this.

 Season‚Äôs over. My life‚Äôs in shambles. At least the NBA season is starting soonish.

 Maybe I should become a Ravens fan instead.

 Maybe I should go on a meditation retreat.

 Maybe I should move to Bali and eat bugs.

 Maybe you should stop reading this and instead watch this video. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: I'm lazy
body:
It‚Äôs so easy to be lazy.

 Like why would I be productive, when being lazy is so much easier?

 That‚Äôs the question‚Ä¶

 Laziness is sort of like sleeping with hookers.

 It feels good in the moment but you‚Äôll soon be disgusted with yourself.

 Although sometimes, that‚Äôs exactly what you need‚Ä¶

 I‚Äôve never been a 5am, cold-shower, rigid-routine type of guy.

 But I work relatively hard.

 And every so often, I just don‚Äôt want to do anything.

 Usually I snap out of it by telling myself:

 ‚ÄúStop being a bitch. Do you want to be poor? No? Okay, grow up and do the work.‚Äù 

 That works 9 times out of 10.

 But sometimes I‚Äôd rather sit in a middle seat between two Lizzo‚Äôs than power through it.

 That‚Äôs when I turn to ‚Äúlazy-maxxing.‚Äù

 I give in.

 For a few days to a week, I let the laziness win.

 I experience the thrill of rebuilding an NFL team on Madden, playing a full season in one day, and seeing my guys lift the Lombardi.

 Hormozi could never.

 But after a brief period of being a bum, I hate myself so much that I reset.

 I become more conscious of all the little things‚Ä¶

 Waking up earlier, taking walks, less scrolling, and so on.

 Then I go back to work, reinvigorated.

 Now, I‚Äôm not encouraging this strategy.

 There are probably many better ways to fix yourself.

 And there‚Äôs a 90% chance that you simply need to be more disciplined.

 But if you really just can‚Äôt muster up the ambition to get shit done‚Ä¶

 Maybe try lazy-maxxing. (I‚Äôm not liable if you get addicted to drugs or prostitutes).

 Just don‚Äôt stay there too long.

 The reset only works if you channel it into something productive.

 Here are some non-lazy winners inside Artisan Lab: ‚Äã

 Lloyd's first $10k month (only halfway through September)...

 ‚Äã Khesraw made $20k from one client...

 ‚Äã Jayden closed a whale client...

 ‚Äã ‚Äã Join them here. ‚Äã

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

subject: Re: your first 5 figure client
body:
One of the hardest things you‚Äôll ever do in business is switch vehicles.

 Especially when your current vehicle is ‚Äúworking.‚Äù

 I remember when I was stuck at $15k-$20k/month with my SMMA.

 That business allowed me to drop out of college, save up six figures, and have complete time/location freedom.

 But it was a constant headache.

 Just the thought of scaling it gave me anxiety.

 So I stayed half-in, half-out for almost a year.

 I was too nervous to shut it down, and didn't have the clarity to go all in.

 Eventually, I pulled the trigger.

 I started to get info-product clients, realized it was way better, and the rest is history.

 Now we‚Äôre here.

 And over the past 6 months, I‚Äôve watched one of my Artisan Lab members go through a similar transition.

 This is Lloyd:

 ‚Äã Fun fact: His name is actually Michael but when he was pledging a fraternity everyone said he looked like Lloyd from the show Entourage.

 I guess he liked that name better so he ran with it.

 Anyway, he had a cool gig working as a videographer for SteveWillDoIt.

 He was paid well and that job provided a pretty sick lifestyle.

 But he wanted to build his own thing.

 So he joined AL and decided to get some info-product clients.

 Within about 6 months, he hit his first $10k month outside of videography:

 ‚Äã If scaling feels impossible, it might just be time for a better vehicle.

 That‚Äôs exactly what Lloyd realized.

 And it‚Äôs the same thing I‚Äôll be breaking down for you live this Wednesday at 7pm EST.

 I‚Äôm running a free webinar on how to land your first $10k/month info client and start building something that actually scales.

 ‚Äã Sign up here. ‚Äã

 See you Wednesday,

 Ben

subject: Why, {{ subscriber.first_name }}? (CHC)
body:
Certified Hood Classic for you today -- Originally sent Dec 12, 2024 

 Before we get into it, go here to sign up for my free live training this Wednesday. 

 Alrighty, enjoy: 

 The other day, a member in Artisan Lab told me that he was having trouble staying motivated.

 He asked me, ‚ÄúWhat's your why?‚Äù (meaning the deeper motivating purpose that drives me to succeed).

 Here‚Äôs my answer:

 When I first started in online business, I just wanted to make money.

 Not having to work a 9-5 sounded cool.

 Traveling sounded cool.

 Having the freedom to create my own schedule sounded cool.

 My ‚Äúwhy‚Äù was mostly made up of self-serving factors.

 I didn‚Äôt have to rescue my family from poverty and I didn‚Äôt have a grand vision to save endangered turtles.

 I wanted money because it looked fucking sick.

 And the idea of clocking in and out for the better half of my life sounded wayyyy less sick.

 Sickening, if you will.

 Furthermore, I had this feeling in my gut that you‚Äôre likely familiar with.

 It‚Äôs the feeling that told me that I couldn‚Äôt live a dull life.

 I‚Äôd try to suppress it sometimes, but it never worked.

 I simply knew that if I didn‚Äôt take a chance and at least attempt to gain full agency over my life, I‚Äôd be absolutely miserable.

 I‚Äôd rather end up homeless.

 So when I looked at it that way, there was one glaringly obvious option‚Ä¶

 Build the life that I actually wanted to live.

 Not for anyone else. Not for a greater purpose. But for me.

 I wanted to escape the inevitable future pain of mediocrity.

 Is that selfish? Sure.

 But had I deluded myself into believing that I needed a stronger ‚Äúwhy,‚Äù perhaps I never would‚Äôve started.

 I could‚Äôve rationalized, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not motivated and I can‚Äôt work because my life is decent as it is.‚Äù

 Don‚Äôt let Simon Sinek (author of It Starts With Why ) fool you.

 Your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù can be ripping an SVJ through the Hollywood hills.

 Your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù can be having the autonomy to wake up at noon every day.

 Your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù can be club-hopping in Ibiza with a bunch of ungrateful models.

 My point is stop worrying about your fucking ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and make money.

 Do you want to be miserable?

 Do you want to be poor?

 Do you want to be an incel?

 No?

 Okay! Then what the fuck else are you gonna do with your time? Lol.

 Eventually, your motivating factors will naturally evolve.

 Once you check off the superficial desires, perhaps your focus will shift to retiring your parents, setting up future generations, or saving the Goddamn turtles.

 But right now, you probably don‚Äôt care much about any of that.

 If you‚Äôre honest with yourself, you just don‚Äôt want to worry about spending money.

 And that‚Äôs completely fine.

 You don‚Äôt need to find some moral justification to stay motivated.

 It‚Äôs okay to want something, simply because you want to prove to yourself that you can get it.

 ‚Äã Ready to get rich now? ‚Äã

 See you at the top,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: 9,131 days on Earth distilled into one lesson
body:
I‚Äôm getting old.

 Today I turn 25.

 Despite my senior citizen status, I still don‚Äôt have chest hair.

 I also don‚Äôt know how to spell the word ‚Äúrestaurant‚Äù without auto-correct and I can‚Äôt change a tire.

 I thought these things would be programmed into me by the time my brain was fully developed.

 Guess I was wrong.

 However, I‚Äôve learned a few things that may be useful to you.

 And because it‚Äôs my birthday, I feel obligated to distill 9,131 days on Earth into one lesson.

 That‚Äôs a lot of pressure.

 Ummm‚Ä¶

 Wear a rubber and don‚Äôt get in the car with female Uber drivers. 

 Sorry that was mean, let me try again:

 Five years ago, I was starting my sophomore year of college.

 I‚Äôd made $1k that month as a freelance videographer but felt directionless.

 In my journal I wrote in all caps:

 ‚ÄúIDK WHAT I WANNA DO BUT I CAN‚ÄôT DO NOTHING.‚Äù

 That sentence beautifully articulates a constant battle we all face:

 The tendency to drift.

 I remember sitting in my dorm, debating between taking a bong rip or going down a YouTube rabbithole.

 I thought about my life at 25.

 Either I take control now, or I wake up in a reality I didn‚Äôt choose.

 A job I hate. No motion. And a Toyota Corolla.

 That night, I chose the bong rip and pushed this existential crisis to tomorrow.

 That was a dangerous decision I made more times than I should‚Äôve.

 But luckily I snapped out of it.

 I‚Äôve wrestled this tendency to drift for years.

 And I won just enough times to get me here.

 So I guess my lesson for you today is this:

 You don‚Äôt have to be perfect.

 You don‚Äôt have to sacrifice everything.

 And you don‚Äôt even need a David Goggins poster on your wall.

 You just need to notice when you‚Äôre misaligned ‚Äì and have the courage to do something about it.

 Those moments when you hear that voice inside ‚Äì that‚Äôs a breaking point.

 It first whispers, ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt what you want. What are you doing?‚Äù

 Ignore it long enough and it yells‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúWake the fuck up!‚Äù

 If you hear that voice, you‚Äôre one of the lucky ones.

 You haven‚Äôt let the world beat the light out of you yet.

 But it‚Äôs up to you to follow it.

 So here I am.

 Twenty-five, no chest hair, still spelling ‚Äúrestaurant‚Äù wrong.

 But I‚Äôm grateful I listened to that voice in my head a few times more than I ignored it.

 Because those few decisions compounded into the life I get to live now.

 If you take anything from this ramble, let it be this:

 Your intuition is a compass.

 Most people bury it under weekends and half naked women on social media.

 If you can keep yours alive and actually act on it‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôll end up somewhere worth being.

 Here‚Äôs to the next 9,131 days.

 Ben

 P.S. This Wednesday at 7pm EST I‚Äôm running a free live training where I‚Äôll show you how to use AI to land, operate, and scale with info-product clients.

 Instead of stacking tiny retainers, you‚Äôll learn how to close clients that can pay you $10k+/mo.

 ‚Äã Register here. ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: Info is the only business left
body:
Before we get into it, my free live training is tonight at 7pm EST. ‚Äã

 Sign up here if you haven‚Äôt already.

 Alright pitch over, let's dive in‚Ä¶

 Everybody wants to sell info.

 Why wouldn‚Äôt you?

 It‚Äôs one of the simplest, highest margin businesses on earth.

 You live your life, record videos, and people send you money.

 All the benefits of OF without showing your tits.

 But there‚Äôs a problem:

 Info is a privileged business.

 You have to earn your way in.

 Sure there are some successful grifters‚Ä¶

 But most of the time, if you‚Äôre not really good at what you‚Äôre teaching ‚Äì you won‚Äôt last.

 So if you‚Äôre an early stage entrepreneur, you likely have no ‚Äúknowledge‚Äù to sell.

 And the actual ‚Äúbest business model online‚Äù isn‚Äôt feasible for you.

 That‚Äôs why the Info-Agency model just makes sense.

 Over the past few years, I‚Äôve watched nearly all of my agency/sales friends transition to it.

 Because once you see how much money is flying around the info space, you realize there‚Äôs no comparison.

 Why would you beg boomers for little retainers for your ‚ÄúAI Agency‚Äù (SMMA)...

 When you could just plug into a business that already has unlimited demand, proven offers, and an audience ready to buy.

 Stop cold emailing dentists.

 Start slinging info.

 Info is the top of the food chain, and the only way to get in early is by running the backend for people who already have the leverage.

 ‚Äã I‚Äôll break down exactly how to do it tonight at 7pm EST. ‚Äã

 See you there,

 Ben

subject: I'm officially a guru
body:
One million dollars.

 I used to think that was ‚Äúnever-have-to-work-again‚Äù type of money.

 I guess it can be if you want to live modestly.

 But me?

 Noooo.

 I‚Äôm far too pretentious and egotistical to settle for a measly $1m.

 Last week, I got this stupid little plaque in the mail:

 ‚Äã It‚Äôs the Clickfunnels Two Comma Club award.

 When you make $1m using their software, they graciously let you pay them $500 to get one of these.

 They built their entire business off this thing.

 The software sucks.

 It has random bugs, it‚Äôs incredibly limited, and the funnels just look scammy.

 But everyone seems to accept that it‚Äôs part of the game in pursuit of the guru plaques.

 This is my second one with my name on it ‚Äî though the first was for a client who was nice enough to throw me on there.

 But this one is just me.

 I remember the first time I met someone with a 2CC award.

 It was this guy I was working with on a basketball training offer.

 Every time we‚Äôd hop on Zoom, I‚Äôd see this shiny plaque sitting behind him on the wall.

 At the time, I was aiming for my first $20k month.

 I couldn‚Äôt even imagine making $1m in a year.

 That award felt like the pinnacle of success.

 Fast forward a few years and now I‚Äôve got two of them.

 Like most arbitrary milestones, neither feel like I thought they would.

 That‚Äôs just how it goes.

 You work really hard chasing what you think you want, only to get there and realize it‚Äôs not all it‚Äôs cracked up to be.

 I guess what‚Äôs cooler than this plaque are the lives changed in its pursuit.

 I‚Äôve helped 18 year old kids make their first $10k online.

 Just the other day Joao, one of our earliest members sent me this message:

 ‚Äã He lives in Portugal, joined with very little experience, and is now hitting $14k/mo.

 On top of that, nine members of Artisan Lab have hit their first $100k months.

 And in early November I‚Äôm hosting my first ever in person mastermind, exclusively for AL members. ‚Äã

 We‚Äôll have a couple dozen info-agency owners at the PH for a two day info-bender.

 Now that is pretty cool.

 Meanwhile I‚Äôll throw this award in the closet to collect dust next to its counterpart.

 To slinging info,

 Ben

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

 ‚Äã

subject: (1) Ben messaged you
body:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}, what‚Äôs wrong? You barely touched your webinar discount + bonuses. ‚Äã

 It‚Äôs been two days now‚Ä¶

 This is usually the part where I start pulling on your heart strings.

 I‚Äôve written so many emails like this for my clients that it‚Äôs second nature now.

 First I would reward you for taking the initial action (coming to the webinar).

 Then I would bridge to the problem‚Ä¶

 ‚Äú95% of people will do nothing with the information I showed you the other night.‚Äù 

 And I‚Äôd dig that pain a bit so you feel it‚Ä¶

 Here‚Äôs a direct quote I write in all post webinar sequences for my clients:

 ‚ÄúYour life will become a perpetual cycle of "almost." 

 You'll almost start a business. 

 You'll almost approach the pretty girl. 

 You'll almost become the person you know you can be. 

 But you won't. 

 You'll be stuck watching videos about how to make money, how to improve your relationships, and how to stop your lingering anxiety... 

 Because knowledge means NOTHING without the appropriate action.‚Äù 

 Did that make you feel any pressure?

 If so, go here and apply to join me inside Artisan Lab. ‚Äã

 If not, keep reading.

 You‚Äôre a skeptic.

subject: How to buy a $10M mansion (Tutorial)
body:
I‚Äôve started a bad habit.

 Well, I have many bad habits.

 But this is a new one. And it actually isn‚Äôt all bad.

 53 minutes ago, I sat down to write this email.

 That means what you‚Äôre reading right now is 53 minutes worth of work.

 On my way here, I got distracted by something shiny‚Ä¶

 Zillow. 

 Do you know $5m in Miami Beach gets you?

 A mansion on the water.

 Butler included.

 And playboy models feeding you grapes!

 Just kidding.

 For 5 MILLION DOLLARS‚Ä¶

 You can get a shack.

 You‚Äôll have to share this shack with four homeless people.

 They don‚Äôt bite but you have to feed them occasionally and put a needle in their arms regularly.

 I‚Äôm only half kidding.

 You can get a nice place for $2-$5m.

 It‚Äôs not the type of house where you‚Äôd walk in and hear an echo as you say ‚Äúwowwww!‚Äù

 But it‚Äôs cute.

 You only enter ‚Äúwow‚Äù territory if you spend around $10m+.

 I feel poor.

 ‚ÄúWell Ben, you don‚Äôt need a mansion in Miami, you can get a beautiful place in Kansas for $1.5m!‚Äù Blah blah.

 I don‚Äôt wanna live in Kansas.

 So I guess my lesson for you today is:

 If you want to stretch your relationship with money, go to Zillow.

 Pick your dream location and look at some houses.

 This will likely result in you considering how you can accumulate a lot more money a lot quicker.

 Then ‚Äì once you‚Äôve had your existential crisis ‚Äì start an AI lead gen agency for dentists.

 Close every dentist in your state for $1k/mo.

 Take that money straight to the casino.

 Put it all on black.

 If it hits, congrats.

 You can now almost afford a shack in Kansas.

 See you in Miami Beach.

 Ben

 P.S. If you don't wanna live in a shack, go here. ‚Äã

 P.P.S. If you made it all the way down here, reply and lmk :)

subject: How to turn a bad idea into a good email
body:
Good morning, happy Monday.

 We‚Äôre gonna try a fun experiment today:

 You and I are gonna write this email together.

 If it sucks, it‚Äôs your fault.

 If it‚Äôs great, it was all me.

 Ready?

 Alright‚Ä¶

 On my walk back from the coffee shop, I came up with the lesson for this email.

 It‚Äôs kind of basic, so we‚Äôre gonna have to dress it up.

 The core message I want to articulate is this:

 To get what you want out of life, you simply have to ask for it.

 Well, and you have to work towards it.

 Oh‚Ä¶ and you can‚Äôt be a complete idiot.

 This idea sucks.

 We sound like if Mark Manson had a baby with a reformed hoe who turned into a self-improvement podcaster.

 I don‚Äôt think you can say hoe in an email {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "bro" }}, that‚Äôs offensive.

 We should delete this.

 No, no.

 We just need to start off with a story.

 You: Got anything? 

 Uhhh I guess the other night when I was at dinner.

 Go on‚Ä¶ 

 They tried to seat me with the poor people.

 You can‚Äôt say that. 

 Sorry, they tried to seat me on the terrace and I wanted to be in the main dining room.

 Okay‚Ä¶? 

 I said to the GM ‚Äúhey brother, any chance you can move us to the main dining room?‚Äù

 He said ‚Äúlet me check,‚Äù and walked to the host stand.

 20 seconds later he took us to our new and improved table.

 And then what? 

 Uhh that‚Äôs it.

 That‚Äôs your whole story? 

 Yes.

 And you think we can write an email about that? 

 Well, it‚Äôs deeper than that ‚Äì we just have to explain it to the reader.

 How so? 

 When you want something, you don‚Äôt settle.

 You don‚Äôt buy the Corvette C8 when you really wanted the Ferrari F8.

 You don‚Äôt stop following up with the prospect until they tell you to fuck off.

 You don‚Äôt accept a life that‚Äôs ‚Äúgood enough.‚Äù

 Sure, sitting on the terrace would've been fine.

 They‚Äôll still bring us the same food.

 The atmosphere is almost as good.

 But it‚Äôs not what I wanted.

 So I asked.

 And sometimes, that‚Äôs all you need to do.

 Winners don‚Äôt settle.

 That's the whole lesson ‚Äì it‚Äôs simple, obvious, and easy to forget.

 But you might just settle your way into a life you didn‚Äôt want.

 Would ya look at that! We turned a shitty idea into a decent email.

 Good work, my friend.

 To building a life we actually want, ‚Äã

 Ben

 ‚Äã

subject: From zero to $10k/mo in 67 days
body:
‚ÄúYou can easily go from zero to $10k/mo in 90 days!‚Äù

 Bullshit.

 For a complete beginner, there‚Äôs about a 90% chance it takes you 6+ months ‚Äì- no matter what business model you choose.

 The 0-$10k/mo phase isn‚Äôt about finding the ‚Äúright vehicle.‚Äù

 It‚Äôs about upgrading from neanderthal to modern human.

 Before $10k/mo you‚Äôre effectively a toddler.

 To become a grown adult, you need new habits, new skills, and new thoughts.

 That‚Äôs a lot of change to cram into 90 days.

 Sorry to burst your bubble.

 However, there are some outliers.

 Every now and then, someone will come into Artisan Lab and just ‚Äúget it‚Äù right away.

 The best way I can describe their mentality is this:

 They accept the fact that they feel like they‚Äôre in over their head but they refuse to let that stop them from taking action.

 Obviously when you start something new there‚Äôs a lot you don‚Äôt know.

 Instead of trying to learn everything at once, get a baseline understanding as fast as possible‚Ä¶

 Then jump in the deep end.

 When you do that, you might just stumble your way into money a lot quicker than you thought.

 Just like Shaeis did:

 ‚Äã He joined Artisan Lab exactly 67(!) days ago. Yes, six seven.

 Since then, he hit his first $10k month.

 He had zero previous experience.

 I wish I could take full credit for his success but I can‚Äôt.

 Sure I gave him a roadmap‚Ä¶

 5 weekly coaching calls.

 Countless hours of course content.

 1-1 support, a community full of winners, and everything he could possibly need to hit $10k/mo as fast as possible.

 But he was the one who executed.

 I can‚Äôt take credit for that.

 The 90-day $10k promise is highly unlikely.

 But Shaeis proved it can happen.

 He didn‚Äôt wait until he felt ready.

 He got in the game, took consistent action, and figured it out.

 That‚Äôs the difference.

 If you want a shot at being one of those rare outliers, you can join us here. ‚Äã

 Talk soon,

 Ben

subject: The single trait that makes money inevitable
body:
I have a friend who‚Äôs a little autistic.

 I don‚Äôt mean this in a negative or derogatory way.

 But it‚Äôs this ‚Äúrainman-like‚Äù advantage that‚Äôs made him rich.

 Yesterday, we were sitting at lunch.

 He had his back to the street as a car with a loud exhaust went by.

 Without turning or seeing the car, he said ‚ÄúSVJ.‚Äù

 It was indeed a Lamborghini SVJ.

 Two minutes later, he blurted out ‚ÄúPorsche 911 Turbo‚Äù as one went by ‚Äì again without turning around.

 He can do this for hours.

 It‚Äôs like when Steph Curry shoots and turns around as the ball goes through the net.

 Pure conviction.

 Not coincidentally, he‚Äôs made a lot of money with a car rental business.

 The same thing goes for crypto.

 He‚Äôll go on 20 minute spiels about some random niche crypto shit that I don‚Äôt understand.

 But he knows it like the back of his hand.

 Also not coincidentally, he‚Äôs made a lot of money in crypto.

 ‚ÄúEvery time I follow my curiosity, I end up stumbling upon an opportunity.‚Äù ‚Äì I just made this up but it sounds like something Warren Buffet would say.

 That line pretty much sums him up.

 He goes deep into whatever fascinates him and the money is almost a side effect.

 Nearly every successful person I‚Äôve ever met is incredibly curious.

 That‚Äôs the cheat code.

 When you‚Äôre obsessed, you naturally put in the hours, notice the details, and see opportunities that others don‚Äôt.

 Over the past six months, I‚Äôve watched an Artisan Lab member go down this journey of obsession.

 His name is Khesraw.

 He lives in Afghanistan ‚Äì not exactly the place you‚Äôd imagine you can build a business online.

 But his curiosity for copywriting and funnels pulled him down the rabbit hole.

 Last month he made $27k in profit from just one client. ‚Äã

 The client is in the fitness niche, one of the hardest industries to scale.

 Yet since joining Artisan Lab, he‚Äôs applied what he‚Äôs learned to push their business past $200k/month‚Ä¶ and he gets paid on a rev share.

 $27k.

 One client.

 From Afghanistan.

 If you want to feel bad about yourself (and learn a thing or two), watch his interview here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }}: Permission Granted
body:
It‚Äôs 8:59am in Beverly Hills.

 I‚Äôm sitting at a Starbucks next to my hotel.

 I don‚Äôt know how people operate on Pacific time.

 The second I opened my eyes, I felt behind.

 Time to catch up.

 I‚Äôm looking out the window and thought I just saw a dog driving a car.

 Then he pulled forward and it turns out he was on his owner's lap.

 Another guy wearing AirPods just walked by and seemed to be in an argument with whoever he was talking to.

 Imagine trying to explain this to a caveman.

 ‚ÄúYeah so that person isn‚Äôt schizophrenic, he‚Äôs actually talking to someone on the phone.‚Äù

 Caveman: ‚ÄúWhat the fuck is a phone and why is there a dog steering a flying metal box?‚Äù

 Ok anyway, you‚Äôre here to learn something ‚Äî and so far I‚Äôm just wasting your time.

 Who am I kidding?

 You don‚Äôt need my advice.

 You don‚Äôt need anyone‚Äôs advice.

 The life you‚Äôre looking for can only be accessed when you source conviction internally.

 That doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôll make perfect decisions but at least you‚Äôll be the one in the driver's seat.

 So let‚Äôs use this email as a reminder:

 When you get some time today, audit the way you‚Äôre living your life.

 Are you in alignment with the direction you want to go in?

 Or does something need to change?

 Just think about that one for a bit.

 Odds are, you already know what to do.

 You‚Äôre just waiting for permission.

 Let‚Äôs stop doing that.

 Alright, I gotta stop people watching and go do something productive.

 If you‚Äôve been stuck in a ‚Äúwaiting for permission‚Äù phase, I can help you here. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: If you don't know where to start, do this (CHC)
body:
Certified Hood Classic for you today -- Originally sent Dec 6, 2024 

 Enjoy: 

 ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where to start.‚Äù

 Sound familiar?

 I was combing through Artisan Lab applications this morning and found a theme.

 There‚Äôs a question that asks applicants to share any roadblocks they‚Äôre facing.

 Around 90% of the answers are long-winded variations of ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where to start.‚Äù

 Whether it‚Äôs picking a business model, starting outreach, or creating content‚Ä¶

 Everyone finds a scapegoat as to why they aren‚Äôt taking action.

 Perhaps a better way to describe this dilemma is ‚ÄúI want to be told where to start.‚Äù 

 You feel stuck because you have an abundance of options and you're not doing anything about it.

 Any business model can work.

 Any style of content can garner attention.

 Any outreach method can get you a client.

 But instead of trying something and seeing if it works, you convince yourself that you need more information.

 You‚Äôre left in a perpetual cycle of looking for more information rather than actively creating data that steers you in the right direction.

 One thing I know for sure is that everything that‚Äôs ever been created was done so from scratch.

 Someone, like you, didn‚Äôt know where to start.

 They tried something and it probably didn‚Äôt work the first time.

 So they tried a different method, now with more data.

 They do this over and over until they‚Äôve crossed off many of the ‚Äúwrong‚Äù answers.

 In doing so, they came closer to the answer‚Ä¶

 And then it clicks.

 Action creates clarity.

 The route to success is found after knifing through tens, hundreds, or even thousands of routes that don‚Äôt directly lead you to where you want to go.

 But they continuously reroute you until you arrive at your destination.

 And the once ‚Äúdirectionless‚Äù version of you ceases to exist.

 I can‚Äôt tell you with full certainty what will work for you.

 Neither can anyone else.

 We‚Äôre all different people with various natural advantages and inclinations.

 That‚Äôs life.

 The ones who are rewarded are those who act despite the fact that there is no universal rulebook.

 You just gotta start moving and trust that you‚Äôll find the answers while you‚Äôre running the race.

 There‚Äôs no way around this truth.

 ‚Äã Trust yourself, and you‚Äôll be rewarded. ‚Äã

 Ben

subject: The only guarantee I‚Äôll ever make
body:
‚ÄúIn this world nothing can be said to be certain, except death and taxes.‚Äù - Benjamin Franklin

 Nothing‚Ä¶ really?

 Mr. Franklin, you're telling me that the 18 year old billionaire can‚Äôt actually guarantee I‚Äôll be driving a Lambo in three months?

 What a scam.

 Guarantees on coaching programs are like marrying a girl you met at the club.

 They sound pretty and look good.

 But one day you‚Äôll realize that you overlooked the stipulations and this thing‚Äôs got problems.

 The majority of money-back guarantees in the info-product world are fake.

 They‚Äôll say, ‚ÄúHit $10k/mo in 90 days or you don‚Äôt pay!‚Äù

 What they don‚Äôt say is the laundry list of conditions.

 You have to complete 72 modules, post 43 times, and sacrifice your firstborn.

 99% of people won‚Äôt qualify ‚Äì and that‚Äôs the point.

 To be fair, some risk-reversals are legit.

 But I‚Äôve stayed away from guarantees on Artisan Lab because they attract the wrong kind of people.

 I can guarantee that if you show up consistently and do the work, it‚Äôs likely you‚Äôll get results.

 I can also guarantee if you do nothing, you will remain where you are now.

 That‚Äôs about it.

 However‚Ä¶

 There is one archetype that I can almost guarantee success.

 Nearly every time this certain type of person buys from me, it‚Äôs like they hit a 10 leg parlay.

 Phillip hit $100k/mo in 4 months.

 Dean hit $27k/mo in 3 months.

 Modjadji and Javi hit $30k in 6 months.

 The commonality is that all of these guys came from a sales background.

 Let me show you what that looks like in real life.

 Yesterday, I interviewed our newest name on the list of successful closers turn operators ‚Äì Kareem.

 He joined AL June 13th, making about $7-$10k/mo as a closer ‚Äì spending 8 hours a day on the phone.

 His goal was simple: get off sales calls and make more money.

 After two weeks in the program, he began outreach using the strategies we teach inside.

 And exactly 42 days after he joined, he got his first client:

 ‚Äã In just two months, he 5x‚Äôd that business‚Ä¶

 And made over $30k from his rev share.

 Without taking sales calls all day.

 ‚Äã ‚Äã Watch the full interview with Kareem here. ‚Äã

 Death. Taxes. And closers becoming successful operators.

 Ben

 P.S. The price of Artisan Lab is increasing in about a week.

 I‚Äôll share more details soon, but if you want to lock in the lowest rate, now‚Äôs the time to move. ‚Äã

subject: They're robbing me blind
body:
I might be the worst sports bettor of all time.

 Without exaggeration I‚Äôm around a 10% hit rate over the last two weeks.

 This means I‚Äôm losing 90% of the time ‚Äì which I guess is impressive in its own right.

 But last night, I took a safe bet.

 The Eagles were favored by 7.5 points on the road against the Giants.

 That‚Äôs a big spread, meaning they were heavy favorites.

 Rightfully so‚Ä¶

 It‚Äôs the defending Superbowl champions, playing against a rookie quarterback.

 Philly is 4-1. New York is 1-4.

 The New York Giants haven't won a Thursday night football game in TEN years‚Ä¶

 Until last night.

 Not only did they win‚Ä¶

 But they won by 17 points. 

 Seven. Teen.

 And once again, I lost money.

 Sports betting and business are similar in some ways.

 You risk your dollars to hopefully get more dollars in return.

 If you can predictably turn just $1 into $2 at scale, you‚Äôll soon be rich.

 My goal with the people who invest into Artisan Lab is to do exactly that.

 They give me their hard-earned money and I help them turn it into much more.

 Apparently it‚Äôs working a little too well‚Ä¶

 I got this message from Lorenzo the other day:

 ‚Äã He paid me and then told me I undercharged him.

 And that was before a recent addition:

 Sanjay, who manages roughly $1M/month in ad spend, just joined as our newest coach.

 We now have coaching calls every weekday‚Ä¶

 And by next week, Sanjay will have finished a brand-new paid ads course that‚Äôs being added to the program.

 So, a week from today -- October 17th at 11:59PM EST -- the price is officially going up.

 If you‚Äôve been waiting for a sign, this is it. ‚Äã

 Here's your chance to go back in time and bet on the Giants money-line last night‚Ä¶

 Where $1 would‚Äôve turned into $3.40.

 ‚Äã Apply for Artisan Lab here. ‚Äã

 Ben

 P.S. If you‚Äôre ready to join and would rather skip the call, just reply to this email. I‚Äôll personally answer any questions and get you in at the current price.

subject: I was amost a normie
body:
The more I sit still, the faster I die.

 I‚Äôve had one panic attack in my life.

 Let me rewind about five years and I‚Äôll tell ya about it:

 I‚Äôm a pledge in a fraternity.

 My entrepreneurial desires have been buried under frat parties, vodka, and bong rips.

 Turns out that shit works wonders ‚Äì especially if you‚Äôre trying to convince yourself the normal path isn‚Äôt all bad.

 I‚Äôm having a blast‚Ä¶ as long as I don‚Äôt think too much.

 Because when I start thinking, that‚Äôs when I start questioning‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúWhat happened to your dreams, Ben?

 Where‚Äôs the version of you who didn‚Äôt want to settle‚Äì‚Äù

 ‚ÄúBader, we have a party on Saturday, make sure you‚Äôre inviting girls.‚Äù

 My fraternity brother said, snapping me out of my moment of introspection.

 Then I took a bong rip.

 Although I was smoking regularly, this one felt different.

 I was about to learn that weed and suppressed dreams are a bad combo.

 The best way I can describe what happened over the next couple hours is this:

 I felt trapped in my own body.

 Every negative thought I disregarded over the previous few months hit me at once.

 My mind and body were screaming at me‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúYOU‚ÄôRE GOING IN THE WRONG DIRECTION YOU IDIOT!‚Äù

 I curled up into a ball in my dorm room and slept it off.

 When I woke up, I wish I could tell you I got to work.

 But that would be a lie.

 This was one of many warning signals I got during this era.

 It‚Äôs like I was living in an internal civil war.

 My dreams were fighting against the lies I told myself in an attempt to bury them:

 ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know where to start. 

 You don‚Äôt know what route to pick. 

 You don‚Äôt know what you don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶‚Äù 

 Stagnation was killing me.

 But finally, I woke up.

 I started following my curiosity.

 One rabbit hole led me down the next.

 And even though I felt like I was in over my head, I kept moving.

 Next thing you know, I‚Äôm on zoom call pitching someone on a service I learned two days prior.

 That was a stepping stone. And it allowed me to get where I am now.

 Had I never overcome those thoughts that attempted to paralyze me, I wouldn‚Äôt be here.

 So if you‚Äôre sitting there overthinking, wondering if it‚Äôs ‚Äúthe right time‚Äù ‚Äì it‚Äôs not.

 It never will be.

 And that‚Äôs the point.

 You move first, clarity comes after.

 Here‚Äôs your excuse to start moving today‚Ä¶

 The price of Artisan Lab is going up this Friday at 11:59pm EST.

 If you want to get access to the same system others are using to hit multi-5 figure months (see the P.S)...

 Join here before the price goes up. 

 Ben

 P.S. Some recent big wins over the past few days‚Ä¶

subject: Is Artisan Lab beginner friendly?
body:
Is Artisan Lab beginner friendly? 

 Someone replied to yesterday's email with that question.

 Here‚Äôs my answer:

 Beginner friendly ‚Äì yes.

 Idiot friendly ‚Äì no.

 Shaeis has been our fastest complete beginner (without any previous agency or sales experience) to hit $10k/month.

 It took him 67 days.

 He came into AL and just got it .

 He networked his way to a few clients within a month.

 He said yes to things he had no idea how to do.

 And had enough confidence to know he‚Äôd figure it out.

 Most people aren‚Äôt like him.

 If you‚Äôre brand new, it‚Äôll likely take you a month to get a basic understanding.

 Then another month to actually feel confident in your skillset.

 And then you‚Äôll probably spend 2-3 months trying to sabotage yourself.

 You‚Äôll half-ass your outreach, lack discipline, and think about starting a different business instead‚Ä¶

 But if you don‚Äôt quit after months 4-6, a turning point is near.

 By then you'll have confidence in your skillset and know it‚Äôs just a matter of consistency.

 You‚Äôll commit to showing up every day‚Ä¶

 And soon enough the dominoes will start falling.

 That‚Äôs typically how it goes for beginners -- with any business model.

 The first 4‚Äì6 months are about building the foundation and reprogramming your mind not to quit or get distracted.

 But I promise you, the longer road is just as rewarding.

 Tomy joined AL back in July of 2024 with zero experience.

 Ten months later he hit $10k/mo.

 ‚Äã Today, he‚Äôs making his clients $62k on a single webinar, traveling the world and creating content.

 It took Ergun just six months to go from complete beginner to his first $10k month:

 ‚Äã The point is, yes -- Artisan Lab is beginner friendly.

 But you have to bring effort, humility, and a willingness to learn.

 Plus you can't be an idiot who quits after sending one outreach message.

 If you can do that, we can teach you everything else.

 The price goes up in a few days... if you're waiting, now‚Äôs the time.

 Apply here. 

 Ben

subject: The hardest decision I made in business
body:
In 2022, I went through a bad breakup.

 I had to look this girl in the eye and say‚Ä¶

 ‚ÄúI‚Äôm too good for you now.‚Äù

 She was my ride or die.

 She watched me drop out of college, move across the country, and truly become an adult.

 But I had to kick her to the curb.

 This ‚Äúgirl‚Äù was my marketing agency for local businesses.

 We had a lot of firsts together.

 First client.

 First $10k month.

 First $100k saved.

 But in 2022, I realized we no longer aligned.

 I‚Äôd outgrown her.

 Still, I stayed longer than I should‚Äôve.

 And because of that, I hit an income ceiling for nearly a year.

 Eventually I realized I was being an idiot and started replacing my local clients with info product clients.

 Here‚Äôs what happened to my income:

 April 2022 - I made $5,100 with 7 clients.

 July 2022 - I made $16,000 with 6 clients.

 And by December, I made $31,000 with 5 clients.

 I should‚Äôve left that bitch earlier.

 Nine months later I hit $100k/mo and bought my dream car in November 2023.

 Since then, I‚Äôve watched many of my friends discover the same gold rush.

 Phillip ‚Äúbroke up‚Äù with his sales job to partner with info businesses.

 He hit $100k/mo in less than a year.

 Sean (now a coach inside Artisan Lab) quit his SMMA to partner with info businesses.

 He‚Äôs worked with Charlie Morgan, Joel Kaplan, and just closed a $1M/month client on webinars.

 Sanjay went from running eCom brands and trading sports cards to partnering with info businesses.

 This weekend, he got a trophy at Jeremy Haynes‚Äô mastermind for scaling his client to $1M/month through ads and is taking home over $100k/month in profit.

 On Friday, Sanjay‚Äôs paid ads course is going live in Artisan Lab. 

 With that, the price of the program is increasing.

 Current members get it for free.

 But if you wait, you‚Äôll be paying more.

 Join here before the price goes up in 2 days. 

 Ben

subject: The fastest $30k I ever made
body:
‚ÄúHow fast can I make money?‚Äù 

 That‚Äôs such a silly question that everyone always asks ‚Äì myself included.

 But today, I‚Äôll entertain it‚Ä¶

 The fastest money I ever made put $30k in my pocket in 3 weeks.

 It‚Äôs May, 2023.

 I‚Äôm sitting in my 1 bedroom apartment with Sanjay, gambling on horses.

 Each of the past three months I‚Äôve made just shy of $50k.

 In between losing our bets, Sanjay shows me an Instagram story.

 A luxury jewelry dealer with a massive following is launching a coaching program.

 I kid you not, this guy put his Venmo on his story to start selling it.

 No sales page, no application funnel, and no social proof‚Ä¶

 Just his Venmo handle.

 Clearly he has zero idea how to monetize his six figure audience.

 Perfect.

 Sanjay and I do some digging.

 A minute later we find his phone number (it was literally on his jewelry business website).

 We call. His assistant answers.

 I can‚Äôt remember exactly what we said but it was something along the lines of:

 ‚ÄúHey we‚Äôre not actually interested in buying jewelry from you but we saw you‚Äôre starting coaching. We run marketing and operations for info-product businesses.‚Äù

 Somewhat surprisingly, it went well.

 The assistant told us they were looking for someone to help.

 A few hours later we got on zoom with the assistant and the main personal brand guy.

 We pitched him on building out the whole launch.

 Sales page, webinar, backend tech and set up.

 $15k plus 10% of cash collected.

 He says yes ‚Äì but we only get paid (including the set up fee) once everything's built out.

 Let‚Äôs do it. If we get scammed at least it‚Äôll make a good story.

 We sprint to build everything.

 Two weeks later it‚Äôs launch day.

 We make $50k from one post and a couple emails.

 Another $100k over the next few days.

 And just like that, a $30,300 wire was sent to my bank account.

 22 days from the time we cold called him to the time we got paid.

 That‚Äôs fast money.

 Will that happen for you?

 Probably not. At least not right away.

 But the only reason it could happen for me was because I‚Äôd found the right vehicle ‚Äì the same one that allowed:

 Yahya to make $75k in a single month from his first client.

 Khesraw to go from $500/mo with 10 clients to $30k/mo from one (while living in Afghanistan).

 Kareem, who hit $36k/mo in three months.

 You can join the winning team here‚Ä¶ 

 Or wait until the price increases tomorrow night at 11:59pm.

 Up to you :)

 Ben

subject: Ran out of time
body:
I just started a timer.

 It‚Äôs been one of those phases where I inefficiently time travel.

 Every day is flying by.

 I write an email, get coffee and my day is over.

 So timing myself here is an effort to fix that.

 Awareness plus action seem to be the remedy for most problems.

 Become aware of the problem and what creates it.

 Take action in an effort to solve it.

 Simple.

 But this isn‚Äôt just limited to productivity issues.

 This little recipe will fix your whole life.

 If you don‚Äôt like the direction you‚Äôre going in ‚Äì become aware.

 Not just that you don‚Äôt like it, but what will happen if you don‚Äôt change?

 What habits aren‚Äôt serving you?

 What beliefs are limiting you?

 What daily actions can you take to move in a positive direction?

 Once you get this stuff down, congrats.

 You‚Äôre already further along than most people.

 Now you just have to execute.

 And that‚Äôs the hard part.

 When I‚Äôm trying to be more productive or instill a new routine, I follow one corny ass principle:

 Make it easy. Make it fun. 

 That sounds like a slogan for a condom brand.

 Discipline only takes you so far, but systems can carry you for miles.

 It‚Äôs kind of like being an NFL quarterback.

 Even if you‚Äôre a great player ‚Äì if you're not in the right scheme talent only goes so far.

 But an average player in the right scheme‚Ä¶

 He can win a Superbowl ‚Äì like Jalen Hurts and the Eagles last year.

 Build systems so you don‚Äôt heavily rely on how you feel

 That‚Äôs where the awareness in step one really matters.

 It‚Äôs not about journaling or overanalyzing your childhood trauma.

 It‚Äôs just figuring out what‚Äôs not working, then building systems that make the right thing easier to do.

 Audit > adjust > execute.

 And just like that, I‚Äôve spent 27 minutes cosplaying as James Clear here so I gotta go.

 But before I do:

 Artisan Lab‚Äôs price goes up tonight at 11:59pm EST. 

 If you book a call before then, you‚Äôll still be locked in at the current rate.

 If you don‚Äôt, I will send the mafia after you. 

 Clocks ticking ;) 

 Ben

 P.S. If you‚Äôd rather skip the application and call process, go here instead to get pricing.

body:
There‚Äôs a popular saying in real estate:

 ‚ÄúLocation, location, location.‚Äù

 A house on the water in Malibu is worth exponentially more than the same one sitting in the slums of Chicago.

 Why?

 Because it‚Äôs in a more desirable area.

 ‚ÄúNo shit, Ben. Now why the hell are we talking about real estate?‚Äù

 Good question, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 In the info-product world, the equivalent phrase would be:

 Social proof, social proof, social proof.

 Two businesses can sell the same offer with identical deliverables‚Ä¶

 But the one stacked with testimonials wins every time.

 Proof is the most valuable asset you can have. It shows your prospects that people just like them are winning.

 Let me tell ya about a few:

 James joined AL in December 2024 with zero experience in the info space.

 Eight months later, he‚Äôs at $20k/mo, and got his biggest client through a direct intro from me.

 Three days in, he landed a $5k/mo client + 16% rev share.

 Two months later, he made that client $600k, and Yahya pocketed $75k+ profit.

 Jace came in over a year ago, pivoting from SMMA.

 I‚Äôve seen him hit $20k/mo... Then $50k/mo.

 And now six-figure profit months, consistently.

 These are just a few of the dozens of wins inside.

 If you‚Äôre on the fence, hopefully they give you the conviction to take the leap.

 You have until tonight at midnight before the price goes up.

 Apply and book a call before then to lock in the current rate.

 Or click here to see what‚Äôs inside and join directly.

 Social proof, social proof, social proof.

subject: This isn't for you
body:
I‚Äôm gonna write this one for me.

 Content gurus tell you not to do this.

 They say, ‚Äúmake content for the audience! If you don‚Äôt tell them what‚Äôs in it for them, they won‚Äôt listen.‚Äù

 There‚Äôs truth to that statement.

 But like anything in life, if you don‚Äôt enjoy the process you‚Äôll lose to someone who does.

 I‚Äôve always wanted to avoid making content I don‚Äôt like.

 I cringe at the creators who fall into this trap.

 Every video becomes a string of sentences arranged to get people to buy their shit.

 They use those corny AI-looking thumbnails and start to sound like everyone else.

 That‚Äôs because they‚Äôre only making content for the audience.

 The best creators find the balance between making what their audience wants ‚Äì and what they want.

 And ironically, that‚Äôs what resonates the most.

 This lesson that applies to everything else in life:

 If you‚Äôre only doing something for the end result ‚Äì sales, views, or validation ‚Äì you‚Äôll eventually burn out.

 But when you do it because you want to, because you love the craft‚Ä¶

 That‚Äôs where you find magic.

 You build for the sake of building.

 It‚Äôs how you quiet the voice in your head that‚Äôs screaming at you to express yourself.

 When you try to please everyone, you lose yourself.

 And when you finally stop trying, you start to sound like you. 

 So sure, this one‚Äôs for me.

 But if you‚Äôve ever caught yourself over-optimizing for what others want instead of following your own curiosity‚Ä¶

 Maybe it‚Äôs for you too.

 Happy Monday,

 Ben

 P.S. The price of Artisan Lab officially increased.

 We also just added 3+ hours of new paid ads training from Sanjay, so if you‚Äôre inside already‚Ä¶ you got a good deal.

 If not, this is still a steal.
