subject: Become a construction worker
body:
I got cinnamon and honey in my coffee today.

 What an elite combo that I‚Äôve been sleeping on for far too long.

 Anyway I have something to complain about.

 Everywhere I go in Miami, all I hear is:

 ‚ÄúBzzzzzzz clank clank bzzzzzzzzzz.‚Äù

 Then it stops for a sec.

 And then ‚ÄúBZZZZZZZZZZZZZZ!‚Äù

 That was my impression of a drill.

 The construction is absurd.

 There‚Äôs a new building going up on every block.

 They‚Äôre all named after a random luxury brand with ‚Äúresidences‚Äù on the end.

 Dolce Gabbana Residences.

 Mercedes-Benz Residences.

 Cipriani.

 E11EVEN.

 Imagine visiting your friend and he‚Äôs like:

 ‚ÄúYeah bro I live in the Chrome Hearts Residences.‚Äù

 To which you respond, ‚ÄúOk sick I‚Äôm right by the Gucci Tower, see you in 5!‚Äù

 That‚Äôs basically what‚Äôs happening.

 From my balcony, I have a birds-eye view of one of these projects.

 When I moved in about six months ago, it was maybe 15 stories.

 Now it‚Äôs gotta be close to 30.

 Every day these guys show up with hard hats and drills.

 They do the same tedious work, floor by floor, day after day.

 It looks insanely repetitive ‚Äì but they‚Äôre building stories fast.

 Business is quite similar.

 You show up and do a few redundant, boring tasks.

 If you can resist the urge to get distracted or start working on a different project‚Ä¶

 Eventually your tower will be complete.

 This is a lot harder than it sounds because your mind is typically not your friend.

 You‚Äôll get bored halfway up, convince yourself another project will be faster, and start over from scratch.

 Don‚Äôt do that.

 90% of the time, the problem is not the business model ‚Äì it‚Äôs you.

 YOU don‚Äôt have the discipline to be consistent when novelty fades.

 If you were actually a construction worker, you‚Äôd get deported.

 Sorry that was insensitive.

 But act like a good construction worker.

 Drills. Hammer. Nails. Cat call women on the street.

 Tower complete.

 I‚Äôll help you build your Residences here. 

 Ben

subject: Proof you‚Äôre closer than you think
body:
I cold plunged yesterday.

 It was my first time in a while.

 Once upon a time, cold plunging was my entire personality ‚Äì for about two weeks.

 I‚Äôd scoff at people who‚Äôd never endured the piercing feeling of submerging their body in 45-degree water.

 ‚ÄúWhat a normie, skinny fat, soy-boy loser,‚Äù I thought.

 But for the past couple years, I‚Äôve rarely done it.

 Until yesterday.

 And ironically this time, I was the normie, skinny fat, soy-boy loser.

 I was at this spa with a cold plunge right next to a hot tub.

 I figured I‚Äôd start off with a few minutes in the cold, then move to the heat.

 Four seconds later I was running out of the water.

 I imagine this is how they felt on the Titanic ‚Äì except my experience was worse.

 Time for a new strategy.

 I got in the hot tub for a few minutes, then went back to the cold.

 This time, it worked. I lasted about 5x longer.

 The only problem was 4 multiplied by 5 is still only 20 seconds.

 This pissed me off.

 I used to sit in that damn tub for 10-15 minutes without flinching.

 So for the next half hour, I went back and forth between the two.

 I could only last about a minute in the cold.

 Each time, I thought I‚Äôd be fine once the first 30-second shock wore off

 Each time, I was wrong. 

 Alright, one more attempt‚Ä¶

 I submerged into the frigid water telling myself:

 ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve done this before.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúThe pain will subside, just breathe.‚Äù

 ‚ÄúIf you get out you‚Äôre gay.‚Äù

 That last one really got me.

 A minute in, I‚Äôm fine.

 Two minutes in, still chillin.

 Three minutes in, it feels like a hot tub.

 I stayed in that bitch ass water for the next five minutes.

 Now, I know you‚Äôre thinking, ‚Äúwowwww Ben you‚Äôre so fucking sick dude!‚Äù

 Thank you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Here‚Äôs the real reason I‚Äôve told you this silly little story:

 I only accomplished the goal because I knew I could.

 I‚Äôd done it before ‚Äì meaning I had previous data indicating it was possible.

 That‚Äôs why I was so stubborn.

 I didn‚Äôt want to fail at something that I knew I could do.

 So my question for you is:

 If you knew that you couldn‚Äôt fail, would you ever quit?

 Probably not, right?

 Your success is guaranteed.

 It might take three months.

 It might take a year.

 It might take five years.

 But if you just keep getting back in that cold ass water‚Ä¶

 Eventually it‚Äôll feel normal.

 People just like you have done it ‚Äì it‚Äôs your turn. 

 Ben

subject: This part sucks
body:
‚ÄúI‚Äôve got nothing for you, just keep doing what you‚Äôre doing.‚Äù

 I said this to an Artisan Lab member on a 1:1 call yesterday.

 We‚Äôll call him Joe.

 Joe already has a handful of clients and closed three new deals this month alone.

 He‚Äôs sending 10+ quality pitches per day and it‚Äôs clearly working.

 Despite this, he‚Äôs not making that much money‚Ä¶

 Yet.

 None of his clients are whales.

 He‚Äôll close a deal, get a $2-5k setup fee‚Ä¶

 And then start undoing all the shit they were doing before.

 It can take time to tear a business down and rebuild it the right way.

 Because of this, Joe isn‚Äôt making much from his rev shares.

 What an annoying spot to be in.

 Every time you get a client, it feels like you‚Äôre blue-balling yourself.

 You think, ‚Äúthis is the one! We‚Äôre gonna make millions together.‚Äù

 Then you realize, ‚Äúohhhh, there are a lot of problems we‚Äôll have to fix first.‚Äù

 But here‚Äôs the good news:

 Joe is doing everything right.

 He‚Äôs closing solid clients who are able to pay him setup fees.

 (which is important because it means he‚Äôs not working with broke retards). 

 He‚Äôs inches away from a big win ‚Äì as long as he doesn‚Äôt get distracted.

 Here‚Äôs what I told him:

 1. Maximize everything you can with your current clients.

 Go above and beyond to get the best results possible.

 Your goal right now is to find the winners you can scale with long term.

 2. Keep doing what you‚Äôre doing on outreach.

 Don‚Äôt stop getting new clients until you have clear winners.

 3. Be aggressive ‚Äì but patient.

 By that I mean understand you‚Äôre the epitome of that three feet from gold meme.

 You‚Äôre swinging the hammer over and over.

 You know the gold has to be back there somewhere.

 But you don‚Äôt know which swing will be the breaking point.

 The only thing you can control is how aggressive you swing.

 So if you‚Äôre in a similar spot to Joe...

 You‚Äôre working hard, doing the right things, but getting a bit discouraged‚Ä¶

 You‚Äôre probably a lot closer than you think.

 You don't need to change what‚Äôs working -- you need to double down until the dam breaks.

 Here‚Äôs what happens then:

 ‚Äã Just keep going.

 And if you want my personal help making the image above your reality ‚Äì go here. 

 Ben
